reviews.review: Humbling & Breathtaking. I absolutely loved this visit, the history, the sentiment, the stories, the layout and the sights and sounds. Definately worth a visit.
Wonderful. It was really delightful and peaceful to walk around the gardens and seeing the temple dedicate to Confucius, so interesting to see the Turtles Steele dedicated to the doctor laurates.
A good place to visit during a half day tour. We had a wonderful guide who showed us this complex. Very insightful, and I would recommend this with a guide (or a very good guidebook).

Temple of literature is the first university in Vietnam. The Temple of Literature is old buildings looked poorly maintained about 10 minutes away from Hoan Kiem lake. It was constructed in 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong’s dynasty, first to honor Confucius . In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong continued the work and built Quoc Tu Giam as the first university of VietnamInside you'll find a pond known as the 'Well of Heavenly Clarity', a low-slung pagoda and statues of Confucius and his disciples.The entrance fee is 30,000 VND . Opening hours: 8:30 to 11:30 and 13:30 to 16:30 everyday except Monday and national holidays.
Beautiful to visit. Arrived to hoards of people lining up and quickly discovered it was graduation for many students. This made the whole experience surreal. Definitely go to this place.

Surprisingly interesting oasis in centre of Hanoi. Came here with family on last afternoon in Hanoi. Beautiful Confucian architecture, relaxing place to browse around (as long as you time it to avoid the busloads of tour groups...)
Very busy with students . Interesting building, we visited on a Sunday and found it extremely busy with students who had graduated at other universities and came here to have photos taken.

I enjoyed it but is not amazing. Its ok for a short visit...once again, try to arrive soon if you dont want to be there with a lot of people and take your time to enjoy the peace. It is interesting to see this and to realise how old was first vietnam's university. Sometimes, with my western eyes I forget all the things that were happening in asia in those centuries and it was good to remember. Curious and good to see but not spectacular. It worths it, by the way

An Ancient Temple Surrounded By Manicured Gardens and Water Ponds. Visited the Temple of Literature on a weekday, in the Early afternoon. The Ancient Architecture of the Temple, and other structures, is Very Impressive, and the surrounding Gardens and Water Ponds, are All Very Well maintained and Quite Impressive. This Location is Very Popular with Tourists from All parts of the World.Would Totally Recommend paying for A Guided Tour, to get an Understanding, of what is actually Located here. Certainly Allow at Least An Hour for this site. Entry is 30,000VND.There is Also a Tourist shop on site, with Items of varying prices.

Nice place to visit in Hanoi. I went there on foot from Hoan Kiem lake. It is a very nice place to visit in Hanoi. If you have time, I recommend. The place is not big, but not too small. In general, I like it here.

This was ok, but would have rather skipped to see more of the old quarter. The history of this place was very interesting, and the temples were ok. It was hard to tell they were recently restored. We saw a number of classes taking their graduation pictures which was fun.
Cool place, plenty of history. One of the oldest institutions in the world, since turned into solely a tourist attraction, still boasts a true historical feel
This is a very cool place. Take a guide with you to explain everything. This is older than most countries and is such an amazing place to visit and appreciate the culture.

Beautiful Vietnamese architecture. Probably the most beautiful sight in the city. Highly recommend. We were lucky to arrive on a day when a group of students were celebrating their graduation which made it very entertaining. However the architecture and temples are impressive enough to make it worth a visit in its own right.
Beautiful buildings. Interesting place to have a look round with some beautiful buildings. Some kind of graduation happening while we were there so spent our time avoiding getting in their photos!!

Definitely worth a visit. We stopped by with the kids. We enjoyed our time. We spent about an hour wandering around looking at the things. (Without a tour guide of any sort). It's a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The history, and sheer age of it is impressive. We enjoyed the topiaries, fish, and bonsai trees. As with anywhere, there are the stalls selling trinkets and souvenirs, but we enjoyed window shopping without being accosted. Entrance fee is 30,000 VND per adult.

Very surprising. For some reason I didn't have massive expectations of this place but it ended up being my favourite sight in Hanoi. We were lucky to visit during the Vietnamese graduation and so it was very lively with lots of photographs happening! We also got to speak to some lovely local kids who travel here to practise their English with tourists. The shrines are impressive and the surroundings beautiful. Go see it!

enjoyable visit. it tells you about the history of the university and you are able to look around,you ind out about the culture and beliefs of the vietnamese people,well worth going,on the day we were there,some students had completed their studies and we had our pictures taken with them wearing their mortar boards and gowns,which made it very special
Not really too much to do. Pretty nice, but there was not really much to do. We where just very warm and bored after walking in 15 minutes
Fantastic experience . So much to see and do. Fantastic history and so much respect for the Vietnamese for putting intelligence and education in such a high place in society.

Lots of history and culture . This university that is nearly 1000 years old has a rich history that is worth visiting and learning about. Only need about 45 minutes to visit. Was full of school groups on the day we visited (Sunday)
Interesting. A nice little sanctuary in the city. We were there on Graduation Day which was a nice experience. The turtles representing each class were also a nice touch.

Educational and serene. Lovely place to visit. the souvenir shops are run by the government and are priced reasonable with a great variety and good selection. Our visit coincided with a few groups of school children. We were amazed how well behaved and polite they were and all genuinely interested in the history.

A Popular But Worthwhile Destination . The Temple of Literature feels like it is straight out of a kung-fu movie. Perhaps, a kung-fu movie where instead of becoming fighters the students become doctors and scholars instead. The grounds are beautiful and totally worth visiting, but beware: lots of tourists and local weddings/graduation groups come here for photos. We went in the afternoon on a Saturday and it was PACKED. We left, saw some other sights, came back around 4:30pm and it was wayyyy less crowded. Worth a visit for sure.

Both interesting and beautiful. Thus temple was much more than we thought. We had a professional guide with us who was able to inform us of all the different aspects of the temple. We loved the music supplied by a traditional quartet and the temple interiors were very beautiful. Great place for photography.

Another interesting place for a history buff.... It used to be a school for the rich people, but in the end it was opened to public... It isn't a school anymore though... It's said that if u touch the head of the big turtle statues inside then u'll have a good luck, especially kids who do that will pass their exam... Now since they r UNESCO heritage, it's not allowed to do that anymore... It's an interesting place with lots of histories behind it, but make sure u come there with a tour guide, becoz there isn't that much infos on site...
Fascinating. A wonderful piece of history and very interesting. Our guide was great and very knowledgeable we enjoyed our visit
Nice . It is a good place to walk around.I think it is more interesting with a guide, so you learn something new - it's not much written in english.

Interestingly located. Temple of literature, dedicated to the sages, is located right in the middle of all the chaos of the city, and as such can be a place of refuge for a while. Its relatively quiet an serene, although not more than a 30-minute visit in my view.
Do not miss visiting this place. Excellent place to learn a little more about confucius. Excellent architecture, good historical place, excellent bonsai trees in the forecourt.
Old flames. It is good to go there and study the old flames of Vietnamese history and culture, and take good pictures

A quiet walk in a loud city. Upon entering the temple, the outer walls shield the city noise and you relax into a walk through the gardens and buildings. With shrines and artefacts on hand to view, an afternoon visit here is seldom wasted.
a taste of Hanoi history. we enjoied so much this temple. we strongly reccommed to take a visit , even if your stay is short in Hanoi.
Nice place. It is nice place but don't expect something special and don't ecpect a library or books to see.It is quiet and gardens are good for relax.

Living Culture. The temple still holds a prominent place for students whereby they will come to pray before major exams. On the day of my visit I was lucky enough to chanced upon graduating students who are taking their graduations photos in colorful traditional wear. It is also common practice for students there. Great that the ancient architecture is still embedded with current living culture. The design is tranquil and if you are wondering why the spot looks familiar, take another look at your 100,000 Vietnam dong note whereby the landscape is captured there. Lots of nice place to photos and considering the structure is mostly made of wood I would commend the conservation and upkeeping of the place. Well done!!

very very nice place. must be here Visiting the Temple of Literature you will discover historic buildings from the Ly and Tran dynasties in a revered place that has seen thousands of doctors’ graduate in what has now become a memorial to education and literature.
Interesting place. Very nice place to visit and admire the history and effort that has gone into this place. Great care is taken in the gardens.
Historical, but..... It is a nice spot to visit....i. However I've been to many other in Japan Cambodia and Thailand that were much much nicer
Very nice and active. Astonishing temple that you cannot miss if you spend even a single day in Hanoi . The museum is very interesting also with wonderful artpieces.

must be here if you are in vietnam. The ground of Van Mieu here are beautiful, walking through each courtyard you can feel like walking in a new world. Unfortunately, it is a very busy of tourist so be patient to line up or get through crowds at the entrances of each chamber.

History dating back over a century ago.... We were lucky to have by far the best tour guide with us Tuan Anh Dao, who was friendly and knowledgeable and knew our needs to perfection. His passion for the history and the meaning and significance of Confucius and the amazing courtyards and the story of the turtle which would be told to every scholar and student of today. Great experience...we learnt alot

Why not?. I expected something totally different. When I saw that it was advertised as the oldest Vietnamese universitiy, I expected rooms with thousands and thousands of books, manuscripts and so on. It actually looks like a temple, statues, gardens and fishponds. I would recommend to pay the entry fee of 30k, and see what it is all about, but do not expect anything WOW. Enjoy

Cool!. Nice dip into history of culture in Vietnam! A bit expensive for what it is and perhaps get a guide otherwise difficult to understand what you are seeing. An interesting break from the bustle of Hanoi old quarter!
Too Touristy.. Coach loads of tourists arriving ensured it was not a tranquil and quiet place to be. The only place in Hanoi where we were pestered by street sellers.

Misleading title. When I was told to go to the Temple of Literature and the National University, I thought it was two different places and I had visions of books being venerated in a modern university: nothing of the sort. It is as much a temple as anything but one which, in the course of its 1000 year history (it was being built as the Normans were compiling the Domesday Book), held a teaching position, overseen by the king, in the literature arts. Not a lot to see but what there is is interesting. Beware the taxi drivers outside who will offer to take you on the meter but then rig the meter to badly overstate the cost of the ride. Practically nowhere should cost more than 40k to 60k dong.

Interesting . Pleasant grounds and an interesting walk through the different sections of the original place of learning in Vietnam. The tourist information on signs in Vietnamese and English provided us with useful background information, but I would recommend hiring a guide so you can appreciate the full extent of what is on show.
Worth a visit. Oasis of tranquility in this manic city. Go with a guide or you won't know what you are looking at. Very interesting place.

Interesting . Interesting place. They have tablets still from 11th century with roll call of students names etched in them who completed schooling. Children come to us to practice their English without expecting anything but a chat and a smile.

Beautiful temple . A very nice experience walking through the temple and grounds. Well worth the entry fee! Just outside the temple is a very nice garden path also with lots of Vietnamese family's playing and runners. Go check it out afterwards.
Cool Temple. Nice temple to check out and walk around to get a break from the heat and the city. Definitely worth the $1 entrance fee!

Peaceful calm in the city. A beautiful garden, and buildings remind you of the history and education in Vietnam. A small group playing traditional music, incense burning and local students drawing made it a delightful hour or so walking around.
Beautiful. Really worth a visit! Be sure to have a guide so s/he can explain the history behind the Temple of Literature, otherwise it just looks like a very pretty historical site

A touch of History. This is a really ancient part of Hanoi, and fascinating to visit. I was lucky enough to see some graduates from this year who had made the visit to have their pictures taken at the oldest centre of learning in Hanoi. Look for the giant gong, cleverly disguised as the worlds largest wine barrel!

Went without a guide - not sure it's worth the money . That's pretty much it. The history of the place is very interesting but we read it in advance. The place is pretty but not that interesting to look at.
Very nice. Nice park and temple. 30000 VND entrance fee per person. Entrance is on the south side. Worth a visit.

SERENE ENVIRONMENT. I found The Temple of Literature and National University a beautiful place where one can find inner peace.
The manicured gardens and music played in the temple are a sight to behold.

Totally worth it. Great visit, historical site with nice explanations about history.
Fair price, the visit takes at least one hour.

The best of the cultural attractions in Hanoi. I have been to Hanoi twice and I have been to most of the major cultural attractions including the Temple of Literature twice. It is by far my choice of best cultural attraction in the city. It has a lot to see, has well maintained and attractive grounds, it has lovely sculptures and trees including bansai, and it presents an authentic picture of north Vietnamese history.Of the various sites we were to our kids seemed to like it the most.We would recommend it.
A little bit disapointed. Its very pretty and beautiful but I hoped something biggest. There are just five small areas and thats all. But its just 30 000 dng.
Interesting. Very interesting place to visit. The history is amazing. Certainly recommend if you are visiting Hanoi. Very easy to get to

Interesting place worthy of a visit. 30k VND entrance fee. Lots of touts at the entrance trying to sell fans, cyclo rides on the way out etc. It's an interesting place but really small - hard to believe it was once a university by modern day standards, you can probably cover this well within 45 minutes if you read the signage, take some photos and wander the 2 shops. It has some architecture which wouldn't look out of place in China. The shops inside sell some interesting goods which we haven't seen elsewhere in the city and prices are pretty reasonable so we didn't even barter over the small amounts of money involved. We were lucky and watched as the security guys fed the koi fish which are otherwise hidden in the pond. There were a ton of them!! Definitely worth a visit.
Most interesting. A different experience. Not the type of temple we had been seeing. This one is devoted to those who achieved a degree as well as a religious experience. I enjoyed the visit
Time for you to think . You have to visit here simply to get and understanding as to where the thinking comes from in Vietnam. It also reveals why education is so important to the Vietnamese.

Calm tranquilty in the middle of chaos.. Did not expect to find this on the busy streets of Hanoi. Once through the gates the calm and tranquillity surrounds you as you pass through several gardens and courtyards. In one area indoors you can sit a while and listen to three ladies playing old musical instruments. Beautiful young girls just graduated having their pictures taken in national costume was lovely to watch. Allow at least an hour preferably two to take everything in.

Favorite Part of Hanoi. This was a highlight of my week in Hanoi. Entrance fee is 30,000 VND and worth every penny. Spend the afternoon slowly meandering around the grounds and taking pictures. Walk into every building and go around each corner to see hidden sights. It keeps going and going. Very historical and lots of insightful information posted everywhere. Very popular with local, and foreign tourists and worth every minute spent there.
Culturally interesting . Requires a taxi ride from Old Quarter. Not too big an area to cover even on a hot day. Good explanations on board at entrance on English.

Small and nothing much for sightseeing. This place is pretty small and boring to me. There was not much to look at and I would not recommend it to anyone who has seen lots of temples/pagodas in their home country.
wonderful taste of history and appreciation of learning. The temple is great, but the impression that education is so valued throughout their history says so much about the national identity too.

Temple of Literature. The temple is a place of refuge in noisy Hanoi, were it not that it's overrun by tourists. We were there at the moment some Vietnamese classes were taking graduation pictures, which made it special but also even more crowded as tourists would swarm around them to get a picture. Yet the temple as such is worth the visit because of its architecture, the old steeles and the mere idea that being good at poetry would give you the best position in ancient Vietnam. An ideal world!:-)
Everyone loves Confucius. Well worth visiting, lovely gardens and architecture and Confucius sits proudly and serenely looking very wise!

Great place to immerse in Vietnamese literature history. Didn't regret visiting the Temple of Literature as we found out about how literature became an important part of Vietnam's formation and how graceful it was for the scholars to arrive at success via the different rooms representing different stages/progression starting from the beginning/entrance of the building right to the end of the fifth building. It is evident that there was also heavy Chinese influence in the history of Vietnam. The location exudes tranquility and peace in the middle of the busy town. Next to it is a small park where people go for exercise or walks. You are required to buy a ticket to enter. Great place to visit if you have the time. Allocate at least half a day for it.
Beautiful Grounds. Peaceful grounds. I spent a lot of time wandering around here. Def worth a visit. Its relaxing place in a city that is a buzz of chaos.

Senerity. Literature & education are the way of freedom and the Vietnamese understand this well. The tour guide explained the significance of the turtle, pheonix, crane & the dragon statues, all very important in the culture & beliefs & the teachings at the temple.
Tranquility in the middle of Hanoi. Well worth a visit to learn of the history and culture of the city. Beautiful gardens and buildings make this attraction a must.
Temple of Literature. An interesting piece of Vietnamese history. Reccommend to read up a little prior to visiting as little information is available in English.

Fascinating plave. This place is really worth a visit. A fascinating history where you can spend many hours. We will make another visit when we get back to Vietnam as we did not have enough time to do visit justice.

Incredible Exprerience. It was amazing to walk through years of history and to be physially present with our children. It set the tone for my children to value and appreciare knowledge and education which is an important factor in our lives. If you have an appreciation for history, then I would definitely recommend visiting this place.

Back in the past. I have visited the temple of literature twice and am reminded of the quiet and dedicated past the students led in those years. No computers or mobiles and no motorbikes - just the perfect peaceful surrounds to study.

Interesting . This place is much more interesting than I first thought. It is also a very pretty place. DO NOT pay for a tour when you buy your ticket! As soon as you walk through the ticket checkers there is many students offering free tours. The free tour from the Uni students was actually the highlight for me. We got to find out about the place and ask any other questions we wanted :-) Our guide was lovely!
Best Place to go. I loved the Temple of Literature . I can understand a lot of thing when I visit this place . The guide told us many thing about this University . I will come back again !

Calm and serene, in spite of the chaos. An awesome place. You can either choose to wander round by yourself or book/join a tour group. While it's nice to get a running commentary, I like to wander round and savour a place at my own pace. Not all the displays are translated into English, but about 90% are. A temple of learning that celebrates centuries of academic excellence. A lovely counterpoint to the modern trend of celebrating fear and ignorance. The opportunity to laugh at people doing funny poses next to statues in the place just added to the irony.
I felt humble!. This was overwhelming. Dated back to 1047 - really! Just think about how magnificent that is. Absolutly worth a visit.

Beautiful grounds!. I loved walking around the serene temple gardens. In late September, it was a treat to see so many university graduates in caps/gowns/fancy dress, taking their pictures with friends.

Interesting. A lovely place to see on your visit to Hanoi. I had a guide and she explained how important this old university is to the students of Vietnam and how they come here to ask for luck with their examinations. Another part of the city with beautiful gardens.

Good cultural history. Our family really enjoyed visiting the Temple of Literature & National University, which we did part of a tour. Spent a good hour at the Temple (you don't need to wear a long skirt or trousers or cover your shoulders here).

Beware of dishonest trishaw driver. This place is beautify and worth a visit.We took a trishaw ride here, we agreed on 50,000 VND. After we arrived here, the trishaw driver said one person is 50,000 VND and asked for 100,000 VND because there are two of us!The trishaw drivers in Hanoi tend to ask for prices that are two or three times that of a taxi ride. Beware of trishaw cheats!!! The taxi fare from one tourist spot to another one is usually less than 100,000 VND. Do not take small taxis, they are usually run by cheats with rigged taxi meters. A short trip from Ho Chi Ming Mausoleum to the Hanoi Opera House cost me 485,000 VND! It should only be about 100,000 VND according to my estimate. I was later advised by my hotel staff to avoid taking these taxis run by cheats and criminals.

More than just another temple. The temple is huge and amazing. It has some very old text books. There are many Vietnamese students which come to talk to tourists and practice their English and it is quite fun talking to them.Beware: the taxis in front of the palace agree to drive on taximeter, but it runs 3-times faster! It should be 10,000vnd per km. If it goes faster, tell the driver to stop the taxi and threaten with police. It worked when we did it and we did not pay anything.

Peaceful area in the craziness of the city . This was a lovely area, we saw lots of younger Vietnamese men and women visit for graduation photographs. A Vietnamese student stopped us to chat to help practice English. Only thing I would say is there is nothing which explains much about the place or why it is such a landmark!

Not to be missed. An absolutely stunning temple. We went in the low season so we didn't have a guide but we got the basic idea while we walked around- there are some information signs in English but not too many. Make sure you visit the whole of the temple as we almost missed the back temple by not going round the back. A truly interesting insight into Vietnamese culture.
Worthwhile visit. Really enjoyed it here. Learned quite a bit of history, which was something I wasn't knowledgeable about before the visit.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit and good to see the different houses and temple s
We enjoyed as a family
Well worth it !!!

Interesting jouney through Vietnamese History. The Temple of Literature is like an oasis of peace in the bustling, noisy Hanoi!We recommend to spend, at least, one hour, to enjoy the gardens, ponds, and admire the architecture and exhibitions.The day we visited it wasn't overly crowded, so we could actually walk through the gardens and take as many photos as we wished, and take our time to read the information available at the exhibitions, and watch a graduation ceremony. :) There are public toilets and gift shops available.The entrance ticket costs VND 30,000.

Worth to see. Pleasant calm place, ancient, well organised. The temple is old and touching. Very clean, tidy. If I had more time, I would spend the whole day there. Interesting place for learning more from the history of Vietnam.

Enjoyable tour. When we arrived it was very busy and there were no tour guides available. When we went in we noticed a table inside at which local students were offering free tours. we did this and were provided with an excellent tour of the Temple by a really enthusiastic and impressive student, at the end he would not even accept a tip. This is a very interesting tour.

worth seeing. it's worth seeing and nice to photograph, interesting too. Cheap to visit and is a must-see though not when you have seen a load of temples and pagodas in SE Asia, it's much the same as many.
An absolute must-see. We didn't know what to expect but this is a gem. Full of history, beautifully laid -out and, despite the numbers of visitors, a centre for quiet reflection.
rival to libraries of oxford. Best to go with a guide..which we didn't. But the exhibits are fascinating insight into scholars of years gone by. the public toilet was incredibly clean.
Nice place to visit. The gardens are lovely to walk through, Temple is very pretty and interesting to look around and to find out about its history. Give yourself around an hour to appreciate it:)

Wow!!!!. This was just the place to be n we were there on d right day..What better than being an spectator to a graduation ceremony of a kindergarten..The little kids were singing in their ceremonial costume..This was the first university in Hanoi n has a Confucius temple too..The landscape is well manicured n stunning..A must visit place..
Literature. A place where all the new graduates go to have their photos taken. it is steeped in history and well worth visiting

First university in Hanoi . Quite small for university but very nice history and structure is nice! I like this place, a lot of big tree (some very old) in the garden. The gate also impress me.
Must come to visit here when you arrive Hanoi
Peaceful oasys in Ha Noi. We enjoed very much the visit ot the Temple of Literature during our visit in Ha Noi last august. IEvwrithing was very interesting.

Great-- Wonderfull a must see. Not at all what it sounds like. It is beautiful and tranquil. The grounds are beautifully kept, manicured lawns, bushes cut into animal shapes, bonsai trees, interesting buildings, a lovely temple. And you may be lucky enough to catch a musical performance. A must see when in Hanoi
Average. A cute place to see, but not extraordinary. If you got time it's worth it a visit but if you have a day i suggest you to focus on something else.

An oasis from bikes. It took my girlfriend and i a while to walk to on a very hot day, and of course we had to battle through the millions of bikes. But this place is a small oasis in the city. Although its situated next to busy roads once inside the street noise is all but gone. The temple is interesting with gardens. However the price charged compared to time spent seemed a bit steep.

Very quiet place and pacefull. A very quiet, pacefull, green and spiritual place: it worths a visit. Unfortunately we saw it under a shower rain, but, despite that, we had a very good time walking along the paths.
Interesting . The story and history of this place is really interesting. If you have the time it is well worth a look.

The first university in Vietnam. In 1076, Vietnam 's first university was established here to educate sons of mandarin and royal family.The temple is make up of five separate courtyards. The stone stelae which is record the names, place of birth and achievements of men who received doctorates in examinations held in 14th century. Only 82 stelae are extant, they considered to be the most precious artefacts in the temple. They are arrayed either sidd of the third enclosure, each one sits on a stone tortoise. Nowadays they made a protective barrier for the stelae to prevent visitors touch and damage its.
Beautiful Temple and park. It's a beautiful attraction in Hanoi. It's good to relax and read a book in a sunny day! :) Totally worth a visit!
History. Very interesting place with lots of history. Nice garden and highlight the importance of Imperial examination

A must. Don't skip this temple, it's a very nice place and it has a story to tell you, the doctors in multiple disciplines were trained here. The architecture is beautiful, the green grass is well done and It's also a moment of quietness in the middle of this crazy and noizy city

Very interesting place, must see!. The oldest university and one of the oldest temples of vietnam, interesting and a beautiful place in the heart of town. Must see. Can do in 30 minutes, give yourself 45-60 min.
Beautiful gardens. Quiet, beautiful gardens right near town. A lovely place to go for a walk and enjoy the day. Make sure to get a coffee nearby and relax.

very interesting historically.. We hired a guide who walked us through this ancient university which is now a Buddhist temple. The grounds are quite nice and the explanation of the stele and other details was very informative. Thank you Nguyen for a great day.
Confucius celebration. Celebrating Confucius' thinking and teaching, along with a short history of the University. Nice gardens. Worth a quick look if you're in the area.

Beautiful temple but quite empty. Having been to other cities in Vietnam after discovering Hanoi, I'm no longer impressed by this beauty. However, if you're only visiting Hanoi, it's worth to go there to have a look at how the Vietnamese are good at architecture and have a great taste despite the orange-yellowish opera and other buildings. Expect to see turtles, gate, gardens, pond ... !
The most historical visit in Hanoi. Although not being a very impressive place, it totally deserves a visit because it is one of the historical ones in Hanoi

good place for capture. I've been here before going to Sapa, I dont have plan going here, but after have lunch at Koto restaurant (left side of the Temple of Literature). This is nice place, so good for capture.

So much history here. It was a very quick visit here as it was rainy the day we went. There isn't much to see and most is outside but it was cool seeing something that has been around since 1070. The souvenirs at the gift shop were less than other places we were happy to purchase a bunch of items from here.

temple not a museum. Slightly disappointing experience considering that the price is 15000 vnd while you can easily visit the entire complex in less than 30 minutes, anless you wanna stop by for prayers and offerings..Is a nice place but is smaller than i expected and there is no much to see or visit.. apart the temple..

Nice bit of history in the middle of chaotic Hanoi. Very nice place to wander for a while and absorb the history. The old architecture is amazingly located in busy chaotic Hanoi. Around the corner from the Fine arts museum as well.
Pretty gardens. The gardens are really pretty and there's some cool topiary but there's not much else to say about it.

Knowledge is Bliss. Sanctify knowledge and those that pursue it.
A great place to visit with any weather to take a break, relax and think.
Great with any weather.
Con fusing. We spent time here that's not having a guy sounds it to be quite confusing as to the actual representation of this temple although we did have a slight idea from the bro sure

Of ancient cultural significance. This is not one mere building, but many, a collection of awesome time capsules, grand and steeped in onflowing history. The reverence for learning and wisdom began here. One of the most interesting places you'll come across.
Very interesting. This temple has many interesting areas, courtyards and gardens that are very different from many others and the learned history also was nice

Nice Temple. Visit Ha Noi you must pass by this temple where marked once talent people of Vietnam. The idea of stele is a nice design help record the history. Vietnamese students want to visit this temple before their important examination.
Very interesting place. The Temple was well worth the visit. Even on a rainy day it was very easy to stay dry and enjoy our visit

Holiday. We visited very old very sculptural beautiful gardens with bonsai trees in the shape of many animals.
This is a very serene and peaceful place to visit.

Kung Fu Panda experience. The Confucius temple and the beautiful gong, drums and other relics of this 10th century university was a good hour's worth of time spent on my weekend in Hanoi. The curio shops inside were very genuine and the student guides actually go around helping you understand. The golden turtles and the storks are amazing to look at. Reminds you of the Kung Fu Panda movies.
Confucian university.. A great place to visit learning about Hanoi's first university which dates back to the 10th century and the teachings of Confucius.

First Hanoi school. This is a must for anyone visiting the old quarter very interesting and plant of souvenirs and so much to take in on this site take your time as you walk around these historic buildings as there's so much to take in you won't be disappointed . I visited with my Vietnamese freind who is a design engineer and takes his students as part of their traing here .

Interesting if slightly underwhelming. We had expected a truly restful and relaxing experience and, though is is undoubtedly a fascinating place and we enjoyed reading about the history of it, it was very busy and not restful. We'd still recommend, but don't expect to be sitting enjoying the tranquility during the peak season.

Beautiful, small temple that can get crowdy. Next to the Museum of Fine Arts, this little temple and its park were actually a university for young Vietnamese scholars. Interesting visit and many photo opportunities, but the place can get crowded with group tours.After the visit, turn left and recharge with yummy fruit smoothies at the street vendors shops at the intersection of Quốc Tử Giám and Van Mieu streets.
a must. loved petting the egret down to the turtle head and all the amazing decorations!! it is a peaceful oasis in the very chaotic hanoi!

Hanoi Highlight. I have waited a long time to visit this ancient temple. You sense how much Hanoi is an ancient city as students came here to study under Confucius. It has multiple paved courtyards each with its own purpose. We were lucky enough to hear a concert of traditional Vietnamese bamboo music here. Many students were visiting as they had recently graduated and had come to give offerings of thanks. Our private tour guide gave us lots of information which was enlightening. Not to be missed.

Very Old . This site dates back a long way and has had additions up to the early 20th century. Hanoi's original university set up in the Confuscian tradition. Good signage to explain to visitors in multiple languages. Gardens ar very beautiful with many topiary figures. Plenty for photographers

Crowds hide the beauty of this place. During our visit the place was so crowded it was difficult to even walk through the park. There were many students taking pictures which was fun to see but added to the masses of tourists. Would have been very interesting and nice to see without the crowds.

Really beautiful and peaceful . We had a guide take us around . He told us lots of info which was great . Very beautiful and quite . Looks of photos needed . You dont need to worry about being covered over either . It was very hot when we were there . Nice gift shop too inside . Plus nice jewellery shop opposite entrance . Very interesting history . Beautiful . We really enjoyed it .
Beautiful temple. A beautiful temple with beautiful treets and garden. For me, it was a great surprise in the middle of the city.
Beautiful place. It was a nice place. I spent most afternoon there walking around and chat with young student about it's history. It is a good idea to join a group tour with english speaking guide

Beautiful temple with interesting history. Well worth a visit and it will take you around an hour. The entrance fee at 30,000 dong is a bargain but to get the full benefit of the visit I would recommend taking a guide.The buildings have over 1,000 years of history and were originally used as the site of Hanoi's university. The temples and gardens are beautiful and all laid out according to Feng Shui principles.
Quiet retreat in the busiest of cities. A beautiful 1000 year old temple buried in the centre of Hanoi. Well worth a visit. Roaming the gardens was a welcome respite from the bustle of busy Hanoi
Dont miss this in hanoi...good for photography. Always visit this place when i have free time visiting hanoi. It is an excellent place for photopgraphy. Dont miss it.
Nice. It's nice and frankly nothing more. It has a few statues and a kind of art gallery. The thing I liked the most was the gardening, it waw beautiful !

To know more about Vietnamese education and architecture . If you want to learn about the history of Vietnamese education, then you must come here. Or only enjoy the fresh air, quiet and green area amongst busy Hanoi streets, you can get them all here

Historical. It's actually the first university in Hanoi if i'm not wrong but it looks like a temple for me.The interesting part is there're lots of turtle statue which held the name of the student in that place. I heard only the best got his name written on the turtle. There's also a story that the new student would stroke the turtle's head to have some luck in their studyAside from the history, I found the place is spacious and has the feeling of something come out from old movies. And I LOVE it!!!

1000 yrs of academic history!. Having a guide tell you more about the history is the temple - adds a lot of value to the tour. 1000+ years of history here is quite amazing - thankfully it was not destroyed. Well worth a walk around.
Nice Temple. It's a nice relaxed visit compared to all the other packed places! Downside was that some information was not provides in English.
Lovely budist temple. Free entrance different pavilions, cute turtles it must be a great honor for the best students of Vietnam to have their name in such a girgeous place.

One of the nicest places to visit in Hanoi. This temple is both impressive and interesting.
Be sure to either have a guide or read a tour book, before or while you travel this site.
Do not miss the "hall of fame" on both sides of the inner court.

Wonderful...that is all. I was really looking forward to visiting here and it really didn't disappoint.30,000 dong gets you in and it's a bargain. The main gate you walk through is weather worn and full of character. Once inside there's so much to see: starting with the gardens with flowers laid out into Chinese characters and trees adorned with lovely red lanterns. Next there's another gate which leads to a big pond (for want of a better word) with what look like big bonsai trees, stone turtles and memorial stones all around. Then, there's another gate which leads to the main hall which is full of red and gold, the smell of incense and is just superb.To do this place justice, it needs at least an hour. If you are a fan of temples, you will love it here.

Nothing. You should pay get in it, even using their toillet.Not good for price andeven if it were free, it would be the same.I hope you not to get here. Not good, also there is nothing to enjoy arount it.

A BEAUTIFUL TEMPLE. The Temple of Literature provides an oasis of calm amongst the frenetic activity of Hanoi. Enjoy walking around the gardens and learning about Confucius before visiting one of the nearby cafes for some refreshing Bia Hoi!
A break for the city. A beautiful place to visit, full of history and quiet ,to rest from a breathtaking Ha Noi. We enjoyed the company of some old vietnamese people, playing cards or exercising!

Ancient and beautiful. This was another must see. Lovely temple complex was the site of the oldest university in Vietnam. which was built in 1070 by the King Ly Thanh Tong. Quite simple explanations, not a huge lot of information but enough to give you an idea of the significance of the place.
GREAT SITE. i been there so many time but still found down it so charming, great for family and student who came seeing how Vietnamese pay their respect on education

Holiday. A must visit in order to understand the real application of Confucian philosophy, so many hundred years ago, in order to create a class of intellectual talent that is needed to take a nation forward.
Living history. We visited with a guide who really brought the history of this ancient temple to life. Wear easy to remove shoes so that you can step inside the buildings.

atmospheric. This university is near as old as Oxford, really gives you a feel for the civilisation and its antiquity. Students still come into the temple to pray for good results, so its alive and thriving
Very nice. Well conserved temple rich of pagoda, altars, budda, incens. Many courtyards to rest. Must seen in Ha Noi.
Vietnams first university!. The history of this place is fascinating. Undoubtedly they could do more to bring it alive for visitors, and I would recommend reading up about it before you go.

Historically rich and peaceful setting. The buildings and statues hold much significance in the history of Vietnam. It is the site of Vietnam's first national university and a place of worship. A nice plce to stop to get away from the commotion of the city for a little while.

Temple of Literature, Craft Link and Koto Restaurant. Just across the street from each other, we visited these 3 places during the same afternoon. Temple of Literature, dedicated to Confuscious, was especially interesting after seeing many Buddhist and Shinto temples in previous travels. After visiting the temple of literature, go out the main entrance, turn left, cross the street and you will find 2 Craft Link Stores, a non profit organization which helps traditional handicraft producers to market their goods, generating income for the poor or marginalized people of Vietnam....good quality products.A few doors down the street, to the left when leaving Craft Link is the Koto Restaurant, which recruits marginalized or street children and teachers them cooking and the restaurant trade. They make excellent food and are highly recommended

Impressive. Definitely worth timing your visit to a changing if the guard. Inside you can see the somewhat modest traditional hill-style long house on stilts where Uncle Ho wrote his missives and commanded his people. The gardens and lake are very tranquil and romantic & I suspect a popular place for marriage proposals. Today it was pouring with rain but still enjoyable.

The temple of literature with a difference. Undoubtedly the Temple of Literature and National University is an extremely important cultural site. It's been here for almost a thousand years and looks like it's been carefully preserved and maintained for the whole of that time. Within its perimeter wall are pagodas, courtyards, small ponds, statues, pavilions, a giant drum and gong (both, alas, unbangable) but, surprisingly for a temple of literature, not a single book. Not even a Dan Brown. Allow 60 minutes, more if you're interested in early Vietmanese architecture and the history of Confucianism.

Nice but too crowded . This is akind of new renovation with the old style of architecture of the royal university. The temple is very nice and honor but due to it is one of the most popular tourist spots so there were too many tourists group in and out. Inside the temple, the yards and hiding under the trees, people standing everywhere , this could have made the atmosphere was very chronic
it is what it ie . history nothing else to say speaks for itself cricky whatote you want me to say im not writting a book , go see this beautiful ovely city and Hanoi people discover

Catching up on ancestor worship. Architecturally and culturally this temple displays its local cultural traditions. Rich colours and traditions show the quality of artifices in this location. Well worth visiting.

Impressive. Definitely worth timing your visit to a changing if the guard. Inside you can see the somewhat modest traditional hill-style long house on stilts where Uncle Ho wrote his missives and commanded his people. The gardens and lake are very tranquil and romantic & I suspect a popular place for marriage proposals. Today it was pouring with rain but still enjoyable.

interesting - a university on this site since the 12th century. Well worth visiting, and spend time in the last of the 5 pavilions looking at the photos of the civil service exam process of old! Allow at least 90 minutes to experience properly.
Big area in the middle of the town . Is a nice area with a lovely small park area in the beginning. But is important for chinese and viatnamese people.
Power spot for a prospective students!. Many of my Vietnamese friends took me to this place to pray for my future success. It was very good memories.
An oasis of calm. Interesting history of scholarship. Beautiful grounds, and lovely music wafting through the buildings from the live performances.
Not to be missed. Fascinating buildings and lovely gardens in the heart of Hanoi. Good interpretation and interesting history.
Beautiful. Temple and early place of learning. A wonderful window on Hanoi's past and must see on a visit to Hanoi

Beautiful History. We did this as part of our private tour, so I'm not sure how much the entrance fee was. Though, guessing from the price of other places in Hanoi, it must have been about $2-3US.It was nice to slowly walk around the place, with the guide stopping here and there to feed us information. What I found particularly fascinating is that it was Vietnam's first university. We went before lunch and it didn't seem too busy. It is lovely and I recommend you take an hour to visit here!

Loved the courtyards!. Confucian temple and Vietnam's first national university. You will be treated to 5 courtyards in the 5 hectare property.Just be careful with the vendors outside the temple. 3 of us were robbed (money taken from our wallets) as we were paying.

Sightseeing in a cyclo. Visited here during a trip round the city on a cyclo. It sounds like it's going to be a boring museum full of books but it's far from it. Whilst a stop here doesn't take long, it was a sea of tranquility in a very noisy city and a lovely surprise to see an old temple and gates. Be wary of the hawkers selling t shirts/ fans etc at the gate before you go in though. No bother once inside.

Delightful garden in the midst of chaos. I have walked past the Temple of Literature so many times in the past 10 months but have never gone in, but on a weekend afternoon, before I went to the Indigo Store for a dye workshop I decided that it was the moment. The Temple of Literature is a beautifully tranquil space in the middle of the chaos that is Hanoi. A collection of buildings that have existed since 1070, built in dedication to Confucius, the Temple of Literature has been excellently maintained and is a nice stop for some peace, quiet, and a little bit of history.

Temple of Literature Hanoi. Visiting the temple of literature was a journey into the past. The temple is devoted to confucius and the construction started in 1070 AD. The temple complex and its architecture conforms to the concept of feng shui with a well laid out gardens and ponds. as you enter the principles of Confucius are depicted on both sides of the pathway. There are elaborate statues of Confucius and other teachers in the temples. There is also a temple devoted to the Kings who patronised this National University

Definitely worth visiting! . A lovely day out, the temple and artefacts have been beautifully preserved. A lot of information boards to learn about the history of the monument, and many photo opportunities of the wonderful architecture.
Wonderful temple in Hanoi. Tranquil place to while away an hour or so, for a bit of a break from the hustle and bustle of the rest of the city. Thoroughly recommended.

Lovely and historic . My family loved visiting this temple. It does not hold interest for very young children, however for my two older ones 9 and 11 years, i think they understood the significance of the Temple. My wife and i could have spent more time here.

Incredible and so enchanting . This is an important piece of Vietnamese culture that has impacted on the world. Please make sure you get time to go. We went in the rain and it was ethereal and tranquil, the street noise just wafts away into the distanceHumbling experience.

Tranquil visit - lovely sense of calm . There is so much history packed in to this stretch of the busy city.I loved the exploration of Confucianism amidst very tranquil gardens.Such a fascinating visit

A Historical place. Chinese culture had influenced certain part of Vietnam thus the existence of this temple. Confucius and his 4 beloved disciples are being housed in there. It was amazing to see Vietnam first university there as well, the university was originally build for the royals and richs to study and later extended to the rest of the people. There are a lot of carved stone turtles in there to honour the talents. There are a few courtyards and it the place was huge.

Favorite place in Hanoi. I loved the architecture and history at the temple. I had not planned initially on visiting this location, but my tour guide recommended it and I was glad that she did! It really highlighted the influence that Confucius and the Chinese culture has had in Vietnam.

Beautiful and tranquil setting. Worth a visit to see the extensive gardens and temples. Very magnificent and impressive. Worth walking all the way to far end to see the statues which are beautifully decorated .
A little bit of history.. Even the locals said it was too hot to be out that day so it would have been fine had it been cooler.

A tranquil escape from the city. I have been living in China for the past 9 years, and have visited many similar temples, shrines, gardens.However it had been years since the last time I came to a place like this, and I realize how much I missed it.It is not a big place, but I has manged to create a tranquil, somewhat spiritual bubble in this bustling city.I do advise you make this one of your priority stops while in Hanoi, it's worth going there for 1-2 hours, to rest, take in some of the atmosphere and plan your next visit.It is not far from some other sites nearby.

Best Architecture in Hanoi. This reminded me of the temples in China, but much better maintained. It was wonderful to see students making a traditional visit in beautiful outfits. The place is in excellent condition and was a pleasant diversion from the busy streets of Hanoi. Truly worthy of a visit.
Great destination to visit in Hanoi. If you have time in Hanoi, this is a good choice to visit, in order to learn about Vietnamese education as well as old Hanoi architecture
Amazing temple. This temple gives a good view about historic live in Vietnam and it is very nice to walk around and see all buildings still in good shape.

Amazing history!. This temple has so much history. Being the first university to be built in the Asean region and a place to worship Confucious, there is so much to learn and see. It is also a unesco sight which makes it worthwhile to visit. You should allocate at least 2 to 3 hours if you want to capture the details.
Visually apealing, could have more english description inside.. Worth seeing if you're in Hanoi. Confucian university if I got the message correctly. Beautiful inside with bonsai or similar trees.

Fascinating place . This is a must when in Hanoi. The history and the architecture together make for a great place to see. This is a central part if the history of this city and is a must. University students offer a free tour if you want to get to know more of the temple and the school.
beautiful!!. The gardens and scenery were beautiful. Lots of hidden spots and gems to see. Not too crowded. Beautifully kept shrubs, plants, and bonsai trees.
The first university of Vietnam. Visited this place on new year, full of students trying to buy words and people come here to pray. it is a must come when you visit Hanoi.

Confucius Said...... An interesting place about the philosopher, himself and his pupils. The best way to See this is with a guide. This way you will receive a better understanding about the history. Worth visiting

Touristy and pretty, but small. This was my second visit here after 7 years, and I still was happy to come back and pay the 30k entrance fee to see the stone tortoise tablets again. The shops in the back section take away some of the charm this place could have.
Confucius says..... Active temple of Confucianism. Largest collection of his works outside of his hometown in China. Spectacular architecture and temple areas. Worth the visit

Temple of Literature (The first university in Vietnam). There are beautiful place and have a lot of history and story of Vietnamese education. I recommend you to go with local guide or you can find some free guide (Student volunteer guide) in the temple because they would make you more understand but I don't sure about the day that they are available (Maybe Sat-Sun) The entrance fee is 30.000VND / person

Great for tour away from hustle and bustle. Very nice and quiet, beautiful architecture. Entrance fee is 30,000 dong each and totally worth it. Check out the massive tomb stones dedicated to students who passed the King's exam over 1000 years ago.
Very peaceful. Another place that really needs a guide to expain the history & culture. Fascinating place which can take around an hour to visit if you have a guide.

Need local tour guide. The place was well preservation and worth to be visited.It should be better if there was guide to grouping guests and introducing detaily about history and architecture.Parking was bad. The sign showed price following time 8-18: 3k and 18-20: 5k. But some one erased the number "1" in "18-20" to get 5k.

Vietnam's first university. This is another must see. The university was in use for approximately 1000 years. After seeing the different buildings find a bench and relax while enjoying an ice cream treat. Avoid buying the souvenirs there because they're a tad overpriced. Children are free at all museums.

Site of the Oldest University in Vietnam. This lovely temple complex is the site of the oldest university in Vietnam.It is a pleasure to contemplate the Confucian statues and stroll through the gardens.
Eh. It was your standard temple. Nothing to fantastic to see unless you're interested in the history. But walking around wise it was rather boring

Temple of Literature is the first university of Vietnam, which was built in 1070 by the King Ly Thanh Tong.. Temple of Literature is the first university of Vietnam, which was built in 1070 by the King Ly Thanh Tong. Today, the Temple of Literature where sights of domestic and foreign tourists as well as where the compliments for excellent student and also a place to organize the annual poetry on the fifteenth day of January. In particular, there is the element of today's officers to "good luck" before each exam.

Must see in Hanoi. This temple was truly spectacular. Take a walk through history and submerge yourself in the beautiful buildings and gardens. I left here feeling a deep sense of calm. Watch out for dodgy taxis out the front when you leave though!
Expected more. Somehow I was expecting a more romantic place. Instead, all you get is some yards, temple buildings and the very ancient (and historically relevant) stone plates.

Worth a stop for about 30-45 minutes. I stopped here for less than an hour; that really is all that is required. It is peaceful and relaxed. Like most places in and around the Old Quarter of Ha Noi, the admission price is 30,000 Dong (about $1.25 US). It is open on Mondays and Fridays, whereas most Ha Noi museums are closed those days.
Interesting Experience. It was an interesting trip to the Temple of Literature. You get to see how the first ever University in Vietnam was.

Fascinating atmosphere. Vietnam's first university founded in 1070! Amazing to see the inspirations of Confucius, one of the wisest men to have lived. Amazing to stand on the ground and imagine how many minds have overcome limitations there.

Interesting kind of . Interesting History connections with the Doctors Stone Steale. Lovely ancient temples in a nice surrounding garden. Quite simple explanations, not a huge lot of information but enough to give you an idea of the significance of the place.

Won't Even Seem Like the City.... This gem is a slice of history and green space that hardly seems like it's in the middle of the city. Not crowded, and the architecture is truly unique. Great place to practice photography. The history was evident, from the old stone stelae to the Pagoda with the huge Confucius statue. Incense curling into the air, fragrant and thick. The gardens green and lush. We hung out and wandered for a long time, not wanting to leave. No crowds. It's secret is the simple pleasures it offers.

Beautiful grounds, a guide will help you understand more. We wandered around the beautiful grounds and buildings here. We had a rough idea of the history, though we did not have a guide.I think that you would get a lot more out of this with a guide explaining the history to you.

Should be one on visitor's Must-See list while in Hanoi. History of this first Vietnam university is very fascinating to say the least. It also offers a nice, quiet place to think and unwind from the hustle of Hanoi modern life, which is happening just outside the main gate. Check calendar for cultural events and activities when planning your visit, if possible.
Very nice :). The history of the place is quite interesting, and the buildings are really quite pretty. There's not a HUGE amount to it though, so your visit here probably won't last long.

Ancient and beautiful,take a camera!. Highly recommended ,historic ,mysterious and often full of pretty Vietnamese girls in their traditional Ao Dai and No La conical hats posing for cameras in I emphasise a very tasteful manner. Pick your moment it can get crowded as a very popular venu.

A must see for Hanoi. The temple is nice break from the city and traffic. The administration price of 30,000vd is still very reasonable, which can't said for all the attractions in Vietnam now.
It's really just a please walk though some histroy. If you like history, temples and eastern architecture, you'll love this place.
Ancient !!!!!!!!. It was built in 1070 around very ancient and inside we can find the Chinese famous religion Confusion idle and also open class rooms and some details of local Kings on first floor

A lovely place. I wouldn't say this is a "must see" but it certainly is a beautiful place and a great introduction to the history and culture of Vietnam. It's located right in the center of the city, so it's an easy hour stop as you are exploring Hanoi. The grounds and temple are beautiful, even if you are not part of a tour. I'm sure that a guide would be able to explain more of the history, but even on our own we couldn't help but absorb the sense of culture there.

If you like temples... . There are signs in English with some explanation of the origins and their meanings, but it was all very dull. The buildings were beautiful, entrance very reasonable but I'm sure Hanoi holds many more interesting sights

Fascinating bit of Vietnamese Culture. Located in the heart of Hanoi, the Temple is beautiful and a lovely introduction into the history and culture of Vietnam. I recommend paying a little extra for a tour guide. You will learn a lot about the education system in Vietnam and the rich traditions that guide much of their culture. Easily accessible and beautiful grounds.
A must see place. Had a great time here. Got a chance to join a group tour to learn about the history of the temple. Nice place to visit

Travellgalore. Pleasant, near to all busy streets. ENTERING the site by paying the Entrance fee of 30000VND. AND WORTH IT. i love it! More interesting to be learner and being educated the History of that era.
An ode to knowledge and study. Peaceful and quiet. Dedicated to Confucius it was Vietnam's first university. An ode to knowledge and study.
meaningful place to see. Hanoi temple of literature is a meaningful place to visit, you can visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. it's worth to see

Oldest university in Hanoi. A relatively short trip to the temple as it was sooo hot (2pm) and humid. Beautiful grounds filled with topiary and mature trees, amazing old wooden buildings and a tranquil setting.
FREE TOUR!. Take the free student tour! Really free and easy way to get more info about the site. The student who gave me a tour was kind and knowledgable.
Temple of Literature. Interesting history and insight into Vietnamese culture. Our guide had a wealth of knowledge. Can recommend this for people who are interested in history.

The first University of Viet Nam. It is a good place to visit in Hanoi. It is very old temple, more than 1000 years old. You can see a long history about Hanoi on the boards and books in therem It also bring luck to students
beautiful. we went with novntravel tour and came here when we did city tours. it is great place , so beautiful and good for people to find more about the culture

Worth A Visit. This is a huge historical vestige. it was the first royal university of Vietnam . Said that the government used to use this place to give the wards to exceptional student yearly. Beautifully maintained and a great place to get out of the chaos that surrounds.

Traveling in time. We love the idea that the temple is very well kept and it makes you feel like traveling in time when visiting. It is easy to appreciate the Chinese influence over Vietnam History.
I would highly recommend to research a bit about the history around the building so you can make your visit richer.

Very nice place but be careful entering. I usually don't bother writing reviews but I thought I'd just send a warning to those who attempt to purchase anything (i.e. ponchos) from the people out the front. You pull out 500,000vnd and they will straight up snatch it out of your hand and cause a scene... You won't get your money back, they have a strong grip and they will outnumber you. Other than that, the gardens and temples were lovely :)

Amazing . Beautiful gardens and architecture. Very peace with many small gardens and sections. As it's has great historical and cultural importance it's well worth a visit. Be aware of three taxi drivers out "Grab-a-Cab"or "Uber" app on your phone if your taking taxis.

Amazing buildings and history of Vietnam before the Vietnamese War. I found the buildings amazing and showed the connection with China in adopting Confucius and chinese characters by the Vietnamese royalty. I would recommend you visit this place if nowhere else in Hanoi.

To us not one of Hanoi's main attractions. Though it's considered to be one of Hanoi's main atractions, we'd expected more of it. In Vietnam we've seen more interesting temples. The steles are worth to have a look at though. Maybe it's better to go there with a guide, who will give some background information on the temple complex.
Beautiful!. This is a beautiful location to walk about. Lots of great history and Gorgeous gardens. We visited while it was raining and it did not hamper our visit at all.
Beautiful and spiritual. Beautiful gardens and bonsai trees. It is a temple in the middle of a busy city and there is so much peace within the walls.
Fine place to see. Pay attention to all the trees in the garden cut to reassemble the 12 sacred animals, and the old turtles with name tableaus on top of the shirls
A peaceful setting. Really interesting place, good to go with a tour guide to find out all of the history and story behind the university.

So much interesting history in one place. Take a guided tour!. Many interesting historical relics at this UNESCO site. You might miss a lot of them if you do not have a guide or do your research ahead of time.

Temple of Literature is Worth the Visit. Not too crowded and very open and easy to navigate, our trip to the Temple of Literature was worth the effort to see the history, the statues, and the horticulture.

Really enjoyable visit- seems an odd choice to go to but really worth it... Might not be for all- but we thought this was different, buildings interesting-there was a graduation happening and beautiful ladies in national costume being given their certificates.

A slice of ancient history. This place can easily be written off as another tourist trap. Another historical monument in an Asian city. All of which is true.But The Temple of Literature is significant in many respects.Firstly, it is a truly historic place, and many of the sculptures and stone statues here hark back to many hundreds of years. They would be valuable collector pieces if one were so inclined.Secondly, this location, and the streets around it demonstrate what an old city Hanoi really is. This is the very first university of Vietnam.Hanoi city is over a 1,000 years, and this temple to Confucius, and learning in general, is not much younger (built approximate 1070AD apaprently).Thirdly, this is literally a monument to the value of education that is held by the people and culture of Vietnamese.So now you know why Asian kids are so smart!
GOOD STOP IN HANOI. Nice place for great photos and learning. Nice trip to walk to from Hanoi Elegance Diamond Hotel and see the sights.
Amazing !. What a place ! Have to go with someone who can explain the history and richness of this place. Exceptional and beautiful .
Beautiful piece of history. An exquisite part of vietnamese history showing the length of their intellect and philosophy. I am so glad it was rebuilt

A gem to visit in the city. The temple of literature is a place of surprising quaintness and beauty. The green lawns, manicured hedges and lush old trees make it a very scenic and cool park like environment. Old structures, archways and roofs offer many great spots for beautiful photos. The temple itself is nothing special though the grounds surrounding it that are a joy to walk through. I would say that this is a must visit when in Hanoi. There is a small fee for entrance. Come in the late afternoon when it isn't so hot (if you're here in the summer that is).One word of warning. Do not get into one of those touting "taxis" that are waiting outside at the entrance. These are independent operators and cons. They may have meters but their meters are rigged and you'll end up paying at least 3 times more than the normal fare. Walk a little away from the entrance and hail a cab. If you try to hail a cab in front of the entrance the touts may get aggressive. As a general rule in Hanoi, look for the taxis that are from one of the main companies (e.g.Taxi Group, ABC). They will display the fare rates as well as a Driver ID prominently on the dash. It's a shame that these scammers are allowed to operate as they blemish an otherwise pleasant city.

Cultural Place with Great History. The place where you can find the shadow of older days. Unlike other places in Vietnam, you can find Chinese wording in this place. The culture is similar to ancient China where people go for examination and seek for a position in government afterwards. I am impressed with the way the local municipal take care of this attraction. The place is clean and peaceful. The signboards are clear to explain the attraction well.

Beautiful monastery . One of the oldest places in town, the monetary built in remembrance of the Chinese philosopher Confucius. In the middle of a buzzing city this place of serenity. Once inside you hardly notice the noise from the city, even though it is on the other side of the wall. Well preserved, beautiful old buildings. And apparently still in use by the monks. Nice piece of history I recommend to see on your visit to Hanoi

Well worth a visit. We actually really enjoyed this. Lovely gardens and a pretty pond leading to temples. Impressive steles which act as a parchment certificate of the learned scholars. Students still visit the temple to pray for good grades.

Temple Dedicate to Confucius. This is a large, green oasis in a busy part of town. It was the first national university of Vietnam. The area is dominated by large gardens with a small pool and a low pagoda which houses statute sof Confucius.

Typical place to visit !. Have a rest in this place, it's a magnificient garden, with a temple.inside the temple you'll see typical decoration, very exotic !I don't remember if the entrance is free, anyway it worth it !
Temple of Vietnenam. Temple of literature is good place to visit and move around ,oldest university in Vietnam with big compound

Temple of Literature and National University. This was a very very old building with a lot of history. Set in the city of noise but so peaceful and beautiful gardens.Entrance fee was 30,000vnd - very worthwhile.

Very nice architecture..... . Considering the area's look and feel is very french, this is one place that stands out. Goes back to 1070AD and is built with the chinese-asian structure in mind. It mainly has gardens with sculptures of turtles (which is a sign of one their wisdom gods) with boards that held the names of every person that graduated during that era. Part of the temple used to be a national university and it was home to many scholars who also took on the role of traveling across cities to spread the knowledge and educate more vietnamese people. It would probably need no more than 20 min to see the whole place and you pay VND30,000 per person but worth seeing.

Great place for a student of literature.. Not much to see but you admire the tradition it represents. While the narrative is more to be heard than seen, you don't necessarily need a guide. The curio shops have small trinkets you can buy and the stone inscriptions make for good pictures. We were lucky to see a batch of local graduates turn up here for a photo shoot. It was a lovely experience.

Tranquil, well explained and nice shops. Our kids really wanted to see this area as it appeared on one of their TV adventure programs "the amazing race". All of the history was well explained and a good mixture of things to consider. Worth a visit
Calm amongst the chaos. Spend some time wandering this oasis of calm away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Lovely gardens and temple.
Interesting. Our visit was a bit rushed due to our itinerary. Nevertheless, we found the visit worthwhile and rewarding.

Nice to take a few pictures and learn a little history. . Not the biggest of sites we visited but still offers a few nice pictures and some interesting readings about Confucius and history of the temple.

Definitly worth a visit. This place will calm you down. This is the first university in Vietnam. You can burn incense to gods inside temple. Enjoy the old architecture and sculptures. Cameras are allowed inside the temple. There were few small stores for visitors to buy gift items. There are names of scholars since the 17th century carved in stones. Entry fee was around 30000VND or NZD $2.

Fresh and cool place in the hot and humid city. Good place for you to walking around and sightseeing. Many big, green tree where you can hind your head in the sunny day. I meet many students there. They very friendly smile and try to talk to you

Hot in June. No A/C. We went in June. It was too hot for me to enjoy the visit. Yet, the visit was interesting and is a fascinating history. I enjoyed learning about the place and had a feeling of the significance. We had a guide who helped too. We ignored the hawkers at the entrance. Our guide bought our tickets.
Calm and beautiful. Great set of temples in the middle of busy crazy hanoi. Like a quiet island inside noisy hanoi. Had a great 1.5 hours there. Plenty of students there. The nicest temple in hanoi.

Worth a visit. I enjoyed rambling around here. It's not huge so you'd only need an hour to take in the surroundings and read all the info.There is a nice atmosphere and it's a good place to sit and think if you find a quiet spot away from the large selfie crowds!This is somewhere to visit on the way to other nearby attractions or if you've a spare hour or two.
Very interesting . This is very interesting to visit but I would highly recommend to go with a guide to get the most out of it. There is so much, which you would otherwise miss or not understand.

A good place to visit whilst in Hanoi. Considered one of the oldest sights in Hanoi it is dedicated to the Chinese philosopher Confucius. This is where Vietnam's first university was founded. Spend the day taking your time walking the beautiful courtyards and old structures.

One of the nicest attractions in Hanoi. I thought that the lovely gardens, delicate architecture, interesting history, and peaceful feel of this place were fantastic. It was very hot, and part of the time it rained, but I still got a good feel for the place. This place was the first university in Vietnam. It's been here for nearly a thousand years. It's clearly been restored and is in very nice condition, with plenty of effort spent on the gardens in particular. They had a variety of topiaries, trees, flowers, ponds, a temple, statues, shops, and carved, decorated historic gates with some fairly good signage explaining the stories of the past. I enjoyed the beauty of the plants and the elaborate, ancient style of the architecture, even without a guide to explain too much. I had researched it ahead of time, so it wasn't too difficult to walk around and get the idea. It's not too complicated to walk through- one main path goes down the middle, through a series of gates, gardens, pavilions, and courtyards, to the temple in the back.The best part was the courtyard edged with rows of turtles with the 'stelae of the doctors' on their backs. The stelae are 72 large stone tablets, listing the names of university graduates over hundreds of years. Many carvings were faded and worn away, but taken in its entirety, it's very impressive. It really brought alive the idea of the scholars coming there, year after year, for hundreds of years, hoping one day to see their names carved on a tablet like the ones in those rows. What surprised me was that each turtle was a little different, unique from one to the next. I guess it's natural, since some of them were made many generations after the first ones, and styles and techniques change.Overall, a very enjoyable 1.5-2 hours to wander around, buy a postcard and a souvenir, enjoy the gardens, read the history, and take lots of photographs. There are a bunch of shops towards the back, in the courtyard before the temple. You could get a drink or a snack (and lots of other souvenirs) and enjoy it in the gardens. There was a bathroom, but if I remember right, you should be sure to bring change, because it costs 1000 dong to use it.
it is so different from the western culture. beautiful garden with beautiful buildings. So peaceful to walk around and see all the studybooks, which we can't read.

good. nice to see but not much info here if you are seeing without a guide.dont make the mistake we did in the rain and not paying attention to our map, and miss the last courtyard!! easy to do as you have to walk along the side and behind the impressive temple building to last courtyard.
It is a must go in Hanoi!. This is one of the most important temples in Hanoi and perfectly translated Chinese influence in Vietnam.

Beautiful architecture . A must see coming to Hanoi. Amazing how the students of the past went through classes on confucius, politics, literature. I am always going to remember the significance of the turtle - longevity, shell facing heavens, body towards the earth.

There are So Many Other Temples to Visit in Hanoi. I'm sorry, but I did not find this temple that attractive. It was crowded and after having visited other temples in Hanoi, Hue and Ho Chi Minh City this place did not even compare. Yes, there is a lot of history associated with the temple, but I just didn't find it that great.

Only if you have extra time and a guide to explain. The temple is a revered part of Vietnamese History and Culture, and if you have done a bit of homework and understand the history behind it, it is a wonderful spot, if you are doing a race through without a guide, go straight on to Ha Long Bay
Just been there for 10 minutes . Nice place to learn a little about Confucianism but not many things to do and see, 10 minutes are more than enough to visit the whole place.

Beautiful Peaceful grounds. We added this stop at the last minute because we could fit it in. I found the grounds every peaceful and the buildings beautifully maintained.
