Tourist Tip - this is a great spot for souvenirs! If this hadnt been my first day in Vietnam, I could have known better. Finer quality and vintage type item, ie opium pots water puppets etc.

The first university in Vietnam. A great place to see. This is the first university in Vietnam. Each doctorate used to have his name carved on a stone (after completing his doctorate). There are interesting things to see. A guide will help you understand the various types of Buddhas who are there.

Nice place, good to know the Vietnamese traditional culture. It is the first university of Vietnam, it look similar to places in China, but some different with the Stone turtles, I spent half day inside this place
Day filling . Alright place to go, get a tour guide for more details and interesting conversations. Temple itself is alright, wouldn't have minded studying here myself...

Very nice visit. I liked this temple despite the overload of temples during our holiday. It is small, tranquille and very pretty. It was very hot though during our visit. We could buy cold water inside.

A temple that honors knowledge and learning - full of history. Getting a knowledgeable tour guide and reading up is highly recommended. There are 5 courtyards. The design and layout is based on harmony (Feng-Sui in today's language). Very serene and peaceful. One courtyard has the alters of Confucius' most accomplished students (Doctors). The most inner courtyard (5th) is the Imperial Academy/University. We learn from our guide that the historical literature and philosophy are Confucius-based. Built in the 11th Century, this temple and layout is based on the original Confucius temple in Shandong, China. The traditional early Vietnamese-based writing system is based on the Chinese character writing system (Han characters) with a few additions of local words. The pervasive Vietnamese Imperial examination system that filled the civil bureaucracy for centuries is based on the Chinese Imperial Examination. Even the titles of the first, second, and third place finisher of the examination are the same as those of Chinese. The students had to learn all the Chinese literary classics such as the Four Books and Book of Rites. In the 16th century, Portuguese missionaries invented a phonetic language system based on Portuguese alphabets - for the main purpose of evangelizing. It was not officially adopted until 1918 as part of the nationalist movement. The Latin system is easier and quicker to learn, thus bring more people into literacy. However, the government now recognizes that this cuts the newer generations of citizens off from the country's early written history. So now it supports transliteration of older and more obscured classics. Around holidays, there are calligraphy masters outside of the temple that write out greeting and good-fortune signs on red papers.

Great place to visit and get out of the craziness . This place is a little gem.Fascinating look back in Vietnam's history.Beautifully maintained and a great place to get out of the chaos that surrounds.Only downside was a couple of groups more interested in taking selfish than enjoying the experience (not the temple's fault) and converting some of the space into stores.Still well worth including a stroll if on a self guided tour of the nearby mausoleum and other sights

Serene ancient temple. For only 30k VND you can visit this ancient temple in Hanoi. Ancient stone carvings, statues with offerings and peaceful surroundings make your visit worth it. Easily combined with a visit to the Mausoleum.
A good place to visit. Very calm and serene atmosphere. Nice gardens. Good shops to buy some small gift items. Full of literature and history.

History, learning, tranquility . We walked to the temple from the old quarter, just under 2kms. The walk was pretty comfortable and provided opportunity to see various shops, etc. Given that you're often on the road it's not a walk to do with young children. The temple of literature had 30,000 dong admission. Well worth it for the insight into education and learning in Vietnam. Various graphics provide information. The gardens are lovely and tranquil. The temples are colourful and architect impressive. There are steps into and out of temple. I'd recommend visiting.

An interesting sight. The first university in Hanoi. Or so I'm told. An interesting confusian temple that only takes 30 minutes to look around. A good historical landmark, although more interesting temples are available.
Visit if you have time. This is where education started in Vietnam, and is a resting house for the intellectual . It has a buddhist temple and surrounded by greenery.

Worth a visit. The Temple of Literature is the Temple of Confucious in Hanoi. It was Vietnams first university and built in 1070.The temple, courtyards and galleries are interesting and we enjoyed our visit.It wasn't too crowded and offered an interesting insight into the history of tertiary education in Vietnam.
Temple of serenity. Lively quiet and peaceful venue with a rich history. Loved the statues of the turtles (or successful scholars).Gardens beautifully maintained and manicured). Great facilities.

A beautiful studying center.. If you visit Hanoi, you need to visit the temple of literature, an ancient university that educated Vietnam elites up to the eighteen century. The whole site is magnificent.

Educational and Fun. Visited this site with our 3children and found it well run and very educational.Kids all found something to interest them and gardens outside were nice to walk through and have lunch.

Must see atraction. This was the first place I visited now that I am living in Hanoi. Although there were many, many tourists when I was there, it was still and nice and peaceful atmosphere. It is definitely a must see attraction when visiting Hanoi.

Pretty place, very busy. Try not to visit this site on the weekend or during the school holidays. It was extremely busy, very hot and you could not appreciate the beauty of the gardens and architecture. It is a shame it has been so commercialized though...it takes away from its old world charm.

Actually really liked it!. Not a big fan of museums but I really liked it. Really interesting to see a temple that values education, so unique. Probably tip: get a volunteer guide once you walk in. They are students and will give you a free your (seems like a great way for them to practice their English).

Temple of literature pat the head of the Turtle. This was a an ancient place of learning the lists of those here are almost unreadable carved onto stone. Next to each record is a turtle one of the four revered creatures in Vietnam. If you pat the Turtles head you shall become brilliant. Yes I patted it! Beautiful surroundings.
Engaging place. The architecture was some of the best I've seen in Vietnam. definitely value for money would recommend anyone to visit.

Great place to experience culture. Was pleasantly surprised by this attraction. It was 30VND to get in but there was a discount for students. The area is very beautiful to walk around and easy to find with a city map. The history is interesting and there is some good price souvenirs to be had. Highlight was reading the history of the turtle monuments, only down side was that the lady at the desk was a bit rude
I recommend you go with a guide. This could have been a very interesting place, but there is very little information about the site. It would be good to go with a guide or tour, or Hanoi Kids.

Step back in time. This was a great place to walk through and soak up the history of Hanoi. We had a guide but there was a team of volunteer guides near the gate. They were students keen to practise their English so while I'm sure they would appreciate a tip they are genuinely offering a free service. The garden and buildings are beautiful with some excellent bonsai trees throughout.
Oldest uni in Vietnam. It was interesting to see the Chinese influence of the country. It had a small pond with some nice flowers and topiary. In the back is a statue of Confucious.
Interesting. Good to see the first university in Hanoi. New did it as part of a private tour. They have clean toilets there for 1000 VND but can be quite crowded

you have to see this, its like walking to old chinese temple. The temple is divided into some section. Its a chinese ambience with old and unique picture. Its not just a temple, it has lotus ponds, bonsai plants in a pot with miniaturenof the temple and people, old stone with the name of graduatein the back of the old building, it has a tall bird and turtle, i heard the lady next to me said that you have to rub the chest and feet of the bird, and the head of turtle, but until now i dont know what is the story behind

Understanding a grear culture. As an academic I found this place to be fascinating, an illustration of the depth of this culture going back a thousand years. Subjects historically taught here were Vietnamese History, Buddhism, Literature and Confucianism. Now simply a historical monument.
Beautiful and Thoughtful. Important understanding of the history of the Vietnamese education. Peaceful and inspiring in the center of the city.

Great Bonzai. We spent an hour or so wandering around this interesting place. Plenty of small courtyards to wander around and explore and a great collection of Bonzai. Remember to visit the final pavilion to listen to the 3 ladies playing traditional musical instruments

A few moments of relative tranquility while in Hanoi. Worth a visit if no other reason than to get off the crazy streets of Hanoi. It is a quiet, sedate stroll thru a well maintained set of gardens and restored architecture dating back to 1000 AD. Signage is in English and tickets currently 30,000 dong (kids under 15 are free).

Beautiful setting, a bit of a tourist trap. Do your reading beforehand so that you get the most out of the temple. It is quite interesting and there are a few informational plaques that are helpful. The gardens are pretty and relaxing in the midst of crazy, busy Hanoi. It was crowded and buzzing with hawkers at the gate, but worth a visit. It is a significant landmark and essentially the first university in Asia.

Peaceful and pretty. The grounds are a tranquil setting in the middle of busy Hanoi. The architecture is nice and there are signs I'm English to explain some of the sights. It's not overly big though so don't expect to spend too much time here

Peaceful haven in a busy city. . The temple is very lovely and the gardens and courtyard well maintained and clean. Fascinating history, Only need to be there 20 mins or you can stay for as long as you like.

T o L. Worth a gander just to see one of the remnants of Confucianism in Hanoi. Not recommended in the rain. Since Hanoi was razed to the ground by the B52s in the Vietnam war, there's no building actually older than 40 yrs but they've made a good job of it looking authentically old

serene and amazing. A beautiful set of courtyards and pagodas which astound with their age. Well worth a visit . We used a guide and learned a lot . I am amzed how you can walk around , touch and photograph in asian temples.

Nice quiet place. It's a nice quiet place to stroll through. Just as we were leaving there was a big tour bus that pulled up and it became very busy. Before that it was nice and quite and a great place for a relaxing stroll. Some great history here too.

Old history. For me, it's just a normal temple with quite a history and value for the local people and believers. It's quiet and peaceful with it's vast gardens and views. Great for a quick retreat between the bustle of the city. There were souvenir shops inside the temple area, best get your souvenirs here because they came at a cheaper price than outside in the city. (I checked)
My Journey My Views . This Is Really A Place Worth Visiting While We Are There In Hanoi The Capital City of Voetnam As It Is A Source Of Inspiration And Information For The People Who Love Education.

recommend. Nice piece if archktecture, very impressive and lots of details.
Althouh it attracts tourist, it stays very calm and quiet which makes it even more enjoyable.
The gardens are lovely too with there shaped trees and multiples bonzai.
Interesting. Good arquitecture and ambience; with a good guide you get to know it better. The shops around are worth a visit, specially with local productions.

Pleasant visit, some nice architecture. This was a basic trip away from the main area we stayed in.
Very cheap entry (30k) and a nice stroll through the grounds and some history to read about Confucius.
Certainly not 'exciting' but quiet and easy.
I would recommend going here just to get out the hustle of the normal streets.
Expect to spend around 30-40 mins
Good temple with a lot of history. This was once a university to get doctorate degrees. Now it's a temple to visit with Confuious at its core.

Where is the Literature?. From the view from the street and reviews I'd read previously, this temple is a 'must see'. Maybe I'm missing the point of this building but I didn't see any references to literature. A beautiful temple in equally beautiful grounds. That's all I can say! Was in and out again in 15 minutes.

Not just another temple, this has its own flavor. basically the people go to save the prayers for those that are studying and will be graduated. The facilities are beautiful, with gardens, ponds, arches and doors and the major building has the images different in its form and position.
Definitely A Must in Hanoi.

One Attraction You Should Not Miss. The Temple of Literature underpins Vietnamese culture and society. Steep in Confucian ethics of Ancestor (scholar) worship, this is one attraction in Vietnam you should not miss. The architectural form is unique to Vietnam and is a haven for artists and historians.
The gardens are a great attraction too!. History, gardens and temples - all in one place. Well worth a visit to learn about Vietnam's first university.
Worth to pay a visit. The entrance fee is reasonable and you get to see the Chinese-style temple. Please bring along an umbrella with you on a sunny day or rainy day.

Simply beautiful . We came here as part of our private tour and it was an absolutely stunning place.
Very interesting to see how much pride people have taken to keep it to such a good standard.
It was very calm and we got there early to avoid the crowds.
beautiful. Beautiful temple where full of Vietnamese crowd. Beautiful lotus lakes along way to main building...

Hanoi kids make it worthwhile . We visited the Temple of Literature with Hanoi Kids on a half day tour. They made the visit interesting by explaining about the architecture and history of the site but if we had visited on our own I think we'd have been disappointed.
It's beautifully built and peaceful but not really much to see or learn.

Nice, Peaceful Attraction. The Temple of Literature/ National University is an attraction of historical and cultural importance. This attraction contains very important historical items. This place is centrally located in Hanoi. It is worth a visit for something to do and to take some pictures.

It's beautiful, but you don't have to go inside if you have visited other temples. as the title goes, It's beautiful, but you don't have to go inside. most of the temples in Vietnam has similar features, and this one is not an exception. It is beautiful, but I don't think it's worth going inside if you have visited other temples here.
Famous historical site. Learning a lots a bout Vietnamese history a thousand years old Temple. Temple of confucious and the first national Uni of Vietnam

Best to go with guides to explain what you are looking at. We visited this attraction with the Hanoi kids. They were great tour guides and we spent over an hour he with them understanding what we were seeing and comparing with other similar experiences. There is not a great deal of English signage so go prepared with a guide book or local tour.

Must see while visiting Hanoi. Great place to visit while in Hanoi. Build as a temple dedicated to Confusius, it became a school and later university.Visit the Temple of literature early in the morning, as it can get crowded with students later in the day. Vietnamese students love to take pictures at this place, specially after graduation.Very cheap entrance fee (less then a dollar)

iconic Confucian architecture. The atmosphere inside is totally different from the world outside of the wall, quite and ancient. The interesting story i heard from street vendor. In the right corner of the first wall is place the son of the king and his friend played some gambling games. Therefore, some one who would like to have luck in games coming here to worship

Wonderous and beautiful . Definitely one of the most scenic locations in Hanoi, the square pools of water edged by beautiful gardens and bonsai is breathtaking. The architecture and walls breathes life into the gardens and speaks volumes about the history of Vietnam. The main square is a hive of activity with shop entrances fronted by large old bonsai. Well worth a visit.

Worship to knowledge. This is a small place not overcrowded by tourist. I had the chance to see a lot of high school graduates in robes attending a kind of gratitude ceremony for their accomplishments.
Good with a guide. Visited after mausoleum . Good to do with a guide as they give you a very informed tour of the real meaning behind the old university. Great insight into Vietnams history

Nice sightseeing spot. Great architecture and got lots of information inside it. It would be very hot during summer, so don't forget to bring hats and cold towel/water with you.
In the souvenir shop they sell musical instruments and sometime they perform short songs which is quite attractive.

Pround History. The first university of Vietnam. Many talents studied here and their name carved on the big stone board. Listen the guide travel explain why tortoise carried the big stone board is amaZing experience

Almost 1,000 years of history in the heart of Hanoi. We arrived mid-morning with a bus load of Buddhist monks in hot pursuit, we had a 2-minute head start on them and the film crew following the Thai TV stars that arrived at the same time. There was trouble brewing in the air and we couldn't tell who was going to kick things off. As it turned out, everyone was well behaved, even our 2 kids who took a keen interest in the amazing Bonsai trees scattered throughout the complex. There's five stages of the complex that represent the 5 elements of Vietnamese culture; earth, fire, water, metal and wood. Each of these are typically represented at the alters honouring one's ancestors that seem to be everywhere in Vietnam. We had a guide with us from HanoiKids and this was the best way to view the complex. Make an effort to go through all 5 sections as most people seem to crowd the first 3 and not delve back far enough to appreciate the history behind the temple and the university that's seen in the 4th and 5th. The gardens are also immaculate and worth a visit just on their own. Well worth the VND30,000/Pax entry fee with kids under 15 free.
Beautiful architecture. Nice building and grounds very pretty not a lot to see there it is not a big place but interesting enough.
Ingesting and pretty . Nice to visit. Nice shops. Good to see a the history and the temple and it's garden. Very nice in the middle or the city.

Wonderful Confucian school and grounds. An interesting few hours can be spent wandering the grounds and buildings which form the oldest university in Vietnam. The gardens are a tranquil respite from the hubbub of the surrounding neighborhoods.

Well worth 30-60 minutes in the center of Hanoi. A peaceful and historic site in the middle of Hanoi. No individual aspects of the site are exceptional, but it's interesting, historic and educational. It's well worth the time to investigate.

A serene place of historic importance.. Felt very peaceful being in this serene place, we were lucky to be treated with a tradition Vietnamese music show in the premises. Worth a visit, leisurely so, to take in its serenity & soak in its history.So very well preserved & showcased.

Like Chinese temple. The influence of China is visible everywhere in this temple (architecture, gardening, sculpture), although the difference between Vietnam and China is not always clear for Western tourists. It is interesting that this is not only a temple, but used to be an university. You can imagine how nice was the campus!

Impressive. Being my first time visiting a confucian university, I must say the view was spectacular: the red color, the intricacy of the architectural details, the feeling like you have stepped out into a different time...the temple is a physical ode to erudition.

Sightseeing /Historical . Part of my friend Deepa's holiday package included a tour guide who took is around the Temple Of Literature. Luckily he knew his stuff and gave us so much information. Beautiful if your into history like my friend & l. Thankfully when we went round it wasn't crowded so we could take out time have a good look at everything which was well maintained. Certainly worth taking the time out to visit.
Very cool!. Tons of Chinese influence from the Confucian era, this place was a pretty cool place to see during our travels in Hanoi.

Beautiful place to visit. There is so much history . The temple is a beutiful place to come if you want a lesson in Eastern history, love hixtory building , want to learn more about cukture . A must do for Hanoi visig
Peace and serenity. Very peaceful and quite temple in the center of the wild hanoi! Very impressive cultural heritage!!!
Beautiful. Beautiful temple and definitely worth a visit if going to Hanoi. Costs 30 000 dong or so. Be prepared for lots of vendors trying to sell things at the entrance!
Good place. I came here and know more this place . The history of this temple is really interesting indeed . Shall not spoil it for you but it's definitely a place to come to know more about vietnam

Beautiful place for a short stop. Beautiful place for a brief stop and also close to the Fine Arts Museum, so the two can be combined.Visit won't take more than half an hour - to stroll through the courtyards.Quite crowded when we visited - especially with groups.

Such a wonderful site. It was so good to see the seat of this historic learning institution. It was very well visited in particular by students who are graduating from their various schools.Lots of books on sale. Great visit.

Beautiful and thoughtful place to visit. This temple was nothing like I imagined it to be, it may be a museum today but it is a glimpse into Eastern culture that took me completely by surprise. There is so much history here that we just don't learn about as part of our 'English/Australian' history lessons at school. Beautifully preserved and filled to bursting with symbolism, the Temple is a beautiful place to come if you want a lesson in Eastern history, love historic buildings, want to learn more about culture or just want to spend a couple of peaceful hours admiring your surrounds. A must do for any Hanoi visit.

Quick visit. Nothing special. Entrance free not expensive. 30000 dong per person. Guide map or book extra.Not very big and not a lot to see. Grounds are sparse.Be careful of taxi touts at the front. We were so hot and sticky so decided to get a cab and head back. We paid 60k from hotel to west lake which is further but this guy charged us 163k for a shorter ride back. Before we got in the cab I asked him how much. He said meter. Something made me look at the meter but I didn't register as i was all hot and bothered. The meter started at about 115k. When we reached our corner (he didn't even drop us in front of the hotel as he knew he was scamming us and we could have got the hotel to help sort it out), he said 163k. I said what. No way. Not paying that. Afraid he may be a gangster so said I will only give you 100k. He asked for 150k. I paid him only 120k which is still double the cost for a shorter ride. Remember to use only Group taxi. Even if they said meter, don't trust them. His reason was that the taxi was one way as in one way traffic. He even stopped before the lights turned red. He didn't even move when lights turned green. He wanted to clock up the meter. My husband got the Google map out and I noticed the driver was fully checking out what my husband was doing. He was doing it on purpose so that the driver wouldn't take us on a round about longer way. Cheats. This makes Vietnam look bad and let's the country down as it has tarnished it's reputation for us.

Pretty. This was a really pretty attraction. However, you cannot spend too long there. It was quite small and very similar to other temples (if you have been travelling around Asia). There was also a weird festival going on in the centre courtyard which meant that the whole place was littered with souvenir stalls and other random things which detracted from the beauty of the temple. Nice visit (30K for student)
Much literature indeed. The history of this temple is really interesting indeed. Shall not spoil it for you but it's definitely a place to come to know more about Vietnam
Holiday. The history in this place is amazing. Still used today for graduation photos. Our tour guide gave us an in depth tour for us to understand

For Temple Lovers Only!. The Temple of Literature is, according to most of the guide books, a 'Must See' attraction, well maybe if you are really into old temples and history then yes, if you are not, then to do fully, and see everything takes about an hour, less than half that if you have children. It is quite a way from the centre so take a cab there and back. Would I go back and see it again - No - once was more than enough.

Very interesting. The temple of literature was very informative. It had some beautiful gardens and told about ancient scholars. Upsetting that there was no shade for the fish in the main pool, but overall the temple was an awesome experience. The toilets were also very nicely kept for public use toilets in Vietnam.

The old signs to show the map of thoughts of today Vietnamese. Văn Miếu Quốc Tử Giám - means the temper of study. this temper show how the old Vietnamese leveled the talented people who were not only hard work in study all kinds of books (though major based on the book about Tao of Movement) but also this temper built with the intention of encouraging youngsters study harder and harder to have their named listed in this temper as the sign of proud for their families in many generations.look at the name of persons who achieve highest possible rank of study, you can find their thought and their wish for people, for country, for peace... but you also can see that their thoughts were not respected by nowadays people by seeing the poor display of their statue, you can guess that Vietnamese can only see the old things as a tool to collect money from tourist rather than to look at history to learn from the pastit should be one of the most respectful place but the authorities does not care as it should be as the same in Japan, in Korea or culture-similar countries nearby as visitor, you should look at it carefully to see the hidden message which can show you the power of the old kingdoms and also can reveal the secret of the collapes

interesting and relatively peaceful within the chaotic Hanoi city. Beautiful gardens, lots of temples, interesting architecture, and an ambience of positivity, advancement and tolerance. Worth visiting.

Beautiful Gardens. The gardens surrounding this temple are beautiful. The true significance of the temple was probably lost on we westerners but the buildings and the historic importance is impressive.

Touch the turtles head for good luck. I visited the Temple with friends as part of a guided tour. It took around thirty minutes to complete. It was interesting, if you can touch the turtles head you will also receive good luck. A custom that dates back to when the building was used by students taking their exams.
Interesting temple with beautiful gardens. Long history of temple dedicated to studies. Architecture, and nature/gardens are very much worth a visit in the middle of busy Hanoi.

cool and charming gardens.. We shared the expierence with several school excursioners! they charming traditional uniforms of the girls were lovely, The information was available in english and very informative. Our bicycle rickshaw found it very easly from the old quarter giving us a taste of the hectic traffic in between scooters cars and bicycles.

Averagely interesting. Went here because of the reviews but if in hindsight I'd probably have gone to the Museum of Ethnology or something else. Moderately interesting but lacking information for travellers about the history of it all.

Quick Visit due to celebration. Glad we went, reluctant but daughter insisted we go as she lives in Hanoi. There was a celebration going on the day we visited so it was not as quiet as it could have been, but very interesting..

A center of learning. An amazing place. The Temple of Literature & National University was the first intellectual center of learning. If you visit Hanoi this along with Ho Chi Minh's grave are must places to visit.

Beautiful grounds . We went here on our last day in Hanoi and enjoyed the history of the temple as well as the temple all the way in the back on the second floor of the scholars. We also went across the street after to the fine art museum was was cool. Both places about 2 dollars to visit.
Visiting the Temple of Literature. In my opinion one of if not the best temple or pagoda in Hanoi. Tends to get quite busy with tourist so maybe get their early.

Lovely grounds and buildings . Well kept and interesting. Visited on a tour which was great because it provided information about the temple and the history associated with it. Otherwise do your research prior to visiting as there is little information inside. Beautiful temple and worth visiting.
Visiting once is enough . As we visited at noon so the weather was extremely hot. We didn't even want to stand up and walk. The scene was not that beautiful. And again EXTREMELY HOT!!!!

Really interesting. I came here with a group of friends and it was really beautiful. In Vietnamese culture coming here before exams will bring fortune. You might also see groups of students coming here for their graduation photobook.

A must see to undersand about Vietnamese culture. Luckily, I visited the Temple of Literature when it was not too crowded so I could fully enjoy it. The temple itself contains so much valuable culture meaning. The history of a thousand year, the hidden stories behind every symbol. I searched Hanoi Audio Guide on App Store and this app guided me in every detail so it was a good choice for me with out a tourguide.
nice destination. really love Hanoi and we have ben in there - they are very nice for looking the place for relaxing in Hanoi

Beautiful Grounds and Buildings. We really enjoyed our visit to the Temple of Literature. The grounds themselves are beautiful with lots of gardens and ponds in the Vietnamese fashion. The architecture was some of the most interesting we saw in Vietnam. There are lots of buildings and a couple of courtyards to check out. It is also quite nice to be in a more peaceful setting even though the chaos of the city is right outside the walls of the compound. I would highly recommend checking out the Temple of Literature if you have a little time in Hanoi.
amazing place. this is the first university of VietNam,and honor confucius and Chu Văn An thể very famous teacher on Feudal system It is so quiet and cool in these hot days in summer.

A nice side trip. We enjoyed going to the Temple of Literature but feel like it was meaningful only because we had a guide (from Free Hanoi Tours) to help us appreciate what we were seeing. A beautiful place with beautiful grounds. If you don't have a guide then I would recommend doing some reading ahead of time to help you understand/appreciate what you are seeing. We were glad we went and would recommend going.
Beautiful architecture and gardens. Nice way to discover the Vietnamese architecture and culture. Well kept and easy to walk through. Highly recommend
So nice!. A beautiful place, with a lot of flowers and altars, is peaceful y great to walk in there, definitely a must to visit in Hanoi.

Unmissable, see the golden turtle.. Beyond the main entrance a succession of gates lead from one courtyard to another indicated the stages of learning eventually leading to a doctorate.The third courtyard contains a large pond with buildings on left and right containing the tombstone like stelae on which were inscribed the names & details of the successful scholars.They look illegible to me but it seems they can still be read if you get close enough.We now come to "Great House of Ceremonies" which contains a shrine to Confucius and a life size golden giant turtle.The final building the Thai Toc hall was closed in preparation for some major event, a Graduation Ceremony perhaps?We too were enthralled by groups of charming schoolchildren coming to celebrate the end of the school year.
Beautiful & peaceful. This was the first University in Hanoi, but it no longer serves as a school. The grounds and temples are beautiful and worth a visit.

Pretty and interesting to see the local school children. The buildings are attractive and you learn about Confucius and the rise of Confucionism in Vietnam. With it being exam season we also got to see the local schoolchildren coming to pray to Confucius for success in their exams which was really interesting and the girls all wore long white dresses with flowers in their hair.

Beautiful historic building, not much info. The Temple of Literature is very ornate and beautiful. There is however, not a lot of literature for English speakers with the tour. Koto restaurant and nice little coffeeshop nearby are good.
Nice place!. This used to be the first University of Vietnam and here we heard many stories of Vietnam histories and culture!

Quiet it wasn't . Our review had said this was a quiet bastion from the turmoil of the city. Not quite. It was before finals and it appeared every student in Hanoi was there making offerings and sending prayers for good exam results. Besides every tourist had appeared to come that day. The temple was beautiful and the steles and turtles fascinating. I would suggest a weekday visit rather than a weekend.

Interesting. An interesting place to visit to know about the first temple turned university of Vietnam! I've only spent less then an hour there due to the intense heat, but nevertheless never regret due to the rich heritage of the place!

Great part of our trip !. We booked Hanoi city tour through HALONG BAY CRUISES website and we visited this place as a part of our trip. It was not too crowded and we haf a great chance to learn this is the very first university in Vietnam and hear many great stories about it by our local tour guide. It was worth a visit !

Interesting attraction. This was an interesting place to visit and I suggest you take guided tour as you get everything explained to you. It would have been easy to just walk through and not fully understand the significance of everything without one.

A relaxing break. The Temple of Literature is probably the oldest historical building in Hanoi, dating back 1000 years. Site in a very realising and lovely garden it gives you the opportunity to take break from this chaotic city

Great architecture and design. I'd highly reccommend visiting the Temple of Literature with a guide. We learnt so much about the area with our guide, and if we had just walked through by ourselves we wouldn't have known what the area represented. It's a beautiful property with lovely gardens.
Great with HanoiKids!. Went here on a HanoiKids tour. Well explained and beautiful place with great character. Shrine to confucius particularly impressive

Take it or leave it.. It's a temple with some lovely gardens, quite nice if it's not a stinking hot day with a bunch of graduation ceremonies going on (or at least that's what they looked like). I think if you went here as part of a tour, or with someone who knew something about the history of the place, it would be more interesting. Don't go expecting it to be anything other than a nice garden with some lovely old buildings.
Nice but crowded. Nuce and peaceful place except it isnt really spectacular and also very crowded with school groups. If you don't have much time in Hanoi, I wouldn't recommend it.

Visit the first University in Viet Nam. This is really beautiful for you walking to disscover some interesting place of the first University in Viet Nam. in here, you can see many student come here and take photo after gaduated form University. If you love learning about history, this is a great place for you.

Very interesting history, beautiful building . This university was founded 20 years before Oxford - and the building has original timbers from that time. We were told the wood lasted so long because it was buried under the riverbed for 6 months after being felled, so that the silt entered the gaps in the wood fibres, making them exceptionally strong. A beautiful building with lots of history, you can touch the breast of the Phoenix to give your children good luck in their education ....Well worth a visit!

Not so interesting. The Temple of Literature was not what I thought it would be. While the surrounding gardens are attractive there is not much to learn about the site itself. Maybe some background information before a visit would make it more worthwhile as some others have suggested. I did see some attractive girls being photographed so that was a plus!

Amazing Historical Site. So this university was set up just after William the Conqueror invaded Britain. Kinda telling really. The place is beautifully maintained and it took an hour to go round. The doctors stones where the names of graduates are recorded are a real piece of history. The interpretation was nicely done in English, French and Vietnamese. Beautiful

First Vietnamese university. We enjoyed visiting this charismatic place and were amused that the lake of clarity was so murky, The temple is beautiful, the gardens wonderfully kept and the history of the place worth reading about.
lovely walk through the gardens. Very crowded, but great to wander around. Hot, an umbrella would be good. Read about it before you go so it makes more sense.
Nice an quiet. A very quiet place. Gardens are beautifull. There is not much to read or learn since nothing is described. If you want to visit it is better to read some information about first

Beautiful place to visit . I enjoyed the Temple of Literature more than most of Hanoi's touristy attractions. Lovely gardens and learnt a lot about the history of Confucius. The site of Vietnams first university where original entry was only granted to those of noble birth. We didn't book tickets in advance. We were trying to go to the military museum but it was closed during middle of day so went here. This was way better. We took a cyclo from the old quarter to the temple. Prob a good 15 mins to get there thro crazy traffic. But this was a highlight too. We saw so much from the seat of the cyclo with all the traffic buzzing around, and toward us! Def go by cyclo. They are comfy and it's exhilarating. At the Temple its good to have your lonely planet book or info with you so you can actually sit in the gardens and read about the history while you are there. It makes it more real and enjoyable. As usual in Hanoi, tiger beer is available nearly everywhere so my partner and I sat in the shade, had a drink, watched local university graduates have their grad pics taken and immersed ourselves in the centuries of history of the place we sat.

Simply Beautiful. Our family of 5 visited the Temple of Literature in May 2016. The grounds were well-kept and the architecture quite lovely. Maybe we were lucky as the temple was not very busy. There was just the right amount of information for us to learn about this attraction without feeling overwhelmed by the content. It was a hot day which may prove challenging for some but you can easily walk through the grounds in an hour. Admission was 30,000 dong (free for children). A must-do if you are in Hanoi.

Interesting. Again, I must stress the importance of using Hanoi Kids as tour guides to make the visit more interesting otherwise you will just amble around and not appreciate the Chinese influence on Vietnam.
Our guides were very knowledgeable and made the trip very interesting for us.

Worth a visit . Hanoi is one of those places you walk all day, stopping every now and again to take something in, have something to eat or a drink. $2 per head to walk in (it opens from midday each day) and it is a lovely, peaceful setting and. Nice to walk around. Like everywhere, there are people by the truck load, but nevertheless a good place to have one of those stops (and don't forget KOTO next door for lunch; superb!).
Crowded and noisy . Perhaps I saw too many pagodas and structures before getting here. And way too many school kids in tours didn't help matters. Probably nice late in day in lights and no crowds.
Tranquility. It was a gentle walk back into the Past. And since it isn't a large museum in the terms of artifacts, it wasn't a time eater.

Worth a look. Very interesting temple complex, made very special on our visit as there were quite a few groups of graduating students coming for their group photographs. Always good to see the locals praying at the temples unperturbed by the tourists. Have lunch at KOTO before or after your visit
Lovely tranquil temple. Beautiful grounds to stroll around and a very interesting temple to visit. A small gift shop to take a souvenir home. We really enjoyed the visit.
Loved. Were here during graduation photos, which was amazing. Everywhere should have a temple of literature. Best gift shop in Hanoi.

Edifying!. A lovely sojourn from the bustle of the streets, this is a tranquil and historically important site. Whilst we had done some background reading, we found it helpful to visit as part of a city tour with a guide as he was able to provide a nuance to the stories that can't always be conveyed in guide books. Very easy to visit solo, as we did on later days.
Great!. We went there on a rainy day and the rains made the place even more charming. Nice architecture, interesting history, and beautiful lotus ponds make this a lovely place to visit in Hanoi.

Absolutely fantastic place, not to be missed. Otherwise known as the Temple of Confucius, this place hosts the Imperial Academy, the very first University in Vietnam. We were there on an exceptionally et day, and we had to keep darting Dom one spot o another, but even that didn't detract in any way from the overall impression we got that this place is something right out of the top drawer. It was built in 1070 and, although it is only one of several temples in Vietnam dedicated to Confucius and his sages and scholars, every inch of it resonates study and learning. The site consists of five courtyards, as well as 82 Stelae of Doctors. This is what remains of originally 116 steles, each based on stone turtles of varying appearance. The fifth courtyard was only reconstructed in 2000 because it had been destroyed by the French in 1946. The whole site is set in beautiful grounds and is an absolute "must see" hill in Hanoi.Entrance fee is 15,000 dong and it is open for 8.30am to 4.30pm, although it does close for lunch. I think it is also closed on Mondays and national holidays. . It is about a 10-minute walk from Hoan Kiem Lake.

A PLACE ONE MUST NOT MISS.. This place is not very far from the Old Quarters and it can be reached by taxi or motor bike. If you need exercise, you can walk there too.The Temple of Literature is about 10 minutes away from Hoan Kiem lake. It was constructed in 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong’s dynasty, first to honor Confucius and nowadays to celebrate the doctorates and high rank scholars of Vietnam. In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong continued the work and built Quoc Tu Giam as the first university of Vietnam.The temple is divided into five court yard, each with its own significance and history. The first courtyard stretches from the main gate to Dai Trung gate; the second stands out with Khue Van Cac pavilion. If you notice well, you will find the pavilion symbol on all street signs of Hanoi. The third courtyard is where doctor names was listed on a tombstone above tortoise backs.There are a total of 82 tombstones, with names and origins of 1307 doctors, corresponding to 82 examination courses from 1442 to 1779. If you visit the temple at the beginning of the year or in May when many important examinations take place, you will catch sights of numerous students who come and rub the tortoise head. Such an act is believed to bring them luck to pass the test.If you are keen on architecture, Temple of literature has one of the most typical architecture style for centuries in Vietnam, composed of wood and tiles. Along the pass way is hundred-year-old trees that have witnessed ups and downs of history.The entrance fee for the complex is 10,000 VND (about 50 US cents). Opening hours: 8:30 to 11:30 and 13:30 to 16:30 everyday except Monday and national holidays.

First university in Vietnam. About 10 minutes away from Hoan Kiem lake. It was constructed in 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong’s dynasty, first to honor Confucius and nowadays to celebrate the doctorates and high rank scholars of Vietnam. In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong continued the work and built Quoc Tu Giam as the first university of Vietnam. (Ref: Wikipedia)Worth a visit! 45 minutes to1 hour shd be sufficient.

Go with guide. It was raining when we went there so it was a bit of a hassle. It was also a bit crowded as there were also students taking their graduation pictures (aside from tourists). Nevetheless, we still found the place interesting and good for taking pictures. You can explore the area in less than an hour. Entrance fee is 30,000 dong or roughly 1.5 USD

Must do great seeing local kids having fun . Second time I have visited the Temple of Literature only 30,000 dong to enter the best part of the Temple is seeking all the local students with plenty of color and celebrations taking place plenty of great photo opportunities are available so don't forget your camera.
Temple visit. Nice experience. Very interesting to people who like culture. Nice to see, good to know. Cheap entrance fee. Beautiful temple.

Nice sightseeing place. It is a confucionist temple surrounded by georgeous gardens. Very well maintenained.It is a little crowded, not only by tourists but also by locals. Specially students. When I visited it, there was some sort of school event going on.The entrance fee was 30000 Dangs or 1,40 usd. Nice place to take amazing pictures.

Education starts here. This ancient structure tells the story of hundreds of year old history of Vietnam. It contains all the details of the ancient education system including the uniforms of the teachers students, names of the class toppers. This is the place where the locals celebrates their graduation and take blessing before their exam.

Worth a look. This temple is more like a park than anything else. It has the usual temple like features, and as it is also a place which records the academic achievements of graduates of times past. The grounds are well maintained offering a sort of island of tranquility in the heart of a busy city.

Good for history and culture of Hanoi.. This stop was included as part of our tour of Vietnam. I would suggest you have a guide with you for this attraction otherwise you probably won't get much out of it. Our guide was extremely informative and we learned a huge amount about the beliefs and history and culture of the Vietnamese people.

Beautiful. Had the fortune of going through with not very many other individuals. Pleasant structures and wonderful patio nurseries. Well worth looking at. Attempt and get in ahead of schedule before the visit bunch franticness begins

An oasis of calm in bustling Hanoi. This is a lovely place - not too crowded, with a lovely, restful feel. There's a small charge to enter. A couple of largeish ponds with water lillies on each side of the path leading to the main temple. A worthwhile visit.

Historical place that explains the Chinese influence in Hanoi. Very old complex dedicated for education. Very intresting history that give you some lights about the influence the chinese empire had on the region.
There are so many spots for beautiful pictures. It is recommend that you go with a guide, so they can explain the use of the complex and how it change through time.

Visited on graduation say. Really nice place to spend an hour or so, when we were there it was graduation day and it was interesting to see all the students.
Worth a visit

Quaint Little Temple and Garden Walk. Doesn't take too long to walk through but the lily pads were in bloom and it was a lovely reprieve from the hustle and bustle of the Hanoi streets. Also KOTO is right across the street - don't miss out on this charity with amazing food after walking through the temple!

Nice view for photos, and learn, for sure. I just imagine myself brought back to the past, imagining scholars from around the country studying. That must be very good but challenging situation at that time! Nice view, and you will have some photographers taking pictures of the gorgeous ladies with Ao Dai, especially on Sundays. Try rubbing the crane statue, for good luck. Fare ticket is 30k VND per person.

Historical place. This is an interesting and historical place. Buildings are beautiful and in pretty good condition. I found this place a bit boring though. Also be aware of the taxi drivers outside temple. They are often not confirmed taxis, meters are often fixed and they demand you to pay a lot of money. I recommend to walk a little further from the temple for get an reliable taxi.

Stunning. An architectural wonder in the middle of the city. Enormous pots with outsize bonsai and miniatures hidden among the roots, standing on turtles. there are (stone) turtles everywhere. Was there during graduation time (May) and this is when the graduates come for photos, quite fun to watch, even on a hot day. Offerings to the ancestors included beer cans and choco pies.

Must see attraction in Hanoi.. It was raining when we visited Temple of Literature, but we still had a good time touring this place and saw a traditional Vietnamese performance. There is plenty to see and this ground is big and well kept.
Wouldn't bother going. Just another temple, save those 30.000 for something else if you've seen more than four temples in your life
Very interesting visit. Went with our own guide and really enjoyed learning about the history of early education in Vietnam. Well worth the visit with lots of shady spots on a hot day.

A tranquil oasis in Hanoi. The temple is reached through a series of gardens and squares and is a very pleasant afternoon excursion after the bustle of Hanoi. Worth the visit and, if you are lucky (as we were) you may even catch groups of students arriving in their best finery for their graduation ceremonies.

Part of intrepid tour. A charming place, beautiful gardens. We were fortunate to be there on a graduation day so many students in caps and gowns added excitement and atmosphere . Also saw many younger students praying for knowledge and success at the temple with school principals in support. Only place in Vietnam I had to pay to use the loo and I had no small dong so it was an expensive penny to spend- loos were however clean.

Beautiful . We visited for just over an hour in the late afternoon. It would have been lovely to stay for longer, it was very peaceful despite the traffic outside the walls. The buildings and grounds, and the statues and interiors were all beautiful. There are materials explaining the history, translated to English. Lots of items for sale inside if you need water etc.

Worth a look. When we arrived for our tour, the place was over-run by graduating students in their gowns. The attraction architecture is similar to other sites and quite attractive. If you are there, it is worth visiting but not stunning (may be I am getting "temple wariness").

One of the major attrations of Hanoi. Here in the Temple of Literature you learn about Vietnamese history through their education system, as well as the Chinese influence to the country. This place is sometimes filled with collage students taking photos for their graduation, lots of photo opportunities.You should have a guide to know about everything when visiting this place. Otherwise you won't obtain much from just reading.

Serene and chill but a bit 'meh'. This place was cool and big but it was a little dull in comparison to other things you can see in Hanoi. I'd recommended going to pub street and enjoying yourself and skipping this one.
Must see. A place of history and outstanding beauty. All a good couple of hours. Don't miss the area behind the main hall / temple.Most beautiful gardens.

Enlightened by Temple of Literature. A little distance from lake keim area a taxi was the best option getting here.Very popular with locals & tourists early morning is best time to visit this important historical site..Dedicated to Confucious (Khong Tu) in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong, the Temple of Literature is nowadays used to celebrate the doctorates and high ranked scholars of Vietnam.There are 82 tombstones atop a turtles back with names & origins of 1307 doctors circa 1442-1779 in one section.Other sections have the first university building of Vietnam ,a museum , bell house, drum house ,wonderful gardens, pondsIn early May many students come to rub the head of the turtles for good luck in their upcoming exams. On our visit , many graduation photos were being done.Buy the brochure with your entry ticket to help understand what is what ... Or.. Just wander and appreciate the beauty , serenity and coolness amongst the trees.. Some over 100 years old.Well worth the time visiting it.
A little bit of History . Enjoyed walking around this site and our guide was very knowledgeable which probably made the visit. I now need to read up on Confucius.

Historically important. This is a fascinating place that is historically important. It was one of the first universities and is a Buddhist temple at the same time. No longer a university, it is still a place that trains monks.Very beautiful and worth visiting, but try and get a guide as no literature at the site

Worth a stop. Came here based upon all of the reviews and are glad we did. It's a pretty setting and you get a decent bit of history out of it. Nice place to walk around for a bit. They had a guide brochure of sorts which we bought thinking it would provide a map of the grounds and a bit more information about what we were looking at. Didn't turn out to be the case (really wasn't that informative), so if you're looking to save a little money, you could probably take a pass on that. We only had less than a day in Hanoi and easily fit this into our itinerary since it's close enough to the other main sites in town.
Go with a guide . Nice temple and one of the symbol of Hanoi, but you must go there with a guide,otherwise you will not be able to understand the place
Fun for a short visit. Nice for a brief visit if you are in the area. Some interesting photo ops. It costs 30k VND for entry. You'll spend maybe 30-40 minutes there.

Wonderful to see but not what I was expecting. Lovely to see but can be done in a matter of 20 - 30 mins. Very cheap to get in (about £1 / $1.50) it's been renovated a few times so there is not much in original condition but well worth a visit if your nearby.
Why?. I just don't understand what people found interesting. Nearly all of it us rebuilt and there is no information around the building.
Nice temple. This is a major temple in the City - first part is original but 2nd part is really new, but still a good place to go and have a walk

Interesting. If you are interested in eastern culture you'll enjoy this place. Even though it is called a library, it was actually a school of medicine, the names of the graduates can be seen on the stone tablets on the grounds. The gardens are nicely kept.
A bit of history . Head to the Temple of Literature for a couple of hours to learn the arduous process one had to go through to pass the Royal exam.

Enchanting. One of the more engaging sights in Hanoi. Located quite a distance from Old Town, you will need a cab to get here. The entire complex is enclosed by a peremeter wall except for the entrance, thus what's within the complex is indeed surprising.Wall through the 3 door gate (centre - royalty, right - in, left - out) and a quiet, enchanting garden awaits you. There are many sections to these temple including the main temple buiding that still stands after more than 1,000 years. The temple was build by the Chinese who ruled Vietnam for a very long time. It was dedicated to medical graduates from Vietnam. There are many stone tablets engraved with the graduates names on them. It's indeed surprising to know such a cultured society lived in Vietnam a few centuries ago.If you are hungry, there are a few eating place outside the complex. Turn left when outside and you will see a Bun Cha eating place. Quite good and on budget.

lovely architecture and interesting history. we visited with a guide which made the experience both more interesting and more detailed. We enjoyed the various sections and the history and also the gardens. lots of photo opportunities!

Thank you so much!. I've been there 2 days ago with my friends. The place was beautiful and unique. However, during touring this place by ourselves, one of my friends was trying to taking a picture and she dropped her i phone 6 into the pond! It was really embarrassing at that time... We asked the staffs help and one of them got into the pond, looked it up for her. That must be not easy to find because of lotus and mud. We would like to say that we appreciate your help!
located in Dong Da. Great place to visit ,the temples and gardens are lovely , the history of this temple is amazing , be sure to time your visit when the is a holiday or festival

Love this place. A nice garden and beautiful temple, we went there on a day when students from colleges around hanoi come to take graduation photo. The female student wear gorgeous traditional dress. A good place to visit in hanoi.

Not so much to see. If you have less time for wandering on around vietnam, put this last on your list. Place is a bit small and crowded. Not so much to see except a few altars. Although the garden was good.
On our Own. We went here by ourselves. It was beautiful. If you read about it before you have an idea of everything but they do sell a guide brochure.
Part of a tour. Nice place, lovely gardens and some great facts about the University and the culture. A little boring but part of a tour
Beautiful. It was lovely to walk through and learn about the history, it was very beautiful and great for taking photos. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful place with great history. If you live in Old Quarters Temple of Literature is very near so it is easy to walk there. Weekends it can be crowded and especially during graduation. Really worth of visiting, beautiful gardens and like an oasis in the middle of Hanoi.
Interesting place to visit. It was very interesting walking through this site. The history was interesting and the buildings make it a must place to visit while in Hanoi.

Quite hot in April. It was on a hot day but i still enjoyed my walking around the area. There was a group of people on their package tour and i just joined them to learn abut this first place of Hanoi

Long history of learning on display with modern students. First day in Hanoi and off the Temple and its Graduation day. A huge crowd but all added to the atmosphere. We had a guide who explained the background and history of the place and just what was occurring with the students.We were able to view the tablets showing the classes going back hundreds of years and then walk the gardens to the shrine at the top of the area. The area had an amazing array of statues, idols and more. Great to read about the history and watch the students going through the same routine as hundreds of years before.
Unique place. The temple houses 80+ large stone tablets on which early academic texts are scribed. Set in nice gardens, with explanations in English and French.

Expensive for what it is. Paid for what I feel should be a free attraction as they make money out of you in the gift shops/food venders inside. If you have free time then go have a look but it's not on my top 10 things to do when in Hanoi

Tranquility in the City. This site contains tranquil gardens and nice walking paths away from the hustle and bustle of the busy city. There were fewer tourists here than at many other sites I visited so it was a nice break from the crowds as well.

Wonderful history.. Even if you visit without a tour guide there is much to learn and understand. There are many plaques to read but if you want to learn the significance of it now I recommend visiting with a Hanoi local before exam time.

wisdom is health. went somewhere in the middle of the day, without really having planned...Beautiful and tranquil garden, with notable bonsai and shrub art. some nice buildings.a little crowded though and hard to understand the details without a guide...usual to see students graduating as the temple is the ancient site of VN's first University.

Very interesting introduction to the history . The temple of literature is a must see attraction in Hanoi, with a good guide or guide book it does give some of the ancient history of Hanoi and Vietnam. It is a pleasant site but very busy.
Pretty. Gardens are lovely to look at, lots of children where graduating pre school i believe. Was lovely to see. Doeant take too long to walk through. Turtles where very interesting to see.

Nice compound for a visit. This park/historical site is a collection of gardens, gates, and traditional buildings. Some new, most are old (some dating back a 1000 years). The surroundings are very peaceful, and a stroll here is a pleasant way to pass an hour. This is also Confucian praying grounds and temples, an the first university of Vietnam.The best part though for me were the beautiful bonsai trees.

Great visit, graduations a plenty!. Wonderful old university buildings and temples. The whole place had a lovely atmosphere and as our visit was on a Sunday there were many students in their graduation robes

Fascinating insight. Here we have an 11th century university. At a time of the Norman conquests the vietnamese were building state sponsored centres of learning. Yes, large parts of the buildings have been rebuilt (following American bombardment) but this doesn't detract from the sentiment and feeling of peace engendered. You've got to love a nation that venerates a philosopher and teacher. So take time on your visit and drop in. If you don't feel it what have you lost? An hour or so of your time and a few ding. Well worth the risk if you ask me.
Well worth a visit. Glad I made the visit to the Temple of Literature. Low cost entry. Lovely gardens.,trees and shrubs. Many splendid buildings.

Interesting and peaceful. The Temple of Literature & National University had a wealth of history especially the 82 stelae which have the carved names of the scholars who passed the royal exams. The tortoise sculptures were also beautiful. The nicest part of the Temple was the peacefulness of the site. I would recommend to those who want to learn more of Vietnam's history.
A must see. Beautiful.. Our guide was superb. The temple is lovely and is an oasis in the middle of busy Hanoi. This was the first university in Hanoi.
Awesome. Had the fortune of passing through with very few other people.Nice buildings and beautiful gardens.Well worth checking out. Try and get in early before the tour group madness starts

A historic place to visit. I went there with friends. The game we enjoyed was to take a photo to imitate the scene on the 100,000vnd note. And the rock inscriptions were interesting, especially because we can read the Chinese characters on them. Deep inside there's a hall to play Vietnamese music. We bought some of the traditional musical instruments in smaller sizes. A nice place to spend half day there.
Lovely temple in peaceful surroundings. A fascinating historical site, well worth a visit. The Confucian temple itself is beautiful, and the gardens are lovely.

Peace in the middle of Hanoi. This is a beautiful place with a lovely calm atmosphere, really nice break from busy Hanoi. Beautiful buildings and gardens and really interesting history, You would probably only spend about an hour here, but I'd still reconmend it !

Escape the hustle. A lovely tranquil escape from the craziness of Hanoi :) The gardens and buildings are lovely. It's nice to visit a place where learning was celebrated over a 1000 years ago and the names of great scholars recorded and cherished. There isn't much on display that is translated to English so if you don't have a guide you won't understand most of what you're seeing. It's is still a beautiful place.

Choose on attraction in Hanoi and go here with a good guide. Been here several times with guides and guests. If you have a good guide there are so many stories about this place. It is beautiful, creates a love for learning and don't miss to take a picture with you and your friends and family together with all these very happy students who visit. And just consider if they continued to build the road like these pathways....you would never walk in water like on many Hanoi roads when it is raining heavily.

Surprisingly interesting and inspiring.... My first reaction when told that we were going to the Temple of Literature was 'oh god another temple'. BUT, I was pleasantly surprised and learned much about the ingrained tradition of education, teaching and learning in Vietnam.During our visit we watched several groups of students celebrating their graduation and it was inspiring to see their proud and happy faces. The temple has managed to maintain some of the 'head stones' celebrating the highest achieving graduates in their 1000+ year history. It was a pity that the temple didn't have a leaflet or signage in English providing explanation of the inscriptions highlighting those students' achievements.If you want to get the most of this temple I suggest you go with a guide who can give you a sense of the Vietnamese people's attitude towards the importance of education. Definitely worth visiting.

An heaven of peace. 1. Quiet, quiet, and quiet, so relaxing in the middle of a crazy tow2. Easy to access3. Good preservation4. Not need to be a smart intellectual to appreciate5. Nice for the monuments, airy for the gardens

Watch out for this taxi scam. We got out of the Tran Quoc Pagodaand this taxi guy zeroed in on usHe was a sweet talker, very smooth and offered his taxi serviceWe got in and he rode us around town pointed out interesting landmark and sweet talking the whole timeHe mentioned this was peak commute time so the rate was extra!!!We later on found out this was bogusSo the most expensive taxi from Tran Quoc Pagoda to Temple of Literature was 500000 dong ($20)We only realized the scam after the fact so we did not get his picture or anything to show the authorityThis guy was actively talking to tourists to use his serviceWatch out

walk with a local guide for the fuller picture, large site.. We took in this site and story with a local walking tour. The structures within the walls, the gardens and even the ponds have hidden meanings and uses. Best to have an understanding as you walk through, to see how the buildings and surrounds inter-relate brings the site's history to the minds eye. We were lucky to have a local guide who started his explanation of the Temple before we entered the site. The pond outside is a part of the temple routine as well...Lots to see when the history is explained. Nice respite from the traffic and pace of the modern day.

Unexpectedly interesting. Our guide suggested this visit and we politely but reluctantly agreed. To our surprise we found it fascinating. Older than any European universities recording degree recipients over 1000 years old. Still holds great symbolic imports for today's students in a society that puts great importance on education. Live traditional music was an added bonus. You need a guide to get the most out of the visit.
Interesting and calming. The area is convenient to visit great restaurants such as Koto and is an interesting and calming break from the major-hustle of Hanoi.
Pleasant place to visit.. Interesting place to visit – one hour is enough. A pity that the ‘teachings’ in the stones are not translated to English…

Inspiring. Walking through the history of the National University was an absolute inspiration! Luckily for us a graduation of the nations brightest was occurring at the same time as we were there. I recommend that you double the time you think you need to ensure you capture the full atmosphere of the confusion spirit that abounds this wonderful piece of Vietnam.
You'll need a local guide to explain everything. Lots of buildings and gardens to see. Lots of history and symbols that need explanation so make sure you have a local guide.

Wonderful but confusing.. During our visit to the temple of literature we got a little confused.We paid our entrance fees, headed in and started wandering around.It was beautiful with a wonderful garden, clean courtyards and beautifully designed buildings. The information posted was awesome too. Just enough information to help you understand the temple.Where it started to get confusing was when we left. We walked out the gates and followed the road up along the outside of the temple. It was towards the back where we realized we had missed an entire area. The main temple/school is behind the building housing the statues of Confucius and the teachers.We had missed this entirely as there's no clear path around or any clear signage. We had seen the information describing the layout and were confused at not seeing this final spot, now we know why.We turned around and tried to get back in to go see it, but we couldn't get in without a new ticket.This was hugely disappointing and could've been avoided with a little clear signage.Altogether we enjoyed our visit but would've liked it much more if we had made it to our main destination. We would recommend it, but would strongly advise seeking out the main temple/school which must often be missed based on this same issue.

Historical education centre. A revered historical site over 1000 years old devoted to education and the training and testing of bright students , sourced nationwide. Not a lot to see than exrtremely old buildings and one modern reconstruction. Most notable is the relative calm and freedom from traffic noise all pervading in Hanoi. Major disappointments are that most explanatory displays are only in the Vietnamese language and there are too many gift/souvenir outlets spread throughout the complex, at least 5. Allow 1 hour to visit. Entry free VD30,00.

Full of history. You can feel the vibrance of history in this place. A place for scholars since ancient times. Nowadays converted to a temple for the present generation of students to pray for good exam results.

Quiet and near solitude. I visited the Temple of Literature on my way home from work. Dusk was falling and the place was nearly empty, save for a few people exercising around the sides of the gardens. The buildings are beautifully preserved and the gardens beautiful, especially the ancient pools of water lilies. I will go back to feel that peace again in the middle of the chaotic city.
Worth a visit! . It has an entrance fees of 30000VND. One would pass 4 courtyards before reaching the temple. Each courtyard has its own importance and is very well maintained.

Slow burner. The Temple of Literature is not a place that impresses immediately, when seen from the slightly chaotic entrance, but as you pass through each courtyard section the place starts to pull you in. The temple has been there for almost one thousand years and the Confucius connection and all those stelae honouring doctors and mandarins of the period as well as the memorials to great philosophers of the day start to work their charm.Our guide seemed to have his own private descriptive version of each courtyard and lost interest around the 3rd or 4th. It was only by luck we pressed on to find ourselves among the buildings of the 5th courtyard. There were some Vietnamese girls playing quiet melodies on local musical instruments and the atmosphere was much more tranquil in that area and even the air seemed cooler. Hardly anyone else seemed to have reached that end of the complex so it was possible to explore the lower and upper floor in relative peace. Coming back through the courtyards we found most of the tourists and locals clustered around the souvenir shops and drinks/ice-cream outlets.Read a good guide book or online source before coming here, it will make the whole visit so much more worthwhile.
Important Attraction.. Large ancient area which can get busy. Students have their post grad photo's taken here. Plenty to see plus toilets and two shops available. Good photo opportunities.
Beautiful. Very interesting place where university graduates go upon graduation to give thanks. Beautiful gardens and buildings.

Hmmm...meh. It was okay and had some interesting history but overall this is something to do if you can't find anything else to do. To be honest I found the groups of giggling school children more interesting than the location. They had a ball taking pics of me.
Some cool pieces of garden art. Not quite what we expected. Only 30k entrance & nice little area to walk around. Not much shelter from sun, shady bits are great.

Graduation day. Vietnam's first university and an interesting place to walk around with several pavilions and temples with open courtyards and pretty gardens.It was graduation day when we were there which was quite entertaining as there were lots of groups having their pictures taken, throwing their mortar boards etc
Very impressive. Very impressive. Architect is amazing. A popular destination for graduations, etc. Very busy so go early.
Worth a trip. Learn about the previous scholars within Vietnamese history and see some interesting architecture, decent explanations in English +/- lonely planet
Nice escape from busy Hanoi streets . Beautiful spot. Visited by crowds of people. Good photo opportunity. There are many annoying street sellers at the entrance so keep walking and ignore them.
Another site with our Hanoi Free Walking tour guide. Very interesting spot with several pagodas. College students like to go with class mates to take group graduation photos.

big temple, good restauration. We walked to the temple coming from Ba Su road. We were there at about 9 am. There were some groups. When we leaved, about 1 hour later, there was so many people. You can pay for a guide. We have good travel guides, for us it was enough. Big temple with good restaurations and good English and French explications

Uninteresting. It really is just a largish, not wholly kempt compound with a central courtyard, a temple, some steles that can only be understood if you know Vietnamese, and a smattering of souvenir stores. There are far more architecturally interesting things to see in Hanoi, to justify the trek out to Van Mieu just for a stroll through a dusty compound. It may have historical significant, but you can't quite experience it when visiting. One way to have a more interesting visit is to come on a weekend or holiday, when the locals descent upon Van Mieu with great enthusiasm. It's interesting to watch graduation parties and wedding couples, and that's about it.

Beautiful old buildings & very informative!. The tickets are only 30,000 and you can spend hours looking round inside (or whiz through quickly!) The buildings are gorgeous, there's lots of green in the surrounding gardens and park, it's certainly the most peaceful spot in Hanoi!There are lots of well translated signs that are very informative, you can certainly learn a lot here!
Fascinating place. An interesting insight into the links between temple and education in Vietnam. The temple and gardens are nice to wander around and absorb the atmosphere.

A great place to visit. This complex is much bigger than we expected as you progress through a series of arches into the next area. We were fascinated to see the names of each years graduates in medicine written on tablets that resembled grave headstones. The architecture was amazing and it is well worth a visit. Allow at least an hour for your visit.
Most important Temple in Hanoi. This place is very beautiful and calm.Its the most important Temple and ancient university in Hanoi.Full of student coming to take picture in their graduation day.

One of the best attractions. Hanoi City is not just the old Quarters. You would not understand Hanoi if you just confined yourself within the maze of streets in the Old Quarters. You should venture west and explore the attractions which cluster around the Citadel, the Lenin Square and the West Lake. I started my exploratory `Journey to the West’ from my hostel in the Old Quarters. Early morning, I visited the bustling Dong Xuan market, strolled my way to the Imperial Citadel of Thang Long, passed by some beautiful pagodas, the renowned Catholic Church of Hanoi and visited the aged old Chua Tran Quoc Pagoda at the tranquil West Lake. Turned southwards from the West Lake, I also visited the Military Museum and by the time I came out from the museum and walked across the road to show my respect to the statue of Lenin, it was already past noon. After a short rest at the Lenin Square, I proceeded to the Ho Chi Min mausoleum and the Presidential Palace before culminating my one day’s exploration in this Temple of Literature. The temple is located beside a park towards the south of the Citadel. I visited the park and the side door into the temple was open on that day and I entered without buying an admission ticket. The outlook of the temple bears the stamp of the same unique and elegant Vietnamese architectural design you find in temples and pagodas in the imperial city of Hue. However, the interior architectural layout, the courtyards, the deities and the doctor’s stelea resembled those I saw in the Confucian Temples in Beijing and Qufu. Even the characters on the walls were in Chinese characters and showed the deep influence of Chinese culture and Confucian philosophy in Vietnamese culture. The feudal ancient Vietnamese dynasties adopted the Chinese model of the Confucian Imperial examination to select talented government officials to run the country. Surprisingly, the Academy was built with a focus on educating the royal families and the elites. The emphasis in Confucianism is the cultivation of virtues and values in the individual like filial piety, loyalty, benevolence, integrity and his character. Through the imperial examination, people of character and good virtues are elected to run the government machinery.
