It was one of the best system during those era where the lower socio economic class of the society can find their way up through the academic ladder despite their class status, thus an advanced and a very meritocratic educational system. However, the assessment syllabus was based solely on literature and the humanistic arts not on science or engineering. As such, the country remained technologically backwards like China under the Ching Dynasty and could not withstand the onslaught of the cannons of the French colonialists. When I walked out to the front entrance of the temple, I noticed a young pretty Vietnamese lady donned in white `ao dai’ costume was standing near the entrance of the temple. Her gorgeous figure, the shining black long hair and her silky smooth white Vietnamese traditional costume contrasted in lustre with the front façade of the temple, creating a unique, mesmerizing and spectacular local appeal. Despite suffered severe damage during the Vietnam War, this Temple retains her quaint beauty in the ancient architecture set in a background of well-manicured garden landscape dotted by the few frangipani trees planted near her entrance. Among the attractions in Hanoi, I would rank the temple as one of the best.
Old value. This place distance over 3km from our hotel. Place for old value in the city. Would recommend for all. No much complained this place in Hanoi. Recommend to everyone!

Underwhelming visit. Visited here straight after Hoa lo prison (which was extremely interesting) and was left very underwhelmed by the place. Yes it may of had pretty grounds and scenery but there wasn't much to see! Also a lot of the placards had no English translation so unless you bought a guide book at the entrance (20,000vnd) you will be clueless!

Interesting place, a great meaning in Vietnam history. This is an important place for its meaning in Vietnam's history and culture. It was the first "University" (only for the family and friends of the Emperor) but at slightly over one century old, not so ancient as other similar places in Europe. Nevertheless, very significant since it only was related to philosophy and budas's religion. Impresive is the fact that 2/3s of the structures were demolished by bombings during the last war, most of them now rebuild.
Worth a quick visit if you have time.. The oldest university in Vietnam but reserved for future kings. Interesting and worth a quick look around the temple and grounds if you have time.
Serenity in midst of Hanoi. Small complex that was Confucian school of early Vietnam. Not a lot to see, but it is easy to get the idea of principles and experiences for students. Lovely garden.

Guided Tour. Interesting temple and grounds. Definitely need a guide to explain everything. Nice compact little area for those not wanting to trawl large compounds, this gives great history with eye catching temple and altars.

Aussie Adventurers Abroad. The name sounds a little misleading. It is a temple. There is an area for children to play. The are meditation area. There are lots of bonsai. It can be a serene place away from the noisy street life.

the proceedings. i used to take pictures here, but it's quite crowed when the proceedings of students come. i came here when it was raining and we must use umbrella until the rain stopped, the sky was clearer then

Beautiful place. We took a cab here on our visit to Hanoi. It is a lovely place, but as we went on a weekend, it was quite crowded. Normally I would have been upset because last time I visited (six years ago) it was very peaceful, but this time there were college students celebrating their graduation. Seeing all these young people having their graduation photos wearing their gowns and tossing their hats into the air, seemed so appropriate at the temple of literature. My grandchildren were fascinated by the musical instruments. It was a beautiful morning, very evocative.

Interesting look into the past. A bit awing when you consider this "third world" country had such a focus on education so far before the western world. Great gardens, lovely architecture and easy walk from Old Quarter.
Very Pleasant. There was a lot to see here, and the organisation by staff was top notch. There was a good amount of refreshment stalls to pick from. Toilets were clean.

This was a disappointment. You can read up about the place on google and know what it is! The complex is insanely crowded and is a tourist trap.There are no sign boards for tourists to understand what the place is about. Make sure you don't hop on a taxi waiting for you right outside, as you can get conned like we got!

Beautiful architecture. Loved the beautiful oriental architecture of the buildings, and especially the red timbers and design of the temple at the far end. Worth a look and relaxing wander in the pretty gardens.

Beautiful peaceful oasis in busy Hanoi. An incredible peaceful temple in the midst of this busy city, the temple of Literature is an oasis. Green gardens and interesting buildings with list of history...

WARNING WARNING. I am a regular business visitor to Hanoi and almost every trip we visit the Temple of Literature and have lunch at KOTO. Please beware of taxi from this area. I have been to this area twice in the past few days and both times the taxi driver has tried to rip us off. First time he drove around and around (I have been to Hanoi twenty times) meter got to 69,500vnd, too much but no big deal. When I went to pay he yelled at us that it was 700,000vnd which is AUD $45. He was actually quite scary and very loud. I had to get very firm and start shouting for POLISI, at which point he quickly took off. Today, we hailed taxi, got a few metres and realised his meter was already at 46.000vnd, told him, he changed back to 6,000, but in about 500metres it was up to 60,000vnd! Told him to stop, took photo of him and his cab, he quickly said no money, no problem and sped off. This is obviously becoming a bad problem. The taxi ride from Old Quarter to Temple of Literature should be 20,000-30,000vnd. BEWARE, authorities should really be policing the temple areas.

Without a guide, it's a useless visit . Except for the transient serenity you feel walking into a temple of learning and spirituality, you will gain nothing by visiting this place without a knowledgeable guide. We left the place with just as much knowledge of what it stands for and represents as before our visit.

Ticket seller tried to rip me off. I visited this place on April 16, 2016 and the woman working at the ticket counter gave me £30 less in change than I was owed. I walked away and then turned back around to see her watching me and as I walked back she gave me the rest of my change, which was still in her hand. Sketchy. It's off putting to have a museum worker try and rip you off.

Well worth a Visit. The place has lots of historical significance. It was built in 1070 AD following 1000 years Chinese rule. So even though the rule had transferred to the Vietnamese, the Chinese influence is evident. The temple of learning, or the first university of Vietnam, is dedicated to Confucius. Inside we can see statue of Confucius with his disciples. Besides the historical buildings, many of which were rebuilt following war against the U.S. occupation, of particular note are many magnificent Bonsai trees.

Stunning. Wonderful place to visit. We walked here from our hotel in the old quarter and it took us about 25 minutes (slow walking ).The place is gorgeous. We spent about an hour there. There were school groups too. Lots of souvenir shops on the grounds. But still beautiful.
Lovely Place. It's a mandatory visit in Hanoi. It's quite close to city center. Hire a guide to explain you the meaning of all temples. Nice gardens and you will get nice pictures
Hanoi temple of Literature. A pleasant way to spend 1-2 hours, well-maintained temple, clean, nice gardens , some very old and interesting trees, not too far from the Mausoleum.

Beautiful people watching place. Beautiful structure and gardens. Great place to sit and watch students who come to get blessings or just for pictures after graduation. Nice place to spend some time and observe the Vietnamese people.

Nice place to visit. It was very busy when we were walking around this historic place. It was nice and it was interesting to see the students posing for graduation pictures. A guide was helpful to explain the history.
Beautiful space.. This was a lovely experience. The area is maintained beautifully. There were several school groups there during my visit but they simply added to the ambiance.
Really enjoyed the day.. Really enjoyed the day. very interesting and also very relaxing - well worth the visit and a very interesting day

Great place to visit in Hanoi. . This is a great place to visit for history and cultural buffs. The temples are nice but sometimes can be overcrowded with tourists. One of the great places to visit when in Hanoi.

Relaxed visit. Lovely place to wander and absorb some more of this country's history. School concerts and kids singing only added to the atmosphere. On spying the Aussies they were keen to practise their English skills which was very cute!

DAY OUT. This place is so interesting, beautiful gardens, lots to see and learn about Vietnamese education from the past and the architecture. Fascinating time spent here. You need a guide to understand a more in depth explanation of this temple.
Interesting site for a wander. For a small fee you can enter this site, which is, I believe, a kind of ancient university. Well-maintained gardens and buildings are well worth a look.

A must for history and architecture buffs. We enjoyed strolling through this quite deceiving large complex - if it's not your thing, you can become over-saturated with history, but for those interested I think you will find it an excellent site. It is dedicated to scholastic achievements and a good example of traditional Vietnamese architecture. It's a little oasis away from the hustle and bustle of always busy Hanoi

Interesting place. You do not need a lot of time at this place but it is very interesting. We had a guide who walked with us and explained the different items on display. Without a guide you most likely will not understand the history and significance of this place.

Peaceful in the busy Hanoi. I like to return many times to this impressive garden with old University and law tables. Full of symbols, with pagodas, stone turtles and gardens framed with lotus flowers ponds. You can feel the History.

Beautiful architecture. The Temple of Literature is a beautiful complex of buildings with many centuries of history. It is well worth a visit, though it gets very crowded as young student from outside Hanoi come here to celebrate their graduation and ask for luck with their studies.
Not Fussed. Large complex, the size deceiving when you first enter, however can't say that it's a must for an itinerary. I would have preferred to have spent the time elsewhere.

Pretty. It's a beautiful place needing a wee bit of a touch up. It would only take 10 minutes to go in and out. Much better things to do. We was lucky to see some school kids to a class but nothing huge to go on about

Nice place for taking photos. Quoc Tu Giam is well known as the first Vietnamese University. You will see a lot of senior students come here in Ao dai - Vietnamese traditional dress for taking photo book. I'm sure that you guys will love the buildings and scenery here
Peaceful place. I'm always proud of our country history whenever I visit Temple of literature. The place is nice even for the citizens
Nice place for photos. We went during a graduation and it was packed! however it was nice to walk around. We got some good photos from it.

stunning. An incredible place .proof that good architecture is timeless. If you are feeling a little overwhelmed by the pace of Hanoi ,as I was, then chill out at this beautiful place. Even with the crowds the temple still works its' magic .If kids ask to have their photo taken with you don't worry they are not trying to hustle you, apparently children from rural areas like to have photos taken with tourists.

Very intersting and historical place where I had athe pleasure to meet Christine lagarde who is the Head od IMF!. This is a must in Hanoi.
Most interesting.
A lot of Students visit tis place and get their pictures taken in various places of this Center.

Interesting but maybe needs a guide. I spent an hour wandering around the complex but wasn't fully sure about what I was looking at and the significance of it. There are some signs in English around but I think maybe some online research beforehand or getting a guide there if possible would have made the experience more fruitful

A peaceful beautiful place. The beauty is awesome take your time to wonder through all the buildings. I also think it is good to take a guide with you just so you get to know the history behind the site

Nice place with lovely architecture . Beautiful grounds with loads of history. We visited here as part of a private tour. Lots of information and a place good for young and old. My blond kids got a bit mobbed and had fifty photos taken with the randoms in the grounds.

A deep insight into Vietnamese culture. I am Vietnamese but this is the first time I've been to the Temple. It was such an amazing day. I met a group of student and they offered me to use an app which guides me about the temple. At first, I bought the ticket and just entered, didnt't pay any attention to the Great Gate or the Four Pillars. After that, I realized that everything here has symbolic meaning which stunned me, I was so moved to know more about the culture of this land - more than 1000 years. If you visit the temple, you may search Van Mieu Audio Guide on Google Play or App Store, I'm sure you'll feel the same as me!
Mediocre site. The entry area was visually appealing. However, the site did not have much to offer. Be sure to have money in order to use the bathroom.

A must see...best with a local guide.. The Temple of Literature has an important place in Vietnamese culture. Students still believe it is good luck to make a pilgrimage there before an exam, or upon graduation. There is no English and yet with a guide it comes alive. The story of the turtles and the panels depicting the important virtues of life.

Absolutely beautiful . Stunning gardens, lots of history and beautiful architecture. Very cheap entry, brilliant for photographers, easily accessible, small shops to buy souvenirs and drinks, right in the middle of busy streets. Plenty of culture.
Highlight of my stay in Hanoi. Awesome structure. Clear description of monuments in English. Near the Museum of Fine Arts, Closing hour at 6pm Consider dropping by KoTo for nice dinner thereafter!
vietnam 2016. excellant temple and whilst there this time a number of graduates were having there pictures taken... its a very peaceful place in the middle of the city...
Interesting place to visit. A nice walk around the grounds. Interesting architecture and history. Nice to see students recently graduating and having their photos taken in this historic place.

Enjoyable. We really enjoyed this temple. Well worth the price of admission to see such an ancient temple dedicated to valuing scholarly work. It was graduation day when we visited and there were many students taking pics in their robes which me it even more special.
Compulsory but of limited interest. Good for a stroll. Unable to grasp the interest of this visit. But not much else to do in Hanoi anyway. Avoid on a rainy day.

Good place to understand the ancient schooling system in Vietnam. The place is in the middle of the city so easier to get to. You can get to understand the ancient schooling system of vietnam at this place. Would recommend to go with a guide

Interesting Facility and the first University in Vietnam. The facility was the cornerstone of education from the early days. There is little to guide the visitor as little written in English. On the day that we visited a group of students were graduating and it is presumed that the facility was used as a photo opportunity. Well preserved and centrally located. Note - many of the public exhibits are closed on a Monday.

Amazing Experience. The Temple of litreture is a Temple of Confucius in Hanoi Vietnam, it is well over 1000 years old and an amazing place to understand the value and meaning of education in Vietnam.The temple hosts the "Imperial Academy" Vietnam's first national university. Many students visit here to get blessings and have pictures taken when they graduate, definitely worth a visit.

A charming afternoon. We arrived there without any expectations . ...We really had a good time, walking around the natural setting and enjoy the superb traditional architecture . Thevisit enables a better understanding of Vietnamese culture and history . Nice site and good heritage preservation efforts.**We enjoyed live music and had a nice calligraphy done by an artist on site

A visit with a tour guide. Rose was our guide for the morning and this was our first stop. The information was interesting and gave us insight to the Vietnamese culture. The temple was very old and respected by locals and visitors alike. Some maintenance is needed on walkways to assist in safety. But it is accepted there are higher priorities in this city.

Serene and peaceful. We visited the Temple of Literature one afternoon and found it beautifully peaceful and serene. Not too overcrowded at that time of day. The artefacts inside the grounds were wonderfully displayed and well looked after. We even witnessed some form of school based ceremony with many children sat in rows listening to what we assumed to be a teacher. This included chanting and music from the monks in the temple area at the back. It added to the whole experience. The grounds are relatively small, but we'll worth a look and very quiet considering you're inside Hanoi, a very noisy and busy city at the best of times!!

Interesting tourists at this site - it was us!. Some amateur gardens near the entrance but moving deeper into the property it became more interesting. During the American war the people of Hanoi filled the area with sand so the American pilots couldn't see the pagoda and then drop some bombs. Pretty smart. It was just uncovered a few years ago. While walking around many young teens came up to us to have their picture taken with us and also practice their English. We were a little shocked by this but our guide explained that many of these kids are from out lying areas and do not see tourists that often. We discovered this even more later through the rest of Vietnam. The tourist industry in still in its infancy.

Wonderful First University of Vietnam. You just feel full of knowledge when you enter. It is calm, historical, and wise. It is where great ancestors of Vietnam have spent their time training to lead the country. What a honor feeling when I step into this place. It is just out of the noisy streets of Hanoi, it makes people calm and happy to know about the knowledge transfer from here.
Amazing place. This place distance more 1km from Old Quarter. The place were fantastic for tourist ! Only complain about the small lake do not a lot water and not clean
Definitely recommended. You must have a tour guide to fully appreciate this beautiful, historic place. The best time to visit early in the morning.

check out the history. lots of tourists but worth a look at this world heritage site. If you can get a guide - or over hear some others it will add to your understanding. Make sure you rub the stakes great and tortoises head for luck and longevity!

Great insight into Hanoi History. We went on the weekend and the temple and surrounding parks were full of locals and there was a festive atmosphere.The Temple was full of Student groups who had just graduated and traditionally pray at the Temple to give thanks - it was interesting to observe the event. Local people were also attending the Temple to pray & offer gifts .We had a guide with us who had a great knowledge of the history and could provide great explanation of each of the sections of the Temple making it an informative tour. I think if we had just visited without anyone to explain the history it would have been an interesting place to visit rather than the historically stunning place it became with our guide ( Highly recommend Buffalo Tours).

Wouldn't miss this. Confucius temple really fascinating. I went with a tour guide and he provided the group with fascinating insights of the life of Confucius and what he means to the people of Vietnam. We were also lucky to see university students out in their costumes taking pictures. Was really a great experience.
Beautiful temple. A beautiful temple in Hanoï. Peaceful and not far from the center, it worth the entrance fee. Nice place in this busy city.
Interesting. This gives an idea of the past in Vietnam and allows greater understanding of the culture of the country.
Great history stop. School of Confucianism going back about 700 years. They day that I went there were hoards of recent graduates from local schools

Definitely worth a look. This was very interesting to see as we had a guide with us who could explain what each section was as we went in. I think if we had just wandered in without anyone to explain the history it would have been just a lovely place too look at rather than the historically fascinating place it became with our guide.

Delightful , very happy atmosphere . I loved this temple. People of all types were there including very young children who came to pay their respects. We were lucky enough to see the arrival of a group of students who traditionally come here when they pass their exams.

Worth a visit. A must see place and one of the cultural highlights of Hanoi. Landscaped gardens lead to the courtyards with their pavilions, temples and historic buildings. There are five courtyards and it is worth going to each of them. It is a place of learning and exudes a feeling of serenity. We enjoyed a few hours wandering around and enjoying the peace
Temple. Confucius temple. Lovely ancient trees. A giant well. Had a beautiful piece of calligraphy done by ancient man. $5 but worth it

Good for a short visit, weekends crowded but still OK. We spend some time on an afternoon during weekend, and there was a lot of people, but it was still OK to go around and take a look. Interesting how students go there for graduation photos or to pray for good results in Tests. 30 minutes will be enough for a visit.
Very interesting.. This venue was part of out tour of Vietnam. Interesting with some amusing sculptures! You can go in the houses, which give some insight as to how people used to live.
Very nice but crowded. Very nice Place, worth the visit, but be prepared to find hundreds of people there, local and non local.
nice. It must have been graduation day so it was crowded with students and visitors. Still interesting but not as interesting as I had anticipated.

Busy. This was an interesting temple with lots of local students having graduation photos there. As with others, it is a bigger site than first appears. It is interesting but there are plenty of other similar attractions in Vietnam.
Inspiring place. Very nice, interesting place full of history. We had a very good guide from Hanoikids, who told us a lot about this amazing place.

Historic site. This temple is dedicated to followers of Confucius and goes back to the 13th century when students took royal exams. Stelaes dedicated to each graduate surround a courtyard with the stones sitting on top of a turtle. There are various altars and beautiful gardens to stroll around.
Iconic temple. Interesting historical temple. Worth having a guide as little is translated, easy to spend an hour or so here viewing the various elements.

20 minutes max with children. Quite beautiful buildings in the center of Hanoi. Beautiful statues and interesting topiary based on the 12 sacred animals. Arrived at the time when lots of vietnamese school children were in attendance to make offerings to Confucious. Our children got bored quite quickly. Even the gift shop, full of usual nik naks, was boring to them. Very crowded. The lotus ponds had nothing in. I imagine they can be quite beautiful but not in April. A one time event for us. Entrance fee is 30,000 Dong.

Interesting!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Nice spot to wander about and escape the crazy Hanoi traffic, take a few snaps and let the kids chill out for a bit.

Step back in time . This was situated in a park just in the middle of a traffic island but peaceful once you step through. Make sure you go all the way through the different pagodas to see the temple and climb up to view the courtyard

Step back in time. A great place to visit to understand some of the history of Vietnam and to also see why education today is still a very important part of their society.It's lovely to see school groups there learning more about the history of their country.Some great historical artefacts and a lovely place to just sit for a while and leave the busy city behind for a bit.
very nice nice complex of old buildings. very nice nice complex of old buildings highly important for the history of the culturenice gardensalmost quiet - ideal to go and sit and read or think

Great if you make it before the crowd.. This is the most attractive visit in Hanoi in my view. If you're lucky, you'll find groups of students celebrating their graduation, you'll find pre wedding bride and groom having fabulous pictures taken and you'll always find amazing huge groups of very young school kids being taken around by frightening young looking teachers.The backdrop is wonderful with small lakes and other water features decorated with colourful local adornments, whilst the temple itself is a fabulous building with some wonderful images inside.Only downside if you love photography is the invasion of CocaCola machines which I've needed to Photoshop away - capitalism strikes everywhere!
Interesting. Interesting to see.Many students there having their pre graduation photos taken.Was busy on a Sunday.
Quiet oasis in busy Hanoi. Well preserved, interesting and a much-neededbreak from buzzling Hanoi. And the entrance fee is almost embarrassingly low.

Interesting and well presented. This large area has English boards and is impressive for it's layout and focus. It consists of a temple complex and the usual gift boxes. A guide is needed to achieve full value - do this one with a group or a tour.

Historic Part of Vietnamese History. This temple to Confucius was the first university of Viet Nam and continues as a place of learning today. It is situated in a relatively small park with many topiaries. With a good guide to explain, there is great historical significance and it may be the most interesting site in Ha Noi.

Fascinating temple in the heart of Hanoi!. We visited this temple on a 1/2 tour (the first of two) in Hanoi. It is a beautiful temple with gardens and a pond. We were lucky enough to be there when a few groups of school graduates were there (apparently it is typical that when the teens graduate from school they have their photos taken in caps and gowns in the Temple of Literature).

Cheap so worth going. . Went with my family and got a reduced price as I'm at university. Nothing particularly special if you've been to a temple before but interesting to see what kind of things people studied. Full of your standard American tourists with guides but worth a visit.
Pleasant Place to Visit. Small site located within the city centre consisting of some small gardens and 2 small temples to walk through. The visit would probably last about 30 minutes to an hour.
Interesting calmness!. Was their old university and still is a school. Good history. Easy to access. Interesting calmness once inside.

Hanoi visitor day. Was able to visit the temple whilst visiting Hanoi and where luckily enough to also be there when there was a load of students graduating! Celebrations, balloons and Vietnamese selfies all going on! Beautiful and made the visit!

Tranquil oasis in the middle of Hanoi. The Literature Temple is a good place to spend 1-2 hours just wandering around the area or sitting in the shade of a tree watching people milling about. Very idyllic and tranquil...

An oasis of calm in this buzzing city. A must see, use a guide or do some research to fully appreciate the history. Remember to cover up and if you visit on a Saturday there can be trips of schoolchildren there.

A Thousand Years Old. Standing in front of the much photographed temple you can imagine what it was like in 1070 when it was built as a tribute to Confucious. Its pleasant gardens make it an enjoyable spot to relax and watch art students sketching the buildin.

Interesting if you've got time to kill.... It's always cool to see ancient sites and this one is no different. I can't say that it's a must-see, but if you have some time to see the tourist sites then definitely include this one.
Very interesting. This is a very interesting site and having a guide to explain the history helps a lot. A very peaceful and beautiful location with a lot of history.
Nice place to visit in Hanoi. In the heart of Hanoi, very close to the old quarter. Very nice temple, can get busy with tourist but well worth a look. Very easy to get to.

Worth the visit. Amazing pagoda like temple! After visiting some Pagoda / Temples they tend to look the same, NOT this one, it has several seperate quarters, and during our visit there was a (probably) graduation ceremony, making the temple alive and gave us the opportunity to withness an actual ceremony. Well worth the visit!!
Definitely worth a visit. This temple was a pleasant surprise. Much different than I thought it was going to be. The tour guide we had explained the different areas and the history in clear English

An interesting introduction to Buddhism. This temple was part of a brief walking tour in Hanoi. It was intersting to see the street sellers outside and then to see the temple itself and the various sacrifices made by worshipers. Buddha clearly likes Choco-Pie! People could buy joss sticks, prayer papers and fake money all for offering. We were told that the govenment is trying to stop the sale of praye papers (which are burnt) because it is a waste of paper.

A hidden quiet historical Gem in the madness of Hanoi.. We were led here by our local guide, and to be honest after a quick summary of the place, were left on our own. Like others we were there when local students were celebrating their graduation. It is a nice place to walk around and you can get close to everything. It is celebrated because of it's place in the education history in Vietnam, check out the detail before you go unless you have a guide.

Fun too see graduation . This was worth the buzz of graduates throwing their hats in the air and a wander through to the temples shines was interesting. A bit out of the way but full of life and happy teens all dressed up and full of promise.
Fascinating. Really enjoyed this visit. Lots of information, overt focus on education and producing doctors. Gardens are amazing - topiary of many animals and dragons.

Worth visiting briefly. If you have some spare time and want to get out of the craziness of Hanoi you can have a stroll around the gardens here for half an hour or so. There are also some decent shops and food options not too far from here.

Didn't see what was so interesting. I didn't see what was so important about this place. A couple of pathways, a wall with a few openings in it, a gateway, and a courtyard with acouple of giftshops, and a building with a confusious statue. The only thing related to literature or university, was the roof over the tablets with scholars names enscribed on them, from many moons ago.
Shelter from the Storm. A place where peace and tranquility abounds, whilst outside the walls, pandemonium takes place (the traffic).

Definitely Worth the Visit. We really enjoyed this museum, especially as it was buzzing with students celebrating graduation. It is a nice antidote to the war museums and gives you a better appreciation of the Vietnamese history and culture. Do use a local guide. We would have missed a lot if dependent on the written guides.

Nice to visit!. This is one of the oldest tertiary institutions in the world and worth a visit especially if you have an appreciation for paying respect to ancient academics! Lovely gardens and surrounds and historical ambience. In central Hanoi area and worth including on you itinerary when visiting!

Very beautiful and interesting place. You can really feel the history in this place. I recommend visiting if traveling to Hanoi. Price was acceptable 30k vnd and i hope it goes to keepind that place in good condition.

Vietnam trip . I enjoyed this Temple It was very different from what you would picture a temple to be.
I think more of a shrine of learning. Beautiful grounds and worth the visit.

Interesting and pretty. Great lesson in old literature and in a beautiful setting. The gardens are immaculately kept and the bonsai trees fascinating. Shame about ignorant tourists disregarding signs to keep off the trees. Lots of school trips which was lovely to see. You won't need to allow lots of time here.

Lovely grounds with hundreds of red lanterns, water fixtures, stone carvings. Our visit here was made special by the graduating class that was there that day - lots of photo opportunities, graduates jumping in the air, rushing towards photographers, etc. Shops line the sides of the central areas

Peaceful and calm. This temple is more interesting than I expected . The peaceful when I walked inside. I was there at noon so there are not many people. I felt my mind was refreshed after a hectic walk on the busy streets of Hanoi. There also some infomations about the history of the buildings even though there are not many English signs for that

Great Place . The name of the place is interesting enough to visit it once. And I would like to go back for sure. However, it is important that you take a guide with you so that he could explain you in detail about the historical significance.

One of the best historical places in Hanoi. One will not disappoint visiting this place.The temple hosts the "Imperial Academy", Vietnam's first national university. The temple was built back in 1070 at the time of King Lý Thánh Tông. One can freely walk around various part of the temple and the admission fee is only 30,000 dong which is about a pound. While we were there place was very busy with young qualified graduates who came there for photo shoot. Best time to go there is in the morning before the place get busy. There are few souvenir shops in there selling interesting things. At least allow couple of hours to look around.
beautiful. The place is beautiful and peaceful. The ancient structures and history are very interesting. There were students the day I visited it. They made it more special.

Confucius and colour. Beautiful gardens awash with colour. Busy yet not appearing crowded. In fact surprisingly peaceful considering its popularity and central location. Visit two of the four pillars of Buddism. Rub the back of the tortoise for good health or the belly of the bird for good fortune. Check out the protected stone tablets.

Beautiful complex in the heart of Hanoi. The temple of literature is a very beautiful complex of buildings in the city centre. The grounds are beautiful and it is a must when visiting Hanoi. Tip: If possible go relatively early to avoid large groups of cute but noisy school children.

Get there early before the crowds. The Temple was an easy walk from the old quarter. We were there in the midday, surrounded my many, many school children on field trips, which is charming in it's own way, but makes it hard to take pictures. The grounds are immaculately kept, with beautiful flower displays. We bought the inexpensive brochure (in English) to help guide our way and understand what we were seeing, This is one of the few places we've visited in Vietnam, that have had English translations on signs throughout the temple. For the weary walker, there are benches on either side of the entrance, that are not immediately apparent when entering. I loved sitting there, watching families and tourist go by in a shaded, cool area.
Pretty place, worth a visit if you have an hour. Pretty place, small gardens, temples, statues of Confucius etc. Worth a visit if you have an hour to spare

One of the best thing to see in Hanoi. I love the peace, the history and the place itself. Great place, I'll go back for sure!You might want to go with a guide to understand ereyything about the place.
Nice place.. I visited this place 3 times. The first time was in 2000. Sadly to see some plaques have been ruined.Love the peaceful atmosphere with beautiful trees, bonsai and architect here.
Nice walking arounf. Outside of looking at the buildings that housed the ancient study areas, it is nice to walk around the area and just relax. Nice to hear and read about the history
A must place to visit. One of the most famous place you should visit once you come to Hanoi.highly recommened for group tourists

Educational experience. Learned a lot on education. Confucius' values expressed, and explained by tour guide. The walk was rather difficult with many small walls to walk over and many steps to handle. The temple was beautiful and introduced us to the tradition of venerating various ancesters. in VIetnam.
Historical. A place where one can see the local lifestyle and culture of Hanoi. The local fro the age of three to eighty spend their day here.

Started in around 1000 AC and westeners think we are civilized...... Wat a nice place and existing so very very long. Lovely quiet spot in the middle if Hanoi. Around 12.00 we saw a lot of young students there. Excellent example to us all.

Another quite place. Perfect place to spend a hot afternoon, lots of shade, lots of large wooden halls/temples.They tried to trick us at the cashier, by giving couple of notes with less zeroes in our change.....

Great to see the old customs. It was quite busy the day we were there, but very interesting to see the large tablets for students who passed exams. There were many colorful lanterns and the typical Vietnamese structures.

Very interesting - wish I had had a guide. I'm very glad I visited this spot while I was in Hanoi. It would have helped to have a guide, as I think I would have come away with even more of an appreciation for it. But it is definitely worth checking out.

Probably give it a miss. . There is actually not all that much to do as far as tourist attractions compared to most capital cities. The lady on the gate taking our money did not give the correct change and when we went back and questioned her she had the right change waiting without question so obviously just trying her luck with silly tourists. While we were there, there were students receiving certificates and in graduation gowns that had apparently travelled many hours to gain this photo opportunity. It's the origin of education and has a deep history in such. You'll only need an hour or two to see it all. Avoid the tuk tuk drivers as they will try to rip you off upon arriving at your destination. Ours quoted ( and it was more expensive than a taxi) but we agreed for the experience. Upon arrival he said that was per person. So x2.

Interesting - choco cakes for Confucius!. Pretty busy but worth popping in. Hot in middle of day so advise going morning or late afternoon if possible. Quite steep entry price but the gardens are very pretty and the statues are amusing.

Peace!. very peacefull place! Indeed.when you are insider this garden you really don't care about noise from the roads around. I like to spend few minutes there when I'm in Hanoi. it's a must!I cannot tell your about the meaning of what is inside but I can surely confirm that it worth to be there.

Oldest University in Vietnam. Did a private tour with Tom from Vietlong Travel and really enjoyed the afternoon. The temple was set up to train the Mandarins that advised the generations of rulers in Vietnam. Students now have their graduation photos here and it was great to see the old and the new together in the same location.
Interesting . Did this on a tour with a guide. Happy we had a guide to explain the history, as not much written word around. Very pretty.

old Vietnamese architecture. We only had a short stay here but the sense of history was profound. Due to the history of invasion by other countries in the past, buildings like this are few and far between.

Neat area to explore/lots of history. Nothing special; no signs in English so you really need a tour guide to tell you the significance of each bldg. If you've been touring all day, this may not be the place to go...if you've seen one temple, you've seen them all...

Serene, and wonderful architecture. A must-see in Hanoi. This is a wonderful traditional and very old complex, very serene atmosphere (and in the middle of the Hanoi hustle-and-bustle) with wonderful architecture. The first Vietnamese University, in the Confucius/Chinese tradition. Great to just sit and ponder, but well worth a few hours wandering. Easy to get to by walking, just on the edge of the Old Quarter.

A must see.... Amazing area...The grounds and gardens are beautiful. The paths can be uneven and there are a lot of stairs.You could walk forever so wear comfortable shoes. Make sure you are with a knowable guide so you can learn the history of the area.

Wonderful. Built as the first National University for Vietnam, it is an interesting facet in the way higher education was achieved. Very peaceful and emphasizes Confucius teachings. Restored and beautiful.

Great to see . Cost 30,000 dong per person, would recommend 30-60 mins. Really interesting to see photos and artefacts of what was once a university in old Hanoi. Beautiful bonsais and gardens. Be sure to continue past the temple itself as it opens up into a paved courtyard and there is another beautiful building right at the back

Great history lesson. We visited this as our first thing to do in Vietnam. We had our guides from the Hanoi Kids also recommend and they talk us through the wonderful ancient history of country. Nice tranquil place.
Beautiful site. Very interesting architecture and insight into the cultural traditions around education in Vietnam. The day we were visiting we saw several school groups celebrating graduation.

Beautiful in the heart of Hanoi. We took a lovely stroll through the temple of literature on one of our days in Hanoi. The temple is well preserved and the inside is gorgeous. If you have time when you are in Hanoi, I highly recommend checking this attraction out. Also, reading up on the history makes you appreciate Vietnam's deep history more.

Interesting and nice setting - need a guide. This is a series of courtyards / spaces including a temple and a series of steles. You really do need a guide (or is there a guidebook?) to understand the place and the history and how everything is in chinese so the locals cannot understand the writing on the walls and steles any better than we can! Can see that the venue gets crowded with big parties of tourists and children/students visiting but possible to find space if you take your time. Enjoyed our visit here
Well worth a visit. Allow a minimum of 45 minutes to see this place - it is very interesting. We made our arrangements with Hanoi Transfer Service on our private one day tour.
Very Japanese like. Well worth a visit. It only costs 1.5l Dong to get it and has several gardens which are very beautiful.
Awesome History of Hanoi. I was amazed by the history of the place and the reverence shown by the students who came there to pay respects.

Very crowded---too many tourists is a bad thing!. Like most of the signature "places to see" in Hanoi (and in Asia for that matter now) This place was overrun with tourists from buses. Many of the people hop off the bus and begin jostling for "selfies" at the entrance and throughout the park-like setting. This Temple is actually a series of plazas and compounds joined by a central walkway. It is serene without the blast of people---so plan your visit accordingly---otherwise you may just end up walking through and leaving. Sometimes too much of a good thing is a bad thing! Please, people, no more selfies! Is it not possible to simply go and enjoy a place quietly and remember it in peace?
Interesting. I recommend to take a guide to get the full history otherwise you will miss a lot of details and stories. it was instructive and also beautiful inside and outside.
Beautiful temple complex. Beautiful temple complex, historic. wHen we were there many girls + 1 boy had a sort of graduation ceremony on the complex, a delight to witness!
Great architecture and interesting displays.. We found this to be a very beautiful and interesting site. The statues and architecture are quite beautiful and an interesting history.

Go for the scenery, not the temple. Interesting visit. Although the temple itself was unimpressive, learning about the first national university was extremely interesting. The grounds are a popular spot for Vietnamese people to go and take pictures. We spotted many couples taking engagement pictures, young women doing portraits and huge graduating classes taking class pictures! This alone is enough to make the visit worth it.
revelation. Beautiful complex of buildings, the place has an amazing atmosphere, one of the most beautiful things in the city.

A step back inthe past.. A very interesting collection of buildings and gardens, and where most local students go to contemplate and pray for good marks. The oldest university in the country dating back to the 11th century.

Beautiful grounds and buildings. We walked here from the Old Quarter which is a fun way to see Hanoi. There were lots of school groups who were giddy in saying "hello!" to us. The Temple has a very pretty grounds with trees, water, flowers, and even animal-shaped bushes. There is a lot of history as the first national university in Vietnam. Intricate steles document past students who completed their exams. We witnessed a religious ceremony with drums and prayer. The architecture and red paint were intriguing and make for great pictures. Certainly worth visiting this tranquil piece of Hanoi.
The ancient university. This place was a school or university for ancient people.The building is old and has very nice architecture. The graduated students were honored in the form of stone steles.
Very interesting and decorative. Lovely and peaceful with plenty of history. Beautifully decorated as are all the temples in Vietnam.

Peaceful place in city center. Even sound is almost vanishing here, as this big complex takes place between very traffic roads it is very nice to stay for an hour and let everything go in silence and calm. Beatiful pagodas with park suited for resting of soul and mind in loud Hanoi city.

Lovely . This was one of my favourite places I visited in Hanoi. It is pleasant, lots going on and aesthetically pretty. Groups of small children having tours and university graduation pictures. Would put aside at least and hour and half to visit.

Ancient University is so interesting.. From the start we were amazed by the beautiful wooden buildings, no doubt hand carved because of their age The teachings of Confusious and the benefits of Literature with a theme of Travel slowly like a Tortoise but be wise like a Stork could help as all in life. We loved our visit.
Graduation ceremony when we visited. An interesting place, which was worth the taxi ride out to it, although it's also near to a few other attractions
Peaceful except for the hoards of young school children - avoid mid morning!. Interesting place to visit and older than the traditional 'old' universities of Europe.Well worth an hour of your time.

Pouring with rain but still interesting and beautiful. We paddled our way around this attraction sheltering under our brollys, pretty damp but what a lovely setting and interesting history. Well worth a visit.

Must-do. very atmospheric and bright place, especially if you're lucky enough to visit it on a sunny day when some students get their diplomas and take pictures all together in their academic uniforms
Lovely place. Went on our own and enjoyed the history and the lakes. Very busy as it was Tet would be worth going early.

Should do with a tour guide. This place has a beautiful architecture of the old time with the lake, a large yard with trees and plants. Would recommend going with a guide so you will understand better about the history behind. A lot of students go there for luck before their exam. Very beautiful building and nice culture!
Wonderful quiet oasis. This is a wonderful tranquil oasis in the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Lots of interesting history and places to relax

Calming walk. Visit this nice garden and buildings with the calm atmosphere in the middle of the rushing streets.
This worth a visit.

Interesting history. Interesting visit to learn about the history and culture of this University. Well preserved and exhibit information also available in English. Very busy with tourists though, It would be worth trying to find a quiet time to visit.

Enjoy the place. Inside the place you will find much of the literature history of Vietnan. The lakes and colors inside it will make a nice place to take some pictures. Some days of the year there is a military event, that is very interesting, you will see the respect of the population with these guys.
Visit this temple. In the past years we visited this temple many times. It is an interesting temple, very old. The steles on turtle are nice to see. It is good to read some about it before visiting

Well preserved architecture. Remarkable architecture, lovely bonsai, a long history and some gorgeous sculptures. A place of total calm within the noisy city. Noteworthy are the 82 stelae with the inscriptions of 1304 doctor laureates in the temple. The placement of stelae signifies immortal reverence of talent. They are placed on the back of a tortoise which is considered a sacred animal in Vietnamese mythology.
Lovely grounds. Went with a guide, but sometimes I think these places are better if you just go on your own and sort of absorb the ambience. The staff at the gift shop were very friendly.

Beautiful place to visit . I loved our visit to the temple of literature. Such beautiful surroundings and a place full of historic wonder. I would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Hanoi as a must visit attraction.

Excellent. This place is great.must see! It was a univercity of sorts for hundreds of years and the education there had 42 steps if i recall correctly.it has 42 pillar stones to represent who succeeded.nice flowers and a pool and bonsai(s)

Wish I had more time.. Was very interesting with lots of English translations to explain everything along the way. I was short for time and would have loved to have spent a little longer here as was bigger than I'd realised.
Very interesting. Did this site as part of a day tour and found it attractive and interesting. One of the more scenic places in the city and not to be missed.

Great site in the middle of the city . Loved the authentic building. I did not realise there was such a strong learning culture in Vietnam. The signage in various languages were helpful
The staff at the souvenir stores were polite and not pushy.

Wonderful. We were lucky to attend on a National Celebration day (for Poet's) and so the site was full of entertainment and additional exhibits (as well as people).
Despite this, we found the environment and its history to be extremely interesting and therefore I have no hesitation in 'recommending a visit'

You must see this. We went to the temple with a guide.
It is a beautifull quite place in busy Hani.
It is great to see. It is wise to go with a giude because he can tell you a lot of the history and legends. That makes it more interesting. Otherwise you mis half of the meaning.
Superb Temple that is a must see. You enter the gate and may not be impressed but by the time you finish the series of gardens you will be. The temple itself is small but ornate .
Worth it. It is a realy important place for the pleople from Hanoi, specially for students. There is a lot of history and stories here but you won't learn much if you dont go with a guide.

Ancient university. Young local students.. It is an ancient university established in 11th century AD. I found many young school students taking class graduation pictures there. It is a short 10 to 12 mt pleasant walk from ho chi Minh mousealeum and worth a visit.There was a calligraphor in the temple and for 100k VND I got a calligraphy roll saying "peace and happiness". ☺There are many bonsai trees with cute figurines.

Vietnam College Student tour guides. My niece booked this tour with a program that matched us with young college students from Vietnam. They were the highlight of my time in Vietnam. We talked about everything under the sun. They were truly knowledge about the site and took us to other sites as well. Best way to take in this site.

Well maintained territory and gardens. A pleasant complex with a well maintained territory and gardens. We visited when the students celebrated their graduation, so all was very festive; and temple’s drum and gong along with the praying parents joined that celebration. Beautiful energy.

One of the Must-see in Hanoi. I was surprised from the manner that they worship Confucius. Very interesting place to visit and is better if you have a guide to explain you the history and what symbolizes every thing you see.

Impressive Former Center of Learning. Built between the 11th and 15th centuries, there and numerous altars with gorgeous flowers and offerings to Confucious. Now a museum, these buildings and grounds were once a university of higher learning. The site is beautifically landscaped with bonseid shrubs and ponds. The bronze unicorns are particularly beautiful.
If you are keen to explore Hanoi and like culture. We had time so it was nice for us to just stroll and check out this place..cultural and interesting place.

A fascinating visit. We were fortunate to have an elderly gentleman as a guide.
He knew a lot of the history and was able to make the trip very interesting.

Worth a visit but packed with tourists. This was an interesting site to visit but it was packed with tourists and felt a little like a factory line. It might be better to go with a guide who can explain the significance of what you are seeing.

Neat temple complex. This is a fairly standard temple complex and if you have been to many it would be pretty much the same, but as we hadn't been to any this trip so far it was ok. Being the temple of literature there were a lot of graduating high school students celebrating In the grounds, making a colourful spectacle.The final large building is interesting with a good view from the upper floor.Nice place for a short visit.

Dedication to education in Hanoi.... Visited the Temple with friends while on a tour with a guide (if you don't book a tour there is an entrance fee) to learn more about this historic site. The temple was built in 1070 at the time of King Lý Thánh Tông. It is one of several temples in Vietnam which is dedicated to Confucius, sages and scholars. The grounds of the temple host the Imperial academy, which was Vietnam's first national university. The temple, courtyards and gardens are very well maintained and peaceful. Depending on the weather I would advise taking: Sun Screen, Water, Camera, Hat or Umbrella.

Educational & Historical. Wish the place had a few descriptions in English to understand what is what inside the building. Other than that, the place is pretty impressive considering the era it was built and for those who seek cultural history.

Essential visit. Magnificent ; historic place ; this beautifully restored temple is the ideal place to understand the confucian culture and a part of the religious history of Vietnam. To visit with a guide

One of the most prized cultural treasures of Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is not to be missed on a visit to Hanoi. A thousands of years old ode to education, the campus is mostly outdoors and has the feel of a gracious park. The sun can be scorching late spring through the summer. I encourage visitors to check out KOTO restaurant (Know One Teach One), before or after visiting the Temple of Literature. It's across the street and is a not-for-profit entity that seeks to provide underprivileged kids an opportunity for a better life. And a few doors down from KOTO is Craft Link, where you can find fair trade craft goods made by ethnic minority women.

A green garden in the middle of Hanoi. The temple itself is a little building, surounded by a beautiful garden which maintainanced by local workers.Allow an hour max to travel between the historic stones which are hondreds of years ago. There is a little pool in front of the temple. A few bucks required as entrance fee.

Not really a highlight. I realise this is a very important institution for the local people but I found it not very interesting to me. It was Chinese New Year when we visited and it was absolutely packed which didnt help. It was not a highlight of our trip and we would have done without visiting it as part of our tour.
an experience. We had a guide from Hanoi free tours and Thoa was so informative during this tour. So interesting to see how the educators were taught. Huge place and very popular with tourists.

beautiful area. We were in Hanoi in December and visited the Temple of Literature with local guides. The whole area is very interesting and beautiful. The temples, the park area and the lots of stories associated with the place makes it one of the top destinations in the city for sure.

Established in 1070 - a must visit. Founded in honour of Confucius, this temple served as a centre for higher learning, educating future mandarins for more than seven centuries,The temple had been decorated in honour of the new year when we visited and had a warm welcoming feel.The temple is steeped in history. See the stone stelae, mounted on giant tortoise pedestals, inscribed with the names of the scholars from the 15th to the 18th centuries. The Altar of Cnfucius is flanked by statues of cranes standing on top of tortoises (a symbol of friendship - look up the legend). There is a statue of Confucius and 4 of his disciples in the gilt temple.The temple consists of 5 courtyards. A path through the complex divides it into 2 symmetrical halves. We really enjoyed the atmosphere and history of this temple and would highly recommend a visit if in Hanoi.

Book a Tour Guide, Forget the Brochure. It's the "oldest university in Vietnam". Amazing architecture and everything is still in really good condition. Entrance is 30,000Booking a guide is 100,000 which I really regret not doing! After overhearing some of the tour guides inside, I really wish I had booked one too - you will learn so much more, more history, more explainarions, More everything! What ever you do, definitely do not buy a brochure. Everything inside the brochure is posted on signs inside the University.

Don't go on a Sunday. Feel free to ignore all advice I've ever given but not this! It is hell on a Sunday with billions of selfie obsessed locals and tourists getting in each other's way and completely destroying any ambiance of tranquility and intellect. My worst 2 hours in 5 weeks in Vietnam. You have been warned.

OK but partly destroyed by Ho Chi Minh in the war. Not a bad site - one of the better sights to see in Hanoi. Sadly the main building and the old dormitories were destroyed by Ho Chi Minh in the 1946 war. Inexplicably, a completely different building was recently built in their place instead of rebuilding the old buildings, so the fifth courtyard no longer has any historical reference.The stone steles were good. Pity that none were translated though - it would have been interesting to know what they said.

For those who love to learn. My family enjoyed our visit to the Temple of Literature & National University. With the help of our guide from the Hanoi Free Tour Guides, Loan Ngo Thi, we were able to learn more valuable information than what a brochure would have given us. We were able to buy great souvenirs. My husband who is a hobbyist photographer was able to take pictures that reflected the wonderful culture of this beautiful city. The Temple of Literature is truly a must-see for those who want to experience Hanoi.

Ancient university. This is an ancient seat of learning and students competed once in 7 years for a seat in this "university'. The place is in multiple compartments and truly interesting. The architecture and cultural aspects are enough to merit a visit.
Amazing Cultural History. Loved the history of the place . Reflects the old culture of Vietnam and the level of sophistication of its people .
Great but bad for service.. It will be perfect if I mustnt pay much for the ticket. I think this is a public place so the price isnt expensive.
Worth it. The temple of literature is really cool to see. Architecturally beautiful with lively decoration if I were an ancient Vietnamese scholar id compete to go to school here

Very nice venue with peaceful ambience. Visited the plalce midday anf enjoyed the serene atmosphere. Its very leacful and quiet and very nicely iy decorated. We loved the big drum and the gongs. Teh shrine of Confucius is also very nicr. Wrll worth the effort.

A fascinating complex of ancient buildings. The Temple of Literature is a complex of ancient buildings. If you read the blurb near the entrance, you'll learn that getting anywhere near this place wasn't easy, you had to be an exceptional scholar. The works of Confucius and other learned mean were taught here.There are some interesting squares between the main buildings with water and bonsai on display. Visit the shrines, this is a working temple and holds a special place in the hearts of Hanoi citizens..The day we were there, an event was on which added a great deal of energy and colour to our visit. Hundreds of girls were dressed up to the nines in the traditional ao dai - wide trousers with a split-sided flowing tunic on top. It was something to do with the academic year. The girls were got more attention from photographers than the boys who although smartly dressed, let themselves down by wearing gauche trainers with their suits. Ah, youth!

Beautiful Gardens-Lots about Confucius-NO BOOKS!. This is a very tranquil, peaceful beautiful setting with great photo opportunities as you learn about the history as a university and religious site. There is much to be learned about Confucius and his teachings while at the same time observe people who still practice the religion.

It was too incredibly crowded to enjoy. We made a big effort to walk there from where we started and it was so ridiculously packed with people no one wanted to stay to see everything. It just became a chore instead of enjoyment. What we saw was just average. Cannot recommend it.

Pretty cool architectural experience. Well worth a visit for its architectural value, but you won't find any literature here (which we naively hoped for, haha).. The entry was super cheap (30000 dong)

Very interesting museum . Incredibly interesting museum really stepped in history which goes back a very long way. We were lucky enough to see a graduation ceremony which means this still holds a lot of significance with current students. Much of the free information on offer is in french or mandarin so i highly recommend getting an audio guide as there is a lot to learn.

Surprising view into literatury history. Wonderful view into the value of education in Vietnam. The architecture is amazing and monuments to the founders of the temple. We visited on a national holiday so it was very busy so check the holiday times and opening hours. A must do for those wanting to experience the history and architecture of Hanoi.
Lots of History - Shows their respect for Learning. Our guide gave us a great overview of the history of this Temple. Since it was still Tet, it was decorated with lots of plants and banners.

Must visit . A silent temple of education. Do visit this place with some guide otherwise you won't be able to know the legendary story behind it. Some part of this institute was destroyed in bombing but the Vietnamese people have restored this place.

Historical. This basically the temple of Confucius and the oldest university in Vietnam. There are no students here now but has been preserved and open to the public. Will be useful to go with a guide who can explain the temple to you.

Hats and hats and hats. Really liked all the hats hanging about, it really made this place feel different to the other temples you see a lot of in Vietnam. It's got educational history too, which is interesting.

Nice Gardens. Nice buildings. Old place. Lots of beautiful things to see.. Built in 1070. Lots of beautiful edifices and gardens and pools. A lot of graduation pictures were being taken here. A worthwhile stop.
Decorated for special occasion. A very interesting place, dedicated to ancient confucianism and learning this temple has been in Ha Noi for more than a thousand years.

Must see. This the must see place of hanoi, take your time and enjoy. It was the first university of hanoi and now a temple. Calculate some 1 h and then you could continue to Salmonoid restaurant nearby
Interesting visit. A nice place to visit if you're ever in Hanoi. Go with a guide because not everything has an English explanation next to it. (PS go get a free guided tour with a uni student)

Nice gardens . We went to the literature museum mid morning and there were A LOT of people there. The grounds are very beautiful and the buildings are interesting to look at. However there is not much explanation for each of the areas and hardly any in English, so you won't need much time to see eveything. I would suggest going early in the morning to avoid the crowds and if you are a student bring your student card because you will get in for half price (15,000d instead of 30,000). Also you might find it more interesting if you read about the temple before going, that way you will won't miss the little things.

Meh. Quite a few gift shops within the compound and you still gotta pay to use the WC once you've paid the entrance fee. I wonder how much of these buildings are actually from nearly a millennia ago... The stones on the tortoises are obviously original given their state.

Peaceful Oasis. This was a lovely spot that seemed peaceful and serene. Beautiful architecture and undoubtably interesting history, though limited English explanations meant that we felt like we were missing half the story. Perhaps with a local guide you could, fully appreciate this interesting place.

Temple Of Literature isnt a temple only.... When went there, i so suprised, coz, the temple isnt a temple only. You can see many things inside there. Ofcourse about literature, poetry and park. If u lucky, u can see graduation celebration from local senior high school. They are so cute with their local dress, so happy and i enjoyed it.

nice place.. There was a good place, where is keeping a spirit of Confucius. When I visited this place, because Vietnam was on holiday season, there held a holiday event. I have not visited in normal days, maybe it was too good.

Beautiful temple. Had the best time there, really interesting and beautiful. It's quite big. No written explanations, so should be useful to have a guide. I did, local student who wants to improve their English.

Better to Read About Than Visit. Undeniably an interesting history, and certainly some noble sentiments involved, but to actually visit it's rather a non-entity in terms of asian temple architecture. Stuffed full of tacky shops, jam packed with tour groups blocking the paths, and replete with selfie-stick wielding teenagers cluttering up the place, combined to make for a sharp exit for this disappointed visitor. Mercifully, there's always a good coffee shop to hand in Hanoi, so all was not lost.

Pleasant surprise . Came across this temple purely by chance so thought I'd pop in as entry was very cheap. I have to say it a very colourful and atmospheric place. There was a concert and recital of sorts going on during my visit, didn't understand a word but it sounded melodic and very pleasant, nice place and worthy of the half hour I spent there.

Pretty temple. Pretty temples but there was not as much information as I would have liked to help us understand its importance. I didn't see any audio guides, but it was very busy so we might have missed them
First university in Vietnam, year 1070!. Very interesting building, although it lacks explanations. Beautiful gardens. Gigantic golden turttle, symbol of wisdom, lays in the building.

Beautiful Courtyard. This place is included in all the local half-day and full-day sightseeing tours, so we decide to pay a visit. As we found out, there's not that much to see. The "museum" does not offer any audio aid and there aren't enough English information regarding the displayed artefacts. The structure of the temple is very old, but don't know if it is the original built in 1053(?)
Group visit. We arrived on full moon celebration. So colorful and so beautiful. Very informative. Make sure you go here.
Good visit. Probably the most remarkable aspect of this temple is the small lakes in some courtyards that provide a different landscape to the temple. It is quite old and deserves a visit.

Worth visiting if you like Temples. A pretty nice Temple in the heart of Hanoi. Definitely worth visiting if you are interested in Temples or religious culture. A pretty large complex and a really good example of a Vietnamese Temple. I went during the spring festival and it is still very much in use to pray for good grades for your children.

Temple of LIterature in Hanoi. This is a must-see in Hanoi, along with the Ngoc Son Temple. The Temple of Literature was an interesting complex of buildings and courtyards with beautiful architectural styles from multiple dynasties. Today, students gather in the Temple to have their photographs taken for graduation. We were fortunate to have also seen a musical performance using traditional Vietnamese instruments during our visit to the Temple of Literature.

Bring your own information!. This was a beautiful location, but they have few English plaques. I wish I would have brought information or read about it ahead of time. They do have a brochure available for purchase, but they were out when we visited.

Some history of old Hanoi worth seeing. This was good to see over the course of about an hour and a half. Little was in English so you'd need a guide to get a good experience, but very interesting to see the various stages of the old University. Some great pictures!

Buy the brochure or get a guide. I actually visited this attraction twice in the span of a few days - first with just the purchased brochure, and the second time with a guide. I don't think one experience was necessarily better than the other, but both provided needed context that I would not have gotten if I just wandered through.I'm an academic, so I really appreciated the history of this place. I'd done some reading about the the Mandarin tradition ahead of time, which really helped me understand what it meant to take the test to get ones doctorate in historical Vietnam.Go all the way to the back and check out the different altars (upstairs) and other goodies hidden on the sides. This place is bigger than you'd first think.

Beautiful. Beautiful architecture and well kept grounds, resembling some of the temples we had visited in China. We were lucky that it was not crowded and could take beautiful pictures. Well worth the visit!

A calming temple in the midst of hustle and bustle. The temple grounds are quite large. We had with us the guide from National Geographer so did not opt for brochure provided (VND8k) at admission (admission fee is one adult -VND30k) unfortunately, the time we went there was a graduation for high school students so it was very crowded but what we gathered from the nat geo guide was that browsing every nook and cranny of the temple may take up to 4 hours. The prices in the shops inside the temple are inflated so try not to purchase anything. The temple itself has Chinese Influences in the architecture, halls, clothing and even the arts and crafts.
An amazing building. This Temple & University was amazing place to visit, so much History. We were there so long we were asked to leave as they were closing!

must see in Ha Noi. beautiful grounds & structures; hope you go when it is less crowded, but a great place for photos & contemplative strolls, as long as it isn't mobbed, which it often is.... but don't miss it.

Avoid the weekend madness!. Visited with the in-laws who were here from the States in October. Made the mistake of coming out on a Saturday afternoon. It was wall to wall with young Vietnamese graduates taking photos! Might come back again one day as it seemed interesting enough to visit, but maybe on some weekday morning!
Better Than Anticipated. This site was well worth the visit. The grounds are beautiful and the buildings housing many interesting things to learn more about the customs and culture of the country.

A temple of learning celebrating teachers, students, and turtles. Almost 1000 year old temple/university with huge turtles to honour and encourage learning. How cool is that! Look for groups of students from all over the country who come here to take graduation pictures.
A must see in Hanoi. 40 min to discover a fantastic temple dedicated to knowledge and legacy from Vietnam former Kings. Gardens and Buildings are great.

Interesting Place. Good place to visit especially with a guide, who can explain all about the history of the place. We are lucky that it was quiet when we visited as I imagine it could get quite crowded. Nice gardens too
Great day out. One of my favourite attractions in Hanoi, great place for a stroll and insight into the history of Vietnam some beautiful architecture here

Not the worth the push it gets from guide books. average is all for me, crowded and very touristy inside, the unique experience it could have been was ruined by the cheap Chinese crap being pushed inside. make sure you bring a guide or you all you do is look at old stuff.
Interesting. This was a very interesting place. Go there with a good guide who can explain the significance of the place in detail.
Historical sites to visit. This place was interesting and had a sense of history. I enjoyed seeing the architecture and carvings.

Nothing much that may support it's greatness as the first university of modern day Vietnam. I suggest you get a guide. Which costs 100,000 Dong as stated by the ticket office. If not, at least read up about this building before hand or at least buy it's info pamphlet for 8000 Dong. If you've not gotten souvenirs, get them here. It's cheaper, and some are unique. Anyway's the university has some dedication to Confucius and his 6 students/deciples.

Temple Tour. Peaceful oasis, made memorable with the insights by Phoung, our delightful tour guide from Free Hanoi Tour Guides. There was so much to learn and all the little details were patiently explained. A memorable few hours spent here, and lucky to watch a graduating class of students celebrating and being photographed.

Good place to shop some small souvenirs.. Aside from its historical meaning and constructure, it has various range of souvenirs. Close to Hochimin museam (about 10 minutes on foot), it is worth a visit.

Fascinating insight into the origins of the university, especially the examination process for candidates.. Includes gardens, temples and most interestingly the stelae on which the names of all successful candidates are inscribed from many centuries ago. Needs a knowledgeable guide to get the most out of the tour.
Worth a visit stunning Temple. Definitely worth a visit the gardens and temples are stunning even on a cold windy day in January. It was quiet when we were there so it was lovely to wander around.
Temple of Literature. Visited during Tet holiday, so many Vietnamese on holiday and visiting too! Very busy but still got to see ancient stone tablets and temple of worship. Lovely place.
Paradise in Chaos. Great little stop for some peace and quite in the middle of Hanoi, try to avoid the large tourist groups though.
Place of Wisdom. A spacious area dedicated to renowened Vietnamese Scholars . One needs to read and understand this special place in order to respect and appreciate this attraction .

A very busy temple during Tet. We visited this temple which again was teaming with all age groups and families all intent upon writing a wish on the inner wall,or offering a prayer or several whilst subsequently they would all congregate and enjoy an ice cream or cold drink in the sunshine. Enforce dispersing again.

A bit of history. And a bit of an understatement. This university was established in 1072 A.D. A friend took me the first time I went and I was told it was the first university. Looking for things to do a few weeks later, I returned to the Temple of Literature, only to find that it is the same place. It is set in lovely park-like grounds.
A great temple to see. To be honest, but the end of my 4 week trip to Vietnam and Thailand I had seen enough temples to last me a life time, but this is one to try and tick off.
Must VIsit. First "university" in Vietnam. Established about 1200, just a little before the "discovery" of the new world.
INTERESTING. Our first sight in Hanoi and it was very interesting. It doesn't take a lot of time to go through and it is worth the time to explore.

Worth a visit . You will see many Pagoda whilst in Vietnam but this is still worth an hour of your time. The gardens are what makes it different although I am not sure that all the flower arrangements I saw would be there all year as I visited during the Tet festival.
Must visit. Beautiful temples and so interesting, being the first university in Vietnam.Writing translated in English so easy to follow. Cheap entrance fee and not too busy.

Beautiful!. This place is very popular as it's always packed with people. It's not expensive to gain entrance and once inside it's very beautiful and well kept. There is a gift shop inside which sells pretty much the same souvenirs that any other gift shop/ vendor in Hanoi sells.

Just so busy. We did this tour today and being a Saturday and also the first day it was opened after TET it was extremely busy. It is of interest but on an very hot day it was just too crowded and hard work to really enjoy.

Endless crowds!. I'm sure the temple of literature itself is great to see, but the massive crowds of people meant that we couldn't actually read any of the signage or get inside several of the buildings to see within. What we did see was very interesting, and the short walk in and out of the temple is very pretty - if you can deal with getting crushed from all angles by people shoving and elbowing their ways through. Not necessarily a location worth the stress of getting around it
