Serene architecture amid the chaos. Superb remains of an ancient university and library. Gorgeous Chinese style architecture in iconic colours. Busy at New Year, but still a pleasant escape from the hectic streets.

Large & Interesting Site.. Visited this on a day's wandering. It's a big complex of different areas which have some interesting information as well as beautiful shrines. There's some shops inside too with souvenirs, drinks, ice cream etc. It's a must see on the list of important sights in Hanoi & he entrance fee is around 30K Dong, so very affordable for a dose of culture.

Tranquil temple grounds and ancient stellae. We were there during Tet, when the entire city converged on the place. People were streaming like a line of ants through the walkways. Strangely, it didn't spoil the visit even though it was so out of character to the peacefulness cf the other 350 days of the year.The highlight was a ceremony bestowing gifts on Buddha. Dancers dressed in striking yellow costumes lined the ceremony area. A drum provided the sacred beat for the dancers. It was quite a photo op, but also a moving experience. It is only held during Tet, though.

Great Architecture. Its full of nice architectural buildings. You can see the Vietnam's first national university where they built doctors, engineers, leturers etc. Also you can see the new university complex which they made according to the ancient architectural fashion.

Old University. The Temple of Literature is a huge complex of colourfull buildings. Is situated in a wunderfull park. Besides beeing a university for forming the high ranking civil servants it was also a place of worship.

Nice stop in the heart of Hanoi. Located close to the old Quarter, the Temple of Literature is a nice place to stop. We were there during their National Tet Holiday (the period around NY) and it was pretty crowded but even though we enjoyed it. The only problem is that there is no information in English, so we understood little about the place. There is an entrance fee of 30 000 (around 1,3 Eur).

Of interest to history buffs. The Temple of Literature is a great visual aid to understanding the Confucian system of education and government service. Most of the other visitors the day I was there were on school field trips. A few of the students wanted to practice their English and a couple of girls even asked if they could take a photo with me. Of course I obliged. If you're looking for souvenirs, the gift shops are cheap and have some more-or-less educational items for sale -- like necklaces with sayings (in Vietnamese characters) such as "attain" and "pass an examination."

Interesting but you need a guide.. This place is very, very busy. Without a guide you may wonder what the fuss is about. Some interesting culture and history, very popular with local people who came dressed in their Sunday best.

Holy Experience. My mind is a devil mind, which run here and there alwez. So it needs to be calmed. So temple is the best place to visit when you want to relax and calm down your mind. The spiritual environment of the temple will definitely help you to distress your mind.

Don't miss it when you stay in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is the first imperial academy under Ly Dynasty thousand years ago. It is dedicated to Confucius, sages and scholars. It has an unique architecture with many areas, courtyards. You can see 82 valedictorians' stelae carried by stone turtles. Before Tet Holidays, many calligraphists will assemble outside the temple and write wishes in Hán characters.Before important exams, students always go there for praying the luck and good things.
Nice temple in the middle of the city.. The temple is enclosed by quite a big garden. The main entrance gate is impressive. We walked from Han Kiem lake witch take about 30 mins.

Perfect break from a hectic Hanoi.. The surrounding walls and trees really seclude the park which is great. Making it a very peacful area for you to enjoy and take photos. There are numerous unique buildings and areas here which sort of take you on a journey, so even after a while you dont get bored. I would recommend you to go here, and the entrance fee is only 30,000vnd.
Short visit. Not sure whether it is worth a special visit good to see if in Hanoi as interesting how they recorded knowledge on stone etc
Wish I could have studied here. An absolute must do , loved the Chinese architecture, and the various facets of the university with the statues on top symbolising the life of a student

Ok for a visit, not a priority. The temple is dedicated to Confucio and literature, academic achievements. Nothing special. If you have time and want to do a quick visit it is ok but if youbare in tight schedule and need to choose few places to visit in Hanoi, then I would not prioritize it.The entrance fee is 30,000 vnd per adult (about 1.5 usd so very cheap ).
Peaceful. The Temple of Literature delivered a lovely early morning retreat from the city. Enjoyed wandering around the gardens and temple.
Beautiful and Interesting. You enter the grounds through a series of pagodas. Beautiful grounds and pagodas. The last one contains large sculptures. Well worth a visit.

Graduation day!. We were pleasantly surprised to share our visit with dozens of college graduates and their families. Apparently, the Temple of Literature - an ancient Hall of Learning - is a popular place to "toss your mortar board (hat)" in the air with your graduating colleagues! What a wonderful experience for us!
Well worth a visit. A nice temple complex in the city with beautiful gardens. Inexpensive entrance and not too busy. There isn't a lot to look at but the main attraction is the old stone steles.

Oasis of Calm in the Hustle and Bustle of Hanoi. Graduates are commemorated on ancient stelae. The grounds have several ponds and temples, including the main one with its statue of Confucius. Look for the storks standing on the backs of the turtles and for the golden turtle statue.

Interesting history but need a guide to get the most out of it. Interesting history and nice buildings but rather unsatisfying without a guide. There were a couple of plaques that gave brief outline of the history, but many individual exhibits were not labelled in English. Also it would be good if they could bring in more period furniture and items. I would like to have known what a classroom and desks were like, for instance.

Beautiful & interesting. A very interesting place. Some nice buildings, both externally and internally. It is a place that many just married couples visit for photographs, as do university students celebrating their degree award. It all makes for a colourful and interesting spectacle.
Stunning site. If your knowledge of Vietnamese history is limited, this is a great place to start. We learned a lot from our visit.

For me just another temple. We had a quick look around but for me it was just another temple. Not that impressive and most of the signs just in Vietnamese.
If you have time maybe worth but if not you do not miss anything I would say.
Entrance free: 30.000 Dong, Students 15.000

Insightful tour. By all means visit with a guide. Beautiful architecture, meaningful statues and gardens, along with nooks and crannies that are worth seeking. A contemplative, calm and beautiful space worthy of a morning stroll, learning more about Vietnamese culture and learning.
Temple of Literature & National University. It was a nice and peaceful place, lots of graduating students, taking pictures, celebrating. Nice garden and sculptures.

Traditional Architecture. When we visted this place many graduate students were taking photgraphs with their graduation attires. There are inscriptions of the names of scholars. Temple has four entrances symbolic of 4 exams that the students have to take. The temple has the deity of Confucios. This is known as the Vinh Long Temple of Literature.

Warming. I absolutely loved this place. I sat with the locals for a couple of hours chatting and people watching. It is so mesmerising. If you take the time to stop and enjoy the culture and heritage you can feel go grounded and connected with the people. Was a nice calming place in what can be a hectic city
pretty pretty . temple of literature is pretty and fun for a 20 - 30 minute stroll. its not expensive and has a bunch of chill shrines, the gift shop is also cool.

A must see!. In Hanoi dont bother with the tours. They are way too much. I will encourage u to invest in a comfortable pair of running shoes n walk everywhere! This is an awesome place to visit. You can always tag along when other tour guides are explaining things...but its quite self explanatory!

Special . So much history contained in the five sections of this temple, from Religion to the old University. Highly recommend a tour guide to explain the religions history, the meaning of the architecture, university and each of the five sections of the temple. A must see.

Temple grounds. Historical site that housed the original university. We went on a guided tour with hanoikids so we're able to pick up a lot of interesting facts and tidbits, without that the site may not have been as interesting. Fairly large site that takes about an hour to walk through. Good if you are interested in the history and architecture.

Bit of China in Hanoi. I've never been to China, but I felt that this as a very Chinese experience, some beautiful moments. It was a wonderfully calm atmosphere and got a glimpse into the huge influence of the Chinese "occupation".

Interesting. Don't just go there for the literature, the history of the place, the age of the stones with each ones own inscription. The architecture of the place is lovely, the gardens are so nice to walk through. All schools in the Ha Noi are take their young people there.

Nice first up attraction for our first full day in Hanoi. We travelled to the temple of literature with a guide in the morning and found it a great way to learn a little about the past education system in Hanoi. First thing we were greeted by was the beautiful gardens entering (and the heat). Our guide was great explaining certain aspects of the University. Why so many young Hanoians were getting photos taken and statues surrounding.

Serene Refuge. Hanoi is an assault on the senses and the Temple of Literature is a wonderful antidote to the traffic and noise of the streets. Makes a great destination for a morning along with the Fine Arts Museum (Bao Tang My Thuat) and Koto restaurant both of which are nearby.

Incredible History and Beautiful Surroundings. It's a not to be missed site when touring Hanoi but read up on it to fully understand the historic value to it. The complex itself is beautiful with incredible architecture, inspiring temple, and beautiful grounds. But the real value is the story behind the place.

I have traveled here one year ago with my family.. You have to buy the ticket to enter here. The fee is reasonable. There have a lot sightseeing for the traveler to take the photo. The best weather to visit is during September and October.

Cultural tranquil must see. A great space to get a better understanding of Vietnamese history. Nice gift shop on left side. Can be visited with Fine Arts Museum. Interesting craft stores across the street, including indigo shop.
Interesting Place. One of the must visit attractions in Hanoi and well worth its status.Plenty to see, and all very interesting - recommend doing with a guide to get the most from the visit

Well kept small compact cultural. Simple well kept and yet much to see. The front tower is the one depicted on the Vietnamese dong note. I like the big Vietnamese flag in the garden to remind me that this is in Hanoi, the place looks like one in China. Good photo place. We noted a number of locals were having the wedding photos taken.
Serene. A nice, serene little place located in Hanoi. If you have time is might be worth coming for a visit to get a good feel for Vietnamese culture

Interesting history. One of the oldest universities in the world has got to be seen. I liked the atmosphere of the buildings and their surrounding gardens. In those days successful students had their names carved in stone - awesome.

A must do!. No trip to Hanoi is complete without a visit to the Temple of Literature. We visited with the help of Hanoikids Tour. It was amazing to see such beautiful Vietnamese history. Our trip was made much richer with learning about the Temple. I would highly recommend arranging a tour with the Hanoikids at hanoikids.org. Besides the Temple of Literature, we asked them to take us to Giang Cafe (original egg coffee place) and to eat real local food. Truly incredible experiences!

Worth a visit . It didn't take us long to look around this attraction, it probably took us longer walking to it from our hotel! It was ok, the grounds were well kept, it was a bit shabby in places, but worth a visit.
A university worth visiting. It is a 10th century university with confucius as the centre of attraction. Tablets for doctoral scholars was something I liked

Another tourist destination. . It was a harrowing walk there from the old quarter. The motor scooters have no respect for the sidewalks. Had to pay to get in there too. Architecture was good but you can see other temples for free in the old quarter. Great walk though. Always great walking around.

A highlight of Hanoi. Beautiful buildings with much ancient and more modern history. Temples beautifully decorated, robes warn by leading graduates and large stones on which names are inscribed. Beautifully laid out and easy to visit.

Beautiful Grounds, lots of students!. We enjoyed the well landscaped grounds and the detailed gates and pagodas. A few steps, but mostly easy walking. The statues of the turtles, holding the names of scholars were interesting to see, too. There were many groups of young people all dressed up, taking graduation pictures which was fun. But the highlight was when our tour guide struck up a conversation with a teenage student who had just stepped away from one of the Buddhas where she was praying for success on her exams. She told us where she was from and her hopes for the future. Great interaction. We spent maybe 45 minutes or so here and it was a worthwhile stop.
Joyful location. Joyful location, with historical buildings. It is frequently used for graduations. The great "Masters" have their own amazingcommemorative stones there.

Peaceful respite in a busy city . Ancient buildings set in lovely gardens and ponds. Can be very busy with school children. Quite and separate from the noisy downtown. Study the history before you go. This center of ancient learning was fundamental to the countries growth.
Beautiful Temple. A great visit in the center of Hanoi, a little moment of quiet in the heart of the city. Interesting monument with a particular history and beautiful gardens too.
Really Great.... Great piece of art and culture. Strogly recommend to see. Very good example to history of education in Vietnam.

Well worth a stop. Even on a gray and rainy day it was good to see the temple. As other people write, just the serenity of it is worth a visit.
The temple was like most other temples, but the garden is well kept and beautiful.

Perhaps we needed a guide. A visit to The Temple of Literature by ourselves really only warranted a 3 star review.
As there aren't many English explanations it is difficult to know what you are looking at. Beautiful buildings (poorly maintained in my opinion), a dirty pond, and sad looking grass.
Perhaps a tour with a guide is warranted for this site.

Serene area in the heart of Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is the first university in Hanoi and was used for training the Confucian scholars or Mandarins. Most of the current building is a reproduction, but it has been nicely restored and is in a scenic setting. We often visit with our young children and it nice for them to run around and see the buildings, but we are often harassed by local people asking for photos with them because they are blonde haired (a rare and special thing in Vietnam!). It is a great place to visit for an hour or so and there is a nearby shop called Craft Link which offers fair trade products made by ethnic peoples. There is also a well-known restaurant called Koto nearby, which trains some street kids in the hospitality business. It's a bit of a tourist trap and not the most tasty/authentic local choice, but supports a good cause.

Worth a look. Pleasantly surprised when we walked in as part of our peregrine tour city tour. It is set in the middle of a busy part of the city. It is a very good refuge from the noisy chaotic traffic. It's a little gem great for art, architectural and history lovers to explore. It has many sides to see . It's almost like opening a book and each new chapter shows a different side to it.Tip : see it with a tour guide , allow plenty of time , sunhat, sunscreen ,water, camera
Old University - average interest. This is basically a very old University. There's not a whole lot to see but people who are really into historical old buildings may enjoy seeing it.
Beutiful place. Nice stop for a stort visit. Take the time to read abort in you guide book to gået the full experience.

a peaceful spot in the chaos of hanoian traffic. If you're looking for a spot to refuge from the caotic traffic of Hanoi this is definitely the perfect place to be. During summer can be a little be hot, but it's nice to see the shrubs and trees trimmed into animal shapes and the great temple still used as university, where students walk by. A must.
Nice visit. Beautiful temple. Enjoyed my visit to the temple of Literature. It is located on nice and shady grounds.

Busy busy busy. This is a beautiful place designed to create space for the mind and body, I can appreciate the elegance and intricacy of every element. However, like any tourist attraction in a big city Is is teeming with ( some quite unnecessarily noisy) visitors. Fittingly there were a large group of young Vietnamese people celebrating their degree success in caps and gowns. I was very pleased to see their joy and pride but my selfish self longed for some contemplative silence. I guess I should get up earlier.
Temple of Literature Hanoi. This is the first university in Vietnam, there are many travellers to here daily, specially Vietnamese students

Beautiful. This attraction is clearly highly popular with the locals, with hundreds of schoolkids taking graduation pictures in the grounds, along with a couple of wedding parties. The temple and grounds are beautiful and well-worth a visit.

Beautiful site, though very crowded. It's a wonderful complex of buildings and designs, but it is always crowded with tourists because of this. It's also not quite a large as we expected, so we were all done in an hour. Still worth seeing though for some genuine ancient architecture that hasn't been destroyed.
Great visit. Visited the temple of literature and escaping the hustle of city life while walking around the tranquil gardens and lovely monument

Confucius in Vietnam. Wonderful. Not too crowded, and wonderful sculptures everywhere. The tourist souvenirs for sale were not too pricey and some were uncommon. Good place to spend some quiet time, too, if you just want to rest.
Interesting place!. I suggest you visit it with a local guide. Make sure they speak English, sometimes it is hard to understand Vietnamese English...

Once a university and now a temple. Lovely gardens, but you need a guide to understand the true history of this place. It was once a university and is now a temple but everything there has significance and meaning such as the gates that you walk in and out of - one gate for novices, another for learned men. Definitely worth a visit.Watch out for the hawkers out the front. They are fairly ruthless. There was an incident with one of our tour members where a few of them were bullying her and trying to get into her purse, while another distracted her husband with fitting him with a T-shirt he did not want.

Beautiful architecture!. I enjoyed visiting this beautiful place. There is so much ancient architecture to see. When I visited there was a group of students who were getting their graduation photos taken. A beautiful sight. A great place to enjoy people and the scenery.

Where religion meets the Education. This was built to worship the Lord Buddha but later a very intellectual and intelligent King converted it as the pedestal of Education and converted it to an university.
Wonderful part of Hanoi's culture. I did a guided tour here with Hanoi Kids (who I also highly recommend) and found it really fascinating

'Must see' temple. Somehow i have overlooked this sightseeing place when prepared our first trip to Hanoi using the internet so we've got there by accident just passing by down the street. And to say that i was pleasantly surprised when we got in is to say nothing about this place, i was really amazed. Temple as temple, what is so outstanding about that? I cannot explain, but atmosphere inside is so peacefull and relaxing, architecture and nature are so beautiful and inspiring that you feel yourself like beeing in some forgotten mountaintop cloister... Good place for everyone to relax and think a little about our history, culture or philosophy and make nice photos of course

Have you seen a temple before?. The history behind this temple is very intresting. But if you visited a couple of temples before this i just another one. Then spend your time to more uniqe objects. If you never viited a temple or if you are a temple neard, you should definetely go there.

A historical meaningful site. This place is almost 1000 years old and has significant meaning to Vietnamese culture. That said in order to get something out of it you must get a guide or you will just walk through the site and have no clue what it is. It is outside in the garden so if it's raining go for another attractions.I haven't seen any guide for hire but they're many in the city.

A Peaceful and Serene Attraction. We visited the Temple with our tour group. Definitely worth the one hour stop. I recommend you enter with a guide as you will learn so much more than by just walking around.

Vietnam's first national university. The Temple of Literature is the seat of Vietnam's first national university dating back to 1070, parts of its structure have been rebuilt and extended over the centuries. It was a place for learning for the children of noble families The school continued until Hue became the new capital of Vietnam. The complex consists of 5 courtyards separated by walls.The first two courts are gardens with trees, it’s a serene place which makes you forget the noise of the traffic outside. The third courtyard has a large pond, the ‘well of heavenly clarity’. On the sides of the pool are stelae, each one carried by a tortoise, the symbol for longevity and wisdom. The stelae show the names of the successful doctorate students. The fourth courtyard is the courtyard of the ‘Sage sanctuary’. There are buildings on three sides, the largest one is the ‘House of the Ceremonies’ with an imposing statue of Confucius. On either side of the courtyard there are souvenir shops (which look out of place).The last courtyard contains a large wooden structure with statues and museum exhibits. It is flanked by a large drum and a bell tower. The place is interesting for its architecture – I’s a great place for people watching, too: a bride and groom had their pre-wedding photographs taken, school classes posed for pictures and in one of the halls young kids were sitting on low chairs to listen to a lecture.

Not just another temple. We were pleasantly surprised with the Temple of Literature. It is dedicated to Confucius with Buddhist updates. There have been updates to the ancient temple with a hall dedicated to the University founders opened in 2000. Beautiful gardens and stones honoring the best students dating backed hundreds of years.

Lots of bonsaïs. .. Inside the temple it was beautiful.The shop there has all kinds of little souvenirs at pretty good prices.This was part of a tour so we were there about 30 minutes which was enough.

Tranquil and interesting. A beautiful site with lots to offer. Sculptured gardens, the remains of an ancient university, records of students, temples and a small museum type section. A whole site dedicated to education and insight into ancient vietnamese culture and society. Not a great deal of explanation but equal amounts in English as vietnamese. I followed around a group who's paid for a guide but I don't think it's worth paying for one. Spent a few hours here - nice little oasis.

Beautiful interesting and peaceful. This should be at the top of your list of places to visit in Hanoi. Its got some serious cred in the history stakes - its the quivelant of visiting the library at Trinity College Dublin. Its an absolute oasis of tranquility in the midst of the crazy city and the gift shop(s) are surprisingly good, with a wide range of cheap and interesting stuff. Great location for photography too. Definitely worth the modest entry fee.

Hostorically important venue. All about the students in ancient times and how they gained access to good jobs. The steles (kind of gravestones to us) have been well-protected and the whole site is fascinating. They had to work pretty hard in those days!

Very peaceful . Wonderful history in a very peaceful environment. Amazing gardens and bonsai everywhere. Watch out for the taxi drivers waiting game outside it pays to walk down the road before getting a taxi.

Nice place to go to!. Most beautifull temple I have visited in Vietnam. It is the oldest university of the land, that is nice. Around the temple is a nice garden where locals sport or hang out to relax.

Badly Maintained Gardens. Paid Entrance fee and only spent 15 minutes or less pacing through the Temple. Gardens looked like they were once well maintained and now no longer attended to as well. If you are an avid Temple visitor, than this is a significant one to check off your list, if you are not, it is not worth the visit.

Spectacular sight but ruined by tour groups. Really interesting historical site, well worth a visit. We were there about 3 pm and it was teeming with tourists. Mainly the large groups with guides broadcasting via microphone ruins the experience a bit. Maybe better to hear here early if you don't like crowds.
Must see. It's appatently the 1st university of Vietnam so nearly 1000 years old. Beautiful complex with old wooden temples, stone artwork, traditional shows and gardens etc...

So so not my scene. Was not Impressd at all, nice to see just if you have time. There is only a few builidingd to really take a pic of and the rest just same old same old. It is so so. Been there done that won't do it again.
Definitely worth a stop. The temple is rich with history. I suggest going with a guide who can provide insight into the location.

Central, cheap, beuatiful. Look at the back of the 100,000 Dong note- and you will see a drawing of the monument here. Confuciusand his Fellows, Tortoise sculptures, 10th century Stella's, reflection pool, all here.

Great historical evidence. Similar to the scholars hall and temple in China but with its own Vietnamese ingredient. The buildings are great and the exhibits thoughtful and informative.
Must see in Hanoi.
See the seat of learning. Good place to stroll for 20 minutes, see the buildings, read up on the history of learning and Confucianism. We went to burn a candle for a new book.
Interesting. Quick trip at outskirts of Old Quarter. Enjoyable, easy touring; beautiful flowers. Simple to get to by taxi or walking
beautiful place. Very Informative and beautiful! place to go. One of the must do in Hanoi. Beautiful park on the side.

So Interesting!. An homage to scholarly learning and a nice change from the other temples worshiping a religion's God(s). Lots of people had hired guides to lead them around and tell them about the grounds, buildings and statues and carvings. We opted to save the Wikipedia entry and do a self guided tour. We read each section's entry as we were in it and read the plaques that were hung at each gate and felt that we got the full experience. I guess it depends on what you want to spend and how many questions you want to ask.This place is a small piece of scholarly magic in the city and I'm sure visiting in the summer would have been even better with the lotus ponds in full bloom (they were dead as we went in the winter). Don't take the taxis outside asking to pick you up as their meters are most likely rigged. Take a Mai Linh taxi back to your hotel or your next destination if you can flag one down - they have reliable, legitimate meters.

Traditional Vietnamese architecture at its best. Founded in 1070, the Temple of Literature is the site of Vietnam's first university founded in 1076. The Temple is dedicated to Confucius and honours Vietnam's finest scholars. The Temple is set in formal gardens with pavilions and the Well of Heavenly Clarity. There is a pagoda with a statue of Confucius. A must see for lovers of history and traditional architecture.

Great site to visit in Hanoi. Great site to visit in Hanoi, helpful to gain an impressive insight in the education of mandarins, strange feeling when you see nowadays students celebrating their graduation in the traditional environment.

A must visit in hanoi. This place brings us back to the history of the scholars in olden days. It is a delight for photographers and highly recommended for sightseeing if you are in hanoi. A must visit
Temple!. It's a very nice park with another cool temple. There isn't much information on site about what exactly it is. Not a waste of time.
Nice place. Nice architecture. Good for people who loves art and architecture. Place gets crowded specially with lots of tourists.

Serenity in the midst of the big city. All I am going to say about this place is don't miss it - it is truly beautiful, especially when you consider it is over 1000 years old. The enlightenment in Asian sometimes leaves Western culture standing.
Stumbled in and found it very relaxing. A very pretty location to sit and reflect and get away from the hustle and bustle of the motor bikes...

Lovely. It's beautiful here and there is so much great information, all of it easily explained. The gardens and buildings are just lovely...we even went on a rainy day and it was still really good. It is definitely worth a visit if you find yourself Hanoi.

Interesting. I found the grounds and the architecture fascinating. The temple gave you a glimpse of the Taoist belief system. As we were on a tour I do not know if there was an admission price. This temple us located in downtown Hanoi so it is easily accessible. I would recommend visiting this site.

Historic and lovely . This was a part of the day long city tour that we took. The temple with its courtyards is peaceful and lovely. The whole history goes back over 2000 years and I found a quick read on Wikipedia to be very helpful.

Beautiful spot in the middle of a bustling city. We greatly enjoyed visiting this temple. We just walked around (without a guide) but the information signs were enough to keep our attention. The grounds are beautiful and definitely worth a visit.

Historic University . Beautiful ground, historic first university of Vietnam. Must see if you're in Hanoi. Nice architectural building, just a good place to visit. You can hire clothes and hat to take pictures and become a scholar.
Interesting and beautiful. The history of the monument is very interesting. The architecture and the garden are beautiful. I really liked the nice cut trees and the bonsaï.

A must do + the fine art museum. If you only have a day, this should be on your list. Having a guide might be useful or you can read about it before you go. It's amazing to see how some cultures payed lost of attention to education and literature. Make sure you get there before 2pm, so you can go the fine art museum after this as it's really impressive.

A peaceful stop to escape the traffic. There is only one entrance - if you approach from the other side you just have to keep walking and walking and walking until you find it.This was built a thousand years ago as a University. There are stellae showing the names of the graduates and a large statue of Confucius and four of his disciples. Again here I felt weird being a tourist and looking around while people were worshiping at these statues. There was also a large crane like statue and people appeared to be doing some sort of ritual where they rubbed the belly and then the legs. They were taking photos of each other doing it.We also returned here another day with our tour guide from Intrepid and we learned much more with our guide than we did on our own, and also discovered there was a whole section up the back that we didn't know about and had not been to the first time.The gardens are beautiful and peaceful and I enjoyed contemplating the history of this place as we walked around.

Interesting Site. We spent around an hour here. There's plenty of history here along with beautiful gardens to wander through. The day we visited happened to be graduation day so we were lucky to share the experience with many young graduates! Just imagine the number of cameras & photo shots taking place that day!

This is well worth a visit. Coming from someone that usually doesn't like this sort of experience, it was very interesting with a lot of history. It was amazing to see how far the literature and schooling has come over the many years. This is a must when in Hanoi

In my top 5 things to do. Despite the rain, we headed to the Temple of Literature and was pleasantly surprised. Lovely manicured gardens lead you to the temple. Impressive inside with an explosion of colour - red! Perfect for a dull day.

Birds singing. Nice 'quiet' place to rest away from the Hanoi traffic horror.
And you can actually hear birds singing in the trees above.

Nice Temple. Went to see the temple during my visit to Vietnam. Strangely, there is a fees also to visit the temple. Anyhow, its not much...so did not bother.Temple is clean, beautiful and spacious. Its a quiet place and have some nice idols to see. You get positive vibes going there. Some good photo opportunities too. Have clean bathroom facilities but need to pay for using toilets.The shops there have several stuffs including souvenirs but mostly over-prized. Overall, was a good experience.
Not a 'must see'. Had a walk through here. Was interesting and definitely recommend you drop in if youre going past, but wouldnt go out of your way especially to see it.

Worth 15 minutes if you are in the area. This was added to our day tour itinerary by our travel agent. As it is a temple to Confucious we were expecting a few of his philosophies to be posted around the attraction but were disappoint. Lucky I could look up Brainy Quote on Google to explain to my teenagers who he was. Magnificent gardens and nice historical temple but I wouldn't design your day around it.

Thought it would be boring but was actually really enjoyable. I initially wasn't going to stop here but I am glad I did. It is very quiet and beautiful. It was a very nice break from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. The long history of the temple was also very interesting.

Not to be missed. This is a must see site in Hanoi.The Temple is extensive with plenty of room around the various buildings and monuments.The buildings are well maintained in good condition with a variety of different things to see.

Temple of literature . Easy to get to on our own walking tour of Ha Noi. Many trinkets to buy. It may have been better for us to have a tour guide to find out more about the temple and statues. Very beautiful. How old are the bonsai's ???

Go if you're passing. I went with a vietnamese friend who was more than happy to spend almost the whole day there. It's a nice spot to check out if you're passing but not really much to see and could be done within an hour. I was a little disappointed.

A must visit . If you have any interest in the 54 tribes/groups of the population, this museum is for you. Has full size replicas of the various types of houses of the ethnic minorities and great photos of the faces and dress of them too.

A beautiful a serene place.. A serene and beautiful place in the middle of the frantic bustle of Hanoi, lovely gardens and ponds and pagodas with statues of Confucius swathed in colourful robes. It is an excellent example of early Vietnamese architecture. Apparently it is best to go as early in the morning as possible to avoid the crowds, when we were there newly graduated students were posing for photographs in their graduation gowns and their joy was a perfect match for a special place.

Very beautiful and peaceful place in the midst of bustling Hanoi. . About a 30 minutes walk from our hotel in the Hoan Kiem District is this beautiful and historic place. It was really nice to get away from all the horn honking and busy traffic. We spent about an hour walking the grounds and reading the informative signs. One of the highlights of our time in Hanoi.
Something to see and feel. Nice old stuff there and a projection towards the past. The fondation of VN and early scholars. Avoid joinnig big groups.

Very nice park. Beautiful park and nice small pagodas. Don't expect to spend much time there. There is a small market between the temple and the old quarter, could be worth a visit if you walk the distance

Oasis of peace. The grounds and temples are Very pretty and quaint. An absolute must see when in Hanoi. I recommend going in the late afternoon just before it shuts around 5 to enjoy it the most and to enjoy some peace and quiet from the busy streets

Not really all that interesting.... For the Vietnamese this is a homage to Confucius. For us tourists this is a place with rather mediocre buildings and artifacts. Even the bonsai are so much less than so many other places, where they don't charge you a 40.000 VND.
Great History. With a great grounds of history, this place is a peaceful calm from the city, and definite recommend!

Not as good as i had expected . We travelled to the temple with a Hanoi city Tour and i was disappointed. The Temple is small and not really pretty. But maybe because we had visited bangkoks temples and Angkor Wat before....Toilets there cost extra.
Worth to see. Really well maintained temple. A lot to learn about the cultural development in Hanoi. Easy to walk in the beautiful garden - a quiet place in busy Hanoi. Would recommend visiting it!

Worth a visit. Terrific display of the history of academics in Hanoi. Would recommend visiting. Displays of engraved stone, academic attire, musical instruments, and also a lovely wooden temple at the rear.

Amazing historic site. Amazing space with many restored buildings. The grounds are well presented and offer a glimpse into how the site was once used. Highly recommend obtaining a guide such as a guide from.Hanoi kids or hanoi free guided tours as these university students are able to give a detailed description of the university and its history
great for walking. I loved this park as it was very plesant to walk and although its popular with tourists it felt good and there are many flowers.

Stunning so surroundings topped off with interesting Vietnamese history. I loved walking through the gardens which surround the temple, and the learning about the epistemology of Vietnamese knowledge.
Vietnam First University. Great temple in hanoi, good view and it's built similar to chinese style. buy ticket before entrance 20,000vnd.

The place all Vietnamese youth must visit. Vietnam's first university. The tradition is for the students to visit this place to pray four good marks and thank good academic results. You'll be able to admire the Vietnamese traditional and colorful clothing on beautiful and delicate Vietnamese girls. They all dress up to visit this temple. The architecture is also nice

A good experience. Just not too far from my hotel in Old Quarter, The Temple of Literature is a good site for visiting in Hanoi city. Should travel with a tour guide to get more explanation of literary and educational development as well as its history as our experience. Nice display of Bonsai Trees.
So-so temple. We've been to a lot of temples and this one was just so-so for us. It was pretty, lots of people visiting. Didn't take long to walk through the area.

Ancient Buildings Set In Large Courtyard. The wall around this area extends for a full block and includes ancient buildings and temples, along with various water features. It takes one back in time and is worthwhile outing.

Oasis of calm and interesting history!. Plan on at least a solid 60-90 minutes to properly absorb all the sights and information in this place! We had our guide books and bought the small pamphlet at the gate, but wished we had hired a guide. There was a lot to learn here and we only scratched the surface. Beware the hustle of the street vendors outside the gates, though! We were taken in by a pair working together -- woman pleading with us to buy a t-shirt, working with a guy who quickly appeared to "help" her explain her asking price. If this happens to you - immediately walk away! In a matter of 5 seconds, the guy had taken 1 million Dong right out of my husband's wallet -- we felt lucky to get away without losing more!

Relaxing and inetresting to visit. We enjoyed strolling around the Temple of Literature but one needs to read up before visiting to enjoy the visit or go with a good tour guide, ours was lousy. It was an interesting experience though, when we were visiting there we a lot of students around who just graduated in full graduation outfit.

History of Vietnam. Temple of literature is first university of Vietnam. This place is very popular in history, if anybody wants to deep study of Vietnam must go there and learn many things here..Surrounding of this temple also have many places to visit.. i am recommended to all scholar must visit once here....!
lovely place. always crowded with students who either pray for good results or celebrate the good results, this monument is worth the visit.

Visited while new graduates were having photos taken. A site that reminded us of the Confucian university in Beijing, although on a smaller scale. We visited on a Saturday and it was quite busy, but adding to the atmosphere was a group of recent graduates posing for photos in front of the centuries-old structures.
beautiful temples and gardens. truly enjoyed visiting these temples, beautiful gardens and lovely temples. Most peaceful and intriguing

Amazing First Vietnamese University--Impressive!. What a beautiful and amazing center, from the 11th Century.
Very impressive addition to the trip. The history, religion, and learning all worked together. There is also a gift center where you can get good luck papers with your name written on it.

Mesmerising.. one of my favorite places In Hanoi!. This place is very interesting and has a great deal of history. one of the most ancient places and intriguing stories. The place is very well maintained. there is also an angle of the place which appears on the vietnamese currency. So all in all good place to spend time and learn about confusionism and the various kings from 10th century to 18th century.
Outstanding. Breath taking place with wonderful ancient history! My husband doesn't like tours but loved this ancient spot!

This is quite interesting but I think we are spoilt by our attractions in the UK. I am glad I saw this and I liked reading the "stiels" (I'm not sure if I have spelt this correctly) However, I was a little disappointed.
Educational. Beautiful Gardens. . Worth a visit. I was interested in learning Viet Nam's educational history, especially about Confucius. Loved the gold plated tortoise.
Very impressive. A must see in Hanoi. Probably the most interesting historical site in the city. Beautiful and very old architecture

Charming place. Temple is a significant place for the Vietnamese people. It keeps the history of nation's education history. It was a calm place divided into several zones, free to explore. One of the most famous ones there was the stelae of doctors. But there should be more information in English about all of them. The fascinating place I liked most was the last building with a retrospective of student's stuff and belongings. The atmosphere there was inspirational and challenging: after the visit I wanted to learn more about the country's history.

A thousand year old university in the heart of Hanoi. The Temple of Literature at Van Mieu is a piece of serenity in the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Close to the centre of the city, it is a 1000 year old place of learning, a university, where scholars and mandarins studied and were examined for official positions and promotions in the government of the day. There are contemplation pools, a beautiful pagoda and of course the ancient stelae (stone edifices of the results of examinations and those who passed with the highest marks). The stones stand on the shells of tortoises and have stood the test of time. Students still come here to try to absorb some of the knowledge of the scholars who studied here over the years. Graduates come for photos, but it is also a place to relax and stroll around - a real sanctuary in the heart of Hanoi. I have lived in Hanoi since 2005 and I visit Van Mieu at least once a year. Definitely worth a visit.

Wonderful experience. We were there when the graduating college students were graduating. They wore robes and in a semi circle grew their motor boards into the sky. I took a video and everyone smiled and wanted to talk.
Beautiful grounds and great architecture. The Temple of Literature was very interesting, with lots of pathways and landscaping to see. Lovely architecture and interesting history.
For those interested in VN culture. . Place that set a milestone for Vietnam university development, must visit for scholars and people interested in VN culture

Peaceful setting. Interesting and peaceful gardens, and a little bit of history. However it is not very informative, and there isn't a massive amount to see (I just had to rely on Google). Not really worth a special trip, only recommend it if you are nearby and need a break from the motorcycles.

Culture and Ancient. We had interesting information from guides, Van Mieu Quoc Tu Giam very old, Confucius worship, Chu Van An, the stele Dr .... a quiet space filings bustling street Hanoi, we were reminded of some provisions of the place, the furniture for the word he is a culture of Vietnamese people here.

Beatiful historical place. This place is a large complex with numerous buildings, temples and historical areas. We enjoyed learning about the history of the site, including its place as Vietnam's first university. It is a beautiful area with lots of students posing for pictures.

Absolutely lovely!. Go before the crowds start- at 9 a.m. to have the place to yourselves. Every corner is a photo op! just beautiful! A lot of it has been rebuilt since it was destroyed during the war, nevertheless, its a must see. The gardens are lovely and you can just spend a few hours wandering about here

Temple of awesome!. Looking at the temple before entering already gives a real good vibes so we decided to pay for entrance fee 30,000 dong ($1.25) for 4 of us. Made by a king 1,000s of years ago in honor of the great teacher, Lao Tsu or Confucius, this temple gives great inspirational advised, records of accounts, beautiful writings, magnificent cravings and much more. We really did learn a lot from it's history!!

fascinating urban oasis. This walled complex offers a pleasant retreat from the scooter races on the Hanoi streets in a leafy garden. It is a location for wedding and graduation photos which were fun to watch. If you are looking for souvenirs, this gift shop is the best around so check it out. But negotiate of course.
Historic . The place gets you in the historic side of Hanoi. It's buildings are well preserved. The last one, that many ignore, is maybe the most outstanding.

Beautiful place. The Temple of Literature is a very nice monument. It is amazing how old the space is. Beautiful gardens and nicely maintained structures. For 30,000 VND it is a bargain to enter. The gardens and lake across the street were nice too.
very interesting!. we loved the calmness of the place, located in a park. however we missed out to go with a guide to get some more explanation, because the information provided on site is limited.
How great it is. How great that a country celebrates its poets and scholars. So very advanced a culture! WishI lived in such a country!
A lovely spot. Very interesting old temple precinct, lots to see. Swarming with graduating students having photos when we went...a touch of local colour.

Get a guide! . Great place to visit but needs a guide to make it come to life.
A human one would be best though a book may do in a pinch.
An impressive structure and full of interesting history.

Breathtaking. Unbelievable experience. Read up prior to visiting and no guide required. The experience was just as magical. From the local students in their graduation robes to the famous history and rubbing for academic luck with the tortoise. A very serene and beautiful place.
So so. It's interesting because there are huge rocks with carving literature, almost 500 years old. But to me was a waste of time, the garden is not nice, and the temple is little and no great. :/

A wonderful tribute to the significance of education.. Visited this site as part of a larger tour. To gain the most benefit it is better to have a guide, however, there are excellent explanations on line so thatbyou can understand what it is and the significance of the various parts of the site.

One of the top sites in Ha Noi. I had the pleasure of visiting this site with my buddies from Hanoi Kids, Bach and Binh. It is an ancient university and temple complex with its roots going back to 1100. CE. The temple is built to honor Confucius. There are a series of courtyards to walk through after the impressive opening gate. I had the feeling of walking through history. It was calm and serene. Like the Bac Ho site, this is one of the places that is filled with locals, not just international tourists. Like the Lama Temple and the Temple of Confucius in Beijing, this temple has a series of stele to commemorate those scholars who passed their exams here at the Imperial University. It is in the last courtyard ( I think). There is a great altar and statue to Confucius. Right next door are the remans of the old Citadel.Went in March, 2013.

Great site to visit in Hanoi. We went to the Temple of Literature with a HanoiKids volunteer. We got a lot more out of our visit by doing this. Our guide was full of information and stories that really enriched our visit. The day we went there were hundreds of college students there getting their graduation photos taken.

Can be interesting with a guide to explain. The gardens at the entrance of the temple of literature are manicured and pretty. They have topary animal figures representing the animals of the lunar year.It is worth visiting the temple with a guide so that they are able to explain the significance of the temples points of interest.
Worth the visit. A culturally significant site and location of the first university in Vietnam. Plaques explain the historical significance of most areas.

Nice and pleasant. Very old university. It is nice to walk around. Beware of the hawkers at the entrance, they created confusion about their prices and then refused to return our money. Worse than elsewhere.
Interesting. Interesting and worth a stop, we had a guide that made it more relevant and explained the history of it all.

the very first university..... a very ancient place that takes you through the history of education in Vietnam. as soon as you enter, you are transported into ancient vietnam. the tortoise stele has inscriptions of the earliest scholars, the house of ceremonies hosts the altar of confucius, a great drum towards the rear end.....all these are some notable features to look out for. well worth the time spent.
Beautiful. Beautiful place that is definitely worth a visit. It doesn't take long to walk through. Nice break from the Hanoi traffic.
Interesting history . This is a very old university. Great stories behind all the statues. Take time to find out about them. Has a very Chinese influence. Worth visiting.
Well worth the visit . Well worth taking a little time to stroll to and enter the Temple of Literature to get a better understanding of Vietnamese Culture.

Local culture?. In Vietnam you can see the influence of different cultures. This temple has a strong Chinese touch and it is a very nice place for a pleasant walk away from the city noise of busy streets. You can sure take some beautiful pictures between these walls and don't forget to notice the pagoda represented on the 100.000 dong bill!
Open on a Monday. . If you realized last minute that all museums are closed on Monday, just wanted to let you know the Temple of Literature is open and bustling. Just head over earlier
What's surprise in this big city. There is only one entrance and it's on the south end of the park. I would recommend a guide as there are so many gems to be found.

A living site. The day I visited the Temple of Literature there were multiple graduations and a wedding in progress. Lots of free entertainment, music, dancing and even acrobats practicing behind one building. Clearly, this is a dearly beloved venue for special occasions. The five courtyards are fascinating in their own right as well. I particularly liked the stellae.

Temple of Literature & National University. If you are into cultural history, this is an extraordinary attraction. We visited this location with a guide and he was able to give us an in depth narration of the importance of this temple and courtyards and the significant role it played in the education of mandarins. This is one site in Hanoi that has an extensive historical background and a worthy attraction.

Enjoyable walk through history. Widely considered one of Hanoi's finest historical and cultural sites, the Temple of Literature was established in 1076. It is the Temple of Confucius that housed Vietnam's first national university. The complex of well-preserved traditional Vietnamese architecture honors Vietnam's finest scholars and men of literary accomplishment. A group of around 15 family and friends spent a couple of hours here among the halls and buildings taking in the views, artifacts, and souvenirs, and taking pictures among the five courtyards, Try to keep your options open for spending extra time here.
Interesting Confucian temple. Beautiful ancient site with interesting buildings and gardens. It's a celebration of knowledge. Worth visiting.
Well kept University. Excellent site, with plenty of original artifacts, very popular with international visitors and well worth a visit
Very enjoyable. We really enjoyed an hour wandering around the temple of literature and the 'first' university. It's worth taking a guide book with you to really know what you're looking at.

Fascinating, beautiful and informative. I didn't give myself enough time to sufficiently enjoy all that this place had to offer. The grounds are quite large with many interesting photo opportunities. The shrines are gorgeous to look at the courtyards very inviting. You should definitely go through every building, going through sometimes leads to another that you don't expect to be there. There's not enough written in English, but you can hire a guide very inexpensively and get so much more out of the experience.
Fantastic Cultural Site. Beautiful gardens, architecture, working temple, tourist site. Well worth the visit beautiful and enlightening
One day tour. So interesting, alot of history and kept in amazing standards. The gardens and buildings were stunning . So good to see. my nine yr old loved it.

Well worth a visit . One of the highlights of the trip despite the huge number of visitors ... an amazing historical location with obviously very significant reference for the Vietnamese people.
The gift shop had some affordable and interesting souvenirs too - am keen to read up more about the history of this place now ..

Interesting But Not Amazing. It was little over a week ago I visited this temple, and already my memory about what was in this temple is fading. The temple has cheap admission fees and is a nice place to occupy some time. However, the location is quite far from the centre of Hanoi where most accommodation is situated. The items on display were average (in comparison to other museums). If you have extra time, feel free to come here, but if not, you will not be missing out on much!

Beautiful site. Worth visiting. Beautiful site, well maintained. Better to go with a guide to get the most out of the visit. After the visit go to Koto restaurant on Van Mieu, it's also a a must if you come to Hanoi.
Very Enlightening. Ideally go with a local guide so you get to learn about the history of this place - try and get there early so you miss the crowds.....amazing.

Interesting temple. We were interested to hear that this was an Ancient university and about the years of study that had to be undertaken here. It was fun to see groups of current graduates ( from schools, I think) lining up in front of Confucius in their cap and gowns for photos.

Crowded, but a must see. We've met the temple in Dec, which is part of the wedding season in Vietnam, so the place was very crowded with locals. On sunday, you can see many praying people there and a monk gave some service. Very nice experience!

Serene and Beautiful Site. This is a beautiful temple dedicated to Confucius, his students and a place of learning. There is signage in English, French and Vietnamese keeping you informed about the various statues you see. There is also limited information about the history of the temple. Our tour guide spoke in Vietnamese, so I'm sure he explained some of the symbolism in more detail. It is still a beautiful site, though. Lots to see, take your time and look around at some of the hidden treasures - door guardians, little lions, clouds on the roof, flags, students taking graduation photos, stellas, etc.
Again, in my view over-rated.. Again, in my view over-rated. We did a half day walk all over central Hanoi & glad we had the option to do our own options.
Pretty but i feel you need a tour guide. On its own it's pretty however its stories are only uncovered with a tour guide, we went with APT and it was more interesting then a self guided tour.
A connection to the ancient past. Evocative, impressive, informative. Loved this attraction. A - relatively - tranquil setting in which to enjoy a thousand years of history and learning.

Locals Have Photos taken here. Confuscious Temple - they were preparing for an event while we were here - with local musicians practising. Also graduates or prospective graduates come here to have their photos taken.

Heritage but Dilapidated. I first visited the Temple of Literature in 2002. It was a revelation of history and heritage. But I felt that the place was dilapidated. It was ok then as Hanoi was just opening up for tourism. But after 13 years, the place has got worse and there has not been much effort made to ensure the place live up to its heritage. The only change is the new ticket booth to collect toll. There is not much to read or hear about the place as the guides are not readily available. But it is still a good place to go in Hanoi to learn about the literary and educational development and the influence of Confucius in Vietnam, provided you have a tour guide

Graduation day. There were a lot of new graduates taking group photos and celebrating the end of school. So nice to look at happy young people.The temple is interesting, much more interesting than I thought it would be. The garden is nice and it must be beautiful in the summer.Well worth a visit.

Historical Temple of Literature. Strolling through the grounds is a nice refuge from the hectic Hanoi streets. It's very helpful having a guide explain the history and significance of everything within the temple grounds.

Holiday at Hanoi. The place is a tourist attraction for those interested in History. This place is also visited by local students for worship, before they take up an examination.I liked the quietness and the serenity of the place. The decoration of the Chinese with flower decorated carpet along the walkway is striking about this place. Nice display of Bonsai Trees. Camera is definitely required. The visit will require about 1 hour.

maybe first sight to see inside in Hanoi. one of their oldest palces, interesting back in times, histories, architecture (even if it's rebuilt somewhere 18C), min.1h to spend there. A short walk behind the Ga Ha Noi Station through some Hanoi specific streets.

Interesting and varied - but you'll need a tour guide. Fascinating temple dedicated to Confucius, his students and a place of learning. There is signage in English, French and Vietnamese keeping you informed about the various statues you are seeing and the history of the temple. That said the information is limited and there is so much symbolism through out that you could miss it unless you have a local or a tour guide to help explain it for you in more detail. In which case the grading would move to "4 - very good" Lots to see, take your time and look around at some of the hidden treasures - door guardians, little lions, clouds on the roof.
An ancient university. Simple but unique and amazing. Its a real ancient temple of university at the past. Shows us that education is an imprtant aspect anytime

Good to visit. We took photos and bought souveniors. A tour guide was explaining to his guests about touching the phoenix stomach and tortise head for luck. So we did. Some students graduated n were there with their class to take grad photos.

A tribute to the value of education. According to Confucius a kingdom should nurture knowledge to be strong. Therefore a king should educate its subjects. This is the site of the first university of Vietnam and still where students have their graduation ceremonies. Divided in a series of courtyards and landscaped areas the buildings give visitors the opportunity to contemplate the value of education. This is particularly important in an era dominated by religious intolerance and celebrity culture.

Definitely worth a stroll. Has a feel ofva ancient ruin to it. Pretty old but full.of history. Ancient Vietnam really no different from Chinese n all the stelea reflected that history. I wished more we're readable. Quite a few signs,we're in English which helped enhanced the outstanding. Nice cool day, so good walk around.

Visited as part of a tour . I think most tours will take you here, and it is definitely a place with plenty of history. Shrines and places of worship aren't really my cup of tea and I wouldn't have been sad to have missed this off the list and done some other sight seeing. Going with a guide probably helps, but there are signs in English to assist.

Really enjoyable. I hadn't been here before on previous trips to Hanoi so was very pleased to go this time. I found the whole place to be fascinating and the atmosphere was enhanced by students preparing for their granulation ceremony.

Amazing visit which must not be missed!. This is a different temple experience where one get to sight many interesting areas of literature related background. We had the eBuddies with us explaining the rich history of the temple and got to know that the temple used to be an university during the good ol'days and now, it's a temple where majority of the students would drop by to pray for good grades. It was so much bigger than I thought. We toured the whole university for more than 1 hour and it was a very worthwhile trip. We got to see graduating students in groups celebrating their convocation and it was indeed a sight not to be missed. I would recommend this area of attraction as this is not a usual sighting at most Asian countries.

Lots of Knowledge. It was very busy here there were lots of students robed in Graduation Gowns having there photos taken. The gardens here were nice except for the water features this was due to the lack of rain in the wet season,

It is part of Hanoi's history and cannot be missed. Whether you want to spend at the Temple of Literature only half an hour or 2-3 hours, don't miss this landmark if you visit Hanoi. You can learn a lot about the city's and Vietnam's history. It is a pleasant stroll in a park with internal courtyards and temples. never too crowded. I recommend you read as much as you can before going so that you can really enjoy the visit and better understand how this monuments used to "live" when it was still used by the wannabe State Officials.

Pretty and authentic. Pretty p let ace very busy with tourists making it hard to get pictures. Would recommend visitibg and going early. Good place to buy and send a postcard t house ey will stamp and post it for you for a small fee 20k vnd for New Zealand and card was only 5k vnd

Worth a leisurely stroll!. The Temple of Literature was a great way to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi's city motorbikes. We enjoyed stepping into the quiet, solitude and enjoying the scenery.
Pursuit of Knowledge. A place where the pursuit of knowledge and education is highly prized and ingrained into the psyche of the people for the betterment of the society.

a place to reflect. Beautiful structures that you can only see in this part of the world with a rich history. This was a great place to stroll through and escape the chaos of Hanoi for an hour or so. Must see for history and culture buffs.

We enjoyed the visit!. This was the first stop of our city tour, our first contact with their history and religion. The building itself is beautiful, it's the first university in Vietnam. When we visited, several students were having their graduation pics taken, girls wearing traditional dresses (beautiful), guys wearing suits, this added a special vibe to the place. You shouldn't miss it.
Not worth the time. Nice complex, but not particularly interesting. There are more fun things to do around Hanoi including in the Old Quarter. I'd skip this.

moment of quiet and peace. While Europe was suffering the Viking expeditions and trying to climb out of the dark ages, this was the place where one of the kings established the first university of Vietnam. It is a little haven of peace in the middle of the hectic Hanoi traffic, with a number of successive gardens leading you to the actual temple. You should visit this place if you like historical places of high cultural value, and quiet gardens, where you'll see students celebrating (their graduation), throwing their hats into the air. You will spend around 30 to 40 minutes inside, depending on whether you like to rush or sit down for a while and just enjoy the place

Visit Temple of Literature. We stayed in the Old Quarter and walked to the Temple of Literature - it was a great way to explore Hanoi. The temple of Literature is a must see in Hanoi. We loved strolling through. When we visited there was a graduating class posing for photos. It was fun to watch the excitement. Visit the gift shop near the back - great vietnamese cards and lots of things to look at.

Nice architecture and rich history. Nice place to visit to see the Chinese influence in Vietnam. This was the country's first university and dedicated to Confucius.We went with a local tour guide which made the visit more interesting and also learned so much more. There is a lot to take in here, the place is rcih with history. We went a bit later in the day and it was less busy than first thing according to our guide. It is also a popular place for those local kids who have graduated to come and take pictures in their gradution gowns and dresses, which was nice to see.

Not much to see.. . I get the historical significance but this isn't an active University or anything so it was not that impressive. It's not a large area and like most places in Vietnam, the English descriptions are severely lacking so it ended up being a quick walk into an old temple on the way to the Hanoi Hilton museum.

Informative. Quite a big area to explore, great for you to spend time in. Temple is interesting and beautiful. A pity the lake was dried up, no lotuses for me to see. Bet it would look prettier in summer. Spent around 30,000VND. Interesting to see university graduates in this area too, seemed like they were graduating in this area.

Knowledge is king . As an English Literature graduate I felt I needed to make the pilgrimage here.It's worth the effort - just 30k VND to get in and then a whole 54k sq m is yours to explore.The temple is divided into courtyards containing different stuff: ponds, gardens,, artefacts, shrines, a big gong and a massive bell. There are also stones inscribed with the names of all those who passed the royal exams, which was an incredible accomplishment. We spent a happy hour here, wandering around and watching loads of young people dressed in graduation clothes, posing for the obligatory photos.

Lovely place with a rich history. I'm so glad I visited this place, and really enjoyed strolling on the grounds. The architecture, temples, and writing are strongly influenced by Chinese culture, so it was nice to see that mix of Chinese and Vietnamese influence. Great place to spend 1-2 hours at!

Important place. Nice, leisurely visit on the grounds of the university. Once much larger, the site is now pleasant to walk and explore, and you can get a earl feel for the efforts the students had to put in to get their names engraved on the stones.

One of the best places in Hanoi, a symbol of Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is really beautiful, serene and rich in Vietnamese cultures and history. There are many stories about students taking exams, about the 4 holy animals of dragon, unicorn, phoenix, turtles, about Confucius and his disciples, etc. The architecture is really beautiful and interesting. This is a holy place for Vietnamese students so there are always chances to take photos with them in their beautiful "ao dai".
Must see in Hanoi. This was my favourite tourist attraction in Hanoi. The temple is beautiful and the history very interesting. Many good photo opportunities. Note: 1000 VND to use the toilet.

Long route to Mandarinhood. This served as a tertiary institution for the best scholars in the empire of Vietnam where they were trained in Confucian philosophy,thought and literature and prepared them for the mandarinate. The best students had their names carved on stome stelae in the grounds and you can see where the students lived and studied as well as the various altars for their devotions. Good experience.

Laid back temple. The temple of literature is a quaint temple in the middle of the city, with gardens and lotus ponds scattered around charming looking structures. The Bonsai plans in the complex are not to be missed!
Great historic landmark!. Fascinating and beautiful place to visit. If you want a glimpse into Vietnamese history, this is the place to experience it.
beautiful, even in the rain. Because it is primarily outside, it is most appreciated in good weather. the gardens are beautiful and worth photographing from all the angles.

Condusive to study. A large complex of pagoda style buildings for the study of Mandarin for civil service jobs during the Chinese era. The Tortoise Stele were interesting in that the stele that rested on the back of a tortoise had different facial expressions. We arrived on high school graduations. What better place to hold a ceremony.
Super Nice. Great history.. very nice architecture, it is worth visiting.. Plus one of the rare attractions that is open full-time (without lunch break)

Confusius. Although we were guided by a tour guide we were never Although we were guided by a tour guide we were not clear on what this was. There is a large statue of Confusius but it's not a temple. We were told students come to take pictures here as a group. They also pray before exams. t clear on what this was.
Beautiful monument .... On a sunny day, it is a beautiful place to visit and spend some time walking around. Highly recommend this place.

Graduation Day/s held here.. Lots of graduates from University/ies having their pictures taken - same academic robes for all disciplines - shrine/ temple to Confucius. Lovely to see children (from pre-school settings) and young people of all ages attending in formal, authentic dress.

Fascinating. The temple of Literature is a series of buildings in an attractive garden, which was apparently the site of a university founded in 1048.when we were there many students had arrived to have their class photos taken as it was the end of the school year. Many were beautifully dressed in costume and were great fun. Interesting stories about and statues of early kings who were involved with the university.
Historical place of Vietnamese. The temple show the ancient architect of vietname. Some information show in temple about ancient vietname too,

Like a very peaceful park. We set out for Temple of Lit & National University without having much concept of what to expect. It is a lovely, peaceful park-like setting with gardens, statues etc. Luckily there were lots of students from universities around the area, in their robes, with balloons and flowers etc. having graduation pictures taken. Apparently it is a traditional place to take graduation photos. Seeing the very excited soon-to-be graduates in their graduation attire (similar to Westerners) was fun and brought the place to life (among the stone tablets of Confusius.) Have to admit we didn't spend a lot of time on the actual history of the place, other than looking at the stone tablets (maybe you want a guide?) but we enjoyed the park and student festivities.

beautiful must visit place in Hanoi. very peaceful and pleasant place to visit. one can fire a guide to tell the stories of the place or just come here to enjoy the gettaway from the chaos of the streets.

University of Confucius. Interesting history of how Confucuism came to Vietnam. The temple and architecture was fascinating. It was really busy with lots of students taking pictures of their graduation which wouldn't happen until a year later. I really learned about Chinese alphabet and Vietnamese Sunol which was the old alphabet. Need a tour guide to understand the history or else it would just be another temple. Not really exciting because Hanoi has lots of temples.
Nice garden and little bit history. Former university, nowadays monument and nice garden, where the undergraduate students celebrate their successfully finished studies. Quiet place in hectic city.

An unusual place to visit. This place deserves a bit of time and a good guide to explain every thing . Thse stone diplomas, unusual metal statues ,the pagodas with the large statues and the lovely flowers put as offering are all things to see.

Top Temple. One of my favourite temples in Vietnam. Temple is set in nice surrounding gardens and many statues.Very relaxing, although quite a lot of parties of students on graduation day trips, which didn't bother me I thought it added to the experience.You must not miss this place whilst in Hanoi, absolutely unmissable!

Confucius place. Great place to find out when the first university of Vietnam , all the literature of the ancient kingdom Ly dynasty. Actually the name is wrongly translated, the right meaning is Confucius temple
Beautiful temple. One of the better temples we visited. Must see in old quarter. Nice gardens, reflective ponds etc....
Heritage visit. You need a guide to understand the history and purpose of these buildings. We were there on a day when local students were having photo shoots for graduation.

cutural place but overcrowed. I visited this old university at the weekend when hundered of students coming. we need to wait quite long time to get the ticket. although crowed , it was worth a visit, very cultural and historical. recomended you go on a weekday

Amazing location. Students in their hundreds come for the blessing before (and after) their exams and it is a photographic mecca for their families and friends. The temple, paths, gardens and surrounds can be crowded with proud, happy people. Great fun.

Very interesting. It's very picturesque and vey interesting. Some of the less obvious exhibits have no explanation in English which is a litlte frustrating, but the lovely photo opportunities make up for this
Very interesting. Beautiful buildings, lovely grounds. Was filled with young students when we were ther which was so appropriate .
Beautiful temple complex. This is such a picturesque site that we saw many student groups taking graduation pictures here as well as brides and grooms. Definitely worth a visit.

Need a Tour Guide Here. We had a great tour guide here who explained all of the history here and there is a lot. They were even having a graduation ceremony here while we were visiting. It's a beautiful place but the history that our tour guide explained going back to the 1100's and the original Vietnamese scholars stones on display was amazing. If you just walked around, you would see a beautiful place but the history makes it so much better.
nice. quite coufused which way in the front door ( the map quite ambigous ). nice place. but dunno what to do

Amazing! A must. Leaving this town without seeing it is unforgivable.. Very nice and relaxing place in a busy town. Spent the day walking around and got lucky as there were lots of students around for their graduation, so some very nice photos.

A guide is well worth the investment. We visited the Temple of Literature with a local and she suggested that we use a guide to make the most of the experience and she was right. The guide provided an explanation of the five courtyards that compose the Temple of Literature, outlining the relevance of each section. As there is not a great deal of interpretive material the information provided was very useful, and if it had not been for her we would not have discovered the final courtyard (it appeared that not many people did as it was along a little path that went around the second last courtyard's final building).Interesting facts such as the university only being open to men, but one woman who disguised herself did attend and became the emperor's daughter's tutor provided greater insight.Explanations associated with the turtles and dragons further provided useful value.

It was okay.... I read about the Temple beforehand and it was fascinating. However, going there myself wasn't a very fascinating experience. It might've been better if I had a guide to tell me the story while we were roaming around. There was a graduation there when I went, so in a way, it made the trip better and more colourful. Managed to talk to some of the students who felt very honoured to be a part of the Vietnamese tradition and culture.

The place to see in Hanoi. I enjoyed it very much. It seemed interesting on the internet, but it ended up being one of my favourite sights in Hanoi. Just really nice to stroll around and take some pictures. Very beautiful architecture.
