Really lovely to explore . The first University in Vietnam inspired by Chinese architecture is an incredible place to visit if you are in Hanoi. We are fortunate enough to be there at the time of a graduation ceremony finishing so we had the opportunity to see students celebrating and taking graduation photos in beautiful gowns and suits!
Temple of Literature. Temple is easy to find & an excellent venue to explore & contemplate! Have a guide to explain all the rituals.
a have in the middle of lake. Beautiful peaceful location in the middle of the lake with the most gorgeous and special Bonsai trees

Nice place to walk around and take a picture. Hoan Kiem lake is one of the attractive spot in the central of Hanoi. There is a small temple where has a stuff of really huge turtle. In front of the temple you will see the red wood bridge. It is so beautiful. In the morning and evening, the local people will come to exercise here so you can do it too.

Great architecture!. Definitely worth the time to explore this temple. We were there during a graduation ceremony and the temple was filled with students in graduation robes. A very well maintained garden and plenty of space to spend some time relaxing. There is also great Bun Cha around the corner - great for an afternoon visit with lunch!

First university in Vietnam. The temple of literature and national university is visibly very much linked to Chinese culture and especially Confucianist education. This is the place where many Vietnamese students go for graduation photoshoot. Worth a visit.

Historical Site. The Temple of Literature and National University is a must see when in Hanoi. We had a guide which helped us appreciate the buildings and the history behind them. From walking through the gate to again leaving, I was thoroughly captivated.
A beautiful temple complex. A beautiful oasis of temple buildings and well manicured gardens. An interesting insight into early Vietnamese history.

Quick Walking Tour Sufficient. Visited with a private tour guide. While architecturally pretty, you do not need a lot of time here (15-30 minutes would be more than sufficient). We were there during graduation season, so a lot of students were taking professional photos and celebrating.

Interesting. This is a very attractive place to visit.
It was a university and is a temple for worship. The information provided is stimulating and the exhibits beautiful and well displayed. It is well worth spending an hour there.

Beautiful historical buildings . This is a very tranquil place in the middle of Hanoi. We went with a guide who was able to explain to us a lot about the history of the country and the temple.
However, I think it would be just as good to wander around the temples and gardens and take in the atmosphere.

Interesting for a short visit - best with a guide. I was on a tour with Hanoikids and had a fantastic time at the Temple of Literature. It is fascinating to understand how academic works during the olden days. There were interesting Confucius inscriptions, altars etc. Worth the visit but best with a guide as lots of descriptions are in Vietnamese.

Nothing to see much. But if you are in Hanoi must visit... One of the major tourist attraction. one of the main attraction of Hanoi. but if you are planning to buy some gifts, plz do compare with all the shops inside...
History!. One of the oldest educational establishments in the world! Even though there presently is no formal teaching today - students go there for graduation

Interesting and educational . A nice place where you can learn about how and in what kind of environment Vietnamese youngsters used to study. The architecture is also eye-filling. It is also interesting to see students (sometimes coming from very far away)come and pray for their success at passing their exams and especially graduates who come to take pictures for their graduation ceremony.

Interesting. Worth a visit especialy if you have a guide to fill you in on the history and how it came about.
Go first thing in the morning as it gets busy

Temple pic on back of local VND currency. The most interesting part of this place was to see the temple that is pictured on the back of the VND currency. I know this place has history but because I'm not a local, it was hard for me to appreciate.

Beautiful gardens!. The temple of literature is a must-see in Hanoi. We went there on a rainy day but the views in the surrounding gardens are spectacular and the ancient doctoral steles inside the temple are precious. Worth the visit!

Fascinating & Beautiful. buildings are beautiful & very well kept. architectural designs of the area is amazing. lots of finer detail can easily be missed.
fascinating history & culturally significant. having a guide or researching the grounds is a must.
busy with tourists, special occasion photographers and events. small admission fee

Interesting Experience. We walked around the temple without a tour guide but wished we had someone to answer all of our questions.. The grounds were lovely to walk around and it was nice to see all of the graduates getting their pictures taken. My 12 year old son was not bored and found it all very interesting. I would definitely recommend doing some research before you go or getting a tour guide to explain the history to you while you are there.
Garden Lover ?. If you love gardens and history you will love the Temple of Literature .We were lucky to see a Graduation ceremony with all the students in traditional dress...Unforgettable .
MUST SEE. To visit Temple of Literature and National University is a MUST. It is one of the worlds most exiting places to visit. You can spend minimum half day but full day is suggested.

Confucius in Vietnam. This is not so much a temple but a little city, rich in history and culture. The site of the first Royal university in Vietnam, it is popular with university students on graduation day. We witnessed several groups of graduates posing for photographs in various sections of the temple. There are 4 gates to pass through, each representing one set of university exams. At the very end is the site of the Royal university itself and the temple to Confucius. The grounds are peaceful and well worth a visit.

Small but loveable. When i visited here, there's many graduates celebrate their graduation here. I think is it a kind of tradition because the temple itself is full of stone slabs with names of the scholars in the past.The temple itself is small, but i love it. Especially at the most south area where a Confucius statue is standing

My Visit to the Temple of Literature. Visiting the Temple of Literature was part of the Ha Noi City Tour and being there made me feel like I was in China because of the architecture. The historical place might not be of interest to very young children, and having a tour guide s recommended to answer questions tourists might have along the way. There are also a few souvenir shops inside the temple to remind you about your visit once you get back home. The place is quite big but can be explored on foot without any hassle.

A very interesting stop in the centre of Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is a very interesting site providing historical insights into Vietnam. The site itself is a pleasant setting, and can be very busy when university graduates come there with their friends to celebrate their graduation (I saw this as a plus!)

Eye-opening and very interesting. Very accessible from the Old Quarter by foot. Without going into the fascinating history of this place, you should visit because of its age and antiquity and the feel of the place; I does have 'a feel' about the place. It has ancient buildings, temples, ponds and has a tranquillity about it even with where it is located. You could spend a lot of time there in peaceful contemplation, or even take some first-rate photos.

historic temple. One of the better maintained temples, entrance fee @ vnd30,000. You can also get a calligraphy written of your choice @ vnd100,000. Nice place if you appreciate history, those rock stelees honour scholars from past dynasties 1400-1700 AD.

Calmer in the madness. Not there for very long. Quieter than the surrounding madness of Hanoi. Many groups of graduating students come for photos at this time of year. Try to get a guide for the Confucian temple. 30.000d /pp entry fee.
Insightful. Temple of Literature is located in the heart of the Old Quarter, By visiting the temple one will be able to appreciate the interaction between Vietnamese and Chinese cultures.

Try and pick a quiet time. The guidebook said an oasis of calm in central Hanoi. Unfortunately our morning visit coincided with hordes of students all dressed up and having their graduation photos taken. Whilst this was an interesting spectacle in itself, the crowds did make it difficult to appreciate the harmonious layout of temples and gardens. Perhaps late afternoon is best - I'd certainly like to revisit sometime.

Temple of Literature & National University. This is the place where people came to learn and bow down before giving any kind of exams. We saw loads of students who came with the convocation outfit to take pictures in big groups. Nice place to visit
Lovely for a walk around. We were there on a day when there were many graduations in town. There were tons of people taking photos. It is a lovely site so it is easy to see why they came here.
Good time . Good place to go see, however doesn't take very long. If you want it to be more interesting, make sure you get a guide!

Quiet and mistic. This temple is mistic and beautiful. When we went a lot of school graduates were there for photo section. The temple is very nice inside. One shop is inside the temple but products are little bit expensive. One hour is enought to see this place.

Temple of literature. our tour guide from free walks of Hanoi took us thru the whole complex explaining every detail and the importance of knowledge. It is a beautiful space, and we actually got to witness a few local graduates celebrating their special day, which only made our experience more interesting.

Kind of ok. We popped in but nothing to write home about.
Nice buildings and temple in nice grounds but would not rush back.
Good for 30 mins visit.

Interesting buildings but way too crowded. Daily graduations make for great photo opportunities with the temple in the background. I was confused for the purpose of this location because there was nothing to explain what everything meant and our tour guide just dropped us off. The buildings were interesting but not on my top of the list for things to see.

If you go take a guide. We had Phoung from Hanoi free tours, what an Amazing young lady!! So much knowledge in one so young, great to see, she explained the history behind the layers, a definite must see
Gorgeous temple`. This was a beautiful temple. I went when university graduates were taking grad pictures and it was an adorable sight. Aside from that, I enjoyed the architecture and garden scenery.

A very interesting place to visit. Dropped with our guide, a private tour, not sure what to expect, place was buzziing with graduating students.
As others have said take a camera, plenty to photograph
You need an hour or two
Well worth a visit
See photos

Amazing history. Extraordinary history to this former university. It was great to wander through today with so many bright young Vietnamese who were there to have their graduation photos taken. The history of learning is incredible.
You can go if you have the time. Small place.. guide is a must. You will see exciting school graduates coming for pics. Apart from that very little to do.
Nice but nothing special. As other attractions in Hanoi, it did not wowed me. I liked the stones with the names of the graduates

Interesting place with plenty of photo opportunitues. We visited this place recently. This place appears massive. We wish we have a bit more time to explore. The buildings are beautiful and there are plenty of places that we wish we have time to take pictures. As this is the temple of literature, there was lots of graduates taking pictures there for their graduate photos. I think if U want to see lotus flowers this is not the time as there was only dry stems in the pond.

Learning Only. Imagine, a university without a football team. Or basketball team or marching band. Devoted just to learning. What a concept! Very interesting and lovely. A highlight for those interested in architecture. Bring your camera.

Lovely Place with a Great History!. First of all, we went here at a PERFECT TIME. The day we went, Senior University Students were here to take their Graduation photos, so it was festive! Ballons, lovely VietNamese outfits, caps/gowns...very, very festive and exciting. The grounds are lovely, probably better in the summer as some of the water plants were done for the season, but other flowers were lovely. There are several buildings, some not quite original, but rebuilt.This is the oldest and first University in VietNam...

A study in history. This temple is dedicated to learning. It was Vietnam's first national university. There are 5 courtyard, each one hold significant to literatures. On the day of the visit, many graduating students came here to pray for a successful future, going on to universities.
Interesting place to visit. . It was an interesting place to visit, I wish I had a bit more context while visiting. Wouldn't say it's a must see but glad I went. Good chunk of the area is just shops.
okay.. not too much to see here. just neat that it's an ancient spot for confucius teachings. grounds are a large garden-like area. gotta pay to enter. it's fine nothing too exciting.

Hanoi - Temple of Literature (Van Mieu). This is a Temple of Confucius. It housed 1st national university. It consists of various pavilions, halls, statues and stelae of doctors and places where offering ceremonies took place. It appears on the back of the 100,00 dong banknote,
Go see it. Great Temple to visit. Beautiful architecture and worth the visit. Student tickets at half the cost are available.

Can't wait to graduate!. A place to view the rich heritage in Vietnamese higher education. A place to feel the excitement of young people approaching a time to graduate from college and face the challenging world. A must visit place in Hanoi

Must see. Whenever I visited Hanoi, I always take time to visit this place. Honestly, I do not know why I have been this place so many time. I love the atmosphere in Temple of literature. In Lunar year, You will see a lot of students wears tradition uniform to take a photos with their friends. it is the way to records them memories about the student's lìfe

Good, but not very good. Some buildings, landscape and a few shops selling handicrafts. The temple itself is like others in Vietnam, now within what seems to be the University campus, so many students around. Can be given a pass on a tight schedule.

went twice - big differences in crowd. We went on our own on a Friday afternoon and, although it was by no means empty, the crowds were no problem and the scene was relatively peaceful. On Sunday afternoon, when we returned with our tour group, and it was absolutely swarming with hoards of students and loud tourists. Totally different experiences.
Very Interesting. We were fortunate enough to visit here while touring with our "Free Hanoi Tour Guide", so we learned a great deal about the history. It's a beautiful place, full of rich history.
Great Temple visit.. This place is amazing. Very serene and a great location to visit for a stroll around. Definitely worth the time.

Beautiful setting. The complex takes up a large city block. We easily spent a couple of hours wandering around. It seemed it was graduation day during our visit because there were many students in cap and gown having pictures taken. This made it all the more congested. There's a nice little park on the other side of the wall where you can sit and relax for a bit. Well worth a visit. Entrance fee was 30,000 VND. Bring extra cash for the pay toilets (2000 VND).

This is a lovely place. We were here in November There where a lot of students who had graduated possibly from secondary level or maybe college Apparently it is traditional for these student to visit here en masse to have photo's taken They have stunningly beautiful traditional dresses (can't remember the name ) and the atmosphere was great It is a lovely old complex The only negative is the hoard of ladies selling fans who were a bit aggressive .Not clear if there were so many street venders because of the tourists or the amount of students who were there on the day we visited There was supposed to be a traditional music performance but we could not find any music

Ancient Confucian background!. I came here to learn a little about Vietnam's Confucian background, is quite strange. This is the first university of Vietnam, very ancient. With quite beautiful campus.

Peace in the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. This place looked really hectic from the outside, but once in there is a chance to spread out. The gardens and courtyards are really nice (and peaceful). Have to remember that the buildings are not as old as they look.The last building has interesting displays and statues relating to the university.

Wonderful Visit. Olden university were all highlighted persons graduated from. Now, it is a museum to visit. Nice flowers, fountains, decorations, architecture, shops, temples and many others. The inner entrance gate is printed in Vietnamese currency. Luckily exams are nearby and therefore we met with many graduates who come for pictures in a nice groups with uniforms.

Beautiful. Beautiful old Temple. One of my favorite things about it is that it still seems that is being used by locals today for things like graduation. There was a great atmosphere with what seemed like graduating classes. Worth a look!

Good for relaxing if there aren't many people. Fascinating with College Grads. . This time I went there there were so many people mainly College Grads with friends, family & photographers. It was a sight because of what they were wearing especially the girls. Colorful long dress & when they lose for a pic the combination of they're dresses were magnificent. You can see the happiness in their faces. Was worth a visit...

Very interesting. About a thousand years worth of history here. It was like stepping into the past. Very interesting to see the stone tablets with students' names carved into them. There was also a bunch of graduating students that were having their photos done there which was fun to watch.

Temple For God of Knowledge. The temple shows true culture of Vietnam in paying respect to education and for teaching high values in life for students.
It was amazing to see number of students visiting the temple to seek blessing of God for success in the career.
The construction of the temple is worth seeing.
One should visit this temple while in Hanoi

Prepare well and you will meet history, prepare not, and you will only see buildings!. The Temple of Literature has a long - really long - history behind. It is a series of buildings with all the nice old fashioned Vietnamese architecture that you can imagine, but if you go, be sure to read up on the history of the temple, as it will let you understand why it is not just buildings. A very worthwhile visit and re-reading stuff makes me want to go again.
Elegant surroundings but not much to see without a guide. Recommend getting a guide as while it was picturesque inside the temple there was not a great deal to see. 30 mins - 1 hour more than enough.

Interesting place to see. We visited this place for half an hour or so. There were a lot of students having their graduation pictures here, so it was busy, but its a really nice place, very peaceful and interesting to see.
great visit. when we turned up there were a number of students having their graduation photos taken which was interesting - good for a visit
Temple of Literature & National University. It is worth to see this place. Different culture and architecture. Short distance with taxi. Easy trip.

Educational. I probably should have gone for a guided tour as those around me with guides in many different languages seemed to be more impressed with the experience. Definitely come to see the graduations if possible. Nice mix of old scholars and new scholars.

Good to visit once! . Good to visit once! Temple of Literature is a place where the local graduates take their graduation photos as the place is to commemorate Confucius. Entrance fee: VND 30,000 per adult. It is about 20 mins car ride from Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and taxi fare costs about VND78,000-80,000.
Stunning. Stunning place and grounds. Spent a good afternoon looking around and absorbing the atmosphere. Very well kept and reasonably price. Worth every penny

A piece of history. Located on Quoc Tu Giam St. in Hanoi, and at almost a thousand years old, the Temple of Literature is in the western section of the Old Quarter. Consisting of impressive old architecture with ornate carvings into the stone and wood, it also houses an altar to Confucius, complete with offerings of fruit and flowers.The Temple of Literature was Vietnam’s first university. Initially for the privileged, that changed over time so all could be educated. The temple is made up lots of pavilions and halls and symbols of past graduates. Being a turtle fan, I was most impressed by the golden turtle. Turtles are very symbolic in Vietnam.Our only regret is that the season didn’t allow for displaying of the lotus blossoms.

Vietnam University with local archetecture. This place shows the Chinese Confucius influence with buildings and altar. Small cost of admission, when we went the students were graduating from college. All women wearing local dress with flowers in hair. quite a sight to see!
First University!. If you like to discovery traditional history Vietnam, you should come here for more. It'sfirst university of Vietnam, old style contruction , nice place.

A great place to watch locals celebrate. Of course I found great photo ops amongst the buildings, stele, and landscaping complete with topiaries, but the greatest photo ops were the locals celebrating graduations and posing for their graduation photos. We were even included in a photo with a local. Great fun just people watching against a 1000 year old backdrop!

The cradle of Vietnamese culture. Beyond the (huge) historical significance of the place, this is a very nice park and the centre of much activity in Hanoi (graduation ceremonies, photo exhibitions, etc.). The buildings added relatively recently at the back blend in perfectly with the older section.

A lot of graduation students are here!. We saw a lot of local graduation students in here from different age groups. They dressed up in the traditional Vietnamese clothings and it's so fun to see it. Temple charges 30000 VND per person and it's very very crowded. Although I like the festive atmosphere, but it's too crowded and we hardly can have time/place to take some pictures. I still recommend people to visit this one if you are in Hanoi.

Worth a visit..... I would recommend a visit to this Temple, along with visiting Vietnam Fine Arts Museum which are within a five minute stroll of each other. The Temple was thronged the day we visited, it seemed there was a graduation of some sort taking place. We didn't stay too long however it is a beautiful attraction set within a well maintained grounds.

Watched amazing graduation celebrations. I arrived at the temple while photos were being taken of graduating students. Although crowded it was a lovely festive atmosphere with plenty of photo opportunities including ceremonies and rituals with traditional drums and bells. Wonderful morning.

Beautiful and peaceful. We visited on a day when all the schools were there taking pictures which made it very fun. Its a good starting place to learn about the about the history and culture of Vietnam.

A wonderful experience. We went on the weekend and the temple was full of final year university and college students looking for luck in their final studies. It is a beautiful ancient place which shows the contemporary high value placed on education and hard work that all the people we met from different areas described. Seeing so many young and enthusiastic people in itself was exciting.
Definitely worth a visit. This is definitely worth a visit whilst you are in Hanoi, we visited with HanoiKids which certainly added to the enjoyment with their added knowledge.
No longer a university. Worth a visit to see the buildings but not much more. A bit lively when we visited as there were graduation ceremonies taking place but it is no longer used as a uni.

First University in Hanoi. When I visited this place, there were lot of students taking their so called "graduation picture".. It is an interesting custom of the students to ensure they have good photo before they all graduated and busy with their own activities.
Moreover, you could find temple inside with Confucius and his best students inside the the building.
Very special place. It was a special day, we saw large groups of young students celebrating their graduation, a wonderful and joyful spectacle.
Very pretty. Lovely gardens and lots to look at. Easy to get to as well and gives a good insight into the culture and heritage for those who are time poor.

Historic and interesting restored buildings. The spacious layout and calm spaces were a sharp contrast to the bustling roads, traffic and vendors that circled it. There are plenty of helpful signboards in English and French within -- we enjoyed exploring the area at our own pace. Do note that there's a small entrance fee.

Good start into Hanoi. We visited the temple with a tour guide. Nevertheless all information can be found on panels in English and French. The buildings and parc are very nice. It is very cheap to visit. The place is very busy, not too crowded.

Interest place. Quite an interesting place if you are interested in the history of Vietnam - we visited as part of a free tour, and I'm not sure we'd have taken as much from the visit without the explanations from the guides.
Nice place. This is the first univercity of Vietnam. It's very old & beautiful. Many Pho restaurants & coffee shop around but a bit expensive, maybe because i'm a foreign tourist, lol.

Caps in the air. The temple itself is quite interesting. Apparently restored following bombing in the American War but nonetheless attractive buildings and artifacts. Surrounded by a walled garden and ornamental ponds.One highlight of the visit was a large number of students from local universities all wearing traditional dress with academic gowns and mortar boards. Visiting to celebrate graduation day and to have their photos taken.
Charming. Charming gardens and temples. Nice way to escape the hustle and bustle of the old town and step back in time. Well worth visiting.
Beautiful place. We got to see several graduation ceremonies, was actually really cool to see this. Aside from that, the pagodas, the monuments, the gardens and the temple are beautiful.

Graduation day!. We visited the temple on graduation day. It was great to see this beautiful place but it's normal peaceful atmosphere was altered by the students who had graduated that day. It was great fun to watch them posing for photos and a lovely setting for them.However, on leaving the temple we fell into the clutches of a rogue taxi driver so be careful when leaving.

Peaceful and a must visit. As it was the first University in Vietnam we though we should make the effort and it was worth it. Whilst quite busy at 09:00 am as most attractions are in Hanoi, people soon disappeared as the place is so large. The formal gardens are very attractive with large avenues and archways leading to the main pavilion where we found a large square Koi pond. The pagoda houses a very smiley Confucius statue clothed in scarlet robes.

Ha Noi City tour. I visited this place on the Sunday afternoon, and it is too crowded. But is a nice experience because that day was the graduation day of Vietnam University students, many people took pictures in this historical place. The buildings are very beauty and well maintained, including its historical values, is a must go place in Ha Noi.

Full of culture. Popular amongst students, academic persons, to come and pray for great studies results. Temple worships some of the most famous and influential scholars in Vietnam history.By coincident we went on the day of one of the graduation ceremony. There were students getting scholarships, taking photos, burning incense preparing for university.
A Must in Hanoi!. We spent an hour to visit this beautiful place. very interesting, very educational place, quite, peaceful. i strongly recommend this place to anyone.

Historic, beautiful and a must see. As you enter this building you are surrounded by genuine history set within beautiful grounds. As you pass through each section you realise the next part is equally if not, more inspiring. As with most of these attractions in Vietnam the cost is minimal. You would be foolish not to go.

Must-visit for History Buffs. I always bring my traveling guests to the temple of literature. If you don't visit any other temples in Hanoi, this one should be it. It's got a good description of the process of becoming a Mandarin and lots of information in English about the history of the temple.

Beautifully preserved with great historical and culture significance. This is a Confucian temple, so not really a temple in the religious sense, the name to me is a bit misleading. It was first built 1000 years ago and it was an important step in the national examination system for which a person can become an high ranking government official. This place therefore has great historical and culture significance.Just a run down on what this place really is and why it's significant:Vietnam was ruled by China for many years, and therefore they follow a similar examination system as China. In order to become an official in the imperial court, which are the highest ranking people in the country, a scholar has to undergo many years of studies and many levels of examination. This place is basically the last stop, in which by the time you finish, you take the final exam that would make you an official. Also like in China, this is pretty much the only way a commoner gets to be transformed into a nobleman, so it's almost like a divine procedure that gets you respect and status. This is the basis of the scholar mentality which is deeply ingrained in many East Asian countries even today. Inside the grounds there are beautiful gardens, places of ceremony, many stone seals, including ones that documents events of significance and the ones that containing the names of the people who has passed the final examination. A walk through of this place almost takes you back in time. If you're interested in culture and history, this is a must see.

very interesting. when we went to see the temple of literature it also happened to be graduation day for schools and university. it was wonderful seeing so many students in national costumes paying their respects for a successful exam. the building was very impressive and the story very interesting. we were luck to see it "in use" which was a wonderful experience. worth having a look!
Temple of Literature. Interesting complex with beautiful grounds, including a lake. Ho Chi Minh's two houses were eye opening. Highly recommend

One of the best Hanoi locations. With quiet gardens (always welcome in a hot, busy city like Hanoi), interesting academic history and, if you are lucky, music demonstrations on traditional instruments I think this should be high on your list of places to visit in Hanoi. If you get a chance to visit on a Sunday morning you are likely to see formally dressed graduates with the girls dressed in Ao Dai. The only negative is the number of tourists that you are likely to share your visit with.

Biggest monument in Hanoi. No visit at Hanoi would be complete without spending a long while at this old complex representative of sino-vienamese cofucionism. Recommended to take an umbrella and plenty of water during summer.
Must see. A fabulous and historic site that conveys so much about the traditions and values of education and culture in the city over many centuries.
Fascinating. On the day we visited we just missed a crowd of students that had graduated. IIt can get very busy here. It is a beautiful temple and gardens and well worth a visit.

Historic sight. We were lucky enough to have a local guide take us around and explain that this was the very first education establishment in early Hanoi, where royals would come to be educated, still today many students come to have their photos taken at this historic sight

Simply beautiful. A darling place, beautifully simple and elegant. Try and give yourself sometime to sit and take in the history. The enduring message is that "Knowledge needs to be based on something stable and firm".
My Favorite Site in Hanoi. This was lovely and it was nice the day we visited a bunch of graduates were there taking photos of their graduation. It's very old about the year 1000, and was beautiful.
sightseeing. Very ancient place where on can learn about the North Vietnamese culture. Place well maintained .Easily approachable inside the city .The curio shops were reasonable

Beautiful architecture and graduate galore!. We visited the Temple on Graduation Day and there was a mass of graduates having their photos taken and looking stunning in their finest dresses and suits. The Temple itself is beautiful and well worth a visit. Outside there are a lot of touts trying to sell this that and the other. They are not overly demanding, but perhaps watch your valuables in the throng outside.
Great historical place. One of the most beautiful and meaningful place when going to Hanoi. Peaceful atmosphere and many things about Vietnamese smartest ones in the past you can discover here.

Beautiful and educational at the same time. This tribute to Confucious is beautiful and serene. We caught it on high school graduation day and saw the classes in caps and gowns getting photos shot in historical surroundings...nice way to spend 1 or 2 hours

A piece of Vietnamese history. My first visit to the temple was in 2003, and since then it has changed from a quiet oasis of calm in Hanoi to a bustling tourist stop. Our visit this time seemed to have coincided with a university graduation as there were scores of students in their gowns and mortar boards taking their class photos here.This place is probably best-visited with a guide who can tell you about the history of the university and the imperial examination system and the lasting effect that has on the Vietnamese psyche .

Graduation day. We happened to be here when students were getting graduation shots done so there was a marvellous atmosphere to the place. Had they not been there the grounds themselves are well kept, the information accessible, and it is easy to see how this place has inspired learning. This is not getting 5 stars not through any fault of it, but just compared to some other attractions in the north of Vietnam

Good place to visit on Monday when everything else was closed.. There are quite a few topiaries around the place, but these were a bit undernourished. Some nice older buildings too.The highlight of our visit, was all of the school kids who were taking graduation photos. There were a bunch of professional photographers directing and taking pictures of them, so I was able to take a few

Tranquility in Hanoi. On our recent three week adventure through Vietnam, our last stop was Hanoi. I was getting tired by this time, but didn't want to miss the Temple and it was lovely. A bit of peaceful tranquility in the hustle and bustle that is Hanoi - yes there are a lot of tourists there, but you can still enjoy the peace of this place. We were lucky enough on our visit that there were a number of graduations going on, which added to the colour and interest in the place. Highly recommended attraction to visit.

Lovely stopping off place.. Lovely old styled complex, with plenty of statues and altars denoting the Chinese philosopher Confucius. Some memorabilia of old students, rows of stones, set onto stone tortoises, with past graduates inscribed on them and lovely gardens with fantastic bonsai displays. Check out the large drum and the massive bell in their houses either side of the main building at the northern end.Entry was 300k Dong. There are food and drink outlets inside as well as clean toilets, plenty of shady spots to rest and enjoy the serene atmosphere.Note that when we visited there were hundreds of university graduates in their class groups having their official photographs. Made everything quite crowded but highlighted the importance of the site in the life of Vietnamese academia.

A bit underwelmed . Nog a Real must see in you ask me. Every single graduate in and around hanoi comes there to celebrate their graduation. Fantastic for thema but not as much for tourists because of the hundreds of students. Some locals told us that this wasnt an extreme busy Day but it happens all the time. Still nice to see and visit but as stated; we were a bit underwelmed

Graduation. Full of graduating students, the Temple of Literature was buzzing. Interesting, if a little commercialised to our eyes, but full of meaning to the Vietnamese. It probably helped that we had our tour guide to explain the significance of much of the area. Certainly worth a visit
A nice, serene place. A nice, serene place to take a walk through the gardens. A great way to unwind and calm down after spending a few hours in the chaos outside the temple walls.

Nothing to write home about. OK it is ancient and the wrtings there are set in stone, but nothing much to write home about after its visit except to say you've been there. It is an area of Hanoi which is renwned for traffic jams, so allow plenty of time and avoid rush hours.
Lovely old temple. On a nice sunny day lovely to walk round . On the day we went there were lots f scholars in their robes taking their graduation photos which made a lovely sight
Beautiful Place to See. Beautiful place to see. The Vietnamese are justified in the great pride they take in this ancient University. Well worth the visit.

Come early before the crowds!. One of my favourite sites in Hanoi. There were temples and wide open spaces to take in. When we visited there were students having their graduation pictorial and art students sketching. It felt like a first hand immersion to student life in Hanoi. It was overall a very pleasant experience!

Beautiful landscape . When we arrived the Temple of Literature was closed temporarily for an official visit. With 45 minutes to kill, we went shopping at the non-profit store, Craftlink. The actual grounds are very beautiful and well manicured with a lot of history as well as photo opportunities. The mosquitos were out enjoying the temple as well, which were enough of a nuisance that I wished they sold bug spray at the souvenir shop. As stated in my nat geo tour book, the souvenir shop should be bypassed as the prices are inflated. My significant other still wanted to buy postcards. Buying the postcards wasn't an issue but buying the stamps to accompany them was. One stall had an abundance of postcards to choose from but stated they did stated they "didnt have stamps". Needless to say, postcards are a moot point without the stamp. We went to the store across the way ask if they had stamps, their answer was yes. So we went back to store with the good selection of post cards and bought our cards. They magically had stamps. However, they didn't have the exact amount for the U.S. Stamp ( which should be around 15000 VSD) but they tried to sell me other stamps (19500 VSD). Since I had mailed of postcards already the day before, I knew I was being ripped/scammed. Although it was about a quarter more, it is the mere event that infuriated me. Bought my postcards without it's stamp and went across the way to try to buy stamps but they wouldn't sell stamps without a postcard purchase. Left the temple stampless.Tangent over! What I'm trying to say is purchase things with caution in general at the Temple and everywhere in Vietnam. If you're in need of stamps, your friendly hotel staff may sell some.
Interesting and beautiful place. Gorgeous place with a beautiful architecture for a very cheap entrance fee. Definitely recommend when you are in Hanoi.

Essential to visit if you visit Hanoi. . This place will give you a great insight into the Viet reverence for learning. We visited on graduation day for the uni students and there were hundreds of them there in their gowns having their photographs taken. Try to go in the morning before the tourist buses arrive.
New learning. You learn a lot about their culture and they have quite a number of souvenir items which are reasonably priced.

INTERESTING HISTORICAL SIGHT. I am not a fan of touristy sights but I was impressed with this visit.The extra bonus was seeing all the proud students who graduated taking photographs in and around the location.
Beautiful gardens and statues in central Hanoi. We spent about one hour here while visiting Hanoi. It's centrally located in a park like setting with beautiful gardens and ornate statues.

I hope it's not Hanoi's top attraction. It's "nice", but following the ratings I hoped for much more. Plan 1h maximum for this visit & bring your guidebook or else if you want to learn something from it.

This is one old learning institution. Talk about history. What a site. I degree at this institution 100 years ago actually meant something unlike most degree factories we called universities today. Students all posing with their gold luck signs. Quite a site. Quite hectic as well.
interesting but not for too long!!. Great to see the architecture of the buildings and to learn a little about the religions of the country.
Wonderful place. Very interesting temple with lots of things to explore. It was touching to see that young students still visit the temple before their graduation.
Lovely grounds. Well worth a look. Lovely grounds and great history. We had university students in beautiful clothing having capping photos taken the day we visited. Lovely.

One of Hanoi's must see sights. This shows just how old and sophisticated Vietnam was before the Europeans. The engraved names of graduates go back 1000 years. The temple is made up of a number of courtyards and is a peaceful respite from Hanoi's constant traffic and bustle. Well worth a visit.

A great local gathering place. We were fortunate to visit the Temple on a Sunday when many college graduates were visiting the Temple to have their graduation pictures with their classmates. It was wonderful to observe hundreds of young Vietnamese women dressed in their Ao Doi's and young men in suits and ties. The grounds are beautiful and the 1000 year old temple, honoring Confucius was very interesting.

Nice temple to visit close to the city. For those who do not mind walking through the busy streets of Hanoi, it is about a 20 minute walk from the Hoan Kiem Lake in the old quarter. It is a temple dedicated to scholars and sages and is featured on the back of the 100,000 VND note. The entrance fee is cheap and it's a nice little temple which is well kept with some nice garden work. I do sometimes find it strange though that these temples contain food such as cheese wafers as an offering on the altar!

A good place to visit.. Certainly an interesting place to visit. I was told by the guide that students come here before their exams to seek blessings and come back after graduation to take group photos. I managed to witness happy college kids taking photos here. We shared their joy. :)

Interestin. Beware of the umbrella sellers. Quite sure they stole my mobile when they crowded round us. The street sellers there were more aggressive than normal. Was very interesting & incredibly old

Relaxed & Picturesque. The lake offers a small oasis from the surrounding hustle and bustle of the city. Pleasant for a light stroll during the day in the evening it transforms into a focal point with street side vendors offering drinks and ice cream, locals strolling and salsa dancing groups bringing music and life to the lakeside. A short distance from the night markets and the main touristic restaurants and accommodation.

A must visit.. I rarely describe a place as "a must visit" in reviews, as that's pretty subjective. If you're in Hanoi, there's no reason to not stop here. The Temple is easy to get to, inexpensive (VND$30k) to visit, and quite beautiful. It's primarily a self-guided tour (unless you bring your guide), so read the wiki page or other materials before going, those will give you some background. Note - when you're getting to the "back" of the grounds, there's side alleys that take you back further. I noticed a lot of tourists seemed to miss these as they're on the left and right sides, going past the bathrooms. These alleys will take you to the bell and drum towers and another, less crowded, temple.

Beautiful - but take a guide. Lovely, historic place - but we went without organising an English speaking guide so didn't get as much out of it as we could have. We ended up eavesdropping on other guides' conversations but that wasn't ideal. Will have to return when we are back in the country to get the full experience.

Not worth the trek. Thought we would have lunch close by before going the the university, but the area around there is not very nice (dog poo). No decent placed to eat. Were in and out of the university within half an hour.

check your change. a warning: be very careful when buying a ticket here. I received the incorrect change and was charged 80,000 instead of 30,000 (handed the woman in the ticket booth a 100,000 note and walked away only to look down and see all I had for change was 20,000). I've heard this has happened to others as well. the temple is lovely, and worth the 30,000, but not if you're getting scammed for almost 3x as much.

Great for an hour or so. This Temple was singled out for special praise and recommended highly to us. We had a lovely snack and drink before going in and went for a quick walk to the lake opposite the entrance gates. Nothing much to see there but nice and calming nonetheless. We then went to visit the temple which was cheap (and tourists pay the same prices as locals - Love Vietnam). We had a pleasant walk around and we were lucky enough to witness a lot of students in their graduation clothes as they celebrated their finishing university. Balloons and selfies galore! Some really nice history around this place but some of it wasn't accessible due to everything being in Vietnamese (I kind of like that it is this way - better than English everywhere - it feels more authentic). Some lovely buildings and Buddha statues and a nice easy stroll around. We were walking very slowly and even sat for a second to take it all in and got around it in an hour or so. Make this a part of your day's sightseeing instead of a major part and you wont be disappointed. Nice and serene away from the honking horns.

A slice of old Vietnam. This place seemed to us to be the only really old place in Hanoi. The modern day students were having their photos taken there in their national dress. A peaceful location in a sea of noisy traffic.

Interesting place to visit. We walk with hanoikids students - Frankie and Pie and it was great. They make it very interesting, told us about the place the history and meaning of the symbols. We had very good visit.

Witnessing the excitement of graduation.. The temple of literature is an interesting visit - there's nothing particularly exciting about it, but it's got a nice little history that makes it worthwhile. It comprises various buildings - the majority of which appear to hold shrines which locals seem to visit fairly regularly. The most fascinating part was witnessing the excitement of all the students who still go to the temple when they're graduating from their studies - it was nice to see the grounds still used in line with their original purpose.

Historical place. Was quite amaze by the temple is actually the first University in Hanoi. We met a bunch of students taking graduation photos over there and guess photos definitely turn out to be great !:)

Vietnam's 1st University. Van Mieu - Temple of Literature established in the 11th Century in the year 1070. Set in a beautifully kept garden setting. Entry cost 30,000 dong or approx USD 1.50 pp. This was the main centre of education for the Vietnamese Mandarins. Originally built to honour Confucius. The ancient architecture is amazing and a photgraphic delight. Whats more it's great it survived the Carpet bombing undertaken in the 2nd Indo-China war.

On a fabulous raining day. Our timing was perfect. The graduates were there in force, hundreds, with beautiful local traditional clothing, ready to celebrate their graduation. The umbrellas added to the ambiance. Charming.
Ok. Again this was part of a walking tour so we had a guide to help as out with some in sights to the place. Not such if I had missed the place I would have been to upset
Very good to visit. Temple of Literature and its importance amoungst then and now students. It was very interesting. Good to see

History before your very eyes. Every time I go to this Temple and move around and observe how life would have been in times gone past I am moved by the feel of history. On the day I visited recently the whole place was overrun by scores of school children obviously learning important aspects of their rich and varied culture.

Great to see the graduations. Perhaps it was the time if year but it seemed that each day hundreds of uni students seem to flock here to celebrate their graduation on the site of the first Vietnamese University. Definitely worth a visit. The KOTO restaurant opposite is great, if a little over priced. The green mango salad and banana leaf salads were really tasty though!
Complex.. We struggled to understand this attraction, whihc was probably our fault. An interestimng layout with a series of Buddhas in the inner courtyard

Lovely but crowded. It was really interesting and wonderful to see so many Vietnamese as tourists in their own city with such high enthusiasm, lots of them wanted photos with my 6ft2 husband which was hilarious

Beautiful oasis away from the hubbub of the city. My husband and I stopped by for about half an hour during our taxi tour of the city. It was well worth it and very inexpensive. I think it was about 30,000 dong ( $1.50 ) for the entrance fee. It wasn't too busy when we went there in the early afternoon.There were many female students who had graduated taking photos in the beautiful gardens of this temple ( it felt more like a garden than temple). They were dressed in their colorful, national costume (Ao Dai ). There were a few gift stores in there with reasonably priced souvenirs. Felt strange to have that within a temple. Otherwise it was a beautiful, oasis away from the city hubbub.

Pleasant venue for brief stroll. This was a nice place to walk around. Plenty of beautiful flowers, ponds, and the temple was nice. Lots of graduates posing for photos made it a bit crowded in places. Not an earth shattering attraction but worth a visit.

Short and pleasant walk . $2 gets you into an area of gardens and traditional buildings where you can walk and take some time away from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. It was pleasant enough, there was a graduation going on as we entered which was nice, but not a must if you only have a day or two in Hanoi. Takes about 20 minutes to walk around.

Peaceful place in hectic Hanoi.. Nice short introduction to Vietnamese build up of temple complexes. Big enough to find some serenity, small enough for a relaxing visit. Historical tribute to good leadership. UNESCO details.

Fabulous Grounds. We visited the first University in Hanoi and walked through the archway to the Temple of Literature just prior to exams being held so the grounds were full of students studying. We were privileged to watch a ceremony involving the blessing of students for their upcoming exams. Strolling through the beautiful gardens to the amazing statues of past scholars onto the Khue Van pavilion built in the early 1800s is a great experience. There is so much to see that celebrates the achievements of Vietnam's finest scholars, it is definitely worth a visit. Our guide from EXO Travel was able to provide many details of the history involved and I would recommend a guided tour of this site.

Good visit!. Enjoyed an hour or so there! It was very interesting and informative. The building is very old and well-preserved, simple but nice architecture and layout. You can read the information in English and French to open your knowledge about the old Vietnamese culture. This is a must see to learn the history of education in Asia and the different concept of higher education!

Great way to spend an hour or two. We enjoyed our walk around the Temple of Literature the gardens are lovely and we were lucky enough to be there when there were probably over 200 young Vietemese students receiving there Graduation Certificates which just added to the experience and we got some great photos.

Nice historical place. If you want to travel back in time, literally, then visit this place. It's quite big, and when you enter you don't realise how deep it goes. I could almost imagine hundreds of years ago how young students would be wandering around, reading, learning etc. really enjoyed the feel of this place.
Nice stroll, inspiring. If you are into Arts and Literature... or just needed a stroll among flowers, ponds, trees and interesting cultural structures. Here is the place to go.

Nice relaxing place to get away from the bustling crowds.. I walked here from the Old Quarter and timed it so that I would be there at lunch time when hopefully all the crowds would have gone.I was extremely lucky as there were groups of young Vietnamese graduates having their photos taken here - I spent close to an hour watching them (and stalking the photographer at times).The Temple itself is very interesting and set in lovely grounds.

Interesting. This is a very interesting attraction. Lots of graduates would go there to have their picture taken with their caps and gown. The gardens are beautifully decorated with lots of flowers. It is worth a visit.

Serene place in a chaotic city. Get away from the chaos in Hanoi in the Gardens of the Temple of Literature. Really serene place with lot of history and deep rooted culture.
Also a lot of youngsters go here to practice their English and guide you around the place. A win-win situation.
Nice place to visit. Nice green temple, many annoying saleswoman in front of it. Clean and well established with some souvenir shop inside
Beautiful grounds. Great place to wander and take pictures. Nice descriptions placed around to help you interpret the history as well. We went around sunset and the lighting was just perfect!
Vietnam's first university. Complex dedicated to university started to follow the teachings of Confucius. Beautiful grounds and temple in the back.
Tranquility and peace. I visited here early on a Monday morning, and there was virtually no-one around. Lovely! Beautiful setting, shady and peaceful. Great architecture. Thoroughly enjoyable.

A must see destination in Hanoi!. I didn't expect the temple area to big so big and serene. I'm glad I visited the temple early in the morning because it was still quiet and not many people inside. Definitely worth visiting!

Lucky coincidence: Graduation day in Hanoi. We noticed lots of young, very dressed-up young people posing for photos, and couldn't quite figure out what was going on. Arriving at the Temple of Literature, the mystery was revealed: hundreds of students celebrated graduation day, which included a mandatory visit to the Temple of Literature, the oldest university in Hanoi (founded in 1068) and the cradle of higher education in Vietnam. What a wonderful sight! It brought the meaning of the Temple to life, and made it a special visit.

Beautiful architecture and lotus flowers. Really loved this temple and grounds. It had numerous gardens, gates, side buildings and places of worship. The garden ponds were full of beautiful lotus flowers and I was able to capture the perfect image of a lotus. Very enjoyable....take your time.
Peaceful oasis in a busy city. Inexpensive entry & we were lucky enough to witness some big groups of local students posing for their graduation photos. Interesting layout & lovely gardens.
Temple of Literature. Lovely temple in the middle of a big city. Well worth a visit. Thoroughly enjoyed our walk around here. Plenty to see. Tourist shops are situated here at the end.

A crazy meeting place. Originally a learning place for Mandarins based on Confucius (who never lived here), then a national university.
Now a crazy crushed meeting place (put your hand on your wallet!!)
Young people rent graduation gowns and fake certificates of their graduation.
Also brides to be gather for photographs - it is a beautiful place
Historically significant and aesthetically pleasing. History buffs will enjoy this place, but those who are not so inclined would still appreciate the beauty of the gardens and architecture.

Top 5 historical attractions in Hanoi. Very beautifull and historical place. Worth of visiting if you like history or just see some beautiful places! Visited this place without guide and I just read details from internet and information panels. Good local guide sure could tell more about this place!

Take a guide. Had a walk around here and read what was there. This would probably have been more interesting had I had a guide explain stuff to me. I would say something to visit to fill in time. Not something you would have "missed out on" if you don't go.

Good option to get an idea of what temples look like. Its not a big one but is located in the city so is a good option if you don't have much time to go to temples outside the city area. The entrance is usd3 aprox is my memory doesn't fail me.
Humbling. . Old university for scholars taking the royal exams. Based on confuscian principals. Great place to visit.

Great small piece of history. Hour long tour. Was close to hotel and more of just something to see to kill time. Was well worth it. We hired a guide since we had no idea what exactly we were walking into / through. She was very thorough with explaining the history and meaning behind the old university.

Beautiful garden and temples!. Highly recommend a visit to this little gem!
The gardens were stunning and the temple was very interesting with many artefacts to see! Including some of the best bonsai trees I have seen in Asia!

Nice experience. We hired a driver to take us a around and this is one of the first spots we stopped by.Its such a serene place.A lot to take in culture wise.If you get a chance you must have the man write some messages/meanings on a scroll for you.Lots to learnThere are little tourist stores inside there as well that have souvenirs at a reasonable price

One calm spot in the city. Another must see but find a time after a heavy day as a tourist to enjoy the calm. The buildigns are some of the best you will see in Vietnam and the whole complex is very impressive. The stelai are interesting and a pity there is no translation. Can be very busy but you need to return again and again to see all the different seasons here. Take your time and enjoy.
Fantastic history . I enjoyed this tour more than I thought I would. I would recommend doing this tour privately as you get the chance for much more information. Great bit of history.

interesting. The Temple was typical of most - I enjoyed the experience We were there when there were many school children there - they were so eager to speak English with us - altogether a plus for our visit
Temple of Literature. History, architecture and beauty. Great stop in Hanoi. Need about 1 hour to walk through the gardens.

Right timing enhanced this visit. The day I visited this site there was a celebration of Literary figures, with awards, speeches and dignitaries. A site of Confucianism in support of learning and education. The grounds had historic significance and were absolutely beautiful in it architecture and horticulture.

lovely temple. lovely temple to visit in Hanoi
Vietnam has many templos and after some weeks in asia maybe its too much he he he
this is good place to visit, but nothing like the templos in LAOS

Wisdom seekers. Lots of walking paths, some areas were flooded. The temple itself where the main statues were of the teachers were adorned with the splendours fitting for worship. We expressed our desire for wisdom and knowledge and hoped we were blessed. Didn't wash our hands in the pond for creativity as it looked a bit polluted.

Serene. A wonderful respite from traffic and noise. So serene and peaceful, one can imagine reflective study here among the gifted young of early Vietnam. The stone tablets recording graduates and the bonsai were attractive elements as well. Watch out for aggressive vendors as you enter and exit.
One of the best things in Hanoi. Really nice, worth visiting. Next to the other sightseeing places (Ho Chi Mihn Mausoleum, one pilar pagoda,...) nice restaurants nearby.

Phot tour. A very quiet place to relax and contemplate.
Very Chinese in its construction with an interesting history

fast visit. Don't expect to spend a whole morning to visit this place, it's a small place to see, story to learn something about vietnamese culture, but it's just a tiny spot, not big deal to see.In the meanwhile ,you could visit the fine art museum and end up at the KOTO restaurant in the same spot ,then your morning will be done with a finish touch of culture.

Beautiful park. The temple is surrounded by a beautiful green park. Although its old but it it seems the government preserves the site well. All inside the temple were in good condition and has very clear description of each objects.

Interesting. We visited during Tet, so it was very busy with many Vietnamese families visiting at the same time. My children did not appreciate it, and it was raining, but aside from the crowds, it was a rather peaceful place.
beautiful temple. It's quite a walk from the old quarter but definitely worth it. Nice and quiet and green. One downside is that there's not a lot o information provided

Temple with turtles. Set aside a good couple of hours to visit this beautiful place (and go early). We were shown around by a university student who was able to provide lots of insights into the history of this temple. The gardens are serene and inviting and an escape from the heat. Even our 6 year old enjoyed it!
Unique. A unique site, we enjoyed it more than expected probably because we had read about it quite a lot beforehand.

Great bit of history here. I was reading some of the negative reviews about this place. I can see how it might be boring to those who come without a guide, but we had a really fantastic local guide who spoke really good English and told us all about the amazing history of this place. He explained to us what each area of the garden represents and its significance.

See Confucius!. Except for the Lotus pond the rest of the garden around the temple was very pretty and well maintained. The temple itself was awe inspiring with the idol of Confucius and lots of artistically grown and decorated bonsai plants .The icecream here was refreshing after a hot day's walking around!

Heavy Chinese Influence. From buildings to structure of imperial exams and carvings on tablet, almost everything is so Chinese influenced. Sizes of stuff are a little smaller though. Vietnamese rulers at that time must be superb in politics to not be at war and managed to keep their land. Amazing.
Must visit. Very nice place.. old school temple and feel to it.. must do if you are in hanoiTake alot of pictures!!
Not a must. . Entrance Fee is 30k dong but it is not really worth a visit. You cannot see much in that temple and the greenery is not in best shape. Do not expect to much.

SIMPLY AUTHENTIC AND ENCHANTING. This was the first item on our Agenda and I was mesmerised by the sheer age of the university and its role in the development of education as far back as a thousand years ago. It is situated in a area with large landscaped gardens. The building have stood the test of time and may have undergone structural maintenance work but they still maintain their early days facade in appearance.
Just another temple. A Temple by any other name is still a temple. Nice grounds, nice temple. A tribute to students being recognised for their educational advancements.

One of the most historically significants structures in Hanoi. One of the historically significant places in Hanoi, this is where people would go and train to become mandarins under the old imperial system. It is a beautiful place, full of nice buildings and beautiful gardens.

Beautiful. A great stop, about 2 hours if you take your time. The explanations are all in english so a tour guide is not necessary. Great history and facts to be learnt! The gardens are beautiful and very well maintained.We thoroughly enjoyed it, its got a constant flow of people, but not too many to feel rushed.
Nice gardens, good visit.. It has very nice and tranquil gardens, not the most impressive place you will see in Hanoi. Worth going.

just another temple if you dont look for more information or have a guide!. Not much english or french transation. The building (achitecture) is great, but there is little explanation given in the temple and if you buy a pamphlet for 8000 dong at the entry...I guess a guide or beoing with a local would bring much more interest since the history is quite impressive!

Beautiful and quiet. worth the visit. There were many students when I visited (graduation day) which was really nice. The girls in traditional dresses ao dai are so elegant! The numerous staeles and the "old" temple are impressive. You can chill in the yard with an ice tea. Very nice time. The entry is 30 000 dongs. Go!

Peaceful break from busy Hanoi. A friend and I wandered in here after a busy day in hectic Hanoi. The juxtaposition between the serene, calm and beautiful temple and outside Hanoi traffic is quite something! The gardens are well curated and the temple is in good shape. There is plenty of information signs along the way to keep you up to speed. There is nothing too spectacular to make it a must see, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. It probably won't take you more than half an hour to really soak up the entire experience. Could be a good place to bring a book and sit down for a bit. Quite popular with tourists so you have to wait a bit for the perfect photo.
Ancient Temple. One of the highlights of Hanoi. The temple is peaceful and you will be bale to see ancient scriptures.
Nice quiet time. Beautiful grounds. Very peaceful in the middle of the busy city. entrance fee is 30,000 DNG. 1 hour to spend is plenty of time.Gift shops and restrooms available
Peaceful. Very peaceful place to wander round & listen to traditional Vietnamese lady musicians performing in the gift shop.

Where old meets young!. What a fantastic history has this place, but even today so a life, I visited on Sunday the 4th of October 2015 and together with me hundreds of student who all just achieved their diplomas, some very clearly in engineering, while others must have done law or a business studies. Bur their were also students who attended a ceremony to get better results or their diploma, funny thing, girls in my office still believe only hard work will get you a diploma or degree. The artifact which have been in this place are perfectly restored. Not sure if this was also damaged during the Hanoi bombing. Definetly one of the places you should see when in Hanoi.

A reminder of the history of Vietnam. Visited the Temple of Literature as part of the Tonkin Travel Private Tour and it is a fantastic reminder of the incredible history of Vietnam. Having a guide helps to understand the importance of this Temple

Must visit!. Gorgeous! A tranquil place with a fascinating history. Get a real sense of the tertiary traditions of Vietnam and its incredibly evolved culture of learning. A joy to explore with lots of photo opportunities.

A beautiful quiet retreat from the hustle of Hanoi.. Beautiful gardens, an amazing sense of history. Elegant, quiet and beautiful. The gardens are lovely and it is a cool oasis to escape within from the noisy, heat and bustle of Hanoi. We had a relaxing hour wandering through the temples and gardens.

Oldest university in Vietnam. This was actually the oldest University in Vietnam. It was very interesting and informative I enjoyed an hour or so there. There is great serenity about the buildings quite magical. Also there was a great place to eat very close on the street opposite just can't remember but it was very busy.
Amazing history. Amazing to learn some of the history of Vietnam and to learn they have had tertiary education for nearly 1000 years. The grounds are also very beautiful

Good and relaxing couple of hours.. Went here on my 2nd day, and it's a really nice way of settling in. Lovely landscaped gardens and a very impressive temple and other landmarks in the grounds. The building is very old and well-preserved. There's also a nice public grounds across the way from the front entrance.
Enjoyed the view and the temple.. Temple is beautiful and very large. Connection with literature is lost but still a nice place to visit for a good price.

Interesting history. Dedicated to Confucius, it is the site of Vietnam's first University. There are gardens,topiary animals, and stelae of many of the scholars who have graduated at the top rank here over the ages.
Can tour all the grounds in less than one hour.. Nice little piece of Asian/Confusian history tucked into a nice part of town. Easy to find, long walk from Old Quarter but manageable.

The first university of Vietnam-old and respectation!. i often take my foreign friends to Temple of Literature because i love this place. Its memories and my respectation for Old King and thousand years old university.Temple of Literature still keep its history. You can read the information in English and French to open your knowledge about the old Vietnamese culture, how was the writing and why people put the toteris under the stone notification which has the listed of excellent students on it.But i only think its 4/5 stars because people come here still not put the rubbish into the bin!

unique grounds. Places like this has historical value that unfortunately is not explained in writing if one does it on your own. The place will have more value if someone is with you to guide and explain its significance. That is what we did when hanoikids brought us here. For example, a caucasian couple who was doing it on their own, brought out a 100,000 dong bill AFTER they eavesdropped on our guide's explanation that this particular view is on the back of that money. There is no signage for that. Another is the roof across the upper floor that housed the statues of prominent people who built the temple. People used to throw money on the roof hoping it sticks to the roof.The place is not really that big and can be toured in less than an hour.

Historic center of Learning. Built in 1070and dedicated to Confucius, this huge campus was Vietnam's first national university. Various pavilions, halls, and statues provide the space for study and strict exams of the Dai Viet.

Well worth a visit. Incredible history here, worth going with your own guide to get the full benefit of all the history behind this Even in the gardens with the plant animal sculptures depicting the Chinese calendar to the bonsai tres everywhere. Even our teenagers did not get bored. Plenty of cold drinks to buy as it is very hot. Highly recommended as it is spectacularly maintained.

just beautiful. dont miss this if visiting hanoi, ancient university, so much history, fascinating. plan to spend a couple of hours walking around and looking at all the display. simple but nice architecture and layout, what a great place to be a student. tour guide recommended to get all the details.

A thousand years and still graduating. This ancient university/temple shows the value the Vietnamese have always put on education. We were fortunate enough to run across several dozen students in traditional dress posing for photos at the temple. Apparently it's traditional to do this when you graduate in Hanoi, no matter which university you attended. Their ceremony made the place even more photogenic. There are impressive statues of mandarins with cool beards and robes in the main temple itself, reci img offering of fruit, cigarettes and cardboard packets of biscuits. All very interesting.

Confucius Temple. This ancient temple (previously a university) was the first stop in our tour. Well maintained lawns, buildings and temple, with a good museum-like exhibit at the end. The tour guide (from Urban Adventures) did a great job explaining the significance of various symbols and structures. Very interesting experience.Spent about 1.5-2 hours. I recommend using a tour guide.

The oldest university and shrine. It is said this is the oldest university. But what you will see is a park and a temple, with a lot of stone tablets that has scholars' name (but you can't read it as it is in kanji-like writings. If you haven't seen any temple or pagoda - you will find this place is amusing.
Worth the stop!. Very beautiful setting for an ancient university dedicated to education. Beautiful grounds. This can be fairly quick stop (an hour) or take a more leisurely stroll and stay a while.

Starts of the nation. In all the Asia this university was the first. Educational environment was touched in that visit. While our visit, there was some graduated students celebrating there as traditional constitution. Really the Place deserve to visit.

Ancient Chinese Style Temple dedicated to Confucius.. This is temple is not really a temple per se, for it is dedicated to Confucius. The temple is layout in a long rectangular design. From the entrance, pay a small fee and you can go in. If you are not in a hurry, you slowly walk through all the courtyards and admire the ancient architecture, delicate design on doors and walkway. If you can read Chinese, there are plenty of artifacts from the ancient times such as scholarly texts and examination papers for the candidates.The place felt like one had been transported back to ancient China, worth a visit.
Nice temple!. It's quite a walk from the old quarter but definitely worth it. Nice and quiet and green. One downside is that there's not a lot o information provided..
Such a different unviversity campus. a must see to learn the history of education in Asia and the different concept of higher education than the western one.

Interesting place to visit. Unlike many of Vietnams excellent attractions this one doesn't take too long. There is a 2 story building at the back with some items on exhibit with info mostly in Vietnamese. It it rather commercial with shops everywhere inside and many sellers outside but still an interesting place.
Temple of Literature. Not a lot to see there,pleasant gardens to walk around.Souvenirs can be purchased there,only need about 30mins there

Must Visit. A temple where you learn the culture of Vietnam and how the Chinese contributed to their culture and values. Confucius overload I must say, when you visit this site as this dedicated to Confucius and his teachings. The temple is very huge and good for some relaxation of the mind (as this is names as temple of Literature).

Unexpected Surprise. An amazing place of learning. Worth the small entrance fee but best to have a guide who can explain things. Graduating students were having their photos taken while we were there and they were more than happy to allow us to share in the photo experience. Very peaceful and relaxing place despite the number of people visiting.

Beautiful, albeit crowded. My fiancee and I checked this out along with most of the other attractions in Hanoi. Got guided around by three 10 year old local kids working to improve their English. Worth the trip for the $1 US for entry!

Fortunately we had a guide. We visited here as part of our 1 day guided tour so got a lot of explanations from that.Without the guide I suspect a lot of the background and history of the place would have been a mystery to us.I suppose it may work if you used Wiki or something.Viet Nam has a huge scholarly history and this place has huge significance in that. It is well preserved and cared for now even if not actually used any more. The gardens are lovely - a peaceful oasis in a busy city.

One of the most interesting sites to visit. A very interesting site with various courtyards and ponds and at the end was the main building dedicated to Confucius.
Do make sure you have a guide as they will tell you lots of interesting information.
The diamond monk arrived while we were there which was special.
Prone to a bit of flooding but well worth a visit

Culture and atmosphere in abundance . What a beautiful place. The history is amazing. The atmosphere is overwhelming almost. The gardens are beautiful. The history of Vietnam's first university is in front of your eyes.

Beautiful Grounds and Interesting History.. There are a lot of temples on offer in Vietnam. Some of them less impressive than others. I particularly enjoyed this one. I was absolutley chucking it down with rain when we arrived but we managed to barter for some super cool macs ;) and things improved! It is a beautiful place and the turtle steles with the list of achievements/graduates is worth a look.
spectacular. A very interesting temple to visit ,but go with a guide as there are so many stories relating to this temple and the reason for it`s being that you will miss out on if you don`t.
Beautiful garden. Have been here 3 times and love walking around the beautiful garden. Very amazing reading about the history. Just great

Great job in preserving the historical place. Took a bus and keep asking Van Mieu along the road to reach this place. Having seen the Temple of Literature in Tainan, Taiwan, I could say that this temple of Literature has also done a great share of job in preserving the chinese learning culture in the country.
A place to see the heritage of Vietnam. A great place to walk around and get a feel for the culture of Vietnam. Lots of great buildings. Definitely a must see in Hanoi.

Not too much interesting. I came here once when I visit Hanoi for the first time. There are not too much entertaining activities here. The most impressive moment in here is in spring and summer, many students come here to take photos for their yearbooks. Most of them are girls and they wear the "ao dai" - traditional costume of Vietnamese women. So beatiful.

Nice temple. The first university and also shown on the currency the temple is a great place to visit. We were there around the time of high schools finishing. It is a custom to take your graduation picture here and there were lots of high school grads doing just that.
