Rain boots are needed if you go in the summer. This is great place to see some really gorgeous ancient architecture. The temple itself is beautifully laid out and you can purchase some keepsakes from inside its walls. Look out for the miniatures nestled in the bonsai s. Get some rain boots if you are going in the summer. There is little to no drainage and massive puddles form.

Refection. We had a guide take us around here, and explain more about the place than we would otherwise have known. A great to see and visit, in a lovely setting, with great gardens. The buildings are beautiful, and the pace well looked after

Great with a guide. It would be great if you had a guide telling you about the stories of the temple. My guide didn't really do a good job. She was quiet all the time unless i raised a question. So I had to eaves drop on other people's guides to learn about the temple. Lots of people and always packed with tourist!

Beautiful . When you travel in Vietnam u have to remember that museums are not all the way accessible - you can take a tour guide if you want more info because not every thing is understandable (when you talk about the history) the brochure we got in the entrance was ok, had little info on it but that was ok for us, we still stayed with questions unanswered:)The place is very nice! You can go around for 1h, but remember u need good weather! It is mostly outside30,000 entrance fee
Ancient stones. Perhaps did not really get to enjoy this place to the fullest as hardly could understand my guide. Temple was typical and the turtle stones were interesting.

Nice place to start your visit. You can start your visit here. Three old school buildings with nice flowers in the courtyard. This will bring your to the atmosphere of old days and learning traditions.

beautiful place. Oldest university is a very beautiful place in Hanoi. There is a huge garden and beautiful dragon sculptures everywhere.Few temples also can be found there. I liked the sculptures of huge turtles. Pity that there no additional signs in english,only vietnamese mostly,
Decent place to visit. Interesting place to learn about the Confucian scholars. The place is not too huge too, which makes for a leisurely stroll
Interesting Temple . Visit it during little raining, but I found its look cool and nice.. most important that lot of student, no matter kindergarden or graduate are welcome for day visit..

Need a guide to understand it better!. The buildings, and tablets are well kept, however there aren't a lot of signs so I would recommend going with a guide to better understand the history of the place, and its relevance.
Confucious say..... Brilliant, colourful, aweinspiring (for a learned person, interested in History). Well worth the visit.

Oldest University!. It was an history about the first university in Hanoi, Vietnam and now the people come from everywhere to visit and pray for his life but normally they are the students and pupils come from many the other province to visit.

Hanoi sightseeing. Worthwhile visiting to see historical buildings and artefacts that were from 1000 years ago. Garden is lovely and well kept. Watch out for street vendors outside the front gate who are pushing their way to get you to buy their wares.

Temple of Lit - Confusing but Rewarding. One of the delights of the Temple of Literature is its popularity with Vietnamese who use it to picnic, learn, celebrate graduations and other special occasions and altogether add to its charm and mystery. A series of courtyards with ponds and gardens and pavilions holding all sorts of treasures, it is well worth repeat visits.

So worth a visit. A great location, full of history and culture, also known as the first university. Our tous guide had us hooked with the stories about studies, history, wars and religion and eastern philosophy.
1000 yr Reverie....... Nice place well maintained buildings, Many people around, but feel free & quiet. Ignore any one n reverie 1000yr ago....
Great place but,... Hire a guide to truly understand this place! Luckily with HanoiKids, I am able to understand this place much better, if not I would be so lost.

Nice garden. The gardens are nice and the history interesting. I would say take a visit when you need a break from the busy and loud Hanoi. It's very restful in there so take your time!!! You can even exercise in their if you wish, but it does cost 30,000 dong to enter!!!

Temple of Literature & National University, quite a place to visit!. It is a nice place, with a pretty authentic and original cultural place, you can get a good photo here even if you're not into that historical thing. This place quite crowded because it is one of the famous Hanoi tourist attraction.
1000 years of wisdom !. This place is an 1000 year old place of learning, dont have high expectation. Place is not really grand but worth a visit

Peaceful place. Just nice to walk amongst these very old bulidings and imagine how it was a thousand plus years ago and the quiet contemplation and learning that has occured here. Signs in English so no real reason to buy the book.

Peaceful garden. We did not have a guide here so didn't get as much out of this beautiful place and its history as we could have. However some delightful school children were practising their english and this made the place very special. My children always remember the places with more enthusiasm where we talked to people.The ponds were full of flowering lotus. Not very busy making it pleasant. Reasonably priced souvenir shop with drinks and ice cream that we appreciatedVisited in July and it was very hot.

I have learned a lesson. I guess I have gotten what I had paid for.Booked day tour of Hanoi yesterday in Hue. 25USD. The 12 dollar day trip in Hue was fantastic so I had no hesitation booking this one. This place seems to have significant meanings and history but our guide(very broken English) didnt deliver any of what other 5 star reviewers described.I was sad to witness this historic site was worn by tourist. Poor effort to preserve the integrity of building.I am not a happy camper today.

Do it with someone who is knowledgeable. Like many things in Hanoi, the advantage of visiting such places is gained by having locals as a guide. Again, this was another place in which my Hanoi volunteer and I visited. Without her knowledge it would have been a very quick visit. The day I was there people were graduating, which was nice to see.

fascinating place. beautiful place to visit and learned lots about the history of Vietnam's very first university. at the time I visited the place there were a few students in graduation gowns getting their photos taken which was pretty symbolic I reckon. overall it was worth the visit.

Well worth a couple of hours. This was an included local tour on our itinery with Hoi An Express. Our guide, being a Buddist himself, had a wealth of knowledge and made the experience delightful and informative. His stories about the early university style education and the history of the temple and surrounds made one grateful that we had not just simply walked around by ourselves. Everything there is significant, from the bonsai trees to the stone tablets of the scholastic achievers.

Beautiful Garden. The gardens and the buildings are very well maintained. It's a nice place for photo ops too. However, to fully appreciate the place, it would be best visited with a guide who is knowledgeable about the place and it's history otherwise it is nothing more than a beautiful garden with nice buildings.

Great history & lovely spot. Really pretty and peaceful gardens in the middle of the city. We had a guide who told us all about the temple and history - so much information. Be warned - a little difficult in a very hot day as inside gets very hot and stuffy.

Temple of Literature ...... a librarian's delight. A beautiful Temple right in the centre of town - a must have is a guide!! to tell the stories of the architecture, the history of the University and the statues of turtles. A real culture rush for a visiting Librarian and her friends.

Just another temple . This is a temple for students, parents think it bring wisdom to their children. There is no other point of interest nearby. We spent one hour there, why？ it happen it is Sunday and for unknown reason there are many young girls dressed in traditional attending some sort of festival ceremony.
Part of our Southeast Asia tour. We went here on our tour. It was nice to have a tour guide to tell you about the Temple. It was an interesting place to visit. Beautiful gardens.

Very Interesting. This is ancient park/museum is very interesting for anyone who likes history. The huge stone tablets are doctors writings on deseases and injury. Constructed in about 1040, It is in a walled compound. Many statues and carvings.
Average attraction. It's a bit far from the old quarter and it has nothing special to offer. Do it only if you have spare time to kill

Fantastic site, beautiful buildings, great history. We visited as part of our day tour of Hanois greatest sites. Wonderful topiary in the gardens. Great atmosphere as lines of new graduates came through for their photographs to be taken. Definitely a must see in Hanoi

the water puppet show was the cream of our stay in Hanoi, night markets well worth visiting,. The water puppet show was the cream of our stay in Hanoi. Night markets well worth visiting. But unfortunately some of our tour members were refused to be served in a shopping centre near the theatre where the puppet show held.
Vietnam Holiday Juky 2015. Very Interesting, especially the history of confuscious! Beautiful gardens and hedge sculptures with signs of the Chinese Horoscope.
Local knowledge required. Strongly recommend use of a local to guide you around this site - otherwise you may not fully appreciate the buildings and surrounds.

A little area of serenity amongst the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Lovely gardens, buildings and temples that offer a moment of reflection after the chaos Hanoi's street. Don't miss the courtyard full of bonsai trees.

Chilled, but just ok. Nice chilled place if you are in the area, but I wouldn't cross town specifically for it. We didn't get a tour which was probably a mistake as we didn't really know the history or what exactly we were looking at.

got short changed again. Did the museums and temples today every one didnt give me the right change but this one the temple of Literature was the worst, here in hanoi. I wiated for my change and she very quickly gave me a load of small notes and when i checked i was out 100,000 dong i still stood there waiting ,but got ignored.You would have thought the staff would be checked and stopped this practice.

A must see. A very nice and relaxing visit. This must have being one of the first university in the world. We took a tour guide and the explanations were very good. The temple is in good order , very clean and still a place of workship.
Important place Temple of Literature. How the ancient education was developed there ? You will get an idea about the teaching method. A place for education and culture

Beautifully preserved temple and gorgeous gardens. The temple of literature it's definitely a must see in Hanoi. I only had a couple of days in Hanoi and this was my favorite sight. The temple is well preserved, it was probably one of the best preserved buildings I saw throughout Viet Nam and it's an example of Vietnamese architecture. The gardens are beautiful too, full of colors.

Interesting. While in Hanoi we did a guided day tour which included the Temple of Literature & National University
It was interesting to walk through the grounds and listen to our Guide explain how people studied.
The site is well maintained.

Interesting, but nothing more than that. The temple of literature is a little outside of the city centre of Hanoi. The temple itself isn't that spectacular, in my humble opinion. Still, it is interesting to see how the Vietnamese pay respect and honour Confucianism and education on the whole. We strolled around for half an hour. One off-topic benefit: a calm little place if you want to get rid of Hanoi's busy appearance
Great. A must visit in Hanoi.First university in Vietnam. The last pavillion is the most interesting.Lots of students there asking for blessings...

Well maintained and very cultural. Our last major stop in Hanoi and it was a wonderful walk. We didn't get a tour guide so took our time to view the sights and take photos. Some very nice architectural elements to look at. Not a must see but worth the visit.
Nice gardens. Nice gardens, calm area. Temples average, but I might be biased, been to tooooo many temples in Asia so they all kind of look the same now so it was nothing special. but nice gardens!
Informative. We had a guided tour of this. Our guide was very informative. Would recommend taking the time to go and visit.
Interesting Sight. Spent a good hour or two walking around the place. Interesting to see just how much respect the Vietnamese culture gave to education, and the impact of Confucius' teachings

Fascinating insight into the history & culture of Vietnam. This was a great way to understand some of the historic intellectual influences into what makes Vietnam such an incredible place. I recommend reading "Confucius" by Maher McArthur before or after your visit, it will help organize your thoughts in context.

Taking is the culture . This was a visit that was part a walking tour and wouldn't be suitable for any longer than a few hours.
The temple gave you insight into the culture and development of the society.
It was interesting that we saw a few wedding parties.
Must visit.

A place tourist should visit. I visited Temple of Literature last month with two American friends and all of us had a really good time there. There were information boards in both Vietnamese and English which helped me to understand a lot about the history of the place and Vietnam as well. Souvenir shop provided a variety of necklaces and bracelets that included special Chinese words. My advice is that you should pick a cloudy day to go since the place doesn't have A/C. Overall, I think it worths a visit from visitors.

Quiet and calm.. There wasn't anything particularly interesting about it as there wasn't much to see, nice for walk around to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city Hanoi, since the gardens are quite nice.

Great temple with great history. I did this temple with Hanoi kids. I would recommend doing it by yourself with a good text book and spend spend a couple of hours in the temple. It's an open complex, so going early in the morning to avoid the heat and the masses is a must.

It's nice. Nothing much to see here. When I went there a lot of freshy graduated student came to take a photo. most of the description around here are in Vietnamese, so you have to have a guide. However, it's good to go, to see an ancient shady beautiful place.
Interesting architecture.. Lovely peaceful place to visit, pretty temple and gardens so don't forget the camera. We visited late afternoon so it was fairly quiet.
Quiet and peaceful. Interesting place to explore - pleasant gardens. Not much to actually see as it is more a temple (with some shops) and a nice quiet garden.

An oasis of peace. Actually it was not an oasis when i got there as it was a graduation day of some sort, full of students wearing graduation gowns and their friends and families. Its a wonderful place, like a large gardens, to sit, to walk around, however it is not very big, so allow an hour or so, unless deciding to stay to meditate.
Lovely way to spend a couple of hours. Serene spot in the middle of bustling Hanoi. Highly recommended. Very interesting to see where literature started.

Something to do . Temples and pagodas are kinda a big deal in Asia and it's almost like a "must see and so" type thing but to be honest once you've seen one, you've kinda experienced it, they're all pretty similar...lots of Buddhas and beautiful architecture.My friend was keen to see the temple of literature because it was listed in her trusty guide as something worth a visit. I'd say it was nice to see but I could probably have left it and not felt like I had missed out.

Please, don't miss if your are in Hanoi. I was there some time ago (10 years),and my memory of this place is gorgeous , strong and inspiring !!!
When you are in Hanoi, must do ! ( and it is a very good introduction of vietname food, before (street spot) or after, Hanoi is full of delicious restaurant, offering very high level of authentic Vientnamese food festival.
Dull buildings but nice gardens. Interesting but somewhat dull unless you are fascinated by Vietnames history. Best bits for us were the gardens with lotus Flower lakes and Bonsai trees.
Worth a look at. Very beautiful grounds and a lot of history that my husband had never heard about. A pleasant experience and well worth a visit

Listen to a guide in the temple then stay alone there!. The Temple of Literature consists of beautiful traditional buildings in wonderful gardens with many interesting details, like sculptures, monuments, tombstones, little lakes. It's worth to walk around with a guide who knows the history of the temple and the meaning of all the stones, then to stay there alone. Young schoolgilrs and boys, wearing national dress, often visit the temple gardens mostly after exams. Try avoid the crowd!
very interesting. we liked all, especially undergraduates taking their graduation photos before their actual graduation

Oasis in busy Hanoi. this beautiful oasis in the midst of busy Hanoi is not to be missed. It provides a good understanding of confusionism in Vietnam, the buildings are impressive and to the extend restored this is well done.

A temple of wisdom and serenity amidst vibrant, noisy Hanoi. Whenever I visit Hanoi, I never fail to visit the Temple of Literature to enjoy its very peculiar atmosphere and always ponder what the tortoises may think carrying the steles through the centuries.
Fine but not a must see. Garden with a temple. Not a must see but if you have spare time it's a good option. You will only need 15 minutes to see it

Very Interesting History. A good place to visit if you have a day free and are in Ha noi. The history of the place is quite interesting and despite being in the middle of Ha noi the inside quarters are quite peaceful.

One of the top cultural visits in Hanoi.. Well worth travelling to this location. Escaping the frenetic pace of life in Hanoi this is a tranquil place with lots of good photo opportunities and somewhere to learn a little about the history and culture of Vietnam.
Cultural Highlight. Really interesting cultural site. I would highly recommend having a tour guide to have a more informational and pleasurable experience.

Underwhelming. There wasn't much to see -- the place is well maintained but there really wasn't much to se (the "stelea" and a shrine), and as a "temple of literature" there was hardly anything to read. The focal point of the attraction seemed to be the souvenir shops just outside the inner shrine.TIP: The pamphlet (8,000 VND) for sale at the gate is not worth buying, there's barely anything written in it.

Humble old building. The building that housed the 1st national university of Vietnam. There were tourist souvenir shops in the compound, lots of green grass and an unmaintained pond. Spent about 45 min in here.
Fascinating ancient culture. Loved strolling through the beautiful gardens and learning about the 1000 year old place of learning. A must see attraction in this wonderful city

Grand learning. You can almost feel the energy of this place - set in peaceful and well maintained gardens, the temple gives an aura of academic endeavour that I have not experienced elsewhere. Current day students still visit to pray for success in their exams.

Seeing the historic architecture. great place to see the structure of the old architectural building and see the historic monuments. Just walking around and see the recording on the stone and the temple, you feel as you were a part of the past.

First place you have to visit in your Hanoi City tour. It is a harmony mixture of nature and culture in Hanoi inside the centre as you can have a chance to learn more about Education in Vietnam during the stream of Vietnam history.
Tranquil escape from bustle of the city. Lovely place to wander round, very peaceful. Beautiful gardens and lake and interesting history, love that it celebrates academic achievement.

Worth Seeing. Found it slightly confusing finding the entrance, I clearly walked through the wrong gate as I didn't end up paying and only when I left I saw the paying area. The gardens are very serene, with beautiful lily pads in the water. The temple was a very interesting place, there's not too much to see so you can really slow down and take it all in.
Hanoi in old times. It gives you a look in the past..worth seeing the history and see what Hanoi was like so many centuries ago...quiet place and surprisingly cool inside.

Beautiful and peaceful. The architecture is really beautiful, with cheap entrance fee. Many trees and it's good to stroll around and take pictures. There's also Confucius Temple inside where you can visit.
Beautiful sanctuary in the middle of the city . What a spot! Wonderful place to stop and catch your breath in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Well worth a visit.
Pleasant spot to chill out. The site of Hanoi's first university which had an affinity with the teaching of Confucius. Peaceful gardens surround this spot which is a nice place to relax

A great family afternoon with culture. History, culture, gardens, frogs (!), beautiful live traditional music (if you happen to come by at the right time) for the while family. Wandering about quite some time - make it early I. The morning before it gets too hot!

Step Back in History. The history of this place was truly astounding to me and the story of the location was very special. To think that so long ago people were having their names carved to signify their education and expertise. The architecture is amazing to look at and its a mostly quiet place to sit and reflect if you need that. This is one stop I had wished I had picked up a guide. You should definitely bring a comprehensive guide with you if you are going to self tour as almost everything is posted only in Vietnamese. What is posted in English felt like only part of the story.

Must visit. Located in the middle of the city, this temple was constructed in 1070 AD and is dedicated to Confucius. There are five coutyads, one lake and one well of clarity. You will also see different messages written on raised platform and decorated fully with flowers.
Temple of Literature. Lovely gardens and great architecture, this is really worth a visit. Very busy. This is lovely to just wander around.

This is a temple!. You will have probably done the Bach Ma Temple before doing this one. And that is the right order I think. Start of with the small temple not much bigger than a house and after doing a few of these you'll think like. Is it all going to be like this? That is the right time to visit the Temple of Literature! A garden filled with plants and small ponds before approaching the temple square and building. I loved it! It made my day!Combine this with the KOTO restaurant and you'll have an evening well spent!

A beautiful peaceful location that takes you away from the city's hustle and bustle.. This is a must visit site in Hanoi. It's peaceful gardens and beautiful landscape will allow your mind to take a breath.
Return visit. Have been here before but brought new friends with me this time - serene and an awesome place when considering the learning and knowledge which went on here.
Carved trees. yes very interesting place here is a children school and they are eager to meet visitors alike, and budhist temple is must also on ground lots of carved trees

Serenity, Beauty, and Reflection. As a teacher, the one attraction I absolutely had to visit while in Hanoi is Temple of Literature & National University. The majestic and beautiful architecture is simply stunning and for the mere simple fact that this beautiful temple was built in 1010 is awe inspiring and should make anyone and everyone want to go and see it for themselves. When I walked through the archway, I felt an overwhelming sense of pride and joy because this temple was built to honor literature and education. I actually couldn't help but chuckle a little to myself while standing in front of one of the stone slates with names on it thinking, "This was the gold star every student strives for in the 11th century!" I also thoroughly enjoyed standing in front of the pond with lotus flowers and gazing in to the water; it was a magical moment for self reflection and to feel connected to a culture that I knew nothing about prior to visiting the country. Teachers and education and revered and treated nobly with the utmost level of respect in Vietnam and it touches me to my very core. Whenever someone would ask me what I do and I would tell them I was a teacher, they would shake my hand or bow to me. Walking further back, there is a temple devoted to Confucius and it was extremely insightful to see how respect is payed to one of the great philosophical thinkers. Temple of Literature is a special and beautiful place in the heart of the hustle and bustle of Hanoi's Old Quarter and the juxtaposition of old in the middle of the new is very special.
Relaxing promenade inside cultural world. The good preservation of this place soak yourself in the Asian ancient world and attract the cultural interest while swirling around.
Great place!. This was interesting place for all the tourist known about the history of Vietnam and it has a good location closed the Hanoi Old Quarter.

Ok, but nothing special. Interesting to walk around, but nothing incredibly special if you've visited any other Asian temples. Pretty crowded and touristy as well. Very close to the national art gallery which is worth a visit. I only spent about 25 minutes or so walking around.

Historically Significant. This university was originally built for the son of the king to study. There is also a Temple of Confusious honoring the man most admired by the king and who's teachings the king followed.
A definate highlight. Vietnam's First University dating from the 11th century. We hired Free Student Guides to take us around the Temple. It is very well maintained a must visit.
A moment of peace. A beautiful place, magic contrast in the hectic and the modernity of the vietnamese life. We enjoyed a commented visit and it was perfect.

Historical Educational site. It is is a Temple of Confucius, Vietnam's first national university built in 1070. It has ancient architectural styles of many dynasties as well as precious relics. There are statues of Confucius and his four best disciples: Yan Hui, Zengzi, Zisi, and Mencius. It has four Courtyards. 116 Stelae of Doctors are carved in blue stone turtles with elaborate motifs to honour talent and encourage study. Good maintenance and historical background.

Top cultutal monument in Hanoi. Top monument in all of Hanoi. Many places of worship nestled inside gardens, walls, another garden. Old photos of 19th century monks. Oldest university. I happened to come across a ceremony of older women in traditional costume. It was around Tut (New Year) and families came with children ' praying' for good grades, very full - but more Vietnamese than tourists. Exquisite architecture - great angles for photos.
one of the oldest university. Nice place to see and know about one of the oldest university..choosing the right tour guide will help you..

Well restored temple . We visited this temple at the end of our trip and we were quite surprised! All over the country this kind of monuments are in restoration, but in this case it's done. It's a beautiful place to be, to realize how people from Vietnam take care of the culture in the eleventh century. Don't miss it!

Excellent Temple within walking distance of the Old Quater. An excellent temple that is easily accessible from the old quarter. Entry is very cheap as per most of the museums in Vietnam at something like 30,000 dong each from memory. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi.

Great architecture, great history.. We went as part of a planned tour and it was a fascinating site to visit. Once you get through the throng of sellers outside you enter a wonderfully peaceful area with walled sections where the students would study, the better students getting closer to the middle. Our guide was great and explained every little detail from its creation to its role in modern life, how the stones were protected during the war by burying them in sand and the unfortunate consequence.It's a must visit in Hanoi and takes about 30 mins to 1hr to do it justice.

Eye Opener. The Vietnamese scholarly world began well before ours and appears to have an almost religious order. The buildings were beautiful and the temperature was hot, but it was worth an hour of one's time. Beware the customary peddlers and the usual souvenir stores inside.This should be visited in order to appreciate that Vietnam was not only about war with the French or the Americans. There is much more to the country which we need to learn and understand.

A must see in Hanoi. It looks like another Chinese temple. But this courtyard is well preserved. It took us sometime to locate it as we were on foot. Since it's so hot, not many visitors at hot August,we had some peaceful time there and took close clear look at this beautiful temple.
Very interesting Temple not far from the Lenin statue.. Excellent temple well worth a visit and then you can take a walk slowly to Ho chi minh mausoleum which is also great.

First university. We visited on a weekday and it wasn't as crowded. The were five in-line courtyards in the temple ground. A nice stroll from the first to the last through this historic school gives an insight about the historic academic atmosphere. Most of the walkway was shaded by trees. There was a souvenir and refreshment shop in the third courtyard. Adjacent to the temple courtyards was a big green park.

Half day city tour - Hanoi. My daughter & I did a half day Hanoi city tour with Buffalo.The guide, called Loc, was very informative & verbose, at times.Loc gave a good synopsis of Vietnamese history without making the content dry.One of the places we visited was the Temple of Literature.The place was lovely, well kept & the vendors were keen but not harassing.Our visit wouldn't be the same without Loc's imput.
good to know. 1st school in vietnam, really nice to learn about the history and the language. Not boring, because it's small and you do this in 30min.

Graduation Day. When we visited it was Graduation Day so we got the added bonus of students all being in traditional dress and posing for photos everywhere. Very interesting place and interesting architecture. Well worth a visit.

Oasis. It's on all the tours, so it can be crowded with buses-full of visitors. Lots of variety here, from scenic ponds to spacious courtyards to a pagoda and the iconic stelae on tortoises. You can buy souvenirs when you're not taking photos, but you can see it all in an hour or so if you're pressed for time. It's convenient to other attractions, too, with the fine arts museum across the street, and the military history museum fairly close. Walkers can get to or from the Old Quarter in 20-30 minutes.
Interesting. An interesting place in the middle of the city. The buildings are pretty cool and the colours are great. The shop was rather cheap as well.

Interesting history. After getting past the gauntlet of hawkers in front of the ticket booth, the grounds were pleasant and well kept. History of the site was interesting with the many monoliths inscribed with students from the past.

Okay . This depends on how much time you have to spend. There isn't much information in English but a guided tour would be probably be too much/long for kids. If you've seen a lot of temples already you might want to give it a miss, otherwise it's quite pleasant to walk through.

an oasis in the middle of noisy city. right in the city centre, the Lake is not only just a destination, an air con of the city, a place of historical story, a romantic place for dating, but also an amazing place for taking picture and meeting new people. it has an old Ngoc Son temple by getting through the The Huc tiny red bridge, in the middle of the lake, there's an turtle island which telling people about the legend turtle that living there for hundreds years. green trees are all around the lake,. definitely can pass by to have a coffee or lying down the grass to read a book.

Get away from the hustle and bustle. We enjoyed a stroll around this temple for and hour or so, taking in the beautifully well tended gardens and impressive buildings. It's a lovely way to get a break from the hectic traffic and noise.

Good museum. The buildings are amazing and very well conservated and the exposition is very nice. The most impressive thing was seeing the monks praying inside the temple (i'm not sure if praying is the correct word in budism...) I recommend it!!
Intersting place to visit.... Easy location and interesting place. It is very good tonsee the first University at vietnam. If you visit hanoi, you should see this place.

Don't Miss This Adventure. I really enjoyed this temple. I had a private tour guide that was able to explain the different parts of the temple and how things were set up. Give yourself two hours to see this site.
An interesting part of Vietnamiese culture. In the middle of the city the Temple of Literature offers insight into the culture of the country. Well worth a visit.

Peace and quiet. If you visit in mid-summer the temperatures are very high but the tourist numbers are very low, so you can either beat the heat and join the throngs or suffer in peace and quiet. To be honest I have been in Hanoi in winter and summer and prefer the cooler weather. The temple is close to the fine arts museum and Koto training Restaurant so you can make a day of it. You will find the temple at 28-29 Hàng Cân, Hoàn (The entrance fee for the complex is 10,000 VND (about 50 US cents). Opening hours: 8:30 to 11:30 and 13:30 to 16:30 every day except Monday and national holidays. Rated No 2 landmark in Vietnam in 2015 for good reason. The temple was constructed in 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong’s dynasty, first to honor Confucius and nowadays it celebrates the doctorates and high rank scholars of Viet Nam. In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong continued the work and built Quoc Tu Giam as the first university of Viet Nam. Get a vé, ticket to see the temple which is divided into five courtyards, each with its own significance and history. Look for the hung drums called trống. 1) The first courtyard stretches from the main gate to Dai Trung gate.  2) The second stands out with Khue Van Cac pavilion. You should notice the pavilion symbol on all street signs of Hà Nội.  3) The third courtyard is where doctor’s names are listed on tombstones above tortoise backs. There are a total of 82 tombstones, with names and origins of 1307 doctors, corresponding to 82 examination courses from 1442 to 1779. If you visit the temple at the beginning of the year or in May when many important examinations take place, you will catch sights of numerous students who come to rub the tortoise head. Such an act is believed to bring luck passing tests, so rub the rub the tortoise head hard.  4) The fourth courtyard is dedicated for Confucius and his 72 honoured students, as well as Chu Van An - a famous teacher known for his devotion to teaching. This is also where local authorities choose to cherish brilliant students in Hà Nội, like those with top entrance results to university or top graduation outcomes.  (5) The last and also furthest courtyard is Thai Hoc house, which used to be Quoc Tu Giam- the first university of Viet Nam. Thai Hoc house holds a small collection of old time costumes for students and mandarins, as well as explaining the process of taking and passing the national examinations. This ancient site offers a lake of literature, the Well of Heavenly Clarity, turtle steles, pavilions, courtyards and passageways that were once used by royalty and is revered as a place that has seen thousands of doctors’ graduate in what has now become a memorial to education and literature.
Average afternoon. If we hadn't had a tour guide, this would have not been very interesting. Good to see architecture and the temples, but otherwise not something to go out of your way for.

Beautiful Bonsai and Architecture. We took a cab to get there. Got yourself ready for the strong sunlight . I got a beautiful bamboo hat. A group of university graduates were taking their graduation photos and the ladies in Vietnamese national outfit looked gorgeous!

Interesting to visit. Visited as part of a tour.The Temple was quite interesting and there seemed lots of Vietnamese students there,maybe part of their courses .Worth a short visit but only of maybe half an hour.
Bring a book!. A nice, expansive temple with lovely gardens. Be sure to take a favorite book, find a quiet corner, and find your inner Confucius!

Serene and clean. We spent about 1 and 1/2 hrs here one afternoon, and despite there not being a great deal to see (that is substantially different from other temples) I did enjoy it. The grounds are large and well kept. And even though there were lots of visitors it didn't feel noisy or crowded: there was a sense of serenity and peace away from all the hustle and bustle of Hanoi traffic. The architecture is great; the turtles and the stelae inscriptions are interesting. And for kids, there are ducks and rabbits in the far back area (not sure if they are 'private' or not!) Clean loo available also. And we accidently interrupted a musical performance which was delightful.

Relaxing & beautiful garden and temple! Must see!!. You learn more history and get to relax and see a garden, temple and if you dont know - interesting tombstones!!It is a Temple of Confucius. The first 2 courtyards are peaceful havens of ancient trees and well trimmed lawns where the scholars would relax away from the city outside the thick stone walls. Entrance to the 3rd courtyard is through the dominating Khue Van Cac (constellation of literature), a large pavilion built in 1802. Central to this courtyard is the Thien Quang Tinh (Well of Heavenly Clarity) , either side of which stand 2 great halls which house the true treasures of the temple. There are a total of 82 tombstones, with names and origins of 1307 doctors, corresponding to 82 examinations courses from 1442 to 1779.Cost: 10,000 VNDHours: 8.30am to 11.30am; and 1.30pm to 4.30pm every day, except Monday and national holidays.Also, just FYI: The temple is featured on the back of the 100,000 Vietnamese đồng banknote! =)Enjoy the temple! Is soo nice, worth visiting!

Fascinating place. Fascinating place when visiting with local who has knowledge of all architectural features, gates and statues. We were fortunate to be taken there by our Hanoi Kids pair and they really knew about the features and put it all in an amazing historical perspective. Made the visit so much more interesting
beautiful architecture. This fabulous place is over 1000 years old. A must see for anyone visiting Hanoi. We really enjoyed the visit, as did our 7 year old son.

Beautiful in the rain and sun!. This was really interesting to look round and the gardens are beautiful. It doesn't take all that long, but there are lots of other things around that you can incorporate into a whole day trip.
Must see in Hanoi. Well maintained historical site. Check out those really old text books and artifacts. Worth a visit.

Great to look at - not very interactive. Came here based on recommendations from trip advisor and hostel staff. Maybe we rushed it a bit as it was raining and we were travelling that evening, but it wasn't very interactive as an attraction. Great to look at, view the old medical enscriptions on stone, and take in the architecture and the gardens. Worth a visit but don't expect to spend too much time there, and go with a guide if you want more information about what you're looking at.

Amazing history. Whilst bustling with tourists, this little gem is well worth a visit. It is within walking distance of the old quarter. We walked to the prison, then this site, then to the Ho Chi Minh museum complex and back to the old quarter past the flag tower. This 'temple' is a quiet serene place to enjoy the history and the gardens.

Beautiful, Peaceful Destination. One of my favorite discoveries in Hanoi. So quiet and peaceful. Its like stepping back into time and place. The story of the place and the ancient focus on knowledge and learning really makes you think. It was also a great photo stop.
Interesting Place to visit. I enjoyed going to the Temple of literature and learning about it. Very nice scenery and it was not so crowded when I went so I got to really enjoy it.
Interesting. Anther beautiful garden and temple very busy but worth it..the turtles statues you just want to rub there noses but of course you cant.

Wonderful and peaceful. Wonderful temple with a fascinating history of early education in Vietnam. Make sure you walk all the way to the back (it's a fair walk) and see the stunning final temple.Try and avoid the dodgy taxi touters at the gate - we picked up a cab that had an outrageously iffy meter and regretted it.

A beautiful space away from the outside turmoil. The grounds of the temple and ancient university are stunning. Apparently the best example of Vietnamese architecture in Hanoi according to the travel information. After the Old Quarter and Hoan Kiem Lake I thought the grounds were the next best attraction of the city. A 10 minute walk or 2 minutes in a taxi from Ba Dinh Square I would recommend this beautiful to reflect and recharge the batteries.
Worth a visit.. We encountered students having graduation photos taken BEFORE they graduate. Interesting addition to a tranquil and fascinating attraction.
Worth a visit. Very beautiful and interesting. The history of the University is interesting and this complex is well maintained. Would recommend a visit
Very hostorical place. I like most of this Temple is the location is convenient for visit. Very ambient place. The tour guide is very friendly and helpful.
Beautiful. Beautifully preserved with lots stories and explanations throughout. The gardens are very nice with beautiful and huge trees!.

Interesting temple in Hanoi. I really enjoyed roaming around this temple. It was so serene and comparably better maintained than other temples I've been to. There are interesting souvenirs sold within the area, I bought a good luck charm for students.
Hidden gem. A must whilst visiting Hanoi. Hidden away temple with an interesting history. Thought provoking area with lots to see.
University life. Interesting to learn about Confucius and the importance of learning in Vietnam. Impressive artefacts and learned a lot about education so long ago especially the importance of exams.

Feels like being tricked . I think one of the ancient stone tablets reads "a fool and his money shall soon be parted". Because from my view this place has a below average garden, the standard temple accoutrements, with the addition of some bonsai-like trees. Offerings of packaged crackers and Chinese yuan seem better than the beer cans at other locations. But it's the two rather large, tacky souvenir shops within that really show how low-class a classical (and should be revered) cultural location has become.

Worth your time. Beautiful temple, a must see in Hanoi. Good to spend some time here and relax in the busy centre of Hanoi. Also there are a lot of locals who still go here. You however don't need to take the tours they offer. You can go in for 2 or 3 dollars!
a great place to see. A really beautiful and quiet place among the Noisy activity of Hanoi! A great place to see to appreciate this historic temple.

Important Historical Site. The Temple of Literature was on top of my list of places to visit. The Temple was built around 900s-1000s. I think its amazing that they managed to maintain such an ancient place. I've learned that students still visit the temple before taking exams. While I was there, I learned about the Confucian principles from my local guide. I was at awe that they could trace their "doctors" or "successful exam takers" back as early as 1000+!!

Historian favourite. Like Confucius teaching a great influence to the Vietnamese people! The reason for their gentle and polite society! Dislike the unfairness to the female population in the olden days whereby the girls are not allowed much education!

Pool of tranquility in Hanoi. Well worth a visit if an hour to spend in Hanoi. Cover charge of $1.50. This was our first temple and a great experience. Very tranquil in the middle of a very busy Hanoi and interesting introduction to the culture of Vietnam.

Just a temple filled with souvenir shops. I've been all over Asia and seen temples much better than this. There were no fewer than four gift shops in the temple. The gardens were okay, but the reflection pond was full of trash. Nothing really special about this temple.

Very good place to visit. The Literature temple is one of historical temples. When we walked into the beauty of this, it is very worthy to visit. We got many nice pictures here for our good memory trip in Vietnam.

A beautiful spot to wander and wonder. The oldest university in the world. Had I come alone, I'd have spent hours reading on a bench. A beautiful spot to learn more and think about this country's rich history.

Historical Site. It is first university in Vietnam as I read some information around when i was here. So many foreigners come here to visit. I am surprise about culture with touching into head of turtle. If you touch its you will pass the exam. J

Great place to visit. This is a surprisingly lovely facility and experience. Well worth the effort to visit. Not mentioned in any of the literature are the fantastic bonsai that can been seen throughout the facility

Nice Place. Very Nice Place and beautiful place for looking China in Hanoi, Vietnam.
When we want to go to Temple of Literature people in the Hanoi very helpfull

When traditional Vientmaese culture meets the beauty of archeology. It is very worthy to go if you enjoy the beauty of temples and pagoda. All the archeological and historical temples represent their prosperity in its dynasty and it is very similar to Chinese temples in the structures and outlook. Thus, if you like Chinese culture, as a country influenced a lot by Chinese culture, you are definitely recommended to give it a go !As well, if you are fond of history, they are just like alive textbook of Vietnam history !

Relaxing. Take walk here to get away from the hussle & bussle of the city for a while, can do some shopping on the way if walking or if via taxi plenty around to shop, the temple gives you a good insight to the history of Vietnam. I always enjoy finding some history when in a city or town rather than just walking around not knowing about the surroundings, this temple will give you a lot to take in
Oldest university ever seen. this is one of oldest university I have seen so far where you can touh head of turtle to get the luck before taking an exam, probably, it become true

INTERESTING, BUT ANOTHER TEMPLE IF YOU HAVE SEEN LOTS OF TEMPLES!. Unfortunately our visit coincided with a downpour, however our guide was very informative (City Discovery tours). The temple was colourful, interesting and the history is amazing. I would recommend visiting if you haven't already seen the Buddhist temples.

Beautiful, must see in Hanoi. Beautiful place. Lovely to stroll around the gardens and the buildings are very interesting with insights into ancient Hanoi. One of our favourite places in Hanoi, spent a couple of hours there and enjoyed a drink from the stalls in the courtyard. Cost very little to get in and we would say a must see place in Hanoi.

An INTERESTING OBSERVATION!!. The temple of literature, is and old and interesting building, which houses symbols from a time gone by. It would have been great, if their was a translation of the inscriptions around the grounds, so you had an idea of what you were looking at. Still, we found it quite interesting and enjoyable.

Very impressive and serene. Do you know that the site on the 100.000 dong bill? The first university of Vietnam is amazing but as others have said make sure you have a guide with you because there is a lot of history behind the buildings and structures. A must visit in Hanoi if you are only passing by for a day.

Really peaceful place. Really tranquil and fascinating place. Having a guide was helpful. This Confucian temple was the first university founded in the 11th century. Have lunch at the nearby Koto restaurant run for the benefit of street kids to give them a new start. Food great.

hmmmm.... interesting to see a monument to education. we saw 2 wedding parties and many groups of young students, and the people watching for me was more interesting, although this is a beautiful park-like setting in the middle of Hanoi.

Very interesting - make sure to get a tour guide!. The Temple of Literature is a very interesting slice of imperial Vietnam, but is a bit difficult to appreciate without a tour guide. Thankfully, English tour guides are available at the ticket counter (skip the fake tour guides outside the facility) for a nominal fee - ours spoke fantastic English and knew her stuff.This is a good spot to hit after the HCM Mausoleum given proximity. The Temple is also walking distance to the Hoa Lo Prison--a good weekday itinerary is HCM Mausoleum early morning, Temple, lunch, Hoa Lo, Women's Museum. You'll need 60-90 minutes for the Temple.
Worth it!. My son and I visited. It wasn't what I expected. Actually it was a very beautiful park like atmosphere. I am glad we went and it gave many nice photos.

Monument to Education and Knowledge. This complex celebrates Vietnam's Confucius-based education system which dates back to the 1000's and is a tranquil place to wander around or pay homage in the midst of the mad motorbike traffic of the central city.

Interesting view on promotion of Education and Scholarship by Early kings.. Interesting place, on early Education in Viet Nam, how advanced education was encouraged by the Kings of their time. Conficus was a VietNamese, and how he and early scholars were revered by the Kings and population. People of today touch their statues in hope and prayer that Brilliance of these scholars will be given to them too by Gods.
Tranquil. Go early in the day and you will find this to be an oasis of peace in a mad city. It was our favourite place in Hanoi.
Serene destination. Beautiful building and architecture! You feel like you are stepping back into an old movie! Carved stone dragons on top of the roof!

Excellent. An excellent place to visit. All the facades are extremely beautiful and a lovely place to take pictures. There are a couple of lotus ponds with huge fronds which would look gorgeous in bloom.
donot miss it. it was a big mistake if you missed to visit this temple here can experience more about ancient education system in Vietnam
Serenity. A serene, peaceful retreat. Beautiful gardens and ponds. The architecture is lovely. If you are looking for some place to relax or meditate, this is where you should go.
Walking in the history. You will get to know about Confucius, calm environment and cool place to spend lazy time. you can walk around to observe regular city hustle and bustle

Interesting for short visit. Walked around for less than 1 hour. The bonsi trees are cool to see and of course the temples are interesting. However there is little to no information in English so difficult to fully appreciate the history. Would suggest coming here as part of a tour. Free tours available with 'Hanoikids'. Didn't get a chance to book one myself but hear they come well recommended.
Peaceful visit. This is a must do when in Hanoi, such a rich and long history of education, beautiful gardens and ponds, take your time and experience this wonderful site, great architecture as well.
Why not?. Magic atmosphere walking across the gardens. Interesting exhibition and a glance at Vietnamese students

Second time and still interested . Good place to touch the culture.Interesting fact - if a doctor from this university did something not right, his name was deleted from the stella! Can you imagine how high moral was there?! ...Better to come by yourself without excursions to have enough time to take fotos, see all details. Souvenirs are very expensive on the right side, but on the left you can find some chip stuff.Taxi from Hoan Kiem is about 7 $, entrance 1,5$.

Literature very much related to China. Hv the opportunity to experience & learnt that Vietnam, in those days, is indeed at certain area very much influence by China. eg. the building structure, they respect Confucius, even the main panel displayed in the center of the temple is written by Emperor KangXi.Unfortunately, the young tour guide is unable to answer some of the questions posted cos he can't read nor understand what was written on the panel displayed within the temple.
Ancient and interesting!. This one was the first place to visit when you come to Hanoi. It is very old but great to know some stories and myths about this place.
Real History in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is well worth 2 hours of your time. It is a magnificent ancient structure that is sure to amaze even the most hardened of travelers.

Peaceful historic site. In contrast to the crowded and noisy street from outside, the inside of temple is quiet and peaceful. The temple is surrounded by brick walls.The site was devided into 5 areas that connect to each other by the main way in the middle. I really love the lake, the Stone Steles, the architecture there.

A Place Rich in History and Cutural Heritage!. This is my second time visiting the Temple of Litterature and I am still awed at the deep impression this place gives me. The beauty of the architecture, the significance of the institution, really helps understand the Vietnamese Culture who reveres Education and Knowledge above any other qualities!

Incredible history in beautiful garden complex. Stunning architecture - with some English and French explanations. It was one of the most unique complexes we saw in all of Vietnam. Worth a visit in Hanoi (expect to spend an hour or less).

Historical site without propaganda. The temples statuary and grounds are historically significant and can best be appreciated by having a guide to point out all of the interesting facts. We used a web site that provided college students to act a a guide. They do it at no cost as they are looking to practice their english language skills. One such group is 'Hanoi Kids'.

very interesting historic site. We enjoyed walking through this ancient site that is still in use today. The buildings and grounds are very peaceful even though it is a very busy place in the middle of Hanoi.

Temple of Confucius in Hanoi, Vietnam.. Remarkably well kept FIRST university of Vietnam! Has beautiful gardens with five courtyards. A very historical and educational place to visit.On the day we were visiting, a number of new graduates from universities were there to have their pictures taken in these gardens! Seems to be a tradition amongst new graduates. A guided visit to this ancient monument is a must.

Beautiful, quiet place. Within the chaos of Hanoi, you'll find here a quiet place with beautiful buildings, pagodas, trees and flowers. The entrance fee was 30,000 dong, and it was more than worth it.
Worth Seeing. Good overall condition, in a busy part of the city. They had all the signs of the Chinese Year cut in to hedges.
Beautiful. Definitely worth visiting whilst in Hanoi. Amazing building. Definitely gives a flavour of old Vietnam. We took our teenagers & even they enjoyed it!!

important heritage of hanoi. Nearby HoChiMinh mausoleum you can walk from here, the first university in viet nam, this is place contain many history and impressive place.Yearly when each examination coming there are a lot of students come here to pray for pass the exam.If you want to discover everything about histories, cultures, architectures and exhibits you really need a local guide they will explain what you are seeing.It is a worth place to visit in Hanoi

Beautiful and quiet. This is very good place for getaway and relaxing in busy Hanoi. Its very quiet with amazing architecture and atmosphere. Just walk around, enjoy surroundings and relax. It was one of our favourite places what we have visited in Hanoi

Well laid gardens and amazing history. The bonsai is a bonus! Hundred year old sculpted bonsai trees lining the vast courtyards and beautiful gardens. The history too is interesting, the stelae of the distinguished doctors and thinkers, the statue of Confucius, and the pond with turtles.

Small but interesting. This is a fun place to visit with beautiful gardens, a small pond, and lots of ancient statues. It's smaller than many other temple complexes I've been to around the world but still fun. They manicure the gardens to make it even more spectacular. I suggest visiting this place and then when it gets too hot go to the fine arts museum just down the street to cool off in their air conditioned galleries.

Picturesque...don't miss this!. This was on my list of places to visit and I'm glad I made time for it! It's an interesting place with lots of history, beautiful temple and architecture, and well maintained landscape. As you walk through the It is easy to allow the imagination drift back in time. This is a must see!

Beautiful architecture & interesting history. Loved visiting this place. So interesting to read about, no need for a tour guide in my opinion. Reminded me of something you would see in China, such a strong Chinese influence. Well-kept grounds and a real oasis of calm. Koto restaurant opposite it is worth a look, beautiful spot, many prime ministers have visited and profits go to a good cause. Disadvantaged youths are trained in hospitality there too.

Interesting peace of history. A beautiful temple and an interesting place in which the first way of studying like a university happened in Vietnam. Mr. Vic our tour guide from Wati-Travel took us there and had all the information about the history of the place.

Very interesting. Visited Temple of Literature 09/07/2015My boyfriend Steve & I decided to visit The Temple of Literature on our last in Hanoi & Vietnam, after paying homage to Uncle Ho. We were pleasantly surprised to find a very friendly young volunteer offering to be our guide, explaining there was a group of them offering to accompany anyone interested in wanting to know more about the Temple of Literature. We were more than happy to accept. Our guide Vinh Trần spoke excellent English and was extremely knowledgeable. She was patient and was always happy to answer many of my trivial and possibly annoying questions without any show of frustration or impatience. She made our last day in Vietnam memorable. We both thoroughly enjoyed the visit and would recommend anyone interested in history and culture. Thank you for your time and knowledge Vinh Trần and for sending us the photo as promised. Steve & Roz

Don't miss it!. Don't miss this experience when you are in Hanoi. You'll spend more time here than you expect when planning but it's completely worth it. This is where you begin to grasp the Confucian underpinnings of Vietnamese society. As an American Professor I was surprised throughout Vietnam at how we were treated with so much respect once people found out we were educators.

One of Landmarks in Hanoi. The heat was the only thing not liked and best time to visit was early and to be done before lunch. Overall, it was nothing spectacular, it was nice enough and much quieter than out on the streets. The gardens were good to walk through. The story behind the temple was great to hear.

Interesting. Not for everyone. I think you would enjoy this place if you could take your time or if you had some knowledge of or interest in Confucian doctrine or temple architecture. The grounds were peaceful and the architecture extraordinary. I wouldn't recommend it if you only had a couple of days in Hanoi.

Nice to visit for some tranquility. Overall it was nothing spectacular, it was nice enough and much quieter than out on the streets. The gardens were good to walk through. The story behind the temple was great to hear but I don't feel like I would have missed anything by not going.

Awesome ancient historical site. The place is a very large area. Some parts had been destroyed by the French and had been reconstructed. As it is now the summer school holidays, many children visited to pay homage to the great teacher, Confucius , hoping one day they too will be another great teacher. We were impressed by the 82 stone stelae that recorded the names, places of birth and achievements of exceptional scholars. , located to the left and right of the square pond. Equally unique is the structure of a crane atop a tortoise in the scarlet colored pavilion while going into the temple dedicated to Confucius. There is another temple after this Confucius temple. That last temple is dedicated to a great Vietnamese teacher, the Le and the Ly kings. Impressive statues and interseting history.
Confucian confusion. Great Confucian temple in Hanoi with extensive gardens and lotus ponds. Don't miss the bonsai, giant drum and bell.

Excellent, historical & interesting and beautiful!. Very beautiful gardens, architecture and historical information.Loved the classical music played by locals on local instruments. The heat was the only thing not liked and best time to visit was early and to be done before lunch .

Extensive resplandant complex. We were there on a day there was a couple of hundred primary school kids. Lots of happy noise. As they left we were swamped. Happy feeling.The grounds and temples are worth wandering through.We had a private guide. Not sure if there was a fee to get in, as the Indochina Pioneer guide looked after all that.

Nice historic attraction. Take a scooter for 1 dollar to the temple where you pay 30000 dong entrance. There are usually lots if tourists, try to avoid to go weekends if you can. A tour guide is recommended but I looked at the temple on my own. But I didn't really understand all the background (just one sign with English information there). It was nice to get some peace from the cityhassle there!

A little disappointing.. I couldn't say this was value for money, we were a little disappointed. You are basically paying to see a garden and a shrine. We expected to see some sort of University or some history of literature but there was none to be found here. If on a time limit I would give this one a miss!
Interesting. Very good look into Vietnam's history and culture....architectural and interesting, a must see when visiting Hanoi

Interesting Oasis in the middle of the city. Visited as part of tour, located in the Heart of Hanoi. Beautifully maintained gardens, hedges sculptured into the shapes of different animals. Lots to take in, would recommend a guide to appreciate the history of this place, very interesting. Very busy with lots of school trips taking place, the Vietnamese children took the opportunity to practice their English by saying "Good Morning" to us in English, whilst we greeted them in Vietnamese. Pockets of peace and tranquillity were hard to find but quieter in the garden area. The temple is beautiful, very colourful is located beyond the square where the souvenir shops can be found. There is a small fee charged if you wish to the use the toilets. Worth a visit if your in the area.
Very interesting. Well worth visiting while in hanoi, the history behing this attraction is very interesting the bulidings are attractive and a great picture of Vietnam's history.

A university of life whatever your religion. Tranquil, beautiful and timeless. The message of respect and caring translates into any language and any religious. Well to the Vietnamese people for retaining this place of learning for so many generations.

Interesting visit.....Lots to learn if you like history.. We visited the Temple of Liturature and National University with a Tour guide from Hanoi Free Guides. Having someone local to explain the history of the temple and the oldest university certainly helped make the visit well worth our time.The gardens are well maintained. Each of the 5 parts of the complex have a story to tell. It is interesting to learn that some parts of this site were destroyed during one of the wars and had to be reconstructed. If you enjoy learning about Vietnamese history, this will appeal to you.

Well worth a visit. Beautiful gardens and the temple. Supposed to be a place of learning in the ancient era. Very tranquil and serine. Need a bit of time to read and understand things. A guide would be best. Open space and hence could be hot. There are small shops to buy water etc inside.

Nice site. This is a very nice site, but it has been packed with tours and large groups during our visits. It is not an especially tranquil place, but worth a visit. The crowds do take away a bit from the enjoyment of the space, but you can find some solace in some of the margins of the site.

Nice place to visit . It was truly unfortunate to visit the place on a rainy day but overall I enjoyed it. It gives an insight on their culture and revered kings. Good souvenirs can also be found inside. Entrance is 30k vnd per pax.

I presume it is ok. There is nothing much to say about this place; it just didnt do it for me. It may be great for historians but not my kettle of fish. One of the "done it, got the t-shirt" and lets go to the next place. Having said that, there is nothing wrong or bad about it. What was great is some of the bonsai they had there but it is not unique to this specific place - we have seen many of these in different places in Hanoi.

Historical Education. In the middle of Hanoi, the temple of literature offers a sense of peace in the middle of the city. Besides the beautiful setting, the temple also offers a look into the education system of scholars long ago. Great if you're interested in the history of Vietnam.

Home of Confucius. Beautiful gardens and lots to see and learn - Confucius very impressive but make sure you have a guide and wear a hat ( take water) . There's so much to take in and it was very hot and not much shade.

Little space of calm. Nice garden area to stroll around before you reach the temple, a very interesting place, I especially liked the stone tortoises perhaps not hey were turtles that the names of the star pupils went on.
Visited with Hanoi Kids guides.. This was more interesting than I expected from its name. Very historic buildings. A guide is required to understand the meaning of the layout of buildings.
Recommended sightseeing. Easy to find and very interesting, a surprisingly large site with several temples/pavilions to see and pleasant courtyards in between.

Temple worth seeing. We recently visited the Temple of Literature with the Hanoi free walking tour group and highly recommend it. It was beautiful, the history and the architecture just beautiful. We were also able to listen to some traditional music while we were here.

Beautiful building. Its a beautiful building inside and out. Its really cheep to get in. I went at about 1pm and it wasn't very busy. If I went again I'd arrange a tour or a guide. There are only a few signs telling you a little bit about the building and I would have liked to know more.

A historical site. The place is fascinating, provides a good insight into the historical education system for scholars in Vietnam in the old days. Some beautiful architecture and landscape, worth a visit in my view.

Beautiful Old Hanoi. Serene pocket of bustling Hanoi. Beautifully presented historic site in the midst of bustling Old Quarter. Well worth a visit to obtain a sense of the ancient education system, This is where the Mandarins were educated to govern the country for the Emperors. Fantastic glimpse into Vietnam' past

just take a photo here. The place is quite big, and you can see many things about their university.
Just nice to take a photo here....

One of the must-visit sites in hanoi. Beautiful building, serene environment and make time to sit for a while in the garden and soak up the atmosphere. We visited with a guide and so learnt a lot about the history of this beautiful place as well as interesting facts about Vietnam throughout history.

Just another temple after seeing so many. A good place to visit if you are in the area and not seen too many temples. This was Hanoi's first University dating back to the year 1070, now dedicated to Confucian worship. Visit in the morning, beat the crowds and heat.

Of interest. This place looked interesting and offered a serene stop in hectic Hanoi .
Enjoyed the peaceful surroundings.
Disliked the unfriendly staff.

Confucian wisdom for early Vietnamese kings & leaders.. A must-see & know about Hanoi. To the casual visito replying on guidebooks, this might seem to be only another temple w bigger grounds... But this 1000-yr old university, not originally a temple, deserves all of the the restoration effort that was done to replicate the original structures & grounds -- part of the complex was bombed in the last war. We learned so much about early Vietnamese education & culture mostly thanks to our very intelligent guide from HanoiKids, Minh Trang, who increased our appreciation & awe tremendously on the use of architecture, symbols & colors, the great personalities who built the structures & adhered to the discipline & standards of the school; & Confucius himself, whose philosophy was the spirit behind early Vietnemese virtues & talent.

Check it out for it's Cultural Value. It cost about 50K Dong at most to get here from the Old quarter near Hoan Kiem Lake. Nice scenery to take photos. If you are not into temples - you can spend a short 1/2hr to 1 hr to take photos. The history of the stone tablets is worth understanding and taking photos. Get HanoiKids to bring you here. Entrance fee is similar Hoa Lo prison at 30K for adults and 15K students with children aged 7 and 5 free.
Crowd with tourist. Interesting place to learn about the first university in Hanoi but you should come here early in the morning as it was hot and packed so many people when we came here at 10 am.

A no miss in Hanoi. A University founded 1000 years ago, preserves wonderful heritage items, no miss the Doctors Stones, 87 Stones where they used to carve the name of those who passed the critical subjects…. Very nice environment, safe, can be conveniently reached by taxi.

Excellent piece of heritage. I was lucky to go on a graduation day with a Vietnamese local, who explained everything that was going on. Excellent photo opportunities. A little hard to find, however, but not impossible. Just about walkable from the old town.
Age is gracious. The age and history of this treasure is a lovely place to stroll through.Enjoy the garden in the city .

Wonderful architecture. Like this place so much. Very nice architecture and cheap entrance fee. It's an awesome place to chill around and take wonderful picture. In the mean time, get to see students in vietnam paying their visit in this temple. Great one!

Interesting Sight in Hanoi. We enjoyed visiting the Temple of Literature and National University in Hanoi. Prior to our visit we were not familiar with this piece of history and appreciated learning about it. The grounds are beautiful and interesting to see. The day we were there was particularly hot and the grounds are outdoors and mostly unshaded--so plan your visit accordingly.

A lot of history, but.... The place has so much history. The first University in Vietnam was founded here. But when all summed up it not much to do. The garden was okay, but nothing special. The temple likewise. A nice place to visit and get away from the traffic, but seems like a place where you "been there done that".I suppose if you bring a guide he/she can tell you more interesting thing about the place. Not so much information in English.When it sums up its a place where you pay (VD 30.000) for the history and shadow from the trees.

Well preserved and informational . Had low expectations but this monument was very well done. We hired a private guide and were impressed with the amount of symbolism and history the historical site had to offer. Very reasonable price.
Highlight. Very well preserved but it was the tour by our Active Asia guide which really brought it to life. Don't miss.

A lovely and beautiful walk through culture. Highlighted as one of the top attractions in Hanoi and didn't disappoint. A collection of temples with beautiful statues, sculptures and quotes from wise figures.
Still learning.. Amazing to see the dedication to Confucius by the Vietnamese people both students and adults. Whole complex is worth seeing. Very historic buildings and reasonably well preserved.

Peace and calm amongst the Hanoi traffic. Its hard to believe that outside the high walls the crazy pace of life that is Hanoi goes on. Inside you could be a million miles away.This oasis is wonderful, walk slowly and enjoy. Watch the locals as they look around, the giggling school groups and newly weds taking THAT photo. Never a dull moment here. Sit and relax and watch and soak up the culture. Enjoy this wonderful complex.

Very picturesque, probably better with a guide.. In a part of the world where temples can become a bit samey, the temple of literature does stand out. Due in part to the fact that it is an ex university (the first in Vietnam) rather than a temple. The gardens are lovely, the two main buildings housing shrines and artefacts are stunning and I would recommend walking to the end to see the huge drum hanging from a pagoda. The information on offer is rather limited so I think a guide would actually be beneficial when visiting.

Worth an hour of visit. being mentioned on tourist map of Hanoi we went there and first enjoyed some street food outside the temple gate and then entered the pleasant first courtyard.Then there is lot of history and you need a guide.Otherwise a well laid down place and lots of bonsai plants in the courtyard which seemed decades old. Strolled around for an hour and shopped some souvenirs.
A peaceful sanctuary. We were lucky to have a guide who gave us a great tour of this fascinating temple, which has more layers than an onion! A quiet oasis in this frenetic city

Very beautiful place full of history. This is a must to see in Hanoi. We have not seen a lot of the city, but I am still sure this is one of the best attractions. And you should have a Vietnamese guide to show it to you with inner understanding.

Busy but tranquil. Exams meant long lines and a lot of people. Once inside it was peaceful and the honking seemed miles away. Hanoikids shared the history which made it more meaningful. Would have missed much without them.

An ancient spot where you can enjoy Viet Nam's culture and history :)). The Temple of Literature is a wonderful spot to experience Ha Noi's ancient history and culture... The enormous trees that line the walkways provide welcome shade -- even during the hottest of days -- and the well-manicured grounds invite leisurely strolls. There are three places of worship frequented by many locals as well. Be sure to walk to the far end of place: many visitors seem to stop at the first large courtyard, and they miss the sites found there (e.g. an enormous bell and "drum" suspended within lovely, traditionally decorated "gazebos"). There is a museum with displays of the original facility, clothing worn by the university's graduates, etc. and climbing the stairs next to the massive wooden pillars take you up to a peaceful spot, plus a balcony overlook too. And those marvelous stelae atop carved turtles, with the names of professors and graduates engraved on them, date back to the 1400's (very cool indeed). Enjoy :))

Book a free tour with Hanoi E. Buddies!. Book the tour with Hanoi e.buddies, a local students club. They will show you arround for free and definitely give you an insight view about Hanoi. You also have chance to see the local perspectives about history, culture and so many different things related their lives.

Majestic. This temple, featured on the 100000d, is a wonderful and enchanting tribute to education. Surrounded by lovely gardens, the ancient structures carry you back to centuries old tradition. It's easy to imagine the eager students scurrying about the majestic corridors in their quest for knowledge.
Worth a go. Nice gardens but you need a tour guide to understand what is going on because not a lot is in English ! Still a beautiful place however
Splendid. A tranquil place in a busy city. We were thrilled to see graduating university students posing here for photos, containing the scholarly tradition of the temple.

Walk in and contemplate the temple. Once you get in the surrounding changes. The crow mopped Hanoi switch to a tourist place full of peace and cameras.Ticket price is 30k dong and you can visit the temple in only 30 minutes or stay longer and chill a couple of house. I stayed personally an hour and took some nice shots with my phone.
Not much to see really. To be honest, the place was rather busy with locals on Sunday afternoon, but in my opinion, there isn't really much to see.Entry cost 30,000vnd

Lovely to see. The temple of literature is centrally located and a walk round the gardens and a temple makes for a great hour or so. At 30,000VD (so less than £1 entry) it is good to see and learn more about the history of Vietnamese education.
Just ok!. Was interesting for a quick look around but wasn't too big and could be seen within about 30mins. I would recommend going but you won't be blown away.
On The List Of To Dos. This is something to be on one's to dos when in Hanoi. It doesn't take a great deal of time and is educational. Not at all hard walking. Easy for everyone.
Educational. I would definitely recommend having a tour guide for your visit here as they can explain what everything means. We toured here with HanoiKids. Well worth it.

First university of vietnam. Booked a city tour to some sightseeing places around hanoi, temple of literature was the most impressive place. This is the place where they gossip Confucius. You can get lot of information about the old vietnam education system which is very interesting. In all, it's a place worth to visit in hanoi.
Interesting but half an hour was long enough. It's interesting that people in this part of the world were so much more advanced than the western world!

Confucius School and Temple. This was WAY more interesting than I thought it would be. I am so amazed. Construction of this facility dates back to 900 something CE and is full of interesting historical artifacts. There is also temples to both Confucius and the Vietnamese King that built the temple. (Although I'm ashamed to say his name escapes me at the moment.) WELL worth your time.
Rain. I liked everything. , but the weather it was raining.The gardens were breathtaking. And the temple was very interesting.
