Very educational!. I had a private tour to see the place and I am so glad I did. I learned so much hístory of Vietnam, and also about their Buddhist concepts, Thểre are many symbols in the temple that could only be learned either by reading about them or taking a tour.

Interesting historic site. Seeing the stelae turtles was really neat as well as this historic structure. Seeing any place that survived the wars is always a nice glimpse into the history of Vietnam. A definite highlight of Hanoi

Tourist destinations are worth. This is one of those places that when traveling Vietnam you should visit. Lots of photo opportunities here, whether it's old buildings and surrounding or the students, graduates who came to celebrate the completion of their studies. In particular, before the university entrance exam many families bring their children to visit.

Interesting but a lot of tourist shops. The temple is well restored and interesting. Nevertheless, there are too much tourist shops.
Don't forget sunscreen and water when the weather is hot.

A must stop during your Hanoi holiday. Most of from the East are completely ignorant of Confucius so seeing the Temple of Literature with a good guide should be mandatory. The history is far more complicated than the short, quirky sayings that most of us know about. Plan on about an hour here. Just please respect the monks and other worshippers.

Lovely Place to Visit. We loved our visit to the Temple of Literature and National University. Graduations were happening, with all the graduates in national costume. Very pretty. Lovely setting, peaceful garden setting.

beautiful old structure. The history of Confucianism in Vietnam is in this remarkable temple with ancient stones dating back to the 14th century (although the temple is much older) that give the names of graduates from the University. A really beautiful temple with quite decorative statuary and a tremendous history. Well worth a couple of hours.
A trip to tranquility and education. A lovely place to visit away from the busy city. This temple is in use and a valuable part of the community. To be welcomed to share it was a lovely thing.

Peaceful oasis in Hanoi. Van Mieu is a must see place when you visit Hanoi. It's a peaceful place with beautiful architecture, artifacts and history. But you'll totally need a guide for a more informative and interesting visit and there aren't many activities here. The most interesting here for me are the tortoises and how people are obsessed with touching them for good luck in taking exams.It might be crowd in time of preparing for exams and graduation for Vietnamese students.

interesting place. I enjoyed seeing this place and hearing about the history. Once only open to people with money, the kings son eventually opened it to poor people who were intelligent and would benefit from education
You cannot leave Hanoi without having visited this place. One of my favorite old places in Hanoi where you can take fantastic pictures. A very beautiful place and a must see in Hanoi.
Guide recommended. This temple is very pretty and peaceful, however there want much in the was of information about the place and different things there so I would recommend a guide.
Lovely grounds. Enjoyed our visit, especially the tortoises. Lovely architecture, artifacts and history. Peaceful.Gift shops not actually overpriced as you would expect for the items we bought.

Peaceful and beautiful temple. Gorgeous place to visit. The temple was peaceful and not at all crowded for the middle of the day. The gardens are green, plentiful and beautifully maintained. I could have spent hours in the grounds writing or photographing the surrounds. This is a must do in Hanoi.

Nice peaceful place. It is a oasis of peace among the busy streets of Hanoi. Very interesting to see a temple and school put together and the history of the place can still be felt. The difference between a similar Chinese temple and this Vietnamese temple is the face that in Vietnam people are still worshiping there, but in China not.
Not what we expected but still profound. Confucius had a big influence on the culture of Vietnam and obviously Buddha. Some of the explanations could have been in better English.

Interesting enough when done with a guide. The temple was quite pretty, but to simply walk around it would only take a few minutes and yield nothing more than a couple of nice photos.
You really need a local guide to tell you the stories that go with the temple and to explain the significance of the sites and symbolism.
Interesting. A busy, but beautiful place with old buildings and well laid out gardens. Once a place of learning many students now go here for graduation photos

First University in Hanoi. Nice historical buildings with the 4 sacred animals of Hanoi. Loved how people touched the head of tortoise for good luck in examinations. The place is rather vast, probably will need an hour of so to just walk through the area.
lvoely place. A lovely place to visit. A lot of people go there, so it might get crowded at times. Has a few nooks and crannies to look at. A quiet oasis in a busy town.

Viewing the Temple of Literature. We happened to visit on the perfect day as it was picture taking day for the graduating students. The girls were dressed up in their 'ao dai', the traditional trouser dress worn for formal events. May not have been this high had it not been for the added treat of excited students in their formal attire.

Not much to read and see. Huge place spread over a large area but i didn't feel it deserves a high ranking in places to see in hanoi. I felt not much info is available as to what this musuem is all about except for some plaques here and there.

Picturesque tranquil setting to enjoy this historical site. We went through the Temple of Literature with a guide (from Hanoi Kids) and really appreciated having her there to explain the history and cultural context of the site to us. There is not much signage so it could be difficult to self guide but the site itself is so picturesque with lovely gardens and buildings that you would still enjoy your visit. Staying in the Old Quarter, we caught a quick taxi ride there as it is was a bit far to walk. Built in 1070 and dedicated to Confucius, this first University of Vietnam was traditionally for royal and noble students. It’s a beautiful site to visit. Wonderful old buildings are set amongst five courtyards with well planned and laid out gardens, trees and lotus ponds. The whole layout and design is perfectly balanced, based on yin and yang. It is nice and tranquil, secluded with trees; you can easily forget you are in the middle of busy Hanoi.You can also see the historic stone stelae of carved blue stone turtles, honouring the top scholars. 82 of these great turtle stones remain today. There are also some wonderful decorative statues honouring Confucius himself and past founders. As well as traditionally being an historical important place of education, as we walked around many current students filled the courtyards. Young school children were running around as part of an excursion. Graduating students in their beautiful traditional white gowns posed for photos on the grounds. Really picturesque relaxing spot to walk around and enjoy this historical site. Well worth a visit.
Amazing history.. Was not sure what to expect but very impressed. To think that where I stood, there were students studying maybe 1000 years ago. Very humbling.

Beautiful!. This university is 1000 years old and dedicated to Confucius. It also contains a shrine to the Buddhist monk who set himself alight in protest and burned to death in Hanoi in 1963. He studied there. Well worth a visit and stroll in the beautiful gardens.

Beautiful and historical place. A very peaceful place in the middle of the hectic traffic, once inside you hardly hear the noise. Its well maintained and has beautiful buildings and gardens. I agree that with a guide its a bit easier but even without im sure you can learn alot of this place. Everything is explained in English so cant be a big problem. The gates are special, some nice temples here and a great view when you go on top of the last temple. There are some touristshops where you can buy souvenirs. Good place to take pictures.

This place was awesome!. We were here when about 500 or so university students were coming here for good luck before their graduation. I got a few photos with some beautiful young women in their traditional dress. The complex is quite large and very deceiving as it goes back a long way, it's way out of the way so you'll need some form of transport to get there.
Beautiful. Very attractive grounds and buildings.Lotus flowers growing in the ponds.Temples quite similar to other ones, but nice to see

Go there only you have spare time. Even though it is one of the most popular tourist attractions, Temple of literature are just decent. The landscaping and gardening are excellent but most of the buildings are re-built in late 20th century. If you don't have any local guide, you would be very confused since there is no sign explaining the significance of each building, or artifact.

Early Morning Culture. We went early in the morning when the temple first opened. It was well worth the visit where we wandered around for about two hours. Great for adults but boring for kids. The grounds of the place are well looked after and we enjoyed a wander in the gardens. Lots of students come here for their graduation pictures along with lots of wedding couples.

first national university in Vietnam. It was very nice to go to this place and learn about Vietnam's history of education. The temple offers well preserved traditional Vietnamese architecture, in an attractive setting with gardens and ponds. Well worth a visit!

Steeped in history and also very beautiful. I thoroughly enjoyed my private guide of this attraction. Steeped in history and also very beautiful to look at, I would definitely recommend a visit for 2-3 hours.
So Happy We Visited. Packed with history and enjoyed wandering through it but it's probably a place you'd only visit once. Kids would be bored but we as a couple enjoyed it
Very Touristy, Pretty. This area has many tourists and tourist shops, but is pretty and centrally located - however, it doesn't appear well-kept, especially the water-fountains.
Fascinating insight into importance of education in Vietnam. Well-displayed exhibits with English and Vietnamese commentary. Lots to photograph. Interesting buildings and gardens.

Peaceful refuge in the busy heart of Hanoi. We loved being here. Besides the very nice buildings and artworks you can see there, we found it very peaceful and a nice distraction from the busy vibe of Hanoi. We spent about an hour there, just enjoying the views and peace. Must go place in Hanoi
Peaceful . Favourite site in Hanoi. It's well preserved and peaceful. A very enjoyable stroll. Definitely the highlight of Hanoi

A highlight of places to see in Hanoi - but go with a guide to make it really special!. A delightful attraction that is very picturesque with different buildings and beautiful gardens. You will enjoy it more if you have a local guide to explain the significance of each element of the building...

Well worth a visit. This old university has been preserved well, and you can even see the tablets where the names of the top-performing students are written. Well worth a visit. Incredibly interesting.
great photo opportunity. Beautiful site with lots of history and charm. Showsyou how life was lived so far back. Gives great insightsito the culture of Vietnam. Esy to take some great photos.

interesting and nice. not as impressive as i expected when i arrived but still when you look at all the writings on stones and you think about how ancient this learning place is... besides it's a very quite and beautiful garden to walk and spend some time.

Fantastic view of history. This temple doesn't awe and inspire from the outside, but once you are in the immaculate grounds, it keeps going and going and the academic history is outstanding. Well worth a visit, So pleased to see that it is well respected among the locals also. When we visited it was very hot but that didn't detract from a couple of hour stay wandering around reading the history and seeing the history unfold before our eyes.

Lovely place. This place is beautiful and very rich in history. It has been preserved well, and you can even see the tablets where the names of the top-performing students are written. The serene atmosphere does make you feel like it's a great place for educating young people. This is actually one of the must-see places in Hanoi :)
a beautiful setting. Very interesting. Historical and fascinating as one of the first university settings in Vietnam. Lovely gardens and bonsais…and the people are great to watch too.

History more impressive than reality. Being a 1000+ year old center of learning, we expected a grandiose experience but it just didn't happen.
Nevertheless, worth a visit.
worth a visit. Nice way to spend a couple of hours of your time when in Hanoi - there was a graduation ceremony on when we were there which was lovely to see.

Interesting. You need to do it with a guide to get the full history of the place. When we were there, there were a lot of school children having graduation as it was the end of the school year, so it was very busy, but had a lovely ambience with all the little kids.
Nice for a walk. We were not impressed, but still a nice place to see and walk around. A walking distance from the old quarter and not expensive.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Incredibly interesting. We saw a lot of school children on excursions children all dressed up and some graduating

Underwhelming.. Despite the wonderful reviews in the various guides, we found this Temple somewhat run down and commercialised. Having lived in Asia for many years and visited many temples, we were extremely disappointed with this one considering its importance in the Vietnamese culture and being the most revered Temple complex in Hanoi

Worth while. Great insight into the cross political environment that Hanoi is today.
Interesting architecture and beautiful gardens steeped in old world Vietnamese culture
Very interesting. A very interesting place to visit. Participated in a half day APT tour and our guide was very knowledgable. Would highly recommend this introduction to Hanoi.

A must see if you are in Hanoi.. One of my favourite places to visit. So much history and beautifully restored and maintained. Photo opportunities abound here, whether it be the ancient buildings and surrounds or the graduating students who arrive to celebrate the completion of their study. As others have noted it can get extremely busy, in the hotter months plan to go between 1230-200pm, you will be very hot however the crowds are usually at lunch or trying to stay cool. After that you can cross the road and have a delicious lunch and refresh yourself at Kotos. Put both on your list if you visit Hanoi.

Historical places. It is a common knowledge in Hanoi that before a student wants to take an exam, he/she would like to pray in this historical place to succeed in the examination. The old building has 3 main gates: one gate in the middle is for the king and royalties, one gate on the right (it is called morallity gate) is for student entrance and the last gate in the left (it is called talented gate) is for the graduate student from the place.

Very Interesting Place. You could feel the might of history looking at you from every part of this place.Also we were lucky to be in the same time when several groups of newly graduated students decided to celebrate of getting their diploma there.
Beautiful, but crowded. Charming example of Vietnamese imperial architecture, less so the modern reconstruction at the back. Many tourists, so be prepared for crowds.
A must go place in Hanoi to understand the culture. Not very big place but full of history. Go with a guide and in one hour you get to understand lot of Hanoi's ancient history

Fascinating. The Temple of Literature is the first University of Vietnam. It is a great place to explore. It takes you back to the ancient world as you understand the emphasis that was laid on education in those times as well. The temple itself is beautiful - red interiors and fascinating idols. There is a charming old man who sits and paints messages in calligraphic Chinese script.They also house a couple of souvenir shops.

Impressed by the young Vietnamese visiting this Temple.. Apart from the amazing buildings at this Temple, I was impressed by the Vietnamese school children I saw who were visiting this site as part of their graduation process. This site was not just something that tourists visit - it is obviously still a place that is revered by locals.

Interesting place to visit. Worth a visit...warning though - the day we went there were lots of students who were graduating - they were fine, but was approached by someone wanting to 'practice english'..obviously a scam - and probably would have tried to pick pocket me - just be careful :-)

First university in Vietnam. We enjoyed our time here and would definitely recommend to go see if you have a few days in Hanoi.This place gives you a sense of the rich heritage of education in Vietnam, a good insight on to local education culture.
Nice. Very nice and interesting. With a beautiful garden and landscape. They have list of the names of the doctors who have passed the exam carved into the stones.

A good stopfor Confucian exposure. There's no better option in Vietnam for finding tribute to Confucius! The Temple can be seen in a half hour and is worth including in a half-day trip to Uncle Ho's Mausoleum and the Fine Arts Museum. There are also a few good souvenir shops within the grounds and several restaurants next door.

Definitely worth a visit. We didn't really know what to expect when our guide suggested we visit, however we were pleasantly surprised. The shrines exhibits and architecture are interesting. However I would definitely recommend going with a guide, as to visit without one I think it would be difficult to get the most out of it.
A great site. The Temple of Literature is a must-see site while visiting Hanoi. It's, naturally, full of students so it's a little loud and they love to talk to westerners. Overall, a neat site.

Temple of Literature. Amazing Temple cos the day we visited there were so many students with their graduation attire - who had come there they were taking pictures and it was something nice where you wont get it this side of the world. Vast area and we visited everywhere, Beautiful place and a must for everybody who visit Hanoi

A little oasis in the city. It was great to walk through the temple grounds of this historic site on a hot summer day. Very interesting history. Don't miss the stone stele with the names of old scholars.

Nice visit. Very interesting place to visit. Lots of activity on the day we visited. Many high schoolers were taking what looked like year-end photos. Many people praying to deities of learning and knowledge.
If you visit, remember the museum of art is very nearby. We missed it, as our map was mis-marked.
Ancient university, beautiful gardens. This place is interesting to go to if you want to learn about early scholars and doctors' training in the Confucian method. The gounds ae lovel.

Temple is beautiful grounds. Great place for photos, although you find yourself shade hopping when it is so hot. Tickets are cheap and you are free to take as many photos as you like. Make sure you cover the whole complex as we missed the end part as we headed out for an iced tea!

A Tranquil setting. It was very hot the day we visited but I witnessed how special this place is to the local students and that left me feeling proud to be among them. The garden is lovely on entering and i found it very interesting.Worth visiting.

Old and amazing temple. This is an very old temple from the times of Confuscious. It was full of students celebrating their graduation so a very special time.
Beautiful old buildings and such history, I had a tour guide for the day and he was very knowledgeable about the history.
A must visit

Destination history. Destination of history , a place for people of future generations recognize what our forefathers went before leaving , this is also the place to keep many traces in the history of Vietnam

Very beautiful temple. Well worth visiting. Interesting and beautiful. This is the temple that is featured on the back of the 100,000 Vietnamese Dong banknote. You can spend a good hour or so admiring the architecture and it has very nice maintained gardens too.
Serene heart of Hanoi. A wonderful serene place in the middle of hectic Hanoi where you can wander round & get a glimpse of the old traditions of Vietnam.

Worth visiting. We visited this in April on a blazing hot sunny day when local youngsters were having various graduation ceremonies. Originally built in the 11th century and dedicated to Confucius it was opened as the very first university in Vietnam in 1076 to study Confucianism originally for the rich nobles then in 15th century to the rest of the population. It's no longer a university but holds a special place in students' hearts. After passing through a formal courtyard garden there are various pavilions, one of them housing a large statue of Confucius. This site reminds me a bit of a miniature version of The Forbidden City in Bejing with its courtyards and pavilions but it has more exhibits to see and certainly with all the young excited graduates and proud parents made for an interesting visit.

Peaceful and somewhat quiet. This time of year is graduation time and the temple is the gathering place for a lot of graduating classes.It's fun to see them celebrate, although the usual quiet tends to get disrupted every so often.Nevertheless, a peaceful place of beauty.

Interesting university. It is the policy of the first university in Vietnam, located in the central building in the capital, large campus. There were lots of trees, so that traditional worship Confucius bold architecture of China, inside hanging many royal concubine couplets written in Chinese language, especially with another stone tablet the names of the high passed.Review a place to go to visit in the capital, Hanoi. you must buy tickets at the door, to visit over about 1 hour.

Great place with a guide. We had a guide from Hanoi Kids it was a big help and a great day had we were with another couple and very interesting not realsing how much influence the Chinese had here, and in particular Con Fucious
Graduation Day. The day of our visit was graduation for some students. Wonderful celebrations with families of students of all ages.
Beautiful school. I have been there and i saw it is very beautiful and woudeful temple of school.I hope every one come here to see it.

Ok place. It's not bad if you have time to spare it's worth a visit, a lot of kids come here for graduation great for photos however a lot of screaming, use the side door in the gardens for free entry even though it's not a lot of money seems only westerners pay

Where old and new educational values merge. peaceful place of pilgrimage for academics and where modern Vietnamese students go to celebrate their graduation.... The main pagoda rebuilt in the 1990s after being bombed flat in the war...... You'd never know and there are no recriminations here as life has moved on for the better. The rebuild restoration is a triumph - you would honestly never know the temple was not thousands of years old
Nice and relaxed. Pretty and quiet place in central Hanoi. Definitely worth a visit while passing from one sight to another.

Interesting. Interesting complex,lots to explore and plenty of photo opportunities. We were on a private tour with Selective Asia -our guide was very informative and knowledgable about the history. Definitely worth a visit.

Elegant and peaceful historic temple and gardens. We thought this was a wonderful depiction of the longevity of Vietnamese culture. The temple has few truly original buildings, as it is much restored since first built in the 11th century. The current temples and buildings are elegant, beautifully kept and the gardens are lovely. We hired a guide and would recommend that as there are almost no written materials to explain what you are seeing.

Historical and very educational. This is really an awesome place. Here we can understand the evolution of the country's education. Besides that, there are many artefact on education such as old scrolls and parchment that dates back to the time when china was a big influence in Vietnam. Many of the architecture also have resemblance as well as specific meaning and it is interesting to learn about it.
If u have time. Nice , I learnt something about the way the universities started and worked in the ancient vietnam , how the king was involved in such issues

Beautiful!. Aah, I have special memories of this place. The gardens are beautiful and the best part was that we got to witness little Vietnamese kids graduating from kindergarten and they put on a little show, so adorable! Then when we were leaving a group of recent graduates from college were taking their pics, all smartly decked out in their traditional Vietnamese dresses (ao dai?). According to our guide from HanoiFreeTours, Van, who also recently graduated, graduating is a big celebration with dresses made, make-up artists and photographers hired for the day! The Vietnamese treasure education and this a lovely place to celebrate it.
NIce old place to visit. Visiting this place, you can have a sense of the older times...You must visit it!!!!It's in the center of the city, easy to find it and to go.
A relaxing way to while away some time in Ha Noi.. A nice place to visit, interesting items & history. Good for people watching and wandering around. Some very old items on display.

First University in Vietnam. It was nice for a visit, so you have some ideas about Vietnamese history, education and the impact of Chinese culture/education to Vietnamese. Would suggest to have a tour guide come with you if possible as they would explain it better. Get the free tour guide in Hanoi, they are pretty good

fortunately this place is good for meet Aodai girls. fortunately this place is good for meet Aodai girls. when college girls graduate, they come here and take group photos in Aodai. so very excellent place
Another worth while attraction. Beautiful pagodas and shrines surrounded by tranquil courtyards and gardens makes this a good place to visit when visiting Hanoi.

Nicely crowded. We went there in february 2015, a few days after the New Year. So it was very crowded with locals, which gave it a nice feel. You can just walk around and look at the different 'temples'. You can also just sit on a bench and do some people-watching.

Must visit. This is a beautiful complex steeped in history.
Come early in the morning to avoid the crowds and for good light to take pictures. It's quite the photographers paradise.
The huge lotus ponds with the large fronds are a joy to behold.
Enjoy the ambiance. If you want to know the history get a guide,.

Worthwhile visit - masses of history. A proud and distinguished history, this temple has a timeline going back over a thousand years. Look out for the tortoises and the Rolls of Honour. This is a quiet place, and restful in a buzzing city. A visit of some 20 - 30 minutes, with a guide should suffice.

A historical site of Hanoi 1st University. The history and ancient structures and the interesting stories behind it. Had a wonderful tour with our free Hanoi tour guide Ms. Ling an English major University student.
So very old. You have to get your head around the fact that this temple is 1000 years old. It is quite mind boggling. Beautiful temple. I really enjoyed the visit as I love history.

Amazing. My advice is to go here in the morning. It can get very warm and very busy in the afternoons. Its absolutely worthwhile to see Hanoi's oldest university. We were lucky enough to spot some graduation pictures being taken. Also some nice souvenir shops. You could spent 2 hours here easily

Worthy of a visit. Very pretty spot. Interesting culturally. Best if not too many other tourists there.
As stated in other reviews, & goes for most places, an English speaking guide helps.

Peaceful and interesting. Peaceful, interesting, great for a chilled out hour in the afternoon.
I would go later in the afternoon as quite open spaces and can be very hot

A good insight on the local culture. Do take time to walk about to check out the various figures they worship and why. Bring your mobile phone to google some of these character and you'll get a sense on how these figures has a strong influence on Vietnam way of thinking. Education is placed in very high regards from the very beginning. The Hanoi logo is based on one of the structure here. You will also realize there is strong influence by China but there's also distinct difference the Kings of Vietnam and China. Good to have a guide. Do also walk about to appreciate the structure setup and find out more why the current setup is done this year. Good first stop in my opinion.
Temple of Literature.. This place is worth a visit especially if you have been a tertiary education student before. It gives you a sense of the rich heritage of education in Vietnam.

very nice place. It was very nice to go to this place and learn about Confucius and his philosophy. I guess it would be better with a guide, but there are many signs in English that explain how each king dealt with education. It was really well taken care of.If you are a student ask for a discount (the same for any attraction)
Very Pretty. Small admission charge and many beautiful things to look at! Really enjoyed our time here and would definitely recommend to go see if you have a few days in Hanoi.
Good. As indicated in a previous review, we are spoilt by multiple visits to Japan. But interesting none the less.

History, and An Attractive Setting. The temple offers well preserved traditional Vietnamese architecture, in an attractive setting with gardens and ponds. You can see photos on the internet. It was built close to 1000 years ago to honour Vietnams first scholars and was dedicated to Confucius. It has had an educational association ever since, hence the name. As Asian temples go, it is not particularly spectacular, but the fact it is nearly 1000 years old and so well preserved makes it warrant a visit.

Great Attraction. So much educational history here + cultural performing arts through traditional music and dress. Before every school year students show up at this facility to pray for good grades. This was the first university in Vietnam-awesome.
Good. Beautiful old architecture and gardens. Good gift shop that sold the best postcards I've seen plus stamps.

Enjoyable but need a guide. We were shown around by a lovely local student who gave up her afternoon to help us and explain the details. Still although it is interesting we felt it was just not as interesting as so many of the places we saw nor as visually stimulating. Perhaps it was the intense heat and humidity?

Interesting. Visit as part of a city tour. We had an English speaking guide.This helped to make sence of everything. Enjoyed seeing the student dressed up. They were there asking for luck in forthcoming exams.

Ancient and fascinating. The temple of Literature was a fascinating look at education in Vietnam dating from the 11th century. The notice boards around the complex were informative as we did not hire a guide. The complex is quite large with beautiful gardens and lotus pools. Inside the wooden structures, visitors can see statues of past kings and altars dedicated to Confucius. Of special interest were the crane-standing-on-turtle statues next to the altars. We noticed some visitors rubbing the stomach of the crane, presumably for good luck. Overall, the temple gives visitors insights into how prestigious and privileged education must had been in ancient Vietnam.

salute to education. The temple complex dedicated to Confucius, sages and scholars, is the first Vietnamese University and place of ancient and stringent exams. Built in 1070, it shows just how entrenched the Vietnamese regard for education is. It is such a beautiful place that you don't even notice the section rebuilt following French bombing in 1947. Pop over the road to Koto restaurant for a delicious meal while you are there. Continuing the theme of education, this restaurant teaches street kids who end up in restaurants around the world. The ancient scholars would approve whole heartedly.

Pause for thought. When you enter into this temple and grounds you have to remember that it is an ancient site of learning and not just a tourist attraction. I particularly liked seeing the turtle stele which students used to sit on. It requires about two hours for a leisurely look around. Sometimes there are students there who are graduating and dressed in a traditional fashion which adds to the experience of the visit. When I was there in April there was also a party of school children being shown around the site.

Interesting with wonderful bonsai. We enjoyed strolling around. Gardens, six hundred year old stone tablets from students who attended the ancient university. It's not exciting, but a pleasant, interesting oasis in this busy city.
Interesting. We enjoyed the whole ambiance of this place along with the air con as very hot in Hanoi on our visit
very interesting. well worth the visit, you can take the hotel shuttle bus into the city. It is well worth the visit, there is lots to see

Gorgeous, important piece of Vietnamese culture. What a beautiful place. We went here with our free (awesome) guide Phuong from HanoiKids, a current student, which made the experience probably much richer than if we had gone alone. The love and focus of learning in Vietnamese culture today has its direct roots here. Gorgeous architectural details infused with myths and meaning. One of our favorites of all we saw in Hanoi. Pretty crowded but understandably.
Trip round with hanoiKids. We were taken here with our tour guide Tino from Hanoi Kids. Her knowledge really helped us to understand this amazing place. It's really worth a visit.
I felt in China. Lots to be learned here. The temples are well maintained. I liked the different doorways you have to pass to get to the main temple. Each one in its own style. Pretty
Beautiful Setting. This was well worth the time to visit. A must see place. Beautiful setting as well as educational and spiritual.

An historic experience. We visited on one of the days when graduates learned of their results and judging by their mood they were all successful. The university is a very old seat of learning and largely in good condition. The large number of stele had the names of past graduates engraved going back to the 15th century. A very interesting visit to see the respect the Vietnamese pay to their history,

An unusual historic site. I enjoyed hearing and seeing an historical educational institution with such an influence on a country's development. Even today local students flock there for graduation photographs and good luck moments before exams. Well maintained although many parts now not original structures. Nice to see respect for education.

It speaks everything about the history and culture of Vietnam. Visited the temple as part of the study group. A learned young Vietnamese girl acted as guide for us (who was very fluent in English). She explained the various details about the temple in length. Whatever we understood from the guide’s briefing was......This temple was built in 1070 at the time of King Lý Nhân Tông and was reconstructed during the Trần dynasty (1225–1400) and in the subsequent dynasties. This temple hosts the "Imperial Academy" which is Vietnam's first national university (established in 1076). It covers an area of over 54000 square metres, including the Literature lake, Giam park and the interior courtyards which are surrounded by a brick wall. In front of the Great Gate are four tall pillars. The gate opens onto three pathways. The centre path was reserved for the monarch The left path was for the administrative Mandarins and the right path was for military Mandarins. The interior of the site is divided into five courtyards. The first two courtyards are quiet areas with ancient trees and trimmed lawns, where scholars would relax away from the bustle of the outside world. The third courtyard is the "Well of Heavenly Clarity" ("Thiên quang tỉnh"). After third courtyard one finds the doctors' steles. These are 116 erected steles of carved blue stone turtles with elaborate motifs to honour talent and encourage study. The turtle ("quy") is one of the nation's four holy creatures. The others are the dragon ("long"), the unicorn ("ly") and the phoenix ("phuong"). The turtle is a symbol of longevity and wisdom. In the centre of the fourth courtyard is the "House of Ceremonies" ("Bai Duong"). The fifth courtyard was constructed as an imperial academy. I don’t remember much about fourth and fifth courtyards.A must see place in Hanoi. You may buy various souvenirs from here including Water Puppets, Stamps, Wooden Masks Miniature Statues and Musical Instruments You can also play the traditional Vietnamese musical instruments in the temple for free.
Graduation!. It was graduation day. Lovely to se all of the students in their graduating gowns, tossing their motor boards as they jumped for joy.

Beautiful Temple. Well preserved and very beautiful. Very interesting part of their history. Lovely gardens too.The locals go there to have the graduation photos taken - really interesting to watch the locals go about their everyday life.

Beautiful oasis in bustling Hanoi. This temple is over 1000 thousand years old and served as Vietnam's first university. It is beautifully laid out with gates and ponds and flowers and temple artifacts. It is the perfect place for a quiet stroll when you need a break from the bustling streets of Hanoi.

Peace and quiet, except for the tourists. Van Mieu is a nice place to visit, particularly in the morning. In theory it's a calm and serene oasis in the heart of Hanoi, but since a lot of other tourists have the same idea, it can feel a bit crowded, particularly since it's not a big area. Still, as a garden and in regards to its historic significance, it's certainly worth a visit. I recommend reading up beforehand or joining a tour, as the information that can be gleaned from signs is rather little and leaves one wanting to know more.

A tranquil place in a busy city. You need a guide or take a tour which includes this attraction as there is so much to learn about Vietnamese history and beliefs which you wont get just walking around. They explain the meaning of what you see and how things are placed in certain spots for a reason.It is so peaceful and relaxing and dates back many centuries.

Well worth a visit. The temple is dedicated to Confucius. It is made up of five courtyards. It is busy. The temple was built in 1076 and became the first university of Vietnam. There are still stone stelae with the names of graduates between 1442-1779.It is nice to walk through the courtyards and visit the temple. It cost 30000 dong entry. Please let me know if you found the review helpful.

A little piece of quiet and calm in the center of Hanoi's chaos. We were fortunate to arrive at the temple just a group of graduates from the local university arrived to get photos taken infront and inside the temple. The sheer happyness and joy of the graduates filled the temple and fingers crossed they will have a bright future ahead of them.Even without the graduates, the tempel was a very good experience and there was a lot of information about the history of the place. What struck us the most, was the calmness and quiet of the place, even in the middel of Hanoi's noisy traffic. We spent around 1½-2 hours there. I would recommend to visit the temple if you go to Hanoi. It is worth the visit.

Nice place and doesn't require too much time. I went here on my husbands suggestion and it's nice, but doesn't carry a Wow factor like other places dating from a similar period.Suggest you get the brochure in English when you buy your ticket, as there isn't a lot to explain the site and the brochure is very nicely laid out.It does carry a lot of history, but, in my opinion, doesn't have the same impact aesthetically. If this review is helpful, please tick below:

Very Crowded but Beautiful. I have visited many temples in Thailand, Japan, Korea and Vietnam. This is a very beautiful one, however, access to this temple is tough as parking is limited. The temple is also very crowded which led to lower experience for us. We spent about 1 hour at this temple.

Pretty and Peaceful. Nice relaxing place to visit, only needed an hour. Has pretty gardens, nice architecture. A young childrens class was in session when we attended so we go to observe that. A few nice souvenir shops, good prices and friendly staff.

Worth a visit but not amazing. We went there on the way to the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum.An interesting place to visit and see the history of learning that goes back nearly 1,000 years (1076) - but I wasn't blown away by anything and the English descriptions were limited.Definitely worth a visit - but it isn't a place you can spend a couple of hours at as you walk around and try to take it all in.

Confucius Temple, Calligraphy and Education. Avoid During Tet. This is a beautiful temple and university. We were there during Tet weekend so the place was extremely busy with families and school children waiting to be blessed for good luck in their studies. Their parents prayed that they will continue to do well in school and obtain higher education. The grounds are lovely and the temple itself is very beautiful. It was great seeing all the kids posing beside one of the ancient scrolls and stone tablets as their families blessed them with hopes for knowledge. It was extremely crowded during Tet, but at any other time I think this would be a wonderful spot in the city. Across the way was a calligraphy artist group only there during the Tet weekend. Watching these artists craft their art using the ancient writing style was enlightening.

Beautiful and quiet gem. We only had an hour before it closed for the evening but it was enough to meander around and enjoy the beauty of the buildings and quiet haven from the city. Wish it had an English guide brochure (maybe it does but we couldn't find it) to learn more about the buildings and history.
Worth seeing. Typical Vietnamese architecture and artefacts and as such, it was very worthwhile visiting. Pretty gardens. We walked here from the Sofitel Plaza Hotel.
Worth a visit. You really have to visit this site when you're in Hanoi as it's got a great history. It doesn't take too long though - probably an hour.

Beautiful!. We spent a morning at this Temple and that was enough for us. The grounds are beautiful and peaceful. Very well manicured like every place in Vietnam. We didn't do much homework about the history and we didn't take a tour. Our experience was all on our own and that worked for us. Not many resources onsite so do your homework before you go.There are restrooms and two gift shops.

My Favorite Site in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is one of the oldest structures in Hanoi - established in 1070. The temples and grounds are dedicated to the Chinese philosopher Confucius and a number of other scholars and mandarins who graduated from the school here that served as a center for higher learning. Typical of Vietnamese temples, a gate leads to an outer courtyard garden which leads to another gate and the Well of Heavenly Clarity beyond. The temple of Confucius can be found at the end of the pool. Monuments and stele to various scholars can be found off to the right and beyond the altar of Confucius are altars and images of various scholars and immortals. Many students visit here and light joss sticks and bring offerings. The temple is an oasis of calm and reflection in what you will find is a very busy city. I recommend a few hours of peace and solitude here. Afterward, a restaurant named Koto is a nice place to have lunch. As you depart the main gate, turn left and then look left at the corner. It's in the middle of the block running alongside the temple.

A nice afternoon. We took a walk from old town to the temple. The park and tempel site is nicely decorated. I liked the huge drum behind the tempel. We found it nice but not exceptional. It's worth a short visit but if you don't have time I wouldn't loose any sleep over it.

Lovely escape from the busy streets of Hanoi. We went with our "Hanoi Kids" guides that were very informative. Many things about this place that we would never have known if we went by ourselves. There were hundreds of students that had graduated and were taking photos all over the place. They were wearing beautiful traditional clothes and it made the visit extra special. I recommend going here, and especially with knowledgeable guides. Lots to see and rich history.

A must see. When the Normans were invading Britain Hanoi was setting up a university. Beautiful ancient buildings set in lovely landscaping. Don't forget to go around the temple as there is much more to see.

Always School Children there. This is a lovely place to visit, quiet away from the huslte & bustle of Hanoi. There's always school children or students there as it is part of their curriculum to visit it at some stage. Nice place.

The oldest university. A lovely temple in the ground of the oldest university in Hanoi. Plenty of photo opportunities. The main gate is beautiful and the drum hall at the back is great. The temple has red lacquered wood inside with several statues. You can light an incense stick and ask for whatever you want. Whether you get it or not is another matter.There is a nice restaurant "Koto" also double as a cooking school which has great food and service, just outside the temple.

You just have to visit Văn Miếu Quốc Tử Giám. There is no other place like Văn Miếu Quốc Tử Giám in Hanoi - NONE. This is the first national university of Vietnam. This is where you learn about our culture and tradition - our love and thirst for knowledge as well as our desire to make our family and village proud. Every single stone in the place owns his own symbol and meaning. Get yourself a good Hanoian tour guide or better still, a good Hanoian friend and visit! You will definitely enjoy not just the sight but also the groups and groups of local students coming in to pay our respect to the very first teachers of the nation.

very interesting. Hard to believe there was a university here in 1070+ when Europeans were still living in skins. the grounds are very nice and they clearly tried to combine this esthetic with a space for learning. you will probably benefit from a guide to translate many of the monuments and inscriptions.

A very interesting complex. We visited this temple complex on a Saturday afternoon when groups of graduating students were celebrating. It is interesting that current students wish to celebrate their graduation at the First National University of Vietnam, founded in the 11th century!There were some great flower displays and trees. The complex is well preserved.
Interesting insight. The home of confuscious. The feeling of learning was enhanced by many students enjoying their graduation in the beautiful grounds.
Need a guide. If you go there alone without any guide and local friends it will be dull, boring and not much to see. Better spend time discover other attractions.

Fascinating History. We visited the temple of literature on a private guided tour, such an interesting place with amazing history. It really puts Vietnams past into perspective hearing all the stories behind the temple.A must visit for anyone coming to Hanoi!

Must stop. First university in Vietnam. Back then only few people had access to the university and the final exams were only administered to the best student by the king who ask questions and graded the students. You can find the tombstones of the teachers on both sides of the temple.

very grand. this temple is very grand in the whole of hanoi city... very big area as well... cultural and a sense of nostalgic feeling... happened to see graduation ceremonies while visiting there and it seems that here is a must come graduation venue...

Nothing to see... 30,000 vnd per person entrance fee, very little information in English, virtually nothing to see. My wife and I were looking forward to our visit based on the majority of reviews on here, but it was disappointingly dull. Not recommended, better off spending your entrance fee on some local street food / beers and watching the world go by.
Beautiful oasis in busy Hanoi. The grounds are beautiful and the temples are gorgeous. Many photographic opportunities. Highly recommended.

The ancient centre of learning. Not many countries had set up universities over a thousand years ago but this Buddhist centre concentrated on the teachings of Confucius. There are 5 sections, a bit like a smaller version of the Forbidden City in Beijing and you can walk through and into the shrine areas. You will see people praying at the shrines as you walk through. We were there just as university graduates, having completed their studies elsewhere, come here to take class photos at the original university before going their separate ways. With 100s of undergraduates celebrating in temperatures close to 40c, it was excessively hot and crowded but full of energy. Sadly, bomb damage from various wars demolished some of the original buildings, although these had been rebuilt. Look out for the Turtle scrolls to the top students down the ages when it was still a university.

Picturesque!. The temple was founded in 1070, sixty years after the city was founded as the new capital. This is a temple of Confucius that was the site of the first university. Here, the best of the best were educated and their names inscribed on marble plates on top of stone turtle statues. This is a picturesque site but to truly appreciate it, you need a guide.

Interesting insight into an ancient university. We enjoyed the walk from Old Hanoi although it was a bit wet. The site has photogenic formal gardens and buildings with some souvenir shops. It is very much on the tourist routes, but still retains a lot of character and interest especially if you know a bit of Vietnamese history.
Nice atmosphere, not much in way of information.. Worth a look but it won't take too long. If you are lucky you'll see some graduation photo-shoots going on which adds atmosphere.

good way to learn History. Great place, vivid examples of a long history of Vietnam and scholars.Without a guide, it would be not worth visiting. Therefore, it's advisable that we come with a tour guide.They offer a wide variety of souvenirs for school students and people working with resonable price.
Interesting place to visit. Lots of interesting history and a nice place to just stroll around, take photos and enjoy. Beautiful gardens and easy to get to.
With visiting. Learn the history and importance of the philosophy of education while admiring the architecture of the temples. Attempt to get a local guide to tell you history. Not to be missed.

Hire a Tour Guide. The morning we visited, the temple was busy with school children which looked like they were attending ceremonies and graduations. The courtyards and gardens were pleasant to walk through. Dont miss the huge bell and drum toward the rear. A tour guide would have been of great benefit to fully understand the temple and it's history.

great Place. this area is very nice, when we coming here knew all of information about vietnam history, special here is a old univercity in vietnam with have so much good studrent. we were so like this place has been met a lot of studrent coming here have meeting about education.

A highlight of our time in Viet Nam. This is a lovely setting: a calm garden with traditional temple buildings, and a reverential air. Understanding its role in the lives of local students makes it even more meaningful. The kind of place I'd love to have nearby, to wander through or read in, as part of a daily routine
Great Gardens. It was a wet day but that did not distract from the beauty of the bonsai plants at the National University of the old wooden buildings recommend strongly

History of university in the past of Vietnam. It is in the center area. It is told the story of university and their believe for education of local people there but you need local guide to tell you the story that you cannot find in the travel book.
Temple of Literature. It was very busy when we went but it was easy to navigate through the crowds. Inside the temples are beautifully decorated. Worth the small admission fee.

A must see with a tour guide. Although we were hot and tired and our kids found parts of this boring while we were there, this museum explains all other parts of culture encountered in our Vietnamese stay. Students currently visit this temple to pray before their examinations and graduation ceremonies from universities occur here. Students dressed in white like brides were graduating while we visited. We had a tour guide which was helpful as there are many intricacies to every statue and building and not many English signs. She told us that the beams that you have to cross over to enter a room are so that the visitor bows to show respect to the household. The same architecture of 'climbing' over a raised beam was in many other places we visited in Vietnam and based on this visit our children really understood much about Vietnam.

Excellent Place of Learning. It will take you 3-4 USD by taxi from Old Quarter to this beautiful temple, which is a century old, but is still in very good condition. There is a golden turtle inside the temple, near the statue of Confucius, who is worshiped here.

Memorable experience. The Temple of Literature will remind visitors how insignificant we are. Here is a thousand years of honouring secular learning and ethical behaviour. Confuscious and the early kings influenced how the education of the talented scholars of Vietnam would be carried out. The stone stelae recording the examinations of the 'doctors' are a chronicle. This is a very moving temple that depicts the architecture of the periods and illustrates much of the philosophy of a vast era,You must see this - and reflect.

Still Maintains An Atmosphere of Learning. Very interesting to visit to see the emphasis placed on learning 1000 years ago. History surrounds you here. Takes about an hour to walk around. Guide could be helpful as many signs are not in Englsh
Great Historic Stop. A must see in Hanoi. Yes, definitely a tourist stop, but the history is undeniable and great to see.

Honouring literature and wisdom.. This is an interesting site to visit. Although we arrived on a very busy day, when many University students were having their photos taken to celebrate graduation, and although there were busloads of tour groups descending upon this site, it was quite fascinating. The large stone turtles ( turtle steles) have the listings of the scholars, who attended the University over many centuries. The exams were rigorous and demanding, and a final exam in literature was given by royalty.The main focus of this site is a Confucian Temple which is of great importance today to many people.The pools and the gardens and bonsai were a little disappointing, as they did not seem to have been given the care and attention , that such a popular, important and well visited site deserves.Still worth visiting at 30,000 Dong. Walking distance from the Old Quarter and you can link this in with a visit to the Fine Arts Gallery, which is close by.

A beautiful escape from the city. I live in Hanoi and have visited the Temple of Literature anytime I've had visitors. The grounds are beautiful and well kept. If you hold up the 100.000 bill, you may see something familiar while visiting the grounds. Enjoy!

Peace and tranquility in the old quarter of Hanoi.... Lovely place that is a haven of peace and tranquility in otherwise chaotic Hanoi :-)Very peaceful to walk around... it was graduation day when we were there, so saw some of the kids graduation... nice to watch for a few minutes, but far more fun walking around the gardens and enjoying the peace and quiet.You do have to pay to get in, but it's only 30K VND (about $1.50) per person.Well worth it if you want to escape the hooting and chaos for 30-60 minutes...

Interesting historical site. We enjoyed the beatiful gardens of this temple/historical university and gained some further knowledge about viatnamese history while visiting. We already visited the citadel in Hue and the tempel of litterature linked perfectly to the history presented there.
Beautiful Temple. Stunning temple in a beautiful garden...busy but what isn't in Vietnam. Easy to find and nice little restaurants near by. Worth a look.
Essential visit. Beautiful setting and environment, peaceful location, lots to learn culturally.And nothing to add except to get to the 100 character threshold for Trip Advisor :-)
Interesting. Nice to see the architecture of the old university, learnt about how they set it up, plus the interesting Diploma Certificates given to its students. Very nice photographic area.

Interesting place. This is another of Hanoi's buildings on the "list of things to do". It may be busy with tourists, but the place if beautiful none the less. there's a nice tranquilty to the place as soon as you step through the gate.
AKA "centre of scientific and cultural activities". Beautiful gardens and cultural statues. Lots of history to discover. The smell is divine will all the incense. Highly recommended.
Beautiful. Pay for a tour guide- so much more informative than just walking it. Not a whole lot in English- and so much symbology that is not well labelled unless you speak Vietnamese.

A nice temple within walking distance of the Old Quarter. Having seen many temples over the years, I have to say that they all do start to look similar. This is no exception. There is minimal English translations on the exhibits so you will need to read up on it beforehand to appreciate the importance and history of this place. Still worth a visit though, if only to escape the crazy traffic.

good place to learn more about history. The temple has a long history and its interior contained many statues. It may look old on the outside, but it is not too bad on the inside. Reading the panels containing short write-ups of the temple made me discover more about it and how it contributed to the cultural scene in Hanoi.

Nothing spectacular. This was the first museum I visited and was rather disappointed. Perhaps I went with an expectation. There's nothing spectacular about this place but worth a visit if you have extra time to kill.

Awesome. Okay, I love taking photos of historic sites and this place is one of my favorites. It is a must see. The ancient historical landmark was built in 1070 and was reconstructed during the Tran dynasty (1225–1400) and in the subsequent dynasties. For nearly two centuries, despite wars and disasters, the temple has preserved ancient architectural styles of many dynasties as well as precious relics. Major restorations have taken place in 1920, 1954 and 2000.
Interesting. This is the first University in Hanoi, built in 1076. Fascinating architecture and quiet haven in a "frantic city"A good place to spend at least an hour looking at "Old" Hanoi
Little dull. Not a great deal to see here, would be improved for English visitors if there was a bit more detail about the school's history.
Very nice gardens with beautiful constructions. Very nice gardens with beautiful constructions. It's a pity not to have some explanations in English.
Beautiful grounds and temple. Amazing that this is where learning took place before there were books, Current students were there taking pictures in their caps and gowns.

Visit to Temple of Literature & National Uni. It was a relaxing visit but signs can be in English to be more informative.
In general, the visit was ok.
Serene. This is a pleasant diversion from the bustle of the Old Quarter and the blatent politics of the Mausoleum complex. Peaceful, it is a reminder of the antiquity of the culture.

"Study or die". was printed on the t-shirt of a group leader for a school field trip we encountered during our visit. sums it up! this was my fave attraction in Hanoi and i bet a lot of people's top choice as well judging by the large crowds. we witnessed a family who set up offerings at one of the stelae for their ancestor. the grounds are well manicured and the buildings are very lovely. tho busy, it was somehow also peaceful.

Fabulous architecture. I came to the Temple with some friends, and felt terrible that I have lived here for 6 months, and had not been to the temple yet. It is a beautiful space, with amazing architecture. Definitely worth a visit.

Peaceful and pretty temples. Peaceful gardens, ponds and temples. Keep going all the way to the end to see the final temple. I think some people didn't realize you have to go around the edge of the second to last temple to see the final temple.

Better with a tour guide. It's a very nice place full of history and culture. If you walk around you'll see signs with lots of info, unfortunately without translation. Definitely better to have someone able to explain and talk you through the history of this place.
ok to see. It is a nice location, but far to many people. Its ok to go there if you have lots of time, but no "must see".

Our favorite temple in Vietnam . This temple is different from the others we visited during our 4 day stay. The temple seemed to be "alive", it had energy. The turtles of knowledge on the way up to the temple were fascinating, just to understand the history behind the stone statutes were worth the trip. The temple itself was beautiful and had details in every corner, ensure you take the time to enjoy this temple, you will not be disappointed.

Do not leave Hanoi without visiting. It is one of the best historical places we visited in Hanoi. Do not have to add lots of comments, but beside all the other things do not forget to visit the 82 tortle-carrying stele, (originally 117), which list the names, places of birth and achievements of 1,306 exceptional good graduates

the buildings and artefacts are beautiful. I really enjoyed this vist especially Learning the history with a very knowledgeable guide arranged by Buffalo Tours. The Temple of literature is a wonderful historical monument to the development of Vietnamese society.

The don't build them like this anymore. The Temple of Literature has always been a university, and one of the coolest things to see is the courtyard ringed by stone blocks with the names of all the graduates from the Temple. At the very back, there is a large building with statues of Confucius, the founder of the Temple of Literature, and two other scholars that were important to the temple. Worth seeing.

A beautiful Confucius Temple, also worth seeing the students there. My friend and I visited on a recent sunny day. It has beautiful architecture and it is interesting to watch the schoolchildren and recent graduates having their photo sessions. Well worth the visit, but probably a good idea to avoid the most touristy times of the day.
A cultural must do. Well preserved Vietnamese architecture with 5 courtyards divided by walls. It was the site of Vietnams first university.

Well worth a visit. This we found very interesting especially with a guide who explained how, when and what. One of the better places to visit with its "Chinese" style temple and the statues of Confucious and his disciples.

Interesting but.... I would love to visit this site when it is quieter. Today, it was just way too busy-- big school groups, masses of other tourists, too many tour guides and masses of tourist tat on sale. All of this detracted immensely from what could have been a much more interesting experience. I recognise the irony of a tourist (like me) complaining about tourists but being part of a mass wandering around an important site is just not appealing or interesting
Surprisingly barren, but informative. A succinct account of educational history of the city and vietnam. Confucius actually lectured here briefly. Worth a look.

It says it all. Standing through centuries as a university, the temple is a perfect representation of what Hanoi and norther Vietnam is. It was indeed a wide campus of heritage, history, literature, and Viet architecture.

Beautiful site. If you are in hanoi this is something you really need to see. It is full of history and it's like going back in time. The building itself is magnificent and imposing and can help you understand how ancient Vietnamese used to live and study. It is a must do and you will not regret it

Academia Through the Ages!. How perfect that the day we were in this majestic temple and place of academia, there would be a graduating class on site ! The class of 2015 satisfied the yearning to anticipate and acknowledge the vitality of the institution for centuries. I agree that the temple is certainly the most beautiful in Hanoi. When you get to the beautiful space celebrating the Confusianism- proceed around behind it and you will come to a large open space and beyond that another temple(this next part is easy to miss)This is certainly worth the visit and a wonderful place to wander!!!
a must go to .... visite the first university of Vietnam.You can also observe young vientnamese student that have just graduated that come to take photos with there wonderful traditional dresses.
mix of history and culture. it was interesting to see the young people taking photos of themselves in the traditionnal garment for their graduating

Best with a guide. You need your guide to gain a better understanding of all you see here. It is a beautiful commemoration of the scholars of Confuscious and of latterday rulers - esseniall thiose who passed the civil service examinations of their day. Attractive and enjoyable.

Excellent - especially for a couple of academics!. So nice to see a scholarship board dating to the 15th century! We teach at a University so it was great to see how universal the desire for an education is. Really well maintained and interesting.

It's nice, but nothing more. Considering this is one of the biggest tourist attractions in Hanoi I was slightly let down by it. It's nice enough to walk around, but you'll probably spend about half an hour in there and that's it. For a smaller entrance fee we spent half a day in the Millitary Museum...As a visitor you don't experience the importance of the place as much as the locals.

Go with a guide!. Beautiful and interesting temple which was the seat of Vietnam's first university. To get the most out of a visit you really need a guide - we went with 'Hanoikids' and they were brilliant.

A brilliant insight. The architecture of the complex is phenomenal, We took a guide and found it very informative.The temple is directed towards Confucianism and the grounds, gardens, statues and buildings are beautifully maintained.To put this place into perspective, it was built in 1070, 26 years before the first crusades.

Historic and Cultural. This, being the first university in Vietnam, is greatly influenced by Confucius and rightly so as he was one of the greatest scholar ever lived. Therefore, a good mix of Chinese and local culture through the years.
Exquisite temple. The most beautiful Temple in Hanoi. Rich in history and visual pleasure. It was buzzing with people when we visited, but retained its magic and glory.

Got insights while visiting this. I gained some important insights while visiting this place which is devoted to Confucianism. It features in the form of Chinese characters through flowers the six virtues which were supposed highly espoused by Confucians: Benevolence, Morality, Trust, Ability, Justice and Intelligence. These vary somewhat from the traditional five virtues given by Confucius. I was struck by the inclusion of Ability (才）in the list because this too is important in life.

Very interesting and not to passed by. We were lucky as we had guide who was excellent. The history and tradition is intriguing. The hawkers at the entrance are persistent and a nuisance but that should not deter. It was humbling to observe other tourists praying without them or others being selly conscious

very interesting cultural visit. architecture and long story of the temple which has been built in 1070 for students of high level. as the place is divided in 5 different quarters many visitors can visit easily at same time

Temple of Literature a haven from the Hanoi hubbub. I've visited the Temple of Literature at least three times now, and I enjoy it each time. The grounds and gardens are stunning, and it is a nice way to relax and get away from the intense energy that characterizes the city. While it's usually teeming with tourists, the grounds are large enough to accommodate that and still offer some peace and quiet. It is a very interesting place, documenting the rise of Confuscianism. Informative signs are in English, French and Vietnamese. Be sure to take in the two Craft Link stores across the street - they feature items made from the 58 traditional tribes of Vietnam, such as lacquer and weaving, and some of the proceeds go to support these artisans.

Nice place. This is a place worth a visit but make sure you have a guide to explain what you are seeing. When we went there were several classes of local schoolchildren being given a lecture and clearly not listening but waving and smiling at the tourists
Worth seeing. I was impressed by this place. Doesn't take long to see, but well worth it, better to have a guide to give information. Interesting

Seeing is believing. Over 1000 years old(most of it) and still standing! WOW!!Of historical importance , but it brings up. Conundrum , WHY is CHINESE script on the gates???Makes one think, ..Vietnamese ----CHINESE ??Length of Visit time, is dependant upon the visitor, some long, some short, depends.Beware of large number of tourists , local/foreign !

Ode to Confucious and education. Site of the Vietnamese university built around 1000 AD. Wonderful to see on its own but also interesting to note the reverence of the Vietnamese and the Chinese tourists who visit. Must see.

Worth a Visit. Hanoi in itself is not very big, one can do sightseeing and accomplish a lot in a day. Temple of Literature is not very big, it's worth a visit then move on to other sites such as Ho Chi Minh Complex and Museum of Ethnology. Best to consider day trips outside Hanoi to see something ultimately different.

Great history. The Temple of Literature was a wonderful place to visit. Being immersed in the history of the National University and learning about Confucius allows you a good glimpse of the culture. We visited as part of a city tour so we were lucky to have the added bonus of our tour guide giving us his own insights and injecting his own life experiences.

Interesting. While there, they were preparing for a poet exhibition the next few days, so we were lucky to preview exhibits being set up from outside villages as well as from Hanoi. Beautiful and relaxing place to spend some time.

Worth an hour or two of time. I had a limited amount of time but was able to visit the highlights of this incredibly beautiful grounds. The english pamplet was worth the extra cost as it had lots of information and explanation. Signage was in veitnamese/english and well produced.

A bit underwhelming. My expectations where high when I set out for the Temple of Literature as I had read some wonderful things about the site. I was a bit underwhelmed after walking the grounds and looking at the buildings. My husband and I had already seen some fantastic sites in Vietnam and I guess the reality is that they can not all be stellar. If you are only in Hanoi for a short time I would recommend seeing the National Museum of Vietnamese History, The Museum of Ethnology, Vietnam Fine Arts Museum and the Hoa Lo Prison Museum first.

Beautiful complex. A quiet haven in the middle of the hustle and bustle. Beautiful temple complex with interesting details about the first university of Vietnam. Well worth the visit. Beautiful bonsai strangler-fig trees - amazing!
The first univesity. The Temple of Literature ( Văn Miếu ) was built in 1070. Students from High School or universtiy in Việt Nam always come here to pray especially Lunar New Year.
Loved it!. Beautiful and culturally informative. Lots of graduation students having their pictures taken in traditional outfits.

Lovely Grounds. The Temple of Literature is a lovely place to visit, with landscaped grounds that are well-kept. It is a bit annoying that people smoke everywhere, but when there is a breeze it's not that bad. The inside of the worship area is calm, peaceful and much cooler than the outside areas. I've been to the Temple of Literature multiple times, and will return again because it does have a sense of peace within its walls.

Temple of Literature and National University. A classic example of Vietnam architecture of the ester era. It is so well maintained, the gardens are beautiful, the flower decorations with motifs were attractive. the stone plates with inscription of various subjects are grand. Even the stalls for sale of souvenirs looked like exhibits themselves. An photographrs paradise. what to shoot and what not to shoot was always the question.

Knowledge is Power.... "Study the past if you would define the future" - Confucius. In this day and age we are still learning from the teachings of the Great Philospher, Confucius. Visiting this landmark was a magical experience for me. It abounds itself in history. I had no idea that the Vietnamese were so 'big' on Confucius but then I guess with the Chinese influence one can expect this. It is interesting to note that as we were visiting there, many younsters were in and out making their wishes to the Great Philospher for knowledge. The temple is beautiful and the statues of Confucius and his disciples, if I may call them that, was most beautiful. The grounds are neat. There are a few stalls where one can purchase books, chains etc. Whilst we were inside the building, two beautiful women played the traditional instruments to the most soothing sounds of traditional Vietnamese music. It's worth the visit if you are in Hanoi - why not as I think most of us know who Confucius is.

Mixed Original Style with Modern until the present. Second time to visit here, first university of vietnam Building still conserve for people to learning history of the past.The teaching caring on the turtle's back is the one of memory of the world from announce by UNESCO.

Overrated tourist spot. I disliked everything: the toilets are dirty. The people are rude. The place was overcrowded because of students coming to have photos (people over there are obsessed with photos of themselves) with fake diplomas and fake graduation robes they rent a the gate. It looks like the place is not well maintained in spite of the collected entrance fees.

Beautifully maintained building. Loved the building and the history. Grounds are well kept. I did not like that I was expected to pay to go to the toilet. You have to pay to enter the grounds and then an extra fee for the toilet ????

Temple of Literature & Nat. University. This is a most interesting attaction but it is important to understand the history behind it and the way it functions. It is Vietnam's first university and its teachings are related to Confuscious. To get the best value from a visit, a guide is recommended.

Temple of Confucius, the God of Learning. Dedicated to the Chinese Philosopher the Temple depicts how much value Learning and Education carries.Its a very interesting Temple with several gates leading to the main Temple and beautiful gardens and fabulous Architecture.The main Temple where the Statue of Confucius is installed is simply divine.Many Vietnamese follow Confucianism as their faith in addition to Buddhism.Highly recommended for a few hours visit preferably along with a Guide.
it's a very good temple. we enjoyed going around this temple..... Don't miss visiting this beautiful temple. it is like a forbidden city in Beijing

Not what I expected. The temple is a site of great learning over centuries, with many areas of interest and that still hold great significance for students today, who still visit and pray for success with their studies. Recommend having a local guide, as there are many surprising aspects to this temple. Not what I expected at all. Enjoyable way to spend and hour or so.

A quiet oasis in a city of traffic and noise. Interesting place with a temple and stones from the past. You can complete the visit in less than 45 minutes and you need a guide to give you information - amazingly a lovely quiet and green spot in a very noisy, bustling and vibrant city!
Lovely place to visit. A MUST if you are planning to visit Hanoi. It is fascinating; it's history and current tribute to wisdom-literature, knowledge and spirituality.

Interesting Historical site. The temple of literature provided an interesting look into the history of higher education in Vietnam, especially the importance of Confucianism. I thought the most interesting part was the carvings of the names of graduates, many of which were very old. The temple itself was very pretty as well. I didn't have a guide, but had a good time anyway. Though if you are looking to get more specific information on the various aspects of the temple it might be good to get one.

A must-see in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is a must-see during your trip to Hanoi. It is fascinating; it's history and current tribute to wisdom-literature, knowledge and spirituality. The statues are beautiful as are the courtyards.

Very interesting - but hire a guide for the full experience (5 stars). Visited the Temple of Literature during Tet (2015), and it was a great visit. To understand the history, I recommend getting a guide to explain the history of the temple. The information on site is not that informative in my opinion.Well worth a visit - highly recommendable with a guide.

Temple of Literature. This is History! The Temple of Literature was founded in the year 1070, and was dedicated to the Chinese Philosopher, CONFUCIOUS.In 1076, it became Vietnam's 1st University. An archeological study has found that the majority of the site belongs to Ly (1010-1225) and Tran (1225 - 1400), it really is very old. There are side passages between the five courtyards, and these were used by Royalty who entered through the main gate, and students had to enter via the side passage ways. The open pavillions in the courtyards were used for students to study. The 1st two courtyards are mainly gardens and trees, with the third courtyard being taken up by a large pond called 'The Well of heavenly clarity" On either sides, there are pavillions with steles which are sitting on top of a large Tortoise. These steles honour the schools successful doctorate candidates. The next courtyard is the Sage courtyard which is paved and has buildings on three sides.
