Here, is the "great house of ceremonies " and inside is a large lacquered statue of Confucious. The last courtyard is Thai Hoc, and here you find the large Drum and Bell Tower.We visited here on a city tour, and this made it all the more interesting as we were told the details of all we were looking at.It is open Tuesday to Sunday from 7.30 to 6 pm (8 am to 5 pm from November to March

Precious monument. There is a temple at the inner grounds where many Vietnamese belief one could excel in studies after praying at the temple. Worth a visit & a short walk away from old quarters or Hoan Kiem lake.

Interesting. A good place to visit if you have a guide. It would have been of limited interest without one. There was a poetry completion on whilst we were there so there were lots of local people in there regional costumes which was interesting. (Did not stay for the poetry)

nice quiet place, interesting. Had a guide who explained the history of the place which made it very interesting. They had a group playing their traditional instruments inside, which was entertaining. The place has a very peaceful atmosphere and can get some nice pictures. One can spend about an hour going through the place. Nice bit of history and nice place to visit.
Very busy but lovely place to visit. As it was New Year it was a busy place but still a must to go visit. Very spiritual and interesting to learn about their culture. Entry is only about $1.00

Beautiful temples and grounds. Really enjoyed our visit. Spent about 2 hours here with our student guide and really enjoyed walking the beautiful park like setting and the temples. Our guide pointed out lots of examples of the Ying/Yang symbolism used throughout the sites buildings and landscape.I didn't see any signs in English so might be best to come with a guide or bring a travel book.I think this is one of the must see sites in Hanoi.

See this place if you have time in the afternoon. After a tiring days hectic schedule I visited this place and relaxed here. If you really want to learn a few basic things its better of you search the internet and read the history of it before visiting or to save you the time reading through the literature you may hire a guide. Its not expensive. Some 20-30 USD will be enough to get you a guide

Beautiful Peaceful Space in the midst of chaos. I fell in love with this amazing space. The temple grounds are generally filled with University Students and Tourists but if you go early you can enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. There are lots of gates and little ponds to check out and tours for a fee but you will learn loads about the city and the space. It is the most beautiful temple in the city by far - we spent a solid hour inside checking everything out. There are loads of photogenic spots. :-)

Very interesting.... If you have the time to visit I would...very interesting place with great photo opportunities. Great temple at the end of several areas you walk through to get there. A guide is recommended as not many signs explain everything in English, however, I did hear several different stories about the same items from two different guides...so may be go with a recommendation from your hotel.

Must see in Hanoi. This precious monument is well worth a visit. Anyone who is ever been to university will marvel at the scerenity of this temple complex, and how it must have been an extraordinary experience to study Confuscianism here. If at all possible, avoid the days when Vietnamese families celebrate graduations, as it can get very busy.

Best sight in Hanoi. To make the most of your visit either go with a guide or armed with a good guidebook. Wikipedia has a good detailed description of the different areas of the temple, which is a complex structure with several courtyards. Without some of this information it is difficult to understand the purpose of each area. On a simpler level, there is a peaceful garden with Interesting topiary in the middle of a very busy city.
Learning Curve. We enjoyed this learning experience showing the background of the Vietnamese history. Unfortunately rushed through by tour guide.

Lots of history. You definitely want to visit this place with a guide as there really aren't enough signs to explain everything that is there. And I recommend reading a bit on the internet as I learned a whole lot more once I got home and did some reading on-line. There is a lot to see and would take some time to absorb it all. However, if you just want to go in and look and not mosey you could be in and out in <1hr. When we were there, there were a lot of graduating classes in their caps and gowns having their graduation pictures taken. That was pretty neat to see all the kids and their excitement. It was very unique and unlike anything else I saw on my 9 day trip in Vietnam.

A Look Back in Time. This is the oldest university in the country and housing a variety of ancient relics depicting the influence of Confucius and Chinese culture. A lot of tourists do come and visit this place so it is a bit challenging to take photos and explore the place.
Interesting. This is an interesting place to visit. Our guide was able to give us so much information. My tip would be to have a guide.

Old school in vietnam. This place is nice and so much student coming here for education meeting right.when you coming here you can take photograp a lot ofyou can buy some souvernia stay here with so much kind of souvernia with Price is good

Interesting place. Though by busy roads, the Temple of Literature is a quiet place. Once inside the main gate one forgets Hanoi's chaotic traffic. A walkway through green lawns and courtyards leads to this temple dedicated to Confucius.The temple itself is bright and colourful. Here too is the Imperial Academy. Stellae with names of academicians stand atop turtles, the inscriptions now almost wiped out. There are some amazing bonsai here, as also intricate incense burners.As always in Vietnam, it helps to have a good guide who can explain things and put them in perspective.

counture. nice place in hanoi.This place is the firt univercity in viet nam.we see so many student come here for lucky time.I thing this place bring to us lucky time the same,and foer you the same.Recommend to you.
Lots of history. Worth seeing more for the historical background than for the buildings. Gives you an idea of how Chinese culture permeates their thinking even though they want to be independent.
Beautiful Site. Wonderful place for a relaxed stroll and a bit of a break from the intense Ha Noi traffic and street noise.

Confucius said. This is place is worth a visit. It is a place of tranquility in busy vietnam. It's great to see that some people decided to educate the general population and that they haven't been forgotten with their efforts. The site is great and with many information about life at that time. Get a guide to further your knowledge but you can go on your own and explore. The last building is the most interesting one. It has many boards that you can read.

interesting. we visited this on our first day. It is a beautiful setting with wonderful gardens to stroll through. There was actually an awards ceremony going that day so it was interesting to see this culture in full swing.

If you pass give it a go........ Went to this and thought ther would be more. Sadly, it's kinda not very much there, it's really cheap to get in, but out the way from anything else, so you have to make am special trip and it was very hot when we went.That's not to say it not good, it gives you all they i story about it being the first University of it kind and is interesting but its over in half an hour.

A Must See. A place of tranquility and an amazing atmosphere - aided by the many graduates beautifully dressed up and celebrating. So very sad to learn that this oldest university in the world had suffered bomb damage from the United States during the Vietnam war and had had to have extensive repairs.

Not particularly impressed, but don't skip. I was told this was one of the most important locations in Hanoi, so I went. Twice. At first by myself, but upon realizing that I had zero clue what anything was, I came back at a later date with a guide.It's a nice little place with history behind it, but there isn't much to see or to be impressed by. The first time I visited, I was asking myself why this was a major attraction in Hanoi. Not much explanation as to the importance of the temple. When the guide explained things, I got a much better understanding, but I still found it only mildly interesting.I recommend either coming with a guide, or reading up on the history behind the temple before visiting.

The ancient University of Hanoi. Now almost 1000 years old, the Temple of Literature was set us as a University, and although its original wooden buildings have by now all decayed away, the modern ones have been built as replicas of this, on the original layout. A peaceful place, and it's lovely to wander there for an hour or two.
Nice place. Nice gardens at the entrance, few tourist shops inside, live music is played at the main university's hall, and few unique statues are placed around.

The museum of literature. This museum was totally enchanting and its history fascinating.it was very interesting to see the stones with the exams of the most brilliant students and to read about the emperor that created it.
BEautiful!. This is a must see if you are in Hanoi. Amazing histoyry and beautiful setting. It helps you understand the main religion before buddisum in Vietnam.

Small Little Literature temple. I am a Chinese Singaporean and I think this temple is too small and not much history to visit. The ticket lady cashier cheated us the entrance fee by giving less changes of money as We are not familiar to use Dong currency. Please check your change properly as the q is quite long and hot while waiting. I didn't take photo as I find a lot more better and pretty temple in most asia country.
Good value!. A little bit culture is always good! nice place, but not amazing and very very cheap entrace. if you are in Hanoi and have enough time, you must go.

Proof of old Vietnam. This is beautiful quiet oasis in the middle of the hustle sand bustle of Hanoi.The oldest University from 1067.Well preserved with special honor chiselled in stone ,oldest from 1463.Different and a worthwhile visit.Try it

Nice temple complex, but nothing special. The Temple is in a fairly large complex with gardens and a number of buildings.The temples are quite nice, very busy with tourists and local school trips so it does not feel very peaceful.The overall complex is kept well, but not great and it feels as if it lacks something, so whilst enjoyable I do not think is memorable (especially if you have visited temple complex in Japan).Ticket price is very cheap (30,000 VND), but you are likely to need a taxi to get there

Impressively well preserved. The temple originally dedicated to Confucius in 1070 later became a university for the education of the upper classes. It is a lovely site, quite large, and you could spend some time looking around. Impressive statue of the 'Venerable Headmaster' and 82 stelae honouring the men who had received doctorates in the period 1442-1484. Huge drum and gong which both used to be sounded to call the boys to their classes.

Well worth the visit. Great history. beautifully preserved early university,Many strange things made me think of an oriental" hogwart's"Very busy at weekends ( but hanoi is busy always) but particularly with families,
Very good. Had been here since i was in sophomore. The place had its own traditional and historical marks. This place is very essential part if you want to know about Vietnamese history.
Gorgeous temple to Confucius. To think this is the site of the first university in Vietnam ( 1106 AD) is impressive. Beautifully rebuilt pavilions in a lovely garden setting.

Really nice and interesting buildings. This is definitely worth seeing if you're in Hanoi. It's Vietnam's oldest university so it is steeped in history and that is evident from the very traditional-looking buildings. The outdoor area is beautiful with very well-kept gardens and fountains. Inside there is a small museum with artefacts and a little about the history of the university. Really interesting and absolutely worth a visit.

An ancient proof of civilization. A university started in 1067, where the academicians were honoured by having their cur vit chiselled on tombstones, and some of the emperors questioned them in their examination.
Very good. The First university of Vietnan, really well preserved and great to see. The building is really restful though busy, and calmer than the rest of Hanoi
Tranquil and interesting. Very important site to visit amid the hustle and bustle of the city. Very well maintained. Beautiful architecture.

No signs in English.... Surprisingly underwhelmed by my visit to the Temple of Literature. It's a peaceful place and a nice break from the busy streets of Hanoi but there are no signs or information posted in English. It's 30,000 dong to enter. You would be smart to do research before coming so you know what you are seeing. Disappointing "historical" destination-- as it was impossible for anyone that wasn't Vietnamese speaking to learn anything.

Interesting place. We went there with our tour guide. She explained a lot about the history of this temple. They maintained the place well. And I really enjoyed working around the place while trying to imagine how they studied in that place long time ago.

Beautiful spot . The temple was interesting, there is signage around in both Vietnamese and English which was helpful in understanding about the temple and different courtyards. Gardens were beautiful. A word of warning for those who are disabled or a little shaky on their feet. The stones were quite slippery and uneven and there are steps up and down between each courtyard. When I visited an older man with a walking stick was having difficulty staying balanced because of the slipperiness and unevenness of the stones. I enjoyed visiting here, it was quite peaceful

Peaceful place. We've really enjoyed walking around the university, all the buildings are full of history and the whole place is very quiet/peaceful.Highly recommended if you have the chance to stop over.

A Breath of Fresh Air in Hanoi. This was a lovely place to walk with friends in Hanoi. A bit of history, yes --- but it was most enjoyable as a simple, peaceful place to walk --- refreshing, envigorating.
Lovely Architecture. This is a must-see if you just want the flavor of the city. Well-preserved temples, bonsai, gorgeous flowers.

Have a good guide on hand. The place would be more interesting with a detailed guide book or a very knowledgeable guide. Otherwise, there's not much explanation available for the history buff. It's an interesting place to walk around and can get very busy.

Good for bonsai !. I was a little underwhelmed by this site. It's pleasantly presented but very little explanation is given in English so you need to relie on your guide. Love the idea that students passing the exam don't get a certificate but rather their names carved in stone ( and erased if they misbehave)
Interesting. It shows the art of vietnamese educational culture and history. Many university students still visit this place to pray for getting a passing mark on their upcoming their exams.
Quiet, away from the noise. Great historical significance at this temple..take your time and see it all. then sit and enjoy the peace.

Quiet and Serene but the Stone Turtles have attitude. This is a great place to get a sense of old Vietnam. We opted for an English-speaking guide which was a good thing as captions for the exhibits limited indeed. Check out the stone settas at the front -- each of the turtles are carved differently and some have real attitude.

Temple, well more like a monument to Literature. The day I went here it was a National poetry day and there was entertainment on show. The students released balloons and it was packed. Very interesting to see an alter to confuscious

Grounds as pretty as the temple!. This temple is very Chinese in feel and there are layers of gates leading up to the center where there is a large statue and altar to Confucius. It was an academy for training and testing scholars and dates back to 1070. Colorful spiritual geometric banners line the exterior walkways.

Examination Hall. Visited the temple on women's day and was surprised how many parents brought their daughters to the temple and offered their prayers that the next generation of women be knowledgeable. This is not only a peaceful place, but offers a real insight into the heart and mind of Vietnamese people. If you don't want a guide it is worthwhile to buy the booklet for 8000 VD (it's 40 cents come on) and you understand the whole background. This kind of exination halls are presently being revived in China. But they lack all the atmosphere of this temple. So enjoy it and be thankful to see a place where women are encouraged to pursue knowledge:-)
This was very interesting. A very interesting and informative tour. It was good to learn about the value placed on learning in an historical context.

Peaceful area in the heart of the city. beautifully restored, and so worth while to understand more of the history and culture of Vietnam. the gardens were artfully planted, and the exhibits very open
Invaluable showcase of Vietnamese culture and tradition. Invaluable showcase of Vietnamese culture and tradition. A must see if you want a better understanding of Vietnamese way of life then and now

Old university. It look like chinese temple for me. It shows the art of vietnamese culture and history. Beware of swindler, I bought a card for souvenir and they tricked me that switch between 50,000 and 500,000 dong for exchange.

A must-see destination for your Vietnam family tour. The Temple of Literature is often cited as one of Hanoi’s most picturesque tourist attractions. Originally built as a university in 1070 dedicated to Confucius, scholars and sages, the building is extremely well preserved and is a superb example of traditional-style Vietnamese architecture.

Interesting temple.. The temple was interesting and tells history of early Vietnam before colonization. Many university students still visit this place to pray for getting a passing mark on their upcoming their exams.

Historical, interesting, getting reading for New Year's.. We visited this historic Temple of Literature and National University. It was worth taking a look at the gardens and we enjoyed listening to the musical performers. We did have a guide for the day and that made this more interesting because not all displays are English friendly.

Busy during Tet. Good Guides.. My wife and I toured the Temple of Literature (with the amazing Hanoi Kids). It's very important to have a guide. It was very busy during the Tet New Year celebrations.
There was so much going on. FULL ON. Crowds, displays, features.
We were lucky. I can only comment on a good day. And it was GOOD!
Oldest University in Hanoi. Beautiful temple and an assortment of buildings and gardens to wander through. They even had a Bell Tower and a Drum Tower.

Nice and crowded place. We visited during TED holidays and there were lot and lots of people, mostly family. They were praying for exams (i guess) and writing prosperous Chinese/Vietnamese letters for new year. good time to visit even though lots of people queue for tickets. Nice experience. You can read history of the temple on the wall near entrance if you don't have a guide. easy to go there and everyone knows the place.

Peace in the City. This is a beautiful and interesting Temple complex dedicated to learning. The temple buildings, some of which have been rebuilt are quite impressive with a series of courtyards. A Quiet place in the centre of Hanoi.

Very old, but not very informative. A very old, Chinese based scholar compound. However, nothing was in English, so we left not fully informed. If you really wanted to maximize your experience, probably best to get a guide.

Thousand Year Old Confucian U.. This is really a university set up for the teaching of confucian philosophy and thought. Successful graduates became part of the ruling class. It is interesting to see, especially the stone tablets that recorded hundreds of names of graduates over scores of years. Worth a visit.

Historically interesting, but nothing mind-blowing. This temple was said to be one of the places dedicated to the study of Confucianism. It's a pleasant walk with some nice sights, but there was nothing really exceptional about it, especially if you've already seen temples and pagodas in China or other countries before.
Worth visiting. An interesting place and worth a visit. Loved the turtle steles. Spend a bit of relaxing time wandering the garden.

interesting enough. Interesting enough if passing by however not worth going far out of your way to see. Fairly small with nothing all tat special to see. Still pretty neat how old of a university it was.
Confucius. Step inside the Temple of Literature, originally Vietnam's first university, dedicated to Confucius. Thought provoking.

worth a look. This university Confucian temple is worth a quick visit. Entrance fee is 30,000 Dong. There are 2 big inner courts. When we visited they were setting up for a poetry conference.
It's difficult to make out the surface of the "steeles". Overall it's a little different than most of the temples.

the ever first university. the idea of listing all people that passed the various exams on stone plate, standing on the back of a stone turtle(symbol of wiasdom) is fascinating. the evidence that the emperor employed learned staff in those old times is quite outstanding. The temple is very appealing, with a very nice garden, 2 ponds and a lot of colorful flowers.

Fascinating. You must go with a guide to get the full depth of understanding of this significant historical site. We were very lucky to have gone there soon after Tet, which is when many ceremonies take place to worship ancestors. Education has been important in Vietnamese culture for centuries. A must se when in Hanoi.

Tour. Went there with Hanoi Kids amazing place with all of the history dating back to 1042 which from an Australian point of view is hard to get your head around as Austarlia was only discovered in 1788.

A Beautiful Experience. We visited here as part of a scooter tour. It was really interesting. The Oldest University in Vietnam and there were a lot of things happening on the day we visited. University Candidates were photographed as were Primary School children heading into their High School Years. They have the photos taken before their final results are known, so I guess that's a bit of pressure to perform well! The old University buildings, the interiors, the history, the surrounds, gardens etc also made it a very worthwhile visit.

Temple of Literature and National University. My visit here was limited to the exterior only. Most of the tourist do the same. The old bonsai trees are outstanding if one appreciates what it takes to grow a bonsai tree. We were lucky that we were in Hanoi during the New Year celebration. Everything was so festive,flowering trees ,potted mums,paper decorative banners etc. The grounds are well maintained and clean.
Not what you think it is?. Parts of this shrine have been rebuilt very well.Very popular with locals and tourists.Read up about the site before you get there as there are no signs to explain things.
Unique historical site. You learn how Chinese culture & Confucianism influenced Vietnam's history. Better to have a tour guide.

Mediocre and rebuilt in 2000 . Generally speaking main attractions in Hanoi are few and not really worth to visit, but this one seemed to be the best in town. Advertised as ancient and unique, what you get is mostly a new building from 2000 and many shops selling bargains (plus some writers in Chinese style). Besides the two ponds in the complex are completely abandoned and dirty. Not to mention how crowdy it is. At least the old teacher turtle shaped graves are interesting to see.Entry fee is cheap.
Worth a quick visit. Inexpensive to enter - very interesting to learn about the early scholars of Hanoi, nice to see so many young school groups visiting and hopefully praying for good marks!
An ordinary temple. There's not much that you must see at this temple. Certainly it still retains certain cultural value due to its history.
info about Confucius. An oasis of calm and learning, the first university in Vietnam. Lots of information in English, no guide necessary. Within walking distance of the Old Quarter.

History of Vietnamese Education. It was showering the day we had been to the University of Literature but it was packed by students who had just graduated from nearby institutions on a photo session at this historical site. Groups of students, smartly dressed, smiling with dreams were just about everywhere making our visit well worth it.Taking a stroll in the ancient University our guide narrated a history of the site. Every section in it is remarkably maintained and preserved and it was pretty much impressive to know the history of Vietnamese education.A must visit place.

An oasis in a busy city. Very relaxing area full of history of the first university. Lot of information on the boards which are in Vietnamese, French and English.Well worth a visit, if only to relax a bit in an oasis of (relative) calm

Incorporate visit with Koto restaurant for a good cause . Suggest a visit before or after lunch at Koto restaurant ( opposite)which provide training for under privilege youth . Need to know Chinese Culture to appreciate the teaching of Confucius , a Chinese Great Philosopher . Consider a social contribution as the entrance fee is 30,000 Dong
Absolutely packed. It was the last day of Tet holiday and it seemed as though everyone in Hanoi was there. There was some interesting dragon dancing going on, worth going just to see that.

Very charming place where you can find the trace of the old Vietnam. Love the calm and charm of this historical place. I like all the monuments and the big trees there. Love also the little shows that they perform on regular base complimentary.But some of the new restoration is too much.

A thousand year old building dedicated to education. Absolutely gorgeous buildings, with some great exhibits inside. The quality and skill of the topiary garden is unbelievable. Great, quiet atmosphere when there isn't a local field trip planned here.

nice afternoon stroll. Beautiful temple with great architecture and history, worth the nominal admission price for a great afternoon (expect to spend 2). The grounds are expansive with nice landscaping and old wood temples and prayer sites. We didn't have high expectations but were pleasantly surprised, would definitely recommend to our friends. We didn't have a guide and still enjoyed ourselves; well-educated 30s -40s here. Bathroom facilities available here, cost $1000 dong to use (5cents)

Probably need a guide next time.... Beautiful temple however we went without a guide and found it quite difficult to know what the significance was. There are not many English signage so apart from admiring the architectural beauty and some nice gardens and a bit about confuscianism (3 or 4 panels to read), we weren't too sure what the fuss was about. Perhaps we should have got a guide or read more about it before we came... I guess it's worth seeing though as everyone else has raved about it?

Super Busy On This New Years Holiday. Well worth visiting and seeing the parade of students and parents making offerings in the hope of success in study on this really busy day at this Temple. It was unusually busy so didn't really get to wander aimlessly taking it all in but it was interesting and worth the visit anyway.

Helps to understand Vietnamese History.. It has beautiful gardens and water features around the different buildings. The most important thing is to listen the history to get an overview of Hanoi culture. The Temple was the first University for the sons of mandarins. It was a very strict education with high standards. I really enjoyed this site and recommend to visit..

A nice place to visit if you have time. We were disappointed by the Temple, which is small and lacking in good signage in English. If you have time, you could visit, but also could give it a miss without missing much.
Meh!. If you have lots and lots of time and love this sort of place come here. If not avoid! It's far from the most impressive place in Hanoi and being quite small makes it feel even more busy.
Piece of history. Great to get away from the traffic and craziness that is Hanoi...beautiful grounds, historical writings and educational.

A City Oasis. In this hectic city, one of the most charming finds was this enclosed park and temple, with gracious landscaping and connecting plazas and water features. We sat and strolled, enjoying the concept of a park dedicated to books.
Don't bother. There was really very little to see here. i wouldn't recommend it as there were so many other things in Hanoi which were much better to visit.

Tranquil grounds. The Temple of Literature is comprised of gently crumbling structures and quiet gardens. All in all, a very picturesque spot evoking a mystical history. The present may intrude in a most welcome manner, as it did for us, with a beautiful model in traditional dress posing for her photographer before the fountains.

Great cultural experience. This was a great stop on our trip! The temple and university are beautiful, and the guides are beautiful and knowledgeable. Make sure you get a guide. The music demonstrations ae wonderful.
Beautiful area. There was a lot of renovations while I was there, so the beauty was obstructed, but still nice. It's a great place for photos with great architecture.

hanoi City tour. we went to the Temple of Literature as part of a Hanoi city tour. We saw students that had just graduated & they looked lovely & we're very friendly. It wasn't very special but we enjoyed looking around & the shops in there were very good with nice staff & value for money goods. Pleased we went as part of the tour.

Its not a library. This temple was very beautiful and a great stop if your wandering around Hanoi for the day. Easy to walk to from the Old Quarter, and close to a lot of other good sites. I would recommend going during a week day, it can get very crowed with local events(graduations, weddings, etc).

Title misleads perhaps.... This ancient temple is lovely and complex. A guide or good guidebook will explain it. But don't expect any books! I loved walking through it and felt it faintly reminiscent of Beijing Forbidden city on very small scale.

More than 1k years in history of the oldest university in Vietnam.. I have been visiting this historical, cultural and educational place since I was a freshman 16 years ago. Sometimes I take my foreign partners to this place to help them relax in a peaceful temple with alot sightseeings outside of the noisy and busy streets. Here we can understand more about Hanoi history, old traditional education system, the doctorate examinations....And I do always suggest them to go to this place whenever there's someone visiting the city.

Just another tourist site. Sorry but I am not that enchanted by museums. If you like museums this would be for you. I would personally prefer to just watch the people living as they are now. However it is a beautiful place to hang out for an hour or two...... Maybe watching the hordes of SE Asian tourists gobble it up. The buildings are great. The gardens are lovely. It doesn't cost much to get in.

Excellent. We really enjoyed our visit here. A good guide is essential (we went with Buffalo Tours) and found it extremely interesting and very beautiful. There is a small entrance fee but the guide covered that. We were lucky the day we went as we saw a group of students graduating from a university. As they were dressed in the traditional outfits it made it really special.

Good visit to understand Vietnam history of academia. Temple is a good visit to gain understanding of the traditions of education in Vietnam. There is a big influence from Confucius and China. Not everything is translated to English, so a good guide would be helpful. Entrance fee is 30000 dong or <$1.50 USD. Vey touristy. Should take 1-2 hours. it is open on Monday unlike most museums.

An interesting place to visit . This was awesome really. I enjoyed it a lot. It was so interesting to learn about how it functioned as a university such a long time ago. It wasn't overly busy either which allowed a more peaceful experience.
disappointing. It is not a temple of literature... and it is a bit disappointing to be frank. It didn't help that i visited it when there was a military ceremony going on.
Well worth it for History lovers. Incredibly interesting despite lots of tourists. Well worth a visit, shouldn't need more than an hour or two to see the entire complex

Calmness in a busy city.. A must whilst in Hanoi. The gardens are beautiful. All you can hear is the noise outside the tranquil area.
A must to have a professional Guide.

A temple of Confucianism . It's picturesque and filled with tourists and tour groups. I think after 45 minutes it was enough.
If you're very interested in Confucianism in Vietnam then you might want to spend more time here and perhaps hire a private guide. Otherwise it's a walk around a nice temple.

Tranquill setting. Enjoyable to wonder around this tranquill temple. Watch out at the gate - we got short changed by 10,000vnd by the operator on the desk. May be it was a human mistake..... Nice garden and some amazing trees and flowers!

Not very intersting. I would give this place a miss it was not very interesting. The only saving grace was the day we visited there were heaps of school kids there who just wanted to smile and say hello.

money well spent. It costs just 20,000 VND to enter (around 60p) & it's a haven of peace & tranquility with ancient buildings & gardens to wander around. In fact, on the day we went there it was graduation day & the students were receiving their certificates & having their photographs taken. It was lovely to see them all in their cap & gowns for their group photos and then the girls took theirs off to reveal their lovely Vietnamese traditional dress underneath. The traditional buildings provided a lovely backdrop. Unfortunately, the magnolia trees were not yet in bloom & likewise the lotus ponds but I can imagine these look stunning later on in the year
Tick off the Hanoi Bucket List. Worth visiting if you have the time but all in all nothing amazing. The area is very relaxing with large open grounds and ponds.

Good impression of a Vietnamese templecomplex. Nice garden with lots of colourfull flowers and lovely bonsai trees. We were here just before the Vietnamese new year, and the building was decorated with blossoms and tangerine trees. You can enter the temple in the back and get a good impression of how they worship and make offerings.
Mum and daughter. Very interesting but lots of tourists. Would have been a lovely tranquil place without all the people
Excellent!. To be good for understanding about Vietnamese education. It opens everyday and we would take the taxi from hotel around 2,5km. I hope you will enjoy the time in this relic.

Just so much to absorbe, facinating. This is a specialised place to visit and you need a guide. You will need translations. There are other wonderful trips to take and you will gain more of an insight into the history of Vietnam.

First University. Its good as far as temples in Hanoi go. Its is interesting in that there is a giant bell, giant drum, and the typical temple items. Its neat to see but, there are better ones in the city and abroad.

Ancient & interesting. This is definitely worth seeing during your time in Hanoi but there isn't much information available inside or in the leaflet so get a good guide book to explain what you're seeing.

Nice place to sit awhile if you can avoid the crowds (but check your change!). Having been to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum I made the short walk to the Temple of Literature and was glad I did. The entrance fee is cheap, but I got short changed when I had to break a big note, so check your change!It's a popular spot with groups of school kids, so sometimes it was better to sit awhile and let them overtake, but this is as good a place as any to do just that. You may also see recent graduates in their garb taking pictures of each other.There's not a huge amount to learn, but it's a nice place to visit and close to the mausoleum so why not?!

Catch the musical performance. Went there on a nun programmed trip. We just walked around Hanoi. We caught a musical presentation at the last building towards the back of the complex. They performed traditional Vietnamese music using traditional instruments. Worth your time to listen to it.

Nice place. But personally, not a must-visit.. Beautiful temple with a nice garden. However, might get packed with students at times. We went there when it was graduation season, too many students to take a good pictures. I did however took great photos of the locals posing in student robes and throwing their mortarboards in the air.
historical. did not know when I went in, had no idea and when I saw i realized what it was . who was confuses and how the education was

Well worth a visit. Vietnamese heritage in full flow here along with info on Confucius. Having travelled from Hanoi to Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) there a quite a few temples of literature, so if you're thinking of doing just one make it this one. The grounds and the buildings are beautiful, well kept but still full of authenticity. When you think you are at the very last building, take a peek behind... we found a lovely wizened Vietnamese man who was an artist - we sat down and had a great Vietnamese art lesson with him (language was no barrier - but a lot of pointing nodding & clapping went on)
great place to learn the history of Vietnam. we spent an hour there but you need half a day to really appreciate the place, we are going back again this year 2015 so I can see more.

Beautiful temple. We visited this attraction and were pleased with the natural beauty and gardens that surrounded the Temple. We enjoyed the architecture and the temple dedicated to the history of Hanoi. Our visit only took about 45 minutes, but more time could be spent if desired. Would highly recommend this attraction.

Beautiful courtyards and inner temple.. Gives a peek into the beginning of Confucius and his followers. An important part of the Vietnamese heritage and culture. Very easy to navigate alone tho I did see some people with personal tour guides which I m sure could make it much more informative. Enjoyed strolling the grounds on our own.
Place To Visit!!!. Went there with wife and two local student guides. A nice place with history and lots of ancient things to see. Worth a visit if you are in Hanoi.

Temple of Literature is a must!. The Temple of Literature is amazing, and definitely must see in Hanoi. The architecture and history of the place, not to mention the gardens, are just beautiful. It is a lovely spot to have a walk around and absorb Hanoi's history without any loud hassle of the city. Highly recommend visiting.
Best historical site in Hanoi. Beautiful place with old palaces and temples. And it helps you understand Chinese influence in medieval Vietnam. Well kept.

Plenty to learn of past kings an educators. Nice grounds, also an opportunity to learn a bit about history before the Vietnam war. Interesting stories about Kings and their treatment of scholars, generals, wives etc... I liked this place

Ancient temple of learning filled with Buddhas, lots of school kids. The first thing you will notice here are the large number of school kids for educational teachings and history. Normally, the top performing students in their class are invited here for ceremonies and recognition.The grounds are filled with beautiful floral displays, bonsai decorations, temples, Buddha’s and lots of figures of dragons on the buildings. We were present as one young group of school kids were being recognized for their scholastic achievements as the proud parents watched in the background. It was quite a structured program. The grounds also have several moats filled with fish and water lilies.
Relaxing and beautiful place. Lovely buildings, gardens and interesting place. It is very peaceful. Chinese influence. Lots going on.
very interesting. Large temple like series of courtyards with water features. Very interesting history, well worth having a guide show you round

Sure, why not. Yes its pretty, you get to see the chinese architecture and influence, but when we went there was not only a photoshoot happening but apparently its a popular place for graduates to go have their photos taken, so it was quite busy. We went because it was close to many attractions, but nothing for you to spend a lot of time in.

interesting historical place. A nice place with well preserved buildings and artifact of a long history of the nation' educational.An good occasion to learn about Vietnamese educational' culture as well as the traditional customs of respecting teachers and professors (you may understand more about the Vietnamese' teacher day).This is a hoot - spot for tourism, if you go alone, make sure to come a bit early (around 8 am), so you won't be disturbed by other crowded and noisy group.
Nice Place. You can do your street fighter-ish photo and video shoot here. The entrance fee is cheap. Very well maintained.

Beware the Cashier Short Changing. The place itself is fascinating and should not be missed.View the grounds, the trees, both large and miniature, and the Confucian shrines.When you pay, count your change very carefully ... I believe that the short changing is quite common. When I asked for the 100,000 dong that the cashier didn't give me, she promptly produced it without blinking an eye.
Van Mieu. A place for a 2 hours-visit, bring you back and to show you how Vietnamese marked the contrubtutions of graduates, thousand years ago.

We spent an interesting couple of hours there. We enjoyed the time spent here. It was also interesting to see about 100 pupils who had just graduated and they were having a group photograph to commemorate the occasion. The gardens and grounds were well kept. The architecture was traditional and the history interesting .

Students were here to celebrate. When I was here, many young uniform students came to visit the temple. Dedicated to Confucio, is a landmark worth to see. The big colored flags symbolizing the nature elements are impressive. The gardens with the animals of the Chinese horoscope and the Chinese words on the walls saying that they were here first...come and see too
Interesting. Great to look around and see the beginnings of Confuscious teachings. We happened to go on the day of graduation, which was so cool to see - all the excitement going around!

Beautiful temple . Very big old temple. You can buy lots of sovenir of Vietnam. Most of the places no English caption available. It is very calm place. But last year, I saw lots of graduates taking photos as a group here. I don't know what was the special day. Please identify that day and visit here. You can see lots of youngsters having fun and photographs ....

great area. this place is nice and so good for have so much for student coming here for takephotograp with so group so nice. they were friendly and help when we coming to there have neeting educasion. we will come to here for next trip in vietnam

Untouched temple. Had the chance to see the tample during a graduation day, all of the students were dressed up with traditional clothes. So many of them wanted to take photos with us. A really niec and real vibe, one of the best memories of hanoi

a must see. It was great to visit this place and learn more about how and what the students learnt here, also the site itself is quite impressive.However, some important information is missing and most of it is in Vietnamese.A bit far walking from the centre of old quarter.. Went there by bike and it got parking space as well.. 30,000VND ticket for adult.. The temple itself is very beautiful.. One thing that is kinda make me dissapointed is the translation on the relics itself.. No English..

Well worth a visit !!!. Well worth spending an hour or 2 wandering through the grounds and learning about the history of this great historical seat of learning. Watch out for the hawkers outside as they can be an annoyance

An oasis of calm in a wonderfully busy city. Walking through the entrance the noise of the city disappears and calm seems to descend. It was fairly busy with tourist but this was ok. We paid a little to go in but I can't recall how much. Don't forget to rub the turtles heads at the entrance further in for luck. Worth a visit, don't expect excitement or lots to do but I am glad we did not miss it.

Beautiful architecture. walk into the compound makes me feel like I am in feudal era. Beautiful architecture. The only thing I could not stand is the smell of the jossticks in the confined area. Other than that it was marvelous. You need to pay 30000 VND per person to enter. The area is vast and the entrance is from the south side along Quoc Tu Giam.
Been there for an hour. I did not have much time, so i spent just an hour around this area. Quite nice with great fresh air. Think about going back there next time and learn more about the place

I Recommend a Tour. We went to this attraction on the fly after a lunch we had close by. It was a very nice temple although I spent most of the time trying to lurk around other peoples guides so that I could get the story of the place, most of the plaques were written in Vietnamese. So if you do this, don't do it on the fly otherwise you will question why (maybe)

Beautiful gardens and buildings. This site involves lovely, quiet grounds together with beautiful temples. The day we were there, the temple had a festive air as many university students, complete with their academic regalia, were having their pictures taken. Although interesting, less than a hour should do it here.
Viet Nam 2015. this temple was a delight and an oasis in the middle of a busy city area i like the stones where the names of all the students that have graduated are written down

an amazing place to visit in Ha Noi. Van Mieu is architecturally very interesting. In the five yards of Van Mieu you can experience different stages of Vietnamese architecture.This is such an amazing place to visit in Hanoi.

Worth a Stop in Hanoi. Beautiful grounds and a lot of history. It is a long walk from the Old Quarter, but worth it. Unfortunately, inside the temple grounds numerous gift shops are hawking materials which takes away a bit from the surroundings.

Beautiful grounds. The temple is a long walk, although doable from the old quarter. It is the same price as most other attractions, so not too pricey.The grounds are symmetrical and well tended, the gates and temples are pretty and are a peaceful haven in a busy town. However there is a lack of information in English and some of the buildings are virtually brand new (ie. built in 2000) so I didn't get the sense of age here, rather new grey concrete.

An interesting place to visit. I really enjoyed visiting this Temple. I love the idea of a Temple of Literature. Buildings are very traditional. I loved the red doors with the golden dragons. I also loved the music. I would have liked to have spent a little longer here.

The best in Hanoi. So interesting, should be one of the first things to visit in Hanoi.
The Temple of Literature was the first university in Vietnam, dating from XI century.
Beautiful spots for photos

Great historical place to visit, but some information missing. It was great to visit this place and learn more about how and what the students learnt here, also the site itself is quite impressive.
However, some important information is missing and most of it is in Vietnamese.
Still recommend this place.

Yes a temple for Confucius. Yes this is one of the must see temples in Hanoi. It is better to visit in the afternoon as it is quieter an you have more space and are not pushed along by other groups. The temple is very interesting and our guide was excellent with all the information he shared.

A very big temple.. . A bit far walking from the centre of old quarter.. Went there by bike and it got parking space as well.. 30,000VND ticket for adult.. The temple itself is very beautiful.. One thing that is kinda make me dissapointed is the translation on the relics itself.. No English..
Temple of Literature!. Not that extraordinary place but nice! If anyone visit Hanoi then this is one of the recommended place! I liked the surroundings and entrance of this temple!

peaceful. beautiful gardens
go early in the morning to avoid the tourists. good place to relax
and go back in time
inspiring. Perfect gateway from busy Hanoi. Peaceful, quiet, highly symbolic. Touristy so avoid potential scams...

An interesting attraction. This site is dedicated to Confucius, sages and scholars. It has five courtyards each with its own points of interest. The main shrine dedicated to Confucius was impressive and for us unexpected. Be prepared to spend about an hour wandering the grounds and absorbing the history.

Interesting. Without a tour guide or some prior knowledge, this wouldn't be very interesting for the average tourist.We had a guide with the two of us and he was able to explain the layout of the site, the traditions, the meanings and purposes of each building etc and it meant we had a great understanding by the end of it. Made the site much more interesting so we enjoyed ourselves here.
Interesting. My husband loved this attraction more than I. It is worth popping by and is not expensive so why not.
Graduation day. My friends and I went during a graduation ceremony and it was a great experience! The temple itself was impressive and well-kept.
morning visit. go early to avoid the crowd. we went here at 10am on a Friday and there weren't a lot of tourists but by 11am they were swarming the place. if you collect stamps they sell it here.
Interesting if you take a guide. Like most historical things in a foreign country you need a guide to explain the history and significance of this temple. Was very interesting

Historical Temples and University Buildings. This site contains a number of buildings that have been used as temples and as the first university in Vietnam. The buildings are interesting architecturally, and give a good impression of what historical buildings would have been like in the country. Of particular interest were the large stone monuments with turtles, on which the names of the graduates were written. Whilst we were there, there was a performance of traditional music, which was really interesting. The signage describing the history of the site was decent. Overall, a very good place to visit.

Hanoi's First a University. A very interesting place with nice buildings and gardens to visit. There are explanations in English explaining how former students became qualified in times gone by and were subject to a royal examination by the King who would award a rating. The names were then placed on tablets from 1497 onwards and the last dates I saw were the mid seventeenth century. There is a temple in honour of Confucious which is worth visiting.

It is a temple. It was a typical type temple that you see in the region. I did not think there was anything wrong with it. I saw a statue of Confucius, a few other people graves, a gold turtle and a few other things. I was not that impressed with it. Possibly if you are a local, or you know something of the history you would think more of it.

Must visit place.. A good s/s attraction , it is temple for Chinese Philosopher Confucius. A small but beautiful lawns with good bonsai plants and good souvenirs shops. Very basic toilets with small fee.
History and culture. Very popular with tourists and locals. Not one piece of litter. Beautiful crafts for sale. History+++

Beautiful Buildings, Relaxing Gardens, a Millennium of History!. Symmetrical gardens behind the attractive entrance gate give way to a complex if attractive temples, pagodas, and ancient University building. Even the souvenir shops are packed with interesting colourful items, though rather tacky.

Place of interest, but watch your wallet. Before entering this interesting site I bought a ticket for 15.000 dong at the ticket office. A not to friendly lady gave me a ticket and some change, waving my away to make way for the next costumer. However, as I counted my money before putting it back into my wallet, I realised she had given me 50.000 dong less (2 euro, not such a big deal, but in Vietnam it's a small fortune).As I walked back and expected to get engaged useless discussion, I noticed she had put the money on the side and just tossed it back to me, without saying a word.She was the only Vietnamese that tried to do it in this sneaky way, but do watch out for those people that have decided to include their own commission.Cheers.

Historical site.. Amazing history to this site. Only downside is lack of more information for the foreign tourist. Better signage and floor plans would help. Try doing some research before visit. Also check out some interesting eating places near the temple.
Amazing place. Very interesting either historical and architectural place 1st university in Vietnam We were lucky to see students having their diploma

Good history!. Well! I luv the history of this place . I went here with an awsome guide. I luv hanoi . I understood about this temple which was very old and had a lot of amazing students in vietnam were there. Luv it!

Never pass it. Temple of Literature is one of the greatest places that my family went to visit in the period of staying in Vietnam. The ancient structure made a deep impression on us. It was very interesting to discover temple of Confucius as well as Imperial Academy - the first university of Vietnam.

Worse place we visited . Of all the itineraries we did in Hanoi during our 6 days stay, this is the worse place we came across. People taking a dump on the grass, guys peeing on the gates, all these disgusting things we have to witness kinda spoilt our day at this historical temple. It kinda shows how the locals "respect" this place. It would be nice if they maintained the little pond. All u really see are tourist. Nothing authentic, no feeling of serenity etc. waste of time.

Overwhelmed by the history. 1000 years old with stelae listing the names of graduating scholars on the backs of turtle sculptures -. Awesome. And then a group of tiny exuberant Vietnamese school kids waving to us and calling out "Welcome to Vietnam!" What a brilliant contrast!!

informative journey. Temple of Literature as well as the first National University in Vietnam is very special. it brings ancient structure from Tran dynasty and with the time, it has a little bit chance but its original structure is still remained.

Beautiful small temple. I was lucky enough to go there when a group of students were celebrating their graduation, so the air was full of lively energy. The temple is great for a short visit but there is not that much to see there, but it is cheap to enter and worth a visit
Stunning array of traditional architecture. Amazing to contemplate this ancient Confucian seat of learning, centuries before the first European universities.

Beautiful. It's amazing that there's such a serene place for academics in the olden days. Many graduates from Vietnamese Uni visit here to take their graduation photos. It's great to see them so excited and happy.

A beautiful must-see!. Do not miss this! It was such a beautiful place to visit. Lots of history, beauty and culture. There is a calmness to the Temple... it is surround by such a crazy, fast-paced city, but you wouldn't know it once you are within the walls. The city kind of fades away and you can feel yourself really understanding why it was a place of learning and reflection. Even in the rain (it was bucketing down) it was a wonderful place. Don't miss it!

pleasant place to stroll about. This temple complex in central Hanoi is a very pleasant place to stroll about. Lots of great photo opportunities too. There are old, historic buildings, pagodas and temples, and wonderful landscaping.On the day I visited, there was a group of musicians giving a concert, using traditional Vietnamese instruments.

Very Pleasant Way to Spend an Afternoon. The Temple of Literature and National University is a definite must-see for anyone visiting Hanoi. It's rather a tranquil spot away from the hustle and bustle of the ceaseless traffic and yet right in the city itself. It is a much larger site than you would think from the outside, taking about an hour to an hour and a half to get round leisurely. There are courtyards and pagoda style buildings leading to many other pagoda style buildings and courtyards, all very spacious and tranquil looking. There are inscriptions and signs to help you appreciate what you are looking at, and pleasant landscaped gardens and lake. If you are lucky you will hear one of the many public musical recitals of ancient Vietnamese music at one of the pagodas and at others you can see locals and visitors burning incense to the gods.there are a few souvenir shops dotted around but most of the things are rather tasteful and although some, such as the water puppets, are over-priced many souvenirs are affordable and not much more than if you were bargaining in a market in the Old Quarter. It's a very pleasant site and one which I know has delighted all our visitors, and ourselves, so far.
Must-see Temple in Hanoi. Friends took me to this incredible place on a rainy day so we had the place to ourselves. Location is a long walk from the old city but definitely worth the trip.
Center of Learning!. To see this piece of history - the first university in Vietnam was lovely. And to realize the role Confucius played in bringing order to this part of the world was inspiring.

Ancient centre of learning. We visited here as part of a Hanoikids morning excursion. This added meaning to our exploration of a 12th century university and libraries. This no longer functions as a teaching institution, but it was awesome to learn about student life many, many hundreds of years ago. would definitely recommend visiting with a knowledgeable local, as this greatly enriched the whole experience.

Family Ancestry. Temple of Education. It was so interesting to listen about the history and honor of learning. We were fortunate to see a graduating class of students praying and having graduation pictures taken

Graduation day. We had an excellent guide at the 1070 Temple of Literature - Vietnam's principal Confucian sanctuary.We walked the five courtyards and were there when the students graduated - lots of group photographs of students throwing their mortarboards in the air !!!The first courtyard takes you from the main gate , the second courtyard contains the Constellation of Literature Pavilion, from there you walk through to the third courtyard. This has the Well of Heavenly Clarity. You enter the fourth courtyard through the Gate of Great Synthesis and then the fifth is the Imperial Academy .The grounds are beautiful and have quiet corners to sit and enjoy this amazing place - though not on Graduation Day !!!

Wonderful place to learn about Ha Noi's history. The Temple of Literature is a very wonderful spot to visit in Ha Noi & to learn about its ancient culture. The fascinating buildings are beautifully preserved & maintained, and are surrounded by lovely gardens; inside are many interpretive displays that describe the history of the place as a center of learning. The stone stelae (sitting atop carved tortoises, and engraved with the names of professors and students dating back to the mid 1400's) were a treat to see, as were the statues of Buddha (still actively used as places of worship). I spent a relaxing afternoon there, enjoying the marvelous architecture and peaceful surroundings in the heart of the city... don't rush through this place, but take time to find a quiet corner (e.g., near the giant bell, hanging outside in an open-sided structure), and partake of the Temple's pleasant ambiance... well worth your time to visit, indeed :)
Temple of Confucius in Hanoi. The temple hosts the "Imperial Academy". It is around 30 minutes by foot from Old Quarter. There are a lot of tourists in that area.
Nice, if busy. If you are going to visit old imperial style ruins you need to choose carefully. This is one of the older and more interesting ones in Hanoi.

the first university in vietnam. when we are go to here, we met so much vietnamstudent come to here for meeting when they finish study at university of they. and they share for us so much culture of vietnam was nice. special in vietnam have lua nuoc and something like that is we can not remember. we tolking with they about 1 hour from this time we were understand vietnamese so much. we like vietnam and vietnamese. will stay here again for next time
Hanoi. Vietnam first university lovely gardens and architecture offering and fascinating glimpse into Vietnam's past.

very nice and worth a visit. This is better with a guide who can explain everything to you. Very interesting architecture and grounds (and some amazing trees if you look around). There is also a nice shop where you can buy water puppets actually used in the shows. Peaceful setting - much different than the rest of Hanoi.

What a first university!. I used to wonder why they studied in a temple, but it seems like the university is an extra part of the temple. I can feel the holy and serene atmosphere hovering around the temple. The plants, the lakes, the interiors of the temples are old and bear confucian features. Vietnam seems to have a long tradition of respecting the talented. I truly admire the kings who were very supportive of good men. I wish they are still alive now!
Impressive. Impressed at the preservation of this temple dedicated to education. Parents still come to this temple to pray for their children and educational success.

Very thought provoking and philosophical. We went here as part of our guided tour of Hanoi and were very impressed with the structure and all the symbolism. Wonder what Confucius and his scholars would make if it all today - very interesting and peaceful.
Well worth the visit. Well restored and maintained. Great insight into the Chinese influence on Northern Vietnam -in respect to religion, culture and architecture.
Nice. It was an interesting visit but super crowded. Don't miss the small cafe outside where you can order Bun Cha from the food joint next door. For 25,000 Dong it is the best Bun Cha we ever had !

Wonderful. This is an excellent site illustrating traditional Vietnam. The temple is beautiful in its age and history. This is not neon lights and excitement. This is a place of potential quiet contemplation even with the constant noise of traffic from outside the compound walls and the number of school children visiting. The entrance leads through a number of garden areas to the temple which houses the statues of Confucius and some of his students. The history of this, Vietnam's first university founded in 1070, would alone cause a visit. However, we found this place to be a highlight in Hanoi because of the architecture and statuary. The bonsai in the temple courtyard are set in massive trays and are magnificent. Its a shame about the tourist shops either side of the temple forecourt but the temple really is something. Cost to enter is VND 20,000 but worth more.
Nice and peaceful. Nice space, very peaceful. We should have opted for the guide (100.000 dong) has we would have taken more information from it. Although there is information in English available.
A place rich in history. This temple is an oasis in the middle of the city. Its gardens are nice and the information provided gives a good overview of the university and its history.
Interesting Stop. The temple is a must when in Hanoi. The architecture and gardens are wonderful, but the real intrigue is in the history of the temple itself. I could have stayed all day!

stunning oasis in middle of city with buildings of great interest. Surrounded by a wall isolating the attraction from the busy city. There are multiple areas to visit. Beautiful gardens and nice statues. Look for little subtle figures and wonderful architecture. There are stella like monuments showing graduates from the school in ancient times. An important stop in Hanoi

Very impressive. Established in 1070, 945 years ago. Very humbling to visit this place "Temple of Literature & National University", knowing that it was established 945 years back, when most of the currently advanced world was either in the dark ages or non existent yet.

Really interesting!. Our guide of Hanoi took us here and we had a great look around. The temple was really beautiful and the grounds were very interesting. We really enjoyed looking at the stone turtles and engravings regarding the three exams of wisdom.

Beautiful attraction. The Temple of Literature is the first University in Vietnam. It is both a serene and beautiful place to visit whilst in Hanoi. The architecture is some of the most beautiful and well preserved in Hanoi. A must do in Hanoi!
Peace in the City. Well worth a visit. A little oasis if calm and tranquility. Confucian temple complex. Very informative but tour groups do visit so you may need to wait if you are taking photos.

Historical. Worth a Visit. Take a Taxi here. Budget an Hour. Grounds is beautiful. Worth the trip to appreciate Vietnamese culture and history. While we were here, we appreciated a graduation of proud students. :)
knowledge and tranquility. quiet interesting engaging you can spend hours there beautiful gardens and sculpture an antiquity that is accessible

Very interesting locale, although it's been rebuilt and is not original. The Temple of Literature was definitely worth a visit. The current temple, however, is not the original. Unfortunately, war took its toll on Hanoi and the original grounds were destroyed by Allied forces. So, Hanoi had to rebuild the place. Nonetheless, the courtyards are beautiful and there is a lot of history here, with many of the old statues still intact and reused. We had a guide with us, so we spent a good hour or longer here. It's one of the main attractions and worth a stop.

Very interesting. Well worth a visit. We visitied this Temple with a tour guide who had a lot to tell us about the Temple (which always helps). A lot to see and learn about, food,drinks and souveniers can be bought from here if you wish. Of all the temples to see this one should rate high on your list.

Absolutely Stunning. This place is amazing. It transports you back in time. The architecture is gorgeous. Our kids loved the statues of the turtles and the trees that had been shaped into the signs of the Chinese Zodiac.
Lovely, outdoor experience. Pretty grounds with lovely Bonsai. Nice altars and meditation spaces. Very small museum. Not memorable

Feel the Confucianism. One of the places in the Hanoi mandatory visit list. To tell the truth I wasn't impressed too much during my first visit, maybe my expectations were higher. I had been in the Temple of Literature 3 times and each new time I found it better and better. University have several yards and buildings but everything very simple. One-two hours is more than enough to observe everything inside.

Nothing much to see here. Sorry, but this was not an interesting temple, particularly when compared to ... well, most any other temples, anywhere. The bit of garden is nice, so have a seat on shady bench and people watch.

Interesting. The Temple is presented and maintained very well and offers lovely gardens, temples, old templates dating back to the first graduates in the 1500's and beautiful lake side location where you may be lucky enough to spot the 500 year old turtle that resides there.
Very good. This is a lovely place to stop and take time to look, away from the bustle of Hanoi. The gardens are lovely too
Part of the Paloma Scooter tour. Very pretty place to visit to get away from the traffic and congestion of Hanoi. The sense of serenity is well worth a couple of hours spent here.

A University from 1076. Hard for me to imagine the history behind this remarkable establishment, the "Doctors" are incredible as well as architecture, models the gardens and walls, ponds and the people. Amazing place.

Good overview about Hanoi.. A famous historical place in Hanoi, which was supposed to be the first university ever. If you're interested in Vietnam history and Confucius, you couldn't possibly go wrong here. Even not, with the harmonic combination of garden, lake and trees the Temple of Literature still make a wonderful choice for an afternoon walk & sightseeing.

Really cool. Many of my friends had said the Temple of Literature is the coolest site in Hanoi, and I would have to agree. It's the oldest building in Hanoi and it's quite large. You can walk around the multiple patios, read the info boards on your own and shop in the gift shops. Most people were touring on their own, including us, but it's probably better to get a guide and learn more about this place. Can get student discounts with a proper student ID.
Cool Place. Some interesting things to see here but nothing earth shattering. Enjoyed walking around and seeing everything.
Worthwhile. This old temple is definitely worth a visit. Beautiful gardens and old remnants of the University once operating here.

Visit yes or yes. This place is so relaxing from the bustle and hustle from the city.The architecture is amazing. The gardens, the lake, the structure are really well kept.Actually there is a nostalgic feeling that I enjoyed a lot.Get ready your camera, there are tons of spot to immortalize.
A nice place to walk through. Nice place to walk through. It's quiet here which is nice in this crazy city. But, not really much to see.
extensive. not like the temples in cambodia. very extensive and goes on forever. the giatn drumm is hidden in the very back

Interesting old place. Interesting place to spend few hours. So called, first university of Vietnam, now a historical place. We would have loved some more description etc at the place itself, instead searching your Lonely Planet guidebook.Few good restaurant and shopping avenues nearby, if interested.

Typical of Asian holy structure. So that is how Vietnamse used to teach and study. Too bad girls were not accepted into classes. Anyway, the phylosophy of Confucian was interesting. The design of the temple is eye-catching with the harmony of natural element and man-made element. A holy atmosphere that helped set my mind at rest.
One of top attractions in Hanoi. Very nice park inside. Make sure to climb the second floor in the last building for a nice view. The souvenir shops carry quite a bit of unique things

The best temple in Hanoi. Temples in Vietnam are not as great as in other countries. The Temple of Literature is the best one, I have seen in Vietnam. It is alos the oldest one with several buidings in a small park.

Well preserved historic landmark. Plenty to see here - but very crowded when we were here around Tet. The buildings are well maintained and give a good idea of the Confucian ideal layout. It was very busy when we were there with students crowding some calligraphers to get lucky symbols for their upcoming exams - we were taken to the front of the crowd by an attendant so we could buy some for our kids.

Very nice site. A must see if in your sightseeing list. It's pretty and the story is interesting. Don't hesitate to buy the little guide at the ticketing office. It can be very crowded so go early or late if you wish to enjoy it in a peaceful atmosphere.

Loathsome. Spent 15 min inside and cannot wait to get out. Temple of Literature is pretty much a temple with chinese deities and a couple of souvenir shops circling in a few ponds with lifeless water lilies and brown murky water.

Interesting Place to Visit. Came here as part of a day tour. I enjoyed watching the uni students all dressed in their best for photos - graduation ones I assume. Has a nice tranquil feel about it, plenty to see, and the pagoda was beautiful. Worth a visit.

Charming, pretty and tranquil. Don't miss a visit here if you spend some days in Hanoi. It works particularly well to relax a bit after walking the crazy and busy streets. You can still hear the traffic but the temple grounds are peaceful all the same.I liked the two storey tree house at the very end best with its beautiful roof and charming interior.

Know your history. Not many English explanations. Well looked after gardens. Some buildings are covered to be renovated. Not much to see if you don't know your history here. Was the university in the old days

A bit blah. Way too busy with SO many tourist buses and lots of what appeared to be wedding and graduation groups getting their photos and their selfies! Nice architecture but way too much of the history written in Vietnamese.

Informative. Gives a good perspective on the importance of education and scholarly achievements in Vietnam. Invest in a local guide though for a deeper understanding of the historical background underpinning the first university in Vietnam.

Tranquility and history. If only for the green tranquility of the gardens and pools, if not for its fascinating history, the Temple of Literature is well worth taking the time to visit. We visited during graduation season, which saw the place thronged by uni students in their gowns and caps, giving thanks and gathering for their graduation photos, but that did not in any way detract from the experience.

Well Worth a Visit. This Temple devoted to Confucuis is well worth a visit, especially because it is located on the grounds of a 1000 year old university. Aside from the temple itself the buildings, courtyards and gardens are wonderful to explore. We were very lucky to be there on a day when some musicians were playing music on traditional instruments. We enjoyed listening so much we purchased one of the CDs they were selling.

Very very Old vietnam ...1070 AD !. They really need to do more to advertise their wonderful old buildings. The quality of information is poor here which is a shame as I was really keen to learn about this property. You need a guide or guide book here as the information provided is poor which is a loss for the huge mount of tourists who are visiting here. I love these old properties and its full of culture ,and gives you a sense of the past ..built in 1070 ..but it's not well respected and it needs to be better preserved for the future generations. I would still attend here though its a walk in history and easy to get to . .
Ho Hum. A very important structure for Vietnamese, dating back over 1000 years. Respect of learning and knowledge is honoured here. Very busy and not that interesting to me
For peace and quiet. It is small compared to the grand temples I've been to in Asia. But it was serene and a good place to go to after a full day of roaming around central Hanoi.

Beautiful building and very interesting with guide. It worthed a visit. We took a free one day guide from Hanoi Free Guide group who was a university student. had great time with her and she explain lot in the tour. highly recommend.

An introduction to the rich contrasts that make up Vietnam. We had a great guide for our visit to this landmark, which is a must. We got there on a perfect day to link history and contemporary life. It was school graduation celebration day and hundreds of young students from area schools were there. When they threw their mortarboards into the air at the end it was played out against a complex backdrop of a unique era in the history of higher education in Vietnam, Chinese occupation, the introduction of Confucianism and much more. It was a great site to visit.

Not a Memorable Temple. I would not say the experience of this Temple was memorable at all. Too many tourists and not enough depth to really understand the scope of its importance. I wish there was more information about why this Temple was relevant, but the ticket for admission held no information.

Take the time to understand what this is.. Take the time to understand what this is. This is a 1000 year old university! It's not 'just another temple'. The grounds are meticulously maintained and the Confucian story on the walls of the gates is fascinating. (BTW - when you leave go left, then left again down the outside and look for KOTO restaurant for a refreshing KOTO special smoothie.)
Lovely place. Historical references of the place were excellent, loved to see the Confucian images. Happy to recommend this place to visitors in Hanoi.

Very cool window into history. The temple complex/university was gorgeous and I was especially impressed by the stone tablets where scholars' names were inscribed. I would go back to school to get my PhD in a heartbeat if it meant my name was going on a memorial like that.

Appreciating where knowledge is shared. The Temple of Literature and the first University of Vietnam was one of two attractions we had down to visit and we were not disappointed. It is about 40K VND by taxi from the Old Quarter where we staying. Entrance fee is 20K VND per person.The Temple is designed similarly to all other temples in China and elsewhere in Asia devoted to Confucious. Part of it is original and other structures rebuilt after the war but in keeping with the original architecture. A guide is a must to really appreciate the history and the symbolic nuances of the place. The ticket office can quickly arrange for one at 100K VND - ours was an English speaking guide who is also a historian! The Temple is built in courtyards nested within courtyards surrounded by well kept gardens. Discover the tablets dating from 1000 years old bearing the names of the scholars who passed the old examination system to become officials and ministers of the land. Walk into the inner sanctum to the temple where Confucious and his top disciples are worshiped. This is still a working temple and students visit to pray for guidance during exam time. The precinct is also used for graduation ceremonies for the present University. The second floor of the temple has wonderful views and here you will find the Kings from two of Vietnam's dynasties who valued education and knowledge. We loved the tranquility of the temple surrounds and it was a great respite from a crowded and busy city.

Disappointing. I had to double check whether we went to the same Temple of Literature as most reviewers here, as they seemed quite impressed and we left very disappointed. I was actually really looking forward to visiting, based on the reviews here.It can be a small taster of old Asia if you've never been to a temple before, but if you travelled and been to temples in Asia, this has to be one of the worst and a very poorly maintained site.
