When we went, there were quite a few parts of the temple covered, so having a large cloth over an ancient wall isn't particularly the best of sights, along with a couple of murky water sections with dried up lily pads.All the signs and placards are in Vietnamese (apart from the one pointing to the toilets), so you need a guide for all of your visit.

trip to vietnam. well I just loved Hanoi we went on a Hanoi travel guide from south to north very very good, i'll be taking my husband next year. as we had such a good time.the people are lovely very willing to help.the country side is lovely also a lovely place to visitregards 60petals
A very beautiful place and a must see in Hanoi. You cannot leave Hanoi without having visited this place. One of my favorite old places in Hanoi where you can take fantastic pictures.
interesting history. you absolutely have to ask your guide to tell you how students were / are admitted ... very interesting

Ho Chi Minh was so correct!. The temple of literature loosely tied to Ho Chi Minh's desire for a highly educated society who could properly choose a leader was a highlight of our trip to Hanoi. The centre is beautiful and very picturesque.
Nice temple to visit. This was not too crowded or hot unlike most temples. We also saw students on their graduation day which was special. Beautifully preserved.
University Guides were great. We used the "Hanoi Little Ambassadors" as our free university guides and they were greatly informative, very inquisitive, and a generally great experience.

Beautiful grounds! takes you back. One really needs a tour guide or a good tour book to know what you're looking at and to get the history. We were also treated to a short concert by traditional. Vietnamese performers on traditional instruments. The many gift shops detract from putting yourself in the true atmosphere of what this school was in its day.

Better to come with a guide book or tour guide. Most of the information was written in Vietnamese. My friend and I probably did not enjoy the trip as we do not know what is the history behind of this place. :/

Beautiful and serene. The complex is a lovely place to take a walk and enjoy the piece and quiet in the middle of Hanoi. It's not particularly big but very well maintained, there are a lot of signs in English and the architecture is beautiful.

Amazing architecture. Fabulous terracotta tiled rooves, wonderful series of courtyards, history galore.
Wonderful friendly children practising their English. And a remarkable park next door - check out the badminton court.

Beautiful architecture . This whole complex is very old and beautiful. I would highly recommend visiting here, even if only for 10 minutes. The preservation of the structures are good, however due to weathering the writing on the stones are fading. I'm still in awe at the beauty of this place. Vietnam history is very fascinating to learn about!

Loved it so much the last time I went again. Really interesting place with an air of peace and calm in the chaos of Hanoi's traffic. Lovely gardens and a real historical land mark worth seeing. History, culture, interesting stories and facts, a nice temple and totally amazing to see a "university" with a 1000 year history. It somehow makes western pretentions and arrogance of superiority fall into perspective.

Cheerful atmosphere with hundreds of students. When we visited the temple complex it was filled with hundreds of freshly graduated students, celebrating their achievements and taking pictures. It gave a cheerful feel to the historic environment. The temple complex is one of the few main attractions of Hanoi.

Historical place to visit. This place is big and has a rich history in education. It is a nice place to take a slow walk and you get to see many Hanoi university students take their graduation pictures here. It is a pretty sight as the girls are all in their traditional Vietnamese costume.

Old School. Don't take teenagers. Even though we had a guide, who enlivened the history, the teens were still bored. Too much like school classes, back home, I think.The adults enjoyed this very much. The animal signs, which are the year you are born in, are pruned into topiary designs in the garden are a lovely attraction. Lots of graduating students getting their photos taken at the heritage site. Either, read up on the history before you visit or take a guide. The site is an open garden with a temple at the end. Lots of sellers out the front, but remember there are stalls inside, where you can buy postage stamps.

tranquil atmosphere. take a guided tour , so you can get to know about the full temple of learning. even now students visit this place to get blessings before appearing for their exams. well maintained, peaceful atmosphere.

A place of Beauty in the Midst of a Cold City. When we visited this park this past November we were surrounded by many new graduating students who were celebrating their accomplishments in this Temple of learning.Talking to our guide he indicated that it was a happy day for many young children that had worked hard to get a degree but when reality hit that there were not many jobs available for them it would be sad and, unless they were connected with someone in the Communist Governing Body of Government their future was very limited. We can only hope for the best for these children!

Tranquil. We visited the Temple of Literature during a graduation, it was lovely to witness Vietnamese youth in their traditional Ao dai and suits taking photos. It was a very tranquil scene as well with a beautiful garden. However if you want to understand the historical context you should take a guide as there are no helpful signs that explain the significance of certain structures. Or you can google everything to understand the significance of the temple.
Liked it for a bit of peace. Once inside it is a calming place with nice buildings. There is a bit of interpretation too on various information boards throughout the area.
Great place !. This site is simply beautiful ! Great place to visit. We visited with our children and they enjoyed it. Not too many restaurant around.

One place recommended in Hanoi. Not only foreigners, Vietnamese people also are recommended to visit Temple of Literature. Vietnamese people often visit there especially before important examinations. Peaceful place and nice history, architecture.The small park opposite this temple is good place for relax, so quite and peaceful.

An old cultural site. Partially destroyed by USA bombing this is a place of culture, evoking past distinguished generations of literarians, scientists and educators. It transmits some in-depth admission into local values and traditions. Well kept deserves a 90 minute visit.

Beautiful Templ, Happy Students!. A beautiful series of temples, built in honour of Confucius. A tranquil place, despite there being a large number of people there. A good guide is necessary to explain the fascinating history and architecture. What added to our visit was the large number of elegantly dressed, impeccably polite graduating university students, who were more than happy to chat in English and have their photos taken.

A delightful experience that goes beyond what you can see. There is something calm and inspiring about this place. At the gateway a woman who I guessed to be a teacher, approached me and asked me about the meaning and pronunciation of several words on the English language information. Inside a child sat next to me and asked to practice his English with me. The father was close by keeping a watchful eye but didn't approach. A university operated here at a time when our British ancestors were basically peasants. Inspiring.

Guide adds to experience. We went with Hanoi Kids so a a wonderful explanation of all the symbolism.Peaceful after madness of Old Quarter.Obviously of great significance still to students as evidenced by all those posing for pictures.

Not really that fantastic. To be honest, the architecture of the place is rather similar to countless Chinese temples I've seen and been to in Singapore, Malaysia and China. Do get a tour guide in your own native tongue to explain the significance of the different areas or it will not be a very productive visit.

Beautiful gardens and tranquility. Confucious is revered here.. The pro:1. the grounds are beautiful and floral arrangements spell Chinese words2. Vietnamese universities run their graduation ceremonies here - we got to see a host of well dressed, polite college graduates, happy at this next step. I assume that this place is popular for other functions as well.3. Each temple (there are 5) is interesting in it's own right. Best were the well of heavenly tranquility as there was a graduation ceremony and the temple of confucious, with it's interesting past4. it is cheap to get in, for an attraction. A good way to kill a couple of hours and my young kids enjoyed running around.5. there is english/vietnamese/french translations of all the exhibitsThe con:1. there could have been more guides to help explain the exhibits. I don't think its being used to its greatest potentialIt was cool

Historic place. When we visited this place, it was just after the University graduation and the place was filled with students in the graduating gowns having their photographs taken. Quite an interesting sight. Historic buildings here. Nice garden in there too. We had an English speaking guide take us round.
Not much to it. This is a pleasant looking place. It's a quiet place and that's a nice thing to find in Hanoi, but mostly it's a garden with a few shrines. Your time may be better spent elsewhere.

MUST SEE. I loved every minute here, it was so interesting to see the history here, as well as seeing current students pass through here.... this is something you shouldn't miss....;lots of photo opportunities here
Interesting. From an historical point of view very interesting, beautiful artefacts and well set out. Would recommend you spend an hour here.

A quiet oasis in the center of a hectic city. While there isn't a great deal of translated information, the gardens and buildings are lovely, peaceful and a nice place to get a little break from the busy streets.

Look for Graduating Students. We were here in late November and it was mobbed with students, entire classes, coming to lay offerings for a successful graduation. It was fun because they came in their graduation robes and the women were dressed in very elegantly decorated Ao Dai. Students are very, very friendly. We had our picture taken with them. This was one of the better things to see/do in Hanoi.
An oasis of calm!. This place is like an oasis, in such a busy city. Lovely gardens, with the best Bonsai trees I have ever seen.
Beautiful temple. Rich in history, beauty. It is an oasis of peace and intelligence in the bustle of Hanoi. The wisdom just permeates from the whole temple. I admire these people.
Colourful. An interesting bright museum in the centre of Ha Noi plenty of stone turtles and history to learn. We enjoyed the historic relics.
Nothing great. Nothing interesting and great about this place . You can skip this visit and spend more time shopping.
Need to see in Hanoi. Perhaps the most interesting feature in Hanoi. Lots of college students get their class picture taken here. An excellent cultural experience
Nothing much to see. Nothing much to see here.. I suppose the story behind the place is more interesting but otherwise nothing significant about the courtyards and buildings.

Walking with history in present. Its a interesting place to visit. During my visit, there was batches of students taking their graduation photos and quite nice to see them in their traditional gowns. But there are too many people around, hard to take photos and can't really enjoy the walk. Try not to visit during the afternoon/lunch period.

Just as breathtaking on a second visit. This University predates The Battle of Hastings! It costs just 20,000 dong to get in (about 60p). We bought a guide, which is a nice souvenir but does not say much. It may be worth asking how much the human guides cost. There are a number of simple pavilions to visit, with some displays. The signage is in Vietnamese and English. There was a concert of traditional music playing on the morning we visited. There are gift shops, loos and limited refreshments available. Although there are few stairs, there are lots of "ledges" to negotiate, so wheelchair users might find it difficult to navigate the site.In the road that runs up the side of the park, Van Mieu, there are three great shops, which sell souvenirs where all the profits support poor communities. The prices are reasonable and the quality is high. They are called Craft Link. There is also a great not for profit restaurant called Koto, which trains disadvantaged young people.

Beautifully Maintained Gardens and Temples. Built in 1070, the ancient temple, organized upon the principles of Confucius, is beautifully laid out with lovely peaceful gardens and reflecting ponds, and several altars for worship. The temple is the site of Vietnam's first university, and a place where wisdom and education are still exalted. The site consists of 5 separate courtyards, and you have to climb over several thresholds to move between courtyards. I don't think there are any ramps for handicapped people and there are also few handrails, so keep that in mind if you have mobility issues. An elderly woman in our tour group fell after tripping over a step, and it sort of ruined the rest of the trip for her...The souvenir vendors who patrol the sidewalk outside the Temple are very aggressive, and you have to just push on and don't make eye contact or you will be mobbed !

A must see in Hanoi - but best with a guide!. Beautiful building, interesting history, a must see attraction in Hanoi but we felt you certainly needed a guide or a good tour book to really understand the site - we were lucky as we visited here with the Hanoi Kids who provided a range of information about the place and all the young people who were dressed in traditional gowns and having photos taken - graduation pics apparently, even though they don't graduate until next year winter is the best time to take pics so it's common to see them having them taken at major sites across Hanoi but the Temple of literature is a must place for grad photos.Come early morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds.

City culture. It was interesting to see grsduating students having a photoshoot and Vietnamese exercising there.. Generally a good visit only to see how the locals use the space as a landmark / park.. Not the most important thng to do in Hanoi.. Visit if in the Area.

Peaceful. After getting past the people trying to sell their wares to you this was such a tranquil spot. Students were there when we visited having their graduation photos taken.Wonderful topiarys in the garden representing the Chinese zodiac. Really enjoyed it here
Nice place in crazy Hanoi. You will find a restful place in crazy Hanoi. Lot of student come here to take pictures. After crossing the beautiful garden, you will find temples...

History. Come and visit this old historical site where Confucius is remembered. The place is old and could have been better maintained since it has such a value in the country. An easy morning stroll and look at the sculptures amidst the cool air is refreshing. Since there are no literature found, it is better to read up first or hire a local guide so that you have a better understanding.
i like it. it's a bit boring but a lot of information. the tour guide is very good, she explained everything clear and informative
Tranquil part of city. A contrast to other parts of the city and well laid out. We saw a wedding taking place which was entertaining.

Interesting Architecture. We had a funny time here - great architecture and very interesting. Lots of locals dressed up and having their photos taken. They even wanted photos with us.On the downside - this was the only place on our visit where we got ambushed by touts trying to sell us things.We enjoyed listening to the traditional music - but again, we were hassled to pay 100,000 for listening!

historical traveler. if you love culture and history of a country..i suggest you to come here, it's so ancient surroundings and many historical statues..such as turtles statues as a symbol of wiseness

Interest Place. I took a taxi to get there and met a group tour. There was a good time, I heard from a tour guide. Displays a lot of information about the history of Hanoi. If I come back to this next trip I'm going to rent a private tour guide
Confucious he say....... Confusion temple with gardens at the rear. When we visited it was full of newly graduated students from the university having their photographs taken.

Pagodas & Bonsai. Worth visiting and great Pagodas for photos. Bonsai and gardens lovely. Popular spot for photography as Graduation photos were being taken during our visit. Lovely seeing the beautiful traditional Vietnamese tunics and bouquets in shots.

What's the big deal?. After reading all the reviews, I was expecting much more of this place. There's not really very much to see, and it's not particularly well maintained, so I really don't understand why this is a top attraction...I understand it's important for historic reasons, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Disappointing. Nothing impressive at the Temple of Literature which is modelled after an original Temple of Confucius in China. Sadly, the most valuable items which were the stone stelae dating back to 15th century have not been well taken care of and most inscriptions cannot even be seen. When we were there, boisterous and rowdy university students were having their graduation photos taken and they totally destroyed any form of tranquility that could be had. Worst of all, the innermost courtyard was hosting some children's game show and the constant sound of the host as he cajoled the kids into the activities made the entire place feel like a carnival rather than a place to pay homage to Confucius and the importance of education. Even without the students or game show, the place is quite underwhelming.

it was on the day of graduation. So it was full of young students all dressed and joyfull ,lucky day for this old place. all thoses young girls were all in traditional dresses the place was very a life and so many picture were taken every where.

Old University. This is one place i miss the last time i stayed in Vietnam. A little crowed with tourist but still worth the trip.
Bad thing is we should have use a guide because without ones you won't know the meaning of these building inside.
Fascinating insight to local culture and education. This is a brilliant insight into the importance of education and the value placed on it and the importance of continual improvement

A Haven in Hectic Hanoi. Your first day in crazy Hanoi might put a few people off, but if you're finding it all a bit hectic then head for the University enclosure. its very, very old and a bit ramshackle but if you have a guide then you'll get an idea of the great cultural significance of this place. We were extra lucky as our visit coincided with graduation so there were hordes of teenage vietnamese in their mortars and gowns getting photos taken (and we got hauled into a few of them for fun too). Also you'll be accosted by much more junior children who just want to practice their English - go with the flow and engage with them, it was an absolutely fabulous experience for me, my wife and my young twenties kids. All in all a hot and humid but very memorable day.

1,000 year old well preserved university site. The buildings are in good shape. There are many signs around which are in Vietnamese and English. The history of the location is clearly explained. You can walk through most of the buildings. Watch your head as some of the pass ways were built for shorter Vietnamese students. If you are lucky you will catch a live performance by a small traditional band.

Must see. We were here on a day when many Vietnamese students were here to celebrate their graduations from university. The atmosphere was great and made the visit more special. Watch out for the TShirt sellers out the front only place we have been hassled to buy. Anyway 2 tshirts for $4 US if you decide to buy seemed good price

Best temple in Hanoi to visit. Gets a bit busy with tourists but well worth a look round. In particular the stones which have carvings of the names of graduates dating back hundreds of years are fascinating.

A Hanoi must - no question. This was a really pleasant surprise - a tranquil haven in the midst of Hanoi. I went expecting nothing much but the series of courtyards, with ponds, trees and old buildings was a delight. To stand inside a teaching institution that is about a thousand years old is humbling . It is still used by the locals as a place for celebrating learning and academic success - there were several large groups celebrating graduation when I was there. Very much a functioning cultural icon of old and new Vietnam

Nice place to understand the "Ancient University". It is an ancient version of our modern university. You can get to understand the layout of the ancient university (i.e. study room, activity hall, prayer temple etc.) and opposite this site, across the road is a lake whereby the ancient students go for relaxation. Go and have a look. Not far from Hanoi city.

Centre of attraction for students and educationists. We arrived when a large batch of high school students got there to 'rehearse' their graduation in the coming months. This rehearsal actually is meant to bring good grades and luck in their final examinations.This is a thousand year old Centre for learning, the first university that was established in a temple. It is well preserved. Stone tablets with names of first university graduates and Ph.Ds adorn the garden.The system of education since then to modern times, is depicted on story boards around the area. Images of spiritual mentors including Confucius are the mainstay. Local crafts and arts are on display with a couple of musicians playing traditional music.
Temple of Literature and National University. Really liked the gardens and surrounds very beautiful as was the Temple.This was made better by our very knowledgable guide.

Small place with beautiful "Áo dài" surounding. This place is a symbol of knowledge society in Vietnam. Where often hold a reward celebration for excellent students or pupils. At that time all the women will wear their most gorgeous "Áo dài" for the celebration. This will be a wonderful time for you to enjoy the Vietnamese beauties. Full of "Áo dài" with very colorful, lot of versions and styles in the big yard. Every one is so happy and smile. (Yes of course it was their graduated celebration, and they are one of the most successful student of the year!)I have leaded my friends come here. And all of the men was frozen for a while. Then they are so happy to run around with their camera on their hands. Even some of them could ask some "Áo dài" students to take the picture with them. Nice time
Must See. Beautiful temple and gorgeous architecture. Our visit was made special because students were having their college graduation photos taken it's so scenic.
Beautiful stop in the middle of city. Wonderful architecture and nestled in the middle of this wonderful, crazy city. Not worth buying the guide book.

Very authentic. This is a great place to capture a real temple atmosphere and see where the students go to graduate - there are usually some there in their gaps and gowns to take photos of. You just need to take a taxi but they are very cheap and readily available. Highly recommended
Lots to see. Quite a busy place with a variety of ponds, buddhas, etc. Really needed more time than the half hour we had.
Historic site, food okay. Of course, I am far from being a connoisseur of spring rolls, but one eats here because of the location, not the food

Fabulous Walking tour. We booked a private morning walking tour through the "Sky Bar" who are organizing "Spy Tours"We had a local guide and had a beautiful leisurely walking tour followed by a Vietnamese LunchWe enjoyed every minute of this tour and would highly recommend it

Busy. This area is nice and the grounds are well maintained. It was so busy with graduates getting their photos taken there you could hardly move!It has the usual temple stuff but also some interesting plants and floral arrangements in the grounds . A fashion show was being set up in the central area the day we were there.Some nice shops selling unusual souvenirs and crafts in the central area too

A must see in Hanoi. Was not expecting this university/temple complex in the chaos that is Hanoi. The "university" was actually an old Confucian school/temple prior to the French colonial days.The entire complex is made up of Chinese Confucian architecture and is simply gorgeous. There is a small token entrance fee of around USD1 - an absolute bargain given I can spend 1-2 hours in this beautiful place. Made up of several courtyards ending in the shrine to Confucius, you can simply wander along marvelling at the wooden buildings and Chinese deities. There are unfortunately not too be many signs or descriptions as to what you are looking at. We visited on Graduation day as well as we could see the excited faces of young graduates about to start their working careers and it adds to the atmosphere of the place.There are gift shops in the central courtyard and toilet facilities which charge a small nominal fee for usages.There are no cafes or restaurants but once you are done with your visit, there are a number of cafes where you can refuel just on the road left of the main exit.

Graduation Day. We visited on Graduation day when all students were dressed up, this make this a special visit, we got caught up in the excitement and pleasure, even on a normal day still a good place to visit.

Surprisingly quiet.. Given its location in the middle of car horn central, this area is really surprisingly peaceful. There's some nice to look at buildings and gardens, and a pleasant temple.
There were a few graduating students there on the day we visited which made for good viewing.
It's not amazing or spectacular, but a pleasant place to visit.
Beautiful area. We happened to be there on graduation day. Girls in either pink or purple silk bottoms with white tops. Beautiful architecture. Lots of larger bonsai style trees all around.
Graduation Day was awesome!. We were at the Temple of Literature on the graduation day of thousands of beautiful students that were there taking pictures! It was a big party and I loved it.

one of the tourism spot in Hanoi. This place ever been the university in the ancient period of Vietnam. When you go in, you can see the tortoises that carry the stones which has names of the student who can pass the examinations. Normally Vietnamese people will go to this place for asking about the study or examination and when you go there, you'll see the students who finished their study in bachelor degrees will take the photos at this place also.

Nice But Not Spectacular. I nice, serene spot in the middle of the Hanoi chaos. Note overwhelmingly beautiful. I will say, go on a weekend and catch the college students taking their class pictures dressed in traditional ao dai. Really a treat.

We picked a good day. Students were celebrating their graduation from local universities and were decked out in their finest and posing for photographers all over the grounds. It was a very celebratory day.

Beautiful. It is supposed to be a quiet and relaxing place. But on the Saturday we visited, all local colleges were there for their graduation pictures!!! The place was full of happy and proud students. It is also a beautiful place to visit.

Quiet but awesome!. The temple of literature is the first university in Viet Nam. Eventhough it not too big but very meaning to Vietnamese people. Not only attracting tourists, it is a place for all generations of students to come here and remember to the talented before. It's sacred and sublime. I am always proud to introduce it to international friends.
Graduates made it very different. It wasn't the tranquil visit I expected with lots of graduates having their photos taken, but it made it quite special to see them.
Enjoyable. It looked like we were there on graduation day. Lots of young people dressed up in academic gowns, and girls dressed in amazing dresses. Great temple in there.

Graduation. It was exciting to visit when it was full of thousands of gorgeous students graduating. Photo bombed the girls for fun and they were happy, excited and thrilled to be graduating. Was great to see that the traditional centre of learning is still respected

graduation and learning. a very charming temple and gardens, with lots of student interactions. Fun to watch as parade after parade of students arrive, get organised into neat lines, photographed within an inch of their lives, and leave high heels in hand and graduation robes akimbo, exhausted but happy. Cool place to chill or to join the throng to take photographs or ramble along amongst the statuary and plants.

Tranquility in busy city. Beautiful architecture. The day we visited there were a lot of people celebrating their graduation and taking photos so not as quiet as you might expect but definitely worth visiting. Very overpriced gift shops.
Fantastic place to visit the ancient scholars history. Definitely a must visit. Go in the morning to watch more ceremonies. Old temple with lots of live actions.
Great fun at graduation time. A beautiful old temple that comes alive when filled with students at graduation time - the inner areas are also quite beautiful.

Amazing old buildings... Great to walk through. Also very important to realise that it is an active temple where locals and visitors go to worship. Lovely ancient buildings dating back over 800 years. An oasis surrounded by the insane traffic that is Hanoi!

Pretty but simple temple. Don't expect anything too grand! But expect a nice temple where you can wander around a few buildings and gardens.As others have mentioned, we were there during a graduation which was a really nice thing to see. Graduates in beautiful dresses posing for photos.

Older than Oxford and Cambridge & typically Confucian. This 11th Century university is older than Oxford or Cambridge and is typical of the Far Eastern Confucian colleges where student learnt and passed exams to join the civil service. The bonsai trees are of several varieties, the students' pass "Certificates" in stone riding on tortoises are unique.
Enjoyable!. Went alone one afternoon and glad I did! A nice, long walk from the hotel, but well worth the experience. Do not miss this!

Beautiful place for some quiet time. It would be a unique experience to visit the temple during graduation ceremony. Though we just missed it, but got chance to speak to some students and it was fun. The place is quiet and calm and you get first hand experience of Vietnamese temple

Beautiful grounds. beautiful grounds, arrived here whilst the students were having their graduation which was great to see them all so happy. Also a photography display was up in the court yard which some amazing images! Well worth the trip, spent about 45 mins here

So optimistic. This is a lovely place all on its own with a garden and temple to Confucius. When we were there, however, there were hundreds (perhaps thousands) of graduates having their photographs taken and celebrating. It was so wonderful to see all the young people all dressed up in traditional garb and so happy. It made me feel very optimistic about Vietnam's future.

Quite interesting. Spent fifteen minutes having a look around the gardens of the Temple of Literature, not sure what I was expecting, however, quite nice gardens but nothing spectacular. You can easily see everything here in well under half an hour. Although, at $1 entrance it doesn't break the bank. Plus it was nice to find some greenery to walk around to escape the madness of Hanoi.
Graduation Day. Was there during the graduation day and was awesome seeing the locals throwing their gowns in the air (don't do hats) and all the photos!
VERY GOOD. We had the Hanoi kids taking us round which was very good, as they could explain things. lovely place to walk around , but nice if someone explains to you about the history of the place

Interesting history & beautiful grounds. The Temple of Literature, a complex of beautiful gardens, temples and ponds is definitely worth a visit while in Hanoi. The day I was there were hundreds of university students in their caps and gowns celebrating and taking photos. It was really fun to see their excitement, however, it was incredibly crowded and difficult to navigate (and I got yelled at a few times for wandering into the background. Oops!).

Packed with graduating students. Came here on a weekend, this place was packed with graduating students. It was good to see the students all dressed up in their national costumes then later with their togas, though they obstruct the views. The temple itself is well maintained and the souvenir shops inside actually have cheaper prices than in Hoan Kiem, so it's good to check them out.Entrance fee is 20,000 dong.
Full of beauty and history. I really enjoyed all parts of this site from the grounds to the graduating students in their ao dai's. This is one of my favorites in Hanoi.

A Learned Temple. Although there isn't really much to view about the place, it is a very meaningful place for students who want to do well in their studies or have succeeded in their academic pursuits. When we were there, the place was filled with students in their gowns and traditional Vietnamese dress to celebrate and take photos. They were really a happy lot - obviously very happy with their academic success.

Definitely should go. I've come here 4 times and 2 of them I came with my foreign freinds, we all loved it. This place is not only beautiful, it is a symbol of Vietnamese culture and education. It cannot express my feelings in a few words, but I can say that I'll recommend everyone come here whenever you ask me about The Temple of Literature. There is somtimes groups of Vietnamese students come here to take photos as memories before they graduate from the university. Girls wear "Ao dai" and boys wear suits or shirts. It was very fun to see their happiness and my memories of school time was restored. Tet time, this place is more colorful, thanks to many old and young masters with red paper and black ink writing calligraphy.Different time you visit, different emotion you feel.

Fun & Interesting. The temple itself is looks good. An okay size complex. There is a nice garden, a lot of statues, a pond and the building itself. The most fun are the countless student graduates who go there to celebrate. It is teeming with happy people at the temple, so the mood is good. Go there in the morning if you want to experience this, go in the evening to get more peace and quiet.

I like this the best.. Of all the sights we have visited, I like this one the best and we have spent a lot of time here. This place is very beautiful to me. And there are a lot of things to explore. There are 2 buildings. One is devoted to Confucius and his disciples. And the other building is devoted to the kings who were responsible for establishing the universities. Being in this place, it is easy to imagine how it would have looked several centuries ago when students and scholars populated it. If you are a fan of ancient history, this is a place to be.

Not to be missed. This is part of every organised tour. Best done with a good guide. It is really beautiful, the history is fascinating, though only has a little to do with literature! Ther were a number of students graduating there when we were visiting an they made a very colourful sight and, bizarrely, some wanted to be photographed with a middle aged westerner. Something to do with being tall!
Worth a visit. You will unlikely see so many graduation celebrations take place in one place providing you go on the right day.

worth a visit. Enjoyed a walk around this little temple and we were here when a uni class was graduating. Evidently very esteemed to have the graduate class visit. Some of the stele are very old, but that is the thing really, its very old.

Beautiful temple and surrounds. Definitely worth a look when you go to Hanoi. A great place to buy little souvenirs too. It was particularly fun because there were a number of graduating school students taking photos there. It was awesome to see these local kids dressed up in national gear and celebrating the end of university/ school! Beautiful place to visit and a great introduction to Vietnam. A beautiful temple and it was rather a bit overun from european tourists who seemed to lack the manners that the vietnamese have. Seeing the turtles all lined up was awesome. Although not so tourist friendly in the actual museum part, it was just great to walk through the history. An ideal location for vietnamese speakers however. PS take change for the uber clean western toilet, it's definitely a toilet to visit in Hanoi!

Nice place. This is a nice place to visit, very pretty. There were students graduating who were taking photos there. Be careful and don't take a taxi from right outside. We had an awful experience with this, our driver tried to charge us the equivalent of $30 when it should have been $3 and we didn't have that much and anyway were refusing to pay that amount. He wouldn't pull up to our hotel and just stopped on our street. He got extremely angry and appeared to attempt to drive off with us until we threw money at him and jumped out.

Lovely, but too touristy. The layout of the temple grounds was lovely, and reading about the start of the university was great. The price was also perfect. The only downside was the number of tourists, this obviously can't be helped but did ruin the photos somewhat.
Beautiful 1000 year old Confucian temple. Highly evocative and very beautiful. Peaceful gardens and buildings give an insight into old culture.
Worth a look. Worth a look for the temple and history also nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Love gardens and temple.
A haven of peace. Lovely complex of traditional temple buildings to honour Confucius and pretty gardens. A must see. Huge temple unusually with second story and good views.

A bit to busy at times. This is a very beautiful and popular place; We visited in November and the crowds, the students, the photographers and, of course the tourist, make it very dificult to navegate without bumping into each other. This is a minus but, it is also a plus because students are dressed in full color, are very friendly and wiling to be in the pictures with people that look a bit different to them. It was fun!

Nice to visit as part of a tour. We visited the temple as part of a day tour in Hanoi. It is a nice chinese style temple in a well maintained garden with a pond. Our guide told us the interesting history of the complex. A quite amazing part is the are with the stelae where the names of gradates are recorded. During our visit there were a lot of students celebrating their graduation and taking pictures. The temple itself is nice to see but not extremely special in my opinion. The entrance fee is not too much.
nice. When you stay 3 days or more in hanoi maybe you can go there. But when you are interested of the history of the temple its better to go there with a guide.

A visit to temple of literature. I am a professor of surgery.i teach committed adults.but a visit to the temple of literature in hanoi humbled me.they the vietnamese after the chaos of the wars they had to fight.they have liberated themselves.this the first university in vietbam in the tenth or eleventh century is still celebrated by students from all over vietnam.they come from all over with their graduation robes.reconnect with all the scholars through the centuries.their enthusiasm is catching.must visit.

A Must Visit Place When You Visit Hanoi. Knowing As The First University Of VIETNAM, This Is Amazing Place Ever And I Fell In Love With It. My Latest Visited In November, There Was A bIG group Of Graduated Students Taking Photos. With Their Tradition Dress, It Was Stunning. They Look Incredible and It Even Made It Worth While Visiting. If You Visit Hanoi, This Place Is A Must To See.

Pretty grounds, lots of history. I went here with HanoiKids as my guide and it was a peaceful, lovely place with a lot of history. It's not too large but I had a good time. I would definitely recommend visiting it but it is a bit out of the way from the old quarter. Vietnamese students come here before important tests and after they graduate for pictures so if you can catch that it's a great opportunity for pictures.

Very Interesting. I was lucky to go there the day that all the local university graduates were there celebrating their diplomas with many local traditions. It was especially meaningful to interact with them, great photo opps and dialogues with them.

Not serene the day we went there!. The "serene" temple of Literature was alive with beautiful young people who were about to graduate, and the girls were in flowing, embroidered traditional dress, and crazy high heeled shoes, posing all through the grounds of the Temple. Young men were in suits (and it was such a hot day!). Hanoi's first university dates back to 1070, and is now dedicated to Confucian worship. The gardens are spectacular. I was impressed with the very old turtles who had student names engraved on stone behind them. The display inside of Confucian worship is spectacular. Well worth the visit.

A revelation. With the aid of a fantastic female guide we learned so much about the history and culture of Vietnam that we will treasure the experience for many years. The temple was full of young local University students celebrating their graduation by having photos taken in the temple gardens. The pride of the students was evident and they clearly valued their education. Fabulous gardens and a powerful aura of age and culture make the temple visit a must.

what a wonderful walk. We were lucky because it was graduation day during our visit so we were able to see Vietnamese students celebrate. The temple itself was dazzling and surprisingly peaceful. Great walk and opportunity for pictures.

temple of literature. It's nice to have a temple dedicated to literature :) During our visit there were new graduates celebrating. It's a custom among students to take a picture there after graduation.

Literature but no books. All about the buildings and gardens plus the relics. You need a guide for it mean anything. Otherwise it is just a collection of beautiful gardens and statues. Watch out for locals taking pre-wedding photographs.
Nice place. Very nice place to see, relaxing, when I went there were a lot of students with a kind of ceremony very nice
Day of the graduates. Long old pagoda and lucky us we visited it during the graduation day: So full of students in colorfull traditional suits and dresses
Amazing history. the amazing history of the university was so interesting. The grounds were beautifully kept. It was well worth going there.

Beautiful. The Temple of Literature is well worth the visit, I went with a student from Hanoi Kids, an organisation set up by University Students to help students improve their foreign language skills while at the same time sharing information about Vietnam, it's culture and it's history. The temple was built in 1070, not all of the temple buildings are original, due to war at different times some of the temple was destroyed and later rebuilt. In the third courtyard are upright stones (a bit like headstones but much bigger) with the names those successful at the royal exams, the names in some cases have been worn away through time, some local's use the stones to help trace their family tree. I strongly suggest you google "Hanoi Kids" to act as tour guides, it is free, no charge, you only pay for any taxi or food or coffee you buy.

Worth an hour to see. This site is always on the short list of places to see in Hanoi - block out an hour to walk through to see the architecture. We didn't have a guide or guidebook so an hour was more than enough time to explore.

Beautiful. Lovely campus, taken over for the day by graduating students when we visited. They rather shattered the promised serenity of the place, but it was great to see their celebrations and the temple complex itself is very photogenic. Pop across to Koto for lunch after you visit - amazing food and a good cause

Interesting. We visited the Temple of Literature on a day when many students were celebrating their graduation in the grounds of the temple and it was wonderful to see these happy young boys and girls enjoying their special day. The temple and surrounds are well worth a visit even without the students.
Fun Stop!. We had a great time here. Seeing the temple was interesting & being surrounded by all the recent graduates was great fun. Their excitement was infectious!

graduation day. it was very busy when I visited this place. I believe it was a graduation day. a lot of young people wearing traditional customs. great to see. the museum could be more in depth. but the place was beautiful.

great to travel with a tour guide. this is first university of Vietnam, it used to be the place to worship Confucius . Hence we have the name :temple of literature. I think it is better if you have a tour guide going with to find out more about history and culture . I like the last courtyard with traditional music performance. But you should tip for the musician after attending performance

Lush and amazing. This was one of my favourites in Hanoi. KOTO is right around the corner. I would suggest going on a tour. Still very beautiful and a reflective place but it's better when you know what's going on.
Amazing history. We had a great guide to explain the history behind this beautiful and peaceful area. This is definitely worth a visit, for the history and architecture.

Where Vietnamese Civilization Comes From. This is Vietnam's first university, where the Emperor personally delivered oral exams to doctoral candidates starting in the 11th century. Much has been rebuilt (notably the wooden structures), due to wartime destruction, but the stonework is still there, including the turtle monuments, which honor each new doctor of philosophy with a unique inscription. People still go there to celebrate their own graduations, so you'll see groups of students in cap and gown taking pictures. People also go there to pray for intellectual achievement. You can no longer rub the turtle heads for this purpose (students used to do that before taking their final exams), but you can pray to Confucius, any of his four top students (even Mencius!), Chu Văn An (Vietnam's own "Confucius" and rector of the university during his time), or your choice of three different emperors (Lý Thánh Tông, who built the temple, Lý Nhân Tông, who founded the university, and Lê Thánh Tông, who came up with the idea of the turtles). While I was there, Lý Nhân Tông was getting the most attention from worshipers. Plenty of nice souvenirs available (they take credit cards), but bring a VND 20,000 note to buy the two nice CDs from the traditional music ensemble, because they only take cash. Admission is VND 10,000 (= $5 USD) per person.

Didn't compete with other attractions. A beautiful setting. However, the actual content on the "museum" is limited. And there really isn't much to see. We spent about 5 minutes here and swiftly moved on.

Gorgeous parkland in the city. This is a beautiful temple if a little busy with tourists, school groups and graduations. Glorious pictures of local people enjoying this park., it could do with an information sheet at the entrance
A great tradition. Beautiful grounds and buildings, plus a fantastic tradition of worshipping the best scholars. Something we could learn from in England!

A Major Attraction. Been here and enjoyed walking around and saw many students coming and touching turtles head for good luck and successful exam. Confucius temple is nice but a lot of smoke from incense stick. 1st Vietnam Uni just located right behind this complex after its restoration.Worth a visit and highly recommended

Historical place. It is a nice place to visit to learn a bit about about the Vietnam history and culture. However, if you go in November, the place is super crowded with graduating students taking photos. I went once in May 2005, it was nice and quite so I could walk around and enjoy the place.
students end day. just on the right moments to see studiants just celebrating the end of theis studies -- beautifull places
Visit in October. I happened to go on the day the students were graduating - the atmosphere was great! The Temple is worth paying to get into, and the gardens are beautiful.
A must visit place. It's very beautiful place and full of history. Ticket fee is not expensive. I usually spend more than 2 hours in this place.

Good architechture!. its spread in a large area. Its much fun during the graduation season. you can see the students - girls in particular in beautiful ao dai dress! they are pretty. the place itself is nice!

peaceful. Peaceful place to look around. Beautiful building. Was very interesting learning about the first students to ever be accepted here and how they had to carry their school books. I happened to go during a graduation ceremony so it was lovely seeing the students in their suits and gowns. Pretty gardens.

Worth the Visit. When we visited this temple in late October, there were dozens of graduating students in caps and gowns having their class photos taken. Why here? Probably because this is the site of the first university in Vietnam, opened more than 900 years ago and in operation for more than 700 years. If you look at the back of the 100,000 dong banknote, you will see a picture of this temple. This is an important site in the world of education and the history of Vietnam. Spend an enjoyable hour or so at this most attractive and historic site.

Lovely! . We visited the temple in November, but caught a strange day, as it was filled with teenagers that had graduated! Basically, the gardens were filled with teens taking photos in their togas. Yet, the temple itself was nice, as were the gardens around it. It would be better if there was more info inside of it, but nice nonetheless.

My favorite stop in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature was the oldest university in Vietnam, established by followers of Confucius. The buildings and grounds are lovely and provided fascinating insight into the Chinese influence in Vietnam 1000 years ago. It is a tradition for graduating students to visit as a way of acknowledging those who came before them. The Confucius shrine at the heart of the complex was truly spectacular. Highly recommend visiting if you are in Hanoi.

make an offer. this is where students come to offer something to Confusius. He will assist with exams and other study-related issues ;-). The place is not very large, but there is much to see. From the temple in the back, to the covered turtles who carry the diplomas of the old students.

Hanoi attraction. In 1070, this temple was dedicated to the philosopher Confucious, and six years later became a university. We had the unusual coincidence of being there during graduation ceremonies with hundreds of students in graduation garb.
Respite from the city bustle.. We visited here with guide from HanoiKids who provided many interesting details. It's worth a 30 minute walk through.
Graduating students. Well, bascially it's another temple! But the university part is a bit different, and we were lucky enough to see students dressed for graduation

Tempel of literature. The Hanoi Tempel of Literature is Vietnams oldest university, founded around the year 1000. It is built as a Confucius temple. Students from universities in Hanoi go there on graduation day to pay their respect. This is really place you should visit!
Wonderful architecture. Very nice building and gardens. It was our first glance at Buda´s statues. Gardens are very clean, in contrast with the city.
Old and new. this is a quaint pagoda complex with some very old bits and some modern parts made to look old so hard to tell what is genuine.

Go with a guide. We visited with a tour guide but noticed that you can pay for a guide to take you round as well.Today, there were masses of students there to have graduation photos taken but I felt that added to the place - good on them I say. It's Vietnam's first university so, for me, it was good to see students there.There isn't a massive amount of info on the museum which is why I reckon having a guide is a good idea but you can read about it online too.

Wow - so much learning. We enjoyed visiting the Temple of Literature - it was very beautiful. While we were there a lot of Vietnamese senior students were having their photos taken in their uniforms. They were quite beautiful.Looking at the history in this place, it was amazing to see how long 'learning' goes back in Vietnam!A recommended visit.
Temple of Literature. A great place to visit and take in the surroundings, spiritualism, atmosphere, architecture, culture and serenity.

Try to Go When It Isn't Crowded. We were there on a Thursday and the placed was filled with students taking their graduation photographs. This made it hard for us to really enjoy the gardens or stop at any spot for our guides to tell us more about the place. Speaking of guides, do engage one if you're going to the Temple as there aren't many visitor information signs to explain the different elements.

mixed feelings. Please take my review with a HUGE grain of salt. This place probably deserves a 4 star, but I just can't give it, based on my actual experience. Here are two areas that I suggest you consider before visiting:1. BUSY. The day I went, a Sunday in late October, it was packed with students taking photos and the place was completely overrun by them. This is a good and bad thing. Good, 'cause they are so excited and it is a lovely energy and it was actually the highlight of my visit, just watching them, BUT, it was overrun with them and certainly NOT the peaceful experience that I was expecting. 2. I made the mistake of not hiring a guide. I highly suggest you get a guide, so you can appreciate what you are seeing and the significance of this place.*** If you go, and want peace and quiet, ask about when the best time to go is AND definitely HIRE a guide. I think if I had done the later, I would have rated this a 4 star. ***

A must see iconic historical site in Hanoi. This is a remarkable site to visit. The beautiful courtyards and gardens are so beautiful. More amazing is that this is the oldest university in Vietnam dating a thousand years old. It is also a traditional venue for graduating students to have their graduation photos taken. Every courtyards leads to the main temple. This is a must see for every visitor.

Place with history. First university in Hanoi, built in the beginning of second millennium. But, I believe statues are more recent addition. I more enjoyed seeing the flocks of recent graduates dressed in beautiful costumes arrived for taking photographs. It's feel like a place of pilgrimage for Hanoi graduates.

Lovely grounds for relaxing and people watching . A lovely place to take a break from hectic Hanoi and enjoy beautiful grounds. When we were there there were many many students in graduation and traditional dress taking photographs and it was lovely to take part in some photos with the students.

Important piece of Vietnamese cultural/educational history. The site of the oldest university in Vietnam, originally a Temple of Confucius. The gardens are peaceful, with floral characters representing the core education principles honored in the pursuit of education. We were lucky enough to visit around university graduation time--when groups of soon-to-be graduates gathered for photo sessions. Their exuberance was a real treat. Visiting either early or late in the day might be an advantage. The presence of the students was an infrequent occurrence and, barring that, wandering the gardens and courtyards in a quieter time would be lovely.

Built in 1070 this ancient temple is a must see in Hanoi. This beautiful ancient temple hosts the Imperial Academy, Vietnams first national University.After entering through the ancient gates there are gardens and ponds. The Temple has pavilions and halls. When we were there the temple was full of university graduates taking their final year pictures. The young men in suits and the girls in traditional dress. This a marvelous place to visit and take a few steps back into history.
A+ for learning. Beautiful setting, full of history and respect for learning but also very much of the moment as the students receive their diplomas etc with their friends and families,

A must see. It is a beautiful location highlighting the center of learning for 1000 plus years. It has elegant grounds with ponds and pavilions. Make sure you look at the turtle sculptures. When we were there, hundreds of students were taking graduation photos and elementary school children taking notes. If you need a respite from the noise, you will enjoy this spot.

Peaceful. What a beautiful and interesting place so much to see. Very busy with students on graduation day, but very colourful. The temples are stunning and very informative with the history of Vietnam a 1000 years ago. A big must.

Vietnam's first university. A beautiful oasis of historical and aesthetic interest in the middle of Hanoi. A strong Chinese influence, the Temple is dedicated to Confucius and was responsible for Vietnam's first scholars.

Peaceful place in a peaceful city. The University is the oldest university in Vietnam, dating back few centuries back.
the gardens within the temple are so green and calm, good place for meditation and clearing your mind.
Highly recommend going there when in Hanoi

First university of Vietnam. I have been in Temple of literature for many times. It is very beautiful and interesting place to visit. If you want to see the symbols of Hanoi 1000 years old, you should go their. U can also see a lot of students come their with Vietnamese costume to take pictures

Curious place attracting Vietnamese students . A hetitage garden having old Viet structures. It attracts local students esp. on graduation day as it represents importance of knowledge in Viet society.
Some good quality handicraft shops & Viet cuisine restaurants are around the garden. It helps to plan a visit around lunch.

A former University with a longer tradition than anything in Europe. Beautiful elegant grounds with ponds and pavilions. Lots of Vietnamese people paying their respects and taking in the sights. We saw young graduates having their photos taken. This University had been a Confucian centre of learning set up to train an ethical and contemplative civil service.

Peaceful gardens in the middle of a busy intersection. This was a green haven in the middle of hectic Hanoi. Inside you somehow don't hear the traffic noise and there is a beautiful sense of calm. A fellow traveller told us not to miss visiting and she was right. A joy to visit and not hard to find.

large and confusing. Our guide was very informative. Unless you know a lot about Vietnamese culture, history and Buddhism already I don't recommend just walking around this place on your own. There is a lot to see and the day I was there, kids were taking their graduation photos and the grounds were crowded.

Beautiful buildings. Visited the Temple of Literature as part of the Hanoikids tour. A beautiful setting and well worth a visit, especially when all the students arrived to have their graduation photos done.
Graduation day. Wow what a beautiful attraction and we were lucky enough to be there on graduation day...a very serene feeling.

fascinating slice of history. An excellent historical site that is refreshingly different from a temple of other religious relic. Peaceful for a stroll and interesting exhibits. check out all the photos and displays!
Interesting History. The place is worth visiting, I suggest to read before you go so that you can ask questions to the guide efficiently to understand better
Lovely. Definitely worth going here. Beautiful gardens and temples. Just across the road from Koto restaurant which is a must to eat at
Cool. Very interesting place, so full of history and culture. Super impressive place. The atmosphere drags you and helps you get involved and understand the culture.

Interesting Site. When we visited the university, there were a ton of college students taking photos (graduation, we thought) so it was fun to watch them pose in their traditional outfits. The Confucious statue inside the temple is beautiful, as are the grounds.
Confucious. Interesting to be told about this centre of learning. The scholars had to pass 3 exams before they can complete and obtain their doctorate.

Distinctive Vietnamese culture.. This was a very unique place that had a deep Confucius impact, the kind of teaching that was popular on the Sino-sphere countries like Vietnam, China, Korea or Japan in the past. It was nothing like ours and we learned a lot about Vietnamese history here.

It is not just a temple. Beautiful architecture with great symbolism of Vietnam's old education system. It not only attracts huge number of foreign travelers but also locals including many group to students. This old city seems to be a not-to-be-missed to students who came here for graduation photo session.
Help me learn a lot about Vietnamese education and culture.

Nice place to see.. The place is impecable..garden very well,maintained..
Lots of students graduating and where there to pray..
Very Nice!. We have a tour with the Hanoikids They were very informative about this place. I like it because it's quite unique place to visit. I would recommend for any first time travelers.

Pretty and Interesting Tribute to Confucius. The grounds are beautiful. The temple is well appointed. The explanations are interesting. When I went it was not crowded at all and I was able to take some very nice pictures. It isn't a long visit, but the architecture and background are very interesting.

Beautiful Grounds. The topiary animals and the plants and flowers were quite beautiful and unusual. There were tons of students there posing for graduation photos. The temple itself is quite interesting. Note the tablets which recognize the best students from the 1461 for several hundred years.
One of the to-do things in Hanoi. To be honest, not particularly memorable or fantastic. Glad I visited and got it off the bucket list, though.

Brief visit is sufficient. Came here as part of day tour. Nice chinese style architecture influenced by Confucius. I had a local guide to walk me through the history and sorts. Not sure how it will go without a guide, as this looks like just a regular chinese temple with a small park and small pond in the compound.Been there done that once is enough. Was done in 15mins
A "must see" in Hanoi. Give yourself enough time to walk through all of the courtyards and temples. When we went there were hundreds of graduates in groups taking photos and celebrating.

Busy Confucian Temple. I got confused. There were hundreds of people - students in their graduation togas, wearing suits and traditional local dress. But, once I adjusted to the fact that that this is just a busy day, I settled into photo mode and even had pictures with the traditionally dressed girls and they were just ready to be photographed. They were friendly. So I just got shooting and got nice shots. Confucius would have been happy to see so many visitors.

Long Established Centre of Learning founded long before UK institutions. It was great having our personal guide to show us around this place and to have someone explain about all of the things that many visitors could just look at in puzzlement. Apparently this place was established about 1000 years ago as a centre for intensive schooling, the cream of pupils being selected as advisors for the Emperor. It was a nice calm environment to visit, closeted away from the hustle and bustle of the City.There were many intricately carved stone tablets that apparently record the details of graduates from centuries ago - the level of intricacy was amazing; quite some pressure job for the mason responsible.There were also nice gardens and a temple, where visitors could make offerings in return for the favours of relevant deities.
Wonderful visit. don't miss a visit to the temple. It was filled with high school students all taking class pictures. Very interesting

It looks like a general temple to me. it would be more interesting to me if I could read what are on the rock tablets. There were a lot of tourists, inside the temple. So I even could not get a single clean short. I like to have some exotic snack from the Vietnamese in the temple instead. Do not expecting you will see thing like in a postcard.

Ddefinitely worth a visit. This is a must see if you're in Hanoi & at all interested in it's history & traditions. The courtyards are incredibly beautiful & the whole area very peaceful. The craziness of the traffic outside pails into insignificance when you get inside the temple walls.
Not what expected. Not much interest for western travelers,could not understand a thing,should be some English description somewhere.

Where education begins. What an honor to visit this place. Vietnamese has high respect for this temple. I love the history and how students visited this place to honor those who founded the education in Vietnam.
A little bit of Confucius. A very atmospheric place it has a large statue of Confucius. Again the use of water and trees creates a calm environment and makes for a very pleasant experience.
Nice Temple. Interesting place to see in Hanoi. This temple is not as impresive as other temples in the east of Asia, but yet worth to visit.

A lovely place, but very few explanations. A lovely place to visit, but there are very few explanations -- I was glad I had printed out the wikipedia article prior to visiting. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temple_of_Literature,_Hanoi That way I at least had a little something to go on. That said, our visit was very nice as we made our way through the five courtyards. It was sweet to see recent graduates pose for a class picture in a place that has celebrated learning since 1070. Also some very nice shops where we stopped and had a conversation with the sales person who was studying his English grammar.

Interesting Place in History. Perhaps I’m getting a bit jaundiced over temples, etc – same as you get over yet another cathedral in Europe – but this one has a special place in the history of education in Vietnam and thus is worth a visit. It is however a progression of buildings and courtyards which have some significance but to the casual visitor it is hard to maintain enthusiasm. Interesting but I hope there aren’t too many temples to visit this trip.

A Good Place for capturing memories of Hanoi. This is a very popular tour site of Vietnam that dates back centuries ago. Considered as the oldest university in Hanoi, the place is so picturesque that college students in Hanoi use this place to take graduation pictures with their caps and gowns.When you visit there, make sure to stop over at Craftlink nearby to shop for crafts and works made by 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam. Craftlink offers quality and reasonable prices as part of fair trade policy for these ethnic people.

Loved it!. One of my favourite places in Hanoi. The oldest temple complex in Hanoi, where mandarins were educated for more than 7 centuries from 1070. The names of the scholars were carved on large stones, mounted on tortoise pedestals, and these, now faded with time, are still on display.Ornate gates, red and gold temples, sacred stone turtles and pretty pools. The grounds are well-kept, with flower displays and animal topiary. A group of musicians played traditional instruments in one of the buildings and there are displays of historic text books. Though busy, it still has an atmosphere of tranquillity and beauty.

Worth the look after all it's History.. If you don't know the history of this place or have travel book to tell you about it then get yourself a guide. the gardens are well maintained and there is just a vibe about the place but then the day we visited they had groups of Students doing there graduation.as usual with vietnam at the entrance and exist you have people trying to sell you stuff just keep saying "no thank you"
This place was amazing.. The day we were at the Temple of literature, There were many student graduating , these young people wore their mortar and gown with pride.

beautiful place worth visiting. The grounds of this campus are absolutely beautiful and worth visiting; it gives you a bit of insight into the value of academia endemic to Vietnamese ssociety,historically and contemporarily. Overall, I had a wonderful time the day we visited this site, and would recommend it to anyone that has an interest in the university experience.

preserved in its original architecture and spirit. The Temple of Literature is a temple of Confucius where knowledge and wisdom was passed on and honored. In the middle of the hustle and bustle of Hanoi are these grounds. Tho touristy by both visitors and locals, it is a wonderful place to visit and contemplate what it was to be knowledgible. There are numerous courtyards as you walk further into the property. As you walk deeper into the Temple, you will see folks in the midst of reading literature and learning. The architecture is beautiful and the relics here are in it's original condition....tho it's been refurbished beautifully. Bring a parasol/umbrella and sunblock....the mid-day Hanoi weather can be hot!

My favourite place in Hanoi. I loved the Temple of Literature :) it was so tranquil and pretty. And it gave a great insight to the history of Vietnam as well as to the lives of Vietnamese students today. We went there with a guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides - and she was amazing - so I recommend doing the same. And the venture there by yourself to sit and read a good book if you have the time.
Very touristy. Admission fee is 20,000 dong or smth. Very touristy place. But worth visiting once - I visited it on my one-day tour around Hanoi. Be aware it is very very hot there.
Beautiful grounds and temple. Peace and quiet in the middle of all the hustle and bustle of the city. Photo opportunies at every turn!

A bit of solace. We visited this temple after eating at Koto restaurant which is just across the road from it. It's a nice place to visit with an interesting history. Apparently students go there to make an offering/pray just before they do their exams. As such there were a lot of students there dressed up and posing for photos. It was great to sit there in the beautiful grounds and get a glimpse of the academic life of Hanoi students. It's also a great place to get away from the Hanoi hustle and bustle for a little while. Worth a visit if you've got the time.

A brief glimpse of the past. When I travel I am always fascinated with the culture, history, structure and civilization of the past. A trip down the Temple of Literature would give you a glimpse of the old structure of what the temples were like in the past. A very peaceful place at the heart of the busy streets of Hanoi.

Nice place to visit. I thought it was going to be more impressive in my mind. But I was glad I went non the less. There was a graduation of girls and boys going on and it made the experience most appealing to see these young minds exited about their next adventure.
a wonderfull place. we met there so pretty girls wearing traditionnal dresses!it was a graduate celebration!a big places between gardens and many tortutues statuts!

intersting - but not enough explanations. the place is interesting due to his amazing history, but the lack of signs with explanations ruins the special experience. also, not enough guided tours.its a beautiful place, but i wish i could learn more of it without going back to the hotel and use WIFI to read about it.
A temple dedicated to knowledge. This temple started as a university for the royal family and became a university in the old times. It is not dedicated to gods but to knowledge.
Insight into Vietnamese history. This was a fascinating and beautiful area to explore but I recommend you do it with a guide to get the full history and experience.

Tranquil. I agree with two previous reviews – this comes together having seen Hue and in the midst of the chaos that is Hanoi traffic this is a lovely tranquil spot. Interesting within itself and amazing that it has survived. Nice to wander but very good with a good written or live guide.

Very peaceful. This was a very peaceful and beautiful place. Very interesting to walk around and to read some of the history. Is a short visit and the kids were kept interested. Good when you have an hour to spare. Whilst there is a fee, it's minimal. There are good cafes close by.

Very nice temple. A very nice temple and interesting history and beautiful traditions. Although beware for the seller outside the gate of the temple. It happen to two of my friends, they bought 5 t-shirts but the seller only put four in the carry bag. Unfortunately we just found out when we are already left the Temple.
more interesting if you have been to Hue first. this attraction is steeped in vietnamese history and makes more sense if you have visited the imperial city in Hue first.

Graduation Day. Nothing much to see, nice enough gardens - although we were lucky enough to be there on graduation day so saw all the guys and girls in traditional dress. Lots of them together looked amazing.
Not expensive so I'd say pop in if you're in the area
Great. It was nice to spend a bout an hour over here. It was all about the Vietnamese and it's history. This used to be one of the eerliest university of Vietnam

A memory of a past system.. There isn't a great deal to see here: it is a reminder of the public service examination system that was critical to government for many years, but what remains is fairly under-whelming.

Historic ancient university. This is a large complex and takes time to see it all. Vietnam was invaded by the Chinese and ruled by them for 900 years,so this was an ancient university dedicated to Confucianism and education. In the heart of Hanoi and a peaceful oasis from all the motorcycles.

Change of pace. While staying in Hanoi you will learn very quickly that everyone is in a rush to be somewhere which is very exciting! However as a tourist you sometimes want to stop and take it all in. This is a great place to do it! As soon as you enter the main gates it's almost as though you are transported to ancient times and forget you're in the middle of a modern city. This ancient temple is actually quite well kept so you really get a feel of how study life would have been in this old world.

Relaxing!. In the midst of the kaos of Hanoi, the Temple of Literature was a relaxing, tranquil afternoon! Beautiful architecture and gardens. We went there with "Hanoi Kids" (search them), with two lovely students who were a wealth of knowledge. We hung there for a few hours sitting in the shade chatting and learning about Hanoi and the temple.

The first university of Vietnam. The temple was built in 1070 at the time of King Lý Nhân Tông. It is one of several temples in Vietnam which are dedicated to Confucius, sages and scholars. The Temple is located to the south of Thang Long Citadel. The various pavilions, halls, statues and stelae of doctors are places where offering ceremonies,
Amazing atmosphere.. Visited here for a couple of hours during the city trip. The temple was quite well-organized and informative, learned a lot about Confucius here.
Well maintained. Nice to see relics from centuries ago. They offered free guided tours from college students. Learned some interesting things.

Beautiful gardens!. A great place to visit. The gardens were immaculate..a real oasis in the madness of Hanoi, almost has a mystical feeling to it. Continuing renovations but didn't interfere with our visit

Oldest university in Vietnam. When we visited this temple of Literature and seeing the Steele, I was so ecstatic to realize this is something so real in the very, very old days. I am talking about the 12th century.Furthermore the cool thing is to see the new graduates from the Ha Noi university celebrated their graduation by tossing the diplomas was quite a scene to witness: new & old

Worth seeing.. Glad we visited and had a nice walk through.There was a traditional music group playing the day we visited and this added to the experience.The history is amazing and it is best to have a guide.

It is exciting!. The temple was first constructed in 1070 and in English, it means the Temple of Literature which is one of the famous places in Hanoi and considered by many Vietnamese as the first university. A must if you are looking to find inner peace while in Hanoi. :)

Nice place - would help if guide present. I visited this on my own. I had done my research so knew what to look for and where! But if this would be interesting if one has guide. It is really an oasis in a bustling city.

Must see. Beautifully laid out gardens, buildings and temples in the heart of Hanoi. Easy taxi ride from the hotel. A small admission fee is charged. The topiary is spectacular. History is well narrated in English signs throughout the property.

Interesting piece of vietnamese history. Located In the middle of the busy city. It had a Calming effect after about an hour walk. Ancient old university, beautiful temple and quite serene atmosphere despite of tourists flocking in. Would have appreciated some more info in English. Moderate fee.

Lovely spot. A fairly serene spot, although we were then when high schools and universities were have graduation celebrations. Well maintained gardens and very photogenic. Our guide had let's of interesting information. Also a temple for Confucius.

Beautiful Haven of Peace. God spot to recover from the traffic madness,
Interesting historical buildings set in large and beautiful gardens.
Guides very informative and interesting

Worth having a guide. We visited with Hanoikids and they were able to explain the significance of the buildings, statues and the kings featured here. I suspect it would not have been nearly as interesting without this. It is a nice little Oasis in busy Hanoi.

First under university in Vietnam from 11th century. Was very exclusive.. A bit hard to follow but interesting. The Buddhist temple typical and worth the visit. The stone epithets to those who earned their degrees is unique. Wouldn't call this a must visit but interesting.
Impressive Temple. Very impressive temple, with lots of history and characters. Simply beautiful. Look for the lotuses. Ask for the meaning of tortoises in Vietnamese culture

Ancient history. For anyone coming from a country without a long history (New Zealand), it is incredible to see and learn about a culture that revered education and an ancient tradition that honoured its best students with a stelae sitting on a stone tortoise.
