It is a pity that attractions such as this one, don't have a one page visitor's guide written in good plain English with a simple map. We had a guide, however it depends on their English; accent and pronunciation; and story-telling ability whether their talks are interesting and informative. We enjoy hearing of the history and culture of Vietnam, more so than the religious side of life, so this is one of the more interesting places we visited. The grounds are lovely and again the pools, water-lilies, lotuses and topiary make it a restful place to wander in.

Bit of a walk but worth it. Quite a walk from the old quarter but worth the effort. Set in beautifully maintained gardens, this temple complex makes excellent photos. The souvenir shops inside the complex are reasonably priced. Enjoy a smoothie at the smoothie cafe across the street from the main entrance.
Very Beautiful place. It is the first university of the ancient Vietnam. Must visit place. Very beautiful architecture and garden.

First university in Hanoi!. This is an interesting place as it was the first university in Vietnam and is currently holding many Confucius statue and many different art pieces inside.It is pretty spacious and hold many ancient statue leftover from the old university. It is worth a visit to soak into the cultural and art atmosphere.
Typical of other Chinese Universities. We found it very similar to other old Chinese University set-ups. The stelae are nice. The buildings surround courtyards and gardens.
Good place to visit!. It is a nice place to visit when you travel to vietnam. Clean and nice. Weather is good and bright. Recommend for every guest!!!

Interesting Cultural Site. Good attraction to learn more about the history of Vietnam.I had the benefit of having a guide arranged by the travel desk in Sheraton Hanoi, named Duc, he spoke good English, made all teh difference. Really learn quite a lot of interesting fact about how the Royal family promoted education and followed confucius as a role model for princes and scholars.Great to have this place listed in UNESCO as its the first university in Vietnam and contains steles that has each graduate's name engraved, dating back to 1442.
Ancient scholars. Beautiful landscape. Maintained well. Scenic pictures with ancient sculptures, lake and nice flowers.
Really so so .... It is not something to do... The price is not expensive, but u was expecting something big !There is nothing to see, nothing to do ...
Ancient wisdom. I booked a guide through hanoikids.com and it was well worth the one-on-one tour. Vietnam's first university reeks of history and ancient wisdom.

Lovely for a casual walk around. I am not sure how it works, but we were lucky enough to be there while many students were taking graduation pictures. I have noticed other reviewers posting the same thing, so I can only guess that there is a small group daily that receives their certificates (we were there at about 11am). The grounds are lovely and it is nice to ponder the age of the building and those who have wandered about in the same space.
Interesting but a guide essential. Fascinating due to age however without an English speaking guide, we would not have gained an understanding of the University

Beautiful and tranquil. This place is such a beautiful sight to see. The new section is very modern and beautiful and as you work through it is more traditional and offers temples and beautiful landscapes.

Beautiful escape from Hanoi hustle and bustle. The Temple of Literature is the oldest university in Hanoi I think. It is beautiful and so peaceful - really good place to go to if you want a break from the hustle & bustle of Hanoi. It's really well laid out with gardens, ponds and pagodas. The pagodas are so ornate and colourful - absolutely stunning
Beautiful history. We went to the temple as part of our Hanoi highlight tour. It is a beautiful temple with a lot of history and is very well preserved. One of Hanoi's must see

Really nice & relaxing. Nice place to walk around and spend some time. Aside from the temple, there is a park to the left of the entrance, and a few food & juice stalls to the left. Overall, a really nice spot to spend an afternoon.

Serene gardens, lotus ponds. Peaceful gardens, lotus ponds. Temples, gardens, courtyards in the heart of a bustling city. Artisans at work creating calligraphy
traditional buildings - bronze urns.

Nice place. A must visit while in Hanoi, but one of the few places where you'll be harassed by vendors on the entrance. Usually Vietnamese people is not pushy, but here you'll be overwhelmed by people offering you (overpriced) fans, postcards and handicrafts. That's the only thing that I must warn you, besides that, is a very interesting and nice place.

Historical Temple. Peaceful and spacious. Ancient doors. Nice altars.
Has to pay for toilet use even having paid for entrance fee.
Nice and quiet. The Temple is nice place to rest of many loud motorbikes everywhere. Beautifull garden with old sacred buildings.

Learn Something about Vietnam. This is a good place to learn about Vietnam's past and its strong connection to higher education, the quiet you feel inside the walls takes you far away from the hustle, bustle and sounds of the old city just beyond the old walls... a special place of quiet.

great Classic fist university. this great palce to visit , the King so nice , the lake at the head of temple have many fishs , i love the to turtle . nice to see , i will recommendation to my family .
Temple. Brought here by my tour guide. Is good If u have a tour guide with u to explain the different architecture and history behind.

A Must when visiting Hanoi. One of the most historic and well preserved religious/educational sites in all of Southeast Asia. One of the earliest if not the earliest Universities established in SE Asia, and packed with historical and educational relics. The Temple has undergone a good deal of restoration since we first visited Hanoi 20 years ago, and it has become very user friendly for Western tourists. When we were there a few weeks ago, there was a musician playing "Scarborough Fair" on a traditional Vietnamese string instrument.
Best Attraction in Hanoi. This is such a unique and interesting stop - very lovely and peaceful as well as fascinating history. Worth the effort to make the trip in a taxi - you won't be sorry.

Definitely worth a visit. This is a well preserved part of Vietnam's cultural heritage dating back to the 11th century. We were fortunate to visit on a day that local students were using it to take their graduation ceremony photos, out of respect for the buildings tradition. But even without that, it's an interesting place to visit. Pleasant gardens to walk through, well preserved buildings and artefacts, and a nice bit of calm in an otherwise bustling part of town.

Interesting to pop in if you are in the area. We spent about 30 minutes here wandering the grounds. There is a sense of history but not so much to see. Worth popping in if you are in the area. 30 minutes to 45 minutes should be enough.
Some nice architecture, but that's about it.. We went here basically so we could see one of the many temples in Vietnam. The architecture was nice. Attraction itself was underwhelming.

Temple of Literature & National University. Been there countless trips yet i'm still drawn to its allure despite hordes of tourist,foreign and local alike streaming through its hallowed hall ! A must visit for 1st time tourist to Hanoi !
Historical place. Beautiful by its architecture and by its meaning!!!Good entrance fees. Clean. However quite crowded

Valuable. So nature and fresh from outside to inside. We need to buy a ticket to go in. It has a garden for parking and very cool for hot summer. This location is a first university in Hanoi where King's sons were taught and become an educational relic now. There has 82 turtle stones which are sympols of 82 doctors have extremly great results in all top exams. For Vietnamese students, we go there for praying for exams and taking memorable photos at the final student year with classmates and teacher in traditional ao dai. It's also time for students to report studying results to pioneers in Temple Of Literature. Really good to see for sure.

Literature Museum. Literature Museum, which is considered to be Vietnam's first university. It has beautiful gardens and buildings laid out symmetrically. It gives luck at the exam to touch the turtles. Also here there were lots of people, including a bunch of female students in their beautiful long dresses over trousers.Vktour were skilled to tell about the place.

why the coke machine ?. Well kept site. Amazing that this has been around as a place of learning for 1000 years whereas my University only started in the late 1950's I think.It is just a shame that some historical buildings have been taken over by gift shops ... and the eyesore coke machines are unfortunately placed.
The History of Confucianism. Beautiful old university for for those greats who studied Confucianism in the past. A beautiful piece of history and very inspirational for those who are students.
Very interesting. This is a nice place to poke around for an hour or two. We went with Hanoi Kids, and recieved an excellent tour of this Temple of Literature.

Nice place to kill some time. This attraction is a mix of interesting and "why am I here again". It was nice seeing students drawing pictures and rubbing the steeles (which you can't do any more). Couples were having wedding photos done which was a nice touch. The open space was wonderful and overall it was a good place to visit and cheap enough to get in. However, after visiting this place several times you realize that the place has been rebuilt and made to look old and the original owners would be turning over in their graves if they knew how commercial this place has become. Why is it that I can buy a frozen treat in a 1000-year old temple area? Really!!!
Ok. This is ok, not so much to see, definitely need a guide. Don't need so much time to see it all. A guide a good idea
Goood place for travelers. Histories, culture and memories in the central of Hanoi and its close Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is a nice place for both Vietnamese and foreigner to visit!
quiet nice old university. This is my favorite place to visit on weekend, just to browse the nice garden and relax. the ponds have lotus and you may see the flowers during the season.

What an education!!. Just to know this university started around 1076 and then to see the ancient exam results carved in stone on top of turtle monuments was amazing as was the Confusious Temple! Definitely worth a visit!

A pleasant way to spend an hour. A little way out of the main part of Hanoi, the Temple of Literature is a peaceful alternative to the bustle of the rest of the city. It's walled off from surrounding roads (seems bigger on the inside than on the outside!). You enter through the main gate and gradually walk through different sections - garden, courtyard and ancient buildings. The university is over 1000 years old. The isn't a massive amount to see but it's a nice enough place to while away some time.If you fancy somewhere to eat/drink I recommend KOTO just outside.

Ancient temple in city center. This temple is in the city center of Hanoi. Easy to reach by foot or taxi. There is a small entrance fee. Keep in mind that not everything is signed in english. We were here on a public holiday, so many vietnamese came to visit the temple. Which gave the site a nice atmosphere.
Turtles. Lovely buildings and structures. A lot of photo ops and products to buy. The guides are friendly and helpful and speak English. Well worth a visit. Lovely gardens and statues.

Beautiful and peaceful, but not much here. This is an incredibly beautiful temple and grounds, and I really liked the idea of exploring what was effectively an early university in the Confucian tradition. There's not a lot of information here, which is a shame - but it's cheap to enter, incredibly pretty, and a really nice oasis of peace and quiet in the middle of Hanoi.

hour visit more than okay. we visited the temple of literature for an hour, it was nice, large, with lots of things to photograph. Worth a visit, and when you leave, turn left and left again to reach KOTO restaurant, very good meals for excellent price!

Lovely. It was lovely to walk around here, very peaceful. Beautiful gardens too. I only had one bug bear and it's really petty. We paid to get in which I expected (obviously) but to pay to use the toilet I thought was bad when I'd already paid. I know I will probably get a lot of negativity for writing that as it was very cheap but I don't agree in paying anywhere to pee no matter how cheap. Lovely place to visit

Worth a visit. If you have the time this place is definitely worth visiting. It's a nice calm in the centre of Hanoi. The gardens are really pretty-was quiet early on in the morning which was nice because it meant you nearly had the place to yourself.
Stunning. Hanoi's most beautiful building. You could while away many hours in its serene grounds just taking it in. It is an absolute must.
Beautiful. Really a must see, it happened to be graduation when I was there an it was simply a gorgeous event and a very peaceful place in the midst of busy Hanoi. A must!
Special experience. A special experience visiting Temple of Literature. Extremely well preserved Vietnamese architecture.
Enjoyable. I enjoyed visiting this, though walking to it was a bit confusing. It was very charming and not too crowded. A must do on any list.

Serene but not sizeable. Although rated as one of the top sights in Hanoi, the Temple of Literature is on a much smaller scale to similar palaces in China, Korea or Japan (although based on the same courtyard concept). A pleasant sight and worth viewing but with limited opportunity to stand out for those who have seen other layouts of this nature. Of course, you can always dive into and research its extensive history but a first-hand visit won't (unless you are an archaeologist) reveal much of this!

Great historical complex. Don't miss it. Great history behind it....students go there to pray for good results in their exams...and many many good photo opportunities, nice grounds too amongst the shady trees on a hot day

The first University in Vietnam. An extremely pleasant and interesting attraction the 11th century temple of literature set up by Confucius for the education of the wealthy .Beautiful gardens and buildings .
A must-visit for anyone interested in History.. The first university of Vietnam. If you're interested in Vietnamese history, you can't miss it.

an OK experience. This is ah historical shrine to Confucius and the kings who established the first university in Viet Nam. The gardens are pleasant but the history is not sufficiently explained in English for us non-Vietnamese speakers. Overall, an OK way to spend an afternoon.

interesting.. Basically a temple dedicated to Confuscias with some lovely gardens around. This is one of the nicer things to see around Hanoi. The iconic symbol of this temple are stone tablets standing on the backs of turtles- the names of the graduate mandarins who have passed their examinations over the centuries.

Fascinating place of learning, history and architecture. Van Mieu, the Temple of Literature, was Hanoi's oldest university. Founded in 1070 and dedicated to Confucius. Emperor Le Thanh Tong declared that stelae should be placed for everybody being conferred a doctorate; therefore you find inscriptions of 1304 doctor laureates in the temple placed on the back of a tortoise. Coming here, you might see many Vietnamese students visiting the places as a ritual for good luck before they enter an important exam such as the entrance exam into college. Several attraction including Turtle Steles, Well of Heavenly Clarity, Lake of Literature, and Constellation of Literature Pavilion.Today the temple of Literature is an oasis amidst of Hanoi’s traffic noise. If you are interested in its architecture you will need a lot of time to explore the different meanings and usages of the five yards and its differences. The complete compound is arranged in the form of the human body. While the entrance to the compound is the feet, and the grave at the end the head.This is a most fascinating university compound. To grasp its logic and academics you will need an excellent guide. It is well worth a few hours of immersion and study.

More interesting things in town. This is more of an emblematic place for Vietnam, rather than a place with interesting facts. It is the oldest and most elite university, therefore having 1000 years of history. Its architecture is average and the gardens are well preserved.

Nice and relaxing. Very nice place to see. A kind of university. It is a good place to go to relax and get out of the crowds of the old quarter. You can chill in the beautiful gardens. Worth the entrance fee

One of the great place to visit in Hanoi. We went here last 10th of August 2014 with my partner by a tour guide. So I appreciated the temple because it looked different what I have been used to see in Thailand. When we went further into the temple we saw some performers of the Vietnamese musical instruments so, we let them do and perform the music by using their traditional instruments. It was very nice to watch them and listen to their musical instruments. After the show, they started to sell their prepared tapes for donations. As we going further inside the temple we saw some beautiful and artistic literature & other things. Strongly recommended this place to all tourists in the world to visit too.

First University in Vietnam. Our Hanoi city tour(self guided) morning part came to an end after visiting Temple of Literature. Since the Ho Chi Minh House has strict opening times we started our trip from there and came here before lunch. Architecture of this building was somewhat influenced by Chinese Architecture hence the buildings looked different to others in Vietnam. If you don't have a tour guide, it's better to buy the leaflet (8000 VND) with the tickets at the entrance. They have less illustrations in English on site. The leaflet was a good help.Worth visiting!We visited KOTO, which is in front of the Temple of Literature, for International Lunch and then to onward sightseeing.
Not to be missed. If you are interested in traditional musical interments and folkloric musicology, you will surely find this place interesting. It is the Harvard University of Vietnam.

A lovely place to visit in hanoi. We spent 2 nights in hanoi and the temple of literature/university was one of the nicest places we visited. The grounds are quiet, well kept and full of history and interesting architecture. Well worth a visit
Very beautiful. Loved this place. Very beautiful. Touristy, but so atmospheric. One of my Hanoi highlights. Go there!

Have You Ever Wondered. You realy need a guide to fill you in on this important part of history. I felt in awe of the previous lives that would have benefitted from the literature that was transponded both by the oral and written word from this great place.When you get to the end just comtemplate about the meaning of life through literature and hopefully enjoySee if you can
Overrated. Not much to see honestly. A few gardens, pool and some interesting sculpture and art but nothing to write home about

Tranquil and interesting. Great to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. An interesting site, cool to imagine the oldest university having stood here and Ho Chi Minh having looked at the exact same things as us! There are gardens, courtyards and a few buildings which act mostly as temples as well as some tortoises with grave stone type rocks on them (they mean something and it is better than it sounds..), go if you have time!
Don't missed it if you interest to history. It has long history. Beside it's nice courtyard, make sure you understand the history and function of each building in the complex to really appreciate it.

Nice place. The first university of Vietnam. Temple of literature has great architecture. If you want to take a wonderful photo, let's come here.After graduating from university, students often come here to take pictures and save their memory. You will she many "áo dài" and students.

Educational. You will get a lot more out of the Temple of Literature going with a tour guide. Our tour guide was excellent and he explained everything to us. We did not see any written self guided pamphlets for the temple.

Beautiful place. You don't need much time here but if you have an extra hour I'd recommend a quick visit. The grounds are beautiful and the temple and gates are nice. Lots of coffee places just outside too.

Diamond in Hanoi. I'm a huge fan of ancient philosophy, so when I found out that Hanoi has a temple of literature with several temples of well-known philosophers (amongst others are Confucius and Chu Van An), I knew I had to visit it no matter what.The Lotus pagoda was my first stop and hearing the story of the goddess of mercy reminds me of the Monkey King TV shows (with Kwan Inh Goddess) which means that Vietnam must have a very close relation with China in old times. Too bad they're not, at the moment.One of the best parts about this place is that it's got some souvenir stores around. I spent around USD 40 only for a full bag of souvenirs after some relentless bargaining with the store ladies. The area is really clean too, so the experience was completely pleasant. Will come back for sure another time when I have the chance!

Beautiful grounds. The grounds were lovely and peaceful. Very well maintained with some great photo spots. Would recommend dropping by. It took us about 45 minutes to get through the place. We walked through with tour guides and they were able to explain quite a bit about the history which was very interesting however otherwise there were no signs or plaques explaining which would be the only drawback if going through it alone.
Lovely architecture. A quick but very nice tour. Good neighborhood, we walked here from old quarter but took a cab back since it's very hot in august. Cab was under 5 dollae

A peaceful spot in a busy city. I've been around Asia enough that I'm becoming a bit of a jaded Westerner, loath to see yet another temple. But I found this one to be lovely: the grounds, the shrines, the buildings, the turtle stelae.. It also taught me something of Vietnam's history. And it's only a dollar to get in!There are enough signs in French and English to self-guide a tour, but tour guides are available in many languages.Two tips:1. Ignore the souvenir shops in the third courtyard.2. Go around the temple at the rear of the third courtyard to the fourth courtyard. It seems 95% of the tourists don't realize that the grounds continue.
Photo opportunity. A well maintained temple set in nice grounds and provides ideal photo opportunities. Cheap to visit and arrived via bicycle tuk tuk so the tranquility afterwards was well received!
A nice getaway for one hour. Beautiful gardens where you can get some calm moments. The entrance fee is 20.000 vnd and worth seeing.

Very nice place, indeed... One of the great tourist spots they have in Hanoi. I love taking pictures here.. They have lovely flowers arranged in Chinese words along the alley to the temple. The place consists of a quite big lotus pond, fish pond, flowery parks and the temple itself at the end of the place. Very suitable for those who wants to see the history of the literature of Vietnam.
A must visit when in Hanoi. When you are visiting Hanoi, this has to be one of the place that you MUST visit form my point of view. A very peaceful and serene place.

A great history lesson. I liked that it was still an "active" temple with people coming to pray and leave offerings. We went with a guide which really helped us to understand what we were looking at and get a good grasp of the history of the place. It was fascinating for my teen-age sons to hear about how valued education was back then and how hard it was to be accepted into the National University. There were not a lot of signs in English so either go with your guide book or a guide if you cannot read the Vietnamese explanations there. It would be hard to decipher what you were looking at without some explanation and you'd miss a good story.
Lovely and peaceful place. A great den if tranquility in the middle of the busy city. Great history, lovely architecture, serene place. recommended

Get luck for studying here.. When I was young, I came here for praying with good studying in my school. Until now, I have been here for sightseeing with my friend, in here nothing to change , they still keep ancient Literature of Temple , that's symbol of Hanoi.

Beautiful grounds, interesting buildings. I think it's probably worth doing this one with a guide to get the best out of it.A lot of the descriptions are in Vietnamese.Very pretty gardens.There isn't a huge amount here - but a guide can bring it alive and make it a very interesting visit.If you are curious about Confucious and 'learning' this is the place to go.

Worth a visit after the Hao Lo prison. I wouldn't make the trip just for this place. It is neat but fairly small with not too much to see. However, what is there to see is interesting. It is across the street from an amazing restaurant called Koto.It is within walking distance of the old quarter and jsut a few blocks from Hoa Lo prison.
Old university. Long history where students and parents come to pray and the students touch the head of the tortoise for good luck.

Calm and peaceful.. A firm NO! gets rid of the street vendors out the front, they are not over-pushy. Then inside it is all calm and peaceful. Be aware that the courtyards go on and on. Walk round behind each temple and there is yet another revelation...
Interesting Temple in the middle of Hanoi. We went to visit the temple for a few hours, it was very interesting, but to be honest an hour tops is all that is needed.

Give it a pass unless you're around the area. Nothing to spectacular. Unless you;re in the vincinity, visiting the tower flag, HCM mausoleum, HCm museum etc. then the temple of lit is just round the corner, 10mins walking distance. If you are in that area just to see the temple then it will not be worth it. 20k vnd entrance fee though, but you can spend up to an hr inside looking at the shops, eating an ice cream or just taking pictures in the water lily lake or main temple.

Nice Place but not much happening. Was a nice place with impressive history but lack of English descriptions so struggled to understand. 1$ entry so can't complain at that. No clear toilet facilities either which was bad for me.
A peaceful place to visit.. In a busy city it was nice to visit this temple. A peaceful walk around with information to read about it's history. The water in the centre has turtles in :)

An Oasis in the busy city. Every time I visit Hanoi I take some time to go to the Temple of Literature. IT was the first University in Viet Nam and the stellae still remember the outstanding academics that worked there. Now it is a beautiful place with a nice garden, where You can relax or meditate.Along with Hoan Kiem Lake, my favourite spot in Hanoi.
A must. Built 1070 by emperor Ly thanh Tong this beautyful park with its temples and ponds dedicates to the most famous scientists and writers merits an intense approach to Vietnams history

A very nice garden and link to Confucious. This is a site that unless you have a guide, you will not understand the story and purpose of the site. It has a lot of history and I think it is best understood with a professional guide. Otherwise, it just looks and feels like a traditional Asian garden and temple.
an oasis in town. originally a university for the happy few, it's a real jewel and oasis in full city center: stylish lavish green

Nice place to visit. I went there on a Saturday afternoon. It was not so crowded but the last place you can visit is a bit too touristic.
Beautiful garden and historical places.
A place to see anyway.

Another world in the middle of busy Hanoi. Regular tourists may not find it that way because they would visit in groups but the Temple of Literature on a quiet day would sending you centuries into the past. Every brick, every stone feel ancient.

Very nice place. The temple of litterature is by far one of my favorite place in Hanoi! Definitely worth to see, it is really pretty and i met some nice people there. I believe it gives a great image of the country.

Beautiful!. I come in Hanoi for Vacation in July 2014 from Japan
This temple is beautiful with amazing Garden and so nice Buildings
This is very traditional Asian place
Must see this place to understand many things of Vietnam!

Beautiful temple. CC ( 2013.08.01 )
I and my son visited there for watching Chinese-style temple. This place was not bigger than I think, but very beautiful. We walked around in the temple, and enjoyed temple's mood. There was not impressive thing, but the mood was worth to feel. Good place.

Interesting bit of history. The site looks really nice. We were guided around by a volunteer student who are there to improve their English. Her English was really quite good and she had lots of interesting stories to tell about the place, not all of them you kind find on the info signs!
ancient university. If the weather is hot...you should bring umbrella or hat. The place is quite hot and lots of people come here.

Worth a visit. It is worth a visit. Lovely buildings and interesting history. It's nicely laid out and well maintained. Was great seeing the graduates having their photos taken there; they looked beautiful.

if you want to find out the history about VietNam..... it is the first the university in Vietnam in 19th. come here, you can see six tree which look like Han word. and later you can see many stone turtle . in there has many name of the poinsettias in Vietnam History .Vietnamese prouds of them and before they have exam, they come here and wish!  And you can come here to do that!

Worth the visit. After spending time in Sapa it was good to find out more information about the various minority groups. We hired a motorbike from the Old Quarter and easily made our way out there. Nice little restaurant and cafe for lunches and refreshments. The only thing I could say on the negative was that the gallery isn't well vented or air conditioned and it was a little hot walking around inside. Outside exhibits are no problem - there is loads of shade.

A haven of tranquility in the madness of Hanoi. Well worth a visit - allow an hour or so... it's a poignant place - very interesting and lovely to wander round - not so much to do, but a nice atmosphere to absorb. It does feel like a temple of knowledge.

beautiful and serene piece of history. We went here with our guide, and I'm glad as there was very little information displayed around. Most was in Vietnamese too. He told us all about the symbols, the history and the purpose of the building and its role in the development of culture and peace in Vietnam. If we hadn't had him I wouldn't have had a clue! So I advise getting a local tour guide to give you information as you go round.
must see. The history of this place is magnificent. Nice garden and buildings.Interesting to see the old university.
A free tour is worth the effort as you learn heaps. The traditional band played "Click go the Shears" cool. The young tour guide certainly enjoyed her job and had a sense of humour

Pleasant Place to Stroll. This attraction comprises multiple courtyards, some with ornate buildings, others with well laid out gardens. Lots of attractive bonsai. It's popular, so likely to be crowded.
You can't miss it. Of course. Nice place to be and spend time but tomuch people inside ! May be it's beter to visit it very early in the morning, because when all buses arrive it's a pity!

Elite education. Surprisingly well preseved temple honouring Confusian education system and elite scholars. Vietnamese system appears similar to ancient Chinese system for training the brightest students. The symbolic displays of excellence and high ideals of learning have an inspirational effect. Temple grounds are extensive and well maintained. Well worth an hour.
Impressive and good trip for family. Easily accessible in Hanoi. Very well maintained and lots do history. Provides a good introduction to Vietnamese history and education.

Very interesting. This place was dedicated to Confucius and other scholars and was a very interesting place to visit. Firstly the gardens are beautifully laid out and the topiaries were very skilfully done. The temple itself is very old, intricate and beautiful.
nice & beautiful. I like all about this temple, this is the first univerity of hanoi vietnam. here you can feel the pass of culture
A small piece of calm. This is a fabulous escape from the hectic streets and well worth taking a walk around. Very much enjoyed our visit and well worth taking the time out to have a look around.
Worth the visit. Spacious and beautiful. Crowded - but no more than other popular sites would be. Stunning architecture. Well worth an extended visit.
Confucius He Say. Excellent gardens with lovely buildings. Worth a visit to soak up the atmosphere. Very busy as is Hanoi generally.

impressive building. This was the first attraction I went to see in Hanoi and was, of course, really impressed by the building as I'd not seen anything like it before. The Hanoians are very proud of this temple and it's very well looked after.

Education Nation. I visited with a guide from HanoiKids, who was typical of the striving students coming here to bring good fortune to their studies. Education is highly prized in Vietnam and woe to those who don't do well on the exams. In front of the various shrines are offerings of fruit and snack cakes, and students reverently bowing their heads. The vibe on the grounds of this ancient university is very much of a vibrant cultural institution and not the tourist ripoff attraction that it might be elsewhere. Don't miss it.

Great place to wander through if weather is good. This is a lovely place to wander through and learn something about the education system in Vietnam a long time ago. The complex has 5 courtyards which you can freely wander through. Don't miss the stone tortoise stelae. If there aren't too many tourists is a nice place to get a way from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi for awhile.
So peaceful. The gardens are beautiful - we were very lucky to see graduates having their photos taken and they were only too happy to have a chat.
Crowded, but worth seeing. I initially wasn't sure if we should visit the Temple of Literature, but when I found out it was a _1000_ year old learning institution? Definitely worth a stop.

Vietnam's first university. The Temple of Literature (Van Mieu) was founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Tranh Tong, and is a shrine to the Chinese philosopher Confucius. It was also the location for Vietnam’s first university and became known as a temple due to the close link between learning and religion. Must see is the third courtyard where you can see steles honoring the university's candidates. There are still 82 steles each carried by a tortoise (there were originally 117), which list the names, places of birth and achievements of 1,306 graduate students who accomplished exceptional results during the Le Dynasty, between 1484 and 1780. Entrance to the third courtyard is through the dominating Khue Van Cac (constellation of literature), a large pavilion built in 1802. The third courtyard also has a large pond (the Well of Heavenly Clarity)
Explains a lot. Vietnam's historical commitment to excellence in education is well chronicled at this interesting and easily digested museum. The beautiful gardens, alone, are worth the trip.

Recommended quiet place. When you have been walking the busy streets of Hanoi's Old Quarter for some time, it feels like a relaxation to enter the first University of Hanoi. The courtyards are beautiful, and it is possible to learn about student life as it was 1000 years ago.
It is definitely a place worth seeing while visiting Hanoi.
l

Great experience. We visited this temple with 2 guides from the HanoiKids Tour. The temple has a very interesting history and the fact that we had 2 very knowledgeable guides made the visit so much more valuable. There are lots of small details and interesting background stories... all in all a very satisfying experience.

Insightful. Chance upon this historical site in hanoi. Great history and insight to the past and evolution of Vietnam. past and present scholars and to be scholars all seeking for prayers in a well preserve historical site. some great and affordable souvenirs on sale as well, better bargain else you will be over charged.

Well preserved. Wonderful temple that has been preserved brilliantly. There were quite a lot of students who came to get graduation photos or to get luck for their studies while we were there. We had a brilliant tour guide that helped us understand the history and significance to the temple however they also have plaques in French and English as well.

Scholarly. A sight that struck us is that the local University students still consider this place as an embodiment of knowledge , we saw so many students who had come here for a photo session on graduation, beautifuly turned out young ladies and boys.This is a Confucius temple built in the 11th centuary, so well preserved and one can identify the Vietnamese architecture. This ancient city of Hanoi was a seat of learning . It is a hudge complex having many parts at the end is the Confucius temple, part dedicated to the literati of those times.

stunning. A family of 4 from Australia with daughters aged 9 and 11 and we loved the temple of literature. So much information about education and Confucius which was interesting for all of us. The beautiful musicians were enjoyable to watch. We even ended up being a bit of a site to see ourselves. Lots of Vietnamese people taking the time to come and click a quite selfie in front of our blonde girls, nod to say thanks, and take off. The floral art creating huge pictures in roses were amazing in October.

A Confucius temple. This is a Confucius temple similar in layout to the one in Confucius' birthplace in China. It is made up of halls, courtyards and places for offerings and homage. Vietnam's first university was built inside this temple complex. A must-visit when in Hanoi for historical perspective on Vietnam and understand the value of education to their culture. You'll easily spend 1.5 hours here.The site was crowded when we visited with graduating students from different schools in and around Hanoi. They typically come here for their graduation photo ops.

Enjoying the old Vietnamese atmosphere. As a Vietnamese, when I am living in Vietnam, I always tried to visit this place at least once a year to enjoy its peaceful atmosphere and pray for luck and success.
amazing. It is so peacful and traquil, and you get a very good insight into ancient culture, a must visit/see.

Must see. The history, calm, and elegance of the temple requires a careful visit. Great place to escape the bustle of Hanoi traffic while adding to an understanding of the proud Vietnamese traditions of education and service.

Incredible historical experience. We enjoyed the open nature of the museum and how accessible all the exhibits were to us. The original stone carvings are well preserved and the restoration of the huge timber temples and gardens is commendable. Beware it is extremely hot and the visit with our guide took well over an hour. There are fans indoors in places, but be sure to take plenty of water and I appreciated I had my own fan with me.

Wonderful experience.. A must see landmark in Hanoi. Beautiful temple which was very well presented. When we were there the local students were making offerings for good results and college placements. That made it more special.
Temple of Literature. Very interesting visit. It's obvious that Vietnamese people valors education what can be seen when little children try to contact you in a very good english!

Could be interesting, but wasn't!. We went here at around 10:00 on a Sunday, and by that time it was too busy - lots of tour groups, people having professional pictures taken, students graduating (according to reviews they seem to be there all the time?!) and people praying. I wouldn't normally mind so many people, but the pathways, staircases and spaces around the statues of worship are quite narrow. We did a lot of waiting - waiting for people to move, to finish taking photos, to finish praying - all so we could simply look around the place.There are a few signs in English, but they're very wordy and difficult to get through/understand.There was lots of litter, in the water and in the garden displays - made me feel a bit sad for the place, it deserves better care. It's also quite touristy inside, with lots of shopping available, which takes away from the atmosphere.I'm sure this place would be very interesting, maybe even serene, if you go early to avoid the crowds, and perhaps if you take a guide so there's someone to tell you about what you're looking at!The one thing I really did enjoy was the short music display from three talented ladies - nice to see the monochord being played so beautifully. Otherwise, I probably wouldn't bother...

A place of rich history. It was really worthy to visit this place because of the rich history and story behind the temple and the country's first university. It is really a worn down place, however it has been restored. It is also within walking distance from the HoChiMinh Museum and Mausoleum. They charge you 20k VND for adults and 10K VND for students(regardless of country)! So, just bring them along to get a discount! The day I visited was really special cause it was 2 days before the University Entrance Exam and guess what, it was packed with students all hopeful to get into Uni. It was amazing to see that belief that the locals have and the attraction come to life with that many people. It is said that you should touch the tortoises head to be smart and pray for good results from Confucius.
Calm and culture. A Lovely spot for quiet contemplation away from the hectic city. Very interesting to learn about the old university life and the intricacies of this beautiful structire .

A Point of Interest. A place of historical and culture significance, this temple certainly provided us with a unique experience.However this place is quite small and the attraction of it can be lost quite quickly.
Worth seeing ... but. Not one of my Number 1 places to visit... but certainly worth a look.A very serene and tranquil place within the hustle and bustle

Viet Nam popular destination. VAN MIEU – QUOC TU GIAMVM-QTG – the national university was established in 1076 under Ly Dynasty, and it had 5 different courtyard.Van Mieu and QTG are separated complex built at different times.- The first construction – Van Mieu is the place to worship Confucius by Ly Thanh Tong in 1070.- Quoc Tu Giam was built in 1076 by Ly Nhan Tong.At first, this was a school for the children of the royal family, children of mandarins in the court. Later on, it was opened for all strata in the society.Vocabs:1. The Four Pillars. The Four Pillars are the gate of VM-QTG. In the past, it reflected themselves into lake “Ho Van”. On the top the four pillars were “ flanking young lion and dancing phoenix” these are sacred animals that were usually built up in ancient common house. 2. The Three Doors  The Three Doors Gate has 2 storeys, 8 eaves opening to the 3 doors. Above the three door gate, there were written “literature temple gate”. And the shape in relief of “Two dragons flanking the moon”. On the left of the Three Door Gate there were relief images of “fish and dragon gathering” and “fish and dragon looming in the cloud” depicting the happiness of successful students. On the right, there were relief images of “big tiger going down from mountains” depicting the graduate start their career with strong confident.- The main door was only opened for the King and senior mandarins on great ceremonies(5) while the students and ordinary people go through the two small side gates.VM-QTG has 5 compartment were correspondent to the 5 basic elements of mental – wood – water – fire – earth.2. Dai Trung Gate ( Initiation Area) There are two big lakes here as the two dragon eye ponds in front of Pagoda,and common House in the rural north Viet Nam.- The main axis leads to the middle door of Initiation Gate(1). Parallel with main axis(2) are the two small paths leading strait to the two door at the right and left of DAI TRUNG Gate THANH DUC ( acquiring virtue) and DAT TAI (achieving talent).- This has deep meaning that learning hard will students to become qualified men of both talent and virtue and being able to translate into good service to the King and the people.- Among the 5 compartment of VM_QTG, this compartment(3) of Initiation has the nicest view and environment of hundred years old trees with nice shadow and flower all year round.3. KHUE VAN CAC (is the 3rd courtyard) KHUE VAN CAC was a pavilion of 8 eaves and one top roofIt was built in 1805 in dynasty of Nguyen Gia Long.The three words “ khue Van Cac” were put in front and at the back at the pavilion.Khue Van means the constellation of literature, education, examination. It’s quite suitable with VM – QTG in term of philosophy and content.Khue Star has a deep meaning of literature, khue văn according to the traditional explanation means the brightest constellation in the sky that has 28 stars. Around khue van cac, there were parallel sentences:“the constellation of literature in the sky as bright as the humanity in life”“Bich river of in spring time is as lively as learning for ever”3. Thiên Quang Tịnh ( The well of heavenly clarity) It is a water resource to make the climate of the whole complex equitable. The well has also a meaning as a natural great and bright mirror.The well has a square shape symbolizing the greenery land.4. The stone plaque82 stone plaques in these two sides are the real precious treasure. Listed the names of the doctor laureates of the Le dynasty for over 300 years.The on the two sides of well are the 2 rows stone of 41 stone plaques each in 4 houses.Between the plaque houses are two kowtow porticos built in 1863.In the two stela house are the stone plaques of the first exams of the Le Dynasty in 1442 and 1448.5. DAI THANH GATE  The structure of Dai Thanh Gate is similar to the Dai Trung Gate, it was built on august year 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong Dynasty. In the past, only on the occasion of great ceremony in kowtow of confucius, Dai Thanh Gate was opened.6. Đại bái mônDai Bai comprising of 9 compartment where the great kowtow ceremonies were conducted. Therefore in the center of sanctuary there was a great incense-table, above the incense-table was 4 big letters Vạn – Thế - Văn – Sư –Biểu praising confucius as the teacher for ever.Dai Thanh Temple was built parallely with the great kowtow House and these two buildings connected with each other by a small house. Dai Thanh Temple has 9 compartments and architecture of the later Le Dynasty. This is place to worship Confucius for his philosophy on life. 7. Thái Học university VM-QTG is the THAI HOC House the named university of the Ly Dynasty. Here is the venue of leaning and boarding of students.Khai Thanh House including First court House, back house, right house, left house, bell storey, drum storey.In 1946- these two buildings was totally destroyed by the War.The back House is the two storey wood building. In the middle of the first storey is the place to worship Teacher Chu Van An who has the first Deputy Head master of QTG.- In the second wood floor where worship 3 Emperors.- The first is Emperor Ly Thanh Tong he is the one to command to build the temple of literature in 1970.- Emperor Ly Nhan Tong formed Thai Hoc – the first national university- Emperor Le Thanh Tong who set up those first stone stela of the 82 stelae remained until now.
interesting building. A very interesting building and grounds - worth a visit. We had a guide which really helped us understand the interesting parts of the building and grounds

Place of calm and learning. If you want to know a little more about the educational and cultural past in Hanoi, with a bit of Confusionism thrown in -this is the place. When the tourists have moved on the gardens are a joy to sit in and meditate.

A must do in Hanoi. A wonderfully calm and peaceful oasis in the city centre. A very cheap and interesting thing to do in Hanoi. It is the start of education in the city and one of the first Universities. I would suggest paying a tour guide (not much at all) as they can provide the required background to everything you see around you. Pretty central as well and all taxi drivers will know where to go.
Historic hanoi. A must see in hanoi as it imparts some of the cities 1000 year history. But take a local guide as they can really add to the experience.

A look at the distant past. The grounds are interesting and the architecture is great. The various scholars are viewed as blank tombstone type cement placques sitting on the backs of turtles. The review of 1004 years of Vietnam history

Go early or later to miss the crowds. You will want your camera as this place is beautiful but best without the bus loads that come mid morning. It gets challenging to take a photo without loads of strangers. Enjoy at less busy times of day.
Downtown oasis. Beautiful grounds in the midst of the busy streets of Hanoi - definitely a must see! Really enjoyed the outdoor nature of the Temple of literature and the beautiful gardens.
Beautiful location. A lovely place to stroll around. Our blond haired children here proved to be more of an attraction than the location though.

Must see. The very first university in Hanoi, it's now a temple to Confucius. It's interesting to know a little bit about Vietnamese university admissions of the past. It'll be good to have a guide go along with you to explain to you more about the history of the place.
the first school in vietnam. good area, the people stay here all of forreigner and local people and special student, they come to here so much take some picture

Worth the walk. It was a bit of a walk from my hotel. Especially on a day that felt like 47 centigrade!It was very peaceful there even with other tourists there. The walls seem to keep the city out. Very nice because Vietnamese traffic is something to behold for tourists from outside of Asia.

Definitely take a guide.... Our guide book recommended that we should take an English speaking guide, however we did not really have the time.We found that we definitely should have listened! We found it to be rather underwhelming... we'd seen grander temples just wondering around, but we do think that this is because we didn't understand the significance as there isn't really any guidance or signs.Probably worth going to, but not worth it if you don't have a guide or good understanding of what you're looking at.

Go with a guide. This is a short ride (or walk) from Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum so could easily be combined. The grounds were nice, but without a guide I didn't really take much away from the visit. I wish I'd set up a tour with Hanoi Kids, which I only learned about on my last night in town! If you do go to the Temple of Literature, definitely check out the nonprofit Craft Link store just across the street (43-51 Vanmieu Street) for gorgeous, reasonably-priced textiles.

A functioning renovated temple!. Still students go to this millennium-old center to pray before their exams and graduation ceremonies are held to tie the contemporary to the Old, to the emphasis Confucius allocated to discipline and education. In this temple names of the best students of the past are honored and kings who contributed to this university recognized!

great place. This is one of good place you should go to visit when you come Vietnam, hanoi. Beside knowleged about people culture vietnam you can get and meet Vietnam girl in their traditional clothes

Well Maintained and Peaceful Ancient University Temple Complex. The site of Vietnam's first university, from the eleventh until 18th century, the temple is now a historic site and active temple, consisting of pagodan buildings around a front and central courtyard, with stone statues and other religious altars and images.We found the temple complex very well maintained. The gardens are lush, with lily ponds full of lotuses, and beautiful old trees, and we spotted several frogs. The buildings and statues themselves were in good condition, without having lost any of their historic charm.What I enjoyed the most is that the temple is still visited by Vietnam students, who pray and give offerings to ensure good school marks and entrance at the university of their choice. There were well over a hundred young scholars there when we visited, some with their parents (in some cases praying harder than their children!). A lovely glimpse into a tradition where modern Vietnam meets ancient.The complex can be visited in an hour. Try sit in the gardens while you're there as respite from bustling Hanoi.
Greeeeeaaattt!. A very interesting place to learn about a part of the Vietnamese history and how the Vietnamese university admission process once was.

A place full of culture, knowledge, and history. A must-see if you visit Ha Noi! Every corner of the site is worth seeing; they contain all the history about Ancient Vietnam. The place is very well preserved. However, there is a very small fee for entrance ticket (20,000 VND/person, which is barely $1/person). Prices for the souvenirs are fixed and reasonable.

Nice to visit. As I am a professor, I suppose this place resonated with me. There is a feeling of quiet and learning here that is just special to be in. Good photos and interesting history. Probably a one hour stop at max though.
Nice place.. very quiet. Quite a big compound. tickets are at 20000 dong. if you are a student, show them your pass and get it for 10000 dong

Absolutely loved this place.. The grounds are gorgeous at this first university for Hanoi. Each courtyard is beautiful and the last one with Confucius is really wonderful. Give yourself enough time so you don't have to rush. Also there is a great place to eat if you go left out of the gate where the busses park, it is pho 24 or 29.
Great piece of history. The site is so well preserved and the age of the buildings is mind boggling. A very pleasant place to wander through and enjoy the history.
Temple Of Literature and Nat'l University. Beautiful grounds and statuary in a surprisingly serene setting within walking distance of the CBD. We also were fortunate to see a graduation .

Worth visiting. It was relatively cool when I went so comfortable. The topiary trees at the entrance were very good. The place is easy to walk around and get some good photos. It probably takes about 30 minutes to see everything.
the first school. have so much student come to here cray for they exempt good luck the culture stay here very very so much information about historic in vietnam as some kinds in vietnam from 1898
Best historic garden and buildings in Hanoi. Make sure you visit the Temple of Literature the symmetrical layout of this historic garden and the architecture of the buildings is amazing. A must see !

Temple of Literature,Hanoi. It was graduation day so lots and lots of excited students.....many of the girls in traditional dress.
A lovely place to visit

1 of the Best Attraction in Hanoi. This is one of the best attraction in Hanoi. The history and architecture of the temple is truly astounding. The details on the roofs and pillars in this temple are so intricate and complex, it makes me wonder how they were able to do it 1000 years ago. The cost of hiring an English speaking guide is quite high. Other than that, it is a worthwhile visit.

Well worth seeing. The complex consists of a number of buildings culminating in the most important. It's worth taking the time to stroll through and admire the ponds and architecture of the grounds. Be sure to go upstairs in the final building as there are some very nice statues there

Need more English explanations and perhaps an English-speaking guide. The Temple of Literature showcases Vietnam's educational history and tradition, but the lack of English texts and the need to pay for a guide (from hotel or tour agencies) made it harder for lone travellers to understand its history. Compared to Japan and China, this place is not that impressive on the whole.

Pleasant and interesting.. This Temple and park are worth seeing if just for the history alone.Original site of learning in the 1400's, nice parkland and serene in its setting.20,000 dong to enter, feel they perhaps could have a few more descriptive signs in English.Grave sites are marked by a sculpture of their sacred symbol the tortoise, temples are very ornate.Well worth an hour or so to view.

Temple of Literature Hanoi. I visited Temple of Literature Hanoi (Van Mieu Quoc Tu Giam) together some friends, I understood more culture Vietnam 1000 years ago, Thanks Ms Moon tour guide introduce more experience Hanoi City tour and Person culture
Great place to visit. Visited the Temple with our very helpful and informative "Hanoi Kids" as guides. It was great to have a guides otherwise we would have missed lots.

Learning is king. Competitive exams, sponsorship awards, doctorate scholars.. hundreds of years ago.. where Confucius is god , and young take pictures on the grounds at graduation.. a pleasant place to see in an hour..
Worth the visit. A Nice temple, quiet within the hussle and bussle of Hanoi, would recommend if you have a spare hour
ancient place. history is very good and many people go there. it has nice gardens too. Guide talked about everything very well and I understand it all.

Number one Must See in Hanoi. Temple of Literature is in the heart of the city just outside the old quarter. It is the oldest educational facility in Vietnam. A Hanoi local and good friend took us and gave us many ins and outs you would not get otherwise. She explained about their yearly visit at Tet for the family and one of her great great grandmothers is represented on one of the stella. Lots of local students there posing for graduation photos and that was very fun to see. Just a great place to visit and get relief from the busy city.
good temple. the most famous temple situated in hanoi,also functioned as vietnam's fisrst university.sages and scholars.a vast structure that has exixted to present day.
Amazing monument to literature. A beautiful place to wander and admire the ancient teachings of literature and APRECIATE it in all,its glory

Something of interest to see whilst in Hanoi. We did have a guide from Hanoi Kids that explained a lot about the history, I think it would be difficult to appreciate it otherwise. Worth a look if you have the time.
Nice to take a look around at.. The big attractions in Hanoi are limited. If you are in a city, it's a good thing to stop and see. Well labeled in English.

Smaller than expected but very beautiful. Me and a couple of other girls went for a visit here as it sounded like something a bit different to do.
It was a lot smaller than we expected but very nice nonetheless. It is interesting to find out the history behind it, and the scenery there is lovely.
Worth a visit but don't expect too much from it

Possibility to see students graduate. Calm place in otherwise loud Hanoi. The temple is somewhat interesting, but if you are lucky you get to see newly graduated students. The girls wear lovely dresses in bright colors.

Very beautiful. the garden is lovely with beautiful trees. The temple very interesting and informative. Several floors in the palace, where we admire Confucius, among others. On one wall, there is a "table" on which is written with his finger a vow. I could learn more, but all Vietnamese engage in this practice.
May 2014

Really enjoy the atmosphere and historic value of the location. It is after all, Vietnam's first national university. Informative signs are displayed around the grounds but I particularly enjoyed the atmosphere of the area, and just taking in the historic value of the place. With some imagination, one can picture how things were like centuries ago. Today, it seems like many Vietnamese students like to take graduation pictures here, giving a taste of how student life is in Vietnam. Highly recommended for anyone interested, but do expect that you will be walking outdoors. At VND20,000 or USD1 per person, you really can't go wrong visiting the Temple of Literature!

Beautiful grounds!. We had a guide show us through the grounds at the Temple of Literature which seemed to help out quite a bit. It isn't too big so you can do it on your own but it was nice to have someone showing you the ropes.

Beautiful, historic place. It is clear this place means a lot to the Vietnamese. It is so picturesque and has the ability to transport you back a thousand years when scholars would study Confucianism here. Nowadays university students come here on Graduation Day to take pictures in this wonderful backdrop. If you are lucky you may be asked to be in their pictures! Highly recommended.

A Gem of a Museum. This was our favorite museum in Hanoi. Because it is outdoors, we had to wait until the weather cooled down. We like the history and antique artifacts of this Confucius school. We also found a lot of souvenirs we liked at a reasonable price.
Great - worth a visit. I was surprised how much I got from this visit. Nice place to come and visit on any stay in Hanoi. Beautiful gardens and the Confucian temple is fabulous.

definitely worth a visit. If you are interested to know more about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam this is a place to go. Each ethnic group is presented by original products and clothes. There are also a lot of interesting films to watch concerning traditions and life of the different people- There is also a garden where they built up traditional houses. It gives a small Impression about differences between ethnic groups, their daily work and their way to live
Must See in Hanoi. Beautiful place to visit in Hanoi. The gardens are well kept and it is very interesting to see the first university of Hanoi.

Very small. Its a very small compound and while its very well maintained, some look like the person maintaining the place took some creative liberties when putting it together. The individual items of interest are not very well labelled but I suppose the biggest issue I had was that it doesn't give you a sense as to what its impact or relevance was on today's Vietnamese society.
Worth visiting. It was quite a big complex, and was beautifully landscaped, with well-maintained gardens and ponds. Great for pictures!
Beautiful. Very peaceful place to visit. Would advice to visit in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the overwhelming heat.
Beautiful grounds and buildings. A very interesting and beautiful place to spend an hour in. Really nice gardens and interesting buildings. Definately worth a visit.

Don't bother without a guide. The Temple of Literature probably has a lot of interesting history but I wouldn't bother attempting to go there without a guide. You can walk around but it really is a series of average looking gardens and no real english explanation for what you're looking at.

worth visit. its easy to find in central of Hanoi and in the middle of traffic road. entrance fee is OK, place is huge, clean and many temple to visit and god spot for photograph. i see many students took a photo with vietnam costume, they are really nice girls and sometime they ask for blessing for their final exam. it is worth visit when you are in hanoi.

Very interesting. Again as indicated in other reviews, we ere so thankful that we had a person al tour guide.I found this attraction, aside of the Cyclo Tour, the most interesting. The structure and architecture are nothing great and similar can be seen in many Asian cities.It is the purpose and the history when combined with the environment/architecture that makes it a must see for me. Our tour guide, his historical facts and stories gave meaning to what we were looking at .

Great place for history lesson. A lovely place, wonderful well set out gardens with ponds. It is a very big complex with many tablets to read about scholars who have attended in the past. The temples are very exquisite and the musicians that were playing were very accomplished. Our guide Hoa was very knowledgable.

Place of Learning.. on the day we were there , we met students who had just graduated. They were full of fun and happiness, they requested to have their photo taken with us. It was a good experience of Vietnamese people, they are so nice and gentle.
Tranquility. A lovely tranquil place to visit in the heat of the day. Beautiful ponds full of lilies and lovely flowers all around.

Amazing Temple!. This temple gave us more understanding of Vietnam and the Vietnamese culture. Many students were there when we came. All of them came for good pictures with temple. It is a good place for pictures as well. Highly recommend this place if you have a chance to travel in Hanoi.

So interesting. We went to the Temple of Literature with Hanoi Kids and we thoroughly enjoyed it. Since we went in low season, there weren't many people there and we were able to spend time looking and listening to the fascinating legends that the girls told us.

You shouldn't miss this! . I heard this is the oldest university in Vietnam so it's a must see for all tourists! ☺️ this is where Vietnamese students pray for their examinations so I was also able to do that too, to pray for knowledge! I enjoyed visiting this place! You shouldn't miss this!

Made a great photo day by the graduation 'kids'. The Temple and it's gardens are a nice stroll but not exceptional. What made the day here were the children, of all ages, in their gowns and mortarboards and the pride in their achievement. They also enjoyed having their pictures taken with 'westerners'!

Nice introduction of Vietnam. First time been there but felt that this place gave quite good information about Vietnam. Luckily we had a tour booked and got a nice tour guide who did not mind talking and giving all related information :)

So old….such history.. We had a guided tour around the university and it just amazed me with how much history is contained within those walls. Interesting, amazing, beautiful, peaceful. A real cultural experience.
Pretty Average. There are much better temple's in Vietnam, this place is pretty dull. Does have some interesting history about learning in Vietnam

So lucky to visit on graduation day. We were lucky to visit on graduation day, the girls in particular wore the most beautiful long, white and floral dresses. Nice to take a leisurely walk through the beautiful gardens and buildings. Lot to see, well worth a visit.

Cool. When I went to this place, there was an occasion, a lot of primary pupils there, I don't really know what occasion, they wore uniform and an unique white hat, like "ancient hat"..... The garden very neat, and chinese character so obvious, since the character made from plants. Yes, there was not much in there, but sightseeing nothing to lose (I joined a tour :)) Appreciate the cultures of other people *~*

Good Insight into Ancient Vietnam. We spent quite a bit of time in this peaceful and beautiful area of Hanoi. I found the architecture, the history ,the grounds and the artifacts interesting and intriguing. The place was busy and for a reason in that it has much to offer to both locals and tourists. The small fee of 20k VND is with it providing good value.This is one of the better attractions if not the best in Hanoi thus don't miss it and make sure that you stay in Hanoi at minimum three nights!

a must sightseeing to explore. We, at Cosmos Travel Vietnam Co., Ltd, put into our programs for our clients from Australia, Canada, USA. They appreciated the Temple of Litterature as back to the lost time with Vietnamese civilisation and education system in the feodal dynasties. This is worthy for whom are looking to study Far East culture.
Boring. nothing to see here except the poem written on a turtle back. Some local student took their convocation photo here.

Not much to see. We thought we'd check it out, but I didn't find much very interesting to see.
I guess it's alright if you are in the area. I wouldn't spend more than 20 minutes here.
Nice gardens, and a bit of interesting reading.

A slice of history in Hanoi. A nice, traditional Chinese-style attraction that will take you about 1 hour to go through. Some interesting architecture and decorations in here - very Confucian. Helpful if you go through with a guide to explain the intricacies of the Temple to you.

Very pretty.. We walked from the Old Quarter to this area which was a nice distance and we saw a lot of 'real life' on the way. Temple is really pretty and houses the shrine to Confucius, which was really interesting. Students celebrating their graduation arrived while we there to pay their respects to professors who have taught here over the years. It was nice to see them taking education so seriously.

Temple of literature, a step back in time. This was such a beautiful place, tranquil and serene escape inside a bustling city. You can almost see the academics of a thousand years ago softly step the stone pathways. This was a place for the rich and privileged sons of the era, but the beautiful turtle statues and design, gorgeous old traditional buildings and the musical displays make this a worthwhile trek while in Ho Chi Min! We took a four year old and a baby and they coped beautifully as there was so much to see and do!

Place to release your spirit. Very charming place, try to reach it as early or late as possible according to the working hours, when it is not crowded it is a perfect place to contemplate, meditate. The yards and temple is rebuilt but in a most perfect way.

A living part of Hanoi. Over the many years living in Hanoi, I have always told visitors that the temple of Literature remains one of the top spots to visit in the city.Beyond its well tended gardens, stocked fish ponds, and beautiful courtyards remains the fact that the Temple of Literature is not just part of the country's long history, but rather a living connection between past and present.It is still a common sight in the fall and spring in particular to see large groups of students coming to pray at the temple before they start the school year or for the graduation ceremonies. Likewise, you can always find the occasional nervous student attempting to rub one of the many stone turtles' heads in the hopes of having some good luck during their next exam.The only major downside of the place is that the exhibits are often poorly tended to and usually have no descriptions whatsoever, but this does little to spoil the effect of walking around the grounds.Simply put, I have been here at least 5 times with guests and I can imagine returning at least another 5 times when we have company in Hanoi
The history is inspiring. This was an unexpected gem on this trip. So much academic history in such a small area. Well worth a visit whilst in Hanoi.
Middle City Oasis. Right in the middle of the hussle and bussle. Quiet and peaceful, such a lovely place. Take your time to really appreciate the age and the history here. Wonder the gardens

Worth your while. This place is very historic and holds a lot of value for the Vietnamese people.
Definitely worth your time when you want to see the heart of Ha Noi.
There are also some nice places for lunch around the complex.

A fine place with some good stories. Dont miss this place if you are in Hanoi. They have some great temples, great statues, and great stories to tell. This is one of the oldest temples/universities in Hanoi. You can even see pictures of the old teachers, and at some time you could also see all the names of the people that went to the school.Just give it a good hour, and your done!

A nice break from the bustling metropolis.. I came when shoolkids in their suits and traditional dresses were taking graduation(?) photos. That was very nice. The temple itself is also very enjoyable and provides an insight into the Vitenamese culture. A nice break from the bustling metropolis surrounding it.

Interesting place. But to appreciate it get a guide. I visited the place while there were alot of students praying for their upcoming final exams, provided for a really unique experience and numerous photo taking opportunities.

Small oasis nearby mausoleum. We didn't spend much time here, a quick walk through as unguided tourists. Lots of students celebrating graduation as it is the oldest university in town. It was very hot around 40 degrees but. Couldn't really get excited about the place.

One of the most highlights of Hanoi. You should not miss this place when visit Hanoi. Beside the value of History, Culture, it is a green place to go with the small lake, lush garden that give you a very good atmosphere from the crowded Hanoi

Historic, beautiful, and peaceful. In the midst of the buzz and noise of Hanoi streets, it was refreshing to enter this area of relative calm.It immediately reminded me of a small-scale Forbidden City (Beijing), but I found it nowhere near as enthralling. It is beautiful with the gardens, pond, and various courtyards and buildings.Worth visiting for its historic value, and its peacefulness.

Lovely architecture and grounds. A little bit away from the Old Quarter, the Temple of Literature is definitely worth a visit! We went on a very hot day (when isn't it hot in Hanoi?!) so we were sweating buckets after our jaunt through the five gardens. Took some amazing photos here and then made a swift exit to find somewhere with air-con! Entrance fee is cheap.
Interesting. This place is full of history and certainly enjoyed our visit there our tour guide was very informative

Beautiful Place. We went here as part of a trip with Hanoi Kids. This is a special place right in the centre of Hanoi, our tour guides gave us plenty of information on the temples and University. Very reasonable entrance fee, definately worth a visit if you are in Hanoi.

Beautiful place. This is a beautiful temple in the city. The day I went there are many children taking their preschool graduation photos there. Also high school girls doing the same.
The compound is nice and the atmosphere is serene. Worth spending some time walking there.

Great with a guide. I had a guide for my tour through here and it made the experience so much more interesting than it would have been otherwise. It was a beautiful place to visit but having someone who could explain the history and answer cultural questions is a great addition.
Impressive temple to Conficius. A temple to Confucius, this is also known as Vietnam’s first University dating back to 1070. Must to visit and take a tour through the temple complex. It's impressive.

calm clean cozy spot. Calm clean cozy spot with green plants.
The most inner wood house has 2nd floor and,
I could look over the surrounding old green area.

The beautiful place in the heart of city. Really peacefull and beautiful place. it's still original caulture. it's not so far to walk from oldquater hotel we think the better to take a taxi first and after that you could be walk back
recomend to many other travel..

Lots of grads having photos taken here. We were lucky; schools of students were having their photos taken and throwing caps in the air. The grounds were beautiful and and the temple well kept. An air of dignity freshened by all the optimistic graduates.
Well worth visit. Great with Hanoikids tours ! Bach gave us an excellent tour of this significant site ! Our 9 yr old enjoyed this site

Nicest sight in Hanoi. If you are short of time in Hanoi and can see only few places, go here for sure.
Entrance fee is 20.000 vnd.
There are buses 18 and 34 from the old quarter stopping just nearby, so no need to take taxi. Ticket is 7.000 vnd.

Fascinating history, beautiful grounds. Definitely worth having a tour guide show you around, we got so much more out of our visit by having someone who could explain all the great history to us as we walked around.Make sure you come early though! We went first thing in the morning, and as we were leaving and hordes of primary school children were arriving we could see why our guide took us so early, much nicer when it was quite and you could stroll around the peaceful grounds.

Beware potential short changing scam!!!. We went here after just arriving in Hanoi and Vietnam, and were still getting used to the currency. We paid our entrance fee and double checked the change in full view of the ticket booth as we always do expecting it to be correct. We checked again and again and came to the conclusion we were 100,000 short, a fellow tourist who was next to us in the queue was doing the same and she was 50,000 short. As we turned back to the booth the ticket seller produced the 50,000 and 100,000 bills from by the side of her...no apology, and very coincidental that both of us would suffer a genuine mistake, it was just as though she was waiting to see if we would notice! I would advise all travellers to double check your change when visiting.This took the shine off what is a very nice temple in honour of Confucius and a history of learning in the country. It is well kept, and whilst we were there it looked like students were celebrating passing their exams by posing for pictures in their robes.For this reason I have to give it a low score to highlight this potential problem.

Nice but try to go when not crowded. I visited the Temple of Literature on my first day in Hanoi, hoping to escape the bustling city streets in exchange for some peaceful grounds. While the architecture and history was intriguing, there were several large tour groups at the site which made it rather difficult to fully enjoy. I would recommend going early before the midday crowds.

totally shock !!!. It's was quite a beautiful place with a lot of historical meaning, the traditional music performance was excellent, and you got to see a lot of students in their graduation which is quite nice.... But way..... STEPPING ON THE TURTLE TO CLEAN .... I WAS LIKE " WAIT ! ARE YOU KIDDING ME" at that moment !!!
Pretty Grounds. Nice landscape and a gives you a good imagination of how students studied back in the day! I got to witness students graduating at this place, great experience!

The oldest architectural complex in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature was a university founded in 1070 in honour of the philosopher Confucius. There are five courtyards, with the first two featuring manicured gardens, and a banyan tree that is 1000 years old. The third courtyard contains a large pond, with buildings on either side that house stelae (tablets) dating from the 15th century. These are inscribed with the names of scholars. A path through the centre of the complex leads you between high gates and walls. Present-day graduates often come to this temple to have their photographs taken, and it is a treat to see their happiness and pride.
