In the centre of the complex, The Altar of Confucius, contains statues of cranes standing on tortoises, which are symbols of good luck. This leads to The Temple of Confucius, where there are statues of the great man and his disciples. This beautifully-kept complex is well worth a visit, and guided tours are available.
Great way to experience Vietnamese history. Went here with a guide and the history is fascinating. Was a great way to help imagine what ancient Vietnam was like and what was important to them.

Interesting Temple of Literature.. Lovely place to visit, as some of the artifacts still well kept.We learned about the history and tradition of the scholars in the older days at this Temple of Literature.

Take time to relax and admire this wonderful historical site. It helped that we had Sky, one of the Hanoi kids to help explain the history of this wonderful monument to Literature. It was a really hot day, but we slowed down and took in the many sights - it's really beautiful, and a lovely way to learn a little more about Vietnamese culture.I recommend doing likewise - taking your time, slowing your pace to that of the locals, and just taking in the sights.
Stunning buildings and gardens. This attraction is very traditional and old. I wouldn't say that I loved it, but it was nice to visit.

Beautiful temple. We arrived amid many young Vietnamese celebrating getting their degrees which made the visit extra special. The place was full of happy faces and smiles. The temple itself is large with much to see.
beautiful historic temple. this is a beautiful historic temple. Worth the time to visit and learn about the history of the temple.

Nice place. Very interesting place. You will see alot of Vietnamese girls in what i assume to be their traditional costume taking pictures in big groups. I like the exhibition in the courtyard the most.

Need a guide to fully appreciate what it's all about.. I went to the Temple with a local student guide (free) who helped to explain the importance of Confucius to the Vietnamese. He also told me the stories behind the displays and the statues, this was really invaluable because I would not have been able to fully appreciate and understand what it was all about with out this assistance. There are so many imporant details that would have been missed otherwise, so I would definitely recommend to go with a guide. Aside, the temple, gardens and university are lovely to wander around. Very well kept and the architecture is interesting.

Beautiful serene place of great historical importance. We liked the lacquered doors, the shrines, the doctor's stelae and being able to watch young Vietnamese students being able to come to pray for good luck in their exams. It's lovely.

Nice way to spend an hour. The gardens and temple were nice to walk through. There were a few tour groups and that made parts of it feel crowded. We had the guy in the back doing calligraphy paint us a "happiness" poster-so we must have been in a good mood!
Good location, evening walk from Eastin Easy GTC. The temple hosts the "Imperial Academy", Vietnam's first national university. The temple was built in 1070 at the time of King Lý Nhân Tông.
Beautiful place.. Well worth a visit. Watch out for the cab drivers who pick up right outside - their meters run VERY quickly!

Good place to visit. Although one can go around Hanoi on his own, I am really thankful that I took a tour, because to simply cross the streets in Vietnam is horrible with all the motorbikes not following traffic lights! To get a private tour is even better, because it saves a lot on the hotel pick-ups and drop-offs during rush-hour traffic. The lunch was a real treat, with so many courses. My tour guide from Minh Sinh Travel was very friendly and knowledgeable, and he helped make this tour enjoyable, you should visit this place if you can!
Confucius would be proud!. A fabulous spot which should not be missed. From the lovely gardens and ponds as you go in, to the temple within a super , ancient site.
was ok. a lot of history but a bit boring, if you are short in time then give it a miss,characters, characters, characters, characters, characters,

beautiful place. We went to the temple of literature in the morning, which is recommended because there are a lot of tourists. Yoh should plan at least two hours because its huge. Impressive garden, Konfuzius altar and buildings.

History. Temple of Literature is about 10 minutes away from Hoan Kiem lake. It was constructed in 1070 under Ly Thanh Tong’s dynasty, first to honor Confucius and nowadays to celebrate the doctorates and high rank scholars of Vietnam. In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong continued the work and built Quoc Tu Giam as the first university of Vietnam.

a beautiful place to see. A bit of a distance if you are staying in the old quarter, but well worth the small journey.
the wide open courtyards and the architecture are indeed quite an experience. definitely worth a visit in hanoi
Nice. There are few shops inside where you can get nice Vietnamese stuff at a good price. it is a must visit in hanoi

very good but limited English interpretation. We had a local free tour guide to help us understand this fascinating place. There is little interpretation and so without a guide or guide book visitors will get limited benefit but. Still worth visiting

Be-gowned students everywhere. The temple is set in lovely grounds and we were told that it was built by an emperor in about 1070 AD for his children to attend "university". It was then opened to all children of mandarin rank. The centre pathway was for the emperor's children and the side paths are for the others. After about 1442, all gifted children were allowed to enroll. The are many stelae which record the names of scholars that achieved distinction in their studies. The temple itself is entered through an imposing doorway. A nearby pagoda houses a large statue of Confucius. There are a number of courtyards which are overrun with students dressed in graduation robes posing for photos. There are individual students and whole classes of students. On the day that we were there it was hard to get a photo without many students in the picture.

worth a visit. 20 mins or so from the old quarter, and definitley worth a visit, especially if you can avoid all the students who go there for a blessing/photo opportunity. And of course there is not that much to see in Hanoi. Better than the old quarter.
Temple of Literature. An interesting temple - based upon Confusius principles. A place where students go before and after their studies to ask for a blessing with their education

Stunning. We loved it here. Away from the madness of Hanoi's streets. We were lucky enough to be there on graduation day which was wonderful. The place is lovely. There are four main courtyards to walk around with some English signage. It takes about an hour to look around it.

Interesting history beyond the physical buildings. The temple in and of itself is not architecturally spectacular.. However, going with someone knowledgeable is helpful as there are little nuances and stories that are not immediately obvious to the uninitiated. This will set the context to make the physical buildings and grounds more relevant.

Beautiful trip back in time. Beautify preserved university with tour guides organized to help you understand their complex and intriguing history. Worth a visit if you like taking rustic pictures and taking a trip back in time.

Not to Be Missed when Visiting Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is a temple dedicated to Confucius. It is also the oldest university in Vietnam dating back to 1070. There is a lake, a garden, five courtyards and turtle stelae of doctors who succesfully passed the royal examinations. You will also find a small museum with limited artifacts on display. There are altars where people pray to Confucius and Chu Văn An.We spent a good deal of time watching the orchestra play Vietnamese traditional music using instruments made from wood and strings. Souvenir items are available at various shops. These include water puppets, masks, book marks, CD/DVD of traditional music, wind chimes, etc.

Serene place. This is one of the highlights of Hanoi. Take about two hours to explore the gardens and the temple buildings and learn something from confucian style architecture. You can do it on your own, but someone who is knowledgeable will give interesting details. We went on a weekday and enjoyed the serenity of the place, I assume weekends are crowded. Local students come here to have pictures taken when they graduate. Lovely to see the female students in the traditional attire, the ao dai.Tip: have your hand made calligraph made by one of the calligraphy artists in the temple.

INTERESTING, BUT HAVE 1 - 2 HOURS TO PROPERLY. Visited as part of a tour with 21 of us. The place was busy, bit overcast, but still interesting. We also had a musical recital of local instruments. Overall, nice place to spend an hour or two, but best understood with a guide to explain the details
Worth a visit. An interesting and different spot in Hanoi. The buildings are clearly ancient and the grounds are well-kept and attractive.

Beautiful. A very interesting temple which is worth seeing. Cost to get in is 20000 dong. There were graduating students on the day we were there having their photos taken. This made the temple all the more interesting to visit. Combine the visit with lunch or dinner across the road at Koto.
interesting. Lovely little temple, interesting history. Wish the brochure had more information in it since we had to pay $8,000 VND!

The oldest university in Hanoi. Temple of literature is interesting place. This is the oldest university in Hanoi that build on 1070, which the crown prince studied here. Not much explanation about this temple in here, just a short recap about history of this temple on ticketing area. Admission fee was VND 20.000 and do not wear short pants. Inside the temple is beautiful with its old architecture and historical things. You also can buy some souvenir here with reasonable & fix price. Worth to visit.

Overrated. Hmm. the gardens were good, but for me it was a bit disappointing, nothing spectacular. It was good to see the young vietnamese wanting to try my sunglasses, lovely to see the women in the ao dai's, but nothing else

Nice place. As I went on a weekend, it was incredibly busy. It is a really nice place and interesting. I was with a guide as part of a day tour, but it can easily be done on your own. It is worth a visit.

Very interesting pretty place. This is the site of the first University in Vietnam. It is in a beautiful setting and very interesting. There is a If you are not with a guide there is not much explanation and might not be as enjoyable. The Confucius temple is quite lovely. It is worth a visit.
Worth a visit. I would recommend going to the Temple of Literature. They gave you a nice pamphlet so it was easy to follow what you were seeing. We really enjoyed it.
Good example of confucianist arcuitecture. One of the few places worth to visit in Hanoi. Nice architecture examples of the Chinese influence in Vietnam. I wish there were less people however..
Far away but worth to visit. It is quite far away from old quarter, we take quite some time to walk there. The whole temple is big, spacious, good architecture and gardening.

Visit to centre of education. Was impressed by the oldest university of hanoi . there was a book exhibition going on and was very happy to see a group of students to come there and take pictures and be associated with their history.

worth a visit. Deep history from Confucious times- early university for the rulers family. A tranquil spot in Hanoi with ancient temples, courtyards and statues. A pity more not in English but definitely get a guide anyway.
Real temple. Beautiful garden, atmosphere of poetry and literature, Good souvenirs. Graduation ceremonies interesting and colorful.

Confucian temple. This is a Confucian temple and very different from Buddhist temples we saw in Laos and other parts of Vietnam. Much of it is built of wood, and a red and gold color scheme predominates.It seems to have more Chinese influence, and the fact that it was one of the first universities is very interesting. We loved the stone turtles and the plaques that commemorate the graduates. The grounds are very beautiful with many topiaries. Also, there seemed to be school field trip going on. There were lots of small children in uniforms who seemed delighted to be there.

Strong Chinese influences. Nice gardens and courtyards which you walked through, with some old and some well restored parts. Your guide or a good guidebook is the key to understanding your time here, and the history attached to it, both religious and educational.

Worth visiting - it was helpful having a guide to explain the history.. We visited this site with a guide as part of a day tour. It was very helpful as he explained the history of the Temple of Literature and the University. The buildings are interesting and gardens around are lovely. They were setting up for a big Book Festival while we were there and there were groups of students having photos done in formal dress so it was quite busy and quite fascinating.

Worth a look but don't make it your priority. Perhaps I've been travelling too long and have seen too many other amazing temples as I found this one only okay - borderline boring to be honest. It has some pretty garden displays but the structures themselves were average. There were so many people here too so you couldn't look properly or take decent photos. Maybe you'd learn more from this if you had a guide to walk through it with that could explain what everything meant. Although Hanoi as a city was one of my favourite places, there isn't a lot of attractions to see so perhaps you'll find that you do have time to do this but just don't make it your priority.

A bit run down. Worth seeing but needs to be better cared for as similar historical sights in other countries ( eg Thailand ) are well maintained by comparison. Having said that, It costs very little to get in and is one of the main historical sights in Hanoi.

Creative architecture. I saw the site from the back and I saw this huge bell housed in a wooden structure. I immediately got excited and had to walk a block to enter the site. It's a great collection of old buildings and the story behind it makes it more interesting.
Quiet place in a noisy city. I really enjoyed the Temple of Literature. It is in a little pocket of park surrounded by large buildings and streets. It is a very peaceful place.
amazing. this is the first university of vietnam. they display the turtle statue, each one will representative one person that has the disgust score during exam.

Relatively short walking tour is enough. The grounds are pretty, well-kept, and it is interesting to read the information about the education of philosophers as well as see the tall, metal-cast peacocks and the golden turtle on display. The temple doesn't need much to browse since there isn't much to see. Just enjoy the atmosphere and walk around.

Nice oasis in the city with amazing history. This place is one of the oldest buildings in Hanoi and is the oldest university in Viet Nam. There is not much in English on the boards though there is some information. But you might need a guide to get the most from your visit. In the third of five courtyards are rows of stelae on the backs of stone turtles. On the stelae are the names of students who passed the royal exam - delivered by the king - from the 1400's onwards. At the far end of the complex are two large buildings; one being a temple with statues of Confucius and his followers. On either side of the temple are a bell and a large drum. Amazing history to realize that the royal exam has been conducted here more for centuries.

Okay to walk through, but doesn't need much time. As classically trained visitors, my partner and I were very excited to visit this temple, but we were quite disappointed. There is not really any particular thing that sets it out to be a Temple of Literature rather than any other kind of temple, though it was generally pleasant to look through. With a title as powerful as this, we expected more.

probably one of the olderst universities. On the day we visited the area was awash with young Vietnamese student in their graduation gowns. The temple of literature is well worth a visit both for its history and also architecture in its five areas.

Not quite what the name suggests.. What a place in the heart of Hanoi. Confushious being one of the scholars that studied here. Beautiful old buildings, gardens and relics of years gone past. It was a lovely wander thru this huge place.
First university in Hanoi. The day (March 26 2014) my wife visited many graduations were taking place. Beautiful gardens, small lovely lake. Most enjoyable place to visit.

Ancient University & great turtle statues. One of the oldest buildings in Hanoi is this Confucian temple, it is also the oldest university in Vietnam - founded in 1070. There is not much in English once you are here so you might need a guide, or read up before you turn up. There are five consecutive courtyards, in the third one are row upon row of stone turtles with stelae on their backs - these list the names of students who received doctorates from the 1400's onwards. There are two very large buildings at the back of the complex. First you come to a temple with statues of Confucius and his followers. Behind this is a large bell & large drum. Final building is a two storey wooden building, part museum, part gift shop. Here you will find statues of the original founders of the university.

Temple of Literature. This is a must see place in Hanoi! Unfortunately we didnt have a guide . I would recommend you get one. The history of learning and education is amazing and the peaceful setting a welcome relief from the busyness of the streets of Hanoi.

Misleading name. Well it's a temple, but there's not much literature. I didn't see a single book. Really they need some signs to explain what you are actually looking at. Still it only costs a dollar to visit so it's worth a look if your in the area, I just wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Actually I googled it afterwards and learned a bit about it and there is a lot of history. Probably be a great place to see with a guide.

Nice place for a few hours. We walked here from the old quarter, took a bit of time, but getting there was interesting along the way.We went earlier in the morning, around 10 as we had been there another day, after just walking around to see the sights and got there around 11:30, but after seeing all the BIG tour buses there, we passed.So, in the earlier morning, there were more school kids. But most were leaving, so it wasn't that bad once inside. It is interesting to see the buildings and just take your time in the gardens, and we people watched in the courtyard. We had an enjoyable time here.

Ancient history meets modern Vietnam. Spent an exhilirating hour there whilst hundreds of graduands were excitedly having their photos taken for their year books. A great place to visit. Vietnam has a history to rival anywhere, and this is a major part of their cultural heritage. Don't misss it.
A calm and beautiful place. This is a calm and beautiful place. If you like culture and beautiful surroundings this place is worth your visit!

a big disappointment. was really looking forward to visiting this museum. it is a nice building with nice cafe outside. floors one and 2 i found quite boring (i am not sure why as i am interested in the cultural aspects of life associated with faiths and religion),four 3 was very interesting and floor 4 took me less than 2 minutes (fashion - not my thing). There are a few nice displays but the rest is just photographs with descriptions. i would go again for floor 3 but the rest just didnt do it for me

On the List. For 1000 years this was the university that trained the top civil servants in Vietnam. The best then went to Beijing. It is dedicated to Confucius and studies. The day we visited, many graduating classes from local high schools and colleges were there for photos. Parents and students writing exams were also their to ask Confucius and the statues of other scholars for assistance in their studies. Lovely garden and Lily ponds, ancient trees and bonsai and filled wiTh relaxed walkers...and of course tourists. Join them!
Lots of Scholars. Unfortunately I was unable to really connect with the displays. If you are short of time, it may not be the place to go. Talks about many of the past scholars in Vietnam.

A must see in Hanoi. This sounds quite boring but is one of the best places to visit in Hanoi. It is a series of charming buildings within very pretty gardens. It is very popular with the locals at the weekends for weddings and graduations so it can be extremely busy at this time.

Site of the oldest university in Vietnam. Very interesting and important old architectural building in Hanoi dating back to the 11th century .It was a learning cente for the Mandarins. Inside the Temple of Confucius the statues are magnificent dressed in robes of red and gold. Very spiritual place.

Completely worth it. The Temple of Literature, a Confucian edifice, is well worth a visit; don't miss the musicians playing classic Vietnamese music in the centre building, you may have to wait. The architecture is similar to those in China but this complex is large and well maintained.

Beautiful old temple. Go round the back of the temple as it continues on to the old university. The grounds are lovely. Lots of parties of school children are taken there so it can disturb the peaceful atmosphere.
excellent. This museum was full of great things again, of Vietnam life and culture. You can't take all of it in, in one go. But what we saw was very good.

Interesting visit. Surrounded by busy roads the Temple of Literature is a lovely glimpse of old Hanoi - a time of scholarship and contemplation and traditional architecture. Really worth a visit. You can combine it with the Museum of Fine Arts nearby. very busy at the weekend when the locals also go.

The 1st University of Vietnam. We took the whole morning the visit this Temple. Going around we can saw a lot of classic and old thing that we never seen before. The whole temple covered by a lot of green trees, it made you feel very comfortable to spend time to visit here. No wonder why is the most famous place in Hanoi

A must see! If possible, try to see it on a sunny day.. Fascinating. Afterward, walk around Hoan Kiem Lake and walk across the intricate red wooden bridge. If possible, try to get a guide for the day. Buy the Eyewitness Travel guide for Vietnam.After seeing a lot of places, have ice cream at Fanny's. And perhaps a meal at the Seasons of Hanoi - attractive, reasonably-priced food, English conversant staff. May need a taxi.
Quite interesting. It was very nice to visit the Temple of Literature, specially if you have a local to explain you the history and what things mean. Completely worth it.
Good for a look. Interesting place, the tablets were amazing. Good for a look, about an hour should see you around it all.

Worth a visit. This place is so pretty and worth a trip if you're in Hanoi. I was there with my friend, a local, and it was definitely nice. Being there and not having someone who knows the history would definitely be boring..... they have some musicans there playing historical music. Was very nice!

Bring your camera and a love of history. I recommend you add this to your short list of things to do if you are interested in more ancient history and culture. I recommend taking a guided tour to understand the story of the Temple. As you listen think of our own education system of bachelor's, master's and PhD degrees. Pay attention to the significance of the center walkway. Witness the ancient names on the stellae. See if you can pick up on the symbolism of the turtle and the crane for the ancient Vietnamese.

Needs a Guide. Came as part of a tour, and definitely needed the guide as there's little to no explanation for the buildings or monuments within the grounds. With a guide you get to understand so much more about the area.Otherwise, its another beautiful garden and collection of buildings in Hanoi, and well worth visiting.

Absolutely worth a visit, but get a tour guide. A trip to Hanoi wouldn't be complete without a stop here. It can be a short visit, if you only have limited time, or you could spend a few hours seeing all of it and enjoying the serenity. You need a tour guide to understand the significance of the temple and the history as there are no signs in English.
temple of literature. interesting. helpful to have a guide. visited as part of half day city tour. took taxi to site from old quarter, then walked back.

Read up before you go. Went here with a tour, wouldn't have had any idea what was going on without the guide. Very little information in English, so read up before you go. Lovely area, and at certain times of year filled with beautifully dressed Vietnamese students having photos taken - adds to the busy and beautiful atmosphere. Very interesting area.

Ancient memorial. Basically a memorial to Confucius. First university for the sons of mandarins.An overview of Hanoian culture and ancient Vietnamese architecture.Some of the stone exhibits were quite worn off.
Worth a visit. You would do well to read about it before hand because there is very little information on site. Most descriptions are in vietnamese (with very little in English & French)

Very good. It takes a while to see the whole thing, but make sure you see the whole place, as i noticed some people didn't see the last two courtyard areas, because it looks like it finishes, but you just have to walk around the building. But it a very nice area with confucian style buildings and it is very nice. It is topped off by the best street food in all of Vietnam at one place nearby.

Top ten Hanoi tourist attraction. I think this is deserving of being in the top ten list for Hanoi's attractions. It is quite a complex of buildings, beautifully manicured gardens and the bonsai and topiary trees are quite special, even if you're not into that sort of thing it would be hard not to appreciate the effort and beauty they represent. It's extremely popular with large, small groups and some had megaphones on the Sunday we visited, which are very annoying. I think once you've seen this temple, you can probably take a break. Admittedly, there's only so many temples one can visit, but if you're in Hanoi, this is a good attraction. But if you've seen other temples previously, then maybe not. It's pretty awesome to appreciate this was built in the 15th Century. Confucius say "Visit Temple of Literature".
Another temple. It was okay but a bit disappointing! I suppose if you have seen temples for the past year than this is not worth a visit!
Must visit in Hanoi. This was one of the most well maintained temples we saw in Vietnam. Clean, beautiful path and garden at the front. Worth a visit.

Vietnam's First University founded AD1070. Possibly the best architecture in Hanoi founded in honour of Confucius the Chinese philosopher. For seven centuries the future Mandarins were educated here. There are five courtyards, lawns, pools and lots of architectural features and interiors.
temple. historical place reminding of great philosopher Confucius . very beautiful place to see. I am fortunate enough to visit such a nice place

A must see place in Ha Noi. Go here and learn about Vietnam/Hanoi history.
It is a must see place for travelers, not far from the center of Hanoi and easy to find on the map. It can be reached by bus/motorbike/taxi. Not long stay, an hour is enough. Have discount for student!
Meaningfull place. This is the first university in Vietnam so it means a lot to young people. also, you can easily walk to Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum
Beauty Fades. Education is Forever.. Over a thousand years of history. This place is a must-see. I visit this place every time I'm in Hanoi.

Interesting temple - go with a guide. We visited the temple in January 2014 and a tour group. Although often tour guides give information that you may already know from researching your destination, here the guide's insights were great. A lot of symbolism she identified in the building and grounds is particular to the Orient so if that's unfamiliar to you, take a guide or at least a guidebook. That way you will get a lot more out of your visit.
Very nice. The special style of architecture, the colors, the place/location in Hanoi and sometimes the ladies who are dressed in Vietnames Ao Dai costume all is very special and nice...

An attractive and peaceful place to visit, full of interest.. There is a lot to see here, and when we visited it was relatively quiet and relaxing. AS others have said, a guide will point out the most interesting things, and add some context.

An oasis of calm. This was our first experience of old Vietnamese architecture and we loved the calm order in the middle of the busy city. Fascinating steles listing the graduates of the ancient university. A guide is a very good idea.

A calm location in the midst of a bustling city. We were surprised to find this beautiful and calm place in a city that beauty is not one of its highlights. This university of ancient times promotes the importance of knowledge wisdom and learning. It a pity that theses massages were not always acknowledged by recent governments
Not that much. There was not that much to see,but it was a pleasant place to be. It was very crowded the day we went with students having their graduation ceremony.

Vietnam's first university. This was one of my favourite places to visit in Hanoi (the other being the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Steeped in important history. A guide is helpful to explain all the symbolism & background history to this remarkably unique temple.

Fascinating visit into history. Easy to walk around the gardens and through the buildings.
a fascinating experience and we bought a hand painted banner for our son with a saying of Confucius.

Interesting place of interest in Hanoi. A temple full of history of Master Confucious, worth visiting. But as mentioned by many , you need a tour guide. We went with Hanoi Kids as well and they provide detailed interesting story of each of the historical pieces. You can easily spend an hour there if you have someone who can relate the insight of the temple to you.

Interesting history. A worthwhile site to visit, but I would recommend a guide. We came here with our two Hanoi Kids guides who were able to provide the color behind the temple. It actually is really interesting, and shows the focus on education has been a priority for a long time (as it is today).
to learn about Vietnamese culture. Don't go there alone - book a guided tour and take time to get involved in the history of this place.
The place is nice and include old temples. It is just nice. I would not bother plan the visit around this place unless I happened to be in this area.

A humble temple with a lively atmosphere. I skimmed through the history of the Temple of Literature & National University, so I understood its historical importance.As I walked into the Temple, I can't help but feel the courtyard looks a tad bit neglected and could use some restoration work. The inside of the Temple itself is clean, decorated nicely and looks better than the courtyard.Aesthetics of the Temple and its courtyards aside, the highlight of our visit was actually the group of students graduating at the Temple. The girls were wearing the Ao Dai and were happily snapping pictures away. We visited the Temple on a Sunday morning.Personally, I felt the Temple was just alright but I am still amazed at the fact that its almost 1,000 years old. Only go if you're into history, or if you just want to see a lot of girls in the Ao Dai.

Tracing the Roots of Vietnam’s Culture, Education and Traditions. Confucius was a towering personality and he had a tremendous influence on most Asian countries, including Vietnam. The Temple of Literature and National University in Hanoi is a fitting tribute to Confucius and a host of other scholars and sages. The place is home to the Imperial Academy, the first national university of Vietnam. The temple traces its history to the year 1070 during the reign of Ly Nhan Tong. The temple is modeled after the temple that is built in Aufu, Shadong, and the birthplace of Confucius. The temple comprises five courtyards out of which the first two courtyards were meant for relaxation amongst trees and manicured lawns. The third courtyard is meant for promoting study and recognizing talent. The fourth courtyard was meant to honor 72 disciples of Confucius. The fifth courtyard recognizes education, culture and national traditions of Vietnam. The fifth courtyard in essence was the beginning of the university.

a lesson in history. If you're interesed in history, this is a great attraction. It's not very large and can be done within an hour. However, I highly recommend a guide if you want to understand the history (its not really much of an attraction unless you understand the associated context in history).

Confucian Temple that hosts Vietnam's first national university. We visit the Temple of Literature during our stay in Hanoi as suggested by our guide. Definitely the attraction is in the tourist trail, being literally invaded by tourists. It worth a visit for the historical background and the peaceful gardens. The temple hosts the Imperial Academy that is Vietnam's first national university and built around 1000 years ago. I would recommend to visit it with a local guide or with a Lonely Planet or similar travel book in order to take the best the attraction has to offer.

A Temple modeled after the Temple of Confucius!. Dating back to 1070, this large temple complex is historically significant. It was a center of learning and educated mandarins in terms of higher learning as well as values. It's a beautiful complex consisting of 5 inner courtyards. When we were there, university girls were celebrating their graduation and having their photos taken at this significant center for higher education.

Fascinating and humbling. Really enjoyed this glimpse into learning in the past. The steles were of particular note, as was the information about the ethos behind the learning (ethics and morality). A series of quadrangles led to the temple, which was beautiful. It was touching to see people worshiping centuries after the first worshipers.

Part of the Hanoi tourist trail. We went as part of a tour group and certainly you will need a guide to explain the history etc. Pleasant gardens where you will see a number of local birds and an attractive temple at one end (together with a shop etc). It seems to be a standard stop point for all tour groups.
Interesting, but not a must. Nice to see a University 1000 years old, but the place itself is not "must see" in my opinion.Still one of places where you can have nice picture from Hanoi :)

One of the highlights in Hanoi. A place of significance in the history of Hanoi, but is now mainly a tourist attraction. It is easy to spend an hour walking in this place to look at the buildings and gardens.
Stunning. Take a deep breath and stroll quietly through here. It is transforming. The overwhelming beauty and serenity will change you.

Mildly interesting. The information boards and guides gave little information, but we had brought tablet computers with internet. We read about the Temple, and with this knowledge at hand the Temple became worth interesting. So read up before going here!

Great experience to walk through an ancient learning center. This was an University at the time of Confucius and has all the early learning history of Vietnam. It gives one a complete picture of how the education institute served as a learning and cultural center. The best part is that the national govt has preserved this history as a source of values until today.

A bit of history in all the Hanoi chaos. Finally something with a touch of tradition and history in Hanoi. Worth a visit and a though of what great culture this place once had... too bad it's all gone now...

Busy but worth a look. We walked from the old quarter to the temple, we sore amazing sites on the way including tropical fish in plastic bags on a scooter. It was very busy but we did manage to find places where we could take photos without having people in them. This ancient place of learning and religion was built in 1070. It includes lotus ponds for fish, topiary gardens (more topiary across the road), decorative entrance gates, courtyards, a museum, bells, and a music group plays as well as the souvenir shops. We were lucky as there was a couple getting married and there several woman in national custom ao dai.

Temple of Litterature-Hanoi. A big complex a short walk from the old quarter. It consists of 5 courtyards with well maintained lawns and lotus ponds. At the entrance are 3 gates : the main gate was for the King, the other 2 for the Mandarins and for candidates.This temple ( Van Mieu ) was built in1070 and dedicated to Confucius. It became the first university of Vietnam in 1076.This temple honours 82 doctorates who passed ( in feudal times ) the very difficult exams ; their names are engraved in 82 headstones on big tortoises : touching the tortoise heads will bring luck.;We did and were Lucky because we could assist to a religious Confucious-ceremony.All around this temple-complex, writers and artists will write down a message or poem with very artfull caligraphy.A MUST to visit in Hanoi !
interesting landmark. this is a very good place to see how religion and science was mixed in old times. Lovely setting and not too many tourists in our case.
Interesting history. Nothing to like or dislike. Notice that ancient Vietnamese are very much like Chinese in terms of religion, food and culture.

University building. There are some great stories to tell about this place but make sure you go here with a good tourguide otherwise you'll never hear them. The information found on site is rather sparse so if you go on your own you'll probably miss a lot of the interesting facts and history of the place.

A relaxing oasis in busy Hanoi -Photo Guide. I went here mainly to get some photos - I wasn't disappointed. It was 20K VND entry and 8k for a (poor) quad-fold brochure - with map. The area is enclosed with a wall and has many old large trees to give you 'photo backdrops' that are not just 1960s concrete buildings... nice. The entrance gate is lovely framed with a wall and trees - on both sides. There are several ancient trees with vines/roots hanging which look great too. Inside are a plethora of nooks and crannies - plus several temple areas with cranes, turtles, icons etc.. all very photographic. Nice small lake towards the centre which can produce nice gate reflections. Recommend a 200m and 11-17 type lens plus a flash for inside work - although I did not I prefer grainy high-iso shots of the interiors... Note - most signs were ONLY in Vietnamese. Spent 2 hrs there and grabbed an ice cream to relax half-way. Nice!

Confucionism. It was fascinating to know a little bit more about the teaching of the strict laws of Confucionism, phylosophy that was taught during 7 centuries to mandarins. It is a very beautiful architectonic complex, surrounding peaceful gardens and a lake. It served originaly as a templo for the devotees of Confucionism, then became the university for the prince and lastly for those who would struggle to get the highest grades to become the King's advidor. There are many (around 80) turtle shaped pedestals which bring the names of those who best performed in their studies (academics), per century, from 15th to 18th. You will find an exhibition of the professors and students' uniforms, books and artifacts used at the time. Well worth seeing and understanding.

Nice Garden but not much too see.. We were disappointed. Firstly we were short-changed at the entrance booth. Secondly the information provided on the printed guide (paid for) was rather limited. And finally, the exhibits though interesting are quickly covered.
First University. Fascinating to see the architecture and to know that this was one of the first universities in existence.

Excellent introduction to the early Confucian teachings. Nice sprawling ground in the middle of Hanoi for a pleasant stroll to learn about the teachings of Confucius. We were able to witness a simple ceremony involving young entry level primary students being introduced to education. A good place to understand the early influence of Confucianism in Vietnam.

Incredible. Vietnam has its first university so early. that's surprising. The structure in the temple of literature is quite unique. knew so many interesting stories thanks to the giuide from BC tour. great trip in hanoi. ^^

Best of Hanoi. Occupies a large area, but at an appropriate scale. Has some buildings that were part of the old university and at least two temples all very interesting with many statues of Confucius and his disciples inside. The giant bells are beautiful. The whole set is very harmonious
peaceful. This is a lovely area of serenity in the middle of the city, should not be missed. Make sure you go round the back of the first temple, there is more!

Must see in Hanoi!. The Temple of Literature is not what it sounds like. I expected a museum filled with old manuscripts and grudgingly went along. But it's an old temple where people went to study. Many beautiful buildings and altars.
Beautiful. An expansive set of beautiful buildings surrounded by a garden. When I was there, there was also a group playing traditional music.
Should See. It's a very interesting place. Great place to sit and relax. Great to learn about the history. Glad I went but it wouldn't be on my "2nd time to see" list.
Wow, over 1000 years of university and training.. Amazing to see how advanced they were and so long ago. Great temple architecture and an amazing monument to learning, worth a visit.

Great and worth place to visit. Very far from other attractions but I can manage to visit this place. Beautiful landscape and great architecture building. Not only foreigners, but a lot of locals visit to this place also. Really worth place to visit.

Confucius has so much to tell us. Visit the Temple of Literature and learn a little more about the teachings of Confucius and the history of Vietnam. This is a wonderfully peaceful place and a complete contrast to the rest of this bustling city. In lay-out it is a (very mini) Forbidden City. But whereas you might spend almost a day in Beijing's Forbidden City, an hour would be ample time here, although some guide books seem to suggest a much longer visit. There are comprehensive and informative explanations at various points so I don't think a guide is necessary. Entry is 3 dollars and opening hours are 8am-5pm.
To be seen. Very interesting to visit. A guide will give the information required to understand the history of this site.

Great Oasis within the city!. I have visited the Temple of Literature many times over the past 5 years and have always loved how it serves as a welcomed oasis away from the hustle and bustle in the middle of the city. During Tet it is crowded but on a regular weekday it is very peaceful.

Interesting and colorful. We enjoyed taking pictures here. There are 5 gates to the University which opened some time in the 1000 AD. Vietnamese/Chinese lore states that a coy fish can turn into a dragon (which is one of 4 sacred animals) after passing 5 gates or tests and the University is set up with this theme in mind. The end of the path today ends in a Buddhist temple where people come to pray for good grades before tests.

NIce introduction to the Vietnamese culture. We went on a Sunday just after Tet, when it seemed the entire population of Ha Noi had the same idea. The grounds were swollen with well-wishers and visitors to the several Buddhist shrines on premise, and the beloved and handworn ancient tortoise sculptures carrying Confucian scholar stones were particularly evocative. There are lots of street vendors outside hawking coconut cakes, bird whistles, clay sculpture and calligraphy. From here it is a short walk to the excellent Vietnam Fine Arts Museum

Lovely old Temple. Nice place to spend some time. When we were there there were lots of young woman celebrating getting their degrees so were having photos taken in traditional clothing so it added to the ambience

Biggest temple in Hanoi. That's the kind of thing you take a look because it's famous, you are in the city, etc. Not specially beautiful, nothing really different from other temples. If you have time, ok. If I have to choose I'd prefer to walk on the Old Quarter or have lunch in the French Quarter.

Literature In the Middle of the City. It was a very nice place to visit, if you are in Hanoi for a few days. The architecture is amazing and you can spend a good few hours here looking into all the buildings and walking in the gardens. This a good way to spend $3.00

A highlight in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is an interesting visit and a welcome reprieve from the bustle of Hanoi streets.Our guide book made it look as if it would be an all day visit on the scale of the Forbidden City. It isn't. Unless you want to study the history in detail, you can easily visit it in an hour.

Must see. You definitely templed out in Asia and they all certainly have interesting history but I find them visually so over the top. But this particular temple is an absolute gem and a must see. Gorgeous grounds which are all so harmoniously designed and lovely red buildings which look superb. It's a really lovely and peaceful spot.
culture in Vietnam. Beautiful and interesting historical landmark of this wonderful country. It is definitely worth having a guide with you to inform about the history.

pretty - and open on Monday. I found this big temple complex interesting because I've never seen a temple dedicated to knowledge before. It's quite atmospheric on a misty Hanoi morning.
If you're in Hanoi on a Monday you might as well come here - pretty much all other attractions are closed!

National University - The cradle produce talent!. Only 1 USD (20.000 VND) you can visit a special architectural and historical significance to the country Vietnam. Here is the first university and survived intact until today.
You spend 45 minutes to visit all. So interesting.

Worth a Visit. Although it is the National University it is not what one would normally expect as a university and is more a temple and historical monument. Interesting and different, it is worth a visit if visiting the city and time is available, but I would not personally go out of my way if time is pressing, and you have to negotiate the multitude of street vendors outside. This may sound a bit negative, but in fact our visit was very enjoyable and there are many interesting facets to the buildings.
Very interesting. Very informative, nicely laid out, spent interesting hour walking around then off to Kotos next door for lunch

Good visit. There were many people visiting this site, as it is traditional for university graduates to visit and have their photos taken here. This site dates back to 1070. This historical centre of learning is now dedicated to Confucian worship.

A series of interesting courtyards dedicated to Confucious. We took a taxi to the entrance, and walked through the five different 'gardens/courtyards' through ornate dividing gates. The last courtyard is where the 'teaching' took place, with one courtyard surrounded by plaques [referred to as 'stelae'] standing on the backs of turtles celebrating successful scholars.There is a shrine at the end.

A peaceful place amongst the maddness that is Hanoi.. Tranquility and a special place in the history of Hanoi, not many countries can boast a one thousand year old university, and this one is still mostly intact.
Average. Nothing incredible but there is not a lot of interesting things in Hanoi so u can go there and have a look
Amazing Experience. It was a very interesting and humbling experience to know that scholars were working on their doctorates while in the west we were still getting settled.

The Font of All Knowledge. This place was original. Mant of the displays were quite worn with time. A very colourful place to visit. On the day we visited, we were fortunate that a national folk festival was taking place.
Nothing to write home about.. Not sure why it exists as tourist destination. Story, ok, but boring. Pretty place with some interesting parts.
Much better. A bit tired of temples we came with a little borde mind . We came out smiling after some marvelous moments. Perhaps it was due to Tet, but it was a memory for us.

Beautiful temple and rich history.. This was an amazing place to see. Everything is preserved to look just like it did hundreds of years ago. It is interesting to think that many of the great doctors, lawyers, scientists and other professionals graduated from this university. The history of the entire complex along with the beauty and subtle representations is an amazing combination. The fact that everyone who graduated had their name inscribed in stone there is a great honor. Definitely a must see if you are in Hanoi.

Meh.. it's very chinese. It's like a Chinese garden. if you're chinese, or have been to China a few times, this wouldn't be anything special.. it's simply a very serene courtyard filled with tourists with very expensive cameras.Tip: If you're thinking of cutting through the garden to get to the Fine Arts museum - there is no through road. Think again.

Nice old temple. Really old temple (built in 1070!), pretty well conserved, in the heart of Hanoi. Even if the place looks huge from the outside, you actually make the turn from the inside pretty quickly.You will find inside some nice bonzais, some temples and vegetation (beautiful old tree, animal-form bush,..).

Top tip. Don't miss the rear courtyard (easy to do as the signage isn't that easy to spot) where you can commission a personalised good luck scroll to take away with you for just a couple of pounds - much nicer than those being hawked outside the temple. Nearby there is a park where we happened upon a free water puppet show.

Lunar New Year at Temple of Literature. It was crowded with people because it was Lunar New Year. If you like to "people watch", it's fine. If not, go only if it's not a holiday. It's beautiful and peaceful, with lots of history. Just outside the gate you'll be able to get some famous Asian poetry paintings in Chinese (or ancient Korean?) characters, or have an artist paint a cartoon portrait of yourself.

Beautiful and ancient cultural site. The Temple of Literature - Van Mieu Quoc tu Giam - is an unexpected but very welcome island of peace in Hanoi. Many of the structures were built in the eleventh century, and it comprises a sequence of courtyards and ponds, with gateways, shrines and other buildings. The temple dedicated to Confucius stands at the far end of the central spine from the main gate. It houses a statue of Confucius as well as those of several Vietnamese kings of the eleventh and twelfth centuries. We were particularly taken with doctoral stelae - gravestone-like stone slabs carrying the names of doctor laureates in exams held between the ends of the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries - housed in open-sided buildings on both sides of one of the main courtyards. We went to this ancient site just before Tet (2014) and found Van Mieu, the street to the east of the site, filled with calligraphers practicing their art.

Venerable, impressive cultural site. The temple, dedicated to Confucius and his main disciples, is the second oldest building in Hanoi, dating back to the 11th century. We were there on a Sunday when many families were visiting to make offerings at the altars and generally enjoy the site. Be sure to visit the outside wall where traditional calligraphers set up business to sell scrolls.

It is about culture and conservation. This tourist attraction was once the National University in Vietnam, dated back in 1070 AD. There are few big courtyards with some lotus pond, if you love architectural and conservation, this is definitely a must-visit attraction. When my trip there, there was some culture performance in front of the main temple building. Walking around to feel how the ancient university was.

Culture and history. Spent about an two hours at the Temple of Literature with my husband and parents. My dad used to live near the temple so he was our unofficial tour guide. The two hours seemed like an adequate amount of time to explore the site. It was wonderful walking through the grounds and learning the history of the university. If you weren't lucky as me to have your dad be a tour guide, I would hire or join a tour group to gain a better understanding about the temple.
Great temple. Really nice temple, we visited when the students were graduating which was really nice to see. Like to see buildings still being used.

Worth a visit. It was extremely busy due to Tet, so hard to move around due to the crowds but still interesting. Take a guide book for information so you know what you are looking at, as hardly any translations into English or other languages. Check your change carefully from the ticket seller, as she tried to cheat us.

Serene? Too many crowds, too many shops and no place to sit. Beautiful old trees, banyan (or similar) -great roots. Pools that should have koi are near empty and have only a few inches of dirty drown water. The structures were beautiful, and so were the gardens, but with so many people throbbing and pushing it was hard to appreciate any anything but peaceful. There was no where to sit, and quiet contemplation is difficult when forced to stand. Too many sales stalls (Ho on Confucius scrolls??)Across the street is a small lake in a park like setting with very few guests...peaceful and serene.Also very near KOTO, a non for profit restaurant with the mission of helping disadvantaged youth learn a trade and life skills. Works well for lunch (see separate review if you want to, but just go there....)

An eh-eh must see. This is touted as the best temple in Hanoi to visit and I suppose it is. The grounds are very lovely as is the actual temple itself. It is only $1 to get in, so why not go and walk around for 20 minutes? At the very least, it's a respite from the loud city. It wasn't full of tourists the day we went, but huge groups of Vietnamese students having their school pictures taken I presume. I would have preferred scads of tourists. The students were loud and hijacked large parts of the temple for their pictures making it near impossible to walk around.

Interesting. Another place that I think was overwhelming and confusing about what it really was/ is. The highlight for me was that the day I visited, local students were dressed up for graduation portraits, and the beautiful girls in bright dresses really made the place colorful and fun. The parents all seemed proud, and seeing the teens smiling with friends gave it a local touch even if it was more crowded.

Something to see but less than impressed. Heard from a fellow traveler how beautiful the Temple of Literature was and that it was a must see while in Hanoi. Again, my trip was during the Tet festival and hard to enjoy much when surrounded by the sheer mass of humanity so take my review with a grain of salt. The compound itself is historic, but I didn't find it the least impressive considering other relics in S.E. Asia. There are many students that go there to pray for their exams. Our guide did tell us a funny story that he took an exam without studying, only praying, and then failed the test. I guess the lesson is to pray harder!Again, one of the places to see in Hanoi but was just so so.

Sowing the seed for modern day Vietnam. Try to imagine running an empire using people who didn’t know how to read or write, couldn’t count in numbers or know the difference between a thief & a taxman. This Chinese centre of learning not only established Vietnam's firm Chinese identify by adopting its system of education & ethics but also created a new class of intellectuals, warlords & administrators in this far-off insignificant province who ironically used these same skills to eventually stand up on their own two feet & fight off the very same Chinese. How do they say it? Biting the hand that rocks the cradle.Interestingly, the weak Kinh-speaking nation of Dai Viet (Vietnam) would probably have been destroyed by the Hindu-Muslim kingdom of Champa in southern Vietnam who were expert looters, pirates & slave traders. The Temple of Literature provided the Vietnamese with written language, a code of ethics & military technologies from China such as strategy & tactics which were useful in defending their borders. As China’s most southern province, Vietnam was the gateway for China to clasp its iron fist on the rich Hindu kingdoms of the Khmer in Cambodia & Majapahit Empire in Indonesia. Gold, women & jewels is what it’s always really about. The Temple of Literature's design is said to be similar to the temple in Qufu, China, where the great philosopher Confucius was born. Confucianism spread rapidly in Vietnam thru this institution & is still the basis of Vietnam’s culture today, respect for elders, family & the importance of education. Throughout the complex from the front gate are 3 walking paths. The centre is for the emperor, the left is for the bureaucrats & the right for military officers. These classes of people represented the 3 types of students the centre educated, administrators, royalty, & military officers. Not escaping the destruction, the World UNESCO-listed temple’s fifth courtyard which housed the Royal Academy was destroyed by the French in 1946 as part of their invasion to re-take Hanoi after the Japanese surrender. The Vietnamese had retreated to the courtyard hoping its ancient walls would discourage the French from attacking them & thus destroying the ancient temple but the French let their artillery do all the talking. Ironically, the French had earlier surrendered all of Indochina, including Cambodia, Laos & Vietnam to the Japanese in 1941 without so much of a fight, pretty much what they did again when the Germans showed up on their doorstep in 1940.

Graduation Day!. We were very fortunate that on the day we visited, it was graduation day. All the young women were dressed in traditional dress, hair and makeup done, bouquets of flowers - it looked like a mass wedding! The temple is incredible and awe inspiring - it was definitely my favourite place to visit in Hanoi and we went everywhere, walking between 5-8 hours each day we were there. The gardens are immaculate and very ornate. There is such a feeling of calm as you walk through the grounds - the students study outside which must be amazing for them! I would recommend, as we did, that you hire a guide to escort you as the historical aspect makes it even more special. An absolute must when visiting Hanoi. The hotels all have maps which show where the attractions are and if you like walking, as we do, that is the best way to see everything.

Surely on of the better temples in Hanoi. The temple of literature is surely the best Confucius temple I visited when in Hanoi. It was crazy crowded, don't know if that was that I visited it on a Sunday or that this is a common place for newly weds and others to visit on their "big day", but it is worth the time as other reviewers have said. Being such a popular place to visit by locals and tourists might also be the key why it is so well kept compared to other temples. Well worth a visit!
Very good but very crowded. I got dizzy before getting into the second quarter. It is histoirical , one of the must see attractions in hanoi.

Good place for memories and education. When visiting Van Mieu, I always recall my old schools and good memories with classmates. It is a good place to educate the kids about the importance of education. The garden, tower, pool is a good background for photographing.
Pretty but very overcrowded. very scenic and pretty. costs 20,000VND. was difficult to enjoy as very crowded with people. go early at the very least

A haven of tranquility. This place was one of the highlights of our three days in Hanoi, allowing us an hour or so of peace in the near bedlam of this city.
There is a lot to see and we were certainly not in a hurry to move on to one of the many other attractions of Hanoi.

Very crazy crowded during Tet but worth the time.. Did not have English translations under all the signage / displays so had to guess what some of the stone monuments and plaques were. Liked the grounds, the beautiful temple and architecture, the inexpensive gift shops within the compound.
nice place to visit. Nice place to visit with lovely gardens. The temple features the names of past graduates dating back to the 1000's, you could easily spend a hour wandering around.
A nice reprieve from the craziness of the street. The temple of literature is a quiet haven from the madness on the streets. There are beautiful gardens and a long history to read about.

A favourite place. This is a beautiful, peaceful location in the city, and a favoured place for graduating students to congregate to have their class and graduating photos taken.This location is over 1000 years old and fascinating to wander around and look at the ancient stelae. Plan to spend at least 20 minutes here, if you are in a rush, or 40 minutes if you are not.The only down side was the gauntlet of street sellers hounding you to buy their products. It was the only place in Hanoi where they were so persistent that I was uncomfortable. Plan to arrive and leave quickly, move purposefully to discourage being accosted.
The oldest university. A beautiful site and important stella with the names of the graduates of this school from much earlier period.

A must-see in Hanoi, the town's oldest University and a quiet attractive temple.. The history of this temple is intriguing - set up centuries ago as a University and temple. The site covers quite a large area and there are still some educational activities going on here, but mainly is serves now as a temple. And as we discovered, also a venue for modern students graduating to have their photos taken. Nice gardens, very picturesque and a more authentic take, for me, on the real history of Vietnam that the tomb of Ho Chi Minh, which seems to be the No.1 tourist destination in Hanoi!

peaceful place. It´s realy nice and a peacefull place, I would recommend it to every visitor in Vietnam. Sometimes if you are lucky you can see a couple making pictures with the traditional vietnamese dree for wedding.

Enjoyable. Lovely gardens and setting with many photo ops with a look back into history. We also visited at a time when graduating ceremonies were being held and of course that makes perfect sense in this Temple that is dedicated to Confucius and other scholars. Here you can watch calligraphists, and other artists as they craft their skill. There was also an amazing student photography exhibit that was displayed while we were there which was quiet enjoyable.

Tranquil Oasis in Busy Hanoi. Vietnam's first university, dating from the 1000s, the Temple of Literature is a tranquil place to spend an hour or two during a trip to Hanoi. Cost is minimal, approximately $1 USD equivalent. Upon entrance, there are lovely gardens - including a topiary for each of the 12 Chinese year animals (fun to look at and figure out which is which). Moving further onto the grounds, you pass through a few gateways and see where students studied. We really benefited from having a guide here to point out all the symbolism in the architecture and ornamentation of the buildings and hedges which we would have missed otherwise. A highly worthwhile visit, for the gardens, wood Vietnamese architecture and glimpse into the past. Plus, a much needed break from the mopeds and traffic of the Old Town.

More than just a Temple. The is a great variety of attractions that will satisfy the majority of tourists, such as live musicians playing traditional instruments, lovely temples, great architecture, gardens and statues. It was however disappointing that the attraction is not readily accessible for disabled people. It was also disappointing that we had to pay to visit the toilets after paying an entrance fee.

Definitely worth a visit. The Temple of Literature is a must-see in Hanoi. Factor in an hour or so for wandering around as it's quite a big place. I loved the stone plaques commemorating Vietnam's first "PhD" graduates.

Early morning tranquility . We visited the temple early morning when it was quite empty except the hustle of meticulous gardeners.A very pretty temple with large water features and turtles (china) everywhere - said to bring luck if you rub their heads

A thousand year old good taste. The whole complex continues to reflect the attention the Vietnamese and Chinese cultures of such a long time ago paid to education. Brilliant exams paving the way to high careers in the administration, we in the West had to wait many centuries just to conceive the idea. Here we see it realised in a tastful setting, enhanced these days when the Tét festival is approaching.

Memorable. We visited on a day that many young Vietnamese were graduating and will for ever remember the many happy smiling faces, and their immaculate dress. Probably best to have a guide to explain the history of the Temple - made it so much more interesting.
A fascinating place. This was a very interesting place with a nice garden and beautiful houses. The university has a thousand years history. Look at the nice roofs and the stone turtles.

An Oasis in a busy City. We visited this as part of an organised tour, the gardens were beautiful particularly in anticipation of Tet. Here we were able to understand and appreciate the significance of Vietnamese history and culture and view some iconic statues. As lovers of history we enjoyed this interlude,but no more than an hour would be required.

Fairly average- worth looking if you are bored. We were very underwhelmed by the Temple of Literature. The Lonely Planet Guide and all the hotels recommended this attraction, so we had reasonable expectations.Whilst the gardens were pretty and attractive- we found there was not much depth to this attraction. There was a not a lot to see and the exhibits were not overly interesting. From what we could see the temple did no have much to do with literature at all. We left after 30 minutes and it was a very long walk from the Old Quarter (where most tourists stay). I would only visit this attraction if you are bored and have time to kill. No loss in my honest opinion if you don't see it!

Worth a peak, especially if you are into historical stuff.. I have seen so many temples throughout SE Asia that my standards have become rather high. This place was ok, but not that impressive. I am not much of a history enthusiast, so that is partly why I wan't too excited by it. The complex is roughly the size of a small city block and contains ok landscaping, some ornate stone gates, a number of buildings to check out, and a few other minor attractions (big bells, bonsai trees, etc). My favorite part was the building at the far back which was a mini museum with two levels. Entry was 20,000VND and a printed guide can be purchased for 8,000. There were a few English signs scattered about that talked about the history, but I suppose a guide (book or person) might be necessary to get a full story. I spent roughly an hour checking the place out, but I was also moving slowly and didn't have anywhere else to be. I could of easily seen the whole place in 30 minutes if I was moving faster.Overall this place was ok and worth visiting if you have time to kill and are looking for stuff to do. I imagine people who are into history would get more out of the place than I did.
Quiet, well comparativly. Interesting and informative.Good place to calm down and contact lokals.Musik interesting.If limited on time forget it

Interesting & Colourful. We visited the temple as part of our 14 day tour of Vietnam & Cambodia. I found it very interesting - just looking and absorbing. You do get lots of history on group tours and so I tend to switch off after a while and just enjoy looking, absorbing the culture and reading any of the notices that happen to be in English. I did have some nice encounters with locals: one of them a monk, the other a little girl who was with her mother. There is a lot to look at and there is also a souvenir shop that sells postcards - and STAMPS!

Temple of Education.. Very sober and ancient place full of peace. Can pray for knowledge and success. The college degree convocations are organizes there which is a very colorful day full of bouquets and flowers.

Beautiful. This is the original university of Hanoi. Beautiful buildings and we had the added spectacle of some of this year's graduates from the modern universities coming here to celebrate, dressed in all their graduation finery. What fun

An hour was enough. But don't get me wrong, it was an hour well spent. We went with a private guide for part day market and Old town tour,y and enjoyed this part of the visit immensely. What I found most interesting was the ironwood pillars in the temple. We have been to several other sites in Vietnam where they were termite ridden and water damaged, but these were in pristine shape. I confess to being a little 'templed-out", but this one was worth the visit.

The best in Hanoi. The ancient place is the most authentic and historical part of Hanoi. Some of the chambers are still being used as lecture halls for prominent speakers. To be able to look at the stone steles displaying the names of past scholars was a real treat.

great place. It is quiet and authentic. The place is still used as a university and the current prince went to school here. It's worth visiting. Allow for a 20 minute walk from the old quarter and another 20 minutes for the visit.f you're thinking of where you can eat there's plenty of places next to it. There is a charity that donates all proceeds from food sales in their restaurant to help children from poor families. The place is to the left of the Pho 24 restaurant

A must to visit when in Hanoi. This is well worth a visit. The grounds are beautifully kept (though the water in the ponds is definitely undrinkable). Very interesting history and artifacts. Well worth a visit.

Worth visiting in Hanoi...bring a guide. This was a rather interesting and historic structure in Hanoi. While the architecture and setting are truly quite pleasant, I found the history connected to the structure to the be the most interesting aspect of visiting. There are a number of explanatory panels, but I think without a guide or a local that knows the history, one would be a little lost as to its significance. We had a local friend show us around and that made the experience that much more interesting. This destination is walkable from old town, although if you tire easy, take a taxi.As a tip, there's an awesome juice place, Vu Canu, en route from the old quarter. Stop in for some refreshment.

Well worth a visit. A lovely garden leads to a large pond with 2 huge floral 'walls' at the far end. We saw numerous graduating students having their photos taken and one young lady was happy for me to take her picture. The costumes they turn up in are beautiful. The collection of 'lucky' stone turtles is interesting and the shrine to Confucius with its gold turtle is beautiful and very cool and serene. A local guide will add to your visit if you want to understand the history.
Tranquil oasis in chaotic city. Loved this place... It was very interesting, very beautiful.The layout is interesting, the stories amazing and our guides best of all
Not to be missed!. Unique place! History & Culture! Not to be missed! If you have a good tour guide you will learn amazing history of this place.

One of those rare places in Hanoi.... where you can open your eyes and not see motorcycles. The Temple of Literature & National University has a nice garden and when I visited (beginning of January), there wasn't much of a crowd. I was actually hoping to see graduating students in ao dais for photoshoots but I was not lucky. There are boards that provide important information about the site. Architecturally, I didn't find the temple interesting or special although I understand its significance is more historical and symbolic. Most people recommend hiring a guide to understand more about the place (which I failed to do) but overall, it's a good place to wander around or sit down to write postcards for a bit.

Peace & Calm in the midst of the chaos of Hanoi!. We visited in December with my wife and 2 daughters. The first University in Vietnam. Very small but a nice place to pass some time in the peace and serenity of nice gardens and reflecting ponds. When we were there there was a wedding party getting photos done. All the ladies with the Traditional Vietnamese dresses on. Definitely recommend it to anyone visiting Hanoi.

Impressive place. We visited this with our family of five and with a private tourguide. I think that without the infirmation we received from the guide I would not have enjoyed this place so much, but this fantastic place harbours so much history and all the little hitoric facts like the three gates each time you enter the next part of the temple, and their meaning was just great.Absolutely worth a visit, but do not just walk in or you will be disappointed. Make sure you prepare yourself by reading or better, by engaging a guide.
Old building in centre. Peaceful and beautiful. You just wander around and take in the views of the building. Take a walk around the pond on the other side of the road.

Not that impressive like people say. I was really curious but its big garden with walls around. Inside you can see sculptures of scholars and Confucious instead of Buddha. Young students go there in red dresses to take pics for luck in studying. It was first university in Hanoi so it has big historical value but it does not give you that feeling. No library or anything. Dont be surprise to see Coca Cola cans around saint Buddha or here Confucius. I asked our guide why they put it there because it looks awful to me. Its because they give Buddha things of daily use and Coca Cola represent it ??!! I would prefer to see only Buddhas with candles and flowers :)
Oldest centre of learning in Vietnam. We visited as part of a guided city tour and the guide provided lots of historical information which rounded out the visual beauty of the grounds and buildings.

Just OK. Since we were already at Ho Chi Minh's, this was close by. We zipped through it in 20 minutes. I didn't find the grounds very attractive. The water in the ponds was low (and dirty) and not much landscaping to speak of. Even the surviving (motionless) fish in the pond looked bored. The shrines inside were ok, but not as nice as we have seen elsewhere. There may be a lot of history here, but you would need to bring along a guide book to read up on it.

Back to the Past. Informative tour, looking into how they did learning / schooling in the past thousand years. Amazing how some of the buildings can withhold for more than thousand years, noticed there is no nails, bolt or metal hinges, all were made from woods!

Beautiful place to visit. I went here not knowing what to expect and was so delighted! It is a beautiful temple to visit, lovely gardens, so peaceful. And KOTO is just across the road - a very good restaurant. And also Indigo store - selling handmade clothes, scarves etc. from Sapa Hills.

Vietnam's effort to follow the Chinese mandarin education model. This is the set of buildings that developed over the years as Vietnam tried to educate its own enough to develop the mandarin types to run the country as well as China. But in fact, it seems to have graduated only a relative few to fill the country's needs. Nonetheless, a fascinating example of how to do one form of education.
Worth a visit. This place has lovely gardens, statues and houses. It was interesting what our guide told us about the place and how they use to do things here.

Great place to escape the frenzy and noise of Hanoi. We spent a good few hours here one morning relaxing from all the noise and bustle that is Hanoi. The interpretative notices and boards are very informative and it was especially good to learn all about Confucius and his contributions. The Temple is made of a series of courtyards some of which we may have missed if we didn't go round the sides of each building. Be sure to go to Koto across the road for a bite to eat

One of my favorite locations in Hanoi. This is the third time I've been to the temple of leisure. I always go when I'm in Hanoi. This time there was a wonderful photo exhibit and a man writing on scrolls for the new year. Interesting and beautiful.
The Temple is depicted on the 100,000 Dong paper money. Nice gardens, scripts of past students engraved on cement atop turtle sculptures. Bonsai gardens. Interesting to walk around.

A large impressive complex. Interesting to learn about the way of life for students. Fascinating to see modern day students in their graduation robes still coming here to have their photos taken as the centre of learning in Vietnam.
A Great Link to VN's Literary Culture & Tradition. Well worth the time to visit this well-arranged collection of traditional Vietnamese buildings and artifacts

Peaceful, but not much to see. Yes, it is peaceful to leave the busy streets of Hanoi for a while, and it is cheap at 20,000VND (about 60p). But even with the guide"leaflet" (too small to call a book) which gives a brief history of the place and some more detail regarding some of the temples, there really was not much to see here. Perhaps if you hire a guide there will be more stories to be unearthed, but otherwise there are better things to be doing in Hanoi such as the Hoa Lo prison and Women's museum.

Different from what I imagined. It was intellectually exciting, especially since this is the cradle of Vietnam's higher education. I expected something grander and for the place to have a somewhat revered atmosphere. And my visit had to coincide with a graduation batch's photo-taking session. While it was interesting to be greeted with the Vietnam's national costume on the female graduates, their happy chatter and laughter (and blocking most of the gateways and paths with their phototaking) makes for a rather unexpected experience. Even so, it was interesting to have a glimpse into Vietnam's education historically, and to find heavy imperial Chinese influence as well. I believe it would have been a better visit if there wasn't much group activities going on, this temple is like a sanctuary within the bustling Hanoi, and it would have been nice to visit it like that.
Beautiful and Meaningful. Beautiful architecture and grounds in the middle of busy Hanoi. Hire a guide - this is historically, culturally very interesting.
Nothing much to see here. I was a bit disappointed with the Temple of Literature. I was expecting more on the literature side and lesser of the temple side. But it turned out the other way.
