Special pleace. The Temple of Literature is a complex of a few court yards. Every courtyard is different. In every yard there is a temple. You enter from one yard to another. There are small souvenir shops between the yards. In the last yard there is a beautiful temple. In The last hall there is a short concert with local musical instruments. The purpose of this show is to sell more souvenirs at an outrages price.It is realy special, but make sure not to buy souvenirs you do not need.

One of the few historical sites with strong Chinese influence. The concept of how the universities were run is interesting. there are no signs in English so consider getting a guide (additional fees). Its one of the few places in the old town (actually its a little out of old town) that is peaceful, and tranquil. We noticed a few people missed the last section of the temple as there are no clear signs. Go around to the end and the last section is really very nice. Also note the 'bonsai' trees along the way. If you look carefully there are small houses or miniature boats or people there. Good for 2hrs.

Peace in the Chaos. The Temple of Literature is a great place to stop and reflect amongst the noise of Hanoi. Located not far from the old quarter and amongst bustling street markets, the temple of literature is a peaceful, beautiful attraction dedicated to learning. If you need transport, it seems like every motorbike and cyclo is waiting for you outside!! Across the street from the temple is a small lake - get here about an hour before sunset and watch the locals go fishing and get in their daily exercise - a great spot to people watch

Calm amongst chaos. A great respite from the chaos of Hanoi traffic! I love education and studying so really enjoyed this temple. Even if you aren't into academic pursuits this sight is a must see while in Hanoi. the gardens are beautifully maintained and a delight to meander through. I loved the temples and the Doctors' Stone Stelea.

No much info. I went with my friend and she gave me more info than what was provided, but its expected b/c the entrance fee is quite cheap. It wasn't too big, you can get some nice photos. I wouldn't spend more than 45 minutes in there.

Gorgeous and cheap entry. Entrance is 20,000 dong. The grounds are gorgeous and was actually the most crowded place we went to while in Hanoi and it was the low season in the area. There are nearby highly rated eateries in the area as well.

An Important Place in Vietnam's History. Located across the street from the city's wonderful Museum of Art, the beautiful grounds and buildings of this ancient university are a testament to Vietnam's rich heritage of teaching and learning.

Important historical and cultural building. The buildings (different gates and important artefacts) were all rebuilt or kept to their original structures. It was the first National University of VietNam until she became a colony of France.
A good insight of the Vietnamese history.. It certainly was very instructive for me (but I like history). Didn't realise how old this civilisation goes back to. Amazing jewellery and stone objects.

Definitely worth a visit. The Temple of Literature is an impressive temple complex, which is definitely worth a visit. At the time of our visit, there were loads of graduates taking pictures of themselves. It was really nice to witness this bit of Vietnamese tradition.
Very nice.. Very nice to walk around, relaxing and spiritual. Lovely. Many graduates were visiting on the day we were there and you could feel it was a momentous place for them.
young graduates gather for formal photographs. lots of graduates congregate to have formal photos taken in beautiful attire - an atmosphere of success & excitement

An inspiring visit. The Temple of Literature (or rather the Temple of Knowledge) is an inspiring place given that it represents a life view emphasizing the importance of study, education and knowledge. And when remembering this all this took place around the year 1,000, a period of time where the western world was busy worshiping ignorance, the appreciation of the achievement and wisdom embedded within the walls of this place is even more astounding.

A Gem in Hanoi. It was so nice to see this museum, with statues of Confuscius and the Kings and statues of turtles, Old Architecture, the Bell and Drum, as well as a display of Photographs from some of the best photographers. I even caught a group of graduating students throwing their hats off, which made it a special.

Loved it. Beautiful temple, a peaceful refuge in a noisy, busy city. When we were there dozens of graduates were there in their graduation gowns to take pictures since it's a temple devoted to learning. You can walk to Hoa Lo prison ("Hanoi Hilton") from there (took about 15 minutes.)

Worth a visit. I spent an hour wandering around this gorgeous place. The history is there in all it's glory and it is also the place where all the graduating students go to have their end of year photos taken, so it was lively to say the least! The history of the Temple and its scholars is fascinating and given that it's over 1000 years old is pretty amazing. The buildings and artefacts are all in good condition and there is plenty of information in English on the history and people. Well worth a visit.

The home of higher education in Vietnam. This is an outdoor facility. The grounds are interesting and well tended. There is one major building that is partially enclosed and worth a visit. This visit can be done in an hour. There is a small gift shop that actually has some nice and reasonably priced gifts. If you want a water puppet that performed in the Hanoi water puppet theater, this is the place. Negotiate a bit and the price will be much better than that near the theater.
Don"t miss!. Beautiful, thousand year old, university of Confucianism. Mercifully quiet even though it's in the city. It was moving to see modern day devotees worship at the shrine.
Lovely. Learn how the Vietnamese honor and respect learned wisdom as you walk through the buildings and enjoy the grounds around them festooned with lovely plantings.

Peace and quiet. It's a beautiful place which give you an experience of time. Last time they had an photo exhibition from all over Vietnam and this time it was graduation day for a lot of students. Gives you also a time off from the hectic street life of Hanoi
Interesting and very cheap entry price. Very interesting, nice to walk in winter, and the entry price is very cheap. Worth to go for a few hours to spare.

History and Location.. This is well worth seeing, price is cheap. Beauty, history, and other visitors are worth going for. Location: next to KOTO, Know One Teach One Restaurant. Walk to restaurant. Good food, they teach young people who need a helping hand to work in all jobs within a restaurant and then give them a job.
Another temple site. Quite long in length, there is plenty to see including sculptures, The shops along the way are small and hard to move around in.

Alive. A must see, but best explored with a guide who can bring the temple alive and show you the best way to explore it. Great art displays if you lucky, and fascinating if properly researched before hand rather than just vsiting blindly.

Not worth the line ups and crowds. An average temple site, rather dull if you have previously seen a few of these. Many better sites in Hanoi but worth a quick look if you are in the area for the Fine Arts Museum or Ho's Mausoleum.

Unique University. Its a very old and first university with very rich cultures and history.Every year, before the students graduated from the current university, the class will hold their graduation in Temple of Literature university with photography sessions and the National costume wore by the females student really caught my eyes,The girls were very slim and pretty in this outfit.

Average Buddhist temple grounds. I just happened to be in the area so I made my way in. There was a cheap $1 ticket, and then in you go. The grounds have some nice tree sculptures of dragons and other animals and the entrance walkway is lined with Chinese symbols on both sides made from flowers. Pretty and good photo ops. The water "troughs" leading to the temple were holding stagnant and dirty water, with the exception of one that had some pretty water lilies.The main temple ground is exactly what you'd expect. An open space flanked on both sides by tourist shops and the main pagoda in the middle with the various Buddha statues. It's a decent 1hr walk around away from the hustle and bustle of the city, but I wouldn't really go out of my way to go see it.

Amazing piece of Confucian History. This is an ancient university. There are tablets with inscriptions, beautiful grounds, historic buildings and a very peaceful environment amongst the bustling city. There were university groups celebrating their graduations the day we were there and their smiling faces added to the atmosphere.
Oasis of calm!. Nice to get out of the frenetic streets for a while! Good place to chill and meditate! Not loads in there really but great feel.

Worth a short visit. A calm oasis in the middle of Hanoi. Nothing striking about the place but the historical context is good. There was a photography exhibition when we visited which was interesting. Worth a quick visit.
So Awesome. This was a school of Confucius and his 4 Excellent Disciples. There are ancient tablets that sit on sculptured turtles, a sign of longevity.
A bit of quietness in the city. Big temple with surprises along the way. Pagodas and statues are exquisite and reflects well the worship of intelligence in this place.

Very living example of traditional culture. We happened to visit the temple on April 30th, which is a very important rememberance day in Vietnam and on the eve of May 1st, the traditional day of celebration. The temple was beutifully decorated with flowers all over and people were celebrating very lively. One of the most impressive visits during our Vietnam tour.

The University Grads make this worthwhile - Temple of Literature, Hanoi. Recommended by our hotel, we loved this place - purely because of all the girls in their graduation gowns. Before you even go in, you'll see the streets full of excited girls (& boys) dressed up, and with graduation gowns and caps. Their faces and happiness are alone worth going for.The Temple itself and grounds are nice too, but insignificant compared with the above.Worth a visit to see the grads (as you probably guessed!).

not only for students. Place was jampacked with student taking photos on their graduation. A lot of kids were doing "selfless" by the gates, at the pond, close to the turtle statues etc but still pretty atmospheric.I imagine that it would be such a serene place had I visited on a regular day.

A definite must for a trip to Hanoi. This is a beautiful place to visit and learn about education and learning in historical Vietnam. Reasonably priced and easy to get to from anywhere in the city. I took this photo and felt so impressed by this man.

An Essential Part Of Hanoi. As a frequent visitor to Hanoi (this was my 4th visit in 7 years), I make a point of re-visiting the Temple of literature every time. It is about 2 km's west of the Hoan Kiem lake so it's not too far from the Old Quarter (which is where you should stay). Although it is always crowded it is a very pleasant oasis of calm. It is essentially a string of 1000 year old courtyards with well tended gardens, ornate doorways and statuary. At the far end there is a room (temple ?) in which (on all of my visits anyway) there are 6 or so musicians performing Vietnamese music. All this for a $1 ! I always combine my visit with lunch (or whatever) at KOTO just across the road, shopping at Craftlink, a fair trade outlet for hand made products from all over Vietnam, also just across the road and the Fine Arts Museum at the top end of the road (Van Mieu) (see my separate reviews of these places). They all make for a very satisfying, conveniently close to each other day trip.
Rather Disappointing. After all the hype, we were quite disappointed at the condition and accessibility to the site. It is worth a visit if you are in the area, but not otherwise.

few good and wise men. at the onset of the viisit to this temple our tour guide already informed us that the previous structures that once existed in this grounds were destroyed during the French invasion of Hanoi. hence, I didn't expect much from the place. the temple is very typical of the Chinese temples. nothing much to see except for the exquisite statues and carvings. the stones which etched the names of outstanding students of the confucious' center were something new. it was interesting though that there were so many youth who wore some sort of vietnamese comtemporary attire, who we later learned were new college graduates. their happiness is just communicable. the place looked fun because of them. when visiting this temple, get your cameras ready because there are many picture-perfect views in this place.

Very interesting. One thing I must note before I continue this review is that on trip advisor it mentions that there is no fee for entrance but I did not find this to be the case. I believe there was a entrance fee of around 35000 dong or thereabouts.The Temple itself was very interesting to explore and on the particular day that I went (October 28th) there were students from a nearby university taking graduation photos in traditional vietnamese clothing which was a nice touch.If you are in Hanoi during the day I would recommend that the Temple of Literature should be one of the places you go and see!

Temple of Literature & National University. You should see this while you are in Hanoi. When I used to live in Ha Noi, I would come here to get away from the hubbub of the city and breathe in the history.

photo opportunities. We were lucky enough to visit whilst many students were celebrating their graduation dressed in traditional vietnamese outfits complete with western style mortar-board hats. The temple itself is more like a taoist chinese place complete with usual gardens and architecture.

Ancient Scholars Tributory. The foregrounds of the place are stone etched carvings of names of top notch imperial scholars as a tribute of their academic achievement. There is a temple at the inner grounds where many Vietnamese belief one could excel in studies after praying at the temple. Worth a visit & a short walk away from old quarters or Hoan Kiem lake.

Not what was expected. Having no prior knowledge of what this place would hold, I was a little disappointed in the venue as a whole as it was swarming with tour groups and cameras. The stones were impressive and it made for a welcome break from the city madness, but it has been turned into a temple and a tourist shop and so it has lost some of its appeal for me. At 20k vnd to enter you should probably include it on your sightseeing tour, but it isn't going to blow you away.

Such a vibrant and cheerful spot. I guess that the timing of your visit will colour your opinion. We were ther in December and the students were visiting and dressed in the finery. Their visit was to get good luck for the upcoming exams (which occurs at yearend). There was such a buzz due to the students and this made it the more enjoyable.

Interesting and a bit of quiet in centre of Hanoi. Not a huge place. Worth a visit is you have time. We were fortunate to be caught up in the graduation ceremonies, gave the whole place a buzz.A least it gave us a break from the noise and fumes

Palatable cultural dose for boys 10 -16 years. Lovely Temple. Travelling with 3 boys I need to be really selective if visiting museums or cultural locations as few hold their interest for too long. This one was a nervous choice but the setting , the gift shops, the temple and the students kept them engaged for awhile.

Temple of Literature & National University. One of the most interesting place I visited in Hanoi.This is a beautiful and interesting complex or original and reconstructed buildings, dedicated to learning.The temple buildings, although some of them have been rebuilt, still retained the atmosphere of time gone by. It must have been a fantastic place to study as it exudes tranquility and elegance.

Very nice. We went on a Sunday morning, and the place was packed with students and also bridal parties, all having their group photos taken. (A very attractive people are the Vietnamese). Thesetting of this 'Temple' is beautiful and well maintained, and is well worth a visit.One of the nicer spots in the otherwise chaotic Hanoi. A tour guide is not needed, as your tourbook is all you need.

An Inspiration to Vietnam's Scholars. I love the whole place, seeing the importance of education throughout the centuries. The temple buildings, although some of them have been rebuilt, still retained the atmosphere of time gone by.It must have been a fantastic place to study as it exudes tranquility and elegance. I can almost seescholars in their long gowns walking around deep in thought. Clearly today's graduates are impressed by the ambience and beauty of the Temple that there were scores of graduates and tourists being photographed by their peers at the time I visited in November.

Beautiful architecture. The temple is made up of a number of courtyards and a temple building in the end. The architecture is beautiful and certainly worth a visit.To get a better understanding of the meaningfulness of this place, take a guide with you.
Great place to visit. Excellent history and fantastic architecture, even had a traditional music performance. I would defiantly recommend you pay this a visit for an hour or so.
Delightful to see the Vietnamese youth celebrating. Lots of young men and women in smart suits and lovely dresses enjoying their graduations in a historic setting.

A little bit of calm. This is a beautiful and interesting complex or original and reconstructed buildings, dedicated to learning. Easily enough to keep yourself occupied for an hour or two.It's also a calm escape from the hectic city life all around!
Average expirience. The place is nice and include old temples. At the same time, it is just nice. I would not bother plan the visit around this place unless I happend to be in this area.

Interesting place but not enough English translation. Beware of the ticket lady at the gate as she tried to short change us by 50k! There is very limited English translation which is a great shame as it would have been a lot better if we could understand the history behind the items on display.

Travels in Vietnam. Interesting to hear how this seat of learning was established.......the day we went there the whole area was overtaken by high spirited Graduands having pre ceremony photographs taken! We were in great demand to be photographed with them!
Beautiful. We were lucky enough to be there on a day when a college graduation was taking place. So fun to see all the students posing for their proud families. Great architecture inside and out.

A cultural visit. We visited the temple which was amazing re the colours and the architecture but what made it interesting was we chose to visit on a day when the students were having photographs taken for their year books. This made us feel very much part of their culture and it was lovely to see the young people dressed up in their finery and watch them act out their traditions.

Good to include for a Hanoi city tour. When we arrived, we were somewhat surprised by the crowds. Turns out that it was a graduation day, hence the reason we saw so many young men and women, the latter dressed mostly in colorful and sexy ao dai (or the Vietnamese costume for women).Very good photo opportunity for the timing of our visit, so if you can catch it too, you will find colorful costumes, groups of women and men posing for pictures, balloons all over, flowers too and of course there were those souvenirs in the stalls.I think it cost us VND 10,000 per head for the admission fee. Very good bargain as the place is quite big. After we went through the picturesque main gate, there was a big garden with a nice leafy green lawn and trees, then through the second courtyard with some symbolism attached to present day Hanoi. A third courtyard had a big pond but what was interesting hereabouts was the large number of stone turtle steles - apparently it contained lists of those who passed the exams. Our guide explained the somewhat bewildering and challenging levels of schools that students had to go through (wow, so many). I noticed that the turtle seems to be a recurring symbol which is quite important to the Vietnamese people. We also reached the fourth courtyard, and aside from souvenir shops we saw, I noticed some musical performance going on at the side, Turns out that there was a short performance for bamboo instruments. Very nice - its free, though you are offered some cds containing some bamboo music. I didn't regret buying one because the music was soothing and a great background for parties.At the other side was an altar which seemed to be devoted to Confucius and his disciples. There seemed to be a lot of incense and altars..which am not sure how to identify now. Anyway, again another good photo op :-)Visit for at least an hour to two hours if you are interested in the cultural, religious and educational significance of this historic site.

The busiest venue we visited so it must be good. Whereas every other museum, monument, etc we visited was patronised by tourists, nothing we saw compared to the Temple of Literature. While there hundreds of graduating students from the suurounding senior schools were ther for photos. The girls looked so beautiful in their coloured trousers and white chong sams. Hair imaculate and decorated with flowers and/or jewellry. The boys in dress suits with bow ties (and sneakers!). Maybe for this venue a local guide would be helpful however my wife and I got the gist. Close enought to our hotel in the Old Quarter for us to taxi there and walk back through the shopping streets.

Graduation day at the Temple. We didn't notice too much of the actual temple, as there were so many students celebrating their graduations, we were mesmerised by all the young people and their fashions/photographic opportunities. The temple is obviously very popular with the local people and school children were being shown round and having various lessons in the grounds too. Don't be surprised if you are surrounded by a class of young (tots) people checking out their language skills on you

Read up before you go...... What do you expect from a place called the "Temple of Literature?" It's complicated, to say the least, so we recommend reading up on exactly what it's all about before going. It's a labyrinth of Asian Mystery, even with the explanations provided by the guide. The day we were there, graduates from the University were posing for pictures in colorful caps and gowns and traditional Vietnamese dress, which provided badly-needed levity to what was otherwise borderline drudgery. For a better experience, do your homework before you go.
Not much explanation. It's a great reprieve from traffic and noise, interesting and very old. Close to Kota training restaurant if you need a break from hussle bussle of Hanoi

nice, but needed a guide. This is a beautiful site that is an important historical reference for the spread of Confucianism, but you need a guide to bring out more information if you don't speak Vietnamese.
Really beautiful. While it was lightly raining on our day trip, it was a really beautiful and interesting spot to see.

Wonderful and profound. One of the most interesting place I visited in Hanoi. One of the gate inside this temple is engraved in Vietnamese currency.Temple of literature has a long history spanned to the 10 century. The complex is divided into five sections/halls. Each of them has different meaning representing the stage of human knowledge / education.Since this site is full of symbolism, you may want to take a little reading before you visit it.Admission fee is VND20,000/person. There is a musical performance at the building at the third hall. They play traditional musical instruments.Pay attention to details in this complex, especially at the rear sections. To reach the backyard of this temple you need to go through a small path.Best visited after lunch, and at the school holiday season. It may be full of school children celebrating their graduation, and the atmosphere can become more animated.NOTE: on the road at the eastern side of this temple - Van Mieu street - there is a barber there who may ask for money if you take his picture.

Went with tour. I think you need a guide to explain things as there is not much written info on the site.little stories from the guide really bring the place to life.we were their on graduation day o saw loads of really pretty students dressed up in their gowns and national dress

Such a beautiful place. I did this as part of a free tour with Hanoi Kids Tour. My guide knew a lot of its history. The day I was there, sooo many high school kids were there taking photos so it wasn't too serene; however, I loved seeing all the beautiful Vietnamese girls in their traditional au dais up against the beauty of this temple. Really loved seeing it.

Tour guides help. Me and my brother just showed up and had two young university students offer to be our tour guides for free. Apparently, they were studying for a exam but they were very informative and helpful. I'm not sure how interesting the place would have been without all the information that came out way. Worth a visit.

Wonderful history, happy people. This is a really worthwhile stop during your stay in Hanoi. The history and the buildings are fascinating, but even more delightful are the crowds of young students who come here to take group photos - particularly the girls who are dressed in traditional long dresses. And try Koto restaurant in the adjoining street, truly excellent local fare!

Charming!. Here on November 16th when many students were having their graduation photos taken. What a festive atmosphere. The setting is lovely and well worth a visit. Read up before you go as there is little history displayed.

A once a year experience. We were so lucky to be here on 16th November 2013. It was the day that all the 1st and final year undergraduates had chosen to have their photos taken. What a spectacular sight they made, 1st year girls in their prom type dresses with bouquets final students in their gowns and mortarboards and the boys immaculate in their suits and Italian style shoes all posing for photos (to put on Facebook!)

Lovely building. Not a bad place to visit in hanoi given the lack of things to do. Dont bother with their I formation/fact sheet as it doesnt really give you any more information than what's on ths information boards.

A lil' insight of their education system. Better to visit with a tour guide to understand their culture. Don't be surprised if there a lot of Uni Students having a pictorial when you visit the Temple.

Too many students. There are way too many students graduating here, you can not enjoy the gardens as the students ' graduating' get in the way. I don't thing the graduations are real. I wouldn't waste my time here!
Beautiful! . A quiet place in a busy city. The temple has great architecture and decoration. Very well preserved. It is a must visit when you are on Hanoi.
Pretty. Very pretty providing some nice photo opportunities. Was also nice seeing all the graduates. Definitely worth a visit but you only need about 30 minutes here.
Take your time for this. I did not know what to expect. But when we went though the gate and entered one of the old buildings, it was like going back in time. Suddenly history became alive ...

Van Mieu. We visited the Van Mieu on graduation day. It was full of students, the girls wearing the tipical vietnamese dress and the boys in dark suites. Colrful and gay. THere are several pagodas to visit and a rare temple dedicated to Confucio. Past a good afternoon. Entrance fee is 20.000 Dong
Worth a short visit. Did this as part of a city tour, about 40 minutes was about right for me. Another case of the tour guide providing vale added commentary

Photographing location for students. The place was nice & beautiful, but I won't talk about that as there were so many reviewers talked about its beauty already.My interesting point is about the students who come here to take photos for their graduation. Why there are so many graduated students each day? In fact, most of them are not actually graduated yet. But here is like the place they meet up and take photos in graduation gowns for fun! It's sort of inspiration saying that one day they would graduate. The gowns are available for rent.Well, it's where you can see a lot of pretty Vietnamese girls in their national costumes!

Interesting. I guess I was expecting something more. Yes, the gardens were lovely, and made more lovely by the students that must have been celebrating school graduation that were there taking class, friend and individual photos. The main building was small with a few displays and the history is interesting, but don't plan on spending a lot of time here.

beautiful gardens. The temple of literature is interesting and worth a visit for an hour or two. I went as part of a tour group and had a guide who was able to explain the history of the temple and items on display. I enjoyed walking around the beautiful gardens which are a peaceful change to the hectic traffic on the streets.

A piece of a bygone era. The temple of Literature is really old and historic. Our tour guide told us that it was built as a Confucius Temple in 1070. It is beautifully laid out with three long gates and corridors leading to the temple flanked by lotus ponds. There are several courtyards that lead to various rooms and halls. It is nice to have a tour guide with you who can tell you what is it that you are seeing. But it is not impossible to read it up ahead and navigate the place on your own too!The day we visited was graduation time I think so there were loads of students taking their pictures in graduation gowns. Also the girls were wearing their traditional Ao Dai and boys were handsomely dressed in suits. They added color and festivity to the place and it was nice touch of the modern in a rather old and historic monument!
History of Interest to Students and Teachers. The history of this attraction was really interesting and provided an opportunity for some unique photos.

Do not miss this. I wish that I had more time for the visit to this attraction. We tried to fit too much into one day but this is worth spending a good part of a day at. We didn't pay too much attention as to facilities for persons not able to move around freely unfortunately.

First university of Vietnam. This is a fascinating place, both aesthetically - lovely gardens and buildings - and historically - it has been there for a thousand years - to explore while in Hanoi. It is a little oasis of calm in a exciting city, in which to while away an hour or two and provides a good insight into the cultural and educational history of the ancient city.

Great place.. We didn't expect this place to be so good. There were a lot of students and pretty girls there and they had a live "original instrument" Vietnamese orchestra playing, which was actually fabulous. The place is very green and relaxing and no one hassles you to buy anything, a bonus. The students were doing their "mock" graduations and also "mock" marriages which was all very entertaining. I could have spent a whole day here. Maybe next time.

Not really worth a visit. Save your time and visit elsewhere. Built for the tourists. Did not get a good feel for the Confusius school of learning that existed here for many years. Now a tourist showplace.
Highly recommended. I have been there for few times. Each time is always different feelings. A must see place when in Hanoi

A definite must for any visit to Hanoi. Second time to the Temple of Literature. A definite must for any visit to Hanoi. As a previous review posted "1000 year old gem". And that is pretty much what you get.When we went there were many students there praying for good grades. It was an amazing experience and they were all happy to have their photo's taken. Entry is 20,000 VND for foreigners - $1. Great surrounding area to explore to, great restaurants and road side bars where you can get a beer for 15,000 VND 75 cents.
my impressions. i enjoyed my visit here and was impressed with the layout.however what was required was more information in english and some other major foreign languages

1000 year old gem. The Temple of Literature is one of the things, Ha Noi Citadel being another, that makes Ha Noi such a fascinating city. A visit to the Temple of Literature brings to light the fact that Ha Noi really is an ancient Asian city. Known as Van Mieu, the Temple of Literature is considered Vietnam's first University because this is where men came to study in the hopes of becoming mandarins to the King.The "campus" had been maintained impeccably well and you get a taste of ancient Vietnamese architecture. Some buildings were destroyed by the French in the 1950s - your tour guide can point these out - but many are original, including the turtle stelae.Suggestion: visit with guides from Hanoi Kids. Their knowledge, and English, is outstanding.

A lot of history with a lot of young life in it. We were lucky to visit the Temple of Literature when college students were celebrating their graduation which I think brought in exactly the right type of atmosphere.The "temple" itself is impressive in terms of its history and shows the great importance given to study and knowledge in Vietnam as long as 1000 years ago. It has been of course refurbished many times but you have feeling of "new" in almost all temples I have seen in SE Asia. Don't miss the rows of turtles with the names of former graduatesThe site was full of college students taking pictures of themselves and their classmates and it felt right, they belonged there and continued the tradition represented by the temple.Worth the visit. Go to Koto restaurant before of after (see separate review).
Don't miss it. This is a lovely and interesting oasis in the middle of the busy old quarter. It's an old Chinese university and the temples are very much in the Chinese style

Well weart a trip. This temple used to be a university and is well worth a visit. Although the visit will not take up to much of your time, it will give you an idea of how the local Buddha temples look like. Also have a look at the gardens, they are well worth a look. If you are lucky you will also find some graduates having their pictures taken in the local outfit.Finally don’t forget to rub the tortoise’s head before leaving, a bit of luck never hurts ;)

1,000 year old university. Well worth visiting to see the old buildings and grounds. On my day of visiting I was lucky enough to see local teenagers on a class trip to have their photos taken - guys in suits and girls in the traditional Ao Dai.

Thoughtful and different piece of Vietnamese history. Really enjoyed the thought provoking peaceful environment. Temple of Literature is very unique and an important place to understand more of Vietnam's colourful past

Interesting temple. The temple of Literature used to be a university. Taking the tour of the temple grounds is very interesting . It is the only Buddhist temple that has a statue of Confucius. It is well worth paying the entrance fee and taking the tour. When we were there there were hundreds of University graduate girls having their photographs taken in their lovely Ao dai dresses.

Gorgeous. Really interesting place to visit. Has lovely grounds and has been kept to a high standard.Is not too big so will not take up a huge part of your day.We were lucky enough to go on a morning with a lot of local pre-schoolers who added to our enjoyment with their big smiles.

Temple of Literature. Thee gate into the temple was magnificent--especially from the inside going out. Beautiful gardens and ancient tablets with graduates names back to the 1400's etched in stone. A beautiful location and a great place to people watch--we saw a group of young ladies in traditional áo dà (some in mortarboards) come for pictures celebrating their graduation.

If you are in Hanoi, you should really come and explore it yourself!. A space of peace, green trees and solemnity covers the whole temple of historical and traditional love for study, making tourists feel like they were lost in a land of Confucion and traditional values. If you are in Hanoi, you should really come and explore it yourself!
Historical. Must visit. It was not that crowded as we arrived just after 2pm. The atmosphere and the architecture is great. We liked the landscape as well.
Graduation. What a great place to visit..... We went on a day of graduation for local students so it was very busy but got some great photos with the girls in local dress. Well worth the visit.......

Temple of Literature & National University. I visited my sister in March 2013 and she advise me go to here. I had been gone to here by bus (from My Dinh). Temple of Literature & National University is the first university of Vietnam. This is one of the historic sites of my country. It's ancient and solemn.You can feel the beauty of Vietnam culture when you comes here.

Beautiful Historic Site. Beautiful place to visit and learn about education and learning in historical Vietnam. There were lots of students there to take photos in their traditional attire (ao dai) and graduation cap and gowns, which added to the atmosphere of the visit.

Temple to knowledge. Another fascinating monument that pays tribute to man's hunger for knowledge. Though it isn't much to look at, the history of the place and the stories behind it make this a must visit. The day we visited it was buzzing with graduating students (from schools in Hanoi) who came to get pictures taken. That itself was a sight to see. The hopes and aspiration was so palpable on their faces. The future meeting the past!

Well Worth the Visit. We have visited this site on two separate trips to Hanoi and have enjoyed it both times.The grounds are beautiful as is the design and architecture of the gates, courtyard walls central pool and main hall/statuary.Suggest that you avoid the souvenir shops. They are overpriced and you can get the same items at more reasonable costs on the streets of the old quarter.Go early in the morning to avoid the tour bus crowds.

Fun to Watch the Students. This is a very nice temple area, but the highlight is watching the students have their photographs taken. Entry fee is only 20 Dong. There are some nice craft stores across the street.

Take a guide. We were fortunate enough to have a guide take us to places such as this one and talk us through the history and explain things to us. This made the visit so much more interesting and gave us an insight into vietnamese history and culture and we appreciated the trip here so much more having walked away with that knowledge. Amazing place.
Beautiful and lively place. Lots of school classes go her to have their photos taken, while jumping and waving their hats in the air. Great fun. Very fine temple too.

Really interesting. I had no idea what to expect so this was a fabulous surprise. From the amazing bonsai and shaped trees to the beautiful buildings, this was a lovely place to visit. It came alive with the class of traffic graduates posing for photos.
Beautiful and well worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Packed full of history and on the day we went students graduating. Reasonably priced and easy to get to from anywhere in the city.

A must-see. Our only regret is that we got here late and only had about an hour or so. The Temple is a wonderful place and so0mewhat humbling for us Europeans who bang on about the richness of our univerisites in Paris, Oxford, Cambridge and Bologna. But there is so much to see: stunningly beautiful bonsai trees, topiary, collections of ancient instruments, temples, beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit and a little oasis of calm in an otherwise hectic city!

Beautiful. The day I was there, it was full of life. Vietnamese schools had graduation ceremony, it was really fun to see a lot of young people having fun and taking pictures in suit and traditional Vietnamese dresses. A place which celebrates and embraces education.
A memorable visit to the past. Great time. Wish to have more time but due to being with a tour, we had limited time but we will for sure be back some day.
Nice monument in Hanoi. Nice buildings, well preserved and maintained, too many tourists though as it is a main attraction in Hanoi, but worth a visit anyways.

A Haven of Peace. This temple is much as it stood since its earliest days. It is just beautiful - lovely gardens and ponds, paths for contemplation and shrines dedicated to past masters of this temple of learning. Names are inscribed on stela - I wished for a translation! To have a liaison person available to answer questions and provide context - I would have had a deeper appreciation of the significance of this lovely temple.
peaceful place. The Temple of Literature was a very beautiful and peaceful place. We walked around the scenic gardens. We had a local guide who gave us the history of the place.

Standout temple. A marvelous temple to visit. I saw numerous gatherings of recent graduates dressed very formally for the occasion. So much history associated with the temple. Beautiful architecture and gardens along the central walkway.
Amazing place. Titled Vietnam's first university that still in use today. Very interesting history and pretty place to stroll through and take great pictures.
A Hanoi highlight. We enjoyed the beauty of the Temple of Literature. We went on our own after reading about it but next time, I would prefer going with a guide so that I could learn more about it.

Don't miss this Temple. This is a fascinating temple to learning. Beautiful and calm after Hanoi bustle. The floral displays were unusual and colorful. It wasn't included on our city tour so we would recommend visiting it on your own. We got there by Tuk-tuk.
Peaceful. One of the most beautiful temple complexes we saw in Vietnam. It's a must-see when you're visiting Hanoi, especially for keen photographers. Take your time to stroll through the complex.

Graceful buildings. This complex of courtyards, gardens, temple to Confucius and other buildings is very attractive and full of interest. The buildings from various periods are graceful, the temple is impressive and the collection of monuments to past scholars most unusual

An oasis of calm. After the hustle and bustle of the crazy streets of Hanoi, this place was an absolute oasis of calm. Our HanoiKids guide really brought the place to life with an endless stream of stories and legends on every aspect of the design, layout and historical significance of the place.This place was a highlight of our visit to Hanoi. Definitely worth a visit.
very interesting. Great guide who explained in detail the history of the Temple.We found this a very interesting place to visit as we have never seen anything like this before.
Delightful and Educational. Lovely little museum. Small, quick tour, but very historic and interesting. It helps if you are with a guide who explains the significance of what you're seeing.
Afternoon sunshiny. This is a great place to wander around in later in the afternoon... history, beauty, serenity, enjoyable!

Just to visit a 700 hundred years university. Visit a 700 years old educational complex. Now the educational activities are no longer going on here but the complex attracts the visitors. The students graduated from other universities come here and take photos to make their graduation memorable. The newly married couples also come here and take photos at this place.

Sure, it is a "must go" place to visit when you are in Hanoi. Temple of Literature was formed in 1076 as Quoc Tu Giam - Vietnam's first university, also referred to as Van Mieu in Vietnamese, was established within a temple to educate Vietnam's royalty, mandarins and members of the elite. The university functioned for an incredible 700 years and its gardens and well-preserved architecture offer a fascinating glimpse into Vietnam’s past.This is no doubt a great place to see and enjoy 1/2 hour walking, make sure you come with a tour guide to understand the place throughout.

Beautiful garden and temple in perfect harmony. My favourite garden and temple in Hanoi. The whole garden is symmetrical and based on Feng shui it is immaculate and the Bonsai are so big and stunning. The temple houses statues of Confusis and his scholars. Many university graduates were ther having there photos and it was lovely to see them laughing and having fun. A must see in Hanoi -we went twice that's how much we liked it.

Interesting history and well maintained.. Definitely worth a visit for the history of the place and also the pretty gardens and courtyards. The temple is actually on the bank of one of the Vietnamese money notes. I think it was the 100,000 note. A must visit during your time in Hanoi. Fee is something like 15,000 Dong which is nothing.
Beautiful. This is a beautiful temple with a fascinating history. A great way to understand some of Vietnam's older religious history.
Peaceful place. Located in center of old quarters, near Lenin statue and mausoleum. There is some nice buildings, grass and pond. Must see place if you in Hanoi.

Interesting place. We found a visit to the Temple of Literature very interesting. This used to be the first National University of Vietnam and gifted students came to study here. The buildings are very well preserved and the gardens are pretty.

Very Interesting Place. The Temple of Literature & National University is located to the south of Thang Long Citadel, Hanoi. It has a main gate which leads to three pathways that run the length of the complex. The central one was reserved for the Monarch, one to the left for Administrative Mandarins and one to the right for Military Mandarins. Inside is divided into five Courtyards. Giant turtles have the names of those successful at exams. Fourth Courtyard is for ceremonies. Fifth is the grounds of the Academy. There is also a shop where you can buy gifts.
Fantastic, moving place. Just fantastic, but go later in the day when you seem to have the place to yourself, and feel the calm of the place in a noisy city
Peaceful Place. The grounds are manicured and the turtle stones are amazing awards give to those of achievement. Worth a wander through on your way to the Fine Art Museum two blocks away.

Very interesting. Very interesting temple, with many areas and interesing details. Unfortunately when we went there it was pouring down with rain and this ruined the visit, because we couldn't really enjoy the many courtyards. But I'd still recommend it.

Very interesting. We would certainly recommend a visit to the Temple of Literature and National University. Seeing some of the methods of teaching that provide a backdrop to learning in today's world was incredible and the experience here was very worthwhile.

Temple of Literature (Van Mieu) is a highlight. Don't miss this beautiful temple! I've been here twice and it was as charming on the second visit as it was on the first. Luckily, we were there when a class of students were graduating and that was wonderful.

Beautiful. We went at Tet, and although travel at Tet is often advised against, the Temple of Literature was far more exciting. Many. Vietnamese had co me to pay their respects to he ancestors so the place was alive. There were dancers and giant Chinese chess. The building themselves are beautiful.

Confucian complex.. The Temple of Literature, a Confucian edifice, is well worth a visit; don't miss the musicians playing classic Vietnamese music in the centre building, you may have to wait. The architecture is similar to those in China but this complex is large and well maintained. There are some good bonsai trees in interesting pots especially in the main quad. The supports, in cedar, for the main building are magnificent. A haven of tranquility amidst all the hustle and bustle.
The nice place. There are not far form Hoan Kiem Lake .Please take on the bus no. 02 at Hoc Trang road and pay 5000 VND for a ticket. The temple of Literature are nice place of history

Interesting. You need to know what this place is and why it is significant in order to enjoy your time here and appreciate what you are seeing. There really is not a lot to do inside besides look and walk around. But if you look up what this place it and why it is locally important then you will probably enjoy it more and appreciate it's history and meaning.
Great little spot. I went twice to the Temple of Literature as it was beautiful to wander around and admire the architecture.

Culturally and educationally brilliant. So glad we visited this historical temple of learning. It helped us understand where the Vietnamese get their drive and thirst for knowledge. The country as a whole just wants to progress and the people want to improve themselves. They realise they have ancestrally, `big shoes to fill'. We could learn a lot about raising our `bar'.

Beautfiul site and very tranquil. Evidently the school children come here a lot for inspiration and they were fun to see and wave hello to as they were led around. Each turtle with its tablet has its own face and personality if you will which is interesting to ponder. It is easy to imagine this as a place where students came to read, debate, and contemplate. I found it to be inspiring myself and the red lacquer is amazing. I thoroughly enjoyed this place- I wish I had the chance to see even replicas of the scrolls and writings they were studying- translated of course.

Temple of Literature, The Place to see in Hanoi. The history, 1070 through the 1400's into the 17 and 18th century, The markers of all those who graduated the university at the temple sight through the ages, the pagoda to Confucius, all make this worth seeing. If you do anything in Hanoi, this must be on your trip otherwise you did not see Hanoi. Number one spot for historical background, culture, photographs, etc. ALSO, the gift shops here are quite nice. On the street you are charged really high prices being a travelor and you must haggle and bargain alot but not this place, where the price is marked and they have a variety of items all in one place. Good to knock out the gifts for those back home and enjoy the bauty of the Temple of Literature.

The importance of education in Vietnam.. We had an instructive visit here with Hanoi kids. The most important thing we learned on our visit here was the great respect that Vietnamese have for education as a way to move he whole country forward. This is a tradition that goes back over a thousand years and the ideal prevails today.

A calm refuge from the street madness. It is an ancient testimony to the peoples commitment to education and study. Set in beautiful gardens it is a calm space from the frenetic rivers of mopeds outside.
Fun museum to visit. Nice place to go and to learn a little about Vietnam's history, including the occupation by the Chinese.

Beautiful place. Temple of literature is a beautiful place to visit. It was the first university in hanoi. The architecture is very interesting and stunning. You don't need very long to walk around and see it all, 30 -40 mins should cover it. Worth a visit.
Nice city of this country. Nice city and good for travel Nice people nice for everything but not good for night life so quiet when after 9.00pm
History revealed.. This complex was great - gave a very good insight into some of the history of the country - it was also a quiet respite from the hurly burly of the city .
A favourite place. When I am in Hanoi I always come to the temple of Literature at least once. It is an insight into history but also a place of calm in the middle of a frantic city!
Interesting. Very nice gardens and interesting place. The shops here in the centre of the place sell really cheap souveniers so take advantage of that while you are there. Nice gardens and temples.
Peace and learning. An oasis of quiet (motorbike free!) in the centre of Hanoi, the Temple provides a fascinating history of this ancient institution. Well worth a visit.

Nice place with historical values for the best of the best ........ This Temple of Literature was a kind of inauguration place of the best students of Vietnam in the past. It was told that most likely only once in a hundred years a very genius one graduated from the University here and become the advisor to the King or even son-in-law of the King. The root of the University and the Temple was Confucian. There are a lot of valuable histories of Vietnam in this place and it is also beautiful with its garden .......

Temple of Literature and National University. This former University was so unbelievably difficult to get in. Students had to first graduate top of their classes at each of several levels of schools - primary, secondary, etc. Only the cream of the cream gets into this place. But! The top graduate from here got to be THE advisor to the Vietnam king! And all the rest of the graduates were much sought after.Today its a temple. Very peaceful and beautiful. Worth a visit to get away from the hustle and bustle and have a quiet peaceful 1 hour to reconnect with your inner self.
Very pretty and peaceful. This was very peaceful and beautiful gardens . It had lots of history behind it . We did not have a guide to speak with us we just went on our own .

Nice green and decorated place to visit in Hanoi. Nice place, no cost. Nice gardens at the enterance, few tourist shops inside, live music is played at the main university's hall, and few unique statues are placed around.

It's interesting.. Cannot imagine the vietnamese can read chinese for long time ago. Although they use own language nowadays, part of the them still learning Chinese. I am so appreciated that they still the temple so well.

turtles. I hope that you go with a guide - one that point out the story and the rebuilding that has occurred during the ages in this temple. Right at the front gate was one lion new and one original. not that you could tell from looking at the work. Once it was an honour for the person, their family and their village to have a name on the wall, but when the communists came it was a death sentence - because a doctor was an educated person and one not to be trusted. so many stories in this place.while we there we saw two groups of university students were there for group photos - all dressed in traditional garb plus university cloaks and caps, posing for their class photos. so happy and joyful and also very cheerful if we wanted to take their photos as well. great place to buy little souveniers - bookmarks etc with symbols and words from the university. the temples were very well maintained and we could take as many photos as we wanted too.an enjoyable visit and if you go make sure you have an understanding of the origin of the university and the changes and perils that happened over time.

we learnt much. The grounds and main Temple are excellent, but if we hadn't read up first we would have missed the third section, the National University behind the temple. A thousand year old temple of learning, set in beautiful grounds - which is wonderful.Well worth a visit.. We went with a guide who explained each exhibit and who had an excellent knowledge of Vietnamese history.Don't miss going upstairs for the view out of the top windows. Delightful!

Excellent Place with HanoiKids as tour guide. We went there with HanoiKids as part of their tour of Hanoi. Discovered some of the prefrench history of Vietnam. Thought it was very interesting and educational of the philosophy, beliefs and structure of vietnam in precolonial days.
Quiet place in crazy Hanoi.. Much to see, interesting place, worth to visit. You can go by group but even alone. Take your time to enjoy this old place in the hearth of Hanoi.

Break from the hectic city. The temple is located near the Ba Dinh Square. The place boasts of lovely gardens, good for taking tourist photos. It was a nice place to take a quiet stroll, a break from the hustle and bustle of the motorcycles.
Didn't do it for us. Cheap to get in makes a guiet break from the mania of Hanoi. Nice enough without being anything startling.

A great setting. This was located in the centre of Hanoi and set in some beautiful gardens. We would recommend visiting with a guide who can explain the history of this site, because it is not easy to figure it out yourself. Well worth the visit - allow yourself at least 2 hours to fully appreciate all the history this location has to offer.
Historical. Lovely gardens. Good place to take kids. Picturesque. Was not too crowded when we went . A nice place to sit and look also. Toilets were clean and of quality
A beautiful glimpse into Hanoi history and culture.. A quiet break from the hectic street life and a chance to contemplate and enjoy the sheer beauty of traditional Vietnam gardens and architecture.

Beautiful Buildings steeped in History.. No visit to Hanoi would be complete without a visit here. A basic history of the Chinese Mandarin system would be very beneficial to read prior to going, both to better understand what you are seeing and of course to learn about the cultural history of Vietnam and the importance of Education within society.

Be aware and be prepared for the beggers and pick-pockets that patrol the entrance gate. The Temple of Literature is dedicated to Confucius, was founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong and six years later, Vietnam's first university was founded here.The complex is in a tranquil park in the heart of central Hanoi.

Lovely to stroll through. An interesting piece of history with plenty of information in English. Guides available. A bit of a tourist Mecca. Souvenirs available. Musicians playing traditional instruments in the last temple. You can buy their CDs!
Temple of Literature. we went here with a couple of young fun guides from Hanoi Kids. It was really beautiful and the guides well imformed.

Very famous tourist spot in Hanoi. Must-visit location! Temple of Literature shows vividly history of Vietnamese education. We could also see architecture of South East Asia from this temple. Very new and interesting experience that all travelers should have.

Visit the Tenple of Literature and then head to KOTO. The Temple of Literature (28k with English pamphlet) is reasonably peaceful for Hanoi and a nice 30-40 min visit. It was constructed in 1076 as the first University of Vietnam and taught the Confucian Canons to the brightest scholars. There are names inscribed on a wooden board and tortoise stone stelea recording the doctor laureates of the Royal exam. Pretty impressive having one's achievements memorialized for centuries; better than a Guinness drinking board.
Beautiful oasis of tranquility. Get away from modern hustle and bustle in this treasure from Vietnam's historic past. Very photogenic.

Must Visit. This temple is very different as its main function was education. A guide is a great help as there is so much to learn here. The grounds are beautiful and there are English translations explaining the importance of what you are seeing. Don't miss this one.
Becareful of pickpocket. Harmonious place, worth a visit, travel light and come with a smile not with a high expectation then you will be fine. There is an entrance fee as well.

beautiful and interesting place. Worth a visit. The temple and the gardens are amazing, very interesting. Plan to spend an hour or so there. And right outside of the temple, in the avenue is a great restaurant Koto.

Beautiful buildings and lovely gardens. Once through the lovely arched entrance, the first thing I noticed were the beautiful gardens. Shrubs trimmed to look like animals, carefully pruned bushes and lawns, magnificent ancient trees. The only let down in the garden areas were the couple of 'pools', which had very little water in them, and what water and creatures were in there didn't look very healthy. Similar to other Vietnamese temples, the buildings here were coloured in reds, golds and greens, and well decorated. There were some statues and items here that we hadn't seen anywhere else, and the buildings / features were scattered, allowing for visitors to spread out. It didn't feel crowded, yet I know there were a lot of people there. We spent several hours making our way through, and it was very pleasant.

good, but not as good as expected. Unfortunately the Literaturetemple is a quite busy place and not as impressive as expected, but in the end, it is worth visiting anyway. You see beautiful old buildings in which the former students where learning their confucian teachings/lessons. Therefore the place is arranged very harmonious to make them feel comfortable while learning.Entrance fee must be paid.

Green and peaceful in the middle of chaotic Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is worth a visit. While we were there there were hundreds of Hanoi university students graduating. We got to catch a photo of them in their gowns throwing up their caps. Green and peaceful.

Very nice temple, but watch your change. The temple itself is very beautiful, and well worth a visit. Just make sure that the ticket sellers at the entrance give you the correct change and not pretend that you've only given them 10,000 dong and not 100,000.

1000 years Temple int he middle of the city. the Temple is in the middle of Ha Noi, so it is very easy to find a slot and visit it. it reminds many Chinese buildings with many blocks leading to a major building (in this case the school).
if you are planning to go, book from 1 to 2 hours and you will have time to appreciate the Temple.

Interesting place to know about the development of scholars in ancient Vietnam. Was impressed how Vietnam was already having the education system to develop their scholars in ancient time. Their system was close to ancient Chinese system, with Confucious as the Great Master.
dislike the toilet needs 1000 VND to use it though we had paid entrance fee.

Peaceful but worth having a guide. You could go here on your own and just enjoy the quiet gardens, temples and ponds in the middle of bustling Hanoi. To understand it, though, you really need a guide. We went with Hanoi Kids and they were wonderful in explaining the history and current significance of the temple. Definitely worth seeing.
Interesting. I really enjoyed visiting the university learning the history and traditions of the university was great.

One of those temples. I was a bit disappointed with the Temple of Literature. I was expecting more on the literature side and lesser of the temple side. But it turned out the other way. Nothing much to see here. Visit this place if you have the time, otherwise check out other places.

We were the attraction. We visited the Temple of Literature on our first morning in Vietnam. Our guide explained the history which was extremely interesting. However, as it was Vietnamese Independence Day there were a lot of locals visiting too. When we were asked for a photo we took the camera assuming people were asking us to take photos of their group. It quickly became apparent that they wanted photos with ourselves. It was quite surreal looking around and seeing my family and friends linking arms with young Vietnamese getting their photos taken. And on a day when the hair was thrown up!!!

I like it but I don't like how they manage it!. I like this place. Although there is not many thing to see here but it has an important meaning for the Vietnamese people. Anyway, the government has made it so tourist, I don't like the shops here and how the people sell everything, maybe from China.

Two times there and there was still MORE!. I went to The Temple of Literature in September last year and again, walking there from my house (about 8Km each way) this month. The layout and the beauty iof the first square s astounding. Large ponds on each side within the enclosure greet you with lovely walkways and well manicured lawns and foliage. Tranquil, beautiful, peaceful. The next area (they are divided by ancient "gates") is a square with manicured lawn and pathways. In the third square, there is a masoned square with shops and other buildings. Here you can buy souvenirs and some small snacks and drinks (soda, tea, etc). Finally, in the fourth square, you enter the actual temple area with stele (stone monuments) with the names of successful scholars dating back over a 1000 years. Some, unfortunately, have suffered from time and those candidates are no longer remembered. You can't touch anything here; you can only walk and look. To think of the many who have come here over time, many failing and others being successful, and thinking about how hard that they had to work and to study to pass the exams, this is more a monument to learning and scholarship. At the back, there is a "temple" (just to help you to understand, in Viet Nam, a "temple" is Chinese and a "pagoda" is a Buddhist temple where one can revere their ancestors as they do not "worship" them; however, they do ask for their good passage through the afterlife). Here one can burn incense and see those who are the most venerated of scholars. They all actually do "look alike" as they use the same mold or model for all of them because no one really knows what they really looked like. This is true throughout all of the temples and pagodas in Viet Nam.But wait! There is more. Walk around to the back of this temple area and there is a "final" square with another temple at the back and side buildings. In the temple, every day, are musicians who perform traditional Vietnamese music every day. They also sell CDs, DVDs and some instruments at the best price I have ever seen anywhere else in Viet Nam so far.Overall, this is a pleasant, relaxing, thoughtful and educational experience. I spent 3 hours here with NO camera. Next time, I will take my camera and take photographs that can help you out.
nice place. very nice, not very busy. Go there in the Lotus season so you'll see a lot of flowers in the pond facing the temple.

An oasis in busy streets.. We were shown around by a knowledgeable guide, there was quite a lot to see but it was very hot and we had spent long hours at Ho Chi Minh Square, probably weren't feeling the best.

Meh - it's a temple. It's a confusian temple, sure it's nice and impressive, but not much different from so many other confucian temples around asia. On the other hand, entrance fee is just 1USD, so it can be a relaxing break from busy Hanoi traffic.
Impressive. This is a great relaxing way to spend a morning or afternoon. It is best to go if it is not raining or too hot as the Temple attractions are all out doors.

Lovely complex, full of history. This is a fascinating place, both aesthetically - lovely gardens and buildings - and historically - it has been there for a thousand years - to explore while in Hanoi. It is a little oasis of calm in a frenetic city, in which to while away an hour or two and provides a good insight into the cultural and educational history of the city.

Amazing. We did an organised bus tour to several destinations in Hanoi. This was the highlight for me because the architecture and history is unique and considering these ancient buildings have been rebuilt since devastation it is a beautiful destination and worth visiting.
Very lovely Temple and so peaceful. Easy to get too by taxi, its a great little temple and has fascinating history. Go in the late afternoon so the light is better for some deep red photos.

A 'must' if you visit Hanoi.. A very interesting place to visit, and you will spend a good 2 - 3 hours taking in the history and significance of this site.When finished, take a stroll back to the Old Town or Hoan Kien Lake.
Inspiring Trip. Beautiful and inspiring. It gives you a lot of insight into the minds and hearts of the Vietnamese people.

A "must see" on your to-do list of attraction. This was a very interesting place. It is amazing to think that some of the tablets of learning date back to the 1100's. There was lots to see and learn about. There are souvenir shops for you to buy gifts. There was also a musical performance with traditional music which was very entertaining. Afterwards you can purchase the music they play at a reasonable cost.

Great Place To Visit (With A Guide). This old university is really Worth a visit and we enjoyed the area quite a lot. It is also a quiet oasis in the middle of town and you get a good introduction in the world of mandarins.My only caution is that you really need to have a guide to make the most of your visit as you will be missing a lot whitout one.
Most interesting. A good place to while away some hours in a very interesting place with great atmosphere. Easy to get to by taxi

Probably worth a visit. Did enjoy our visit here whilst on a walking tour but there is not too much to see. Gardens are pretty but that's about it. If you are in the area then check it out but don't travel too far to get here

University turn Temple. A place to visit to learn about the influence of the chinese culture in vietnam. Vietnamese were 'forced' to learn Chinese language.Interesting layout and you will get to see the GIGANTIC statue of Confucius. Think there is a fee to pay but not sure how much as I went on a day tour. A nice place overall and will not take long to visit.

A must visit in Hanoi. A Great place to visit. Although communists have tried to appropriate the tradition... This place is over any attempt! It is important to have a guide with you in order to understand the symbols and the place itself!Really recommendable!!!!

Archaic Charm. The mix of Indo-Chinese architecture has an earthy charm to it. It is a big hit with tourists and therefore little crowded but if you pick an odd hour you will be able to feel the serenity of the place.

Worth a visit. So calm and peaceful inside and our guide was very happy to share his knowledge of the educational system. From the photographs we had seen we thought it was situated outside of the city but it is central and just like a large walled garden in the centre of this huge city!

Very Old First University. I had a great time at this University, current graduates where at the Temple taking photos. It was a place they cherish because it is a like long dream to the Vietnamese to go to this College. It is a pleasant place to visit , the grounds are cared for and many Turtles stones have the names of the high honors family's names of the past and present graduates.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit. We asked a local student we met in Halong Bay what was a must do in Hanoi as we only had one day there and they said this was a must see. How right they were!
Great place, worth a visit. Great gardens and a couple other attractions nearby. Worth spending a day on this side of town!It's a quick stop, but definitely worth it.

Fantastic. This was the first "attraction" that I visited in Hanoi and this old building is a great contrast to the hustle and bustle of the surrounding city. It was extremely interesting and very peaceful. I wish I had taken a guided tour as the English signs were very limited (as is the case in much of Vietnam), but I enjoyed wandering through with my guidebook. I definitely recommend for any visitors to Hanoi!
Good but you need a guide. We were taken here by Duc and Hoa from Hanoi kids. They were great and told us great detail about each area in the temple. We would not have found it so good without them.
Very interesting. Was a little bit of peace withing the craziness of hanoi. Very interesting walking around it and was nice and relaxing while in there. Was a very nice break from the chaos outside!
very nice, i like. definetely worth a visit, very interesting place with lots of culture. i loved staying there. the tourguide was very informativ
Enjoyable. We enjoyed looking around the temple. We learned a lot about the previous way of studying and the teachers in the past.
Very beautiful!. You can see this in less than an hour, it's impressive though...worth doing it as part of a city tour if you can so can see a few places in one day via a tour group/private driver.

Touristic, but for a good reason. In comparison to the other temples in Hanoi, Van Mieu clearly stands out for its size and history: it was indeed the first university in the country, a long time ago.Now surrounded by very noisy streets, the place is usually packed with tourists who are brought in by buses, and who then proceed to have lunch at Koto across the street. Still, there can be ways for skipping the crowds: avoid lunch-time visits or between 5-7pm, when traffic is at its worst.Also, don't forget that the Temple area has many parts, and once you've gone through the first few courtyards, there is a side entrance to the last courtyard -- it might seem silly, but many people end up skipping this last part simply because they're not paying enough attention.

Beautiful piece of tranquility in a noisy city. One of the things about Vietnam is that it's packed with heaps of scooters and people. Walking into the temple of literature is a lovely break. Although there really aren't any benches to sit on and enjoy the tranquility. It's not a long walk from the old quarter or from Ho Chi Mihn's mausoleum. They have cute topiary.
Very Interesting.. Very interesting insight into the history of education in this country. Lovely grounds and temple with lots to see.

Relaxing walk. Visited in July 2013 after a hectic walk around the city, it was quiet and relaxing and it was a nice break from all the traffic. There is not a lot to see but at 20,000 dong entrance fee it is well worth a visit, if only for the quietness.

Tranquil environment - worth the visit. Wonderful surroundings, a very interesting history and an important and rightfully preserved complex. I had a guide who was extremely knowledgeable, otherwise there are some information boards, largely in Vietnamese.

Vast place with hidden areas around the back!. This place is bigger than you first expect. If we hadn't been guided round by Hanoi kids tours then we may have never spotted the areas round back. Past the pagoda, round the back there is a huge space with more to see where students used to be lectured. This isn't sign posted but is interesting to see.
Excellent night. I had gone for a conference and the gala night was organised at the temple of literature.The music and dancers were good.food wasn't too great but ok.

Don't miss this tranquil centre of learning, the gardens alone are worth the visit!. Easily accessed by a cheap taxi, the 1000 year old university is a haven of peace amidst the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Well laid out courtyards leads you through to the centre of the university. Very beautiful. A popular venue for local university graduates to have their photo taken, which adds a little modern twist.good photo opportunities.

A highlight of Hanoi.. This is a very interesting place and not at all what I imagined. It is known as Temple of Confucius and Vietnam's first university - the Imperial Academy. You will explore the courtyards, the stellae of doctors, visit temples and admire the lake of literature. To fully understand the place, its spirit and history it is good to either have a guide or do some reading and go prepared.

a spiritual experience. another favorite of mine. The day we visited a large group of young vietnamese students placed their wishes for success prior to their examinations on 2 wooden boards in the temple. They were so focused and exuded a level of spirituality and faith that I never experienced in my student years; and we bought the most amazing pen made of stone. It looks that an expensive Mont Blanc pen but it cost us 100 000 dongs ($5)

Lovely. This beautifully restored temple cum center of Confucian learning is how a lot of Vietnam's tourist attractions could look given money and care. Well worth the visit and the excellent non-profit Craft Link store is right next door.

Really interesting. Definitely get a guide that knows what they're talking about to fully appreciate the temple, but even if you don't get one this place is so beautiful. Pay to pee toilets though, so be warned!

Temple of Literature. Living nearby I visited the temple of literature maybe 7 times by now. For me always a place to find peace and calm down and to enjoy its beautiful garden and architecture. Inside it's a place full of history and you can feel the dust of past events. It's not only Vietnam's oldest university going back to the lectures of Confuzius, it's a modern place for students to meet up as well. A bit annoying are the Tshirt vendors outsight and sometimes it's overly crowded with tourists.

Expansive. The whole temple is expansive and the architecture is amazing. There are so many details and so much greenery. It is a nice way to spend an afternoon. There are a lot of places to sit under trees and it is a great place to meditate. There is no information given for free so you will have to buy the information pamphlet or get a tour guide especially if you want to know the history of the temple.

Amazing buildings. This is a superb temple-like complex dedicated to learning, teachers and literature. The carvings on the buildings is so gorgeous and the many stories that go along with the various men memorialized there made it extra cool. We saw it on a "City Tour" and it was well worth going.
Very traditional. Really enjoyed it, was very peaceful and beautiful. It can get very busy so go early and that way you can get nice pictures too.

The temple and university is well worth a visit. Located in the heart of the city the setting is superb with peacful courtyards and beautiful flowers. As other contributors have said its best to have a guide who can explain its history. But also leave enough time for you to explore on your own and take time to sit and take in the atmosphere.

Interesting history for adults. A great sense of history given this was the first university in Vietnam albeit for kings and family. A guide is essential as limited English Information available. Impossible to understand without help and significance would be lost. The photos attached do justice to the scenery. My teenage kids got bored quickly and became a distraction so beware. Our guide didn't have much nice to say about the French but nobody does here. Seems they were fairly spiteful in their destruction on departure. Have to see it whilst here.

Beautiful. I really like this little place. Nice gardens with waterlily cover ponds and some temples plus an insteresting history. For you photo lovers - there are some great shots to be had here. A little off the main drag if exploring on foot but worth the detour.

Hidden treat. The grounds are quite small compared to other sights in Hanoi but you an easily lose yourself for an hour just wandering around the gardens and little temple areas. Def worth a visit for some photos if passing by.
Go with a guide. We went there with Hanoi kinda and it was very informative and interesting. We had a great time, spending a lot more time there than planned.
