Smart.. Our tour guide was very informative , he hadgood english but dont interupt them as they talk as if reading from a script and if they lose their place it can be "back to the start". Dont stay for any longer than an hour. The gardens are pretty but the sculptures are amazing.

“What an experience”. A buzz throughout the area and a great place to eat on pavement cafes. If you go to the some place maybe not for the squeamish cutting up frogs to eat but the food is low price and if you ask a guide some great quality

Beautiful temple, worth seeing. This was my favorite place in Hanoi. Beautiful temple, very well preserved, located in a quiet quarter of the city. Dedicated to Confucius and served as a previous university, temple has very interesting worth-seeing spots.Expect to spend one hour exploring this temple.

Experience Vietnams Ancient Culture. Set in beautiful gardens with ponds of lotus flowers and carp this temple is dedicated to Confucius and several Vietnamese scholars. The temple with its beautiful architecture, statues and relics is a great place to soak in some of Vietnams ancient culture.
Great value. Beautiful setting and very interesting. Well worth a visit. Entrance surprisingly cheap, as were most attractions in Hanoi. Take sun screen / shade /Water++

Great spot to look around. Amazing history. Great architecture. We happened to visit on graduation day and it was wonderful to see all the new graduates in their traditional costumes and suits. Definitely worth a visit.

Quiet Place. Ok to visit but if inconvenient, ok to give it a miss too.
Like the quietness and tranquil environment, away from the hassle and bussle of the city and traffic.
Entry fee apply though very cheap. Worthwhile to buy the map as well if you are not on a guided tour.

Historical and Unique. Entering this place, I feel that the old school University was cool! Unique architecture, a long history in this place. With a local guiding me, he tells a long story of this Temple/university. A must visit, nothing to lose, spend around 30 minutes would be good. There's a lot of money on the roof though!

Beautiful, old temple-like buildings that used to be a university. Beautiful, old temple-like buildings that used to be a university, set in colourful gardens.When we were there, there were lots of students and classes celebrating their graduation or groups of girls wearing the colourful national dress known as the Ao Dai. It still serves apparently as a place to celebrate education.

Important historical site. Impressive 900 + year-old university! The grounds are lovely and it's interesting to see the long lists of scholars who studied there. There is an active temple on the grounds.

Lack of English let down otherwise interesting visit. Found that the temple was very interesting after looking up information afterwards on my phone, however a presence of English information or tour material meant I didn't feel immersed in the experience. Beautiful gardens and a traditional music group made the experience worthwhile however.
An unexpected surprise. We didn't know about this attraction until seeing it on our tourist map but it turned out to be one of our unexpected joys in Hanoi

nice stop but not well-maintained. a colorful and vibrant spot yet not well-maintained. a lot of primary school students had some activities on the day we where here along with graduating college students who were wearing traditional vietnamese outfit (esp the women). it was worth some camera shots though.

Amazing!. I spent an hour or so wandering through the temple with an English speaking guide and I really enjoyed it. I would recommend doing this with an English speaker though - none of the signs are in English and there is alot of information and historical significance that is only known by the local or researched (which I wasn't!) people. The gardens are beautiful and very well kept. The water lillies were flowering when I was there and they were lovely. The history of this temple (built in 1070) just blows me away given I come from such a 'young' country with very little history! The stories and legends about various symbols - crane & turtle, dragons, fish etc - were something I only discovered because of my guide.Yes there is an area of the temple that sells cheap and tacky tourist stuff but we just kept walking straight past. Yes there are moto & tuk tuk drivers at the entrance - just like every other attraction in Vietnam!! These things didn't take away from the experience for me. I just chose to ignore them. Definitely worth a visit if you've got local knowledge/research/English guide
Beautiful and peaceful. Definitely visit the temple of literature! So good to see the history and culture of the old world Vietnam

Interesting. The foliage and the plantings were worth the trip. We had a good guide but if you are not traveling with a guide, do some reading before you visit since there is not much of an explanation on site.
A tranquil place in the hustle and bustle of Hanoi.. Well worth a visit to see how the Vietnamese were educating when we were fighting the Normans. Lovely buildings and a serene atmosphere.

Fascinating place to visit. Full of culture and history. Well worth a visit. The children loved seeing the graduates in national costume who come on graduation day to have their photographs taken here.

Beautiful Temple. I really enjoyed this temple, I like the fact it's purpose is to give thanks for education/literature. The grounds are lovely, from the statues to the gardens to the pond with water lilies. We were also lucky enough to come across a photo shoot of some people in traditional costumes that just added to the atmosphere of the temple. If you are in Hanoi it is well worth a visit to this temple.
Not bad. The temple has a long history..Get fascinated by the stories told by the tour guide..A nice spot to have some photos.
Interesting. Well worth a visit given all the history which is behind the temple dating back many centuries and dynasties

best visit in Hanoi. beautiful historical site set in lovely gardens. Very moving to see the students' graduation 'diplomas' on stone turtles dating back from 12th-13th century. The Confucius altar is also very impressive. Went with my 2 kids (1- and 16) and they loved it as well.

Temple of Literature. This place was fascinating. We happened to visit on a day when there were hundreds of university students, fresh from exams, making offerings, patting the heads of the turtle statues and praying for good results.
Place must visit. You can find how they admire & honor Confusius , devide in 5 building , you will get the story from each building by free tour guide

Peaceful oasis in the middle of chaos.. This place was the most beautiful and tranquil spot. We had an extremely informed tour guide who drew our attention to the smallest details. While we there a graduating class was celebrating in the grounds and the level if respect that they had for the place was heart warming. Well worth the visit, but go with a tour guide to get the most out of it.
Gem in a city. Enjoyable half day spent wandering the grounds. Manicured lawns. Ponds with fish and turtles. Interesting buildings and statues. Very relaxing and peaceful place.

Oasis int he middle of the town. Take your time and visit the temple for literature, where you can see the beautiful stone turtles, pagoda, small templates and at the time I was there, ther were students celebrating their school year, soe they were wwearing their national clothes, beautiful:)Negative: at the entrance while buying the ticket they try to sell you the ticket for double price and the guide, which is very poor and not worth the money they ask for.
Not so much to see. The grounds was big, a thirty minute tour will do, to go around and learn about the museum. Not much to see.
Best in town. If you want to get away from the noise and chaos, this is it. History and nice gardens together in one spot

Very interesting place. A very interesting and surprisingly calm spot in the middle of Hanoi hustle and bustle. It's nice to see the well preserved old architecture which is pretty rare in Vietnam I think. Well worth a visit, especially if you're into history, philosophy...

Nice day trip in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is the oldest in Vietnam if I'm not mistaken. It depicted the Confucian and Chinese roots of Vietnam. The school abides by the creed of Confucianism. I liked the historical feel of the temple and the way the architecture was maintained. Great place to visit if you are into history and philosophy.

Cool!. This place is pretty cool. Walking into it, I felt like going to an absolutely different world. It's ancient and sacred. It's pretty amazingly peaceful place in the middle of bustling Hanoi. Definitely a great place to visit while staying in Hanoi.

Nice place to visit. There isn't a great deal of english help to explain this place, unless you want to pay for a guide. But with the help of my Lonely Planet guide I got the gist. Its a lovely set of gardens, and a nice temple complex. But nothing extraordinary.
historical value. there is many poem n good written from the student from this the first university in hanoi. but unlucky, we cannot understand the words because its in kanji/chinese words :p

This is a great place to visit. This is a great place to visit. It's a beautiful setting in the middle of bustling Hanoi. There's a great deal of beautiful history on display and the lake and temple do in fact appear on Vietnamese currency.
Some calm in Hanoi. Great bit of culture and escape! Really interesting. Pop by a music performance. Nice gardens and different temples. Good history.

MUTS SEE IN HANOI. This is the oldest university in Vietnam - over 1000 years old! It gives great perspective on the cultural background of Vietnam. We were fortunate to visit at the same time as Vietnamese students were writing their university entrance/qualification exams. Many visited the temple for good luck. Our young children enjoyed the visit and were moved to buy (at another place later during our stay in Vietnam) a marble turtle because of its association with knowledge and good luck for exams.
Oasis of calm. A real oasis of calm in the middle of the city with iconic traditional architecture. Very appropriate for the original home of scholarship in Vietnam.
One of many temple. It was okay but a bit disappointing! I suppose if you have seen temples for the past year than this is not worth a visit!

a bit of tranquility in this busy city. I have visited the temple of literature several times, it is a very quiet spot in a noisy city. Also it it is a tribute to old masters and professors and gives a different perspective on the history of Hanoi which is not only dedicated to trade or the political city of Vetnam but has been as well a place for lecturers and thinkers

A place worshipping Confucius.. Personally, I like the way they preserved this place. Keeping all the culture and history especially the evolution of education system in Vietnam here. Met some free tour guide here. They are actually university students doing volunteer job during summer vacation. They actually tried to introduce this place to us. That is wonderful as some part of it did not display information other than Vietnamese language. Worth visiting though.
Historic site. Its a historical site for the nation. It will be better visit if you have a guided tour.A definite joint to visit if you were in towm

beautiful ancient architecture. Loved what this building represented and interesting to learn how forward thinking the Vietnamese were (as early as the 14th century they allowed scholars to be from any class background - it took the West longer than that! )Many photo opportunities with such special architecture.

Worth visiting. Interesting collection of buildings around courtyards and a homage to learning and education. The day we visited was just before university entrance exams and we were swallowed by thousands of hopeful students seeking success and good fortune. This didn’t bother us as although moving through the crowds was challenging in the Hanoi heat – it provided atmosphere and made the centuries old buildings coma alive with contemporary meaning.

Very interesting. After chatting with others, I get the impression that you get more out of this sight if you have a guide. Nonetheless, it is still impressive if you tour it on your own. Worth the visit.

Well preserved. Tip: 20 000 (They have student discount).Tip2: Koto restaurant it's very close (basically across the street) and it has good food.Cons: lots of pricey and crappy shops*.The temple is beautiful and well preserved. It has info in English. *Note: Keep in mind that a teacher in Vietnam earns between $60 and $100 (The studies found that on average, teachers had worked 13 years before making more than the average wages...). So $1 or $2 in the US or in Europe it's cheap but in Vietnam it's expensive.
Interesting & Peaceful place. A lovely quiet oasis in the city, full of interesting history, a knowledgable guide makes a big difference in your appreciation of the place.

A very large temple. The size of the temple was astonishing. I had never expected to spend more than 1 hour to visit a temple. Then, I discovered that the temple was the location of the first national university established in Vietnam. Built in 1070, the temple is truly a heritage of Hanoi.The temple is divided into 4 different sections. Do not miss the stone tortoises at the third section, which the names of the candidates who were succeed in royal exam in China was engraved. The tortoises which were built 1484 - 1780 AD, have been recognized by UNESCO as Documentary Heritage of the World.I saw many graduates taking photo in the temple with their traditional costume. Many of them were friendly and didn't mind to take photos together with them. More about my sharing about the temple is available in my blog bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2013/05/ho-chi-minh-mausoleum-and-places-nearby.html.By the way, the architecture of the temple resembles the Chinese temples. We would mistakenly feel that we are in China within the compound of the temple.

Rub the crane!. We went to the Temple of Literature as we were told that all university students go during or before finals week to rub the crane and the head of the turtle for good luck during finals. Well, it was finals week, and we definitely saw students doing this! It was a beautiful old temple but felt relevant because of those students.

Interesting. Worth a visit all if only to see the turtles. The intitute was started at the time the Magna Cata was signed.It is mostly outdoors and can be hot and wet if raining. The grounds and lovely though.
Tranquil, great Vietnamese architecture, beautiful garden. Daily visits except monday: too crowdy! Beautiful ponds, monuments, low cost entrance tickets. Worth the visit!
Amazing Place. This is a national treasure. Its worth spending the time absorbing it, looking and reading all on offer. The big drum is fun also. Nearby Pho and Cyclo drivers make it worth a visit.

Interesting place. We met four Vietnamese students and went here with them. It was great to have someone who could explain various things to us. Without them I don't think we would have understood much of the site or got much out of the visit. I was most impressed with the reverence given to teachers. The site itself is beautiful.
beautiful temple. The temple is of historic importance and is still widely used for graduation ceremonies. It is really nice to see all the (ex) students walk up to the temple to attend the ceremony.

A beautiful and important site. We loved the fact that most of the people visiting this important centre of learning and literature were Vietnamese. This is not a tourist site but an important representation of the value of Confucian wisdom and learning. Apparently many graduates choose to come here to have their graduation photos taken and to pay homage to education and literature. An excellent and interesting alternative to the noise and commercialism of the Old Quarter.

TEMPLE OF LITERATURE. As this is highly rated for all tourists by the HANOI TOURISM BOARD, one should visit it for the experience. The Temple is quite barren this day. The site is large. There are a few historical relics, but most of the explanations are in Vietnam text and verse; so foreign visitors do not benefit much. For visitors who have been to other Asia temples, as in CHINA, JAPAN, TAIWAN, KOREA, SINGAPORE etc this has little to show. Most of the visitors are locals. Visit this as an experience and do not expect much.
Temple of Literature. Every Hanoi person comes here .... it is very traditional and a part of Hanoi's every day life, a must see to understand the people of Hanoi

Pleasant place but very touristy. It is a pleasant place but there is really nothing so special about it. It is best not to go when it is summer in Hanoi (we went in June) as it could get so hot and humid there. Always ask for a bargain when shopping or taking the cyclo.

Calm. Really a welcome into a "calm" place, though crowded, away from the traffic on the streets. Not very interesting though, if you're not a vietnamese speaker. There was a show going on, with too high volume on the loudspeakers.

The nicest temple in Hanoi. This site is peaceful and very historic. You can wander through its many courtyards, and explore some of the wooden buildings. If you are lucky, there will be locals in traditional clothing for you to meet. They are so friendly!

Time wasting. Extremely boring attraction and if you add extremely hot weather you`ll get my view of this attraction. Absolutely identical to any temple in Vietnam or Cambodia "Temple of Literature & National Unicersity" alas has no sense to visit if you have already been to one of those temples. You`d better save oat least one-hour time to stroll around to the wonderfull tiny streets in the old city centre.

Peaceful. We walked from the old quarter to the temple of literature, and were relieved to find some solace from the honking horns and hot sun. The many courtyards and buildings were quiet and cool in comparison.

Beautiful old temple & courtyards inside Hanoi's city bustle. Definitely worth a visit to see the temple & beautifully landscaped courtyards and learn a bit more about the Confucian scholar exams & grueling effort it takes to succeed in passing. Light incense & pray & rub the iron turtle heads for good luck in exams. Explore all the temples, especially the last 2 in the back which have displays of the scholars' robes, pens/inkwells, and photos of Uncle Ho reciting a poem, and also allows visitors to climb the steps to the balcony at the top from which you can see the clay roof and dragon details more closely. Gift shops have beautiful 3D intricate papercut cards (open the card to unveil & display 3D temples, ferris wheel, etc.) for about US$5.00 each.
Worth visiting to understand Conficius influence in Vietnam. Besides, it is a beautiful place. Worth also going with a guide, not expensive, to have a better understanding of what you see.

A real sense of history. As wew were there at a time of graduation for many College and University students, it was wonderful to witness the reference they give to the old traditions and their ancestry.

Lovely hour spent, close to station. A cultural landmark celebrating Vietnamese education over last thousand odd years. Lovely garden and interesting place to wonder close to Old Quarter. Relatively peaceful place to hang for a bit. Close to train station if you need an hour or two to kill before train.

Away from the mad traffic. Not much to see in Hanoi really but this is different- there was a graduation from a girls college or something like that when I was there so lots of brightly dressed locals having their photos taken. It's cheap to enter but you can't pay in USD! They sell lots of tourist junk there. Some really old and impressive cultural heritage pieces on display but practically no english information- perhaps to encourage you to buy a guide's services. I regret not doing this actually as you hear snippets from guides as you walk around that make it mean more.The garden and ponds weren't very well cared for since it's such an important place.
Relic journey in Hanoi. A very interesting place with Buddhist heritage preserved.Very old stone exhibits,pretty gardens and interesting old temple area.
Good value. Enjoyed this part of our walking tour - amazing history and so much to be gained from English speaking guide

FIRST UNIVERSITY IN VIET NAM. This is a nice temple with a lot of history. Visitors will have opportunity to understand about old Confucian influence on Vietnamese education. Entrance fee is $1/adult and it takes you around 2 hours to visit here.At the time I visited - the end of school year, there are many students - Vietnamese girls are dressing in their traditional AO DAI and gathering in the courtyard to be photographed. This is so beautiful and interesting.
Insightful & worth a tour. Loved the turtles and understanding the background of the scholars studying. Helps put year end exams into perspective!
A good historical place to visit and a must if you are in Hanoi. This is how Universities worked many centuries ago, The Doctorates were carved in stone and students worshiped their teachers.

Nice to see. This is a bit touristy, but if you are a tourist, is that not the point. It is a nice place in a nice setting, cheap to enter but full of souvenir shops. We left and had a taxi driver come up out side the gate in a blue taxi, we needed one so got in, and we knew then he was a fake, his meter went up at a rate of knots, we took a photo of the reading as our journey was finishing and this freaked him out, the total cost was 250,000 vnd, it refused to pay it after making many comment during the journey about his meter, told him he was only getting 100,000vnd, still high but not unreasonably so, he argued a bit, but only got 100,000vnd

Beautiful garden and buildings. We happened to visit on a day when it seemed every young person in the whole city, even the whole country was there to pray for good exam results that would gain them entry to university. Not sure if it is that crowded normally but that was the reason we were told to explain the crowds and traffic chaos. Still, it was a very beautiful place and well worth a visit.
First University. My friend from Hanoi took us here and it was very interesting. It is Vietnam's first university. Well worth the visit indeed!

Beautiful!. The Temple of Literature is dedicated to Confucius, was founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong and six years later, Vietnam's first university was founded here.The complex is in a tranquil park in the heart of central Hanoi. Be aware and be prepared for the beggers and pick-pockets that patrol the entrance gate.

Very lovely. This temple was bustling with activity...a bride having photos taken, families, as well as tourists, but never felt crowded. It is more garden than temple but well-appreciated in the city.

Wonderful picture opportunities. We learned that many university graduates thought it a must to have their graduation pictures taken here. It is the foundation for university training for centuries. Very interesting historical site.

Historic Oasis. We visited this beautiful complex today as part of a Hanoi Free Tour. We loved the tranquility and break from the hectic Hanoi traffic. Great to visit with a guide as the history is very interesting and many of the explanatory signs are in Vietnamese only.
interessting. Really pretty place, had a temple in it. Gardens were well maintained. Probably only need 1hr to see it all

Enjoy going there. I visited this place in the early autumn of the year - the time people going there is not much crowded. But I think that it lets me understand fully its beauty. I can read over and bear in my mind its long history, it is so wonderful. I paid much impression on Turtle Steles with the names of those successful at the royal exams, it is so amazing way to recall Vietnamese fathers. I can say for sure that Temple of Literature & National University is one of the places you should visit when staying in Ha Noi.

Peaceful courtyard setting once inside the temple. Peaceful courtyard setting once inside the temple. Good place to visit with a guide as you can get an appreciation of the history of the place and a full explanation of the symbolism in and around the temple itself.

History of Education in Vietnam. We had the pleasure of visiting the Temple of Literature with two students from Hanoi Kids. This made the visit very worthwhile as they shared with us a huge amount of information about this first university and also the culture and history of education in Vietnam.I really enjoyed the couple of hours we spent there and I think anyone who is interested in history and education etc would definitely appreciate this wonderful place and all it represents.

nice gardens. Gardens tranquil and well presented and we understood the cultural and historical importance of the site but there wasn't enough readily available information if you didn't have a tour guide.

a pleasant walk and sightseeing. we spent pleasant couple of hours in this magnificent historical complex and learnt quite a bt of history (texts in English were accompanying all major buildings and site within this complex). recommended.

Nice grounds. Unfortunately we went here when it was pouring with rain. Lots of history and all very well maintained gardens etc. the temple was ok but I have seen a lot better throughout Thailand so was a bit disappointing. Well worth wandering around - probably would have enjoyed more if it was not raining.

The Importance of Literature.. Very nice for pictures, but you would need to know Vietnamese to read the inscriptions on the tablets, which looked really interesting. Make sure you go round to the last house which houses memorabilias from when the students used to study there. I thought the third house after the lake was the end, till just strolling on the side gardens, we discovered that there is still more. Very nicely landscaped. Bustling place.
Well laid out. You wont spend that long here, but as its over the road from KOTO's its worth the wonder through. Its self explainitory as the signs are in many languages

Garden with a small temple. Did not expect to see a small garden with a temple in it. This ranks highly as a Hanoi 'to do'. I have no ides why. Ok to walk around but better off cutting a lap of Hoan Kiem lake. You might even see a giant turtle :)

A Place with Long History. Another place that is located in city centre, and one with almost 1000 years history. It is good place to learn about the history of the city's education and the people which had made significant contributions, which are now worshipped here by the locals.Problem is u need a guide or local to explain all this to you, and even after they had done so, it's not easy to remember or understand everything.Recommended

old old old. wow i was blown away from the age of this place- over 1000 years old.I loves the attention to detail- the statues, the tablets, the stories of Confucius and the topiary. Hanoi is really proud of its intellectual tradition

An interesting place to visit in the city. This is quite a nice temple with a lot of history. It was Vietnams 1st University dating back 1000 years. The buildings are well maintained and there is plenty to see. A small orchestra plays tradition music in one of the halls and there are small shops to buy souveniers. Only disappointment was you could not get a hot coffee anywhere within the grounds.

beautiful, serene. despite the crowds--and i advise you to visit early in the day--this place was so green, so delightful that i was grateful that it was recommended by our hotel. it doesn't take long to see it all, but it was lovely to just walk around, and for us (traveling academics) it was great to see the respect afforded to scholars and scholarship.

A decent resting place away from the mayhem. Went here specifically because I understood it was tranquil - and it was! Enjoyed the hour or so we spent there. The buildings are in a good state, there is enough English so you can get by and understand what's happening and there are benches in the shade to sit for a while. Quite pleasant as an outing in general.

With Hanoi kids. My Hanoi kids tour guide made this an interesting spot. There's a nice combination of beauty, history, religion, architecture, garden and overall culture--so a good place to make my introduction to Hanoi.
Cool Place. This was a cool place to visit. Bring a hat because you will be walking outside a lot. Good for some pictures and a nice walk around the grounds.

Pretty, tranquil site in frenetic Hanoi. At about a $1 USD for the entry fee, it's a bargain. It's a pleasant, tranquil site and interesting historical site. We were there on a rainy day and were able to take pic without a lot of people crashing our shots. I've heard it can be busy on a nice day. A must see in my opinion.

Worth a look. Such a quiet place amongst the hustle and bustle of the streets, nice gardens and lots to see so much history. We went when the uni had graduation and the girls dressed in traditional attire and went to get good luck on their results.

Not very interesting if you don't have a guided tour!. Make sure you take lots of fluids with you, it is boiling hot and you will dehydrate. Beautiful building and interesting history, but if I was visiting for the first time again, I wouldn't make the effort to visit!

Nice but not a must. We came to Hanoi after visiting Hue, Hoi An and Saigon. I think that's the reason why the temple of literature didn't get as much of our surprise. I guess we had seen more beautiful and stunning buildings in those cities. The temple is nice though, it has a nice entrance, a very well kept garden and the temple is pretty much what we had already seen in Hue, and not better. Either way, it's a good sightseeing point.

Many find this site really interesting. Lots of people really love this attraction, but I found it not so interesting, maybe it's me. However I found all the Vietnamese people at this site really friendly.

Some Library !!!. My wife is the local town Library Manager, so visiting the Temple of Literature is Deja Vu. Just Kidding !!The committment to education and excellence of the past masters is well documented and illustrated in beautiful surroundings. It was HOT the day we went and there is no air-con, but there is plenty of shade. An Oasis in the middle of Chaos.

This is a wonderful place. This is a wonderful place to visit for those who want to know more about the ancient history of Vietnam. It is best to have a guide with you as the place will not reveal its history, or the significance of this centre of learning.

Go with a Guide. If you don't, there really isn't a whole lot to see. Maybe I just have high expectations for some of the attractions, but beyond a few courtyards and only a few signs in English, there really isn't anything to see. It's old, which is cool, I guess. And the few things I was able to read were interesting tidbits of information.I mean honestly, the attractions in Hanoi are not really that impressive in general. Do yourself a favor and skip all of this stuff and get a feel for the real culture of Hanoi by just roaming the streets and talking to people/experiencing the Old Quarter/observing the chaos/frequenting the numerous cafes/eating the delicious food. It's a better use of your time.Or don't, and go here for 45 minutes max and seriously have a guide. Otherwise, it's just some old walls and a few paragraphs to read.

Beautiful. The grounds were beautiful and well cared for. There wasn't a lot of substance to actually do/see but we enjoyed it as a peaceful walk through nice gardens with a short temple experience at the end.

Nice grounds - see it if you have time. Pleasant gardens, some interesting bonsai & a great setting for photos but without a guide it wasn't easy to find much information about the place. A pleasant afternoon visit but we liked other sites better.

Moving. We visited the temple at the time when High School and University students get their Diploma and their Degree Course results.It was lovely to see the students (the girls dressed in their traditional ao dai) gathering in the courtyard to be photographed by their loved ones, so much joy in their eyes!Inside the temple parents, grandparents and children prayed together in front of the statues of the Buddha, of Confucius, of Lao Tse........ and they offered incense, money and fruit.It was deeply moving to see especially the parents, to witness the devotion with which they pray so that their children can have a better life than themselves.

What a nice place !. It is so impressive. In a modern city but the temple is still available with historical ancient things.. This is an ideal place for not only Vietnamese but foreigners, Visitors could have opportunity to understand about old Confucian influence on Vietnamese education. Many student come here to practice their lesson a a cool and quiet place .

Crowded, lacking the tranquility it deserves. This would have been wonderful when it was first built. Sadly the endless honking of car and bike horns provides a tranquility-ruining sound track nowadays, as does the daily hoard of noisy 'monkey on a stick' tourists in matching yellow hats etc. which are the scourge of travel everywhere today.Try going very early!

What a nice place to go, an oasis. It's a really nice place, a respite from the storm of the traffic and city. There were lots of graduation groups while we were there and it was great to see the kids enjoying the experience at what was the historical centre of learning in Vietnam. Well worth a trip.
One of the Musts of Hanoi. One of the Musts of Hanoi, very popular with Vietnamese families and couples, not so many foreigners for some reason

Must see.. Very cool place with lots and lots of information as well as things to just see. Shows a lot of the old Confucian influence on the Vietnamese and their education at the time. Very interesting place to see.

Another interesting history of vietnam. Came here with hanoikids and yesh important to have a guide to bring you about here. This place is of a lot of history. This place is featured of the vietnamese currency. also many students come here to take their graduation photos. So you can definitely tell how beautiful and significant this place is.

Beautiful!. We really enjoyed a visit to the Temple of Literature. It was really beautiful and peaceful, apart from tour guides with megaphones in various areas - a little bit disrespectful. Invest in a fan - it is very hot!
What a beautiful place. This is such a beautoiful, calming and interesting place to explore but it's not as large as I expected. Definitely worth a visit.
well worth a visit. the home of knowledge in Vietnam - well worth a visit, especially on graduation day when all the students are there in their robes!

Peaceful respite from Hanoi. Well worth a visit which I suspect would be made more meaningful, as others have said, if you took a guide. There is little in the way of English translation here so a brochure or guide book would help if you don't take a guided tourIt has lovely gardens and is quite a retreat which sits behind pls walls We too visited when there were local girls in traditional dress this time it was for their graduation celebrations as we saw many of them later with their mortar boards and capesWe came around 3 pm and it was quite busy. I recommend a visit mid week and as soon as it opens to avoid the crowdsIt should be noted that this is a working temple where people come to pray and pay their respects and they are very tolerant to us tourists. It would be good to see tourists giving some respect back and allowing people space and privacy while they pray Good photo opportunities here but please do heed the note about the local Chinese faithful who come to worship Confusius

So glad we chose to come here with a guide.. Having travelled around the world a lot sometimes we think we can do it ourself. Most of time we can. But to go to this place with a guide is something that I recommend. We just learnt so much and the story of this place is a very cool one in my opinion. A chance to change not only your destiny but the destiny of your family. Like an ancient version of today's talent show formats.

Interesting as long as you have a guide. This is a huge set of buildings dating back to the 1400's. 50 students at a time took 7 years to qualify. You must have a guise or the buildings and inscription stones mean nothing. Allow a good 2 hours to thoroughly explore
Okayish.... I was actually a bit disappointed in this, I must have been expecting more, something that said LITERATURE to me.Perhaps my inability to read Vietnamese has something to do with it!

The first university in Hanoi. Lots of shade with peaceful grounds to stroll around. Small temples and several pools. Price was 20,000 VND ($1 USD). People selling water out front. They also sell food and gifts in a courtyard inside.
Beautiful. A bit faraway from the old city, it was a nice walk to go there. Not the best thing I have seen in my life but nice enough to go there.

It's the money (no really). This is a great place to visit. It's a beautiful setting in the middle of bustling Hanoi. There's a great deal of beautiful history on display and the lake and temple do in fact appear on Vietnamese currency.If you're visiting Hanoi, this is a must!

Beautiful buildings that capture history. I really enjoyed walking the grounds of these buildings.There were a few little temples in the enclosed compound within the city.The Signs which explain the history of Confuciousism, education and the history of the first kings of Vietnam were written in 4languages. The information was very interesting and you don't really need a guide. I walked the 2km round trip from my hotel and it was an easy walk and easy to find.Cost 20,000 dong to get in.Great photo opportunities. There is a lovely garden across the road and a few cafes near by.Peaceful place for a quiet sit.

Interesting but wouldn't visit again. Beautiful landscape but not informative enough, probably would help to have a bit more signs in English. I wouldn’t see this ‘tourist attraction’ a second time, once is enough. Some nice areas to take snaps but that’s about it.
Beautiful environment. On the day we visited, this lovely temple was full of current Vietnamese students visiting and having their photos taken, some in traditional costume, for luck in their exams.
Nice place. Nice tribute to education, had the fortune of meeting some graduating students there, you could feel the pride in the air! :)

Very interesting. Very interesting to visit and understand Confucialiasiam.(sp??)Very humbling, very busy on the weekend and entrance fee $1. Visit with a guide as they can explain the grounds, and the history behind this site

Very interesting. Lovely gardens and cool. There are quite a few different areas to see but no signs in English to know what it is about. Nonetheless worth the visit. Lots of students wanted to practice their English on us. They are very polite and quite charming.
Interesting and informative. Ended up here after arriving too late to see Ho's mausoleum - but glad we did. An interesting temple and a bit of an oasis in the heart of an otherwise very busy area.
Really Interesting. we were very pleasantly surprised by this templae and the amount of interesting things tolook at - well recommended

Worth a look. After all the the hustle a bustle of Hanoi this was not only a relatively quiet place to visit but extremely interesting. So much history about the the education system. We had a guide show us around which made things easier and more informative about Confucianism.

Worth a visit. A little out of the way, but taxis are cheap and there is a real mix of gardens and buildings that make this place interesting. Fantastic, interesting souvenir shops selling things we didn't see elsewhere.

Don't rank this place too highly on your must see list. 20k vnd per person. As describe by others, there are open area once you past main entrance and gate 2. After gate 3, you enter the prayer temple. There's not a whole lot to see. Therefore visit only if you have a lot of free time. If not, you won't miss too much if you cancel this visit

Crowded, commercial and somehow lovely. This is a very popular place on a Saturday with the locals. There were crowds of people but they added to the atmosphere. Our guide knew a lot of stories and we were able to view the rooms and statues with interest. Many people were praying amidst the milling crowds. I enjoyed the history and the visuals and though it was worthwhile to visit.

A Cultural Day. I think there is a nominal entrance fee but well worth a visit. The layout is a series of large open spaces one behind the other separated by traditional buildings. Sometimes you walk through one building to get to the next. Sometimes you walk round the side so check to make sure you see the whole layout. This place is popular with the Vietnamese. As well as seeing some good traditional architecture we managed to listen to some traditional music. A great visit

History respect. As I know this temple is considered as the first national university of Vietnam which at first purpose was to educate royals. the architectural seems to be affected by China. I was told that the senior high school students in Vietnam mostly want to come here touch the turtle head to wish for luck in the exam to enter the university. And the best graduate students of official university will be honored in this temple. So this temple have the major meanings in encourage learning spirit for Vietnamese's students.

Lovely sense of history. Established in 1070, this is a beautiful, ancient place of learning. Lovely gardens and buildings to wander through and to notice still the respect paid to the emperors of Vietnam.
Very nice for tourists.. Excellent location not far from the Hoan Kiem area, excellent background information and a good introduction to education system in Hanoi
Pleasant escape and very beautiful. A lovely respite from the hustle of Hanoi. Beautiful gardens and an insight into what is important in Vietnam. Make sure you visit KOTO restaurant nearby as well.

Take the tour. We had a very interesting guide and were inspired to read more about Confucious after this visit. The buddhist and confucious connection really spoke to us about the friendliness we've found in this country.

Extremely interesting. Visited with two young university students from Hanoikids. They were able to give us detailed information about the five temples, the history etc.The gardens are well looked after and very beautiful.We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and would definitely recommend.
great place. What a nice place to rest and feel the goodness of Vietnam.Do not miss it that would be a real shame especially the enormous bell !! ;)
Lovely temple. A 1000 years old temple full of history. Nice garden. Very peaceful, Not so busy, so can visit a leisure. One of the must see in Hanoi.

Temple of Literature. Most interesting, particularly the history of scholarship over so many centuries. Takes quite some time to explore all the buildings.
I loved the big copper drum. Must see!

a Chinese Style Temple in Hanoi. Yes, it's because Hanoi just step by to China so is not to surprise when the temple similar with in China.
You need to pay 20,000VND (USD 1) for entrance fee, for the story this temple made about 1000 years ago.
For me who like to photography is good place to capture any detail.
You must visit!
Do not miss. Amazing history, wonderful gardens, interesting architecture, lots of art and old graduation records
Amazing. We went with Hanoi Kids as guides. The gave a fantastsic intro to the place. Lots of students having their picture taken while we were there - amazing.
Very interesting with a guide. The stories our guide told us and seeing or the students coming to have their photographs taken at the site was great.

Peaceful. it was very hot today when we visited so were not really in the mood for sight seeing. We've also seen many other much grander and similar temples in China before, so this was small by comparison. Having said that, once you enter it, you do feel quite removed from the chaos outside and can feel the peaceful surroundings. I think if you are interested in the history of it, it will be very good, otherwise you don't need to spend more than half an hour here.

Interesting. A really nice morning if you can spare the time. The temple grounds are split into 5 parts and it is a very peaceful place to look around and image all the students who have passed through the college. I wish I had had some more information to hand when we first arrived to make sense of what we were looking at, but overall a peaceful way to spend the morning in hectic Hanoi.

A beautiful oasis.. We first visited the Literature Temple six years ago and learned the history of the complex. Today we returned to enjoy the serenity and beauty of the gardens and were not disappointed. The various courtyards all offer something different to look at and it's enjoyable to stop at the back of the complex and listen to music played on traditional instruments. It's well worth the 25,000vnd entry cost.

Memorable. This place is very beautiful and does not feel like you're in the Vietnam, seems very magical. I suggest getting a tour guide and learn about the historic culture and enjoy the beautiful sights!

A place of tranquility amid the chaos of Hanoi. This old Confucian temple (constructed in 1070) is set inside a walled compound. Inside is a magnificent garden and peaceful surroundings. It is one of several spiritual places which the non-religious Vietnamese are still proud to exploit as a tourist attraction. They have adapted the site to the Vietnamese way of thinking surrounding the father figure of Confucius with motherland images more in keeping with Vietnamese spirituyality. The Vietnamese regard Confucianism and Chinese Communism as different versions of the same brand of oppression of the Vietnamese people.Nevertheless the Temple was the first University in Hanoi [lacing it along with other old universities in Western culture. It was aplace of learning for the well to do - but had a practical side as the students had to learn horticulture skills to grow food to feed themselves.It provides another glimpse into the tortured history of Vietnam and its testy relationship with its northern neighbour China. Over the centuries there have been many waves of refuhees and attacking forces that have roamed the country. Vietnam has 54 ethnic minority groups inhabiting its borders - most of them refugees at one time or another from China.This chequered history can be further appreciated with a visit to the Ethnology Museum and the Museum of History in the french Quarter near the Hanoi Opera House ( a replca of the Opera Garnier from Paris - a fine colonial building and the site of many wedding shoots.

Fortunately we had a great guide. With her help, we understood a little more of what this place is, what it meant to the locals etc... without our guide, I don't think we could appreciate this place any better.
Learn about the Mandarins. Would recommend bringing a guidebook or reading about the history of the Imperial Bureaucracy and education system; it's fascinating.

nothing much to say... there's a couple of statues, stone slabs and a lotus pond of sorts but thats about it there is to see.other than the crane and tortoise statue (in which you're supposed to rub the crane's chest and tortoise head), its just a nice quiet walk in and out.there is a souvenir shop inside and you can get them to send your postcards. mind you, it'll take a long time to receive though.
Interesting. Serene to walk through, take a seat and relax, especially with a bustling city surrounding you. There is a fee to enter

Nothing special. The Vietnamese rightly revere the buildings and garden here for their role in Vietnamese history and culture, but to an international traveler, there's little to see. The buildings are modest, the gardens far from special, and the crowds huge. Wander by if you need a brief respite from the bikes and the noise, but there's not much here to make a special visit worthwhile and it's hard to make a visit here last half an hour.

GOOD TO WALK AROUND. My wife and I walked around the lake most days during our stay in Hanoi.We found the best time being at night when all the lake was lit up and there were lots of locals getting some excercise!!There are several cafes around the lake so we did a lot of people watching with a coffee!!.We enjoyed it.

Make sure you see the whole site..... The grounds and main Temple are excellent, but if we hadn't read up first we would have missed the third section, the National University behind the temple. A thousand year old temple of learning, set in beautiful grounds - wonderful.
Beautiful with so much history. Well worth a visit.. We went with a guide who explained each exhibit and who had an excellent knowledge of vietmanese history.

Give yourself plenty of time. In the mid morning, lots of local school graduates come for their photos in traditional dress. Sit in the gardens and enjoy their moment. You can even join in the photos. The restoration of the rear temple is now complete......don't miss going upstairs for the view out of the top windows. Delightful!

It is well worth the visit!. If for one reason or another you only have time to see one or two attractions in Hanoi, make sure the Temple of Litterature is one of them! Extraordinary and pleasing architecture and landscaping, this visit allowed us to have a more in depth understanding of Vietnamese culture.

Very interesting to visit. I spent a few days in Hanoi and after the wonderful ethnographical museum and the Old Quarter I found the Temple of Literature & National University to be one of the highlights of my stay.

Feel the spirit. I have been here so many times but never ever get bored with this first university of Vietnam. You will learn about history, culture and architecture of Vietnam through this complex. It takes about 1 hour to see everything.

Take a tour guide. This is worth seeing but I recommend a tour guide to be able to learn all about the history as most signs aren't in English. Fascinating to learn about the students life here in bygone times. Eat at Koto restaurant over the road - helping out street kids to learn a trade. Similar idea to Jamie Oliver's Fifteen Restaurant.

Vietnam honors those who study most. The society honored those who did best on the national exams. Their names were chiseled in stone. It was interesting to see the list of the best, a list kept for hundreds of years. How proud my guide was to show that someone with has family name was one of the first so honored in the 1400s.The VN Bill Gates was visiting when I did. Still, the nation honors those who do well. The temple is pleasant, with many court yards. It is really worth a visit - and to see what the society deems as worthy of honor.

Interesting place to see but don't expect much explanation. Cool place to check out. I pulled up the Wikipedia article as we went through the Temple and was able to appreciate it more. A rich place to visit but be sure to have a guidebook, a guide, or some other source to derive an understanding of the temple; otherwise you will not appreciate its richness as much.
Worth a look. It was very busy when we went but it was easy to navigate through the crowds. Inside the temples are beautifully decorated. Worth the small admission fee.
Great atmosphere. It is very old university beautifully kept. It has nice feeling and even with tourist seams quiet. Close to Old center.

Rather run-down. Interesting ancient and historical place, supposedly more than 1000 years old. It's very popular with tourists, but unfortunately it has not been well-maintained. Souvenir shops here were cheaper than shops in the Old Quarter.

Beautiful Place. It is a beautiful place, we really enjoyed walking around the gardens and temple. The museum is full of information, written on walls are history of Vietnam, Hanoi in particular, and the first university. It is an extensive site hat details what I understand is the major Vietnamese academic institution of past centuries, and the kings involved. Students studied and took examinations here. Those students who successfully passed exams over the entire course of study could become functionaries in the royal government at that time.

Beautiful but need a guide. This is supposed to be the first university in Vietnam. The buildings are beautiful and there a peaceful mademade pond at the center of the site, however I don't know how a major tourist attraction like this can have no English signs at all. The place would be much more interesting if we could understand the history behind it.

Very Interesting - use a guide. Interesting to see a university of high standards dating back centuries & still being admired by current Vietnamese. The personal guide gave a good history. The best part was current Vietnamese graduates were there in stunning national dress having their photos taken (I do not think that this happens all the time)

Worth a visit. We walked here from the old quarter. It took about 30 minutes after we navigated the motor bikes and crossed the railway line. The temple is very beautiful and colourful. It's great to see their scholars are respected. We saw lots of groups of proud, local girls having their pictures taken.

Go with a Hanoi Kid for this visit!. Utterly beautiful! I thought it was a building or two but it's massive. Go with a Hanoi Kid, who will bring special perspective to the site and what it means to students. We attended in April and witnessed a ceremony blessing students on their endeavors. Must see!

Ancient. This is a series of impressive buildings with massive timber columns holding up the rafters and ceramic tiles roofs, our guide walked us around and explained the history - the DK guide book provided the best references.

Temple of Literature - Vietnam Popular Destination. Temple of Literature (Quốc Tử Giám) is Vietnam's first national university. The tempple was built in 1070 at the time of King Lý Nhân Tông.
I like the second courtyard. It contains the "Constellation of Literature pavilion" (Khuê Văn Các) - a unique architectural, a symbol of Hanoi nowaday.
A guide would have been useful. Almost decided not to add this to the schedule, but was not disappointed. It took a lot of research to understand its purpose. Recommend a good guide.

Average. Entrance fee 20,000VND. We didn’t take a tour guide, hence didn’t achieve much from our visit. The grounds are beautiful, great for photography. Frankly speaking, this was not my favourite and I didn’t enjoy it much. If you want to visit, I’d highly recommend hiring a guide so that you will gain some insight of the temple and hopefully enjoy the visit more than I did.

Interesting and Unique. This is a one of a kind site from what I know in the world so definitely worth the visit. It is worthwhile having a good guide and spending an hour here. You do not need much more.

We prayed for good exam results for our kids!. A step back in time. Very well kept and not overrun with tourists. A good guide is essential as they explain all the local traditions for example local students making offerings in return for good exam results.

Beautiful. The large grounds are beautiful. We were fortunate to see many groups of ladies taking photos in their ao dai. They should be recent graduates judging by their age and the history of this place. Managed to snap a photo with one group!Do request for a guide at the entrance, we did not and I regretted it, would have loved to have a local bring me through the history of the place.

Good visit. The buildings are well kept even the rebuilt ones had the same attention to detail as the first ones. There is a huge amount of history in this nearly thousand year old temple. Was build in 11th century and considered the first university in Vietnam, Temple of Literature and Imperial Academy is a sacred place. Students who graduate have their names engraved in the stone tablets resting on stone statues of turtles.

Worth a visit. It's fascinating to be there and know about the story behind it.There were students taking pictures all over the places. They were a bit noisy but somehow as a tourist, i liked what I saw. Vibrant students on their Vietnamese dresses.

Better with a Guide. The Temple is the site of imperial exams, important in Vietnam's history. Because this history is so important, it would be good to have a good guide, either written or a hired guide.
1,000 years old and still going strong. You might want a guide for this one - the books are good but an in-person can fill you in on a lot of obvious stuff not in the books.

Beautiful temple and full of culture. The temple was full of students dressed in their finery celebrating their graduation...I was honoured to be apart of this as an observer. You need a few hours to walk around as there is a lot to read absorb. The cost was a few dollars and it was worth it. Watch out for the dodgy street sales going on at the front gate!

A Shrine of Great Importance to the VietNamese. Other people's pleasures are always a mystery. I visited this shrine with high expectations ('Temple of Literature' is a very promising title!), but I confess to feeling a little bit lost. It is essentially a shrine to the Mandarin academic tradition, and it is clearly held in reverence by VietNamese and Chinese visitors. I did my best to work up a reverential mood, but it reminded me too much of the hidebound nature of the Western academic industry to be regarded with sufficient earnestness.The temple's main exhibit is the collection of stone stelae which commemorate famous scholars. The stelae (without intentional irony) are mounted on the back of lumbering tortoises that remind one of Mt Casaubon... The site is appealing for its architecture and the gardens, though the coachloads of local and Chinese visitors made it rather difficult to appreciate them.Well, at least I can tell my VietNamese friends that i went there...And, oh yes, watch your change! The ladies at the ticket counter are experts at counting out one note too few!

Magnificent living temple. Visited as part of our tour - lucky to be present for a graduating group of Vietnamese students, celebrating in all their academic finery. Many insights to be had into the Confucian system of learning and examination present from around 1000 AD on.
Tribute to Confucius. This is a wonderful temple that is generally a tribute to Confucius and to learnings.Beautiful grounds and well restored after damage in previous wars. Well worth a visit.

Full of students. We were lucky that on the day we went, it was full of young strudents in their graduation gowns and their best frocks/suits. their youthful energy brought great heart to the space. Checkout the government-run shop as well. The antiques were considerably cheaper than at other shops.

Really interesting. Amazing place to visit.We were lucky enough to have a really great guide who really knew her historyYou must stop to listen to the music played in the old university on fantastic instruments.Whole experience was very interesting.

A relaxing place to escape the hustle of Hanoi.. The entrance fee was well worth the gentle stroll through the temple's peaceful gardens which still felt relaxing given the hoards of tourists taking in the attraction. We all got the feeling of the reverence which seems to exude from the beautifully landscaped gardens and courtyards. The only thing it lacked was information about the place and it how important it is for the Vietnamese. There is a brochure you can purchase for 8,000VND which might be worth getting if you want to learn about the history of the site. There is a well priced gift shop on the site but be aware, the items they sell aren't unique to this temple and can be purchased at many a market stall in the city. Overall, I would definitely recommend this attraction to others.

Nice to see, but nothing spectacular. This was the "Oxbridge" of Vietnam. It's a nice old building, but really nothing much to see. Perhaps a few photo opportunities but no explanatory notes or anything to go with the visit.

suprising little time capsule. the buildings are well kept even the rebuilt ones had the same attention to detail as the first ones.suprising to learn how much history was housed in this place. Confucius as a student. some of the displays are well presented, others are a bit dated.the gardens and the learning tablets were a high light, very symbolic to the vietmanise poeple

Temple of Literature. A must see landmark. We took a cab to get to this location from where we were staying. There was a children's graduation ceremony taking place when we visited, so there was a lot of activity going on that day.

Oasis in the middle of hustle and bustle. This temple is one of the staple attractions of Hanoi. There is a huge amount of history in this nearly thousand year old temple. You really need a tour guide to get the most out of it as there is a lot meaning behind certain aspects of the temple.

Good, but take a guide. Well preserved and interesting, but really glad we had a guide or we wouldn't have understood the significance of the elements of the buildings and contents and got the most out of our visit as there are very few English language explanations around. Worth a visit if you have a detailed guide book or a guide.

Great insight into Vietnamese Culture. We did this with Hanoi Kids (university students who do tours for free to practice their English) because we had guides it meant we had all the symbolism explained. A lot of Vietnams places of interest don't have explanations in English so having a guide is essential. Well worth a vist and so much more interesting than I imagined!

charming worth a visit. Pleasant set up dedicated to Confucius - I did it on a full day Hanoi tour and found time here far too short (as oposed to the HCM memorial which I did not appreciate, overcrowded). I will return to the temple to better soak in the atmosphere
beautiful. Great gardens and ambiance in the Old Quarter. The history of this is fascinating and fun to learn while strolling the grounds. Easy walk from here to the Ho Chi Minh Museum.
Ridiculously old university. This is a serious bit of history right in your face. The site of the 1,000+ year old museum is easy to access. The turtle scholars list are mind blowing.
ok after a long day. We went here after a tour around Hanoi quite interesting,but its hard to take it all in on a short trip

A Haven of Learning and Colour. Beautiful, old temple-like buildings that used to be a university, set in colourful gardens.When we were there, there were lots of students and classes celebrating their graduation or groups of girls wearing the colourful national dress known as the Ao Dai. It still serves apparently as a place to celebrate education.

The very first university in Vietnam and probably the World. Was build in 11th century and considered the first university in Vietnam, Temple of Literature and Imperial Academy is a sacred place. The buildings remain the same as it was built a millennium ago.
Many Vietnamese students often come and pay their respect to the past and wishes for good luck in their academic life.

guided tour. we had our guide to take us round.
many of building have shops in them which spoilt it
The reconstrcuted building to 3 emporors was great as can seee how building made in thjose day.

Not as impressive as I thought. As the first university of Vietnam, I do expect something grand. However, the Temple of Literature is not as impressive.This is a former center of learning in Hanoi. It is a temple of Confucius. The architecture is very Chinese influence and they sell a lot of calligraphy arts as souvenirs too. Very Chinese, just not as impressive. Anyway, still, it is good to pay a visit to understand the culture of Vietnam, since it only cost VND20k per pax.

Elegant antiquity. The oldest building in Hanoi built in 1070. It was founded in honour of Confucius as a centre for higher learning. The gardens are colourfully laid out with bright flowers & topiary animals. The red lacquered & gilt Temple of Confucius is a living temple with an endless stream of worshippers & many interesting artifacts. The tortoise stones are also interesting as they are inscribed with the names of scholars dating back to the C15th. Well worth a visit!

Excellent introduction to an unknown culture and history. Our guide provided us with excellent information about each part, which helped us to really understand and appreciate the significance of this site.Without an English speaking guide we would have struggled as there was limited information.

Interesting insight into Vietnamese culture. Interesting displays, although not much information in English, so we did not understand some of the artefacts. Lovely to be there on graduation day when the place was filled with students and their families. Really brought it alive,

Interesting and inspiring.. We visited this temple / ancient university, and it was amazing to imagine scholars studying there a thousand years ago. Students who graduate have their names engraved in the stone tablets resting on stone statues of turtles. Excellent place for a few interesting photographs and it is in great contrast to the manic hustle and bustle of Hanoi just outside its walls.We were lucky to see a few students all dressed up celebrating their graduation while we were there and they were more than happy for us to photograph them.This trip is definitely better if you have a guide - otherwise it would be difficult to make out the importance and significance of certain attributes of the building.Also make sure that you do not need to use the bathroom as they are really quite disgusting.

A Nice Break. Hanoi is a crazy city, and it's good to be able to find those places that offer a little bit of peace. The Temple of Literature is a good option for that. It is spacious and, while it does have a gift shop at the end, you are free to relax and enjoy an afternoon there. Also, it's pretty nice to not have to deal with hawkers and shoe shiners. If you only have a couple days in Hanoi, you can probably skip this. But if you are looking to get some quiet, take a walk and see this place.
Top attraction in Hanoi. Great spot to visit to see the history of Vietnam. Nice gardens, relics, and things to photograph. Of all our stops in Hanoi, this was the one place most worth visiting.

Guided Tour, A Must. I just came back from visiting this site. Underwhelming, for my standards. But only because I wasn't in a tour group or had a proper guide. There were no English translations so for the most part, I had no idea what's going on. I would appreciate this more if I had someone to explain the story behind the place. There was a throng of students from all grade levels and the place got a little too crowded to take decent photos.There is a 20,000 VND fee where USD1.00 = 20,000 VND. There are nooks where you can buy souvenirs.

Forgettable. Although highly recommended by all Hanoi guidebooks as a "perfect" temple, at least in dimensions, I did not found the Temple of Literature to be outstanding. I would probably not even recognize the pictures in a few months. Besides, it's trampled over my hoardes of tourists in organized tours; an independent traveler such as myself can't get a break.

Ho Hum. Maybe it was the fact that it was over 40 degrees and crowded. we walked around and didn't see much written english. The ponds were opaque green. I felt sorry for the fish. It's good for a 15 minute visit. the idea of this ancient university was better than the reality.
must visit. hanoi's oldest university. very ancient. names of graduates engraved on stone tablets. well maintained. beautiful landscaping. must visit.

An excellent insight into historic importance of Vietnamese education. this was a great insight into the importance and emphasis on education throughout the history of Vietnam. The vist was mad all the more interesting by the groups of school kids and graduating university students that were here doing the same things we were. Beautiful buildings and surrounds

Get a Guide. We visited during Tet so it was very busy. Lovely flower displays were probably the most interesting thing for us. We didn't have a guide so just kind of wandered around not really knowing what everything was. If I went again I would get a guide and from other reviews it sounds much more interesting than my experience.

Lovely temple and gardens. We visited the Temple of Literature with our guide from HanoiKids, it is a beautiful place, we really enjoyed walking around the gardens and temple. I think we enjoyed it more by having guide than if we had just gone by ourselves, I don’t think you can fully understand the history and the meaning of the statues, columns and the history of the place by yourself. There were a couple of groups of local school children and some university graduates there at the same time and it was nice to see locals enjoying it as much as the tourists. Definitely a must see when in Hanoi.

Beautiful temple to Explore with a Guide. We went to the Temple of Literature just before Tete. The temple grounds look amazing with flowers everywhere. We stopped in to see the temple with our Hanoi Kids on our day tour. They took us through the temple and provided us with lots of relevant interesting information. It was interesting to note that many university students come to the temple to rub the heads of the sacred turtle in hope of getting luck to pass a test or to have a prosperous graduation. It was wonderful to hear about the history associated with the temple.I don't think you would get as much out of this experience if you didn't have a guide to share it with you. I think it is worth a visit.

Fascinating gardens and temple dedicated to Confucius. This is a beautiful and serene place to visit with history dating to Cofucius. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful and there are lots of opportunities for pictures.
One area had graduating students in their finest dress willing to have you take their photo. You can also visit the temple which is a fine example.

Need a guide to explain. Without a guide the place has no meaning and we didn't really understand it's significance. Has some pretty buildings and you can buy postcards/hand made cards and other souvenirs. Gardens are well kept.

Informative. The museum is full of information, written on walls are history of Vietnam, Hanoi in particular, and the first university. It was unfortunate that we visited on a rainy morning that we did not enjoy much of the attractions

See it if you have time. It was lovely to see and quite close to other tourist sites in Hanoi (Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Museum and One Pillar Pagoda). The Koto restaurant is also just around the corner - yum! We didn't have a lot of time (about 45 minutes), but we managed to see the entire sight in that time. I noticed many guides taking people around and there were a few offering tours near the front gate (not sure what the price was). We didn't take it up so I can't comment. A nice place, but not a must do.

Best done with a knowledgeable guide. This place would have been another pretty & interesting old building if we didn't have the lovely Hanh to guide us and provide lots of information to give us a feel for the importance of this place in Vietnamese history and culture. The fact that the early kings saw the value in scholarly pursuits and from quite an early stage permitted anyone who could pass the examination to attend is quite forward thinking.
nice visit. Beautiful flower decoration, nice history behind the temple, the 'real' zemple is missing though and it's rather crowded
Definitely a must see. It's full of history and very beautiful pagoda. I loved that they had a wall in the main pagoda where you could write your wishes and dreams.

Academic Relic of Centuries Ago. We visited the Temple of Literature. It is an extensive site hat details what I understand is the major Vietnamese academic institution of past centuries, and the kings involved. Students studied and took examinations here. Those students who successfully passed exams over the entire course of study could become functionaries in the royal government at that time. There are many buildings here and they present a complex view of the academic culture of ancient Vietnam. Artifacts of past times are provided. The area had many local tourists visiting while we were there, and this could be distracting. But if you focus on the buildings and their history, you realize the depth of academic interest in ancient Vietnam, the Confucian influence from China, as well as the influence of Vietnamese local dieties. If you have time, this is a worthwhile place to visit.

Great photo opportunity. We arrived when students traditionally come to the Temple of Literature to pray for good marks. Over time, this tradition has morphed into a bit of a party and the students come dressed in their finery. no praying, no studying, but a great photo opportunity

Temple of Literature. A large impressive complex of traditional buildings that were the seat of learning in the 11th century. Interesting to learn about the way of life for students (bring your own tent and staples for the next 3 months!) Fascinating to see modern day students in their graduation robes still coming here to have their photos taken as the centre of learning in Vietnam. Worth a visit

Temple of Literature. A very interesting place to visit. There is lots to see as well as a musical group playing Vietnamese music. When we visited there were many students celebrating their successes and others preparing for their exams and collecting their personal scrolls. You definitely need a guide who can explain the history and significance of the various areas to enable you to get the maximum benefit from your visit.

Worth a stop. If you take a tuk-tuk there, you will enjoy wandering around the temples and learning the history of this beautiful area of old Ha Noi. Across the street is one of the major handicrafts shops, so be sure to stop, but know that there is a larger and a smaller one, so be sure you go to the larger one.

Historical. A very historical place.Very interesting . But you must have a guide to explain to you. You will find your self back into the past.They have very nice souveniors there which you can't find in old quarters.
Temple of Literature & National University. This is the real gem in the heart of the city. Well worth a visit - go and spend a good couple of hours there.

Pretty place to visit. A pleasant enough place to visit, but not a must-see.It was extremely busy whilst we were there and we witnessed a man being pick-pocketed and we were given the wrong change when buying our entrance ticket, which put this attraction on a back foot before we even started our visit.

Nice to see. A small place, but nice. It is not a must when you are in Hanoi, but it is ok to go there. You can see some altars and the temple looks very nice from outside with all the big status and turtels.

Peaceful in the middle of busy Hanoi. Even though its located in the center of busy Hanoi and frequented by many tourists, this temple offers peace and tranquility. Its absolutely amazing. Additionally, there is a lot of history that makes it even more interesting. Luckily, we had a great tour guide that shared a lot of history behind the temple and the various statues. If you are venturing without a guide, we suggest that you read up on the temple, as its a gem.

Peaceful oasis in the heart of the city. The temple and university is well worth a visit. Located in the heart of the city the setting is superb with peacful courtyards and beautiful flowers. As other contributors have said its best to have a guide who can explain its history. But also leave enough time for you to explore on your own and take time to sit and take in the atmosphere.

full story in Hanoi!. its location little bit far away from old town .5 mix by taxi but becarefull with taxi driver.Temple and revealed things so interesting that it had me spellbound, the history of this place goes back centuries yet, bears resemblance to practices in use today...connect to the past at this marvelous...

Excellent Architecture and Amazing stories..... The temple of literature has some lovely carvings and stories behind it. It was lovely to walk through the gardens and enter the temple courtyard from 1 to the 2nd and the 3rd......enjoyed the pictures we took along with the stories of this place.

Cultural and historical Gem. This ancient university is superbly preserved and presented. It presents in the best light the superb Civilisation that Vietnam has been for centuries. Plan on spending a good 6 hours to truly appreciate these treasured buildings and understand the culture they represent.

Contemplative escape. Each time I've been to Hanoi I've made a point of revisiting these tranquil shaded courtyards to soak up the atmosphere and escape momentarily from the busy streets. I love being reminded that such an ancient seat of learning (it dates from 1076) still plays such a central, contemplative role in the daily life of the city.

Interesting and peaceful. Despite the large number of tourists this is still a peaceful place to come and visit. Less people around over lunchtime and early afternoon when the temperature is at its highest.Peaceful courtyard setting once inside the temple. Good place to visit with a guide as you can get an appreciation of the history of the place and a full explanation of the symbolism in and around the temple itself.One if the must sees of Hanoi.

Awe-inspiring. I visited here with Hanoikids and really enjoyed it. Seeing young children being taken round was a bonus. It is an awe-inspiring place, with so much history and culture, and I would definitely recommend a visit. Very peaceful, in an otherwise frenetic Hanoi.
Confucius at his best. Peace and tranquility in busy Hanoi. Large complex with an impressive historic past. I specifically liked Confucius and the role he played.

Confucian university and temple.. Many courtyards which acted as "class rooms" for scholars doing their "Ph.D." degree courses. If successful they were guaranteed an official post in the heirachical structure of Imperial Government. Lucky enough to be there on pre-graduation day for modern-day students, which added to the excitement and glamour. A true "must see".
Beautiful Temple. Temple of literature was peaceful and beautiful. A decent amount of tourists there but not overwhelmingly crowded. Definitely worth a walk through while in Hanoi.

Awesome. I totally loved this place. the magic areas with the stone turtles on the outside. Inside full military dress warriors. The gardens were just lovely. Architecture is fabulous with a real spiritual twist.
One of the oldest' spots in Vietnam. Symbol of literature and a print of ancient times, i visited it many times, you cannot be bored there, serene and calm
