Worth a visit. Nice to walk through the different courtyards, note the balance in the design. I find parts of it too commercialised for my liking.
Temple of literature. Very interesting especially the turtle stone pillars of the students and it was peaceful to walk around,even in the middle of a busy city.
So interesting.. We even saw a wedding taking place.The vietnamese culture really comes out in this university.The stories explained by our guide about each part was facinating.

An interesting place. On my arrival I was in awe of this place, from the front, the temple of literature does not appear to be anything special, but as you enter through the royal entrance I found myself in a spiritual and special place.I could have spent hours soaking up the temple. I would highly recommend the temple of literature and my suggestion, do it on your own, as more time is needed.

Worth stopping by for a look.. The University was a great stop for some interesting history into Hanoi. Nice temples and gardens around the buildings. The evening was a nice time to visit as there weren't too many other people there. Love the details of the architecture.

A wonderful experience. We were so lucky to arrive when there was a festival going on. Great dancing and extremely enthusiastic singing by the veterans. They clearly are very proud of this setting and understandably so. The history of the "doctors" quite fascinating.
Colourful atmospheric temple. A slow walk through the courtyards, garden and temple certainly pays off if you want to catch some great pictures.

Worth the visit for its historic importance. I loved walking thru this site. Not a lot to see but just lovely to see the school children and army officers enjoying their excursion.Worth the visit for its historic importance

Peaceful temple. Was peaceful. Nice place to take a snack/picnic and relax under a tree. The temple is serene. The stele are impressive. Good late afternoon or early morning spot when there are less tourists.

Astounding!. Thought this was going to be the most boring...BUT...don't judge a place by its title kind of experience.We hired a guide who talked us through the Temple and revealed things so interesting that it had me spellbound, the history of this place goes back centuries yet, bears resemblance to practices in use today...connect to the past at this marvelous place.

Doctorates in Stone. This is how Universities worked many centuries ago, The Doctorates were carved in stone and students worshipped their teachers.A good historical place to visit and a must if you are in Hanoi.

Beware of pickpockets. This attraction was very educational but please please beware of pickpockets. I was standing taking pictures and all of a suddenly, I was completely surrounded by a mob of people. I assume they work in groups. I managed to get free of the crowd and then I looked down at my purse and the zipper was opened. Luckily, they didn't take anything but that left a sour taste in my mouth.

Tour guide is a must. Without a guide you would not know what it is you are looking at, you would think you are in just yet another temple ground and miss the overall importance. Found it incredible that locals show total disrespect for roped off areas and touch and climb over things and statues. It was buzzing with people when we visitied at the weekend.

Great place to visit but dont rush it. This place is both the confucius temple and the former examination centre for mandarins. We were there just after Tet (New Year) so it was very lively with lots of people obtaining lucky red posters to put up to help with exams etc.Outside the temple to the right of the main gate is a street where calligraphers write more lengthy scrolls. If you visit the T of L, which we recommend, you do need to do a bit of reading about the history of Vietnam first and also take time to read the explanations at each courtyard gate in order to really appreciate the layout and function.

Pretty little place - good for photographs. This place is for the eyes only - there is no information to read as you walk through. Sides of the temple are packed with stalls and you'll likely be hassled to buy things.

Go with a tour guide. This place was beautiful and makes for some good photos. But the information boards are in Vietnamese and so make sure you go with a tour guide for the full benefit. It's an interesting place but I wouldn't make it high on your list of things to see. An hour a the very max would do here.

Visit on a graduation day. The first University operated from 1442 to 1779. (notes from my guide). As one enters sees a long courtyard with two artificial pools and many plants and decorative bushes.The buildings are at the other end of the courtyard, the one near the other (most of them are closed). We happened to be there on a graduation day(13.11.12) and all the graduates go there for the graduation photos. Male wear costumes and females wear the local costume usually red and white. many wanted to have photos by and with me!!! Very flattering!!!

Interesting, but very crowded during Tet.. Vietnam's first national university. The temple was built in 1070 and is one of several temples in Vietnam which are dedicated to Confucius with scholars receiving high honors. The temple is featured on the back of the 100,000 Vietnamese đồng banknote (about $5usd). During the Tết celebration, calligraphists will assemble outside the temple and write wishes in Hán tự. Great for gifts.
Historical sight. Amazing to see that they have kept this in such great condition after all these years - very beautiful and much larger than I expected
crowded. Good for VNf olksnot an outstanding temple. avoid on holidays ccccppccpcppcpcpcpcppppcpppcppcpcccoococococ

Quiet. The quietest place we found. Really interesting even though we didn't understand a great deal(we went there without a guide or anything) Recommend having a thorough explore. Definately worth the admission(which was hardly anything anyway)
Very interesting visit. The temple of literature was the most interesting visit we did in Hanoi. It is full of students who come to celebrate their graduation.
Wonderful sight. This is a highlight of Hanoi if you are interested in History, Religion, or Architecture you must go here.

great cultural center. We got lucky and visited during the new year festivities and the grounds were really spruced up. Great history in the temple and lots of activities going on during the weekend. having a guide for this will help you to appreciate more

A quick glance into the educational history of Vietnam. The grounds were packed with Vietnamese as there was some sort of event going on when we visited.Nevertheless, it was quite an enlightening and entertaining experience as we revisited where the scholars of ancient Vietnam studied. We couldn't see the full area as some were blocked off to host the event. This is a must see if you find yourself in Hanoi.

A must see but be prepared to set aside enough time. Founded in 1070, this place has a ton of history and so much to see. To do it justice, you need to spend at least 1 but preferably close to 2 hours here. While the travel guidebooks will give you a good idea, do yourself a favour and get a local guide. A smart guide can really bring this place to life as there is very little English signage.

Interesting. It was very crowded because it was the time of year when the old teachers of the university make their prophesies to peoples futures. Some of them looked about 20 so suspect jumped on the band wagon. Interesting place for a visit and not far from the art museum.

Staff refused to help me when my phone was stolen. My iPhone was pick-pocketed in front of the altar at this temple yesterday. When I realized it was missing, the staff at the booth that sells tickets refused to help me in any way and even waved me aside as I was talking to them in tears.According to staff members and other visitors, pick-pockets are rampant at this location -- so much so that it makes me wonder if the staff invites them in and then takes a cut (like everyone else in this country) from the sale of the goods. We went to our hotel for help, and the staff there said we had to pay $15 to the corrupt police force just to get them to look at our report (we don't expect to get the phone back, but we need the report for insurance purposes). Not sure if this money even went to the police -- or just into the pockets of the hotel staff. Very upset with the people of Hanoi right now. It seems like everything is a scam.

One of the highlights of my trip to Vietnam. A profoundly interesting place- best to go with a knowledgable guide or much of great import will be lost. A true treasure not just of the Vietnamese but of mankind.

Much more than I expected.. Visited this site, which was one of the stops on our day tour - a complex of temples and libraries that documented literature over time and how literates have been captured and honoured over the years in this institution. The buildings themselves are worthy of a visit for their architectural significance.

Vietnamese first University. Our guide took us to visit Temple of literature, first when I just got into area I was attracted by quiet and peaceful architecture. After noisy bizzzzbizzz from motobike, car and other horrible traffic's noisy inside the wall that is peaceful place very old and beautiful.Then my guide explained all stories of temples of literature, Vietnam reserved very good site.... and guide said if you visit Temples of literature at the end of june and first of July this places will be very clowded by students who will do examine to get into university, will come and tauch on turtle's head and wishes they will pass....

very historical. That was very historical. in that area Vietnams people came and pray as well but all BAD People like ( prostitute, Gambler, mafia guys) do pray out side the territory. because that say they are not good enough for entering that area.
Building structure remind you KANGFU PANDA or old chines movies. :)
and many stories you will find there.

If you love calligraphy go.. If you are lucky enough try and go on their New Year Day, as it will be surrounded by calligraphy folks who will write anything you want. The locals go here at this time. If you can't make it then, try when it's spring as they have several gardens.

Unmissable. This place just buzzed with excitment for us especially as some of the students were walking round in their gowns having their group graduation photos taken. Some even posed with us!! It is a beautiful maintained site well worth a visit.

Ok for half an hour. This is an important venue to the residents of Hanoi, but there's not a huge amount to see here. The original features were interesting, such as an enormous gnarled tree and some sunken enclosed pools. There's various large stone ornaments fashioned like turtles (but look like tombstones). Sadly none of the guide text is in English, so I can only guess what these were.I strongly recommend you do not go during Tet (Chinese New Year). This is a traditional place of worship, and the place was rammed full to the point of it being annoying. We had a quick whizz round and decided to leave as there was little to see, and trying to navigate the massive crowds was not much fun
temple to Confuscius. Pretty run down but the red Buddhas at the back make for good photos. Shouldn't be high on your list, but worth a visit.

Traditional learning. This is the way it was in the mandarin tradition. You feel as though you are in a place of learning. The stele are interesting. We loved seeing the students dressed up for their grad ceremony, the girls were and absolute picture of elegance and all so happy
Worth getting a guide. We hooked on to the back of some other people's guided tours & realised you can't enjoy the full value of this place without one. Lots to learn & appreciate.
Of Reading and Writing ...Hanoi style. A beautiful garden with superb early stone carvings.The tortoise, the symbol of learning stood proud surveying the gentle walk ways. A must.
Well worth the visit. It seems to have finished but enter one part step though and another vista opens up. It is a beautiful complex.

If you have time go here. If you are pressed for time then it is ok not to drop by this place but if you have time then it is a nice place to visit. Not part of my absolutely must go list but part of my nice to go to list :)

Nice, but don't expect to be overwhelmed.. A nice place to visit in a city that has so little to offer to a tourist as Hanoi, but only because of the dearth of attractions.
Historic, large and beautifully maintaned, it is well worth a visit if you happen to be in Hanoi.

A garden in the middle of the city. Not the university one expects. Five parts, conveying the 5 basic elements, a temple at the far end. Was beautifully decorated for the new year. However, not too impressive

Major historical site and local attraction. A tourist attraction important also for local people and so a place to observe domestic life. When we visited there were numerous students, the women in national dress, celebrating graduation.

Must see. The temple of literature is a must see in Hanoi. Lovely gardens, a serene set of buildings. Our guide provided us with a lot of interesting information about it history, it was clean, and quiet, and just a lovely afternoon. It was partially destroyed in the war, but rebuilt, and parts of the temple date back about 1,000 years. There are statues of Confucius and Vietnamese kings.

Souvenir temple. I was very disappointed with this temple as it has been taken over by the souvenir sellers. I found it very tacky and unworthy of a visit. Somebody else said they had enjoyed it so maybe it is better to get a guide to take you and explain what is going on.

Worth a visit. Great to see the place where we could find a memory of first university in Vietnam 1000years ago. The highlight was the information on the back of turtles, try to see and listen from the guide.

Dignified and Quiet. Make sure you buy a guide book for here or you won't have a clue what its about. We saw a graduating class have pictures which made it interesting. There were too many hawkers out front annoying us.
Interesting history of education in Vietnam. A small area with lots of souvenir shops. Nice photo ops. Worth a visit, however it would not take much time.

Nothing too exciting. I didn't find the decorations or architecture that appealing compared to other temples in Hanoi but its a larger temple with three sections. The first is a garden with mossy ponds and little bushes in the shape of animals. The second area had a square pond in the center and stelas running along both sides. The third area has an open courtyard with souvenir shops on both sides and an alter building in the back center.

Oasis of Calm and Contemplation. Wonderful historic sight with spiritual overtones. Well maintained with reasonable English didactic panels. Beautiful garden and well located. Just accross the street from one side is the Craft Link which is a non-profit selling fabulously skilled items by women of various ethnic groups at very reasonable prices. A few doors down is KOTO (know one teach one) restaurant which provides jobs and training to local street chhildren.

Good to have this peaceful place in the noisy downtown. Nice and well-maintained garden. The temple was completely renovated in 2000.
Peaceful moment there. Really surprising because the surroundings are noisy
In October you can watch a lot of viet students who have been graduated. They come to the temple to make nice pictures in traditionnal dress with their families.
Very nice place to visit. The temple is in the middle of a beautiful garden and well decorated. Moreover, we were lucky to see some very well dressed graduated students!

Unforgettable. It's great to see how students used to study in the past. The antique houses and stone stale are really amazing to me. Visiting here gives us an insight of Vietnamese education in feudal time.

Nice but do not expect too much. It is interesting because of history but not very impressive. Visit takes 15-20 minutes. That place is very important for locals and must visit but do not expect too much.
Interesting history. The temple is in good condition and has an interesting history. Avoid the spruikers in the entrance.

A corner of peace.... I think it's the most beautiful place in Hanoi ... In typical Chinese style, it is very pleasant to walk in the gardens attention to detail, where the flowers are some of the sets and form shapes and words ... And the stems of stone, resting on turtles, where engraved with the names of the first graduates ... The whole complex leaves a deep sense of calm and inner peace ... A haven of serenity that contrasts with the chaos of traffic a few meters away.
lovely. unique and easy to find... i went here this morning... only $3 take a taxi from my hotel... you can buy like sovenir or something

Have A Guide & Learn The History. This is definitely a top attraction in Hanoi, and there are good reasons to this. It's good to have a guide as we experienced with the Hanoikids who told us the many stories and insights to the temple & former university. Very interesting indeed to know the history. We went there around 3pm and it wasn't too crowded. The temple is still being used to pay respect to Confucius. At the end of the temple, there is a nice displays of historical items eg the elaborated clothes and intricate carvings of the altar on the upper floor.

Honor a 1000 year old culture. It's amazing to see scholars honored from 1000 years ago. It made an impression on my children. They rook pictures of the pagoda to honor teachers. Our tour guide told just enough stories to engage them, but not bore them.

A fascinating insight into early education in Vietnam. This is one of the must-see attractions in Hanoi although it does not entirely maintain the feeling of antiquity which one might expect - presumably much of it is restored. However, it is salutary for us to be reminded of the way higher education and learning was organised in Vietnam a thousand years ago and how they celebrated academic and professional achievement - marvellous displays of examination results carved in great stone tablets for example, and depictions of mandarin education and status (the "university" was largely designed for senior servants of the Emperor ) It may not be the most authentic experience because it is geared for tourists and visitors, and some of the merchandising is rather unhelpful but it is certainly worth while visiting the Temple and wandering around the grounds and courtyards.

Serene. The Temple of Literature is a little hideaway from the hustle and bustle of the Hanoi streets. Whilst there isn't much in the way of seating to take in the surroundings, a pleasant stroll is very calming.For a taste of local life, head to the Temple near closing time, then check out the park next door - every kind of sport is played there!

Peaceful with beautifully manicured landscaping. Stone stelae on the backs of turtles and a statue of Confucius are impressive. The surrounding gardens with topiaries are maincured; bonsais with small tableaus are in the courtyard.
Wonderful!. Incredibly interesting. A brilliant introduction for us to Vietnamese culture. There was a special ceremony going on when we were there to celebrate the professors.
Not waht it looks like. Interesting the way people were learning in the past. A beautiful place in town, to see how education was done in the past.

Also a place of quiet and calm. To find this oasis of calm and tranquilty in the noise and crowds that is Hanoi was a really good experience.Go early to avoid the masses, it's also cooler.Fascinating insight into how advanced this part of the world was 1000years ago.Spend time contemplating how this all worked that long ago.Recommended

Temple of Literature & National University – Historically Significant Place in Vietnam. One of the must visit places that is historically significant in Vietnam is the Temple of Literature & National University. Even more significant is the architecture of the university in the background of huge trees. It is good to use a guide as we found because there are no insignia in English and guides are not very expensive either. Visiting the spot early will save the visitors from hassles of crowds and after peacefully visiting the place, one could proceed towards the two art and craft outlets on the road nearby where the prices are quite reasonable. Finally; one could proceed to the famous KOTO restaurant. Do not forget to have an early booking as the restaurant is visited by many people on all days.
Interesting. Serenic, beautiful and well maintained temple. Nice curio stores as well and not very expensively priced.
Historically Significant. This was very interesting as part of Vietnam's history and culture. It is definitely worth visiting.

Interesting. Our guide kept us well informed. Was able to admire the architecture--one of our party is an architect. By the time I got here I was a bit museumed and historied out so probably did not appreciate it as much as I might have done if visited separate from other places of interest.

A nice relaxing environment in a busy city. Great architecture amongst huge trees, this place is a little breather from the rush of the city. I recommend you get a guide to explain everything as there's no signage in English and guides are less than a few quid. I also recommend that you go quite early to avoid the crowds and max your chances of some good photos. When you've finished you can stroll across the road where there are two craftlink outlets (shops that support local artisans with reasonable prices) then finish up at the famous KOTO restaurant which is almost next door to craft link. You may need a booking for the restaurant. That will take you from 9 am to 1 pm.
this is the first university of vietnam. now a temple but originally a university this structure is amazing - the temple and the" good luck turtles" are a glimpse into the past of vietnam.
Respectful. An amazing 1000yo place of learning.loved the time honoured values.heard some beautiful traditional music,
Beautiful , interesting, cheap entrance,. Buy your souvenirs here as they are very well priced. Interesting a I suggest a guide to explain, or just tag onto an English guide . Well enjoyed .

A tranquil spot. This is a beautiful, peaceful site within the city. The temple is visited by tourists and locals alike - the day we visited groups of graduates were visiting and having their photos taken. Well worth a visit.
First University. Quite interesting learning about the history of this place from our guide. Enjoyed looking at the architecture of the building some of which dated back to the 11 century

Lovely ancient heritage place. So glad I chose to visit this place of long educational tradition (rather than the awful prison) and it was good to have our knowledeable guide to explain it. We coincided with a graduation day, the girls so colourful and happy. We wished them well

Most interesting place in Hanoi. Most interesting place in Hanoi. We enjoined very much this site.
We had the opportunity to meet many young students who came to celebrate their graduation and it was very nice to meet them.

Small, pretty temple and grounds but don't expect too much to do (or read about).. This is a nice stroll away from the old quarter. $1 entrance fee. There are a few English/ French/ Vietnamese signs that tell a bit about the origins and use of the site. It is pretty and we saw people taking graduation photos there. The gardens are nice, with topiary and some flowers. Doesn't take very long to see everything though. There are a bunch of souvenir stands and stuff inside too.

Great old buildings, very beautiful. This was probably my favorite attraction on a city tour I did in Hanoi. The buildings are very impressive and the place has a lovely charm about it. There is a lot of history here and its an interesting, beautiful place to visit.

A temple of tranquility in a very noisy city. This is one of Hanoi's top attractions, a very interesting example of Confucian influence on Vietnamese culture. It is also a great place to escape the incessant honking, insane driving, and awful pollution which detracts from what would otherwise be a fascinating and charming city.

Confused about Confucious?. This is slightly away from the Old Quarter but worth the taxi/cyclo trip. It is the site of Vietnam's first university, and is a temple to Confucious. A restful place in the middle of all the hustle and bustle.
Beautiful temple.. The grounds are quite small but the temple is worth the quick walk through. Not a large amount of things to see but is still worth the quick visit.

A wonderful place to learn a little of Vietnam in a quiet setting. A very pleasant experience to learn a little of Vietnamese culture in a quiet, serene part of the city. We would have liked to spend more time there to absorb more of the atmosphere, but alas, time did not allow this luxury.
Well worth a visit if you are visiting Hanoi.
Historical site that is in very good condition. The history behind the site as well as the maintenance of the architecture and general history is well worth a visit

fascinating. it was beautiful and an amazing story behind. best to go with a guide to really understand the history of it. i find though that all temples are the same after a while but as it was our first one of the visit it was great. we were lucky the the high school graduates were taking their photos there, lovely traditional dresses and happy girls. It is way bigger than it looks too, when you think you have seen it, there is an other building behind. it is well maintained and very neat.

Nice but busy bit of history. I like this place but be selective about when you come. My advice is early weekdays or you will be in a crowd. Very creative and pretty landscaping, good historical displays and many photo ops abound.

Nothing Too Special. It's quick, easy and fast to look at, but a walk through the Temple of Literature really gives you a feel for the old quarters of Hanoi. A little bit of serenity right in the middle of one of the most bustling areas of the city.

Very large place. You must know what it is all about. The Temple is an extremely important piece of Vietnamese heritage, but the information in English is not really complete to understand the dimension of it. It's a nice place to crash and relax from the roaring streets of the capital.
Serene. Very enjoyable, serene in the middle of a very busy and noisy city. Full of ancient relics and good information about its history.
Worth a quick look. We walked through here in half an hour while we were waiting for our lunch reservation at Koto restaurant (which was awesome). It's a very beautiful place but you won't need long.

Education At Its Best. Very impressive, especially the scholars tablets mounted on the backs of turtles. You come away with a respect for learning and the significance education/educators had on the building of Vietnam for past centuries.

Colourful and interesting. We were lucky - the day after Teachers Day, so lots of young people all dressed up, bands, people dressed as human chess pieces. But very beautiful surroundings anyway, and quite different to other sites.

Historic defence place to visit. My mates and I stumbled in this place, nice 20 mins walk from Hoang Kiem Lake. The architecture is quite attractive and historic, information boards in English are informative and give a good insight into the building's significance. Overall, pleasant, wouldn't say it's a must-see but I prefer it to some of the other museums in Hanoi.
Just another nice temple. We have seen a lot of temples and this one is okay to visit but you will not miss much if you give it a pass.

Quaint and Serene escape in a middle of a hustle and bustle city. Well kept temple with interesting artifacts of old. Hanoi is a hustle and busy city with traffic going left, right and all around. It is such a pleasure to be able to visit this temple in the middle of the city and temporarily escape from the endless street honking. You can still browse at the names of graduates of the past on the many large stone plaques resting of a giant stone tortoise. When we were there, many young locals were there taking picture and celebration their graduations. It's great to see that this temple is enjoyed by tourist and locals.

Need some Literature. An interesting site to visit but you should have a guide or at least some literature/guide book, otherwise you're just looking at a bunch of ancient Asian artifacts. We spent approximately an hour learning about the history and stories of the men who have shrines in their honor. Also sat and listened to some traditional music.
Music to my ears. I love the music - only place I actually got to see some performed during 3 weeks in Hanoi. Other displays, altars etc, nice too.

Confucius and more.... enjoyed this very much - not just a touristy site, but also still valued by locals, as a honorable place to receive certificates and take graduation pictures in traditional dress (see pictures)

Really boring. Not much more to say, than boring. It covers a very large area in Hanoi, but not that interesting though. It was able. To find a few areas to trap tourists into buying unnecessary souvenirs.

A must see attraction in Hanoi capital. It is a great attraction to take visit in Hanoi capital. We spent more than one hour there to learn about its historical development, about Vietnam educational development. It is know as the first University of Vietnam and now becoming one of the most busiest touristic icons in Hanoi, Vietnam. We also took time to see around, photos shooting and watched some old men performed handwriting art. It was also an entertaining time for us when walking under the shadow of te old living trees. We love Temple of Literature, National University of Vietnam, and Hanoi is a worth visiting destination!

Do some background research. This place sets an excellent background to a trip through Vietnam. Well worth doing some background reading so at least have some way of piecing it all together. Even if you don't it provides an insight in to how life was ( and influences today). Well worth the visit.

a piece of quiet in the chaos. the world's oldest university is not what we expected. The stelae with previous scholars listed and the lush and intricate floral displays add reverence to this special place. well worth a visit.
Pretty. It was pretty to walk around here and educational to learn about the history / students. Be sure to take note of the students all dressed up taking pictures for good luck.
Oldest university in Vietnam.. Our groups always enjoy visiting this landmark of Hanoi. It is so interesting to see the architecture and the manicured grounds of this ancient facility.
Beautiful Architechture. Have a good walk around the area and take a look at the Stones with DOctor's scriptings. If you understand CHinese, do have a read at those words on the pillar/door/walls

National University. Interesting place to visit as I teach at the college level. You could get a degree in 3 years and it seemed like part of it was home study, interesting concept
Architecturally interesting as well with the stone tortoises
Good but a bit samey. Could have covered this in 30 mins but our guide wanted to explain more. Probably means more if you're vietnamese - worth a look but it's not a wow

More educational visit. We visited because it was listed as an attraction. We do not regard this as a must visit. It has a garden and some traditional buildings where scholars used to reside. On walls and stones, there are names of scholars. unless you are into the History of ancient china and love confucius teachings, this may not be of interest to you. As we have also visited many temples and buildings like these, we were not too excited.You may skip this if you do not have time. We would recommend the hanoi prison, halong bay, old quarter area walk....some museums.
A lovely oasis. Beautiful gardens and a lovely place to visit. Was very crowded and some people found the incense overwhelming but it didn't bother me. Was nice to just sit and enjoy the atmosphere.
A must see in Hanoi. One of the Hanoi highlights for us. Very traditional feel and a great historic feel. We had a local guide with us but would be easily done with a guidebook instead.

Ancient Hanoi. Literature Temple is an oasis of quietness and peace within this chaotic city. When you are here for more than a day, you should drop by for sure. But don't walk there (not a nice wlak) .. get a cab instead.

Crowded. We chose the wrong day to visit the Temple! It was packed with recently graduated Vietnamese students. Nevertheless, we enjoyed the visit especially with our guide explaining the relevance of Confucious in Oriental culture.

very nice pictures with the students!. This is a very nice places where to go for take pictures with the students! It is a very green place, with a lot of nature,trees and flowers. A lot of nice vietnamies girl-students dresses with her beautiful traditional dress, and they will ask to make pictures with them!

Beautiful architectural temple worth a visit!. A beautiful temple not for worshipping but contains names of scholars who sat and passed royal exams. Set in a beautiful garden and full of history. Information are in English and French

Worthy a visit - the local music sessions were the best!. The venue has some good examples of temples and the visit itself is interesting in terms of reading. Personally for me the best was the show of typical music. The musicians played quite a few tunes and were all very good performers!
Temple of Literature. Beautiful grounds, small entry fee. Temple and bits of information on the history. Lake in the middle of the area and gift shops. Enjoyed it.

Good site but you need a tour guide or guide book. We love this site in Ha Noi b/c it's pretty and represents the best of Vietnam's scholarly history. However, we chose to go w/o the benefit of a tour guide and in retrospect we would have often more out of it if we'd had someone explain things to us. There just isn't enough explanation provided. Or I suppose you could use an updated guide book. Ours was 10 years old! To look at everything takes about 45 min. Also, the ladies selling beautiful embroidered t-shirts have the cheapest prices in Ha Noi...$2/each!
A sense of old Hanoi. Keep the best bonsai i have ever seen, beautiful gardens and lovely statues. While the rest of Hanoi seems to have moved on, this place reeks of history

A quiet and tranquil place. If you are from Asia, you might this place nothing out of the ordinary. There are many similar chinese temples in Asia, hence you might not experience breath-taking views here. Nevertheless, the temple is well-maintained and easy to walk around or just sit on the bench and enjoy the peace being away from the noisy streets!

Beautiful. The history and architecture is so beautiful. We saw many students dressed up and taking pictures in preparation for graduation. It was fun to see their excitement. Definitely worth a visit!

Picturesque.... ...and sprawling! This is really a huge temple complex, and within easy walking distance of the Ho Chi Minh complex. The houses and buildings on the way from one to the other are really splendid and atmospheric - some embassies and residences thrown in for good measure. The temple itself has a fairly interesting history, though few outside Vietnam know anything about its background. A pleasant oasis, and I do agree with the guidebooks that it's the one temple to visit if your time and energy are limited.
temple. peaceful gardens, confucious temple. not much to see rather than some sculptures, but I must say I didn't go in depth with historical information.

Beautiful place. This beautiful complex is well worth a visit. And when you're lucky you will meet groups of wonderfully dressed graduate students who want to be photographed in this Temple of Literature.

Nice grounds and buildings. We stopped here on a city bike tour. It was worth exploring for the number of enclosures in the deep complex. Our guide filled us in so we didn't really make much use of the info boards which were around and had English, French and VN. We went early before it got busy. Worth checking out.
Confucius, he say .... Slightly hard to reach, but a nice and undemanding introduction to the importance of Confucian learning to traditional Vietnamese culture.

really like its tradition. Introduced by the guide about this special place, we were amazed at its long traditional architecture since 11th century. With beautiful and old turtoises bearing a stela on back, it is similar to a doctor who devoted all his life to his nation.Also, a temple style with confucious. we like this place

Important Heritage Site and Very Beautiful. The Temple of Literature has been on my must-see itinerary for Hanoi from the first. I just liked the idea of a society that so valued education and literature from such an early date. The Temple did not disppoint. You can visit it as solely as a photogenic and interesting site, or you can get into appreciating the importance of it culturally and historically. Either way, you won't be disappointed.Our visit was vastly enhanced by the lucky accident that it was Graduation Day when we were there, and the gorunds were full of hundreds of proud young students in caps and gowns, or many of the young women in their beuatiful ao dai, all basking in their accomplishment, posing for photographs with friends and family. It was a heart warming glimpse of the comtinuity between ancient tradition and modern society.

The first university in hanoi. I visit there with my local guide and learned that it is the first university in hanoi. A bit surprise to me that inside the temple most are Chinese words, i sudden become the guide to explain the meanings of those chinese words. If you are Chinese, you may found it a little boring.

Beautiful Temple. The temple of literature was one of the highlights of Hanoi for us. It is a well maintained temple with many amazing photograph opportunities and out of all the temples in Hanoi we visited this was our favourite. You can really take your time, walk around as there is plenty to see, plenty of room and enjoy the experience of the temple without being pushed around by tourists.

Incredibly tranquil. A definite must-see when you're in Hanoi, if only for the contrast between the incredibly peaceful Temple grounds and the chaos that is the Hanoi traffic outside! If you've got time to kill, you could definitely pass a couple of hours sitting and reading in one of the little alcoves that are scattered throughout the grounds of the Temple. The Temple's gardens are stunning, and the history of the National University is quite interesting as well. On the morning we visited, we had the pleasure of watching some local students graduate from high school, which was both lovely and very entertaining!

An educational experience. This was a good history lesson on how education developed in Vietnam. The large courtyards with lots of greenery stands in stark contrast to the crowded and congested streets of Hanoi. It was interesting to see how they elevated their first "professor" to the level of a deity, with students coming to pray for good grades...
Amazing. The temple was so incredibly beautiful! Once again did the with the amazing Hanoi kids who knew so much about it so we really got the most of of it!

Not interesting if you dont like temples. Dont like temples? Stay away from temples, including this. Went here with a tour group. Since it was included, i went in anyway. Went out a bit after to shoot a video of the motorcycles.

One of the most famoust tourist attactions in Hanoi. Almost a thousand year old temple. It is like an oasis in the middle of crowded and noisy city. It is the best place to see and understand the culture and life long learning traditions of Vietnamese people

A bit of calm. The entry is on the south side. Fee 20.000 dong. The place is nice because of the lack of traffic, but not special. Outside we took a taxi with double speed meter, 80000 dong to the lake...
Very enlightening. It was was good to have a local guide at this sight in order to fully appreciate the meaning and esteem in which the Vietnamese people hold their university.
Old world charm. More explanations in English please. It is essentially used as a temple now. The souvenir sellers at the entrance sold t-shirts at rock bottom prices and of good quality too.
I found it boring. If you enjoy Chinese architecture and influence, then you will enjoy. Otherwise just another Chinese looking site. Found it very boring.

Beautiful and ancient. Very unique. Not a ginormous sprawling compound of higher learning but you walk in and you could imagine another era (if you can block out the constant din of traffic).
Wished they opened earlier do you could go in a meditate on the grounds.

everyday is graduation day?. it may have been the season, but we had heard several other tourists mentioning that when they visited, there were many graduates around the temple. we were also lucky. this likely gave the temple an extra star in my review. seeing 50 kids throwing their caps in the middle of the temple was a real treat. underneath, the girls were all wearing their traditional clothing. was a great photo op. interesting site to see either way.

worth a quick stop, but no more. a quick walk through worth but no more, as there is little in terms of explanations/texts or much to see. The entrance fee of VND 20,000 is worth a 15min walkthrough though
Another attraction. Linking its culture which quite similar to what we see in China where they taught about Confucius's teachings.

Old Vietnamese architecture and culture. Liked the distinct architecture, flower arrangements at the entrance and the unique temple inside.. Liked the idea of recognising academic merit by conferring Doctorates 500 years back and recording the names on stone tablets. The temple inside is stunning. The only problem is language. But we had an English guide.

What a treasure. We hadn't thought about going to the Temple of Literature, but at the suggestion of our Hanoikids guide we did. I think having someone to explain the significance of the features gave greater meaning to the visit.

Temple of Literature. This site is easy to visit in a short period of time, and gives a wonderful introduction to Vietnamese history. Since any trip to the area will involve visits to a number of temples, it is nice to start with this historical and beautiful one and move on from there.

Popular spot for graduates. The temple itself is nice change from museums. The added bonus is to see local graduates who like to have their photos taken in the temple. Be sure to go to Koto Restaurant across the street - best Vietnamese drip coffee we have had so far in Hanoi, the food is good & it supports a good cause (disadvantaged youth).

Lovely stop to rest, appreciate architecture and history. This is a compound with several courtyards and a temple to worship Confucius. There are signs that explain the history of Confucianism in Vietnam and the artefacts on display. It's a lovely peaceful place to spend a good half an hour to an hour to appreciate the architecture and learn a bit about culture and history. It is a quiet place of solitude in the early morning just after it opens, a contrast to the already bustling hanoi streets just outside its walls.

Get a glimpse of heavenly clarity. In Hanoi - you do not want to miss Van Mieu - The Temple of Litterature, one of the world's first universities. Enjoy a stroll in the little park full of ancient, beautiful trees, before you enter the first court yard, where you have the chance to get a little wiser from gazing into the 'Well of Heavenly Clarity". Then proceed to the inner areas and meet Kung fu-tzu himself and his servants. Bear in mind that Van Mieu is not merely a tourist attraction or museum, but an important place of worship for the Vietnamese. It is very much apprecated that foreign visitors dress with some respect. Finally, do not miss the live classical Vietnamese music in the very back building.

Worth for a visit. We take taxi for the temple only 15 minutes. Many people came here, this was great place to learn more about old architecture in Vietnam in the past and conception of Khong tu who created Catholic.

The place to visit when you're a native graduate. Noticed that the Vietnamese university graduates would come over for a visit fully clad in their robes and hats to be photographed at the famous Temple of Literature. Not too much to be seen, though.

Interesting and colourful. I'm sure that Confucius would be turning in his grave to be worshiped this way, but I have to say that the temple was kept very well and obviously a real attraction to local students seeking a leg up to best possible exam results!

Lovely afternoon walk. One of my favorite sights in Hanoi, it's surrounded by the bustling city streets yet somehow the Temple of Literature manages to hide everything as you walk the grounds. A very nice landscape with some great history!

Wonderful. We are grateful it wasn't destroyed during the Communist era. Our only complaint is that there were too many tourists! We did have the pleasure of being there at the same time new University graduates were celebrating and having their pictures taken.
Fabulous. A must visit. Went with Hanoikids. They provided so much background about the history and culture. Truly valuable experience.

A bit touristy but worth a visit.. Although it is a restoration...as are most of Hanoi's historic landmarks as the wars devastated all cultural sites!....it gives one a good sense of the spaces. There are two models that let you compare the o,d with the restored version.
Worth a look. very nice grounds once you get past all the locals trying to sell you shirts at the entry. Try Koto restaurant near by

Excellent window into history. Excellent window into history of education in Vietnam. We had no idea that university culture went so far back in Vietnamese history. Wonderful temple complex of courtyards, ponds, architecture and landscaped gardens. Well worth a visit!

A interesting place. The temple of literature is really a beautiful histotical site that contains the ancient wisdom and knowledge of the sholars. You can also see the letters writen by the Kings of the past, preserved over the centuries and the gamments of the chief examiners. They have old fossiled artifacts over some million years old on display as well as some genuine pottery discovered then. It's really an experience worth discovering!

Picturesque location for a photo-op. You will see original ancient literature tablets in this place, thus the name. Great experience. When we were there, there were students shooting for their graduation because the place is a wonderful backdrop for any photography session. You should see this place.

A "must see" on your agenda. This is a "must see" on your agenda for Hanoi. It will relly give you another perspective on the origins and development of Hanoi and Vietnam in general. It will give you a better idea of Confucianism and education as the place takes you back to the 11th century. Great place for pictures as it is outdoors. Many students have their graduation ceremonies here so you may see some of that as well.

Good to people watch, but nothing much else. Place was bustling with young people, girls in their traditional clothes and guys in black suits taking photos. Looks like the youngsters have just graduated from school and taking pictures there. Nice place to people watch and perhaps feel young again.Other than that, nothing much significant about the place. There is a temple at the end for praying to Confucius and some stone slabs with engraved names of scholars by the side.

Loud, noisy, smokey. Really nothing much to see here, alot of Koreans and Mainland Chinese tour groups visit this place so it is very very noisy. There are also people smoking indoors which really destroyed my experience here.

Great with a guide. We were brought here by our guide from Hanoikids. It is a great place to people watch. During our time there, there are quite a number of students taking post-grad photo shoot and also some art students painting there. It was quite nice visiting Temple of Literature with our guides. Without them, we will not be able to know more about the history regarding Temple of Literature as there are not much signboards around. With their introduction, it is so much better! Else, you can walk finish the whole ground within 15mins. There is an entrance fee. However, there are half price for students! Too bad we didn't bring our students card :XAnyway, temple of literature is a not-to-be-missed attraction! But with a guide of course! :)

Great for people watching. The Temple of Literature is interesting with it's stone statues and historical gates, however I enjoyed people watching instead. Many local Vietnamese visit to take photos in traditional attire and it was fun to watch and speak with them.
not to be missed. a lovely site not to be missed. make sure you have a guide so that you have a feel for this history and process that his site represents
Temple of Literature. Not so much to see as we had expected. Finished looking around in about 20 mins. Can skip if you have a tight schedule.

Not much to see. A bit dissappointing, not much to see. The good thing was that the entrence fee was cheap. If you are not in a hurry you can pop in to wach the old building, but dont bother if you dont have much time. Take another stroll in the old town instead.
Feel in. Feel in this space full of legendary knowledge and brilliant people. Very impressive. Go, see and feel the atmosphere of the academy.
old temple - young visitors. Temple is very special and ancient site - a journey back in time if only for an hour or so, popular with young locals

Oasis of cool in a bustling city. Trust me, you will need a break from the Asian immersion and heat that is Hanoi. This is a lovely garden area in walking distance from the Hanoi Elegance Hotel. By walking to this site, you get to see the real daily life of the people
Photogenic ancient treasure. I found a lot of sites to not live up to the hype in the guidebook, but this one was worth the visit. Very well kept ancient temple and photographs well.
spare only a moment. We visited the temple of Literature in November 2012. Its a nice walk, but a little boring if you're not into Temples. If you're pressed for time, I woudn't bother.

Very worthwhile day tour stop. We visited this Temple site during a misty rain and when hordes of students were getting their pictures taken before graduation. This added to the living tradition and cultural significance of this historic Temple.

Must see. During our visit we encountered over 100 women students visiting the temple....they had just graduated from agricultural school. The temple was beautiful full of energy, young students and flowers

Very interesting.. A fascinating smaill sight and a must visit. This is well signed and explained in English
The stalls sell good priced art souvenirs.

Among the most interesting sites in Vietnam. My friend and I recently visited Vietnam overall, the trip was very amazing and the Temple of Literature was one of our highlights. Our guide provided us with a lot of interesting information about it history, it was clean, and quiet, and just a lovely afternoon. There were some ladies just outside the temple who were pretty pushy about selling their postcards, but other than that...no complaints! I highly recommend it.
Nice temple. Great for a photo opportunity but not one of the places I would spend too long at, not enough to see or do.

The old university now a Temple. It is a old university were a teacher started teaching children about religion and education, it is about 1000 years old and pretty cool for one time visit, though there are lot of people visiting every day.

Worth a visit. We were lucky as when we visited students had just graduated from University and they flocked here to have their photographs taken at the original Vietnamese university.Wonderful bit of history and fabulous buildings to admire.
Beautiful site. Our visit was during the students graduation ceremony it was an unexpected surprise. Well worth the visit!

Beautiful wooden architecture. I really love this place - actually more than most of the other places in Hanoi. This is so called "the first university of Vietnam" and so naturally attracting a lot of local students in suits and ao dai. Beautiful to see all these people gathering and walking around the "first university of Vietnam". The place is comprised of wooden houses and spacious gardens and ponds. Make sure you walk to the end of the place as the last building is the most gorgeous and beautiful architecture (make sure you also go up to the 2F when you reach there). As against the modern Vietnamese houses and buildings, the houses and buildings in this space has decent use of color, which I like the most. Must see in Hanoi!!

Lots to learn; interesting stories to hear. We visited this attraction with the HanoiKids, a non-profit organization aiding kids and their desire to learn English. They were very knowledgeable and enhanced our experience. It was interesting to see the efforts both the community and students have put forth in the name of education. And who knew that the carp symbolized students? Or that their goal is to become dragons? Very interesting.
nice peaceful place. Good for lazy walking and seeing some temple architecture. Very silent place compare to noisy streets of Hanoi.

Was sooo busy!. The day we visited the temple on a the day of the Teacher and the place was full of students dressed in stunning clothes to pay tribute to their teachers. The grounds are lovely and worth a quick look.

Confucius. If this is your first visit to Hanoi it is worth starting here before you see too many tenples and hear too many different stories. The gardens were spectacular, beautifully mnicured and such as array of colour and design, flags everywhere also add to the photo opportunity.

Quick interesting photo opp. Old Asia look. Many beautiful and varied works of art. If you go early it is quiet and serene. Only 20,000 dong to enter. The souvenir shops are not high pressure and are not ripoffs.
part of the tour in Hanoi. Nicely preserved and local/musical is very well planned. My tour guide gave very good history and explaination that helped made it more enriching experience.

Interesting place to people watch!. Our visit coincided with graduation and so was full of students dress in their finery all photographing themselves and showing off. Great fun. Temple and history really interesting too.

Not really worth it - count your change. After reading the LP I felt this site was a bit of an anticlimax. The review was very generous for what was there. Average gardens and a couple of empty temples. There are far nicer temples around and far nicer gardens. WARNING - count your change. I broke a large note and received many small notes for change. I counted my change at the counter and it was short. The lady just stared at me blankly whilst I made her count it three times... with a contemptuous attitude she finally threw the right change at me.I mentioned this later back at the hotel and another traveller said she had the same thing happen. Another traveller I mentioned this to a week later also said they had the same thing happen to them at this place.Be careful - Dont be ripped off.........
Not fantastic - Skip if you are short of time.. The temple ( used to be a school) is divided into 4 quarters and it is mainly just gardens. Nothing much to see.
Interesting. The Temple of Literature is worth a visit. It has nice architecture and restful gardens, as well as an interesting history.

Quiet atmosphere. I almost surprised this university, it was a temple as well. you have to buy ticket before get inside, most classic architecture was impressive and relatively great by the roof of temple with dragon and mean of King.
Time to relax. Come here for a peaceful couple of hours when you feel the need to relax and see yet more this fascinating country has to offer.
one of the first universities in the world. learn about the classes that were held, various levels reached, see the plaques with names of graduates - another must see in Hanoi
Great place. I was really in awe at the magnitude of cultural heritage of this place and its very intricate details
Don t miss it. Very interesting. Everyone visiting the Vietnam Capital has to visit it. It belongs to history and culture.

Very good. We enjoyed our visit to this location. Immersed ourselves in a bit of local culture and history. A few cheap souveniers sort of cheapened the place a bit, but it was nevertheless very good.

Lovely Grounds. but I'm afraid that's about all I got out of it.Maybe I missed the point, but I certainly got more out of reading about it before visiting.Sure it's the oldest University in Vietnam and the architecture is interesting but trying to keep out of the way of people, (particularly graduating students) taking photos doesn't make for a pleasant day out.Go if you must but be prepared to be jostled around.

Interesting and peaceful break from Hanoi. Although the temple was not that unique compared to all the others I visited, I found the grounds to be relaxing and full of interested buildings and features. Vietnam's first university build around 4 or 6 years after the temple in around 1076. In November, there were many local college graduates posing for pictures with their classmates. Although this is not currently a university, it symbolizes the importance of eduction for all college students in Vietnam.
spiritual. My title says it all ...must see, the trees alone say old and wise i took some beautiful pictures here.

Nothing special. The site was too small to hide the throngs of people and the temple complex itself is nothing special. My visit was a pleasant but largely forgettable experience. There are far more impressive, tranquil temples to be found in other parts of Indochina.
Tranqulity amongst the madness. A beautiful oasis among the clamor of Hanoi. Also used by the locals - there were school parties everywhere - not just a tourist attraction but a living venue

We went twice in 6 days!. This place is amazing. Really a sancuatry in the craziness which is Hanoi. It's always crowded, so maybe going when it first opens in the morning is the best idea. If you're looking for authentic Vietnamese crafts, make sure to check out Craft Link next door to the Temple. It's a non-profit helping artisans sell their wears.

2nd visit and glad i did it again. Was with friends and we went to this University on my recommendation. The fee was 20,000 dong (67p) and for this you get beautiful and peaceful gardens several Buddhist temples. While i was there traditional music was being played which added to the atmosphere. The story of Confucius is told. A fantastic place to spend an hour or so.

top 3 hanoi attraction. one of the best places to visit in hanoi
we were there when the students were having their photos taken - everybody in their traditional outfit - place is beautiful on its own but this added even more charm to it

Ancient Seat of Learning. Now a museum, not an active University, but it pre-dates Oxford and Cambridge, has lovely architecture, and some interesting aspects, e.g. the stones showing who passed exams on the back of turtles (as in the Confucian Imperial College in Beijing).
Fascinating. i visited in the rain late one day, without so many visitors, and found it's calm and serenity such a wonderful counterpoint to the rest of the city.

Beautiful. Just beautiful! The gardens, the doors, the temples are stunning. When we were there, there were lots of high-students getting their pictures taken for graduation. It was a nice respite from the hustle and bustle Hanoi.
Oh to be educated. Imagine all the work that you need to do at university... but no internet... A good place to have a wander through.

Worth a look with a guide.... I say with a guide because without I am sure we would have just wondered around, took some photos and thought 'yeah, that was ok'. Our guides were from Hanoi Kids (a fantastic organisation) and they talked us through the history of the temple and what various signs stood for etc.

Timewarp in the city. You'd be excused once entering the gates in believing you were in the suburbs or even a small town somewhere in the country and about 1,000 years ago, if it wasn't for all the other tourists that is. It's a great place to visit for 1-2 hours at a slow pace or just 30 mins if you're rushing. Beautiful buildings and well preserved history make it a rewarding visit and there's enough information in English to make you feel like you understand it's role in Vietnamese history and culture. Be careful not to visit during Tet (Lunar/Chinese new year) as it get's overrun with Vietnamese visiting the temple, unless you want to experience the crowds. There are old maps from the French era and even further back which is interesting as it shows you how much Hanoi has changed in a few hundred years.

A quite place within in walking distance from Old Quarter. I walked to this Temple of Literature along with my local friend a University Student from the Hoan Kiem Lake area. Just that it had one entrance, we had to take a full round of this place before reaching the entrance. Inside it was a very cool place with ancient structures and a nice garden,. A must visit place if you are in Hanoi
Quiet Time. Nice to spend some time here. Do the research before you go, so you know what you are looking at in each courtyard.
It's about the kids. If you go at a time where university students ( who look like they're in grade school) are there to celebrate and take their pictures, you'll enjoy their joy in this setting.

I would have never been admitted in the old days. It is good to learn about history to make better use of today. Education in Vietnam has always been highly valued, and young people today learn wisdom as well as how to think intelligently and long-term. I have learned to greatly admire these people!

Worth going. This is the first attraction I visited and recommended by a final year university student who wanted to learn conversant English. She brought us there by taxi and her service is free, arranged by the hotel staff. I tipped her after 3 hours of sightseeing and we had lunch together. This temple was used as a university during ancient times and and the history behind it is quite interesting. It's worth visiting. Have to pay for admission but affordable.

Lovely break from the bikes!. Definately a site to visit - the first university in Vietnam and a dedication to Confucious and his pupils. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours and get some peace from the bikes of Hanoi.
The nicest thing we saw in Hanoi. I loved the architecture. They were playing traditional vietnamise music inside. Really nice.  I did not like that it was crowded.

The highlights of a visit to Hanoi. The Temple of Literature (Van Mieu) is one of the highlights of attraction in Hanoi. It is a university that is open for the first time in Vietnam. The temple is dedicated to Confucius and it was a very strands university granduates with very little. We meet young students who, dressed in traditional robes, colorful, there are offerings before the start of their university and make photo shoots for their scrapbook. It is a green and peaceful place while surrounded Traffic vibrant city. The granden is very nice with beautiful trees.
Well Worth a Visit. The Temple of Literature was a (relatively) quiet refuge from Hanoi's constant sounds of motorbike horns and engines.
the one place must be go when you came to Hanoi. I like this place for history study of vietnam. Many things very old and shown literature of Vietnam. You should be come here when y
Interesting. Able to walk here from the 'Old Quarter' Interesting stone stelae noting names of successful students dating back to 1484. A quiet oasis in a bustling city

Temple of Literature. I liked the garden that you entered through with the plants with saying arranged from different colored plants and the bird and turtle bronze statures that were in the main building.

Nice garden & deep in history. The temple was once the first university in Vietnam. Check out the statue where a big bird stood on the back of a turtle. It represented the heaven and earth. Also, the graduates got their names carved on a stone board erected on the back of turtle, signifying long life and auspiciousness. The temple had a Confucius statue and the plaque conferred by the Kang Xi Emperor from ancient China. Worth a visit!
hanoi visitor. Loved the Temple of LIterature, so interesting, varied and beautiful. Little school children visiting singing tunes, interesting musical performances and wonderful history
Beautiful and atmospheric. A lovely, quiet place to come and view some of the oldest architecture left in Hanoi. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Spot. Enjoyed wandering through the gorgeous buildings.. there's a photo opportunity everywhere you turn! You will need a cool drink somewhere along the way, but there are plenty of beautiful spots to sit and contemplate. The sounvenir shop was surprisingly well priced.

ONE OF THE BAST PLACES IN HANOI. It is really interesting to go there - gardens, temples, statues - all are there, moreover you will have an opportunity to forget about noisy streets there, in spite of the fact that it is almost in the city centre.
Youngs wanting to graduate. Many youngsters go dressed as graduates to ask for luck in their studies, girls and boys dress up and is like a party, colorful and fun to watch.
Historical walk. Easy to access. Lovely building. Full of historical value. The bonus is that you get to see graduates in traditional costume having their graduation photoshoot.

Antique architecture.... Before travelling to Halong Bay, we had one day and one night in Hanoi. My family deceided to visit Temple of Literature. Our tour guide said that this is the first university in Vietnam. When first entered into this temple, all we were surprised with its architecture. Very antique! We also saw many beautiful girls in very beautiful dress. They said this beautiful dress is Vietnamese costume called "Ao Dai". They were taking photo. And we also took some photos with them. It's was a meaningful day with my famiy!

a temple. this is a temple that the entrance fees is not high. However, not much special as I went to many temple in China. The only thing that is special is the Vietnam student took thier graduate photos there. Quite interesting to see them taking album there ^^
Interesting. Well preserved building. Plenty to learn about the Temple without a guide. Easy to walk around and enjoy.

great sanctuary in the middle of the hustle and bustle. interesting grounds were the high light for us. also liked the mini-lake park across the street. and easy walk north to the very worthwhile art museum, interesting alleyway life just to the east.

Fantastic Place to Chill. Loved this place because we took our time and sat and relaxed in the beautiful surrounds. Highly recommend.Didn't like the ladies playing the traditional instruments inside - sat down and listened to half a song with all intentions of making a donation (there is a well labeled box at the front) but one lady felt she had to come and ask us for $1 each to watch!!! You don't HAVE to pay - they're performing in a souvenir shop so you can listen all day for free if u pretend your shopping, therefore asking for $1 each is quite a lot. Maybe if I'd had a chance to listen to a few songs I may have felt it was worth a donation of that amount but I wasn't paying that much up front by force - its the cost of the entire entry fee! Keep in mind these ladies perform inside the temple but are not an essential part of it, you should still visit the temple - we got up and left rather than paying...

Impressive historical site. Beautiful gardens and historical buildings. Not easy to understand the significance of all you can see here without a tour guide but it didn't matter terribly as we had a guide book to help. I'd recommend doing a little background reading before going.Either way a great attraction in Hanoiand well worth a visit.

Interesting place if you like history. This was an good tour for Vietnamese history and architecture. It is also a tribute to the scholars who received doctorates from the 1400's. Take water because it's really hot walking around.

Amazing place.. A must see while in Hanoi. An interesting part of the region’s history. Amazing architecture. It was great to see the recent graduates from the surrounding universities taking photos of each other, our guide informed us it was considered lucky.

History of Scholarship in Vietnam. It opened my perspectives to a dimension of Vietnam I never imagined. The artefacts, pictures and explanation boards in English brought me through a segment of Vietnamese history that elucidates part of why Vietnam is what it is today compared to many other nations in South East Asia.
Busy. Nice place to visit, should be on list of things to do. Didn't get harassed to buy things, was nice grounds to walk along before lunch at koto
Fantastic history. A bit less to see, though and a favoured haunting place for people trying to sell something to tourists-annoying.

Great Photograghs. This is normally a good place for photos, when we went it was raining and there were lots of tourists. It is a 'Mecca' for students before university entrance exams (May) so avoid it at that time - I found it quite difficult to find out much about the place as there wasn't much explanation of who the statues were of etc, and the guide book is badly translated. In the pagoda part there were some amazing shrines - but no descriptions at all. My kids enjoyed the space - but be careful as you enter through the gardens as there were a couple (2 seen by me, maybe more ?) of abandoned syringes in the entrance. It was an OK place to visit - but it could be a lot better with some explanation and a clean up.

A Great Place to Visit in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature has been restored and shows what life was like for the early university students hundreds of years ago. It is a lovely location in the centre of the city and well worth a visit.
Must Do. Great choice great place. Temple of Literature taught Confucian studies beginning one thousand years ago.

A Must-Do in Ha Noi. Arguably the world's first university, the Temple of Literature (great name!) taught Confucian studies beginning about 1000 years ago. Today it's incredibly atmospheric and a not-to-be-missed attraction.

Tranquil Spot in the middle of the Hustle n Bustle. We visited with a guide from Hanoi Kids (great choice!) and thoroughly enjoyed our time here. The history, the architecture, the surrounds all make this a must visit in Hanoi.
Nice. We enjoyed it but perhaps only go to a couple of temples. After a while they all start to look the same - like Bali.

Beautiful place!. Very nice place, specially if you have a guide who can explain and give you further information. The lack of signals and explanations in English can make the tour a little bit disappointing if you go there by yourself.

Ancient Place of Learning. The Temple of Literature was established in 1070, so must rank amongst the oldest universities in the world. It would be well worth while to either read up about the temple before a visit, or to go with a guide. There is so much of significance and so many interesting artefacts that one would bypass if uninformed.Have you ever wondered why the Vietnamese use a Latin script? That came from the time of occupation by the Portuguese. That was just one of the many facts of interest learnt from our guide.The temple has a number of courtyards, all of which have a different significance. Bonsai trees, some of which are over 400 years old, are an attractive feature, as are the colourful and tranquil gardens. The temple is a haven in the midst of Hanoi's frantic traffic.One word of warning: be careful of the very aggressive T-shirt sellers at the entrance to the temple, and don't let them see your money. One woman had her hand in my bag and tried to grab a handful of notes. She became loudly abusive when stopped. The modus operandi seems to be to thrust T-shirts at people and then demand payment. So beware and be aware!

Blown away. We thought this might be a bit intellectual and hard going. What a magnificent asset to this city - a university active and working while the UK was in the dark ages. And what lovely, balanced design. Simply not to be missed.

Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam. I finally found this trip advisor entry - their name bears no relation to to that on the English guide/pamphlet available here.This and the Fine Arts Museum are close together, so you can plan your day around that.This is the site of the first university in Vietnam (was a Confucian place of learning), and still holds significance for current uni graduates it seems. Half a dozen graduates in lovely white dresses were there on a photo shoot; actually we encountered photo shoots for weddings or graduations in similar attractive places we visited in Ha Noi.Entrance fee 20k VND per adult.Highlights:Attractive courtyards, and many bonsai plants.Doctors' stone stelea.Historical items, such as parchments, writing implements, gowns. Important: Walk all the way to the far end courtyard, as few tourists seem to venture there, there are historical items on display, and also go upstairs. Also another food/drink shop.Also, in that area, there was a small auditorium with a small ensemble of women playing traditional instruments as well as singing...the singer had a really beautiful voice. Naturally there were CDs for sale of them, and so now I have a sound track for my travel slide show! All that made this visit worthwhile.FYI, nearby are two "charitable" restaurants, we ate at KOTO (Know One Teach One) which was fine and not expensive, the other Cafe Smile (which we did not see) - both in in Van Mieu St I believe.

Nice and well maintained.. Visited back in 2007, came back again.. still well maintain and really looks good. This time, the tombstones are finally cordoned off lest the possibility of any vandalism.It's a nice break from the noisy roads outside!
Interesting place. The Temple of Literature is interesting but doesn't require much time. Combine it with lunch at Koto, and you've got a nice package.
Quiet in a busy city. Interesting temple and fairly quiet compared to rest of city. Liked structure of the gardens and the wonderful monuments to great students of the past.
Literature temple. Fascinating and picturesque. You can do it in an hour or two then go to HCM Mausoleum where HCM had his house and office.

Well worth a visit. I found Temple of Literature fascinating and would highly recommend. The grounds are beautiful and given that it was built in 1070 - is quite astounding. Also - while there - were quite a few graduating classes there to take photos - which added to the charm.
Importance of learning, several hundred years ago.. Amazing how the Kings of yesteryear cultivated education. Confusious, disciples, sholars, etc. Great architecture.

Worth a visit. This temple was the first university of Viet Nam now it worships King Ly, Chu Van An - a mandarin under Tran dynasty and also a great teacher, Conficius. This complex includes a pond and three beautiful courtyards, enter this site the bustle and hustle Hanoi seems left behind. There are some stone steles carried on back of tortoise, the students usually touch the tortoise's head for the luck before exam. A trip to there with a tour guide is highly recommended.
Nice buildings. The buildings here are nice, and there are some explanations in English.Worth a visit if you have a day or two in Hanoi.

Interesting. It is a trip to the past, you can see carved stones dated in 11th. century, nice building, even when have been rebuilt, wonderful gardens....nothing the Westerns are used to see.It is worth to pay a visit.

Must see in Hanoi!. This is certainly one of the top 3 attractions I've visited in Hanoi. Very traditional atmosphere and if you're lucky you will see some locals taking her graduation pics here, it is a funny experience!
A quiet place in a busy city. It's a nice place to walk around for a bit, especially in Hanoi, where there are more motorbikes than mosquito's
Peacefull place !. It's an important visit to do in Hanoi ; architecture of the place is very interesting and the plaque in English gives all the information you need.

Worth a trip!. This Place was one of the great schools in the past centuries and on 82 steles are in the exam results of state exams and a short biography of the specimens. The temple is the most impotant Confucian sanctuary in Vietnam and I can I have a relaxed take a quiet period in the otherwise quite hectic Hanoi. The building, gardens, art, atmosphere, everything is well coordinated and together make an green oasis in the chaotic Hanoi. The Temple of Literature is one of the highlights of a visit to Hanoi. Worth a trip!
Temple of Literature. An interesting look at an important piece of Vietnamese history revered by the people of Vietnam. The concert using native instruments was particularly interesting.

V interesting - lovely. This was one of my favourite places in Hanoi. Plenty of cultural history, some wonderful temples, shady retreats and perfect for soaking up the Vietnamese atmosphere. Take a camera as there's some lovely highlights. Very interesting.

Peaceful park in the centre of Hanoi. Lots of visitors here with many school groups who were attending graduation ceremonies. Interesting history of Confucious philosophy. Beautiful gardens and well maintained.
A place of solitude. An intimate temple experience, certainly compated to places I have been to in Thailand. A quiet, cool oasis in the centre of Hanoi- well worth a look.

The first university of Hanoi (or Vietnam?). It is a short visit but interesting. I liked all the turtle figures in every corner. The area around the temple is also nice for walk on the sidewalks. Furthermore the citadel is close and you can connect all the main sights in this area in one long day trip. Enjoy. 20.000VD or 10.000VD for students is very fair.
Very nice to visit. It is great to see this temple and to learn about the history. It is nice to know that many students came there

Definitely worth a temple in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature (Van Mieu) is one of the highlights of a visit to Hanoi. It consists of five walled Innenöfen. He was one of the great schools in the past centuries and on 82 steles are in the exam results of state exams and a short biography of the specimens. The temple is the most important Confucian sanctuary in Vietnam and you can have a relaxed take a quiet period in the otherwise quite hectic Hanoi

Interesting bit of history. This temple was a peaceful corner of a busy city. Interesting park setting. It was good to have a guide to explain. Without a guide it would be a curious walk in a park with a Confucian flavor.
