Lovely tranquility and history. We defied epic Hanoi traffic to get here, but it was worth it - plus an interesting walk. Lovely, tranquil grounds, gorgeous buildings and impressive, interesting artifacts. We went on Children's Day, so there was a dance performance.

Nice touch. A great place to learn more about history of education in Vietnam. Although the temple itself is not really ancient, the story surrounded as well as history of stele is very interesting. Like it
Well kept. It was more than what I expected and well preserved especially for the entrace price which is very cheapMake sure to visit the neighbouring shops especially Craft Link and eat at koto.

Great buildings and gardens. Although the place itself is great the organization is just a bit too messy.I can honestly say it is one of the most unique places in Hanoi and very peaceful although your in the middle of the city. The only thing is that things seem a bit run down and the entertainment level is very low.

Interesting place, nice gardens!. Nice gardens, but unfortunately when I went it was raining a lot and the place tends to get flooded.Be careful walking the grounds because it tend to be slippery on the adobe tiles. Great statues throughtout but you need a knowledgeable guide who could explain and narrate the history behind the altars, statues and art found here. Very reasonable price for admission. Folkloric musicians gather on the mini auditorium located at the back of the property to play some traditional instruments. There were a couple of ladies there playing and it sounded very nice!Had a nice, energetic guide who didn't rush me at all.
Temple of Literature in Hanoi. Temple of Literature is considered the first university in Vietnam and it was built in 11th century. It’s a nice place to visit when you've arrived Hanoi. Don’t miss it

centre of learning. it is great for people who study Confucius and his teachings.it is a very old institution ,just maintained well enough to visit in present time.but very less info on this for public other than i gathered from my guide Mr. wind, who is a very young and eager man,
Tranquil and stunning. Bring some time to walk around the gardens and explore the temple, guides will only rush you through...

Well preserved temple and great sight seeing spot. The temple is a great place to visit. The structures are well maintain and plenty of history to look for. Inside the main temple houses many famous Chinese scholars statue.
Must visit this place when in Hanoi.
Highlight of Hanoi. Its large, take your time to visit. Read about it before you go. Respect the local culture. Best time to visit is early morning of late evening. Around midday, many groups.

Great history. A beautiful temple area to visit. The buildings are very old, being the oldest university in Vietnam. A pleasure just to stroll liesurly around and to see some of the ancient graduates lists among the grounds. Allow a couple of hours to see completely. Within walking distance from the old quarter also.

Charming spot in downtown Hanoi. Quite a beautiful place. Admittedly most of it was reconstructed in the 2000's but it has a nice feel about it.
If you are not vietnamse you will have to pay extra on the entrance fee. An all to common practice in South East Asia.

It's more of a temple than a university.. Interesting to know that temple was built with philosophers and ancient teachers to pray for. Steleas were built in different sizes not because one teacher was greater that the other but because of the financial status of the region when it was being built. Most students still come here to pray for exam success.
Good to see. It's not a must see if you have seen other temples/pagodas... However it is in a very good shape and it is interesting.

An Old Learning Relic to Visit. Great place to see the history of education through the ages in Vietnam. I t is crowded but good. you will get accosted by hawkers as you enter and leave the attraction.

Average in terms of things to see, but historically very important.. Lots of walking and average amounts of seeing. The only explanation of the place we got was about the tablets of graduates from the high exams in ancient times. What's amazing is the historical significance of these exams. Only about 1300 graduates (passed the exam) over the course of more than 300 years. 86 exams during that time, so about 1 exam every 4 years. This equals to only around 15 grads every 4 years. The best of the best of the country were here. Amazing huh?

Small yet interesting. The temple of literature is like a Confucius temple. I have seen much grander ones in China and Taiwan. But considering that Vietnam was a satellite state of China in the past, naturally their temples will also be of a smaller scale. But what was interesting is the cultural significance of the place and you can tell how much Chinese culture have influenced the Vietnamese in many ways of their life.

The best museum we've to yet. No political statement, just history!. It's right out of the Forbidden City. Similar look, great expanses, cool historical monuments, nice ponds, beautiful pagoda, and no obnoxious crowd of ugly anything. In all, a great place to go for $1 a person. And eat on the next block.

Hidden Oasis in Hanoi. This is a great place for a bit of a peaceful rest. A lovely temple, especially if you appreciate flower arrangements.It is very historic and with quite beautiful buildings.The entry tickets was so seasonable, take photos is accepted,this complex is well worth your while.It is an oasis of calm in a crazy city. I would go back here for the peace and quiet!

Visit here early, then cross the road for a lunch at Koto!. Having visited the same outside of Beijing, it was fascinating to see the same traditional layout. Very clean and easy to move around,the Garden of Stele was impressive. I learned that the highest exams were conducted by the king himself, the last ones occurring in the early 1900's.

Pretty but not on a rainy day. The temple is quite pretty but nfortunately the weather wasn't the best when we went. Little indoor space so not ideal. Ok for a look round on a sunny afternoon but equally not a big miss i you don't have time to go.
Nothing much to see. This plc can be placed as one of yr itenarary if u r staying in hanoi for more than 3 days...but d temple US quite beautiful..
Tranquility. Loved the heritage factor, the peace, the tranquility, the ambiance. Interesting history, the signs in flowers....great place for a bit of a peaceful rest.
Ancient University. Quite good, lots of tourists (not so good). Would rate the Imperial Citadel in Hue more highly, but the comparison is not a fair one I guess.

A nice temple, especially for flower lovers.. A lovely temple, especially if you appreciate flower arrangements.While not that much to see on the site, the mare tranquil nature of the temple is a blessing in Hanoi's chaotic traffic.It'll take you apx. 1-1.5 hours to explore the temple, which could be too hot around noon, so you are better of visiting the temple in the afternoon.
An oasis in the craziness of Hanoi.. This is a lovely, tranquil place. it is very historic and with quite beautiful buildings. We used a map to walk here from the old quarter.

Must see in Hanoi. We really enjoyed this visit with our guide and learned a lot. The place is very beautifull and serene. We were lucky that there weren't too many visitors so we could enjoy and take nice pictures.
Not spectacular. We liked the rock turtles but it lacks the quietness a temple of literature should have. The pagodas are nice. One even has Ho Chi Mihn in place of Buda.

Historic for sure and quite a lot to see. There were quite a lot of interesting sights at this site. For one, the symbol of Hanoi (the signature gate-like structure) is located here and the turtle steles with the names of past scholars. Having said that, I probably wouldn't have visited this place if it's not part of a group tour. It's pretty hard to travel around without being wary of taxi scams anyway so going for a group tour probably gives you a peace of mind. APT Travel, the agency that handled my tour is a safe bet.
Avoid visit on wet days. It was raining when we were there so hard to appreciate, but a tranquil place if it wasnt for all the tour groups!

Very beautiful place to visit and find out the part of Vietnam history. My girl friend and i been there while staying in Hanoi. That was a great time for us to join in the old architecture of house and traditional music concert. You have to visit literature when come to Hanoi as my first visit time. The entry tickets was so seasonable, take photos is accepted. We felt very comfortable and will come back if have reason visit Hanoi in the not far future.

Tranquil Oasis. Calm and tranquil, the Temple of Literature is a little oasis in hectic Hanoi. The cool courtyards lead towards a temple honouring Confucius, where people still seek blessings and light incense. The entire area pays homage to education and educators and has some interesting bits of information about the site which used to house Vietnam’s first national university.

Good place to spend a few hours. I went in the afternoon, it was nice, not too crowded. However, it is not labelled as the Temple of Literature but called something else. There could be more signage in English and I felt that unless you were walking about with a copy of the Lonely Planet it did not give you an insight into the history. Otherwise very good place to spend a few hours in Hanoi. Not advisable to walk there unless you really like to walk like I did!
literature. very nice temple and quite place to study. the temple is very big and reflects chinese power in vietnam. we found a traditional music concert also.

Beautiful Serene Temple in the Heart of a Bustling City. Magnificent manicured gardens, colourful stupas and blossoms, magnificent temples, this complex is well worth your while.It is an oasis of calm in a crazy city. Spacious and open with nice shaded areas to sit and relax. I preferred the exterior, garden area but most people go for the temple which I can understand because it is very beautiful. The entry ticket is so cheap too, I can't think of any reason why you shouldn't go. Look, it won't change your life or anything, but it is very pleasant and if I ever went back to Hanoi, I would go back here for the peace and quiet!
Great for local music. Interesting place to visit but a bit same same. Local music played live which was great to hear being played up so close
This should be on your itinerary for Hanoi. Impressive site, not to be missed when you visit Hanoi. Visit with a guide so you can get some explanation.
very interesting. one of the places to go. dont think there wasnt anything i did'nt like about it.. its like any new place, have to see it
Beautiful. The landscape here was magnificent and it is very calm inside. Was nice to get to know a bit of history of the place and exploring the grounds. Worth a visit.

Hidden Oasis. Such a beautiful, clean and well-kept place. The grounds were immaculate and historical. When you need to get out of the hustle and bustle of Hanoi this is the place to come, it is peaceful and beautiful. (Follow up your visit here with a lunch at Koto - 5 minute walk from the entrance)
the besst in Hanoi. the architecture. the sofisticated gardens, the peaceful. All in this place is nice . for me, one of the best places to visit it in Hanoi

Nice place to spend a few hours. This was a nice peaceful place to spend the afternoon away from the craziness of Hanoi. When we went there it was graduation day and there were loads of students having their photos taken. All the girls were dressed in their Ao Dais and looked so beautiful, especially with cape and mortar board on top. I'd say it was worth a visit.

A humbling experience. As a teacher I found this a very humbling experience as so much respect is shown to education and to teachers at this place and in the history of education in Vietnam. Education in the wider sense includes music and spirituality and it was evident everywhere. On occasions I have heard music performances and the ambience is wonderful. Some of the players who play here also perform with the water puppets in the city
Wonderful place. We went here with the Hanoi Kids. It is an amazing building. There was a concert inside with very unique and interesting instruments. Our Hanoi kids were great tour guides.
Peaceful. Lots of history and, unlike some Hanoi museums, information boards. However, worth a visit just for the peace and quiet!
Turtles and incense. Going to the Temple of Literature makes one feel as if there is some contact to authentic Vietnamese culture.
very interesting place. very peaceful (if you come early) and to be seen in Hanoi. the place is a peaceful confucius temple in the city centre.

Set Among Beautiful Grounds. Temple of Literature is a must see. The garden areas are quite beautiful and there are numerous trees that are quite old. The Chinese influence for this university/temple is quite obvious and the emphasis on education is seen throughout. They allow pictures of all the statues in the buildings but remember to be respectful as people do come to pray. Remove your hat when inside the buildings. i think it is sad that it is no longer a functioning university, you wonder what the current universities are like. This was the first place I actually had hawkers try to sell me something at the entrance but they were not persistent after you said no, unlike other places (Thailand, Cambodia) where you are hounded constantly.

Boring. Maybe this place would have been more interesting with a guide, but we went by ourselves and there were very little English signs to explain what we were looking at. The stone turtles were the most intersting thing about the Temple. If you have limited time in Hanoi, I would just skip it.

Very interesting!. This is a place filled with history. It is essential to have a good guide (or read up on the place) before visiting. The buildings and surroundings are both interesting and beautiful, but the place has much more to offer. Plan no less than an hour for the visit. The history behind the Temple of Literature proves my theory right to a point, as I have long claimed that while we were trying to carve a wheel here in the west, they had advanced education in the far east........This place was high on my "what to see in Hanoi" list, and I do not regret the visit.
Very beautiful. Worth a visit and a wander around to understand some of the history of learning and study in Vietnam.

Good but not stunning. Was nice place to visit And it was interesting to learn about the history off the university in Vietnam, I found there was enough in English, tho I did purchase a guide leaflet on the way in

a taste of ancient China. for those who never visited a Chinese temple, this is a nice example of one. Roofs, red-painted doors, statues, ... clearly one of the hot spot of Hanoi. No more than one hour visit

Good play in the center of Hanoi. A good play to visit in the center of Hanoi. You could have a chance to discover the long history of Vietnam and its education. This is the first University which was establish in 1000s.A good place to visit and discover

Seen better in other Asian countries. The temple was pretty, but little more than that. It was interesting to see because it IS Vietnam's first university, but there was very little information available in English and the amount of space allotted to selling touristy trinkets was disappointing.If you only have a couple of days in Hanoi, don't make this one a top priority.

Great to discover Vietnamese Culture. Temple of Literature is so beautiful and the garden here is lovely. If you lucky, you will see young Student women wearing traditional ao dai, this is really charming tradition dress.

tick the box. it seems like they shunt bus loads of tourists through this place at a cracking pace. the concept of literature hundreds of years old, engraved on stone tablets is amazing, but the place itself crawling with obtuse tourists was a bit distracting. of course, i spent a few hours walking there on foot, and it was blazingly hot at midday, so perhaps the serenity was lost on me...
Interesting. We watched the local children sing How wonderful that this is not just a dusty old relic and actually used for purpose. Music demonstration interesting and relaxing
Get a Guide. Temple and oldest University in Vietnam. Bring sunscreen or an umbrella during summer. Go early in the morning to beat the crowds.
nice place to visit. nice place to visit in Hanoi which i would recommend to friends, family, couples etc. take your camera and a smile :)
Maybe I just didnt get it. We visited the temple and to be honest I wasnt very impressed, yes it looks lovely but maybe I just didnt really get it but I was expecting something more.

Must see in Hanoi. One of Hanoi's must-see historical landmarks. This Chinese-Vietnamese style temple complex dates from the 14th century and gives you an nice introduction to Vietnamese culture.
The turtle shaped stelae with the names of all the graduates of the past 600 years are quite spectacular.
Temple and gardens. we arrived here on the day before the national entrance exam for university, so it was packed with students wanting good luck. Worth a visit...pretty grounds.
A tranquil place in the center of a buzzling city. We had lots of fun taking pictures with Vietnamese students in their school uniforms celebrating their graduation

An icon for the Vietnamese. This 1000 year old temple is regarded by the Vietnamese as the cultural centre of Hanoi. The buildings are well preserved and the grounds are appropriately maintained. The temple does show the close links that Vietnamese culture had with Chinese Confucianism, though the Vietnamese often seem unaware of that.From a tourist perspective it is a questionnable attraction. If you have not been to China then it may be of interest. If you have been to China, don't bother going. The crowds, traffic problems and general lack of interpretation can make it an unprofitable experience. Whatever you do, avoid it on a weekend or a public holiday. The locals will overwhelm you.
Worth a visit. Nice visit with a beautiful history. Let a guide show you around, as we did, because there is so much history and you can feel walking through the temple.

Good place with literaturical importance!. It is quite interesting to see the place where Confucious started the first university. There is not much to explore. If you visit the place, please enquire about a chinese artist who writes scrolls in chinese symbols, You can make him write your name along with any symbol. It is interesting and he charges just 2 dollars.
Very beautifull and quiet.. In the hectic city of Hanoi, the Temple of Literature is a nice quiet spot. But as most of the sights in Vietnam, there were no signs in English, to enlighten us...

A serene place to walk round. This only takes (maiximum) an hour but is worth seeing, just to appreciate where Confuscious started the first University for mandarins/scholars. Made up of various low pagodas and divided by brick pathways and grassy areas, this area was where thousands of students came to take their exams. A few decent souvenir stalls line the complex.

Worth a quick visit due to historical importance. This is apparently Vietnam's oldest university and worth a visit being dedicated to Confucious. There was not much to explore from an architectural perspective. Other than the statues of Confucious and his four students inside the main altar, there is a small pond - legend is that this was used to screen out students with bad intentions. Some stone tablets carry the names of university toppers from those years as a means to preserve their achievements.

Interesting History. We were here in July, and it was extremely hot, and there isn't much shade here. Lots of history here, and the architecture is amazing. You don't need to spend long here - maybe an hour. Worth heading here just before or after lunch as there is a brilliant restaurant on the road near called Koto, where they help street/disadvantaged children learn new skills and how to cook/serve/work in a restaurant. You pay above normal prices here, but the food was amazing and all the profits of the restaurant go back to helping more kids learn.

It was raining and it made us rush. Perhaps a good thing. The best thing about the temple of Literature is the great restaurant nearby. Koto Restaurant is this amazing idea where street kids are taught and employed in the arts of the restaurant. The foods great too!

A short dive into history. A great little piece of culture in the middle of Hanoi. We paid $20,000 (1 USD) to get in and read about the many teachings of Confucius. This attraction is worth a visit, but I would not go out of my way to see it. A nice half day trip with KOTO for lunch across the road.

One of the better temples in Hanoi. Beautiful gardens, courtyards and pools with multiple temple buildings, pagodas and walkways.We particularly enjoyed the bell and drum towers at the very back of the complex.
To me, nothing much to see. Love the traditional music performance. The Tour guide was lousy. We could not understand his English at all.

Lots to see worth a look. Another very friendly place mingling with locals ended up in other peoples pictures as well as some interesting things to read and just check out, a couple hours dissapeared .Good alternative to shopping.

Not exceptional but since there is so little to see in Hanoi.... For 20,000 VND you enter this temple where young privileged scholars would study back in the days (5 centuries ago or so). No need for a guide really. Bits of garden which is enjoyable since the temple is surrounded by noisy and polluted large streets. The central lake is on notes of 100,000 VND - fun fact. Every scholar has his stelea with a little turtle head - a symbol of longevity. Overall it's a nice tour since culturally speaking Hanoi is relatively poor and if there is something you must see while you're there is this temple.

Education in Old Hanoi. The place is unique, the buildings are awesome, and the gardens alone is worth the trip. I like the beauty and value of the place where you can see the Philosophies of Confucious written in flowers all over the gardens.
Amazing history. If your in education this is a not miss. Try to go during lunch when there are less people. Guides will help make this more memorable
Serene temple. Bonsai is wonderful, so are the massive stone turtles. a serene spot in the midst of a bustling city.
Great peek into Vietnamese people and their history.. Great explanations. Nice place to spend a long, quiet afternoon.

Thanks for wasting my time!. 500+ reviews and it has four stars? Are you kidding? There’s nothing to see!! It’s a poorly maintained park full of trash and a bunch of tacky souvenir shops. We saw a few signs but nothing’s in English. I want my dollar back!

Beautiful temple in garden setting. This temple to learning and literature has many old buildings of beautiful design in a delightful, formal style garden. Although quite busy with tourists and graduating students when I was there, it has an air of tranquility. There was also a beautiful performance of traditional Vietnamese music in one of the temples.

Beautiful scenery for a stroll. This is a great setting to go for a relaxing stroll if there weren't so many visitors. The Temple of Literature is basically a long rectangular park in the middle of the city with a stone wall surrounding it and cutting off the noise from the motorbikes. There is a typical Vietnamese temple in the park, along with a reflecting pond, bonsai trees, regular-sized trees, flowers, decorative shrubbery, and statues. Oh, and don't forget the people - it was very crowded, especially in the more confined spaces like the temple. But it's so scenic that it's easy to overlook the crowds.You can enjoy this sight even without knowing the historical significance of everything inside it. Definitely check it out while you are in Hanoi.

A beautiful setting and fabulous history. It really helps to have an English speaking guide. There is so much symbolism throughout the Temple that we would have missed a great deal if we had not had help.Our student guides took time to stop and pray for good exam results. I hope it works.Each courtyard has meaning and the whole complex has developed over the centuries, each building has special significance. Temple to Confucious is magnificent and the staircase in the Kings' building is one to remember.For me the defining moment was seeing the stellae, inscribed with the names of those who achieved their doctorate.
Best sight in Hanoi. Beautiful setting very interesting and a nice break from the mad rush.

A place to dream. It was boiling hot but you must go here to appreciate the life long importance placed on education in this country. I was hoping my kids would pray along with the locals for good academic results. The old trees are also something to see. Wow.

926 years of beauty and asian culture.. Imagine a tree-lined shady avenue which opens in what is apparently asian architecture and lacquered deep red pillars; well this is so much more..it's like a combination of garden and square basins covered by large waterlilies, which was established in 1076 in honor to Confucius and cultured scholars, notably mandarins. When these guys got a degree, their name was placed on marble slabs hung on turtle-shaped stands in the garden, and there are so many! We may well consider this place a campus of nine hundreds ago, like the Oxford of Asia. Well worth a visit!1
Beautiful. This is a stunning piece of history. So beautiful. The only downside was it was so humid when we visited we nearly melted before we finished! Well worth a visit though.

A must!!. Take the time to visit this temple for its history goes back to 1010.
It does show a bit of the far back roots of Vietnam which we seem to forget due to its more active recent history.

Serene place of learning. This Confucian Temple has been home to scholars for many centuries. We were lucky enough to be there when University students were graduating there. Classic layout and gardens. The styles honouring scholars are most impressive.

Just another Buddish temple, but focused on educational achievement. The only special thing about this accessible temple is that it is of great historical and current meaning for students in Vietnam. They come there to pray to Confucius for good results. Hopefully, they don't put all there hopes on this and supplement it with good studying, but it give an interesting site to observe...

Amazing. Liked the turtle/herron pairs and the bit turtles with the lists of scholars... we did hear that a lot of the buildings were pretty seriously 'rennovated' (i.e. almost total replicas) but it was beautiful nonetheless!

Nice day out. The temple of literature has beautiful gardens to walk through. It is well maintained. It only costs about a dollar US to get in so worth it to walk around, especially if still a student. Make sure to see the old man at the back who appears to be giving advice to young Vietnamese students using old school ink on parchment. Impossible to stay more than 1 hour here though.

Fascinating and attractive. As our son is very interested in Confucius we couldn't miss a trip to this historic university of Confucianism. We were not disappointed. The guides were fantastic - they spoke English well, gave enough information in an interesting way without over-doing it, and always had answers to any question! We found it to be a peaceful, attractive little haven in noisy, busy Hanoi.
Nothing much to see. Pass by if you are around, but don't go out of your way
Very nice and impressive. In this place you can feel peace & know many things about history of Vietnam, the learning tradition and many scholars whose knowledge makes anyone of us admire

Beautiful architecture. The entire place takes you back in time, the buildings and sculptures are very well kept. Beautiful and peaceful place, as well as interesting due to the history of its foundation.

Great Temple. Once again second time here, and mentioned you need a good English Guide to explain, as you miss too much of what this Temple is all about. After a tour of here make sure you to to KOTO Restaurant, great food and where street kids are give an opportunity to learn all about hospitality.
The history of education in Vietnam. This place is about the birth of the national university and education in this country in the early days.

Amazing place. I was very pleased to visit this place, but felt a lack of information available on site. I purchased the leaflet, but many sculptures had no explanations. I would like to know more about the site "on site".
Serene and informative. This was a good place to be toward the end of the day as it was so serene and there was a beautiful recital by the local musicians in progress.
Beautiful place. Lot's of history and beautiful sight to visit if you're in Hanoi

if you're into history. If you like history you will learn a lot from this temple. It's very beautiful and unique. A lot of turtle statue, which is considered to be sacred by the local, and considered bad luck if you touch its head. This place can get really crowded, sometimes before the examination you can see students come and pray and this temple to get good results.

A must do in Hanoi. We went with Hanoikids to visit this temple. Interesting to learn about Confucian and the former education of Vietnam. The guides of Hanoikids were knowledgeable about the local area and cordial.

Worth a visit. Very interesting temple that can be walked too from most parts of central Hanoi. It gets very busy with locals and tourists and just watching the locals ignore all the warnings to touch the many tortoise heads is fun (apparently it is good luck to touch the turtle heads)Inexpensive to visit and a must on any tour of Hanoi

the best place I've visited in Hanoi. The title says it all: if you are interested in Vietnamese culture and history, you MUST visit the Temple of Literature. It's really impressive and free of charge.

Historic but under maintained. This is an old structure and while beautiful in grounds and setting; architecture and nostalgia, I think that the walls and could use a little paint job, but charming none the less. Surprisingly we say a few graduates taking pictures in their convocation gowns while on the premise. Education is indeed key to greater enlightenment

Temple of knowledge. My friends and I recently visited Northern Vietnam... overall, we were disappointed with the trip, but the Temple of Literature was one of our highlights. The place was very colorful, clean, and quiet, and just a lovely afternoon. Also, it had vendors inside selling everything from books to ice cream. Especially, there's an interesting tree just to one's left upon entering the place. I didn't know how old it was but it's large and the root system seems to have grown above the ground. John, our guide, was really helpful. He provided us a lot of interesting information about the temple's history. His explainations gave us a thorough idea about the place. There was only one negative fact, that were some ladies just outside the temple who were pretty pushy about selling their postcards, but other than that...no complaints! I highly recommend checking it out.

Temple. It gets VERY crowded and busy so go early if you are going to go as the queue for tickets gets crazy. Basically a few outbuildings and a huge suspended drum at the end. Some stone tablets carved into turtles backs.
Best to go with a guide. There is very little english translation at this temple, so I would recommend going with a guide to get the most out of this important site.
Well worth a visit. Quite a lot to see here. Went with one of the Hanoi kids whocould explain about things which made it more enjoyable.

Good day trip. This is part of the Hanoi city tour must see attraction. With so many tour buses coming in and out make sure you come early. If not consider it a treat that there are large tour groups around and you can just eaves drop on the history lessons. That's what we did.
Incredible scenery. Place, which reminds us about long history of Vietnam
Centre of learning. Loved the serene, respectful atmosphere and the cultural respect for learning.

short respite. this is a pleasant break from the noise and bustle of town, really nice to wander around. When I was there some women were playing music on original instruments which was lovely. It took me around an hour to stroll through. Lovely trees and the old buildings are very nice.The toilets were clean too!
Well worth a visit...get a guide. We visited in June with 2 children and 2 adults. Our guide was lovely and well worth the extra money. A highlight of our trip to Hanoi.

Definitely worth the walk. I walked here from the old quarter - took around 30 minutes dawdling along looking at stuff on the street. Really interesting old building with much history. Definitely worth a look!
Temple. Very interesting ..Chinese culture...Enjoyed the Buddahs and ambiance of it all

Mmmm...ok. Right - perhaps I was not in right frame of mind. But ut really is another temple...I know some people are irate reading this. But I guess i will have to go back. Pity signage is not in English as well...but that is me being snobby.

A Green Pond. I've travelled China and seen some of the most beautiful temples it has to offer. I thought this would be another to add to my list and I was sadly disappointed. The Temple is very well kept, but so are most botanical gardens and at least they're free. Worth a miss.

Well maintained. I was impressed at how well maintained the Temple of Literature is. Decorated with flowers, it was filled with people worshipping Confucius and his 4 accompanying disciples. Lovely courtyard with a set of water puppets to photograph. There are some souvenir shops inside.
The temple of Confusious a must see. Loved this place even more so with a guide, they explain a whole lot more that what you see. Go with Hanoikids they are very knowledgable.

Historic and atmospheric. Worth seeing especially if one is a history buff.
The locals visit to get inspired and for good luck in their studies.
ok. A thousand year old university with ponds and temple to please.

Beautiful place in the city. The Temple took almost a whole block. You walk in a linear fashion to see everything from start to finish. However, didn't need to buy a pamphlet as it costs 80,000D which I thought the ticket booth lady said 8,000D. My bad, but I bought it anyway. There's enough information plastered around on signs that you didn't need a guide or a pamphlet. Big bells and a big drum were cool. As were the old turtle statues and shrines of Confucius and the other vietnamese scholar. Beautiful place right in the city.
tourist hotspot more than temple. it has nothing much inside but it costs you 20,000 dong for the entrance.
must-see in Hanoi. current entrance fee is 20k dong. well-visited by locals praying for good luck in exams. temple generally well-maintained.

A key Hanoi attraction. This temple is Vietnam 1st university and essentially Chinese in architecture. Was brought to the attraction by the HanoiKids, who hosted our us on a day trip. If not for them, it's just another heritage temple to most foreign visitors as there are not much write-up (if any) on the premise.So it's better to have a guide to better enjoy the temple and understand its significance. Local university students flock to the temple prior important exams to seek divine blessing for good grades via one entrance and exit via another. Most have to touch the head of turtle stone sculptures (which have been cordoned off during our visit). There are calligraphy sessions for visitors to savour the skill of the artisans. The schedule can be confirmed on the site.Good to spend within 1 hour to cover the venue.

Ancient learning. The Stele and the history they tell of learning and achievement make one wonder how Europeans and northern races managed to get to where they are today when most war still barely civilised the people of Vietnam had universities and graduation ceremonies. The gardens are peaceful and one can feel the history all around
Chinese culture in Vietnam. An important historic relic in Vietnam and touted as the 1st university in Vietnam which had trained scholars for the country for hundreds of years

Beautiful view, service could be improved. This is a beautiful location, with wonderful flower arrangements, and splendid architechture. There could be more information on what was going on here, or a tour guide on site (All tour guides had to be organised externally or through the hotel), which was a big let down for me.

Nice place, but skip it if your time is limited. Having visited Hanoi several times, I would say the city as a whole is definitely worth visiting. However, I think most short term visitors would be better off skipping Van Mieu (as the Vietnamese call it). The same goes for many other of the city's "attractions." Hanoi is a city for taking in the atmosphere. Do sit down for coffee at a quaint place in the old quarter, sample the local street food and draft beer (bia hoi), stroll around Hoan Kiem lake while senior citizens are doing Tai Qi, love birds are holding hands, students are reading books and youngsters are playing badminton. Hanoi is not a city for sightseeing. Its monuments and museums can be pleasant and interesting. But to be honest they are generally modest and unimpressive compared to what you would find in many other historic Asian cities (i.e. Shanghai, Beijing, Yangon, Kyoto, Bangkok, etc.)In a nutshell, Van Mieu is a small, historic, temple-like compound with some gardens, pavilions and altars. Tour books may point out that the site was founded as a Confucian academy 1,000 years ago, but like many places in Vietnam, it has suffered from harsh weather conditions, war and until recently, neglect (the original architectural planning has been maintained, but many of the buildings you see are relatively recent reconstructions. )If you have several days in Hanoi, by all means visit because its very near the city center and the admission is cheap. But don't bother if you only have a few days, don't bother .

We didn't stay long. It was nice to walk around the temple and the gardens but there wasn't really much to keep us here for long. We walked from the Mausoleum which was a bit hot and busy but ok. If we did it again I'd get a taxi.

Gorgeous.... That is Hanoi... in this city, there are still many ancient buildings surrounded by modern ones. This temple is so beautiful. It's worth to pay the entrance fee and to walk inside the temple area. Many visitors and school students visit this place. Good spot to take pics.
Peace in a busy city!. Worth paying the entrance fee just for some peace and quiet... and empty pavements!
Amazing culture and history. A must see, you could spend hours here, so much to explore, see and do

Back to school. The Temple of Literature is a well conserved old temple complex with a lot of recollections of former students and professors of this “Confucius-school”. On several places Chinese capitals indicate the qualities a student needs. One Chinese character that fascinates me is the “Thai”, the sign that stands for Talent. It reminded me of the fact that talent is something you have to work for.In the last part of the temple a traditional musicgroup was playing. It was impossible to enjoy the music because they kept asking to buy a cd.And after the long stroll through the temple... On Van Mieu Street are some streetpubs where you can have a draft beer Bia Hoi: sit and enjoy the street.
The first university in SE Asia..... Great architecture and beautiful grounds. This site has such important historical value.

Good history & serene surroundings. We had a tour guide from Legend Indochina travel, who spoke good English and could explain the history behind this. It was marvellous to see young men and women (in au dai) who have just graduated from uni taking photos at this location - how apt!
Interesting.. Nice place to visit, we went early in the morning since we didn't have much time before we had to leave. The place was also filled with lots of students. Really nice to see.

impressing. Must see, very interesting, With a good guide you learn a lot about history and Vietnamese education system. There is a nice garden with bonsai's in the form of animals from zodiac calendar.

Lovely gardens. Enjoyed looking around here but I really liked the huge book made out of flowers. We had a guide here but unfortunately she was very young and not very informative I feel I did not get as much as I should have out of it. But very glad we went.

One of the highlights of the Hanoi city tour. On the Hanoi city tour a stop at the Temple of literature is programmed. The guide informs you about the history of the institute, starting in the 11th century, and the severe regime and strict requirements were in place to complete a study. The complex is divided into numerous courtyards, connected with decorated gates and beautiful buildings. It is a pleasure to stroll through the courtyards and let history envelop you. To be recommended.

Check out the doctoral degrees. I enjoyed the tour of this university and temple. It was originally established in 1076. The gardens are lovely. The altars were spectacular. The event was a cultural experience for me because many of the visitors laid money at the foot of the altars and prayed. I have a picture of the roof with money scattered across it. That would never happen in the United States (someone would snatch it for sure). The only problem I had was the ticket vendor tried to take 200,000 d out of my hands when the entrance fee was only 20,000 d. As an aside, you have to pay 1,000 d to use the restroom.

Sit down and feel the history and atmosphere of this place. This place is truly a dont miss. It is one courtyard opening onto another courtyard, that are all beautifully gardened with very old buildings. The architecture of these buildings was a beautiful sight. They have built newer buildings over and around to protect some of the historic features. But unless you were told about this you would never had known as they were built in exactly the same style as the very old buildings.To sit down and feel the atmosphere and history of this place was very relaxing and peaceful.We were lucky as we were with 2 young uni students (from Hanoi Kids group) who knew every detail about this place. And we fullly came to understand the history of it.
Beautiful. Amazing gardens and architecture and loved the musical performance.

A hide away from the hustle and bustle. A really relaxing place with a kind of meditative feel to it. Quite unbelievable that this place was built so long ago. The buildings are still in such good condition and the architecture is really impressive. A lovely place to escape and take a little walk around.

Amazing. This place was truly a beautiful place to escape the heat and pace of Hanoi. The beautiful temples and the landscaping of the gardens was truly beautiful. Worth the visit..just go early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

a visit to the past.. It is more like a chinese temple. Crowded. Must go on a day when there is no crowd. I would have spent more time and enjoyed the Temple of Litrature on a day with less tourists and locals.

Worth a visit. This was a fascinating place with courtyard after courtyard giving a good appreciation of what it was like to gain an education so many years ago (it opened in 1070). Be careful of the souvenir sellers on the gate though, they're quite aggressive.
Beautiful. What a great place to visit. Peaceful and beautiful. Highly recommend

university built in 1070. full of youth & wonderment. A must if you're into architecture & history. Image..built in 1070 & still full to crowded with 100's of young people, studying for there own degrees, getting their inspitation from the surroundings. Marvellous place.

This is an oasis in the city. The temple shows why Vietnamese have such a tradition of learning. How refreshing to see high honors for people that were outstanding scholars! The gardens are beautiful and cool when the city is sweltering.

Beautiful old university let down by tacky hawking. This was a fascinating old university now museum to the intellectual endeavours of the Vietnamese elite from centuries ago. Beautifully restored and maintained, the buildings a re a delight to walk around in. Something that would be useful would be a translation of some of the tablets that outlined the achievements of graduates from the university. Unless you can read Chinese, they are indecipherable, which is a shame as it would give you further insight into what was clearly a rigorous academic culture for so long ago. One thing that did let this attraction down, however, was the presence of tacky souvenir stands and hawkers (even one women who had parked herself and her wares underneath a sign out the front that warned people off for buying and selling goods at that location!). It was unecessary and definitely detracted from what was a very interesting and pretty peaceful experience.

can be skipped if you're pressed for time. I was expecting more considering that this is one of the top attractions in Hanoi. The temple, however, looked very ordinary. If not for its history, it would not be interesting at all. Still, the grounds are well kept and the courtyard ideal for picture-taking.

Great to see where Confusio worked!. Peaceful, full of history and meaningful for Vietnamese, this is one of the places they feel proud of, and they're right. Bargaining with T-shirts sellers, fruits sellers, hut sellers to get into the Museum takes time and energy, but still is an interesting experience for those not familiar to this culture.

A glimpse of China's influence in Vietnamese Culture. If you liked the Emperor's Summer Palace in Beijing, you'll feel right at home in Vietnam's oldest university. The Chinese influence is obvious, but this university has become a culteral focus for education in Vietnam. As you tour the grounds there is a feeling of relaxation and renewal that is impossible to describe to thse who haven't experienced it. This may be why every graduating student in Vietnam visits this site before they begin their chosen career.

A true testament to knowledge. This is a place of history that makes you wrestle with your per-conceptions. This is a beautiful place created a thousand years ago as a way to mark knowledge and learning. It is a gorgeous setting and a marvelous place to slow down and absorb and to contemplate the flow of time and the march of experience.
Inspiring. The culture and the history has been retained and despite being ancient it is still relevant today

Gorgeous!. This exquisite example of traditional Vietnamese architecture is set in beautiful gardens and was a gem to visit. We went on a Saturday, when many Vietnamese also visit, and were treated to some wonderful classical music. We also saw many young Vietnamese women dressed up in traditional costume coming to have their photos taken!

Nice. Nice, not outstanding. If you spend in Hanoi more than 2-3 days of course you have to visit this place. In my opinion nothing impressive, I was honestly expecting something more, but still worth it a short visit.Don't buy the informative book at the entrance if you already have a guide, ie Lonley Planet. The lady at the ticket office cheats on the change, count the money as soon as she gives it to you before leaving.
Good to se how was the first university in Vietnam. special site of culture and literature, a world apart and the ancient culture and history of education in Vienam.
hard to describe. this kind of history just has to be seen..... well worth the visit.
Very interesting. Take your time. Best done with a guide and plenty of time.

Beautiful old architecture. One of the rare successful reservations in Hanoi. Good for short sight seeing, photo taking & Vietnam education history exploring.If you have chance, visit here during Tet holiday (2-3/1 Lunar New Year) and you will be able to watch human chess, shu-fa and some other festival activities.
Okay. We weren't that impressed with the Temple. I would suggest to go if you can, but if you must cut something from your list this may be it.

Did not disappoint. This site did not disappoint...from the Great Portico entrance to the last Hall in the complex. The various gates, halls, statuary, courtyards and especially the Garden of the Stelae exceeded expectations. What I did not expect was added experience of Vietnamese enjoying this lovely site. At the Temple of Literature we saw a number of couples having their engagement and wedding photos taken, a group of young girls taking turns (and giggling the entire time) with two very tall American teenagers, elderly men playing checkers and other every day happenings. For the shoppers, there is a wonderful little gift shop to the left in the Courtyard of the Sages (courtyard past the pond - Well of Heavenly Clarity)

Confucious. Respect for Talent - the architecture & sculptures.
Directly opposite was the Koto restaurant where street kids
are taught and trained in hospitality. Good food - worth a visit.

Nice gardens, peace and quiet. Well cared for, small entrance fee is charged then you access the long grounds. Interesting historical attraction.
Locals play some live traditional music, very special indeed!

Beautiful and Brilliant. Wonderful reflection on the history of Vietnam and the foresight of some of its previous Rulers. We visited with guides from HanoiKids and thoroughly enjoyed it. We did get swamped with people on bus tours but just around 12.30pm it was almost empty so this may be a good time to visit. Amazing bonsai, beautiful architecture, rich in history and a great place to visit. Minimal entry fee.

So picturesque. We visited about 9:00am & were surrounded by several groups of young people who we found out were graduating classes there to have group photographs taken. They all looked so great in their Ao Dai.Visiting the temple was a great experience & the grounds are beautifully kept, A small oasis in the city.

Enjoyable. Not what I was expecting. Beatiful gardens, very historical. A guide would make this visit much more informative but we enjoyed and took from it what we could. Souvenirs and cool drinks available.
Higher Education must-see. Those interested in higher education should make a stop here to see the tablets of those who completed their degrees centuries ago.

Really interesting. Lovely oasis of calm in the frantic city. It was interesting to learn about the importance that the Vietnamese/chinese place on learning and this is steeped in history - a vietnamese Oxford/Cambridge college!
Nice Setting. Nice, quiet setting but not much there. Interesting background to understand the symbols of Buddhism.

a hot afternoon with the degree students. the hot afternoon i visited the temple of Literature, some students had graduated in the temple. W hat a great place to have your degree presented to you, after all the hard work1
picturesque. Lovely complex full of a variety of buildings. Good for a walk through.

Well worth a visit. If you go take a guide to explain the site. It makes for a much richer experience.
It is allways crowded with large school groups so go there early.
lovely gardens. Beautiful architecture and gardens. Nice for a little quiet time from the crazy city.

Interesting Architecture and History. Visited here as part of a tour of Hanoi, loved the history on the place and the architecture. It was steaming hot when we visited here but still our guide took the time to explain everything in detail. Soak yourself in the history and culture and you will really enjoy this place.

interesting stop. We liked the insight into the historical development of education and Vietnamese philosophy presented here.
We also like the government owned gift shop inside.
We didn't like the 'hustlers' who confronted us upon our leaving the facility.

Good for a visit. We walked around the temple area for over 1 hour. Only costs 20,000 VD each. It is interesting enough and probably worth a visit if you are ever in Hanoi. The garden area is well maintained and the buildings are well kept.
Beautiful and calm. This is a calm space in the middle of a wildly alive city. Even if the architecture and the history are of no interest, you'll enjoy the order and the peace.
Milidly interesting. Not a lot to see. But worth the trip. If you're in Hanoi it's worth seeing.
Very interesting place. This was a very interesting place with some beautiful buildings and great historical artifacts.
A must see. An iconic landmark of Hanoi - a must see. The temple and site are easily accessible and very well maintained.

No. This was possibly the worst sight in my whole travel of Southeast Asia. Ofcourse it is extremely touristy and surrounded by fake students and annoying moto-drivers etc., but I just don't understand how they can put an ATM and a souvenir shops inside the temple complex. Very average temple anyway.

quiet spot in Hanoi. We enjoyed visiting the temple of literature, not just because of the building itself and its hystory but also beacuse it is a little espace of quietness in crazy -noisy Hanoi. I recommend the visit.

a bit of peace and quiet in the middle of the city. the temple of literature is a great little oasis in the middle of hanoi. get out of the hussle and bustle of the city and relax in the peaceful setting.
Interesting. Fantastic old buildings and history. Peaseful place and very interesting

Rebuild Temple of Literature & National University. This temple show Vietnamese priority their education since 1000 year ago. It is also the proof that they were studying Mandarin before Uncle Ho language.
Inside have a lot of status shows the name who were succeed to achieve honorable in their study.
Interesting. Take an hour or so and wonder thru this amazing place. It's cheap, like every other tourist site in Vietnam and it's something you;ll never see back home !
the oldest university of Vietnam. the oldest university founded in 1174 a.Ch. in wonderful old buildings wth a very strong selection of the students.
Peacefull but not impressive. Liked the garden and the information given on the site.
A must. Beautiful place - interesting as well. Great gardens and not too expensive to get in.
Great for a quick visit. Great to see but an hour should do it, it a bit out of the way.
Old Time Elitism. Nice insight to the elite education of previous Emperor's underlings.

go to the pagoda instead. have to say i thought it was a bit of a let down
it's just the location of
Quiet in the hustle and bustle. Not as much to see as we hoped but still interesting and KOTO nearby very good for eats
worth a look. visited this museum. has some fine architecture but the lack of shade on a hot day made it difficult to enjoy

Temple of "Little Richard". A nice afternoon stop arranged by Indochina Pioneer was the Temple of Literature, which has sounded to me like the “Temple of Little Richard” when Philip, our guide, told us about it. It is a peaceful spot, surrounded by walls from the Hanoi traffic outside. It was formerly the most prestigious school in Vietnam, founded and maintained in the Confucian tradition, with the names of students in each class who passed three rigorous exams carved in stone tablets, and the names of top students memorialized in the temple inside, where statues of three famous headmasters stand today. The buildings, classic examples of Vietnamese architecture, sit among beautifully landscaped grounds. The boys especially liked the elaborate dragons at the entries to the inner complex. It is a pleasant, peaceful stop amid the bustle of Hanoi. For more details of this and other parts of our trip, go to http://maketrax.blogspot.com
Amazing. Its great. The history slap you in the face from the first minute and you realize that this country has been around for a while.

The training school for mandarins - a haven of peace in central Hanoi. To give it its Vietnamese name "Van Mieu", it is the ancient training school for national mandarins and is older than Oxford University. Her the top government officials trained and took their exams which were set by the emperor every few years. Although traffic circulates right around the Van Mieu it is often a haven of peace in central Hanoi and best to visit early in the mrning or late in the evening when there are fewer visitors. It is built much like a forbidden city or a pagoda with several parts that culminate at the end one. There is a rebuilt building (the former one was bombed by the Americans) housing the stues of kings and scholars still revered today. A must on a visit to Hanoi.

Nothing Special if You Have Traveled a Bit in Asia. A historically significant but ultimately unremarkable structure. In Northeast Asian countries, this would be a minor sight.Best to go very early in the morning before the crowds arrive. Does not make the place more impressive, but at least it is not crowded.

Beautiful gardens and peaceful if you're not sharing with huge crowds.. The walk down the main promenade is enjoyable if you manage to dodge the tour buses. The temple is significant as it represents the time in history when Confucian philosophy was dominate at all levels of society. There are a lot of gift shops.
Enlightening. This is a fascinating, extremely educational place to visit. The grounds are also beautiful and there is a wealth of history here. A must see on any visitor's list!

Temple of Literature. Try to go a little later in the day when it's not so hot. So much around there, including the War Museum. See pics herehttp://womentravellingalone.blogspot.com/search/label/Hanoi%20-%20Vietnam
Peace and calm in the middle of Hanoi. Try and avoid the tour groups if you can. Beautifully renovated after the destruction of a lot of the site in the wars.
good but not a most see. bets is if you are donne go for lunch at koto......
Literature Museum. There were no books, it was not what we expected, I guess we expected pages open of historic books, History of Vietnam but there was nothing
Fascinating insight to Vietnam educational culture. We were there on a Sunday and many students were there in traditional dress to pray at the temple for success with thier exams, fascinating.
Temple of Literature. Easy to get to, had a great atmosphere, not as large as I thought it may have been.

You have just got to see the stone turtles. Good seeing the first university and Confuscias. The turtles are so cute, you can see the different styles. Get the Hanoi Kids to take you there to explain the significance. Well worth it.
A Haven of peace. Very qiuet and impressive area in the midst of a very noisy city
Another temple. This was a nice place, but if you've been in Asia for a while, it's just another busy temple.

Worth seeing. Although busy, this is a site worth seeing in Hanoi. It is cheap, clean, tidy and has very good signs to describe where appropriate. There are hawkers at the entrance but they weren't too much of a problem.

an oasis of peace. surprising large area of neatly lad out buildings and gardens in a busy part of the city
there is an air of tranquility here
lots of visitor groups and school children (all of whom want to chant hello in english to anybody why looks foreign)
Come in an animal, leave a person. That's what the tour guide Hong told us. That is what education does a person. Nice tour. Vietnamese value education a lot.
Relaxing. The temple was a welcome break from the hustle and bustle of the old district. A serene place of beautiful gardens and architecture
Must see!. You cannot visit Hanoi without seeing the Temple of Literature. We went with a local guide who told us so much information and made the whole experience much more rewarding.
Cool Buildings but. the buildings are cool and it is a nice place to walk around but if you have spent any time in Asia you have seen the same thing a thousand times.
Worth a visit. Doesn't take long to walk through this ancient temple and is good to see a confusion temple for something different.

A Highlight and not just for the architecture. The place is filled with students dressed in the most beautiful (and scruffy) costumes. It is alive as a place of learning (well an annex to the leacture rooms really) not just a relic from the past. The architecture and history are also facinating. Liked it a lot.
Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple in the middle of the Hanoi craziness. Worth going to see and take pictures. Crowded with all the tourists. Some fun souvenir shopping here as well.
Worth a Visit - and open on Monday. Interesting history - worth paying a couple of dollars for a guide. We went on a Monday and found it was open - many museums are closed on Mondays.

Peaceful and tranquil. It's interesting to see the layout of the temple but if you have visited any of the temples in China, then you wont be missing out too much not visiting the Temple of Literature. Nevertheless, if you're in Hanoi, it is still worth a wonder in the peaceful place.

an interesting historical site. fascinating to learn about the academic system back in ancient vietnam. the architecture is typical of chinese structures. easy to get to and strongly suggested if this is your sort of thing.

An Interesting Site. The Temple of Literature is of great historical importance in Vietnam -- it is after all the country's first university, founded nearly 1000 years ago. The back part has been rebuilt, as it was destroyed during the war, but it is still quite nice.

Calm and sophisticated. This is a beautiful, spacious, gentle and calm Temple, very well maintained. A number of courtyards lead you into the heart of the building - traditional musicians were playing here when we visited. A lovely place.

Beautiful temple and wonderful music performance. Next to the Museum of Ethnology, this was my favorite spot in Hanoi. The temple is lovely and very peaceful and serene in the middle of such a busy city. The best part - and the part that our kids (aged 7-10) enjoyed the most was the performance of traditional Vietnamese music. The musicians use fantastic instruments I had never seen before and played beautifully. It's definitely worth stopping to listen to and watch.

Go back in history. This is a wonderful place to visit for those who want to know more about the ancient history of Vietnam. It is best to have a guide with you as the place will not reveal its history, or the significance of this centre of learning. It is certainly worth a visit to go back in time
Worth a visit. As one of the oldest universities in the world it's definitely worth a look around but do take a guide tour so that you can really understand the history.

Interesting for a short visit. Went here as part of our Hanoi city tour. This is a pretty standard stop I think. You do need to go on a tour so the guide can explain what you are looking at otherwise you will have no idea. I have seen many temples, this one not that impressive but interesting enough for half an hour or so. Can buy some interesting bookmarks and knick-knacks from the shop here. Bought one saying'pass the exam' for my daughter. Hope it helps.
Fabulous!. Go early to avoid the crowds if you want the perfect photo
Lovely!. Don't miss this gem! The temple is in a lovely setting, it's a little bit of peace in the middle of the wonderful chaos that is Hanoi!
Very interesting. interesting place - great architecture, lots of learn

Education is important.... .... to the Vietnamese people. There were many students at the Temple and all praying for luck and achievements in their studies. Showed how serious these young people were about having an education and good results.

Beautiful place despite shops. Take a guide with you for the best experience. To understand what is what and who is who on the temple´s altar one need good guiding. I hoped to hear some traditional Vietnamese music but the ensemble was not there. If You take a taxi from the Temple make sure that is from the well known company.

Should not be missed out on!. The most impressive thing I saw in Hanoi. Everywhere you look you are struck with beauty. I also bought a very beautiful jade necklace here, pricey, but at least it's definitely real.
beautiful collection of buildings. Wonderful architecture, history of scholarship and learning; a quiet oasis away from the cacophany of the streets

Not much to get without a guide. I asked for an english speaking guide but none was available. I walked through the grounds to look at the stones and temple but there was no literature or placards to explain what I was looking at or why these artifacts were significant.
Cultural experience. The wonderful thing about this beautiful temple is that lots of young vietnamise girls come here to take pictures wearing fantastic national clothes.

A must see. Actually, it was the first university in Vietnam...amazing. The Temple of Literature is a tranquil place among the chaos of Hanoi. A quiet place even with hundreds of children on the day I visited. Our guide helped us to understand the meaning of everything we saw...a must!

Hanoi experience. Hi,Five separate courtyards with a place of worship at the far end. It was a nice experience and a pleasant walk around although quite crowded. I didn't really get much of it except it was one of the first places where scholars were personally given a Q and A by the King of the time to see if they had the skills and abilities to go on with studying and be accepted into an elite school for further education with the ultimate aim being to help and benefit the nation.There were well laid out gardens and courtyards but a lot of this was in Chinese and Vietnamese withouit translations available and I had no guide.I was expecting classrooms, studies and texts from great people and many Confuscian ideals and although they are mentioned briefly on a couple of courtyard walls there was not much more detail but worth a couple of hours.I should have read up before I went a bit more to be fair. A good bit of easy paced pleasant walking around that did me no harm.

Go early, or late. We visited this place late in the morning, when the temple and grounds were full of tourists. This was poor planning on our part, but a pity nonetheless, since this would be a lovely place to stroll around at a quieter time.
Nice. Nice buildings and pond interesting architecture and history most of the informations sheets are translated into english which is good as well
Nothing Fantastic. 20,000 dong for entrance fees and 10,000 dong for local students. Would appreciate if there's some explanation to the different buildings.

i like it, because after that i can understand more about the Vietnamese culture. i like that because look like the temple but that is the first university in HaNoi. it is very interesting.
I dislike because some one sell some thing in the street followed me and invited me, i said: No, Thank. But they still invited, after that i must bought
Fine... but not amazing.. The stone turtle tablets are interesting. There was an old-timey music group playing in the last building... not "amazing". but a good time.
An amazing enclave in the middle of the city. It is a wonderful refuge when sightseeing. Very peaceful and calm. A must see!!!
beautiful people. there were many students there dressed up in traditional Vietnamese clothing. they had recently graduated. They were very curious about us and asked us many questions!
must see!. Hidden behind a long wall this is really a treasure one must see.

One of the treasures in Hanoi. The most peacefully place in Hanoi. Here, you can disconnect of the noisy hanoian atmosfere. Charming temple with a very long history. Actually, it was the first university in Vietnam...amazing
Worth visiting as its so old. Worth visiting as has some interesting exhibits but very touristy. But if you have time its worth looking at.
Great atmosphere and lots of history.. The construction of the site and your ability to fully explore the whole building.
Don't miss!. This is, together with the Old Quarter, the best thing I've seen in this beautiful city.
Peaceful. The Temple of Literature is a tranquil place among the chaos of Hanoi. Some English information available but a guide may be helpful.

Great atmosphere. Even with the many tourists, it's able to retain a unique atmosphere of a dynasty gone. Wonderful shape of historical architecture. Only 20k ($1) adult and 10k (50cent) students, can't complain.

Beautiful and serene. The grounds of the Temple of Literature are lovely to walk in. A quiet contempletive place even with hundreds of children on the day I visited. Go early. I have been here before and it is a wonderful start to any trip to Hanoi.

Tranquility in the middle of Hanoi. For a very nominal fee you can escape from the noise and traffic of Hanoi and wander around the gardens. There was some kind of noisy presentation being made to a large group of school children in one of the larger courtyards, but otherwise the place wasn't all that busy, and there plenty of things to photograph. It's a bit like a small version of the Forbidden City in Beijing -- a chunk of history now surrounded by a big city.

Calm and serene. I think that this is a must see when coming to Hanoi but you needn't spend more than a half hour here. Calm and fragrant, it is nice to just wander through. Read up about it before you go because there aren't many notices or signs around to give you an idea as to what you're looking at.

Educating visit. I agree with previous reviewers that this is worth a stop in your tour of Hanoi. These classic Chinese influenced carvings are usually available to rub their heads for good luck. My favourite attraction there was a gorgeous gold plated tortoise. Lots of high school children here, girls looked beautiful in national dress which they have to wear. Our guide helped us to understand the meaning of everything we saw...a must!
A must see. A very interesting place with beautiful architecture and landscaping.

Interesting with Great Photo Opportunities.. The Temple of Literature is very uniquely designed and great to walk around for an hour or so. Just bring some water if its a hot day! It has great sculptures and buildings and shrubbery carved into animals. Very very small fee to get in, but well preserved so worth it!

Another must see in Hanoi. I did visit the place without bothering taking a guide and a tour. You can make nice pictures there, and then the visit is for little money. I am not sure it is worth to take a guide for this place, and avoid the souvenirs shops that are not interesting. You can find better things and cheaper in the old quarter

History for the Scholars. The importance of Confucian philosphy is present here, It is lovely walking and the Stellae are still standing and you will appreciate the doctoral concept from here. You can compare it to the more modern area in Hue
Beautiful. A great place to understand the long history of the scholars of Vietnam.
A pieceful place in town. It is a beautiful place with some history. The sellers outside were just too much on that warm day.

Liked visiting this ...Wish we had a Guide. I agree with previous reviewers that this is worth a stop in your tour of Hanoi...if you have a guide. While there are some signs in English, you will not truly get a feel for the place and it's significance without a guide. We did not have a guide and struggled to understand what we should know about each section of the temple area.Also were discouraged that you can no longer touch the stone turtles that have the tablets on their backs. These classic Chinese influenced carvings are usually available to rub their heads for good luck. They were roped off during our late March visit.

Stunning. The Temple of Literature was beautiful. Some of the statues were stunning. My favourite attraction there was a gorgeous gold plated tortoise. The flowers were lovely. It was a nice peaceful attraction.
Full of History. Enjoyed visiting this historical place. Lots of high school children here, girls looked beautiful in national dress which they have to wear.
Temple of literature. Lack of information but interesting building nonetheless
Stately Past. Really interesting being where education has been passed down fro centuries. Our guide helped us to understand the meaning of everything we saw...a must!

Educating visit.. This is part of their culture and you should pay this temple a visit, if you have the opportunity of having a tour guide who will give you a lecture on the different parts of the temple ... do appreciate it ... every little bit of history is interesting to know and will help you enjoy your stay in Vietnam.

Fantastic and Cheap. If you are interested in this kind of thing its a must to see and kept in pristine condition considering its age, there where a lot of children there when we went, actually reading there essays out, and also a few local instruments being played very entertaining

A must see. Beautifully preserved, atmospheric and peaceful. You get a real sense of the history of Hanoi (a millenium old city) here. Well signposted so you know the significance of what you're seeing too. A must see in Hanoi

It's a peaceful place.... As a lover of learning and one interested in the history of education, this was a must-see. However, aside from it being a nice and quiet area within busy Hanoi, there wasn't all that much to see or do - not even benches to sit in and read. It's a place with loads of history but very little of the history is presented in English. It's certainly worth a visit if you've got some time in Hanoi, but it's likely you will want to leave after 30 minutes.

Oldest university in Vietnam, take a guide. One might be tempted to try and visit this alone and with only 20.000 Dong entrance fee (1 Dollar) there is not much money to waste. On the other hand, the whole area is so full of symbols and history that a good guide will help very much along. Very nice gardens some artificial ponds make for a very nice setting for a university in which over the centuries the high beaurcrats for Vietnam have been trained.It tells a lot about the values and morals of the culture of Vietnam. Even without a guide there is a lot to see and discover but with somebody to make it alive it gets much more impressive. All signs inside are in Vietnamese so reading will most likely not help you. In either way it is a nice place to spend one hour away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Very relaxing and beautiful at least.
Interesting visit!. This is a place to visit if you are in hanoi! Some well maintained gardens with interesting history and buildings. Inside are some souvenir shops.

Our first encounter with Confucius. Unless you have a guide or literature that explains what ytou are seeing, most will go right over your head. There are crowds but no lineups, and images of Confucius and his disciples. It all makes sense if you can get it explained. There ar eno english signs to help you along.However that aside, if you are with a guide, then it puts a whole new understanding on Confucius and his imporance to the development of this culture.

Interesting place to visit. I like the landscaping with Vietnamese characters written with use of plants & flowers. Inside has interesting collections of awards written on cement/concrete to recognize it's scholars; a statue of Confucius & it's best 4 students. There is also a free dance & music performances.

Must see Hanoi.. Even after 3 weeks of non-stop temples and pagodas, this was worth the walk. It's an oasis in the madness of Hanoi, and a reminder of the huge influence China had over the region over many centuries. It takes about an hour to enjoy fully, especially if you catch the musicians playing their weird and wonderful instruments - that alone was worth the minimal entry fee. Going early would also be a good idea - it was getting really busy by the time we left around 1130.

Lovely. If you see anything in Hanoi, see this. It is such a contrast to the noise and crowds in the city proper. The buildings have been restored but what a feast for the eyes architecturally and aesthetically. Tkake some time to learn the meaning of the various bits of the complex. Note the cambre of the paths. Take your camera. Buy a little something from the shops. Then, go over the road and find the shop that sells the real local art and craft of Vietnam the profits of which go to the people who make them.

Interesting but too packed. Would be better with a guide and not filled with disrespectful, over-enthused teenage school kids climbing all over 600 year old statues, but still worth a visit. It's 25,000dong (I think guidebooks etc are out of date).
Very Interesting. Interesting architecture and exhibits, although it is best to have a guide with you to explain many things. Our guide was "well versed" and made this come to life for us.

Better than the name implies. This is ancient temple/school complex celebrating the Confucian influence on Vietnam.Really quite interesting. Remarkable buildings/gardens and ancient Stella. Be respectful in the temple, no shorts,halter tops, etc. Definitely worth an hour or two..
Tranquil place in the centre of chaos. Really interesting look at the history of higher education in Vietnam. Very clean and well presented sight. Signs in English and vietnamese.

Worth the trip. Very pretty grounds and temple. Worth checking it out for all the history of the place. Bus loads of tour groups walking around though, so don't think you will get much of it to yourself unless you find a quiet corner and sit to soak it all up.
Temple of Literature. We loved our trip to this site as part of a full day tour of Hanoi booked by Thaison Hotel
Nice buildings.. Very nice to walk around in the ancient university of hanoi. beautiful old buildings.

Beautiful temple. Very colourful temple/ pagoda, i liked the miniature life of Buddha in a bonsai sort of tree.
Lake with tortoise/turtle. A must see
First University of Viet Nam. Its nice to spend an hour even just walk throught the place with fully information all walls along the temple. Very interesting
Packed with people,. A beautiful place, definitely worth a visit, but be prepared to literally bump into hoards of people.
Nice insight into the past. This place shows where legends like confucious studied. Good insight into Vietnams leterary past
Confucian roots. Interesting to see how deeply the influence of china and Confucianism run through Vietnamese history and culture. A beautiful temple in the Chinese/viet style.
Peaceful and pretty. The temple was well maintained, peaceful and pretty.

If you visit one university it should be this one. We visited this temple/university with our guide and that is the best way to do it - it has a fascinating history that is not apparent from just walking around by yourself. Definitely worth visiting.
A calm oasis in the busy city. A very old centre of learning based on Confucian ideals.

A Brilliant Piece of Vietnamese History. Not only is this a quiet oasis of calm in a tumultuous city, it also shows and explains the story of human endevours from a different perspective than the Egyptian, Greek, or Roman ancient cultures.
