Must have in your Hanoi itinerary. One of the most important sightseeing objects in Hanoi, we went there as a part of a city tour. Having a guide and a guidebook clearly helped, as there is not much information in English inside. The temple itself is wellkept and impressive, the only thing one can regard as a bit of a minus is that some parts of the temple were used for selling some tourist knicknacks, which bit affected the overall impression.
a quiet oasis in the centre of bustling Hanoi. Escape the chaos of Hanoi streets and immerse yourself deep into the Vietnamese history.
Not very spectacular. Not very spectacular -- very few signs in English, and , sine we were there without a guide, much was left to imagination.

A must visit in Hanoi. I think the temple of literature is on most people's itinerary. It is not only visually beautiful and a place of quiet amidst the hustle and bustle of Hanoi life, it is also a view into the past university life in Hanoi.

Impressive - and touristic. A very interesting place to visit - a must for Hanoi. Unfortunately, all the big tourist buses think the same and unload hordes of tourists there (I could communicate in german with almost everybody in there...).Staff is not very friendly, pay in VDN or they charge you 4 times the real exchange rate in USD - instead of 20000VDN (=1USD) they asked for 4 USD. Don't even try to go to the toilet without giving a small "donation"..These are the only downturns, you definitely have to see this place of wisdom (university) and nice architecture! Would go back there next time visiting Hanoi.
Must see. It is a peaceful garden despite tons of tourists. The garden is telling a story of Vietnam in the past and what it will become. Very nice place to visit.
NO a/c and no Heat. Depending on the season dress to the season it is old not much to see .
Do not miss when in Hanoi. A must to visit.... of great historic importance.... Confuscious explained....

Interesting area dedicated to learning and the first university in Vietnam. This is a large, interesting place with different sections dedicated to learning and education going back to the 11th century in Vietnam. Some of the information is in English. This a popular sight and tend to be crowded, but is large enough so is not a major problem. Entrance fee is very inexpensive.
A rebuilt icon. While it is a fascinating space it is of necessity a rebuilt temple because the french levelled it with bombs. It still has a feel of serenity about it which works.
Fascinating Place to Visit. We were there during a poetry festival. Masses of people and it was very enjoyable and interesting, as are most of the places in Vietnam.

Thoughtful place to visit. The Temple of Literature is a wonderful place to visit if you are in a contemplative frame of mind. Looking at it and reading the information, one can almost picture what it might have been like a thousand years ago. It should be on a mandatory list of "Things to Do in Hanoi".

Scenic grounds. We were glad to have stopped here in between the Ethnology and Women's museums. The gardens and buildings are very pleasant to stroll around. I must confess to be ignorant of the significance of the temple and site, but it was a happy experience nonetheless to visit and spend some time in these pleasant surrounds amidst the bustle and chaos of Hanoi

One of the must-sees in Hanoi. The Temple of Literature was founded as a University long before anybody in the west had ever heard of universities, so it goes back a long way. Added to by successive Emperors (a bit like the Egyptian Temples) it makes a fascinating historical record as well as being a very peaceful and inspiring spot containing some of the best examples of Vietnamese historical architecture in the country.

Interesting place to visit. This was our first 'site' in Vietnam. It was quite interesting and very impressive although I don't think that I would note it as a 'must see'. It is definitely very popular but I probably wouldn't recommend it.

Interesting place worth checking out. It's a nice walk around the Temple of Literature. It's basically a big temple that was (for hundreds of years) a university. There's plenty of lakes and pagodas to have a look at. It's nice and close to the old quarter. Definitely worth a look.
was 1st University in Vietnam. the temple should be can more interesting but somehow i think it less maintenance.

Not all that interesting!. There is very little to see here and it will only take you 20- 30minutes to see everything. The statues are mundane and the gardens are not kept well. Although the ATM in the courtyard is funny! Since its cheap you could go but don't make it a priority!
Well preserved. Nicely laid out, not too busy with tourists. The scholar stones are very interesting as is the main temple.
beautiful architecture. the only thing i could say about this place is : beautiful architecture. It is shabby, colorful and authentic.

Beautiful site. I visited the museum on my own, it was lovely to walk through. There were some signs in English, giving the basic outline of what the Temple of Literature is about, they normally sell guidebooks at the front counter - but were sold out when I went. I think it would be useful to buy the guidebook to get a better understanding.
Learnt about "Confucious"and the connection to a good Education. Beautiful temple and place to visit with a very interesting history that is still so relevant in todays teachings and education.
Not a lot to see.... A nice way to spend a lazy hour - walk around the gardens and get a few nice photos.

If you like temples go to this one. Perhaps a bit over visited as this was the busiest place we went to - if you like temples this one is compact and easy to get the most out of your visit. It includes the symbol of Vietnam.
very interesting. especiall look out for the music students, amazing stuff
FASCINATING. I thought this was going to be boring but I found it really fascinating. It was obviously a very early university. I can recommend a visit & was glad that I went.

Classic Hanoi ..... Breahtaking very large complex maintained in wonderful condition. Easy to spend a day here! From the entrance it looks like one building - but there are many temples. Absolute must for the traveller to soak up.
Beautiful. Be sure to get a tour guide - lots of history and deep meanings behind the architecture.
beautiful and serene. very beautiful old part of town - do it together with the national arts museum

Tranquil, beautiful respite. I loved this place, so relaxing amid the noise and clutter of Hanoi. I recomend it. Temples in Vietnam are beautiful, with the red lanterns and flowers and incense. There are a couple of good restaurants nearby, Pho 24 and Ko To. Culture, good photos and good food, what more do you want! Takes 20min to visit.
Nice. Interesting, relatively quiet in the middle of the city. Old with lots of history. Worthwhile.
You better study up to know what you see. Five courtyards with throngs of people in Chinese style.

Surprisingly spectacular. My teenage daughter who has been to China said this was far more interesting and impressive than the Forbidden City. We loved the writing wall for making requests, right at the back of the temple.
lovely. I enjoyed this attraction - it was well worth seeing, and filled on the day with the most gorgeously dressed students.

Beautiful Temple of Literature. The complex was magnificent and it was great to discover a great historical centre of learning, the temple being the oldest university in Vietnam. A must see for anyone interested in history, architecture or a wonderful afternoon away from the Hanoi traffic!

Calm. We went there on the 1st Sunday in February when they hosted the Asian Poetry day. Entry was free which was a pleasant surprise and much of the poetry being read was translated into English! It is worth the visit for the architecture, the history and gardens. Alongside the outer walls is a non profit organisation charity shop where you can buy some good souvenirs that go to directly helping those in need. It is called Craft Link.

Teeming with visitors. We discovered this temple accidentally during our 2010 trip. We were fortunate at that time to see a large group of recently graduated ladies in their ao-dais and I had a whale of a time photographing them and emailed them their photos as souvenirs.We purposely visited this place again during our Tet 2012 trip. As it was much colder compared to our first trip, we did not see visitors wearing ao dai. However, we still enjoyed our visit, seeing throngs and throngs of locals and tourists coming in and out. We arrived in time in the early morning to witness some senior ladies, garbed in very colourful traditional costumes, singing and dancing outside one of the inner temples.There was also a "live game" inside, which looked like chess, with a giant chessboard. As an announcer mentioned the latest move of a player, a man with a flag would move the marker to the correct location.Outside the Temple of Literature there were many artists writing calligraphy on red scrolls to encourage their customers so that they can do well in their studies.We plan to visit this place every time we make a trip to Hanoi.

Interesting temple, pretty grounds. I don't know if I'd recommend spending hours here, but the grounds are beautiful and peaceful with some really interesting temples on site. A good insight into Vietnamese culture and academic history.
Nice to visit. It allows me to appreciate the history of the area and the architecture of the wooden ancient building. The building is impressive and well maintained. Definitely worth a visit
Worth a visit.. Apparently this was one of the world's first universities. Has a temple, nice gardens and a shop.

Vietnamese educational center. it was not good to see the tradition of Vietnamese people during the TET. the guide took us there informed us all about how important the education is for VIetnamese people in the old day and now-aday. Great time

Feels like a Chinese temple complex. Vietnamese showing its strong Chinese influence. Unique, I love the stella denoting the scholars bio. Advice: read up its history before going, no descriptions. Well-maintained, and if you are lucky, you will see scores of Vietnamese girls in their ao-dais taking their graduation photographs there.

Dont miss the Temple of Literature. During Tet this Temple was aboslutely packed with visitors both locals and people from all over the world including many Vietnamese. As Lonely Plane says , dont miss it.

Nice Architecture.. Nice old place to observe. The buildings are beautiful and interesting but the garden is not. The turtles are surprisingly very old antiques. But it would be better If I had a guide to explain me the detail of the place.

A place to reflect!. The reverence for scholarship is astounding given the period in which this was built. The architecture is amazing as are the statues and bonsai. A place of quiet in the midst of the mayhem in the streets.
Great temple to explore. If you like to take pictures, you will not be disappointed with this temple starting from the gate and all the way to the back.
A Temple to Literature. Westerners should all come here and learn that we were far from being the first devoted to learning.

Wonderful. Loved this place. Serene and an oasis of tranquility in the heart of noisy Hanoi. Well worth a visit! Make sure there's enough battery on your camera, you'll take plenty of pictures here :)

Very Good Indeed !. This area is well worth a wander from the old city. It is an oasis of tranquillity in an area that used to be a couple of kilometres from the old city and a kilometre from the citadel. There are several other interesting sites and sights close by. So visit the area not just the Temple of Literature.

Interesting place, but probably would be worth going with a guide. This was a nice tranquil place to visit with many interesting sights inside, however I felt we were not "seeing" the whole picture, so it might be worth going with a guide for this attraction.
Interesting. Very central and interesting but not alot of the signage is in English so a guide would make it more interesting.

Nice morning spent away from the traffic. We spent a lovely morning walking around this temple dedicated to the scholars of the past. It was nice to get away from the crazy traffic, plus there were English translations.

Very Interesting Temple. Whilst it is a bit out of the way it is an interesting walk from the Old Quarter - especially if you go via the French Quarter - allow about 45 minutes each way (come back via the Citadel - past the Russian MIG fighter jet!) . One of the best Temples we visited in our 3 week trip - lots of stuff about Confuscious and regular performances on local instruments. If you aren't careful you will miss the most interesting part of the temple which is well hidden away behind what looks to be the last temple but you have to go up a little side alley to get to it - and it's not signposted anywhere either so if you haven't got a guide or a guide-book you will miss it !

A beautiful place- worth getting aguide. The right guide can make all the difference - we had someone who was so passionately enthusiastic that it brought the place to life - make sure your camera is well-charged!
One of World's Oldest Universities. A bit out of the way in town but an oasis of tranquility. Great historical significance.
very spiritual, well maintained. a peaceful place, well maintained helps to learn a little more about the history of scholars in Vietnam.
Old History today.. Just i wanna see it. I like it! If you can touch to head stone turtle - you get fortune!

A peek into a vanished era. Well worth going to as we got an idea of what parts of old Hanoi would have looked like. The buildings are mostly from 1000 years ago and the restorations were tasteful and in keeping with the older structures. After visiting, we could see parts of old Hanoi peeking out (and often enough abandoned and crumbling) under the new Hanoi - especially in the Old Quarter.
worth the visit - interesting history. Definitely worth visiting during your trip to Hanoi, has very interesting history and is a desitnation for both Vietnamese and foreign tourists.
Fascinating. Really beautiful quiet retreat in the heart of the city. They charge a entry fee but think was only 40p.

A beautiful, restful place to visit. The university complex has lovely gardens to walk through plus the temple, and amazing stelae marking the successful doctoral candidates from hundreds of years ago. We enjoyed our time exploring and taking a break from the exhaust fumes out on the streets!

Go there. Beautiful old temples, with history and serenity. Loved the classis old roof lines (dragons). You pass through one building with courtyard and then keep going. There are 5 in all and each interesting in its own way. A serene and reflective place in a chaotic town.
Nice to visit.. the place itself is majestic, and it offers a lot of insight to sino-vietnam relations in history

Step back in time..love of learning. One of my favorite sites in Hanoi it was a great place to learn about the real vietnam scholars and to enjoy some local music. I wish we had some more time at this site.
While away a few hours here. Very peaceful spot in the midst of the chaos that is Hanoi. Take your time to wander through this pleasant spot. I spent a couple of hours here.

Great buildings with a long history of Confucianism. The entrance to the main area is the city symbol of Hanoi. Temple of Literature has impressive Chinese architecture and well-maintained. The red colored arches rooftops combine with vast garden and ponds with massive statues of Confucian and Vietnam early Kings.The stellae on the turtle back showed that there are many scholars has been studied in Hanoi during Confucianism period.

Very Interesting and surprising attraction.. Really enjoyed the temple of literature in Hanoi. Is thishe oldest university in the world ? Vietnamese students celebrting graduation give this a exhuberant spirit. Historically they used to rub the headsf ancient turtles for luck. Unexpected delight of hearing traditional vietnamese classical music in one of the jalls. Speel binding. A must for Hanoi.

Nice. A nice break from the busy streets of Ha Noi. Unfortunately not a break from the constant selling, wish I had a photo of the woman trying to throw t-shirts at me right under the sign saying 'no selling or buying souvenirs in this area'. Very pretty grounds, shame the inside of the temple was being used for storage.
Wonderful Historical Perspective. You get a nice look at Vietnamese architecture and the culture of learning that goes back almost 1000 years at this complex.
interesting historical building. If you are interested in old buildings or just want to spend a few minutes off the bustling streets, then the Temple of Literature is a good visit.
best temple in the city. amidst the hustle of the new hanoi this place brings you back to the cultural and religious heritage of the country .

Good to stop in if your in the area. The temple of Literature is a nice little get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Its high walls keep out the sound of the traffic and its gardens are well manicured.
Breathtaking. An oasis amid the bustle of Ha Noi. Our trip to the temple was rushed--give yourself plenty of time to explore the grounds.

Craziness!. The grounds were super clean. The facilities very well kept. This is virtually a holy place containing the history of the Vietnamese people for hundreds of years!
While you are there... Go to lunch at To Lan to the East of the Temple Grounds Building 9 on Van Mieu Street! AMAZING BUNCHA!!!!
Get a guide. AS with most attractions in Vietnam, there are no English translations, so unless you know what you are looking at, this can turn out to be another superficial visit.
Birthplace of the oldest university in Vietnam. Worth a visit to see the place where the first university of Vietnam was founded (in 1070, according to some sources).
Best place in Hanoi. This was our absolutely most favorite site we saw in Hanoi. It's amazing to see this history and preservation of this site. Very worth going to visit.
Definitely worth a visit. Interesting building, full of history, which has beautiful gardens. Definitely worth a visit

Tranquil Stroll. A lovely walk through quiet gardens and temples. Very nice live traditional music- you can come and go as you please. (Be aware of taxis outside of temple who took us on an expensive ride in circles until we finally cut our losses, got out and walked the rest of the way back to our hotel.)

Important historical site. Probably the most interesting historical site in Ha Noi, it's also simply a beautiful place for a visit for a couple of hours. Take note of the ancient turtle-tablets bearing the names of the Temple's scholars.
share in graduation delight. Not much to see but very busy with students dressed in fantastic costumes celebrating their graduation and taking photos with family and friends
beautiful old place. Serene despite being in the middle of town. History going back 1000 years.
This could be better maintained but intersetng!!. Loved the feeling of solitude. Did not go at a busy time of year so could ffel the draw. Very nice.
Great photo op. Very nice place for photos. Exhibits lack English translations.

A bit of a walk from the Old Quarter, but very enlightening. So happy that we made the trek out to experience this site... a bit of zen in the middle of the city, and really fascinating history. But don't bother to buy the pamphlet if you have a Vietnam guidebook... it was pointless, as there are several signs in English with better descriptions.

A pocket of tranquility in Hanoi. When you pass through the walls which separate the Temple from the busy streets, you could easily imagine how it felt 1000 years ago when a scholar passes through the gates for classes. With the high brick walls and big trees, the sounds of Hanoi are muted as you work your way past the courtyards.The Temple was built to honor the ways of Confucius as the learning pedagogy at that time leaned towards on the Chinese style. The third courtyard has a murky pool in the middle with stone turtles bearing slabs on their shells surrounding it. The next courtyard holds a temple with a red lacquered statue of Confucius and a gift shop. When we were there end Oct 2011, no guided tours were available. It might be a good idea to read up on the Temple before heading over to appreciate the buildings and courtyards that you pass through. Entrance fees are about VND10,000. You would need a minimum 45 minutes to explore the place.

Peaceful - except for the hawkers at the entrance. A beautiful place, and one of the few where there were many hawkers at the entrance. Once you fight your way through them them the peacefulness of the temple takes over. Lovely place to contemplate the passing parade
Tranquil beauty. This place is lovely - a calm oasis and so much history. Great photo oppurtunites also. (across teh road from KOTO!)

authentic and historic. There were many university students there celebrating their graduation. Also a group of high school students doing a field trip. It was crowded! The gardens and gates were arranged for a purpose, and the central building was traditional and nice. Just watch out for the musical performers. The moment we sat down, someone came over and asked for tips and were quite aggressive about it. They were pushing the students away so the tourists can sit down and tip them. The music itself was good.
Interesting Intro to Hanoi. I'll tour started hear, shows how much the Viet has such reverence for scholars and education. Cool bell in the court yard.
Okay. Interesting if one knows the significance as our guide explained almost every detail
Insight into scholarship. A lovely, quiet location that offers insight in the role of scholarship in becoming a mandarin 1000 years ago. The throne used military to defend and learning to govern.

Amazing Viet zeal for learning displayed here. The Temple is VIetnam's first university. Right away one senses the reverence that Vietnamese give to learning early on in their history. It is evident in the physical layout as the place is graced by five courts and a memorial to outstanding scholars. Hedges are trimmed to look like upright books while altars are dedicated to the famed professors of old... To this day students troop to the temple for good old-fashioned lectures and prayers led by esteemed temple scholars. I have no doubt that VIetnamese of today and the future will continue to benefit from the virtue of learning from the Temple of Literature.
Significant Historical Site. A must see location. A historical site of national importance. The stele were more than impressive.
Beautiful. A beautiful temple.It was a treat to see a large group of young female universtiy students arrive to celebrate their graduation-in full traditional dress.

Don't miss this.. Take a guide if you can (but get one of the accredited ones as you come in). The temple is large - a series of temples, and at the far end is a really pretty, serene courtyard. We were there on the day of graduation and it was lovely to see the students posing for their graduation pictures against the backdrop of this ancient monument.

A nice compound. By this point in time, I've been to so many Buddhist temples, that this was nothing new to me. If this is among your first trips to a Buddhist temple, then you'll enjoy it; otherwise, it will be a neat stroll with some pictures but nothing to wow. Go there only if it's a part of a package. I did like the New Year's floral arrangements with old Vietnamese/Mandarin characters and other designs.
Great. I went with a tour group and it was very informative :-) i loved everything from the "Good luck turtles" to the Huge Bell...
A must-see. A wonderfully serene and inspirational experience

Great for a stroll. After the controlled chaos of the Old Quarter, it was very pleasant to stroll through the grounds of the Temple of Literature and visit the temple itself. (Some good restaurants and shops nearby as well!)

artificial flowers. cultural heritage and influence of Chinese philosophers Confusious.
Potential for refurbishment of buildings and replacement of artificial flowers with REAL flowers....or plants...

They have done a great job. Museums in Vietnam get a bad rap, because most of the time they deserve it. Poor signage, awkward feel, and stanch atmosphere make museums a thing to avoid...but the Temple of Lit. has done a great job at maintaining a great atmosphere, but also keeping clear, and most of the time, good signage. Take your time to examine the Turtles when you're there and look at all the fine details involved.

Interesting window in Chinese/Confucian influence in Vietnam. Beautiful setting. Mostly local tourists. An interesting change from the Pagodas and more religious-oriented worship sites. This was focused on learning and Mandarin training going back 1000+ years. Great contrast to Hue, etc.

Well worth a visit. Visited this place with a couple of Guides from Hanoi Kids who explained the significance of the buildings etc. Was surprising to find such a site within the hustle and bustle of Hanoi.
An interesting insight into the history of Hanoi. We went there with the Hanoi Kids tour. To have students explaining the historical importance of this site made it even more interesting.
Great insight to Vietnamese history. Interesting insight into Vietnamese university and education. A well preserved temple with a good display of artifacts.

Worth a visit if you are in Hanoi for more than a couple of days.. Went here with Hanoikids tours and it was prettier and more interesting than I expected. There were graduation pictures being taken and girls in Ao dai everywhere...really charming.Very cheap entry arount $1.5.The grounds are pleasant to walk and it helps to have a guide.
Beautiful ancient university. This is worth a short visit as it is a very old university. There are explanations in English posted everywhere

First University of Hanoi. Great history here and on the day we visited many university students who had finished were making a type of post graduation pilgrimage. Again peaceful and interesting. Having a guide is helpful.
Interesting. The day of our visit we were lucky enough to meet some graduates, complete in caps and gowns. A big tourist attraction so make sure you get the services of an English-speaking guide.

Education has great value here.. It is a huge and well maintained place. The listings of the student classes on the turtle tablets in yhe temple bear witness to the history of the emphasis on education and the 1000 year age of the facility.

A sanctuary in the city. It's a temple and after seeing a few I didn't expect much else.
But this is quite different, but I can't explain why.
A few signs tell the story of the temple as an university but else it is up to you to take in an enjoy the suroundings.

Culture Central in Confucian Vietnam. We had an excellent visit, even with kids in tow and large crowds over an Easter weekend, in part because their were ceremonies taking place with Vietnamese students getting "blessed" in preparation for exams. An excellent insight into one of Asia's great cultures.

Packed, but interesting architecture and history. When we visited the Temple of Literature it was teeming with visitors, mostly locals. Despite the crowds, this is worth a short visit if you're in Hanoi as it's easy to get to and inexpensive to enter. The architecture is pretty cool (although there's not a lot of architecture like it in Hanoi, you can certainly see plenty of good examples in Hue, too), and the temple's history as a university is fairly interesting as well.

Beautiful grounds and loved the art exhibit on show. LOGISTICSThe Temple of Literature is around 2km west of Hoan Kiem Lake and is definitely within walking distance of the city. I would recommend you do it as part of a larger walking tour of the city featuring Old quarter sites (Ngoc Son, Memorial house, Bach Ma, St Josephs cathedral) > History museum > Hao lo prison museum > Temple of literature. REVIEWThe building itself is beautiful and the grounds are well preserved. The fee to get in is small but it is very overtouristed. We enjoyed our brief time here mainly because of the photography exhibit which was on display out the back (visited on the 1/12/2011). If it wasn't for this I would've found it possibly a little bit boring.CONCLUSIONDefinitely worth a visit due to it's proximity to old quarter and it's fine architecture. If the photography exhibit is still on display that's a bonus.

A Pleasant Escape From The Noise. Enjoyed a leisurely stroll through the complex. It's a city centre location, but feels like an escape to the country. A pleasant distraction from all the noise and activity of the surrounding area. Possibly not as big or elaborate as other sites elsewhere, but an interesting place to pass an hour or two. When we were there it was graduation day, which meant there lots of students dressed up taking photos of each other - the boys wore shiny suits and the girls wore colourful silk outfits. Fantastic photo opportunities for all the tourists present.

Historical University. This is where the King tested your educational abilities if you reached that level. Large site, well restored, lots of history, buildings, gardens. Also Koto Restaurant for the training of street kids & poor is across the street & the means are fantastic. I believe Australia helped set up.
Quaint ol' place. Well preserved but understandably touristy... Great opportunity for good photography

Nice enough, but nothing special. So, it's a Confucian School, a pretty small one and one that's not very well preserved, either. The 'temple' bit is very small and not really as vibrant as many other temples (I guess because it's not a real temple but more of a tourist and picture-taking site). The gardens are pretty boring. Taiwan, South Korea and of course China has many nicer schools - nothing special about the much-lauded steles. There are thousands of them in Asia. Anyway, it's a nice change from the usualy bustle of Hanoi and cheap enough. What I enjoyed best about the visit was the 20 minute walk from the Old Quarter to get there (it's easy, grab a map and give it a go).

Amazing.. As someone who values education so highly I absolutely loved this amazing treasure. What an amazing place. The buildings might have been replaced a few times and the shops run by the government (so expensive) but to sit in the place Confuscious once sat, devising exams for the worthy citizens of Hanoi is incredible. Just step out of the chaos around you, into the garden and relax. Drink it in.

Wonderful. The Temple of Literature is an outstanding example of the long history that Hanoi displays. Dating back to the early 1400's the stone tablets carried on the backs of turtles records all who attended what is considered Vietnams first university. If you can get a guide to explain the history of the temple it is an interesting and rewarding experience.

Dry. It was not exactly what you would expect for a temple and a former university. Plus, the lighting was not very good and there is nothing much about it and information provided at the attraction was scant.

THE tourist sight in Hanoi. 1 AUD fee, well, I think everyone has that to spend. So make sure you go there and have a look around the temple often referred to "our oldest university" (it actually was a uni long long time ago!). The temple complex is in walking distance from the city centre (roughly 15min). Many young Vietnames get taken their graduation photos there. Take a photo too. Its fun :-)Hint: As soon as you come into a big kind of yard (with some souvenir stalls around) and you look right onto the temple in the centre, please make sure to walk around that temple too (to the left there is a small path way) as there is another temple with an even bigger yard behind!Its a lovely atmosphere in this complex and also many Vietnamese seem to enjoy the quietness in this bustling city!
Rub the turtles for luck. I love the old world feel of places like this, out of the hustle and bustle of the city streets.

Nothing much if you don't know story behind. This is great place but it s not interesting if you don't know what is the story behind this little temple. Guided tour should be included in this temple/university tours. Make sure it is not too long and not too short.
Very interesting. this spot has the old charm and is beautiful to visit. We enjoyed our visit.
Worth a quick visit. Intersestin aspect of Vietnamese history but really only need 20 mins. Go early before tour groups arrive

Another important place to visit in Hanoi. Although initially not very 'exciting' to view, when you go through to the end of the site and visit the temple area, it is very nice. An important historical site for the Vietnamese, being the site of the oldest learning facility.

an oasis in hectic Hanoi. Take your camera for this beautiful location. it's mainly outdoors with many little courtyards with wonderful photographic opportunities. The grounds and temples are just beautiful.The day we visited there were dozens of young students attending their graduation ceremony. The girls were mainly dressed in beautiful Vietnamese outfits and the boys in western suits. They were very excited and happy and we were included in some of their photographs. Their enthusiasm made us feel happy too.

Oasis of tranquility, well worth a visit. I only stopped into the Temple of Literature because it was "on the way" walking between the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and the Hua Lo Prison. But I am very glad that I did, and I enjoyed it more than either of the other attractions. When you have walked for 20 minutes through noisy bustling Hanoi, and you pay your entrance fee (10,000 Dong, or about US$0.50), you step through into another world of calm tranquility. There is a loveliness to it which is hard to express. When I arrived, for reasons I never really worked out, there were a lot of young pretty Vietnamese girls formally dressed up, running around laughing and holding hands. I remember thinking to myself that if this wasn't what Heaven looked like, we had to at least be getting close...If you walk all the way up the far end, there is a housed area which presumably hosts the museum. Not much is provided in English, so you need to try and work things out a bit for yourself. But there are a collection of very old looking scrolls on display with dates like "1405" written next to them. Even if you don't fully understand, it is pretty enigmatic.But the gardens and ponds and the flowers and pavillions all make for a very welcome break from the hustle and bustle. It really is well worth the time to stop in and see.
Beautiful tranquil gardens. A peaceful and tranquil setting amongst the bustling city.

Tranquil spot that's open on Mondays. This temple, which takes up several square blocks in the middle of Hanoi, is really many temples in one, connected by peaceful gardens and paths. I loved the Steles of the Doctor Laureates--newly declared "world heritage documents" by UNESCO. The Steles are stone tablets engraved with the names of scholars receiving doctorates over a three-century period beginning in 1484, when Europe was still emerging from the Middle Ages. Keep going through the courtyards all the way to the back, where you'll find a two-story temple with a statue of Confucius, a golden tortoise and some Ho Chi Minh memorabilia. One more good thing about the temple: it's open on Mondays when most other Hanoi attractions are closed.

Graduation day shouldn't be missed. A wonderful location to walk through and absorb the history and culture. We were lucky that on the day we were there new graduates and their families, friends and younger students were celebrating graduation. Traditional dress, flowers and smiles everywhere - a very memorable experience.
Greta place. Quite, not much other tuourist. Close to the center by foot.
history wrapped in living culture. the mix of history with young students dressed in their current day finery was enticing .. it was busy but a not to be missed attraction

Nice architecture, good crowd!. This is a worthwhile stop in the Hanoi sightseeing itinerary. Suggest to take a guide as the explanations make it more interesting- there is about 20-25 minutes of walking to do inside the compound- the architecture is an interesting mixture of Chinese and Vietnamese elements. The place is a gathering spot for youngsters so has a nice buzz to it. There are couples who come to do their wedding photo shoot, there was also a bunch of girls dressed up to take pictures here, so it makes for a lively outing here
It is like going back in time - highly recommended!. For only 100 Dong entry fee but it is worth it - a must see.

Peaceful oasis in the middle of the city. This was one of my favorite sites that I visited while in Hanoi. It seemed to go on forever and through every doorway there was something new. The noise from the street disappeared the moment we walked in and it was just peaceful all the way through. I definitely recommend this as a tourist destination.

Very interesting. Thjis is another must visit. Make sure you have a guide to explain what you are looking at and to explain the history of it all.
Visit KOTO restaurant for lunch.

Great place for pics and to learn about Viet Nam's system of education going back 1000yrs. Wonderful place to take pics and get to grips with the early eductaion system of Viet Nam. You will need to find out the process of a Mandarin as well as why they are represented by Turtles. You will also see a different way of offereing money by throwing it on the roof the main building ? I know just stand next to it with a big net but the notes are smallest in Viet Nam and worth about 10p or 15cents. A guide is recommended as there is so much to learn about the buildings and how the functioned as well as all the symbols and carvings. It gets very busy around school holidays so trya nd avoid June and July or just go early in the day. It much cooler anyway and easier to get around
Guided tour a necessity. We did this without a guide and only had a very limited experience as most wasn't in English
aok. liked-all the statues on the outside and the shrinesdisliked-hawkers out front

the best monument in Hanoi. You will see the symbol of Hanoi. The first university in Vietnam.It's very clean. Some anotation are in French. The best it's to go at the opening doors. After it's full. So if you don't like queue or waiting for a nice picture, go there when the doors open.

Highlight of the tourist attractions. A very interesting and beautiful place to visit. It has a lot of history and is well displayed for you to take it in while enjoying the peaceful atmosphere, nice gardens, architecture, statues, etc. There are a lot of people there most of the time but it doesn't take away from the attraction.
Lovely step back in time. One of the better sites in Hanoi - lovely building and history.
Worth an hour visit. We were taken by Hanoi Kids who made the place really interesting. Well worth a look at. But not more than hour

Lovely temple for a little bit of peace and traquility..... The first time we went to visit the temple it was closed due to visiting dignitaries. I am glad we went back another day as it is well worth a visit.Even though there are crowds of people milling around, there is a certain sense of peace and tranquility that comes when entering the Temple. The Temple complex and grounds are lovely and we spent quite awhile just looking around. We didn't go with an organised tour or guide - so not sure what we missed out on information wise - but maybe that added to the tranquillity of this place for us - we could just wander and read information at our leisure.It was also nice to visit a place that did not have street vendors or touts trying to get you to buy something. Instead, there are a couple of nice souvenir shops if you want to browse or purchase something.Tip: If you are looking for somewhere close by for lunch - Koto is just across the road.
Ancient University. Good example of ancient architecture; also an excellent shop!

Colourful Graduation Day. We visited on a Sunday and it was very crowded with locals, especially hundreds of young Vietnamese college/university graduates getting together for graduation celebrations in the grounds of the Temple which is considered Vietnam's original university. The girls were like beautiful butterflies and the boys sedate moths in their dark suits and white shirts and ties. It was a delightful experience, made even more memorable for us when a young Vietnamese girl got up her courage to talk to me - my Lonely Planet book was the ice-breaker. She knew about it the origins of this icon of the traveller's world because her teachers had told her about it - maybe communist Vietnam still wants to learn the lessons of how an individual can make good if they come up with the right idea at the right time!While the visit itself does not take long, it is one of the "must-see" sights of Hanoi and we found it was walkable from our hotel in the old quarter.

Signifant, but not exciting. This site is significant to Vietnam because of it was the country's first college. We went because we have read so much about it, but it was not exciting after seeing many temples. The highlight was the turtle tablets where the names of mandarins were transcribed. Each turtle tablet represented a mandarin class.
Educational. I appreciated the reverence for learning and education. The ponds required some maintenance.

Boring. Perhaps it is because I did not have a guide here but other than to view the attractiveness of the grounds, I did not find this to be an enjoyable attraction. I would skip it if I was to return to Hanoi.

beautiful. This is a really beautiful complex with lots of little areas to explore. We really liked our time here, it was a good way to relax and get out of the hussle of the city as the grounds are very peaceful. The turtle statues are really interesting and there are so many of them! Also make sure to take in the traditional music, there are usually people playing music on traditional instruments in the center pavilion.
Serenity in chaos. This is a great place to visit in Hanoi to get away from the constant noise and chaos in the streets of the old quarter. Beautiful

First University and also first choice to visit. Is you want to know about the traditions of this country, know about the way education effect the life, and also to see a world Documentary Heritage. This is simply the choice.
Interesting insight. Visiting here was an education in itself, most enjoyable.
Worth a visit. I recommend joining an organized tour of Hanoi so you get the most out of your visit.

Well worth a visit. Liked: It seemed to be some sort of graduation day and there were dozens of students all wearing suits and beautiful dresses. The buildings and Stelae were impressive. A good place for a picnic

Beautiful. We visited the temple on the graduation day of many Vietnamese students. The ladies were dressed in the traditional Ao Dai and the men in suits and were taking many, many photos of one another - very interesting to see!
It would have been beneficial if there was further information on the Temple written in English. Worth a visit.
Worth visiting.. 11th century chinese temple and also the university. Interesting!
A must-see in Hanoi. Beautiful Confucian temple. You could spend hours here if you wanted to meditate in the gardens. There are some interesting gift shops by the main temple.

Hello Confucius. Very interesting settings. The sculptures in the temple (at the end) are very interesting). We where lucky enough to run into "Graduation Day" and all the kids were dressed up taking pictures of each others-beautiful.
one of the few peaceful places in Hanoi. Very relaxing, quiet place to visit. Also one of the only places you won't be hassled by street vendors. Very picturesque

Peaceful spot in the middle of the hustle and bustle. Lovely architecture, built in 1071, impressive... A perfect place to steal a couple of hours of peace from the chaos of Hanoi. Gave you an idea of the grace and tradition of that period, worth a visit.
Lovely building. Very interesting but felt more information in English would have been of benefit.
stone tablets. had chinese characters on stone tablets but rather boring in our opinion.

An oasis of calm in a bustling city. Once you get past the hawkers at the gate, you find yourself in a calm and tranquil setting, with beautifully manicured gardens and silk lanterns everywhere. There are five courtyards in all, with the innermost two housing the actual temple and associated buildings. the third courtyard contains a pond with open buildings on each side housing large stone tablets on stone turtles with the names of all the scholars who passed through the university.The temple complex itself is beautifully ornate buildings in the usual vivid red colour that you see so often in Vietnam. While we were there we saw many young girls in the traditional Vietnamese Ao Dai. According to our guide they believe a visit to the temple will help them get good grades in their study.This temple is a lovely place to get away from the noise and crowds of Hanoi for a bit.

A quiet place amidst the din of Hanoi. 1st University, very very old and serene. Place hits you as you enter from the humdrum of congested Hanoi traffic, you walk in to peace and tranquility, we saw students drawing what structures they see, lots of tourists and students milling around quietly; strangely they become noisy once they leave the front gate:), it must be the place!!A must see place, the big stone tortoises (they have stories too, look up in the web), the pool with lovely photo options of reflections, the courtyard which leads into the Confucius temple is pretty striking and colourful too, we spent about 90 minutes as part of the city tour, if we were alone we could easily have sat and read about the place more form the books we had for 2-3 hours. I must see place with great atmosphere, it can grow on you.
Interesting Site. Too busy in the weekend but worth the viist to learn more about the history of Vietnam and dicover why they highly value education.

The temple of literature. Literature is a peaceful place located in the heart of the bustling city. When you get there, you can feel a solemn atmosphere of peace It is the combination of a templearchitecture and ancient university. This is something very special in terms of culture andarchitecture, it is unique and bold and national identity. I also like coming here because the fresh air and a quiet space. It can be said, the work of your country's great.. It is a living structure rather than a ruin. The Vietnamese are very proud of this historical structure from their past.

Quiet backwater in noisy city. Though there were plenty of tourists this was a genuinely peaceful interval in our stay in a hectic city. Subtly different from a Chinese temple. Liked the ponds in the courtyards.

“Beautiful serene plance”. The Temple of Literature built in 1070, was a temple to Confucius. It was also Vietnam’s 1st university. amazing temple and there a ton of cool things to photograph here. It is very cool to walk into a place that is so calm in a city with so much commotion. I really enjoyed my visit here and think it was one of the best things I saw in Hanoi .The temple is one of the main attractions in Hanoi and should be included as part of a visit to the city
Escape the city. The most improessive temple in the city. In a lovely garden. Such a lovely place to escape from the hectic city.
Peaceful and calm in the bustle of Ha Noi. Calm!! THis place has beautiful temples, and small lakes. The culture shop in here has some hand made prints on rice paper- beautiful!
Very interesting. It was a special day and we got to see all the college coeds getting their pictures taken for graduation. They had passed their exams. Temple was very nice.

Must visit to appreciate Vietnam.. This site still influences many aspects of Vietnamese life. The Confucian priciples and influence are worth learning. There is some great architecture and the inner shrine holds some awesome photography opps.

The Temple of Literature.. The Temple of Literature is a peaceful place in the middle of this busy city. It is a combine of temple and university. It was a place where doctors and teachers were trained in the Vietnamese tradition. The architecture is very Chinese, appropriately, as the site honors Confucius. The Temple of Literature, or Van Mieu Quoc Tu Giam, as it is called in Vietnamese, has been preserved quite well from its origins. It is a living structure rather than a ruin. The Vietnamese are very proud of this historical structure from their past.

The most special place.. The Temple of Literature was the most special place that I've ever visited. It showed us a lot about the Vietnamese culture as well as the spirit of study of the Vietnamese people. I was very happy to visit this temple as which I learned about ancient manuscripts etched in stone, saw many students and young artists. Just being there gives you insight into young people lives in this beautiful country.

Amazing history but we wish we had a guide. Incredible history in a beautiful setting. We really wish we had hired a guide as we missed a lot of what we were looking at as there are few signs in English.
reverent. spiritual and peaceful place to contemplate past, present and future
Nice but not breathtaking. Definitely a place with a lot of history. There's not that much to visit in terms of rooms. The Konfucius statue is ok. Don't bother buying the guide for 5000 Dong.
Fantastic. A must see in Hanoi. A chance to see lots of amazing history of Vietnam's culture.

Just a temple in Hanoi. This temple is the biggest temple in HANOI. If you have never been to a temple before and you have free time than you can go here. But if you have more interesting things to do or have been to other temples in other countries than you can skip this one. Anyway the ticket was less than 50 cents so it is still a very good value for money.

It's really an experience worth discovering.. The temple of literature is really a beautiful historical site that many foreign don't understand in a country with such a long history and culture. You can also see the letters writen by the Kings of the past, preserved over the centuries. They have old fossilsed artifacts over some million years old. It's really an experience worth discovering! Make a visit in Hanoi and you'll have a good overview of the depth of the culture.
Very nice Chinese temples. Since China had a strong influence for over thousand years on Vietnam this is a pure example of Chinese influence
wonderful. just go there, and you can SMELL the culture! absolutely recommended!

Oasis in Hanoi. Really peaceful place to wander and get away from the hustle and bustle, second visit for me this time and still enjoy it here....had time to watch some craftsmen restoring the wood panellingnand got some great photos....recommended
big on sites. A huge place filled with interesting artifacts. Some good maps available & necessary to get the most from this cultural centre.
Astonishing. We were surprised that the famous Confusius teaching was there for centuries and well kept. We thought it supposed to be in China...
Cool and tranquil place. An important glimpse into the importance of education in Vietnamese history.

Deep historical significance. The experience of wandering inside those walls puts our 21st century world in perspective. Don't expect books, as there aren't any to be found. The temple houses monuments to scholars and offers information on the cultural significance of the establishment of education.
Over hyped. This attraction is given over to commercial activity and has little interpretation in English. If you are pressed for time give it a miss.

Beautiful serene plance. In the midst of all the bustling activity of Hanoi, the Temple of Literature provides a calming influence. Got dropped off there by a cabbie who tried to rip us off. His meter ran at ten times the regular speed and he asked us VND 350,000 for a 3 km trip. We got away paying just VND 35,000 after threatening to take him to the cops.The Temple itself is in a wide expanse of green. Has a couple of idols and a few shops with some affordable trinklets. Can take some decent pics around the place.
Photo opportunity.. We were happy we had a guide to explain a little about the attraction otherwise this would be little more than a photo op.

Such a cool place to visit. This is an amazing temple and there a ton of cool things to photograph here. It is very cool to walk into a place that is so calm in a city with so much commotion. I really enjoyed my visit here and think it was one of the best things I saw in Hanoi.The stores here have good prices so it is a nice place to stock up.
Temple of Literature. I like very much, it is very nice to see and learn history os this place.
Beautiful grounds. Attractive setting worth half an hour visit. Beware taxi drivers who insist that a 70,000 metre reading is actually 700,000.

Small, Crowded UNESCO Site. Many guidebooks describe the Temple of Literature as a half-day obligation, but it is really only a 1-2 hour activity. Its prime claim to fame is a collection of stone steles (large stone slabs) inscribed with the names of the graduates of Vietnam's first university. The entirety of the temple complex is actually rather small and overrun with Vietnamese school children who visit to pray for good grades and admission into the schools of their choice (in addition to common tourists).On a nice day, it's a good activity to pair with the Ho Chi Min Mausoleum complex (gardens, museum, etc.) because they're only a short walk apart.The temple is one of the main attractions in Hanoi and should be included as part of a visit to the city, but don't expect a large comple with good English-language signage -- read up on the sight's history before visiting or take a tour with a local guide from one of Hanoi's numerous tour companies.

An interesting history but a lack of information. The Temple of Literature seems relatively mediocre in terms of its offerings and information. It was mildly interesting with a few interesting facts here and there but overall it wasn't the most exciting place to go. The green areas surrounding the temples/shops are quite relaxing but there seems to be a limited amount to what you can actually do. Overall, I believe there's probably a great deal of history the place but I wish they had provided it more clearly (and not supposedly through an extra brochure you had to purchase). Just visiting without a guide (we had a guide but they weren't not extremely knowledgeable on everything when questions were asked - but please note this was an external guide) or paying for more information makes it quite substandard.

Well worth the visit. This was recommended by the hotel staff and was well worth the visit. With the cost of taxis only a few dollars, this is accessible from anywhere in Hanoi. The restaurant Koto is over the road, so both can be comfortably covered.

Not a must to see but still worth visiting. This historical site shows a lot of the Chinese influence in Vietnam.I didn't research enough before my trip to know this. So it came asA surprise ( read : weird ) since it didn't look Vietnamese which I pictured in my mind to be more gentle, more refined. Once upon a time, Vietnam or at Least Northern Vietnam was ruled by China.Not quite as nice as the Chan Clan Academy in Guangzhou, China but IGuess it had similar history. The courtyard, the gates, the walls, theGarden's layout are all Chinese. Once upon a time, this was animportant place - it just didn't look it when I visited.Very popular among the tourist - domestic and foreign.As a photographer, my eyes were more keen on the vendors outsideSelling handmade sweets, toys, snacks since they were unusual andDistinctly Vietnamese.There were some hole in a wall snack houses/restaurants nearbyThat served Vietnamese food. Yummmmm!

This is a UNESCO site? No translations for anything! Read up before you go.. I am still trying to figure out why this is a UNESCO site. I knew it was before we went, but... Sure the things there are old, but nothing is translated into any language other than Vietnamese. Going here you will have no idea what you are looking at. The things here are protected fairly well, so maybe that is why it is a world heritage site. There were not many people when we went, but there is really not much to look at... We stayed like 30 minutes, walked through the whole thing and were thinking hmmmm what did we just see...Something that is not good is that kids touch the turtle heads, eventually it will ruin them.If you are tall, beware of low hanging beams! I am about 190cm tall and I nailed myself on one of the beams going under a door. Watch your steps and your head!Overall I am not impressed with this site.By the way, if you are looking for the Koto restaurant, as you exit through the main door turn left, walk to the first street at the end of the temples and then turn left again, look across the street and you will see it within about 30 seconds of when you turn left. It is a little difficult to find because the sign is not easy to see and the colors make it difficult to see. But, it's there. It's probably the only restaurant opposite the temple on that side of the street.

Finally, some sightseeing. The Temple of Literature built in 1070, was a temple to Confucius. It was also Vietnam’s 1st university. It is a nice place to wander around but it was quite busy. Lovely gardens & bonsai trees, some nice buildings & gates & a couple of lotus ponds.One of the few ancient sights to see in Hanoi. We are used to seeing lots of Wats, Temples & Tombs in SE Asia & we were disappointed in Northern Vietnam re the sightseeing.

Interesting insight into Vietnam's past. We visited this Temple early in the morning.Unbeknown to us, it was a day of celebration there so was quickly becoming very crowded and very difficult to move.This Temple has some interesting items and worthy of a visit, if you are a teacher or educationalist.

Finally a quiet spot in Hanoi. Great little place to go and get out of all the traffic of Hanoi. The one thing I recommend is checking out the musicians setup in one of the back temples. Nice chance too see traditional Vietnamese instruments in action.

Nice & quiet attraction. Admission is only 10,000 VND. Nice walk around the area. You enter one way and come out the same way. You could spend an hour here. Liked that there was sufficient English/French/Viet signs to get a good understanding about the place and the ppl. Around the corner is Koto (restuarant).

Worth an extended visit. Located at walking distance from the Old Quarter, the Temple of Literature is worth a visit. Admission fee is 10'000 dong (about half a US$). A thorough visit requires at least one hour, preferably more, as it is mentally difficult to rush through such a place. There, the first Vietnam university was established in 1076 for educating the elite within the framework of a Confucian Temple (named Van Mieu) erected a bit earlier (in 1070). It displays among other things a series of 82 steles (not gravestones) of doctors who graduated there between 1484 and 1779. The steles are sitting on the back of large stone turtles (see picture). The entire place can be visited including a first floor in the worshiping place dedicated to Confucius and his followers. Around the inner courtyard of the temple, you will find, unnoticed by most visitors, a display of bonsais, some with tiny characters or small pagodas (see picture). Souvenirs shops. WC (fee: 1000 dong) on the West side. Essential explanations are posted in English and French. Guides in both languages available against fee.The Temple of Literature offers an area of peaceful and relatively quiet environment in the otherwise hectic and noisy traffic in Hanoi. It is popular with tourists as well as the local population. Don't miss it!
Must see if you are in Hanoi. Big complex and was very crowded, which was expected since its a major tourist site seeing spot. Good spot for taking pics of Buddahs, temples, drums, bells.

Ok place, not that impressive. If you've seen temples in Asia then you will not be impressed by this one. It's a decent place to go if you are looking for something to do in Hanoi, but if you only have limited time, it would not be too high on my list of places to go and see.

The first University of Vietnam. Hanoi Temple of Literature is the first National University of Vietnam.Opening from monday to Sunday.Reading information about history in Temple we know that vietnam has a 1000 years culture and history.
Walking around the Tample of Literature you see very beautiful sight-seeing,good fresh air.
We met a lots of people from all over the world visting temple.

Beautiful building, well worth the visit. Lovely spot to visit, set in a big block of land with beautiful gardens and lots of plaques in english explaining the meaning of various things in the grounds. We accidentally went on the first day of the lunar month, which meant the place was PACKED, although it was interesting to see all the local people making offerings etc at the temple! Cheap entry, and they have a concession rate so take your student card if you have one.
Its great. So much history behind this site. Fantastic. There are so much to see. There were some interesting artifacts too

History about Vietnam. I think people must come to this place. At there , there are many things that's people can find and understand more about Vietnamese. It's a attract location , there are many travelers come here. It's a good choice for traveler when they come and visit Vietnam

The first university in the world. When I been here I know it is a first university in Vietnam and in the world. I can survery more about history of university of Vietnam. It's a location attract many people and traveler to travel and visit. More than that I can get more experience about life , people and history about Vietnam. Note : Traveler should go

Attract location with many interesting things. Going to visit Hanoi, but not on Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam is considered you have not come to Hanoi. For me, each to Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam is a discovery, inquiring about the history and architecture of the vestiges of this

Good if You Haven't Been to a Confucius Temple Before. The "Temple of Literature" is basically a Confucius temple like you find all over China and the Buddhist world, except not quite as attractive as many of the others. So, if you've been to Confucius temples elsewhere, you don't need to go out of your way to see this one. However, if you haven't seen them, then this is a nice stop on your city tour of Hanoi. Take a guide with you to explain about it, or at least buy the brochure, as there isn't much information inside to help you understand what you're seeing.It was partially destroyed in the war, but rebuilt, and parts of the temple date back about 1,000 years. There are statues of Confucius and Vietnamese kings, where local people come to pray and students pray to Confucius before their exams. However, this type of temple is not as important anymore in Vietnamese culture as it is in Chinese culture. It won't take you very long to visit here, about a half hour is probably enough, but if you have a guide to tell you about it, and you haven't "been there, done that" yet, then this is definitely worth your time to stop by for a visit. Perhaps the nicest part is that it's like an oasis in the middle of the city - you step inside the walls and barely hear the honking and motorbike engines from the streets around.
Quite interesting to see. This is an impressive struture and it is interesting to find out about the old religions of Vietnam. It is helpful to get a guide who can explain the history of this temple.

One of the better Hanoi attractions... interesting and educational. Although we weren't blown away by the attractions in Hanoi, the Temple of Literature was a surprisingly above average sight-seeing experience. We walked there from the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, which took about 15 minutes. Be sure to purchase a brochure (3,000 dong), as it contains important information for understanding the site.The temple honors important contributors to Vietnamese education and societal development. It is interesting for its architecture (king's passageways vs. those for commoners), historical stone stelae (names of those earning doctorates carved into stone), and devotional areas to Confucius and scholarly kings. Built upon the grounds of the first national university, the temple is still actively used by the Vietnamese, for both prayer offerings and for celebrations. We witnessed gatherings of school-aged children dressed in beautiful gowns, perhaps marking an important educational accomplishment, such as promotion or graduation.Be sure to count your change after purchasing your tickets -- like another reviewer, we were short changed 10,000 dong. Change is given out in small bills, making it difficult to know instantly whether it is correct or not. Once we realized the error, we returned and the worker was quick to hand over the 10,000, almost like she had it ready just in case. "Mistakes" such as these are unfortunately common in Hanoi -- always be on guard.

Worth a visit. We almost didn't go to see this place but decided to visit it when we were in the vicinity. I'm really glad we did because it's located next to a nice park which is an added attraction. It's larger inside than I expected and is basically a Chinese temple. The place is very colorful and has vendors inside selling everything from books to ice cream. There's an interesting tree just to one's left upon entering the place. I don't know how old it is but it's large and the root system seems to have grown above the ground. This is another great place to visit in Hanoi.

Temple of Literature a MUST SEE in Ha Noi. My husband and I recently visited Northern Vietnam... overall, we were disappointed with the trip, but the Temple of Literature was one of our highlights. Our guide provided us with a lot of interesting information about it history, it was clean, and quiet, and just a lovely afternoon. There were some ladies just outside the temple who were pretty pushy about selling their postcards, but other than that...no complaints! I highly recommend checking it out.

Among the most interesting sites in Hanoi. In my opinion, this is the only large "classical" historic place to see in Hanoi. It's decent sized with well kept grounds and buildings that look historic. In other words, there's enough of an old world look and feel with enough upkeep that you know this temple/university is a very important historical site. It's relatively quite inside, so you can get away from the maddening buzz of the traffic for a short bit. Each gate is a photo opportunity as is the farthest in temple and turtle shaped seats of the scholars. A definite must see in Hanoi.

Beautiful Respite from traffic and air of Hanoi, but watch your change.. The Temple of Literature is a must see in Hanoi.Lovely Gardens, a serene set of buildings. When we were there a huge Vietnamese youth group was visiting and that enhancedmy musings about the virtues of a culture that has a temple to Literature in the first place. Check out the books in the giftshop.It was hilarious to see the bios of Reagan, Bush, Hillary and Bill Clinton translated into Vietnamese.One note of caution......the female ticket taker, definitely tried to shortchange us, and when we caught her, she tried to cover by telling us we had only given her 10000 dong. Bad move as she had already given us about 25000 in dong, so it was illogical.She became very angry at being caught, but did give us the correct change.......

vietnam. This temple was one of the best places to go see in Ha Noi. The stelae immortalized the names of candidates who passed the rigorous exams. When I used to live in Ha Noi, I would come here to get away from the hubbub of the city and breathe in the history.

A MUST if you appreciate history. My partner and I decided to visit the Temple of Literature on a whim. Thank goodness we did that. The Temple of Literature is built in 1070 and presents an excellent history of the buildings and the importance of education from hundreds of years ago. This place used to be used for Confucian education and later became the first University in Vietnam. The grounds itself is so serene and peaceful and the buildings have nice architecture from years past. For those who apprecaite ancient history and classic old buildings, this place is a MUST.

The First Thing You Should See. You must see this while you are in Hanoi. First, it is a look into the past of the city and country--long before the Uncle Ho, long before the French. It gives you a good overview of the importance of Confusianism in Vietnam. As important, it is a haven of quiet in a city of noise. After (or before) you visit the Temple(s), you might want to sit and enjoy the park-like setting of the temple. If you're lucky, you'll get to hear a musical presentation in the last of the Temple grounds. Don't miss it if the opportunity presents itself.
